name: Puhemies. –
text: The next item is the Statements by the Council and the Commission on the outcome of the G20 summit (2016/2769(RSP)).

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to be here on behalf of President Juncker, who will be addressing you tomorrow, to give you my opinion on the outcome of the G20 summit, which took place on 4 and 5 September in Hangzhou, China. The European Union was represented as always by President Juncker and the President of the Council, Donald Tusk, whom I had the pleasure of accompanying, given the highly economic agenda of the summit and the fact that the Commissioner for Economic and Financial Affairs is still accompanying the President of the Commission to the G20 summit. This was an opportunity for China to show, first of all, a very great sense of organization, there was no doubt about it, but also of a global responsibility that it now assumes as a key player in the world economy. For the G20 as a whole, it was an opportunity to demonstrate, after years of crisis, that we can make more aggressive policy decisions to ensure long-term sustainable growth and restore confidence. I think that, in a context of questions, that challenge was important, and it was met. We have presented a series of issues on which the European Union is at the forefront. I am thinking of everything that goes in the direction of a global growth strategy, with the idea of pursuing structural reforms, but also of positioning itself as an example in the field of taxation, the fight against tax evasion and being a promoter of international trade and an advocate for investment.  These themes were the priorities for key world leaders. Our strategy has been to show that our European triangle - investment, structural reforms, responsible public finances - is working, but we must continue on this path to ensure sustainable and positive change in the long term. You could accuse me of complacency for that. No, there is no reason to be complacent, it was said and repeated during most of the interventions during our two days in Hangzhou as a call to act urgently to provide tangible results for our citizens who are waiting for them. Our major economies are very closely linked, and slow global growth faces, as we know, multiple obstacles. The risk of a vicious circle was well identified: low productivity growth, inequality also increasing, all of which provoked a populist response - we do not have the privilege - which in turn slows down reforms and, therefore, further slows growth and so on. The G20 has therefore decided to use all policy tools - monetary tools, fiscal tools or structural tools - to stimulate growth and focus on efforts to implement reforms. Cooperation has also been launched on innovation and the digital economy to increase productivity and long-term growth. In addition, the leaders meeting at the G20 delivered a strong message: after a period of long crisis, we must think about the future; the benefits of growth, globalization and innovation must be appreciated by all, not just by a privileged group of people.  For the first time, and I have been attending these summits for a number of years now, a concept has burst into the public debate, and that is a good thing. This is the concept of inclusion, a fundamental principle that should be observed with a greater emphasis on skills, social protection, but also on the definition of trade and other fiscal policies that must take into account this parameter of inclusive growth. The priorities of this Commission, like those of the G20, are, as you know, already geared towards social justice. Trade was also on the agenda. International trade is an engine for jobs, growth and development. That is why we are concerned about the sluggish growth of world trade and that is also why we continue to vigorously defend free trade against the protectionist temptations that are emerging. But the Commission has also made a great deal of emphasis on the fact that free trade must be fair in order to have the support of our peoples and this Parliament. To be in favour of free trade is not to be in favour of free trade under any conditions, whatever the terms, without reservation or regulation. The G20 plays a key role in supporting a multilateral trading system that is strong and rules-based. We have put a lot of emphasis on this in our discussions at the G20 and the President of the Commission has personally engaged in a fight which, I believe, Know this, this Parliament is committed to this matter: the defence of the interests of the European steel industry and workers affected by a context of global overcapacity and, let us say also, of Chinese overcapacity.  This is an important issue on which an important step has been taken, in Hangzhou, with the G20 agreement, to form a global forum on steel capacity with the support of the OECD and of course the approval of the Chinese Presidency. Fair international taxation is another essential condition for restoring our citizens' confidence in the global economy and also for enabling the government to provide the investments and services that are so necessary for our economies. All companies, I keep saying here, in my capacity as Commissioner for Taxation, have to pay their fair share of taxes in the countries where they make their profits. You know that the European Union is at the forefront of these efforts and that it has already adopted several very ambitious proposals last year. We were encouraged to see all the G20 countries once again firmly and strongly committed not only to implementing past agreements, but also to go further in the wake of the Panama Papers affair, which continues, it is true, to weigh on people's minds. The G20 has therefore agreed to put in place a list of non-cooperative jurisdictions for the next summit in 2017 and to consider defensive measures in the event of non-compliance. This international list of the G20 is complementary to the list that the European Union itself is about to launch and which must also be operational in 2017, with the problems which are complementary and which I believe fit well. In the fight against terrorist financing, the G20 will continue to lead the WORK of the FATF. Leaders called for a swift and resolute implementation of its new strategy against terrorist financing and for strengthening coordination with those who do not participate in the task force, particularly vulnerable countries. The Hangzhou meeting also provided an event to discuss financial regulation reform, which, I recall, was a flagship initiative of the G20. The focus is now on the coherent implementation of agreed reforms, such as the Basel III framework and its completion by the end of 2016. The Chinese presidency has also strengthened discussions on the international financial architecture. We know that there is an ongoing risk to the global economy. The unanimous agreement to maintain a strong IMF with sufficient resources is a significant result. Last year in Antalya, we called on the G20 to recognize the refugee crisis for what it is: a global challenge that requires a global response. With the help of this Parliament, the European Union has put in place a comprehensive set of measures to manage this crisis, but we can only meet this challenge if the international community as a whole makes coordinated efforts. We have kept a clear message to our G20 partners that we want the level of solidarity between nations necessary to solve this problem, which is still missing, to now emerge. The answer elicits resolute but also cautious optimism. G20 members said they were ready to share the burden of the refugee crisis, specifically calling for increased financial assistance and resettlement of refugees. G20 cooperation to support development and food security, especially in Africa, is also important in terms of controlling migration flows. The summit was also an opportunity for the G20 to reaffirm its commitment to the Paris Agreement. The pace of ratifications is good and it is now very likely that the threshold for the agreement to enter into force - I am talking about COP 21 - will be reached this year. The main message from the European Union to the G20 members in this regard is that they must now act just as quickly to implement this agreement. Of course, as you can imagine, many leaders at the summit wanted to hear the response of the Europeans to the UK referendum. President Juncker wanted to reassure them that we were ready to face it once the British government has communicated its intentions. You know that the Commission has appointed its negotiator, my compatriot, predecessor to the post of French Commissioner, Michel Barnier. We want to build a new partnership with Britain that works for everyone. A formula always comes to mind, and it is also shared with the British government: Britain, it is its choice, will no longer be, after this negotiation, a member country of the Union European Union, but it will remain a very decisive European nation for a whole range of policies that we have to pursue together. At the same time, the President stressed that there were many things that the European Union of 27 could achieve together. This is our objective for the future and it is in this spirit that the President will address the House here tomorrow for his State of the Union address, speaking both of the Europe of 28, which is ours, of the Europe of 27, which is our future, and of the Europe of the 19, that of the euro zone, which is the beating heart of Europe. But I do not want to anticipate what he will tell you, I think it will be an important moment for the Commission, for Parliament, for the European Union, before the meeting of the leaders of the 27, to be held in Bratislava on 16 September. Those are the few things I wanted to present to you. I would not like to be any longer, I can go back to that G20 meeting later, which I believe was, again, organised in an impressive way by China, very well led by the Chinese President, with many results, which are entirely in line with what the European Union could expect.

name: Françoise Grossetête
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Commissioner, it is regrettable that the Council is absent to talk about this latest G20 summit, which was rich in policy statements but which has not convinced on the facts. It is to be welcomed, as the Commissioner has explained to us, that Europe has managed to impose its economic agenda. The roadmap adopted at the summit intersects many of the priorities that are proposed by our Group of the European People's Party and which have guided our work for months, i.e. justice, fiscal fairness, to combat inequality, the promotion of trade in the context of regulated globalisation and a growth strategy based on investment recovery and structural reforms. It could also be said that there is a small victory on the issue of steel overproduction at the global level, since it has finally been put on the table and it is not insignificant that this subject has been discussed in China, countries whose subsidies fuel unbearable dumping, which overwhelms the European steel industry. Despite these advances, I regret that many other crucial topics have been addressed only half-word, if at all. Among them, the refugee crisis. You have talked about it, Mr Moscovici, but if we have to be optimistic, I think it is still very limited. Climate change: of course, there was an announcement on the ratification of the Paris Agreement by the United States and China. Nevertheless, we are waiting for the facts. There is also the war in Syria. I will also mention another topic, mentioned in a few lines in the final communiqué. This is the fight against antibiotic resistance: no concrete commitment has been made, even though this is one of the greatest public health scourges of our century. Faced with issues that call for a major response, little is finally retained from this summit. Even the stated will to fight populism, if it is positive, fails to reassure us entirely. Promises only engage those who believe them, they say. Let us hope, however, that these promises made to this G20 also engage those who made them, otherwise this summit will have served only one thing: to demonstrate once again the power of China, which is for better and for worse, as a key international player.

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I am grateful for the invitation to discuss the outcome of the G20 Summit which took place last week in China and where the European Union was represented by President Tusk and President Juncker.  G20 leaders discussed various topics of global importance and, crucially, issues on which the G20 should provide leadership. I will focus on issues which I find are of particular relevance from the point of view of the Council, including migration, the global economy, trade, taxation and climate.  Let me start with an issue which is very high on our agenda, namely the management of migration. I consider the G20’s recognition of the current crisis as an issue of global concern to be a very positive signal. The EU has stated in international forums on various occasions that migration requires efficient and coordinated action and it calls for all stakeholders to take responsibility in a spirit of partnership and burden sharing. The EU and its Member States are fully assuming their responsibilities, but expect other partners, namely our G20 partners, also to do their part.  The communiqué by G20 leaders is a step in the right direction, as it calls for scaled-up support to refugees and host communities. The EU will certainly use the opportunity of the forthcoming New York summit on refugees and migration, which you will discuss with High Representative Mogherini later today, to take the G20 conclusions forward and pursue  more equitable sharing of responsibility for what is clearly a global challenge. My second point is the global economy. G20 leaders in China pointed to the progressing global economic recovery, while recognising that growth was still weaker than desirable and that downside risks remained. Challenges originating from geopolitical developments were also mentioned. Accordingly, leaders declared their determination to use all policy tools –monetary, fiscal and structural – individually and collectively to achieve the intended growth. Importantly, there was the recognition that growth needs to be inclusive in order to ensure that it serves the needs of everyone and benefits all countries and people so that no one is left behind. This is recognised in the Hangzhou Action Plan, which summarises the main commitments by G20 members. The G20 summit also made a strong case for international trade as a driver of global economic recovery. To this end, G20 leaders committed to strengthening an open world economy by working towards trade and investment facilitation and liberalisation. The establishment of the G20 Trade and Investment Working Group is an important step in this regard. The G20 reaffirmed its commitment to the multilateral trading system, with the WTO at its core, and to advancing the post—Nairobi work in the WTO, including the outstanding issues of the Doha Development Round, with a view to achieving positive outcomes at the next WTO Ministerial Conference in 2017.  I also welcome the G20 commitment to ratifying the Trade Facilitation Agreement by the end of this year and its call for other WTO members to do the same. The EU, for its part, has already ratified. However, we need to recognise that anti-globalisation sentiment and opposition to trade are increasing. The G20 therefore emphasised the need to communicate the benefits of trade and open markets more effectively and to ensure that the benefits of trade are spread more widely. It also recognised the structural problems caused by excess capacity in some industries, most notably in the steel sector, and agreed that this required a collective response. G20 leaders therefore agreed to establish a global forum on steel access capacity, which should report to the relevant G20 Ministers in 2017.  Let me mention two more issues. Taxation is another priority that the EU shares with the G20. I particularly welcome the establishment of the G20/OECD Inclusive Framework for the implementation of the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting initiative (BEPS) as well as its first meeting in Kyoto. The EU has pioneered BEPS implementation with the recent adoption of the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive (ATAD), but timely, consistent and widespread implementation of the BEPS package at global level remains critical in order to establish an international level playing field and avoid further loopholes.  I am also satisfied with the endorsement of the proposal for objective criteria to identify non-cooperative jurisdictions with respect to tax transparency and with the objective to prepare, by July 2017, a list of jurisdictions that have not yet sufficiently progressed towards a satisfactory level of implementation, as well as to consider defensive measures against them.  Following the adoption of conclusions on taxation last May, the Council has already started to determine, on the basis of a first screening by the Commission, non-cooperative third country jurisdictions with which dialogues should begin during the course of next year. The objective is to establish an EU list of such jurisdictions and explore defensive measures at EU level, in the tax as well as in the non-tax area, to be endorsed by the Council by the end of this year.  Finally, the G20 Summit reaffirmed the commitment of its members to sustainable development and strong and effective action to tackle climate change. The G20 leaders are committed to countries’ ratifying and implementing in a timely fashion all aspects of the Paris climate agreement, including financial assistance for developing countries. In particular, the G20 supported efforts to enable the Paris Agreement to enter into force by the end of 2016.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, re-globalisation, rule-sharing and inclusion are the key words of the G20, but these must now be implemented so that we do not remain empty words.  Reglobalisation, because we have a duty, as the European Union, first of all, to create a new globalisation that assesses the impact of global phenomena, trade agreements, the digital revolution, migratory flows and introduces appropriate corrective measures so as not to leave anyone on the sidelines. Sharing, because we need rules and trust between partners. The establishment of a forum to control excess capacity, starting with steel, is a first positive sign. Finally, inclusion, so that everyone is part of it and do their part. Significantly for the first time this summit recognises the importance of including women as growth drivers. In the face of the failures of old globalisation, offering a protectionist response is as easy as it is harmful. It is up to us to put forward a new proposal that keeps the world connected without leaving anyone behind.

name: Sander Loones
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – In the G20 leaders' communiqué, we read that the world economy is recovering. Although you can read between the lines that people have some doubts about that. At the same time, people are asking for more public investment, and when I read the weekend newspapers, it says: "Finally, the policy of savings has failed. It's time to try something different." That was also the line of the six southern European countries that had coffee with Mr. Tsipras in Athens on Friday. With all due respect, the truth has its rights. Global debt has not fallen since 2008. On the contrary, debts have increased in businesses, banks, households and, certainly, governments. The total debt in the world is currently EUR 200 trillion. That's more than three times the overall global economy. Please don't let us tell the blisters. More investment okay, but then we will also have to save first to make those investments possible.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, thank you for the debriefing that we received. I do not want to reiterate what has been said, and I think there are a number of important points. The reconfirmed commitment to growth, innovation, facilitation of investment and liberalisation of free trade is, of course, highly relevant. I also appreciate that China committed itself to free trade and to fight protectionism, and of course the decision to set up a global monitoring entity for the over-production of steel is highly relevant, especially nowadays for Europe. In this respect it would be interesting to know from the Commissioner what will precede the work at multilateral level, how we are going to perceive it and whether the Commission has already considered the technicalities. I would like a bit more information on two points. On refugees, to which the Minister devoted some time, I think that the recognition of the problem might not be entirely sufficient. Secondly, we know that Putin met Obama on the sidelines of the summit and that a deal has been brokered on a ceasefire but I wonder why we do not have anything in the conclusions from the G20 summit. I think that, both on the refugee crisis and on this, this does not send the best signal. However, my main point is the following: while there is a recommitment to free trade, I wonder how credible the EU is in reconfirming this with its international partners if, at the same time, while on the one hand we are talking multilateral liberalisation, bilateral agreements and so on, we have, on the other, voices in Germany, France and elsewhere in Europe saying that the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership – an important free trade agreement – is basically dead. We know what the Commission had to say but I wonder how the Council, and how the Presidency, will react on the issue, because this is definitely a hit to the credibility of the European Union.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr Moscovici, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, in China we saw interesting declarations at the end of the G20 meeting. But citizens are asking for tangible works, not words. Measurable result and not just a meaningless rhetoric. For example, on the issue of tax evasion: the Commission's decision on the taxation of Apple on widespread tax evasion in Ireland was correct. We need projects. You rightly pointed out, Mr Moscovici, that global cooperation on refugees is needed. But can Europe set an example on this issue when European cooperation itself is not being implemented, and do we have Member States that refuse to accept and implement decisions on proportional distribution of refugees? When fewer than 400 experts have been sent to my country, Greece, which is taking on a huge burden to help with the process of taking in refugees?  Moreover, in terms of investment and tax evasion: tax evasion in the European Union alone is 7 times higher than the European budget for 2016, amounting to EUR 1 trillion a year. We therefore need effective projects and not just words, and I expect the Representative of the Council to explain to us in his secondology, together with what he will tell us, why he was late for such an important meeting.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, representative of the Council, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I am very grateful to the representative of the Council for coming too late, because this has given us the opportunity to take note at the outset in full beauty, as Commissioner Moscovici excels at the bingo. Mr Moscovici has said that it has been successfully agreed that sustainable growth will be guaranteed in the long term. He said that Europe is at the forefront of growth. He said that the Commission was quite right and successful in prioritising the social. Mr Moscovici, you are absolutely right to say that you cannot think that you are complacent. You are not complacent, you report from a parallel universe! You said that the results of the Hangzhou Summit would fully meet the EU's expectations. That is the most pathetic thing to say, because business as usual is good enough for the EU. Apart from some small advances, such as the Steel Forum for Overcapacity, which has already been pointed out, or the fact that cooperation on the subject of green finance has not been buried, this meeting in Hangzhou has brought little substance. What has brought us, however, is the recognition that Europe is only playing second violin in such a global event. In the run-up to this summit, much has been said that if China does not recognise the UNCLOS Arbitration Panel's decision, China would be treated as an international pariah. There has been a lot of talk about Russia being cornered because of the role it unfortunately plays in Ukraine and Crimea, for example. The fact is that this was not mentioned at all at the summit. China and Russia were at the centre of the action, while the EU was on the second bench. And I think we need to start to stop complacent that business as usual would be good enough for us if we want to change that. The EU has failed to ratify the climate agreement. The Americans and the Chinese have made a big act out of it in Hangzhou. This shows how much we are lagging behind, and you, Commissioner, are expressing precisely the spirit that is ensuring that things do not get better.

name: David Borrelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the last G20 in China did not produce the results that we would all be entitled to expect from such a summit meeting, nor those decisions that the seriousness of the world situation would require. However, positions useful for moving towards true and more shared progress have emerged and in some cases have established themselves.  I would like to highlight the few positive factors, rather than the problematic ones, which are there, especially in terms of omissions. I believe that a reality such as the European Union must demonstrate its ability to design and implement itself in order to be credible in the world and therefore to influence it. Firstly, there is support for the fight against climate change. Now, after the ratification of the Paris Agreement by the world's major polluters – I am thinking of the United States and China – the European Union must ensure that not only do all Member States do this quickly, but also influence so that the third countries involved do the same.  From this point of view, we must also consider the green finance initiative and the proposal to channel a significant proportion of the funds currently directed at fossil fuels towards clean energy solutions. In this respect, we expect the Commission to give concrete form to the circular economy project. The declaration to build an open and resilient financial system based on international cooperation in the field of taxation and financial transparency is also something that must not be dropped, but it must be put into concrete form very quickly. I hope that this Parliament will address these issues and that the Commission will do so immediately with the 2017 work plan.

name: Janice Atkinson
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Madam President, at the recent G20 meeting my Prime Minister, Theresa May, expressed the UK’s determination to once again be a global leader in free trade. Now that the UK will soon unshackle itself from the EU, it will be able to reach out to its Commonwealth partners, which it could not do before, because of EU restrictions. Africa kept in poverty by aid from this place will instead be able to trade freely again with the UK. India and Australia, representing major markets, have already shown their interest in a free trade deal. China, another huge market, is equally ready to look into a free trade deal with my country. If even a tiny country such as Switzerland has a trade deal with China, then surely the UK can have one as well. And it will. All the while the EU has no trade deal with major markets around the world. You exclude Russia because of your stupid sanctions. I hope my country reopens trade negotiations with Russia and we will continue to have a good relationship with it.  The EU dictates the trade policies of European countries and, unsurprisingly, with meagre results, unless you believe that the few deals that it has managed to negotiate with countries such as Morocco, Papua New Guinea and Algeria are game changers. Of course you do have your secret TTIP negotiations – and how is that going, by the way? Your friend Obama tries to push through TTIP, and that mostly serves the interests of multinationals. It does not serve the people. TTIP will end up in the bin, as the French and German Ministers have already publicly announced that it is dead in the water.  I am not gloating over these failures, but I do want to point out that the EU has a bad track record and has failed the peoples of the EU. Member States have their hands tied behind their backs because an unelected Commission is deciding for you. I bet the UK will have a trade deal with all major economies across the globe before the EU and yes, even with the USA. Obama will soon leave office and a new US government will be more than happy to sign a trade deal with the UK, just like the rest of the world.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Madam President, what can we learn from the G20 summit in China? Yet there was much to be said in the country of steel surpluses, low-cost textiles that flood world markets, with the consequences here in terms of job cuts. The Chinese president has protested against any idea of protectionism or trade barriers. He's defending his interests, but we're not defending ours.  On the ecological front, much has been made of the signing of the Paris Agreement by the United States and China, but at the same time it was learned that Turkey was planning the construction of 80 coal-fired power plants and China is not abandoning its plan to build thermal power plants until 2030.  The situation in Syria has made little progress, despite the very fragile and very partial ceasefire that has taken place.  At the G20, we will have communicated a lot, occupied the ground. We talked morally, hand on heart, we wanted to advance growth and above all to fight against populism, as Mrs Grossetête has, at the moment, welcomed. The problem is that fighting populism is increasingly fighting people.

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is interesting to read the Final G20 document and to hear the council and commission's comments and to reconcile them with reality. I would like to point out this with just four examples: the gin has been talking about tax equality and tax fairness in the G20 for years. We are not making any progress at all in the European Union, and if we did not have at least one Competition Commissioner who is now trying to pull the emergency brake, because the Member States are still not stopping this unfair tax competition, then we would not be a single step forward in Europe either. That is why, in my view, what Commissioner Vestager is doing is at least a small good sign on the horizon.  The second is innovation: we are talking about strengthening innovation. But if you look at what we are doing in Europe in practice: we are talking about strengthening innovation to finance the Juncker Plan, then we are taking money out of broadband expansion in Europe and thus depending on the areas for which it is particularly important to receive European funding so as not to be left behind by the future – namely our rural regions – and development.  The third, structural reforms: many, many explanations, too. It is a pity that a number of structural reforms that were made ten or fifteen years ago have been withdrawn in my country, but when I look at other states – France and Italy – at least my impression from the outside is that there are no structural reforms going on there at all, but that there is a de facto stalemate.  And on trade, we are talking about trade facilitation agreements, we are talking about improving trade, and then, in principle, at the same time as the G20 talks in China, we see how our Member States can really damage the good trade agreement between the European Union and Canada by having it declared a mixed agreement by the European Commission and not making any progress at all. to continue to negotiate this agreement, but quite the contrary; it is being deceived by the Commission.  I would like not only to make statements, but to try to put these declarations into practice; in this respect, in my view, the Council is failing completely and, unfortunately, the Commission is failing in many areas.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the G20 summit in Hangzhou was a successful one, and I would like to say a few words to congratulate China for the way it was organised and presided over. The S&D Group certainly welcomes the decisions in key sectors such as fair taxation, the refugee crisis and terrorism, and also the commitments to solve the problem of over- production, especially in the steel sector. But, as we know, it is one thing taking a decision and a totally different one putting it into practice. We are very happy about the stance taken by the Commission against Apple in Ireland because, for the S&D Group, fair taxation is a key element in a wealthy and competitive economy. It is evident, however, that, alongside the measures to be taken at EU level, we need to act globally in order to make sure that the rules are binding for all. This is where Europe should assume its own responsibility as an important actor in the international community. One key message, deriving from the G20 summit and more generally from the global economic situation, is that we need more growth, and that we cannot expect only developing countries to be the ones leading the process. The EU needs to do more in order to re-launch growth in the economy and to create more jobs, with more flexibility and more investment. The G20 was also an occasion for the US and China to ratify jointly – and I would underline the symbolic importance of that ‘jointly’ – the Paris Agreement on climate change. This is an area in which Europe had always taken the lead but, at least this time, the United States and China got there first. They are the two biggest world polluters, so maybe this is equally a sign of world change. Europe should draw its own lessons because no EU Member State has ratified the Paris Agreement, and this is once again the difference between nice speeches and the action which is so necessary for European citizens and for the survival of the European project.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the main conclusion from the G20 summit is that world leaders have avoided addressing the need for a fair distribution of the wealth generated and for combating poverty and unemployment affecting the planet. The fight against global poverty is becoming imperative, not only for reasons of moral order, but also because hitting poverty will greatly boost active demand. In addition, tax dumping, tax evasion and tax avoidance of multinationals, as well as global debt, which has skyrocketed, must be tackled. The G20 referred the measures to the calends on the refugee crisis and on tackling the problems of the European steel industry. For refugees, all the G20 did was simply express wishful meals, but without making specific commitments and shouldering the corresponding burden. Finally, instead of taking measures to protect the European steel industry and its workers, they simply decided to create a tax, and the issue of measures against China, which is causing the problem in the global steel industry, was simply referred to the future.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The G20 summit had a very ambitious headline: Towards an innovative, vital, interconnected and inclusive world economy. I was pleased that global leaders understood that today's major challenges require such an ambition. Unfortunately, the good stopped at the headline. The final declaration does not contain a single binding commitment and is rather proof that the 20 most powerful economies do not know how to agree on how to solve today's challenges. For how else to interpret the following sentence: "We support efforts to promote voluntary knowledge diffusion and technology transfer on mutually agreed terms and conditions." Seriously, i'm sorry. Not a single word at all about who, when, how, with whom. We live in a time of enormous populism. We desperately need growth to move away from the xenophobic stain in which we are stuck. We need to deal with the refugee crisis, Syria, Russia, the climate, epidemics, racism – and the only thing that the 20 most powerful economies agree on is voluntary knowledge diffusion. Seriously! Colleagues, the G20 summit demonstrates the lack of common denominator and shows that EU and G20 leaders are not adults. Then it is no wonder that voters vote for populists who promise gold and green forests. We need concrete measures, measurable results, reasonable and thoughtful responses to today's challenges and determination to respond to them. That's the only way you can win the trust of the voters.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, this G20 meeting – one more - represents a true hymn to hypocrisy. Perplexed by the disastrous results of their policies, the G20 countries, representing more than 80 % of the world's wealth, are proposing another attempt to resolve the squaring of the circle. In this way, we seek to reconcile economic growth, the deregulation of international trade and climate issues, all properly wrapped up in social justice. Of course these pious statements may elude many people for a while, but they will not be able to deceive everyone forever and ever. Financial instability, corruption, social inequalities and the global warming itself represent many other faces of neoliberal policies at the service of the great international capital.  It will not be two or three or even twenty rich countries solving the problems of humanity, it will be the peoples struggling to build a progressive and anti-capitalist alternative, capable of responding to the serious problems of the planet for the benefit of workers and peoples and not in favor of a small handful of multimillionaires.

name: Patrick O'Flynn (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, it is good that countries meet to talk things through. It is even good that the EU – for so long as it exists – tags along for the ride. But let us be clear: summits in China are not going to solve the key problems facing Europe, namely economic stagnation and the social disruption caused by uncontrolled, irregular and large—scale immigration from Africa and Asia. So long as the euro remains, growth across its members will be weak. We have had 15 years to find this out and every year provides us with more evidence. On migration, Mrs Merkel seems to expect all the Schengen countries to clear up her mess, and Mr Juncker thinks national borders should be abolished altogether. The EU’s representatives will keep going to G20 summits but every year they will be pushed a little further out to the fringes in the family photograph. The awkward truth is that, with every passing year, the failing EU and its members count for less in the world. Mr Moscovici is right to say that the UK will remain a decisive European country in the years ahead. I very much hope that it can be a beacon for Europe, encouraging other European countries to take back control of their politics at a national level and make good use of the extra social solidarity that the nation-state provides. Only by harnessing this can European voices command the influence in the world that our great continent deserves.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed representative of the Council, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work he has The 11th meeting of heads of government of the Group of 20 major industrialised and emerging economies took place in Hangzhou, China, on 4 and 5 September. The discussions focused on building an innovative, strengthened, connected and inclusive global economy. An action plan to boost the weak global economy was called for. This action plan will be urgently needed when we see that investment in Europe has still not reached pre-crisis levels, that we have an investment gap of EUR 400 billion in Europe alone, and that Eurostat has now had to scale back European growth for the first half of 2016. The so-called Hangzhou Consensus is now intended to achieve more inclusive growth based on better macroeconomic coordination, open trade and innovation. One focus is on digitalization. Yes, these are the right priorities. However, it seems to me to be more concrete that the global steel forum has been decided upon and which is due to present very specific measures as early as next year. The conference has also committed itself to the implementation of the climate protection targets. China and the United States have certainly set the highlight here by committing to agree on the Paris climate change targets. That's the highlight, the show was stolen from the Europeans. But that is also important. The assessment of Green Finance, the fight against tax evasion and, in particular, against non-transparent tax havens is also positive. A list is due to be made at the G20 summit next year. I hope that this list will be created; so far it has not been possible. Let's see what the future holds.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, the summit of the leaders of the 20 developed countries took place in the wake of three important events: 'Brexit', the Russia-US approach and the failed coup d'état in Turkey. Russia, the US, Australia and China have expressed their intention for economic and trade cooperation with Britain. As the European Union, we must be careful, and I am mainly addressing the negotiating team: if the Union is to take a vengeful stance in the negotiations – and I am thinking mainly of Germany – then it will send a negative signal to the other countries of the Union and, above all, to the rest of the world. The US and Russia are working together to fight terrorism, while Putin and British Prime Minister May have agreed to develop bilateral trade and strategic relations. It is therefore time to abolish the sanctions regime in Russia, which only creates problems in the economically weakened countries of the Union. Finally, as far as Turkey is concerned, it must now be subject to severe sanctions, especially in the face of Erdogan's threats to release flows of illegal immigrants and refugees. The President of the European Council, Mr Tusk, said that Europe has no other opportunities to welcome new waves of migrants. It is blackmail, then, for Erdogan to ask more and more of the Union, but it is mostly foolish for European leaders to endure such humiliation by showing submissiveness.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the G20 meeting was held at a time that is more uncertain and more risk-laden than we have seen for decades. It could have been an important meeting in this perspective, but very little came out of it. And what came out of it did so because all the crucial problems that the global world order is facing were avoided. Nothing was really said about Syria, with its global impact not only on refugees but also on stability and security. Nothing was said about Ukraine, with the breaking of international law and international agreement that is undermining the rules underpinning world stability. Nothing was said about the need to fulfil Western sanctions against Russia, which is breaking international rules. The conflicts on the islands in the South China Sea were also avoided, as were, in reality, the issues about obligations for the countries to fulfil to combat climate change. Nothing was said, either, about the need to enhance legal certainty for investments in the global order. We are today facing the undermining of respect for international rules. We see this very much in Russia and in China, who say they will not follow international court decisions. The next time there is a G20 meeting it will be important for the European Union to take the lead in restoring legal certainty and respect for international rules, because otherwise these meetings have no real meaning. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. – Madam President, honourable Member, do you not think that this meeting should have paid more attention to the role of the dictatorial regime in Turkey in the migrant crisis? And don't you think more time should have been paid and asked about sanctions on Turkey, which, just as Russia annexed part of Ukraine, annexed territories from a sovereign state for the second time? I remind you: the annexation of Cyprus and the current invasion of Turkey's armed forces in Syria.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I think it could have been a good idea also to mention what has happened in Turkey in two ways: first of all, to strongly react against any sort of attempt to have a coup d'état, because what could have followed that would have been a civil war with a real disaster, even more than the disaster we are facing. Secondly, I think the importance of Turkey coming back to full respect for civil society and independence could have been stressed. I think both things should have been said, but the G20 avoided things that were crucial and I do not think that, in the time we are living in, we can avoid the complicated issues. We need to deal with them, hopefully together, but at least together with democratic nations.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank President Tusk for entitle G20 participants to the need for active solidarity. After all, the causes of migratory pressure on Europe are global and, therefore, solutions must also be global. However, we have a difficult job to do, because there are member states within the European Union alone that do not really want to play their part in tresmaning or solving this problem. The other thanks go to President Juncker, who has warned the participants, specifically the Chinese hosts, in a very precise way about the perverseness of Chinese steel exports to EU Member States. I think that you have done a very good service in protecting jobs in Europe. Finally, I would also like to suggest that, although China's accession to the Paris climate agreements has been or is around the time of the deliberations, at the forthcoming G20, I believe that greater, even greater and continuous attention must be given to the need to ensure that European wills to be represented, that fossil fuels should be left underground, wherever possible.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for This summit has been too short in several respects. A number of things have already been mentioned: it is too short in the area of free trade, if there is no talk of free trade being not defended by many European politicians, but is constantly being called into question. It falls short when calling for more government spending, without pointing out that we have major problems in combating the over-indebtedness of the states that are supposed to finance this expenditure. But it also falls short when talking about terror and the fight against terror, without talking about the spiritual foundations of terror and the urgent need to combat the spread of radical violent Islamist ideas – in all countries of the world, and especially in Muslim countries around the world, which are partially vulnerable to the attack. , which have nothing to counter the attack of these Salafist and Wahhabi and fundamentalist and anti-Islamic, And is affiliated with the Taliban or ISIS , have nothing to counter on social media, have nothing to do with social work, which is sometimes exemplary carried out by these radical organizations. It must be made clear here that the West also has an answer for believers who have a conservative view of the world, but who do not want to be ready for violence and who want to close themselves off from these attacks on their religion.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, the conclusions of the G20 summit echo the belief in the doctrines of neoliberal globalisation and the promise - wishful meals - that this globalisation will work for the benefit of all peoples, all countries. There is a desperate attempt to hide responsibility for the refugee crisis, for instability in the Middle East, for economic problems, for poverty, for poverty in rich and poor countries, for the environmental crisis. Mr Moscovici, the major problems of the global economic crisis are mainly European problems. The reason for this is your policies: the policies of austerity, budgetary discipline, cuts in public investment and public spending, the reproduction of unemployment and the brain drain from poor countries to the richest. This is the policy that Greece also receives from the Memorandums, most not least the memorial policies that lead to these results. So the wishes of the G20 and the European Union, Mr Moscovici, on the humanisation of capitalism no longer convince anyone.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Ladies and gentlemen, we have heard a great report here, which has coloured everything beautifully. There is talk of fair free trade, fair growth for all; no one should fall by the wayside in the future. Ladies and gentlemen, if no one falls by the wayside, we will have solved everything. Then we no longer have a migration problem, and then we will have fair trade, fair growth for all.  They are calling for more solidarity in the refugee crisis. Where is this solidarity? On the one hand, Frontex is being transformed into a migrant ferry service instead of a border agency, and on the other hand, Australia is doing exactly the opposite: they are saving the migrants and bringing them back to the appropriate starting point. Have you spoken to the United States, which is responsible for all these migratory flows? How many millions of refugees are the United States of America taking in?

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to first of all welcome the conclusions of the last G20 summit, because the emphasis has been placed on several elements which are of strategic importance to the Union. I would like to stress first of all the issue of development and the need to effectively implement the objectives of the 2030 Agenda. As Parliament's rapporteur on policy coherence for development, I was delighted to see that the issue of political coherence for sustainable development was mentioned in the conclusions. I believe that the Union has a key role to play in promoting this concept of the CPD, of policy coherence in the service of development, and this forum has been a great opportunity. Another point is the issue of refugees. We have been hit harder than others by the refugee crisis, and when it comes to this issue, we must work with other partners to determine the root causes of the crisis, and the root causes are also political causes. We must not forget that refugees come from regimes that are not democratic and are far from the rule of law, and cooperation must therefore be committed to this. In this context, it is a little sad to see that Russia is back on the international stage. It is accepted as a normal partner, even if, as we know, Crimea is still occupied. Russia continues to openly violate international law, and we see the effects. Separatists are encouraged. In Transdrestria, three days ago, the leader of the so-called Republic of Transnistria has just asked for Transdistria's accession to Russia on the basis of a referendum held ten years ago. Our actions always have consequences and it is important to remember that Russia is a very bad partner in terms of international law and, indeed, the rule of law.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: I think you can say that the outcome of the G-20 was encouraging on the one hand, but also very disappointing on the other. Because yes, it was very much about growth and jobs, but the solutions in the G-20's statements are nevertheless very much "business as usual": supply-side economics, a strict fiscal policy and a lot of emphasis on reform, while the world is desperately waiting for the opposite, namely question, question and demand. The world economy is facing a shortage of demand. Low interest rates and large assets in governments and companies should therefore be used to stimulate the real economy. It is such a shame that this was overlooked last week. Investments, both public and private, and room for wage growth are very much needed. I therefore sincerely hope that this will be an open eye in Bratislava next Friday.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – Madam President, halting the migration of people to Europe cannot be just a European task, just as global actors – above all, the United States – have a serious responsibility in its creation. This should have been enforced by the EU at the G20 meeting. I quote from the joint letter from the Presidents of the Council and the Commission that 'we will call on the parties involved to increase humanitarian aid and to increase the resettlement of migrants'. At the same time, Donald Tusk declared that 'Europe is slowly reaching the limit of its capacity to take in refugees'. Well, that claim is closer to reality. It is time for the leaders of European countries, with Angela Merkel at the head, to get their heads out of the sand and face the will of the majority of the population. We want to protect our European identity and european culture!

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – We have heard in an interesting debate that the G20 summit has only partially been successful. While the leaders agreed on new measures to combat tax evasion, the United States and China agreed to ratify the Paris climate change agreement, the leaders showed a yellow card for China dumping in the steel industry, reaffirming their commitment to global trade and free trade agreements. It also shows that the US and Russia have definitively claimed responsibility for the ceasefire in Syria.  Certainly, the summit has not been particularly successful for the new UK Prime Minister. In it, US President Obama reiterated to British Prime Minister May that Britain will not have the privileges of negotiating a new trade deal with the US, nor does the US intend to change its traditional foreign policy priorities. He stressed that one of America's top priorities is the transatlantic partnership with the European Union.  Soon after, even the Japanese government handed may's study, which found that many Japanese companies would be forced to move their seats from the UK to other members of the European Union if the British do not remain members of the single market.  Well, still, the G20 has brought some perhaps less visible messages. This is a stronger commitment of the 20th to free trade and, in this context, to combat various forms of protectionism. This certainly applies to China and also sounds like a warning to a possible change in the post-US election.  The new economic momentum must be based on innovation and fairness, and economic growth should be inclusive. These G20 summit messages are good.  I hope that the results of this summit will encourage the European Union to step up the adoption of free trade agreements with Canada and the US.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, even the G20 is moving further away from the dogma of austerity and calling for the use of public investment to boost growth. Indeed, Europe is in dire need of public investment, as it has not been so low in decades, even though interest rates are historically low. I think it is an important fight, because public investment is a guarantee of quality jobs and social progress for all, but it is also an indispensable support for the real economy.  It is also sometimes a remedy for the flight or even the cowardly desertion of the private sector. The latest example is Caterpillar's abrupt stock market layoff in Gosselies, Belgium, where more than 5,000 jobs were lost in a matter of minutes. There's nothing economic about it, it's just a few thousand families who are sacrificed to fill the pockets of a few haves with huge dividends. In addition, Caterpillar has been depriving Belgian public revenues of several million euros for the past 15 years by repatriating its profits to Switzerland. Yet the G20 also calls for an effective fight against tax havens. Caterpillar has therefore become a bit of a symbol of what is wrong in Europe, and if Europe is not able to move towards more social and fiscal justice, its citizens will definitely turn their backs on it, and I think they will be right.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Such summits as the G20 summit are, in fact, fundamentally problematic. Great expectations are being nurtured in advance, which cannot then be met, and they also show that much of what we see as a priority in Europe is not considered to be really important at global level, especially if you weaken yourself beforehand, as in the referendum on Brexit. From a European point of view, in addition to the very superficial and by no means innovative treatment of the economic framework, there are three main shortcomings: migration has been discussed only vaguely; above all, there is a lack of common intentions to solve the refugee crisis. The same applies to the fight against terrorism, where measures against money laundering and illegal arms trafficking would be a priority. If this does not succeed, then our work is similar to that of Sisyphus. Finally, an area that is one of the EU's strengths, the digital sector, has been almost completely omitted. Sustainable growth must, above all, address this issue.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, even if there are no immediate solutions from these summits that the world needs, it is already important that the great powers can at least agree to a correct diagnosis of the main problems facing the world.  At this summit, G20 leaders realized that the world faces the return of nationalist and protectionist discourses. Seduced by such discourses, the populations of several countries are pointing to globalization as the main culprit of the labor and social difficulties that affect them. In their final communiqué, G20 leaders are willing to fight protectionism and remove obstacles to trade and international investment, while recognising what is important, that globalisation is not a homogeneous phenomenon.  In developing countries and emerging economies, globalisation has been linked in recent years to progress in the field of poverty reduction, increased average life expectancy and reduced infant mortality, among others. But in developed countries, it has had some adverse effects on, for example, precarious work and tax evasion.  The final communiqué recognises the benefits of globalisation and that they need to be widely shared. But a communiqué does not replace a plan, and lacked a clear commitment around global regulatory measures capable of neutralizing the difficulties that globalization has also caused and relaunching growth.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I must confess that I would have expected better conclusions from the G20 debate. It is all very well to say that we must grow the economy and acknowledge that, without widespread and uniform growth, the dramatic social and economic problems that the world is experiencing would not be solved, but proposals must also be made that are consistent with the assumption and these proposals are not there.  In order to have sustainable growth, we must have strict environmental standards to comply with. These are not there, and compliance with the existing rules, as you know, is very lasco. Secondly, we must have an economic policy based on a common fiscal policy. With regard to the things you deal with, I very much appreciate your work, but it has to be said that in the world the focus on fiscal policies is very low. Competition between product quality and production systems has been replaced by competition based on not charging taxes.  I believe that this direction needs to be radically changed and Europe can set a good example by solving the problems that you are dealing with.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the G20 conclusions on immigration seem to be a simple acknowledgeing of the seriousness of the crisis and an unnecessary rhetorical exercise. It was preferred to postpone rather than to intervene with concrete solutions.  It is absurd that only 1 paragraph out of 48 has been devoted to the issue of immigration - one has to wonder what kind of world the G20! leaders live in), a paragraph that many, including Amnesty, have called hypocritical because the call for greater burden-sharing by countries that do not take on their responsibilities first sounds like an empty and ridiculous appeal.  Currently, only 27 countries in the world have regular refugee resettlement programmes and just 9 of them are members of the G20. Nor am Tusk convinced me, saying that Europe is reaching the limit: 86% of displaced people are in developing countries. But what are we talking about? We would be more credible in calling for a greater effort at global sharing if we were to give an example by doing so internally.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: – The G20 leaders' meeting in China was full of important topics and the good news is that leaders have agreed on many things. However, economic and trade themes, even though this was a meeting of the world's most important politicians, must see an improvement in people's lives, not only in economically advanced countries, but throughout the world, because it is precisely the improvement of social conditions and quality of life that also has a significant impact on global themes such as migration, migration, the sustainability of the world economy and global trade. I also consider it a very important area to combat tax evasion, which is devouring our national budgets by billions of euros, but also to address urgent diplomatic issues, particularly in relation to Turkey, which is also very important for the European Union in terms of tackling the migration crisis. However, despite some general declarations and agreements, even after this summit, it remains a kind of strange feeling, as if each of the leaders were speaking more individually for their country than for the whole community.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the recent G20 Summit in Hangzhou saw several notable outcomes in steel dumping, tax avoidance and the refugee crisis. However, it was the comments made to my own country, the United Kingdom, which were chilling. With the focus of the meeting on economic growth, trade and investment, and with the UK’s decision to exit the EU, until that exit is concluded, uncertainty will exist in all of these areas. We do not even know, almost three months on since the referendum result, whether the UK’s negotiating position will prioritise access to the EU single market, a single market critical to the health of the British economy, critical to British jobs and, I would say, critical to Britain’s national interest.  And then there were the comments made by President Obama that a trade deal between the US and the EU will be a priority over any trade deal with the UK, followed by the warning from the Japanese that their firms could pull out of the UK if there was no single market access. I urge the British Government to listen, to take action, and to ensure that Britain can maintain what it has in accessing 500 million consumers in 27 different countries with one single set of rules, ensuring certainty for business and the highest standards for consumers.

name: Georgi Pirinski (S&D).
text: –  Thank you Madam President. By all accounts, this year’s G20 summit was dominated by a new and overriding awareness. The rising anger of people at the ravages that present-day neoliberal globalisation has caused in their lives. Media reports have claimed that Australian Prime Minister Turnbull actually called on leaders to ‘civilise capitalism.’ Some of this awareness has found its way in the final communiqué, which states: ‘quality employment is at the centre of the G20’s domestic and global agenda, together with reducing inequalities and promoting inclusive labour force participation.’ These precisely are the Big Issues (in capital letters) that President Junker and his Commission must directly tackle with the utmost urgency and full priority, or see the European project disintegrate under the tidal wave of widespread and completely justified popular protest.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the statements of the leaders and official communiqués of the recent G20 Summit indicate a good diagnosis of the problems affecting the current unregulated globalisation framework. They also understand a good understanding of solutions, strengthen the growth agenda, increase transparency, ensure territorial equity in the impact on economic relations, address the issues that multiply refugee crises and unsustainable migration flows, fight terrorism and respond to the challenges of climate change. In a world where inequalities are deepening and people are increasingly instrumental, the agenda proclaimed by the G20 increases the responsibility of those who subscribe to it. We in the European Union must therefore set an example by putting these priorities on our agenda. This increases the expectation of the speech that will be given here tomorrow by the President of the Commission.  After policies of blind austerity have impoverished and weakened the Union, populist and nationalist vultures now fly over their possible prey. But when we look at the G20 agenda, we see that this is an agenda on which only a united, cooperative and supportive European Union can win. The path is clear, we commit—to us with a path. Let's make it happen.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: - Thank you. Colleagues, we can be pleased that the G20 meeting in China has taken place. Unfortunately, it must be noted that it has not been marked by important agreements and decisions. What could really be a welcome result is his hostess, China, who used the G20 format as another opportunity to promote Beijing's economic model of the world, the One Belt, one road strategy, the deatlantisation strategy. At that time, Canada requested admission to the AIIB, the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, and now, from the major powers, only the US and Japan are not part of this Chinese-led credit institution. The European Union, plagued by many problems, does not pay sufficient attention to the OBOR strategy and its possible consequences. Finally, I would like to welcome the fact that the final communication also places a significant amount of space on the AMR, a solution to the problem of antimicrobial resistance, in order to bring this problem to the level of the United Nations in general.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam Chairman, there were many topics on the menu of the G20 and it should simply be said that the two topics, which are actually completely intertwined with each other, namely migration and refugee crises and the topic of economic growth, were really key topics for me.  I can say that, in a way, encouraging messages come from the G20 meeting. After all, the very fact that the G20 is dealing with the migrant crisis shows seriousness and maturity at the moment. On the other hand, economic growth is linked to what the migrant crisis means, especially when we talk about Africa, and makes it absolutely clear what we need to do in the coming years. I think that it is in this case that the European Union must show its strength and unity, because otherwise, if there are no concrete moves and concrete results, a lot will go wrong, and we certainly don't need that.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, at the summit of the leaders of the twenty most developed countries, namely the G20, it was carefully avoided to address serious problems facing the international community such as refugees, illegal immigration and the consequences of the Syrian war. But how could this be done when among these twenty leaders there are also the main ones responsible for all these problems and among them, of course, the President of Turkey, a country which, with the tolerance of all, is arbitrarily arbitrarily and becomes a danger to peace, at least, in the Middle East. However, there was no convincing answer to certain economic problems such as, for example, the protection of the steel industry in European countries, the taxation of global economic giants and the treatment of social and economic inequality around the world. name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, your debate reflects both your interest in the G20 conclusions and also a number of frustrations, which I can understand, both on the conduct of the meeting itself and on its conclusions. What we all need to be aware of here - I say to those who would have liked to hear about this or that subject - is the nature of the G20. The G20 was created in the context of the economic and financial crisis of 2008-2013 to focus on economic and financial issues. Of course, geopolitical, strategic issues , such as Syria, were present. Of course, there was a whole discussion about Turkey's role, in the presence of President Erdogan, but the main objective was to take stock of the economic policy followed by the major countries on a global scale and to reach a number of directions. I say directions because the G20 is also not a place where highly operational conclusions can be adopted. There are some, I have quoted those that deal with the issue of overcapacity, but the G20, on the one hand, sets out signals that are quite important to the global economy and, on the other hand, gives a number of institutions - the FATF, the OECD - the missions that must be pursued. As this understanding of your frustrations is expressed, I also believe that the quality of this particular G20 meeting should not be underestimated. We could have hoped for more and something else, as always, and besides you hope for more and something else with your differences of sensitivity, which is quite natural. I believe that there is an opportunity in this G20 to seize in global cooperation and we must require our G20 partners to use this cooperation to promote even solid and comprehensive growth that can deliver tangible benefits for our fellow citizens, and then free and fair trade relations, once again for the benefit of all. , and more inclusive societies. The European Union brings to the debate valuable experience, that of the most advanced integration, the most successful on a continental scale in a large internal market, which makes us, the Europeans, the leading economic power in the world, and then also of a political model, a social model, a cultural model. We shared this experience in Hangzhou, both through the role of the President of the Council, that of the President of the Commission, but also with the European countries which are present in numbers and strength, because they are great economies. I think we have achieved results that reinforce a number of our priorities, which converge with them, and I have talked, for example, about the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion. This is a subject on which, for years, the G20 has been the place where a strategy implemented through the OECD with the BEPS initiative is being implemented, and which is converging with our own priorities and the action that, on behalf of the Commission, I am trying to push for a tax system that is both more transparent and more effective. We will have the opportunity to have many appointments on this subject in the coming months. It is true that you have both mentioned the situation in Britain and Brexit. I do not want to go back to what I am saying in the introduction, but perhaps one point, however, which concerns the negotiation of free trade agreements. On this point, President Juncker's conclusion and the reaction of our partners have been extremely clear. As we speak, the negotiation of Britain's exit has not begun. We are waiting for this to happen as soon as possible, understanding that we have to take some time to prepare, to set priorities, but not too long if we want the uncertainty not to spread and end up penalizing investment and economic activity. Then the negotiation will begin. All the while - and Parliament heard yesterday from Mr King, who is the Commissioner to represent Great Britain - Great Britain is a member of the European Union, so it is up to the European Union to negotiate free trade agreements and it is up to the Commission to do so on behalf of the European Union. So let us not have a functioning here that would be curious temporally, with bilateral negotiations, when the negotiation between Great Britain and the European Union has not begun and the European Union itself has its initiative. I was talking about Europe. Let us not forget a very important factor, which is that, in December, Germany will take the G20 presidency. This is of course an opportunity for us, the European Union, to work with a country of the Union, a major partner of the world community which knows, which shares, by definition, the priorities of the European Union. I expect a great deal from the work of Mr Schauble, as German Minister of Economy and Finance during this Presidency, at the level of the Ministers of Economy and Finance who are preparing the G20, and also from the German Presidency afterwards at the summit that will conclude it. The Commission will work closely with the German Presidency to prepare for the next G20 summit in Hamburg on 7-8 July 2017. We hope that some of the priority areas on which an agreement has been reached this time can make further progress and, quickly, we will work to ensure that there are strong priorities that are affirmed. There is no time to waste and, once again, I wanted to present these G20 conclusions as objectively as possible, aware of the limitations inherent in the exercise, but also of the undeniable quality of this meeting, and in its form and substance. Thank you for your time and your more than judicious comments.

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank Honourable Members very much for all the speeches and comments. They confirm your huge interest in the agenda that was a subject of discussion at the G20 meeting in in China. Many issues were raised: economic growth, migration, free trade, tax evasion, steel, China, the Paris agreement and many others. I tried to present how we viewed the discussion on those issues in my initial statement. I share the views expressed by Commissioner Moscovici when he spoke on behalf of the Commission. All these items are extremely important. I dare say that we, as a union, have a clearly defined interest in those areas, but I think that the G20 Summit in China has reminded us once again that this is maybe the time for us to pull together, as a union, to work on those items in order to have an even better position when we try to protect the interests of the Union and its citizens on the global stage. We are committed as a Presidency to working intensively with you, Parliament, and the Commission on all the points mentioned so that, as I said, we can make progress and strengthen our position on the global stage.  Finally, two issues were raised which are part of our Presidency’s responsibility. Mr Telička asked about our further steps as the Presidency when it comes to TTIP. I can say that this will be very high on the agenda for the upcoming Foreign Affairs Trade Council, which will take place on 23 September in Bratislava. I believe this is the place where we Member States, together with the Commission, should assess where we stand in negotiations with the United States. This may be, I dare say, the last moment for us to consolidate our position together and look where progress is still possible in the remaining time of the Obama Administration. But we are aware that our mandate says very clearly where our offensive interests lie, and we as a Presidency will do our utmost to ensure that those interests are protected. On the Paris agreement, which was also mentioned several times, I can assure you that we as a Presidency are currently trying to agree on a clear timetable that will allow the ratification of the Paris agreement on behalf of the European Union so as to ensure the participation of the EU at the upcoming COP 22 Marrakesh meeting on global climate change.  Finally, I should have said at the beginning – but I came late and I apologise for that – that we as a Presidency are trying to control the agenda. I found out this morning that I was not able to control the traffic in Strasbourg, but it was a very nice walk. At the last moment I had to leave my car somewhere in Germany and I apologise once again for this.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed.  Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. At the G20 summit in Hangzhou on 4 and 5 September, the European Union reiterated the need for shared action to achieve objectives such as the fight against international terrorism and corruption, greater fiscal cooperation, combating overproduction in the steel sector and finally resolving the migration and refugee crisis. In particular, the responses that emerged from the G20 summit with regard to these last two priorities deserve positive attention. Finally, there is an awareness that we must tackle together the effects of the migration crisis that has hit Europe, in order to respond to the needs of refugee protection and the root causes of a crisis that has resulted in the death of thousands of human lives. In addition, as G20 leaders have promised, a collective response will be needed to combat the oversupply of some countries in the steel sector, China over all. That is why it would be useful to set up a specific forum to monitor these countries and therefore to combat a phenomenon that risks jeopardising production in the steel sector and the millions of workers working in what must remain a vital sector for European and Italian industry.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
