text: in writing. – The international press reported more this G20 meeting stressing its attempt to resolve the squaring of the circle. Or, put another way, the G20 wants to "civilize capitalism." Debalde. Economic growth, deregulation of international trade and the movement of capital, climate, social justice: here are some of the ingredients of G20 cooking, which seeks, in essence, to cure the patient by inoculating him another generous dose of the causative agent of the disease. The result can't be any different than what we have.  The pious statements that echoed the G20, which do not forget the poignant appeals against the siren song of "protectionism", may elude many people for some time, but they will not be able to deceive everyone forever and ever. Financial instability, corruption, social inequalities and environmental degradation of the planet represent many other faces of neoliberal policies at the service of large international capital. There will be no two or three or even 20 rich countries solving humanity's problems. It will be the peoples struggling, in the construction of a progressive and anti-capitalist alternative, capable of responding to the serious problems of the planet, for the benefit of workers and peoples and not in favor of a small handful of multimillionaires.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The G20 summit took place in an extremely delicate environment for the world and Europe. It makes a strong impression that the topics discussed in the forum were of direct importance to the European Union and this clearly shows the number of challenges we all face. In addition to the need for more sustainable and better economic growth, punitive measures against the world's tax havens, the need to invest in new technologies and address global warming, the focus of the discussions has been on combating terrorism and tackling the international refugee crisis.  In this regard, I believe that the G20 meeting was a great opportunity for the European Union to reaffirm comprehensive global action to share responsibility for resolving the refugee and migration crisis and addressing its root causes. We must also not ignore the fact that the final meeting document stated that the outcome of the UK referendum added uncertainty to the global economy.  The Forum also outlined the important role played by bilateral and regional trade agreements and I believe that the European Union must work to ratify an agreement to facilitate and liberalisation international trade soon.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. – China is responsible for half of the world's steel production and due to market saturation it causes the price of iron and steel to dump on the world market, and the European economy cannot compete with China at a price. I welcome the speech by the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, who said that we should defend the interests of the European steel industry, where 10 000 jobs have been lost in the past few years, and I support its efforts to help China to accept the creation of a mechanism to monitor over-capacity in the steel sector.  One of the negative consequences for Croatia is the impossibility of successful steelworks operations in Split and Sisak, where hundreds of jobs were irreversibly destroyed as a result of price movements on the world market, as well as other problems. I would also like to welcome the EU-China agreement to establish a global forum to monitor overcapping.  For Europeans, and Croats, an adequate solution to this problem is of great importance before accepting the granting of market economy status to China and deciding on trade defence measures on the European market. Decisions taken globally affect all Member States and jobs, so by preventing dumping and establishing fair market relations, we contribute to protecting European industry and jobs.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Pablo Zalba Bidegain and Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, on behalf of the Committee of Inquiry into emissions measurement in the automotive sector, on the investigation into emissions measurement in the automotive sector (2016/2090(INI)) (A8-0246/2016).

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, almost a year ago Volkswagen confessed, before the United States Environmental Protection Agency, the use of trickling mechanisms to pass emissions tests and thus achieve the approval of these products in the United States. The first question I think we should ask ourselves is why this scandal was not discovered in the European Union; why in the European Union we were not able to uncover fraud of such magnitude. Clearly, the answer is not easy but there are many factors, which I would like to discuss here today, which explain this. First of all, obviously, a lack of Europe. A lack of Europe due, above all, to insufficient integration. I have no doubt that if we had been a true United States of Europe, this scandal could not have happened. But I am sure, without a doubt, that if it had been the United States of Europe, our consumers, the millions of Europeans who use a car every day, would have been more protected. But I have no doubt that if we had a single judicial system, consumers in the European Union would certainly be more protected. There is another factor that also explains why we have come to this situation. Undoubtedly, Commissioner Verheugen's vague legislation also explains why we have not been able to uncover this scandal and - more importantly - why this scandal has been able to occur. In addition, I believe that we have to make self-criticism, because Commissioner Verheugen precisely negotiated in this house, with some of our colleagues, legislation which, as time has shown, has been insufficient. Commissioner Tajani arrived and tried to put the bell on the cat to try to push for legislation that would be ambitious in reducing NOx emissions. We were all aware of the discrepancies. This same house approved a report showing that we were aware of the discrepancies between tests under real driving conditions and laboratory tests. The question is, did we do enough then? I think it's time to look to the future. What the European citizens of this Committee of Inquiry certainly expect is that we know the truth and, more importantly, that we make proposals to push for measures to prevent fraud like this from taking place again. And I have no doubt that all my colleagues will agree that we are going to try to get to this point. Crises are opportunities and this is undoubtedly the crisis that the automotive sector needed to adapt to a reality of the twentieth century much more demanding with emissions, much more demanding in the search for new mobility formulas. And we have to be aware that the income of twelve million families is at stake. We need to be rigorous enough, not only to guarantee the incomes of these families, but above all, to give them a better future. There is no point in acknowledging that we should have known about this fraud; what we have to do now is discover the truth and, above all, and most importantly, look to the future. It has been a pleasure to work with my Dutch colleague, with which I look forward to continuing to work in the coming months, as well as with the rest of my colleagues, as shadow rapporteurs.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, let me start by thanking my fellow rapporteur, Pablo Zalba, for the excellent work so far and I am also looking forward to working closely together in the coming months. This interim report is primarily procedural and there was a reason for it, because we only just started with our work. There is, however, one strong political point in it and that is that we call upon the Commission to better and more swiftly cooperate with the work of our committee of inquiry. That was the case when we adopted this interim report in committee. I must say that since then the Commission has considerably improved its cooperation, and I hope that we can continue that way of working.  So far, our committee of inquiry has collected a lot of, well, let us say, technical evidence. We spoke with car manufacturers, producers of emission control technologies, software experts, academics, NGOs. Most of the technical part we have done so far, and we have just begun with the political part of our inquiry. We have had hearings with a whole bunch of Commissioners starting with former Commissioners Dimas, Potočnik, Verheugen and Tajani, and yesterday evening with the current Commissioners Bieńkowska and Vella.  Very crucial also will be our focus on the Member States; I am very much looking forward to the hearings with national ministers in the coming weeks, and I sincerely call upon those ministers who have not yet confirmed their attendance to do so. European democracy also means that national ministers are accountable for their position in Europe. We will also hear the American EPA and the national type approval authorities.  What have we found so far? Well, first of all, we of course discovered that this is much more than just the Volkswagen case. We have seen that other car manufacturers are shutting down their emission abatement technology when the temperature goes below 17°C, or after 22 minutes. That comes close to the 20-minute test cycle, so we have seen that the problem is much bigger than just Volkswagen and that is something that we have to explore further on. Also we still have a lot of questions concerning the role of Member States. We do see that there has been quite a weak implementation and enforcement of European legislation and that is something that we sincerely have to discuss very closely with the national ministers. Another question that we are still digging into is why did it take so long to develop this new real driving emission test? In 2010 the Commission work document said that it would take roughly two years for the technical exercise to develop this test; we all know that it took many many more years and that is something that we have to dig into as well.  Finally, it is one year since the scandal broke and since then we have done a lot, but there are still millions and millions of diesel cars on the European roads that do not comply with current legislation. That is something that we have discussed yesterday with Commissioner Bieńkowska and I am very happy with her strong approach now. We are awaiting, within weeks, some infringement procedures, but it is certainly something that we are still going to focus upon. Also the recall of vehicles, that is still primarily based on a voluntary approach.  I am very much looking forward to the coming months. We will conclude our report in March next year and I hope that we can draw not only conclusions about what happened in the past, but also some conclusions, some lessons for the future, because that might be the most important part of our inquiry.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this is an important debate and I am glad to be here. Firstly, I would like to thank both the rapporteurs for their work. It has been almost a year since the Volkswagen emissions scandal broke, and more than six months have passed since the Committee of Inquiry on Emission Measurements in the Automotive Sector started its work. This was, for both of us, a period of very intense work, both for Parliament and for the Commission. I can assure you that I did my best to act in full cooperation and transparency, and I am committed to continue to do so: to fully cooperate with Parliament in the months to come and until the end of the work of the inquiry committee.  I have done whatever I could to answer all of your questions. I know that you are not fully satisfied, but we tried to do our best and we will continue to do so. I am convinced that this is the best way to uncover all the facts, and to help conclude on the best way forward: for the Commission in its role as a legislator, for the Member States in their efforts to enforce the law, and for the industry to be credible, modern and environmentally conscious. We are ready to help as much as we can, but, of course, we expect, and I also expect, Member States to be equally transparent and cooperative. The Commission has invited Member States to investigate the presence of defeat devices in the vehicles circulating on their territories and to report back to us. Until now, four Member States – the UK, Germany, France and Italy – have prepared such reports. These reports have been made available to the Commission and to the general public at the same time. The Commission recently, by the end of July, transmitted to the European Parliament a first overview on the national investigation. But unfortunately we do not have the complete picture yet. The data submitted by Member States is incomplete and there are still many outstanding questions for which additional technical information is still needed. We, and myself personally, are disappointed with where things stand for now. We need this technical information to be able to make an independent judgement on what has happened. I have insisted with Member States that they should transmit this information to the Commission, and I will continue doing so, while of course continuing to monitor how the national investigations progress. Let me also add one word on defeat devices. They have been prohibited in the EU for more than 18 years now. The legal provisions on defeat devices are clear. Manufacturers, and every type approval authority, never questioned these rules or how they should be implemented. If they do not honour these rules, there must be consequences because this is a law.  I am ready to help in ensuring a coherent interpretation of the rules across the Single Market. For that reason I offered, with my services, to provide practical guidance to the national authorities on how to handle emissions control systems at type approval. We are confident that this will ensure a coherent approach across all EU territory. We all know that enforcement for now is the key problem to be urgently solved. We face the current situation because of lenient enforcement and weak market surveillance. We have proposed to change this and to enforce the current system. A new supervisory system with Commission oversight and mutual control between Member States, together with EU penalties, is crucial for overcoming the problems we are facing today. It will also be key to restore the confidence of our citizens which was very seriously harmed.  The Commission tabled its proposal in January 2016 and it is now up to the European Parliament and the Council to decide. No position has been reached yet in the Council. We would like the work on the draft report of Mr Dalton and the Internal Market Committee to proceed as quickly as possible, but also to adopt the proposal as soon as possible. The reluctance – I would even say the resistance to necessary changes – is discouraging, not to say disappointing. To succeed, we need your support to keep the level of ambition of this proposal. I particularly hope that the work of the EMIS Committee can demonstrate how important the proposed changes to our type approval system are. I therefore call on all of you to deal with the past, but as always I would say to pave the way for the future. Otherwise, a year of very intensive work will not be satisfactory in bringing tangible change. We will continue to fully cooperate with you in the months to come, and of course I would like to say that the Commission welcomes your interim report. I wish both of us success in the forthcoming weeks and months.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the – Mr President, Commissioner, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent work. We have heard a variety of witnesses for almost half a year. They come from the scientific and research community, from non-governmental organisations, from the car industry, to suppliers, etc., as well as from the European Commission. What then in this half-year – what have we learned? The first is the question: how did we get to where we are at all? What we have listened to is that in Europe we are, for ideological reasons, I am not saying that, for wrong reasons, we set the main objective of reducing CO2 emissions. The result was to encourage, deliberately stimulate the development of the diesel industry and the interest of buyers in the purchase of diesel engines, but ignored or revised the fact that, although diesel has low CO2 emissions, he has high levels of nitrogen dioxide, oxides, various, nokši called, which are directly harmful to human health. Chasing one goal, it was reviewed that he had a side effect, a negative effect on human health. Second. The adoption of the last regulation on car emission standards, in Euro 5 and 6 in 2007, did not resolve the already known difficulties with road emissions that they are much higher than laboratory. And thirdly, the problem of not being european monitoring did not resolve the problem, everything remained at Member State level. So, we need to learn from ideology, however, it is necessary to consider all the side effects that might be. From the tests, we must have tests that are related to road emissions, not just to the laboratory. And with supervision, we need to establish European monitoring so that there is no uncoordinated action by the Member States.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, as the Commissioner rightly said, it is now a year since the Volkswagen scandal broke, and we were all completely shocked. We were shocked because of the behaviour of one of the largest and most epic, iconic European companies, trying to increase their own profits at the expense of planet and people. But we were equally shocked because it was not our European institutions or our many type approval authorities or market surveillance bodies that discovered this fraud, but it had been discovered in the States. So rightly we decided to install a Committee of Inquiry committee in the European Parliament – it is the first Committee of Inquiry for more than 10 years – looking at the maladministration, but also making sure that we get the truth above the waterline. This EMIS committee should also rebuild the trust in the European legislation but also in our European products. We are halfway now, and we discovered that it is not only Volkswagen, but many other companies that overstretched loopholes – the legal loopholes – by switching off emission control under a broad range of operational conditions, with the result that after 10 years we have now more emissions and our legal system is being violated. An average diesel car today emits 4 to 5 times more.  Of course, the future of RDE will solve part of the problem but, Madam Commissioner, we were very happy with your statements yesterday. We have to take into account that we also have to readjust the situation as it is today. Cars with illegal defeat strategies are entering our markets daily, letting them emit too much, and that will cause extra pollution for the years to come. In the next month we will focus on the Member States, and that will equally be very important. As the Chair of the committee, I sincerely hope that all of us, together with the Commission, with the Member States, but especially in the EMIS committee, can overcome differences between the political groups and stand as one to solve this problem.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which In addition to Volkswagen's criminal misconduct, the Committee of Inquiry also brought to light the failure of the European Commission. Even former Industry Commissioner Günter Verheugen – one of the predecessors of the Commissioner sitting here today – has had to admit, when I have asked, that the European directives were far too vague. We must also now realise that the American exhaust directives are much more demanding than the European ones and, as has already been discussed, it was the Americans who exposed this scandal, not the Europeans. We are only drawing the logical conclusion from this: we call on the Commission to include in the negotiations on TTIP the harmonisation of the emission directives for motor vehicles and to recognise the higher standards of the other partner. This has great advantages. Firstly, it improves the protection of millions of people on both sides of the Atlantic from harmful emissions. Secondly, the costs of developing and producing different exhaust systems are drastically reduced. Thirdly, the benefits of a free trade agreement could thus be demonstrated in an impressive way. In this critical situation, the Commission could also contribute to the acceptance of TTIP.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on the alde group. – Mr President, Commissioner, no one has yet submitted objective and clear answers to the citizens of the European Union, facts about exactly what happened. The Commission's negotiating mandate formulates clear questions – to investigate alleged failures by the Commission and the Member States. Measures should have been taken to supervise the use of so-called defeat devices, i.e. defeat defeat devices, and in fact they were not. Emissions measurements corresponding to car traffic should have been introduced – and if it hadn't been for the US revelations, we wouldn't have this either. During the hearing before the Committee of Inquiry, experts said it was a long-known problem. Diesel cars did not meet real-world emission limits and could even use various means to do so. On the other hand, the European Commission denies that it erst or has been delayed and is said to have been unaware of possible fraudulent conduct. Lots of questions, lots of unexplained questions. Without a clear answer to these questions, we will not be able to restore the confidence of European consumers, and I personally consider this to be one of the main objectives of our efforts. I would therefore like to call on the rapporteur to make the resulting document, which comes from the work of the Committee of Inquiry, absolutely clear and user-friendly in its communications. Any EU citizen who is able to get acquainted with the results of the investigation must be clear about the errors that have occurred and, above all, who is responsible for them.  The resulting findings should draw a thick line behind the whole case. We should learn from the conclusions of the investigation and translate it into further forthcoming legislation in this area, such as vehicle type-approval and emission measurement rules. Last but not least, the European automotive industry is also waiting for our results. An industry that creates more than 12 million jobs in Europe. An industry for which further procrastination may be a drag on further development.  Lastly, I see that we do not have a representative of the Member States here, a representative of the Council, I consider this to be a big mistake. I think that it should be an effort by all institutions to get a clear result for our citizens.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Ladies and gentlemen, the first report submitted by the Committee of Inquiry is limited to the description of the work programme and makes no political assessment as the investigation continues. However, this does not mean that the first conclusions have not already been drawn. On the contrary, after many hours of hearings and study of internal documents, it is now clear that there are serious political responsibilities. Both the 2010 estimates and the Study of the Commission's Joint Research Centre in 2013 confirmed that measurements could be altered. And yet, no action was taken. The Commission was aware of the possibility of fraud, but did nothing on the grounds that it was not aware of specific cases. Although the Member States were informed, they also did not do any checks. Moreover, while it was known that emission measurements are much higher in real-world conditions than those recorded in laboratories, no checks were requested only in real road conditions. There have therefore been significant omissions by both the Commission and the Member States in the application of Union law and in the imposition of sanctions.  But let us say things by name: loopholes in legislation, strong pressures on the car industry and the safety net of multinational companies have led to the political scandal over emissions measurements. Because Folkswagen's fraud is not an isolated case. We, ladies and gentlemen, will continue the investigation and exert further pressure. We will always work constructively with the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs to get to the result. Our aim is to end all practices that seek unfair profit at the expense of public health and the environment.

name: Claude Turmes
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, one year of the VW  scandal, which is in reality a scandal of the whole car industry. In April - May 2014, US authorities get detailed data showing discrepancies. They did not know anything about defeat devices. What did the US authorities do in that moment? They called in VW and asked them a very simple question: Please can you explain the discrepancy between the test in the lab and your very high emissions on the road? One meeting, a second meeting, a third and fourth meeting, a fifth meeting: VW lied and lied and lied. Fifteen months later in September 2015 US authorities say ‘It’s game over’ and VW has to admit massive fraud. Then VW tried to carry out recall campaigns in the US. They proposed one recall campaign, a second one, a third one. The US authorities had one very simple question: please show us that your NOx emissions are fulfilling the law after the recall. VW was not able to show that, not one single recall campaign was admitted, therefore action 3 came: compensation of consumers and huge fines for not having respected the law.  So Obama and his administration were merely doing their job. You have an industry which commits fraud, and they get caught. What have we done in Europe? We had the same information as the US, years earlier. We had it in winter 2009-2010. The Commission and Member States did not once ask a manufacturer the same question that the US did: Please explain to us the discrepancy between on-road and the lab. Why still no infringement procedures? So the Commission is part of this omertá . Second thing: it is very interesting that the same VW recall campaign which was refused by the American authorities has now been admitted and waved through by KBA; so VW is cheating against consumers, this time with the official logo of the German Government. You come here today with no single action on recall. Why do you not act on recall? You could act on recall. And the third issue is compensation. No compensation, so recapitulation: the Juncker Commission comes here and says ‘restore confidence’. No infringement procedures, despite the facts that you know. No action to restore, no action on compensation, so with that attitude of the Juncker Commission, we will not regain the confidence of citizens and we need it.

name: Eleonora Evi
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, despite the low expectations of the effectiveness of the Committee of Inquiry, I am of the opinion that the work is bringing many significant elements useful for identifying the shortcomings, weaknesses, opacity of the entire vehicle type-approval system and the control of their emissions.  One thing is certainly certain: defeat devices are just the tip of the iceberg of the entire system. I do not want to dwell on the report, but I would like to take the opportunity of this speech in plenary to publicly denounce the fact that the investigation report on Diesel Euro 5 cars marketed in Italy, a report produced by the Italian Ministry of Infrastructure and Transport, is an insult to the work of this Parliament's Committee of Inquiry and, above all, is seriously offensive to European citizens. , which deserve seriousness, competence and maximum transparency on the part of the institutions.  The report is deliberately incomplete and omissionary: the surveys of the 15 cars initially mentioned in the report follow different procedures depending on whether they are fca group cars or not; Fiat cars are even tested in Fiat laboratories in Turin, while other cars are tested in other CNR laboratories. The traces of some Fiat and Jeep models are completely lost, which literally disappear from the graphs and tables of the document – coincidentally they are precisely the models for which there are the strongest suspicions that mount illegal devices, in one case devices that seem to turn off after twenty-two minutes, exactly two minutes after the end of the homologation test cycle and , in the other, a model that in the hot test demonstrated emissions of nitrogen oxides three times the norm.  We are facing a clumsy attempt to hide the real values of Fiat cars. The 5 Star Movement proposes to send back to the sender this report which is an insult to the EMIS committee, parliament and Italian and European citizens.

name: Marcus Pretzell
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. In addition to the fact that VW has clearly broken the law here, we have been able to learn several things in the hearings of recent months: we have found that the Commission appears to have insufficient control over the legal situation, but that it also does not seem to be aware of the few means of control it has.  For many years now, there have been more than just rumours, mrs Bie-kowska, that we have not only a VW scandal, but perhaps also scandals at other car manufacturers. They could have the technical documentation submitted not only by VW, but also by other car manufacturers, at the latest now. They seem to have done nothing in this direction. Nor could you explain to us what you actually did to the States that are obliged to provide you with information. So far, they have not provided for any quality assurance system for this legislation. If we take legislation seriously in the European Union, if we regulate these matters at European level, then we must claim to have the appropriate quality assurance systems in place. Instead, we now rely on the findings of American agencies. And perhaps the different economic interests of the United States and Europe also play a role here. Not only should we allow ourselves to be dareed by the carts of the Americans, but we should develop our own independent findings. That must be the European Union's ambition. It cannot be done with VW paying high compensation payments of almost 15 billion dollars in the United States. Further investigations are also needed at other manufacturers.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner Bie kowska, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We have half-time in the important work of the Committee on Exhaust Gas, and we are doing an intensive and sometimes very technical work. I am quite convinced that we have already made some progress. We should continue on the path of objective work. Of course, the appeal is always there to exploit such an issue politically. There are always colleagues who claim that the Commission, and in particular individual Commissioners, knew about the cheating software. Alone, the proof has not yet been provided. As recently as last week, we heard this speculation: the former Commissioner for the Environment, Potosnik, had even informed his colleague, Mr Tajani, in a letter. I have this letter. The accusations are baseless. I cannot see any evidence in this. That would also be surprising, because Potosnik told the Committee of Inquiry that he himself did not suspect any cheating software. How should he write a letter to this end if he himself had no knowledge? We now have the second half of the committee's work ahead of us, and I would like to call for these political games to be abandoned for the second half and instead to make the legislative processes actually better, but also faster. The Commission has been aware of the differences in nitrogen oxides between laboratory measurement and real driving since 2005. In fact, for the legislative solution – and I expressly include the European Parliament – we need more than ten years for the introduction of the RDE testing procedures, which I hope will now be completed quickly. The emissions legislation takes too long – all the Commissioners agreed on this across party lines. This is the chance for our committee to clarify, firstly, objectively, secondly, to refrain from playing political games, and then, thirdly, to formulate the legislation so clearly in the future that fraud will not be possible in the future.

name: Seb Dance (S&D).
text: – Mr President, as has been said, this is a time to take stock of what the committee’s work has uncovered. We have heard already that a decision was taken in the past to move in a direction that has led to higher NOx emissions, concentrating rightly – yes – on reducing CO2, but having this side effect. It has been stated on numerous occasions that there has been a lack of knowledge and a lack of credible evidence as to the effects of diesel on public health. But, of course, part of the reason why that evidence was not forthcoming is the myriad of levels of responsibility that exist under the current frameworks, ensuring that nobody can take full responsibility for what has happened. You have Member States blaming the European Union, you have the Commission blaming the Member States, and you have the car companies in effect slipping through various loopholes, taking advantage of loopholes and slipping through the net. What we have found out so far is that there is a terrible discrepancy in the interpretation of existing legislation. The Commissioner is absolutely correct when she says that we must use what we find out in this committee of inquiry to make sure that forthcoming legislation does not have the same mistakes, and does not contain the same loopholes and opportunities for ambiguous interpretation of what must be very clear rules. Finally, I thank my colleagues from across the political spectrum on this. It is essential that we work together and it is essential that this does not become a political slanging match between left and right, because we owe it to European consumers and to public health throughout the European Union, to get this right.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: As vice-chairman of this committee of inquiry, I fully support the interim report. Although it is too early to draw final conclusions, we can already make some important determinations. We have clean cars in the lab, but not on the road. The relevant legislation therefore misses its purpose and that was evident to many stakeholders. The one million question is why the action was not more appropriate and faster to remediate the manifest problems, to enforce the rules and to protect public health. There is a real implementation gap, where reality is far from what is technically possible. All the technology is there to meet the Euro-6-NOx standards for diesel today, even in real driving conditions and without a negative impact on CO2 emissions. Although European law prohibits the use of cheating software, not all loopholes seem closed. For example, emission control systems are sometimes unlawfully disabled and it is unclear, for example, from what temperature the disabling is permitted or not. We must continue to work on a strong final report in the interests of public health, the environment and consumer confidence. We will continue to ask critical questions with these priorities: bring out the truth, formulate solutions for the future, and highlight best practices, such as from California, the United States.

name: Nils Torvalds (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, I would like to thank Commissioner Bieńkowska. I will continue to speak in Swedish for the benefit of the public back home.  We are in a particularly interesting and, perhaps, embarrassing situation. In the United States, the process has been quite clear and consumers and citizens have been rewarded, so to speak, by demonstrating unequivocally and clearly that Volkswagen has used what are known as defeat devices, i.e. defeat devices. In Europe, we have a slightly different situation and i am extremely concerned about it. Because we do not just have defeat devices, defeat devices. We also have defeat performance, i.e. manipulation activities. The committee has not received the information it needs, and it points out that there may be other culprits other than volkswagen alone.  As far as citizens and consumers are told, it is of the utmost importance that it can be clearly demonstrated that the Commission and the Members of the Commission did not have their hands in the jam jar during this process. If it is not demonstrated, the Commission will be obliged to ensure that citizens do not receive their compensation for the losses they have suffered, both in terms of a poorer environment and in the case of a poorer product that they have bought. For this reason, I now call on the Commissioner to take this issue very seriously and to take it straight from the front and stop wriggling. Give us our data and maybe we can save the consumer.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, one of the most important issues in the autumn is the reduction of transport emissions. The Commission's ambition is high, with the dream of zero-emission transport. Unfortunately, the EMIS scandal has shown that when greed jumps behind the wheel of a car, the rally is fierce and the ride is cold. Think about: 400 000 premature deaths due to fine particulate matter emissions from transport, a year in Europe – not a small issue.  In addition to protecting the environment, another of the major challenges of sorting out the whole pattern of the scandal is restoring consumer confidence. We all have a screen seat now. The European car industry must stop circling and recognise its responsibilities. On the other hand, the three of us – the Commission, the Council and Parliament – must work together so that the future rules of the game are strict enough and there is no longer room for scams. It's not enough to find the culprits. The whole chain must be passed through so that the information learned from the errors can be utilised and this will not happen again in the future.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for being here today. I think if you just look at what we learned after half a year of the committee of inquiry, what is very important is that all the technical experts say there is no technical reason at all to switch off any abatement technology. It is technically not needed for protecting engines or anything else. We know that a lot of, if not all, car manufacturers are using software to switch off these technologies. Only Volkswagen has been sentenced for using defeat devices, but Fiat are using it, shutting it off after 22 minutes, and other car manufacturers are turning it off below 17°C. There is no reason for that. Still, no other car manufacturer is being blamed for using defeat devices, and action by the Commission is urgently needed. More importantly, as we speak, polluting cars are still driving on our streets. When is the Commission going to coordinate a European recall to get those dirty cars off our streets?

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, first of all I ought to congratulate colleagues because the debate, as I am hearing it, is a great deal more interesting than the interim report, although that was unanimously supported by the committee. It is a very curious report since it is almost totally devoid of content. It is an extraordinarily reflexive and self-referential document. Indeed, in paragraph 1, the committee calls on itself to fulfil its own mandate, which seems strangely tautological and redundant. It also calls on the Commission for more cooperation. I would, however, take issue with one word in the report. With extraordinary hubris, paragraph 4 requires governments, parliaments and the competent authorities of Member States to take certain actions. It is no business of this Parliament or of its temporary committee to require sovereign governments to take any action at all. Had common courtesy prevailed, had the committee requested rather than required, we might have supported the report. As it is, I am afraid we cannot.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to commend the work of our Commission, which is working very carefully to reveal the shortcomings of our industries and institutions in controlling pollutant emissions. I regret, however, that our work on technical issues is too negligent in the fact that the Volkswagen revelations are part of an economic war between Europe and America. When you want to kill your German shepherd, you accuse him of having rage!  If the context does not excuse anything, it can help to understand the logic and implications of this dysfunction. The context is in particular the increasing hostility aroused by nitrogen dioxide in recent years, while European industry excels in the field of diesel engines, it is also the priority given by THE American legislation to all gasoline. I therefore hope that the drafting of our report is not only technical, but more offensive, more political.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE).
text: – We are indeed halfway through the term of this committee of inquiry, and I think, ladies and gentlemen, and this has just been illustrated here, that we have a very good idea of what went wrong, how that cheating software scandal could have happened and, above all, what we need to do now to prevent this from happening again in the future. That the responsibility, Commissioner, is a shared responsibility, we heard that very clearly yesterday at the hearing with you, we knew that. No one, no body, not even this Parliament, had enough to notice that we had to pay much more attention to the tricks of the software in the diesel cars. In particular, the national authorities have failed in their audit work, despite what a few speakers said here a few minutes ago. They are, after all, responsible for the implementation of European legislation, which we have adopted with all 28 Member States. It is therefore a matter of - and Commissioner, for that, of course, we are counting on you to do so - to put that control under receivership and to apply it in a more strict way, so that a level playing field is finally created - and Mr Helmers had just forgotten - a level playing field in the European Union. That's the importance of that control. Europe has always had, and this is the case today, not only the best, but also the most environmentally friendly cars on the market. We have to keep it that way. We must remain at the forefront, including in clean technology. Today, there are already diesels on the market, including in Europe, which do respect the 80 milligram limit. This proves that our approach is good, that we are driving the car sector forward and that the car manufacturers know that they must indeed - to use that word - go into a higher gear. The car industry, or some of it, dear colleagues, we all know that, has deceived us all, deceived consumers. And it is now important - and we have to play an important role in this with our report and with our committee - to put pressure on them to ensure that that trust can come back quickly. This can only be done with ambition and with full transparency.   (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – In fact I welcome your speech and would like to underline the good methodology and transparency of the investigation by the committee of inquiry. At the same time, I have a question for you. How do you think that the committee of inquiry could help, as you mentioned, to restore consumer confidence and ensure that this situation will not happen again?

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. – Two things: First of all, by putting everything on the table, all the information. Yesterday, the Commissioner said of a number of documents which are supposedly secret or would not be tabled: 'I will come up with these documents'. Total transparency. And secondly, ladies and gentlemen, by ensuring that we can approve the legislative proposals, type-approval among other things, and the following proposals on emissions in real driving conditions, because we still need to take further steps, be able to approve them as soon as possible, hopefully in agreement with the Council, so that that can become legislation.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is difficult to legislate to make the driving of vehicles coincide by preserving the health of all, to enforce normal conditions and, therefore, to recognise that driving under normal conditions is done on the road, and not on rollers in a test laboratory, without a seat or heating or air conditioning! It took 10 years to arrive at the real-world tests, which will be implemented in stages and with a compliance factor of 2.5.  But it is even more complicated to enforce, control and punish non-compliance with European law. Today, the situation is incomprehensible to citizens who are obliged to respect this European legislation. Unfortunately, the chain of control and sanctions does not work when it comes to public health. The image of Europe and the European institutions that emerges from it is terrible and serves us all. Because I am deeply European and convinced that the Union must continue its political construction, I believe it is our responsibility to draw the consequences of the scandal that could have been avoided here even if all the stakeholders had enforced the law, nothing but the law, but the whole law.  It is now more than ever time to recall our positions and the raison d'être of this commission of inquiry: the defence of the public interest. The challenge is not to fire red balls at the industry, nor is it to cover actions that placed the economy above all values. The challenge is to restore consumer and citizen confidence. The challenge is to ensure cleaner mobility, while respecting public health and the environment, while sustaining jobs. The challenge is to promote sustainable development that benefits all.  That is what drives my mission as the shadow rapporteur of the EMIS Committee for the Group of Socialists and Democrats and that is what motivates my mandate as an MEP.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR).
text: – Mr President, it has been a year since we discovered that motorists around the world have been cheated by Volkswagen and, since then, the question has been: how did they do it without regulators noticing, not just in Europe but throughout the world? If a company wants to cheat, no system will be 100% secure. But the key is to make it as hard as possible to cheat, and we need to do that as soon as we can. We have new ‘real driving emissions’ (RDE) testing rules already in place, which is one key part of the answer, and we have new market surveillance proposals from the Commission, which are the second key part. We need to deal with this as soon as possible, even while the EMIS Committee is examining specific lessons with a view to reporting back to us next year. We have a type-approval system at national level with mutual recognition. It is the right system, but it needs national administrations to enforce it, as the Commissioner herself said last night. So let us be clear: every administration in the world was fooled by Volkswagen, not just those in Europe. We need a proper peer-to-peer review system for Member States and we need proper market surveillance both at national and EU level. We need a system that works and that we can deliver. We can deliver it to protect consumers and the environment, but we need to get on with it. There is no time to delay.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, most European countries are today faced with serious air quality problems, particularly in cities where there is a higher density of road traffic. It is also in urban centres that most European citizens live and work, which are thus exposed to the harmful consequences of air pollution, which poses a real threat to public health. According to data from this year's European Environment Agency, more than 70,000 people die prematurely in the European Union as a result of high levels of nitric oxide in the atmosphere. We also know that road traffic and in particular diesel engines are the predominant sources of these gases in urban areas. In the face of the difficulties of the municipalities in halting the problem of air quality, which we are witnessing in European policy? We are witnessing a European Commission which, at the very least, can be described as omitted, inoperative and dysfunctional. This appears in the eyes of the European citizen as a hostage to a so-like and illusory industrial competitiveness that is sought dishonestly and cheating by some major operators in the automotive industry. Undoubtedly, industrial competitiveness is an objective for which we must be hit. But is it undoubtedly this way that we will achieve it?  Let us instead invest in technological innovation, try to respond to the needs of citizens with a better quality of life in cities, invest in more sustainable and more efficient urban transport, invest in renewables and cleaner and cheaper electricity mobility, and look at what others, our competitors, are doing at the moment. It is shameful that we have not been able to detect and act on fuel emissions fraud and that others have done so for us. Let us also look at how the Americans have taken responsibility and taken steps to ensure the protection of the legitimate interests of consumers. It is important that the committee of inquiry is able to re-embody the truth about this whole process. The least that can be demanded by the European Commission is that it be diligent in its cooperation with Parliament in the discharge of the truth. It is above all important to know what will change to effectively ensure the monitoring and implementation of European legislation. We must put citizens first, but that is not what we saw during this process. This is not the Europe we want to build.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the famous series 'Sure, Minister' states that if you do not want the truth to come to the surface and everything is covered up, you will set up a committee of inquiry. I am very glad that the European Parliament has decided to make real use of the potential of the Committee of Inquiry. However, there is often punishment for good intentions, so we have to face an uncooperative Commission, the excuses of carmakers, the tossing of responsibility, the blaming of others, etc.  The EMIS Committee of Inquiry is trying to uncover what we all know for a long time, that the whole scandal was known for a long time, but it was covered up by all the insiders. However, we are encountering resistance from those who should be held accountable and their arrogance, which, however, makes us even more difficult to reveal the truth.  Thank you very much to all my colleagues for their cooperation and let me thank, above all, the Chair of the Committee of Inquiry, who, by her systematic ness, proves that it is possible that we will indeed come to a successful end.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, it was a year ago that the Volkswagen scandal broke. It quickly became the scandal of the global automotive industry. One year after the discovery of this massive pollution test fraud, nothing has been done except the creation of our commission of inquiry. No major measures have been taken by either the Commission or the Member States to enforce EU pollution standards, protect citizens' health and restore consumer confidence. For the past year, we have been letting the European consumer get ripped off while the Americans get reimbursed, we let mobile garbage cans pollute our roads. You are going to launch infringement measures against the states that have approved these vehicles, that is a first step. But what do you expect - when I look at the French government protecting Renault, one of the worst polluters in Europe - to ensure that there are no more diesel gates? Let us radically reform the registration system, finally create an independent European agency to certify vehicles and require automatic recall of vehicles if fraud is disputed. It is now your duty to act.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The committee has been running since March of this year, and we have heard technical experts there, we have heard representatives of NGOs, we have had representatives of the car industry there and also former Commissioners – and again my thanks to all those who have promised to come quite quickly. All but one of them worked out very well. Firstly, i believe that a clear distinction must be made between illegal defeat devices and increased emission levels of diesel cars in road operation. Illegal defeat devices are clearly, as they say, illegal. This must be punished, and this is also provided for in the legislation. One must also have doubts as to whether Volkswagen can be pilloried here alone. If I look, for example, at what the Italian company Fiat is producing in such a headline at the moment, it must be made clear once again that the authorities should be scrutinising this very, very strongly.  Secondly, with the RDE measurements that are about to come, illegal defeat devices are pointless. Unrealistic laboratory measurements that have nothing to do with reality will be a thing of the past. This is where the European level has delivered. We have taken the right path here, and Commissioner Tajani has played a corresponding role in this.  Thirdly, defeat devices due to component protection: only many experts knew that this was possible, but rather not to the general population. I think that the committee has also shown that the manufacturers have partly crossed the arc. However, as an engineer, I would also like to make it quite clear that we need these defeat options, which are legal, within a very narrow framework, because it must be possible to protect the technology at extremely high or low temperatures or under other conditions.  I would like to make a comment on the committee in general. I had the feeling that many members of the committee wanted to prove a conspiracy between the Commission and the car industry against the consumer and against environmental interests. I believe that the committee has already shown that this is not the case.

name: Massimo Paolucci (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the work of the Committee of Inquiry has made it clear that the Volkswagen scandal is just the tip of the iceberg. There is not only the fraudulent use of devices born to defend engines in particular conditions, there is more.  As early as 2007, but officially since 2011, it was known that cars marketed on the road had emissions 7-8 times higher than those tested in the laboratory during homologation. It is a serious scam against users and a blow to the air quality of our cities, an even more serious scam because there have long been technologies to reduce NOx emissions.  That is why it is essential to move forward with controls on real emissions by road, to radically change the type-approval standards, to go beyond controls entrusted only to individual nation states and to have clearer and more stringent rules for consumer protection.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The scandal that has given way to the establishment of this committee has severely edched the level of trust in both the European automotive industry and the control bodies, both national and EU. This is not only about violating the right of consumers to receive reliable information about the specifications of the products they buy, but also about the future of a sector that is very important for the European economy and labour market in many Member States, including my country.  Unfortunately, despite many hearings and expert reports, it is still difficult to say unequivocally whether the falsification of the results of emission measurements was indeed a deliberate and deliberate measure or, simply, the result of imperfect methods of testing new car models. I hope that the final stage of the EMIS Committee's work will provide a clear answer to the question of who bears the greatest responsibility and who should be punished, but will not lead to a permanent recession in the European automotive industry.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, it seems an over-prudence to delay further the submission of some political conclusion on the case of diesel engines. At this stage, we know that the existence of emission handling devices and the discrepancy between air pollution and that promised by the new engines was generally known, without anyone acting. In interrogations, car companies and the Commission babble contradictions and evasiveness, but they cannot deny that car manufacturers influenced the definition of new emissions targets and the technical standards that should implement them, orienting regulation to their own interests. This case is likely to be just the tip of the iceberg of how large oligopolies determine European regulations, how private benefits count more than people's lives. In the European Union there are hundreds of thousands of premature deaths a year from nitrogen oxides, so it is hard to understand so much stealth in this report.

name: Julia Reda (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, at half-time we have seen deficits with this committee’s foundation on which its work is supposed to stand. The Commission’s reaction to our request for documents has been unsatisfactory. Time has been wasted by both the Commission and by the Joint Research Centre. Adding insult to injury, we were given the most ridiculous explanations for their non—compliance, including ‘the document was too large’ and ‘we didn’t think the documents were relevant.’ Yesterday Commissioner Bieńkowska in turn expressed her dissatisfaction with Member States’ withholding information. Commissioner Bieńkowska, it is now your moment to excel. Give us your information, give it to us in full and give it to us now. The need to strengthen Parliament’s investigatory powers was also highlighted by a former Commissioner’s refusal to even appear before the committee. Let us therefore work to introduce the Verheugen clause to Rule 198, the right to summon a witness, plain and simple.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: – The EMIS Committee of Inquiry was set up mainly for two reasons. The first is to describe truthfully the reasons that led to the fact that European legislation could have been circumvented in the long term and grossly by large firms. The second reason is the subject of restoring the eerirant confidence of the European consumer. A thorough hearing of all actors should therefore make the rules in this area clearer, stricter and more reflect reality. In the process of drafting new legislation, it has to be said that we have also made progress. We agree with the Commission that emission control must take place not only under laboratory conditions, but especially in real traffic, and also on the fact that the rules must apply equally and everywhere to everyone within the common market. However, it must be said openly that not all Member States are cooperating in this area, which slows down and blocks the whole process. The case also has another dimension, which is not yet closed. Thousands of European consumers have fallen victim to misleading behaviour. In the same case, in the United States, the automaker will compensate the owners for several thousand dollars, but it still refuses such compensation to European customers. If we are to restore confidence in our citizens that the European Union stands by them and defends their rights, everything must be done to ensure that Europeans also receive fair and adequate compensation. Our intention and task is not to punish. The car industry is crucial for Europe and we want to support it, especially with regard to the introduction of new technologies and innovation. The European Union must create a stable environment for car companies. What we are asking of them and everyone is compliance with the agreed rules.

name: Ismail Ertug (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The last few weeks have shown impressively that this committee of inquiry is very, very necessary. The following conclusions can be drawn from the hearings so far: the European Commission answers our questions only evasively, in some cases not at all. The European Commission does not know or do not want to know its own legislation, nor does it know what powers it has, or it does not want to know what powers it has. What is particularly striking is how Member States implement or fail to implement legislation. I wonder: how can it be that, for example, in the dispute over a coolant in cars, the European Commission is immediately on hand to deal with infringement proceedings, while on such a large issue as the type-approval directive, it is letting 23 Member States get away unscathed? The Member States also have a crucial share of responsibility, but one thing is clear: that the European Commission is partly to blame for this, because it has not acted.

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteurs for this interim report. It does not tell us a great deal, but it does set out where we have been going with this, and, for me, there are clearly two strands. I came to this because of my rapporteurship on air quality, and my problems started when I was given a presentation from the Directorate-General for the Environment at the beginning of that process – that is about three years ago now – which clearly showed that they were very well aware of the disconnect between the actual standards and what they delivered on the road. I honestly can tell you that was the first time I was aware of it, and from that moment on I was determined that we should get to the bottom of why that should happen. Now, in this particular inquiry, with these two strands, political and technical, my concern is that we make sure that, at the end of this, we know what the political lessons were; we understand clearly why the parts of the Commission that should have been working together, to make this work for citizens and their health, were not doing so quickly enough and not taking their responsibility seriously enough; and that we have in place a system that will ensure this never happens again.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Mr President, during the last year we have learnt a lot not about Volkswagen, but mostly about the enforcement of EU regulation, about how division of responsibility between the Union and the State works, and about the behaviour or ethics of some of the firms. It was very sad to learn all this, and frustrating, but we have got a chance to change things for the better. I am not afraid that industry cannot do it or that it is too expensive: industry just needs to have very clear and simple rules to follow.  I do not believe that blaming and shaming should be a key part of the committee work. We should be focused on the future: that is the most important thing. We should start with understanding the basic facts and I will try to describe some of them. Firstly, I believe that only cars complying with the rules should be allowed onto the market. That is what we must do: we have proper rules and these are the only way to avoid unnecessary health risks. We know that, by using existing technologies, even current diesel cars can be made clean. What will happen in the future is hard to tell because technology is evolving so quickly. We were late in introducing better laboratory testing. We are now on track. We must make sure that any altering of vehicles for testing will be prohibited. Real driving tests and random sampling should be a very important component of a future better system and should be supported alongside independent testing. I believe that this general failure on our part should be turned into victory, namely into a new system that will be better for us all and that we must bring about.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: Mr President! The scandal of cheating software in millions of cars on the European market is not just about cheating. The scandal is about human life. Because of the cheating, there have been much greater quantities of the harmful NOX gases in the air we breathe. In the EU, 72 000 people die prematurely a year because of NOX, about the same as dying in road accidents. That is at the heart of the scandal: people are dying and the environment is suffering. In the committee of inquiry, we are in the process of finding out why this scandal was not discovered before. For the time being, everything indicates a system error. No one apparently knew anything, and everyone abdicates responsibility – from the European Commission to the Member States. The EU's way of approving and controlling cars has failed. We need a new way to do it. Our control systems need to be much more suspicious. When something looks strange, it has to be fully investigated and we need to have a clear division of responsibilities. Let us learn from this scandal, let us build a new system in which we take into account, first and foremost, people and the environment.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the ongoing work of the Committee of Inquiry on emissions measurement gives a truly complete picture of the technical systems of internal combustion engines, especially diesel engines. We have learned a huge amount of information, not only about the technical aspects, but also about the processes in the preparation and approval of the necessary legislation. For me personally, it is really instructive how strong political pressure to reduce CO2 emissions, which is on the edge of technical possibilities, leads to huge problems. It pushes manufacturers to unacceptable practices to fraud, as with VW, while also putting official oversight in difficult situations.  I believe that the result of the work of the Committee of Inquiry will be not only a description of what actually happened with producers or in the preparation of legislation, but above all how to approach possible regulations in the future. The legislative regulatory measures adopted must ensure technically achievable control conditions and the same procedures for vehicle approval in each EU country.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, on 13 July we unanimously adopted the preliminary report, thus fulfilling the mandate given to us following the emergence of the so-called 'Dieselgate' in the United States, which has affected millions of vehicles worldwide. Following the scandal, the members who were assigned to parliament's committee of inquiry were given a mandate to fulfil. And that is why today we want this report to be adopted, the primary request of which is to allow the committee of inquiry to get to the bottom of the issue. We were tasked with bringing light to a case that is not easy to approach. Believe me, the Members of this House who are members of both the Committees on the Environment and Industry know that we must fight between interests that are difficult to fit in. But we also know that in order to achieve the re-industrialisation of Europe we will need to find a European strategy that preserves the environment and public health while still betting on the productive economy, research, innovation and industry. We were tasked with shedding light in a case where the haze of the rules promoted during Commissioner Verheugen's tenure has been partly the cause of the facts that have led us to where we are today; a haze which even made it difficult to carry out our task after its initial refusal to appear before the Commission and the lack of clarity of its subsequent statement. We must, indeed, look to the future, be transparent, act with light and stenographers. And so, with this report we place the European Commission, the Member States and all the competent authorities and actors involved to cooperate and respect the principle of fair cooperation with the committee of inquiry, so that we can improve the work done so far and prevent the trap from being found once again, where the law is made. That is why, because our priority is the health of our citizens, their jobs and their well-being, we want to reach the end of the research and that it serves to clarify responsibilities and guide a sector that envisages the creation of some 880,000 jobs in Europe until 2025.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Għandna eluf ta' äittadini Ewropej, eluf ta' tfal li ta' kull sena qegħdin jispièèaw jimirdu serjament in ġieli agħar minn hekk. U l-kawża ta' dan hi t-tniġġis fl-ibliet tagħna. name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: – The Committee of Inquiry, Chairman, is united halfway through the driving test: the investigation is moving in the right direction and more information needs to be provided more quickly from all those involved. This unity in the backbench could disappear if conclusions are to be drawn and concrete measures are to be taken. To name a few hot spots: How should the interconnectedness between the government and the car industry be addressed? What about the thousands of lobbyists? And how do we really get clean air? I think, Mr President, that there is only one solution: to make zero-emission cars as quickly as possible. Clean diesel cars don't exist. Clean petrol cars don't exist either. Not with and not without cheating software. Driving on electricity and hydrogen, there's a future in it. Let the European Union focus all its energy on this. Plenty of work for the zero-emission car.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all let me express my thanks to our rapporteur for the work he has done on the report. It is a good summary of our six months’ work in the EMIS Committee of Inquiry. Nevertheless, our mandate has not been fulfilled yet. There is still much work to be done. There are a lot of doubts and there are also many unanswered questions. We are all in this House looking forward to the final conclusions and results. This cannot be done without close and loyal cooperation with the Commission. During the meetings many of us blamed the Commission for the failure to reform the emission control testing system and the type-approval procedure, but this is not the full picture. Not only was the Commission late with taking proper actions, but also Parliament lost time to finalise its first report on the real driving emission legislation. Member States did not take effective action to enforce the explicit ban on defeat devices. The final outcome was that customers lost trust in the car manufacturer and consumers suffered from increased air pollution. We expect the Commission to make sure the Volkswagen Group compensates all customers affected by its illegal practices in the EU, and we expect Member States to swiftly penalise all such practices.  Now we should focus on the legislative work and finalise the third and fourth real driving emissions packages. We have half a year to investigate all failures and submit the final report, which will serve to improve the cars emission framework. Now it is time to make sure that such maladministration will never happen again. We, as the European Parliament, are here to protect European citizens and consumers in the first place from being cheated.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, it is in the interests of Europeans, their industry, their knowledge centres and their citizens that the European Union should take a leading role in the transition to smart mobility.  Smart mobility saves lives, improves quality of life and opens up new competitiveness prospects. In this area, EMIS has already had a very positive impact.  After it, the European institutions and the Member States will have to leave their comfort zone, have to take on responsibilities for effective oversight, have to disclose transparent and credible information to consumers and have to take advantage of existing knowledge, in particular in the Joint Research Centre. After that too, the emission measurement methodologies and technologies associated with the automotive sector in the European Union and beyond will no longer be the same.  In the face of evidence of fraudulent manipulation, the authorities bet on a technological leap. Commissioner, this is important, but it is not enough. We need to eradicate the culture that has enabled the potential fraud that is being assessed – that is the path that this progress report reflects and which the committee of inquiry continues to go solidly.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I want, from the very beginning, to appreciate the work of the Commission, so, half a term, but I want to point out a few things. There has been a lot of appreciation or comparison between the United States and Europe. I am the shadow rapporteur from my group on the approval report. Commissioner, I do not think we need to rush this Dalton report on type-approval, as long as we do not have the Commission's result. What's the point of having a Commission working on the investigation if we speed up this report? That's a problem. The second problem: I do not believe that the United States is better than Europe, that is not the problem. There is extremely easy regulation there, but there is voluntary compliance and I believe that we cannot turn the Commission into the gendarme of Europe, but national authorities must advocate for compliance with simple rules that also protect the population, but not kill industry in favour of non-European industrialists. I come from the industry, I know how hard it is when we over-regulate for the guilty and kill the good ones. I think it is important to pursue compliance with the laws and not to over-regulate. And I don't agree that only the name Volkswagen should appear in the report, because there are other companies that are wrong in this area, and we need to talk about everyone.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE).
text: – The Committee of Inquiry on emission measurement in the automotive sector, together with the European Commission, is carrying out an important task in this investigation. It is more than obvious that we have poor market control over what is happening in the automotive sector in the European Union. The scandal that has been uncovered in Volkswagen is not isolated, and we find this after defeat devices have been officially banned in the European Union for 18 years. Diesel vehicles with inadequate defeat devices are still driving on our roads, thus polluting our atmosphere.  Reducing CO2 emissions is an important task for all of us, so this kind of scandal needs to be reacted more decisively, including by detecting and properly sanctioning those responsible.  The European regulation is too vague in this area, as, despite the legal ban on the use of defeat devices, it leaves too many possibilities for interpretation as to the use of these devices, and it is therefore necessary to regulate this as soon as possible. It is also important that, in addition to the European Commission and the Committee of Inquiry, member states are involved in this investigation. Last but not least, it is about consumer confidence in European products.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the Folkswagen scandal has shown that the famous competitiveness of German companies is almost exclusively due to kickbacks and the illegal and dirty practices they use to deceive the supervisory authorities and consumers. In a question I tabled on 23 September 2015, I asked for the investigation carried out in the USA which revealed the Folkswagen scandal to be extended to Europe and to cover other companies in the sector. As Commissioner Bieńkowska points out in her reply, investigations carried out in several other Member States have shown that there have been misdeeds and methods of circumvention of results in other manufacturers. The European Union should therefore take immediate steps to tighten controls on cars of all companies throughout Europe and impose heavy penalties on those who break the law. I hope that the newly created Committee of the European Parliament will shed a lot of light on the illegal practices of the car industry as soon as possible, and that it will strictly respect the timetable that has been set. On March 2, 2017, citizens need to know!

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, at this point we can say that we are already facing a great collective failure. Failure on the part of those who tried to deceive citizens, the Commission and the Member States with cheating mechanisms, because fraud has been discovered; failure of the Commission, because, knowing, as one Commissioner said, that the rules were flexible and interpreted by industry, did not prompt new rules, new regulation, in time to prevent these things from happening again; and, of course, failure of the Member States, because national authorities have a duty to control and a duty to investigate so that such situations, which are environmentally friendly, that undermine the health of citizens, do not occur. Of course we have to take note so that in the future, which is the most important thing, these things will not happen again. We're talking about our health. We are talking, in short, about the environment, but we are also talking about industry, which creates jobs and, of course, this kind of thing, this kind of fraud, does not help the industry either, because it is under suspicion.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Clearly, the committee has not revealed a number of things, but it has also produced other findings which I think are useful and also good. So one thing, for example – I will summarize it in my words: VW could obviously only achieve the 80 milligrams of NOX registered in California in the USA with diesel cars with fraudulent software. Fraud is, of course, a criminal offence and to be condemned.
