In Europe, the limit value is much higher and, above all, it is quite obvious – known to everyone or to anyone who wanted to know – a high tolerance factor. That is, 600 milligrams came out instead of 180 milligrams, more than three times as much.  That is why it seems that the legal situation for car owners in Europe is different from that in the United States. We must learn from this that it is important that we naturally try to reduce emissions, that is, as far as greenhouse gas CO2 is concerned now, but also, for example, to ensure clean air and fewer pollutants. We must have the framework conditions that allow industry to produce realistic things and which enable consumers to have confidence in, so to speak, healthy vehicles. And we must also monitor ambitiously and pay attention to implementation, and as soon as possible – including real driving emissions.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have repeatedly highlighted the European Union's leading role in the fight against environmental pollution.  However, such leadership entails obligations. The Committee of Inquiry into Dieselgate, which this Parliament has set up, must send out a strong signal, of great rigour and third-partyness, in conducting the investigation, so that the world does not say that Europe is the first to violate those rules. A firm position must be taken, having the courage to denounce, if necessary, any omissions in the adoption of appropriate measures to make effective the application of the explicit ban on defeat devices. The credibility of the European Union also depends very much on this investigation.

name: Werner Kuhn (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Before we have zero-emission vehicles on our roads – whether they are electrically powered or hydrogen combustion engines – we need to look at the current situation and try to find technical solutions so that these limit values can be met as far as NOx is concerned with CO2. That is why it is necessary that, in the case of type approval, type approval, we pay particular attention to ensuring that the exhaust gas cleaning systems in accordance with Euronorm 6 are also technically installed. And it is precisely here that it is necessary to comply with 80 milligrams per kilometre of NOx here in Germany under laboratory conditions, and it is necessary to react to the American market as well. But it has 70 milligrams per mile; that's 44 milligrams per kilometer. This can only be done by using such AdBlue or Blue Motion technology, aqueous urea, so to speak, in an exhaust gas purification system that binds these nitrosen gases, this NOx, and converts them into molecular nitrogen, which is completely harmless to humans and water. This is the issue we will deal with at type approval, so that such things can no longer happen. Market surveillance must be carried out, and this market surveillance must also test the newly registered vehicles on a random basis, even in the case of real driving emissions. It is clear, of course, that it makes a huge difference in terms of exhaust emissions, whether you are using fuel at 130 kilometres per hour or 170 kilometres per hour or 200 kilometres per hour. This must be compensated with new technologies. Only in this way will we actually achieve this objective. It is stipulated that by 2017 or 2019, I believe 168 milligrams of NOx may be emitted under real driving emission conditions and by 2021 only 129 milligrams. That must be our aim. Otherwise, we will actually create a climate in our inner cities that is absolutely incompatible and harmful to health.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to thank all the honourable Members for this exchange of views and this honest debate. There is no doubt for me that we have a common objective: that we have to uncover fully the defeat devices scandal, that we have to draw the best appropriate conclusions from it, and that we have to move forward. Our guiding principles, for all of us, must be truth and transparency. Again, let me underline that I will do all that is necessary, and use the Commission’s mandate and power as a regulator and as a guardian of the Treaty, to restore confidence in the law and trust in the industry. However, let me be honest about it: I do not really want to play the blame game that we are seeing now. I am the last person to do this but I have to be very vocal and say loudly that I cannot, with 100% confidence, blame other car manufacturers, because I do not have the full evidence. I am sending several letters to the Member States, and I will continue to push them, as I am doing now, but I do not have any legal power in this respect. Some of you mentioned EU recalls, and I would very much like to go ahead with EU recalls, but I do not have any legal basis right now on which to do so. I agree it is very odd that in some Member States we are seeing mandatory recalls, in some voluntary recalls, and in some nothing. This is not appropriate and it should not go on like this. However, I believe the Member States have really started to understand that we have to break with some past practices: that they have to be transparent, and give us all the relevant information, the technical and other information, that we need; and that it is their commitment to establishing real market surveillance that will be key to future success. I need the commitment from the Member States – as, of course, I need it from you – so that we will be able to put in place a modern, efficient coherent framework for approving cars, and I want to be very clear about it. I am not doing this against the industry, quite the contrary. I am the Commissioner responsible for industry and I will do all that it takes for the car industry to flourish, to be competitive and to be respected. However, in the interests of the industry today – and I hope that the industry also starts to understand it – I need to be tough, we need to be tough, and we need to be demanding on the industrial side. I want to use this current crisis – and I hope this is a common goal – to put better legislation in place, to have more efficient market surveillance and structures and to move industry into a really new dimension of performance, mobility and automation. I am certain that, with your support and engagement, together, and definitely not blaming each other because that leads us nowhere, we will be able to achieve those objectives. The time is right for this. This is the momentum that we have to use for the future of our automotive industry.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank all colleagues for their contributions and thank and reiterate my thanks to Mr Gerbrandy for the great work we are doing, I believe, together, and which I hope to continue in the second part of this report. Some colleagues have regretted the lack of content, including the lack of ambition of this report, but I must remind you that we agreed that this was an interim report and that we decided that it was an eminently technical report. Mr. Dance said we don't have to fight each other. I agree. Citizens do not expect us to fight without getting anything in return, but quite the opposite. Together, we need to get to know the truth and, more importantly, together we have to make proposals to prevent this from happening again in the future. And we cannot allow, ladies and gentlemen, that this is a report against industry, a report against employment, but quite the opposite. It has to become an environmental report, a report in favour of the automotive industry and a report for employment.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I believe that this was a very encouraging debate, a debate that was obviously not about the interim report, because that was limited to procedures, but much more about the current state of the investigation of our inquiry committee. Why did I believe that it was so encouraging? Because I noticed a very broadly shared common understanding of the problem that did not necessarily already reach commonly shared conclusions, but will be the challenge for my dear colleague, Pablo Zalba, and myself to get Parliament behind shared conclusions in the end. But I do believe that we are on the right track. We should not forget that we are only half-way through our investigation. There is still a lot to be investigated and a lot of evidence to be found. I would like to highlight two elements. I think it was Seb Dance who very eloquently talked about the myriad of responsibilities. He said – and many others did as well – that there seems to be nobody really responsible in the end – not the Commission, not a Member State, not national authorities, etc. That might be the core of the problem that we are facing here. I am sure that, when we dig much deeper into that, we can also draw conclusions for the future, not only reflecting the car industry, but other policy fields as well.  Finally, I think it was my colleague Ivo Belet who said that, if we look at responsibilities, a lot has to do with the inability of the Member States to take their responsibility. I believe that it is a very important thing that came today. Many talked about naming and shaming, whether to do so or not. I believe that in politics in a well-functioning democracy political accountability is crucial, and that might mean naming and shaming if that is necessary. I am not afraid of it and I am not looking for it, but it is part of a strong democracy. That is what we are still building together in Europe, so let us continue with that.

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you to all the speakers, to the rapporteurs and to the Commissioner for this in-depth debate. The vote on this report will take place today. (The sitting was suspended at 12.20 p.m. and resumed at 12.30 p.m.)

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. I welcome the balanced, fact-based report of the EMIS Panel, which does not take hasty decisions but makes its final position on further fact-finding. We agree that it is important to review and improve the type-approval process. I believe that the European car industry must come out stronger and more united from the whole emissions scandal. The situation that has arisen should be used to prepare new strategies and development plans for the period ahead, with particular emphasis on new innovative technologies. After all, it has now become clear that the car industry is facing major and profound changes. This is a very complex process in which account must be taken of the fact that, at the moment, in the automotive industry, technologies based on conventional fuels and new alternative solutions will continue to move on parallel lines for many years to come. Phasing in should help the European car industry to maintain its place as a cornerstone of the European economy, while at the same time increasing its competitiveness and future capacity.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: writing – The emissions scandal has brought about the disclosure of several global car manufacturers about their deliberate misrepresentation of the emission data of passenger and commercial vehicles. It has also caused a fall in consumer confidence. The European Parliament has therefore set up a committee of inquiry in an attempt to restore it. It deals with the measurement of emissions in the automotive industry and compliance with the rules in force, whether by the European Commission or by the competent authorities within the Member States. The Committee of Inquiry is currently collecting and analysing information concerning the use of defeat mechanisms in the measurement of emissions by individual carmakers. This should continue during the autumn of this year. In particular, the follow-up report and the resulting recommendations will be important. Their observance should help to ensure that similar situations do not occur on such a large scale in the future. The functioning of the automotive industry is a significant factor in economic growth and employment. The emissions case has shown the importance of greening the whole sector. There is also a need to focus on limiting the use of heavy metals and other pollutants in individual components and components in cars. Member States have already committed themselves to this in 2003. Nevertheless, to this day, there are a number of exceptions. However, many of them are no longer needed thanks to modern materials and progress. This applies, for example, to the use of lead in car batteries. Already today there are proven technologies that can fully replace classic lead-acid batteries.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I just wonder if it is in order to congratulate the former president of the Commission, Mr Barroso, on his appointment with Goldman Sachs. And also to express my concern that his pension as a former president of the Commission seemingly is not enough. Is that in order Mr President?

name: Der Präsident. –
text: On the first part of your question, I did not ask myself the question. And the second part of your question: there are rules for this. We will now proceed to the vote.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – Allow me to highlight two important facts before voting on today's candidates for eca members. Firstly, Article 286 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union provides that the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, is to adopt a list of members for the European Court of Auditors drawn up in accordance with the proposals made by the Member States. Of course, this means strictly formally that Parliament should only have a consultative role, but that does not mean that the Council should also respect and respect the will of the European Parliament. I therefore think, as has happened in some previous cases, that this time and in the future the Council sees and takes seriously the Position of the European Parliament in these candidacies, otherwise I do not know why we are implementing this whole procedure if, in the end, the Council has a decisive say. And I think for good cooperation in the future, that's important information. Secondly, the fact that, on today's list of candidates for new members of the European Court of Auditors, there are once again only male candidates on today's list of candidates for new members of the European Court of Auditors. And Parliament has long pointed out the importance of gender balance. Parliament's report on the role of the European Court of Auditors in the future states that Parliament will take the issue of gender balance among the Members of the Court of Auditors very seriously. And for information only: at present, only four members of the European Court of Justice represent only four members out of a total of 28 members. And if the pace continues as it seems, the picture will be even more defeatless. I think, however, in comparison, I would add that it is this Parliament that made it clear to the then candidate Juncker that the number of Commissioners in the current Commission should not be lower than the number of Commissioners of the previous College. It is time to enforce the same standards in all European institutions, and I hope that this will be taken seriously in advance.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the You have just made a point in the middle of the vote, and I would ask you what point of the Rules of Procedure you are referring to. You said that you have problems in determining the majority ratios because the whip does not indicate to the S&D Group. Is the whip indicating relevant to you or the parties taking part in the vote?

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mrs Storch, I would like to thank Mrs Storch for her I didn't say I was in trouble. I just said that I'm doing a lot easier. Of course, I pay close attention to every single member, including you.

name: Mercedes Bresso
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the oral amendment introduces support for the coordination of alpine rescue services.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: author. – Mr President, I would like to move the oral amendment as tabled. You can find it at the end of your voting list.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: author. – Mr President, again I would like to move the oral amendment as tabled. You can find it at the end of your voting list. If you want me to read it, I can read it. It is long.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: author. – Mr President, the oral amendment covers here the split vote with the addition of the word ‘particularly’. And then you can find the entire amendment at the end of your voting list. But, if you want, I can read it all.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: author. – I think you know what I am going to say. (Laughter) I would like to move the oral amendment as tabled. You can find it at the end of your voting list. (Applause and laughter)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: You know that the President has excluded Mr Korwin-Mikke from the sitting. He has, of course, the right to vote. That is what he did today. He also has the right to give explanations of vote. That is why I am now giving him the floor, in derogation from the order originally envisaged, so that he can give his explanation of vote immediately and then leave the Chamber.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I wanted to make it clear that any progress in science and technology has been made as a result of free competition, free research without coordination by governments, without doing what we are doing here. The European Union's work towards the coordination of research is clearly hampering research, hampering progress, which is why I voted against this report.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, Mr Korwin-Mikke. I would now ask you to leave the Chamber. His explanation of vote concerned the report on cohesion policy. We are now returning to the normal order.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this report because it is a comprehensive and convincing text, and I believe that assessing the implementation of research and innovation strategies is very important in order to guide current European programming.  Unfortunately, there are many states – including Italy – that are still lagging behind public investment in innovation and technological research, and it is a gap that needs to be remedied as soon as possible for the benefit of the entire economy, especially at a time when innovation is a good response to the crisis.  RIS is also essential for the very implementation of cohesion policy. Only innovative solutions can and should be used, for example, to increase the administrative capacity of local authorities. This is also demanded by small and medium-sized enterprises, which are forced to confront systems that are still archaic and complex.  I support an evaluation and review in 2017 of what has been done to date, to catch up and meet commitments.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, what is the purpose of cohesion payments? It seems to me there isn’t really a moral case for them. There are parts of the world that are genuinely needy. There are many more deserving recipients of our aid than these territories within the European Union. If we have money to give away as development money, it should be targeted to Africa, Asia, and places where it will be useful. Or is it, then, that it is raising the standard of living in the recipient countries? Well if that worked, then Greece would be the wealthiest country in the European Union, having been the largest per capita recipient since 1981 of cohesion and structural funds.  The reality is, of course, this money goes to purchasing the loyalty of interest groups within the recipient countries, and this is relevant because as the UK negotiates its disengagement there is going to be a question of what we continue to pay into and what we do not. Obviously, if we’re going to continue to be part of any programmes or common structures, of course we are going pay our share of those. You will not find anyone arguing about that. But the idea of paying simply because somebody has a medium-level GDP? Not going to happen.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, technology and innovation are the strengths of Europe and of progress in any field. It depends, however, on how we use them. There are investments from the European Development Fund precisely to make strategies that lead to smart innovations and specialisations. We don't have to invest in anything, anyway, we have to see what the result is. And the result has to be a smart specialization. Since 2014, virtually every region in the European Union has a smart development and innovation strategy, but in reality not all regions are putting them into practice and using them. There is a big difference between regions. Where such smart development strategies are not in practice, money should not be invested, because it will be wasted and lost. As such, what I support is to invest only where regions and countries have done their job and adopted such strategies.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report because, of course, cohesion policy is a subject that moves Europe, and I think that we should not stay behind. In this sense, it is important that we add even more intelligent specialisation, more science, to cohesion policy, this smart specialisation should be part of cohesion policy. Multi-level governance should be expanded and its capacities increased. It should also be subject to a participatory approach in cohesion policy for regional decision-making. I supported this report, we discussed it in the Committee on Regional Development and I think it is a good basis for further work on smart specialisation.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I too supported this proposal sharing the rapporteur's belief that RIS 3 strategies play an instrumental role in tackling the innovation gap that Europe and its Member States often face. And partly in reply to Mr Hannan’s question, there is no doubt that continued improvements and advances in the field of both regional and national legislation provide the key to the European Union’s future in this domain. This report outlines the ways and means by which such deliberate evaluation, regulation and moderation would occur. From an Irish perspective I can appreciative the regional focus that RIS 3 may take incorporating regional and local authorities, thus encouraging multi-level involvement. Such efforts are essential in promoting knowledge-based growth not only in well-developed areas, but also in less well-developed regions. We find ourselves at a pivotal stage where the evaluation of existing policies, as well as the coordination of future ones, may be facilitated.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Smart Specialisation Strategy (RIS3) includes multiple policies that touch on different areas such as entrepreneurship, education and innovation and is therefore a key element in the allocation of EU funds to Member States and regions. Given the key role that SMEs and start-ups play in regional development, the importance of business support systems and the need to adopt reliable systems to monitor efficiency at all levels of governance, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We voted against this report because, as usual, it was filled with buzzwords and phrases that sound impressive but which will do nothing to create growth and jobs. The EU’s obsessive interference and over-regulation damage both jobs and growth, and we fail to see how buzzwords and corporate-speak will change that.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this own initiative report, which covers the innovation objective of the Europe 2020 Strategy. Each Member State has adopted its own national targets in each of these areas (employment, innovation, education, social inclusion and climate/energy). National and regional authorities across Europe will design smart specialisation strategies in entrepreneurial discovery process, so that the European Structural Investment Funds (ESIF) can be used more efficiently and synergies between different EU, national and regional policies, as well as public and private investments can be increased. There are some good points in the report, including a broad view of innovation, support for technological as well as practice-based and social innovation, and a monitoring and evaluation system. It also provides investment choices for regions with a limited number of priorities, particularly knowledge-based investments and/or clusters. However, the report focuses very heavily on using cohesion policies to meet the Europe 2020 objectives, places a strong emphasis on public-private funding and financial mechanisms, and identifies competitiveness is the main overarching goal of the innovation strategy. For these reasons I could not support the report entirely, so abstained.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. Considering that innovation is an ever-evolving field, research and innovation strategies for smart specialization should be constantly reviewed.  To this end, a post-2017 review of strategies seems mandatory if these cohesion policies are to be more effective, including taking into account lessons learned from the early years of their implementation.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the Report on Cohesion policy and Research and Innovation Strategies for Smart Specialisation (RIS3). Research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation are an ex-ante conditionality for the allocation of the European Structural and Investment (ESI) funds. Smart specialisation combines and brings together different policies, including those for entrepreneurship, education and innovation, in order for regions to identify and select priority areas for their development and related investments by focusing on their strengths and comparative advantages and contributes to the achievement of the Europe 2020 objectives. The S3 platform, located at the JRC in Seville, plays a key role in advising regions and setting benchmarks on their innovation strategies, helping lagging regions and enhancing multi-level governance and synergies between regions, by providing information, methodologies, expertise and advice to national and regional policymakers. The report stresses that there is a still limited role for civil society, which must be more actively involved, a lack of interregional cooperation and of synergies across ESI funds and other EU funds. RIS3 strategies have to be well implemented and improved in order to tackle the innovation gap and boost jobs in Europe.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation, because at a time of economic recession and budgetary constraints with global competition constantly intensifying, the EU's continued improvement in innovation is of major importance.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. While this report is about innovation and research, it could be expected to criticise austerity policies on public and private budgets that support these areas. According to the rapporteur, the mode of governance of the strategy must be multi-level and compatible with the Europe 2020 strategy. Member States must thereby stand back from the European Commission, which is leading the strategy.  In fact, the European Union is using the SRI-SI strategy to strengthen direct relations between the European Commission and the regions that have become the management authority of the ERDF, as well as trans-European cooperation at the expense of cooperation between nation states.  It should also be noted that the SRI-SI strategy promotes thematic concentration, which has the effect of relying exclusively on large clusters or research clusters without supporting small structures and innovation clusters. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of transparency and democracy I voted against this report. This report has been prepared by the Committee on Regional Development and therefore contains many EU buzzwords but ultimately delivers little.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because the SRI-SI increases the added value, impact and visibility of European funding. It means a real return on investment at a time when public budgets and resources are being put to the test.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for the Smart Specialisation (RIS3) initiative. RIS3 strategies are an important tool to address the innovation gap in Europe, boost jobs and growth.  I agree that the authorities should pay particular attention to monitoring and reviewing strategies in order to achieve high results and to maximise interregional cooperation in the development of large-scale projects that bring added value to the economy.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is about cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation. Similar innovation strategies have already been developed. The present one differs from its predecessors in that it involves local audiences and resources in strategy building in a wide range of ways, and on the other hand shifts the emphasis from technological R&D to embrace the whole process of innovation, thirdly, it would not only copy best practices, but would also build on economic competitive advantage and future potential, not only in terms of the areas' specific strengths and values. The report does not set specific targets, only general objectives, which can always be said. It is similar to the former KGST materials, where efficiency and cooperation have always had to be increased. After all, its main point is to invite dg regions to produce a short policy document on past experience with the strategy and to disse so broadly. I considered this to be supportive.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this report because as usual, it was filled with buzz words and phrases that sound impressive but which will do nothing to create growth and jobs. The EU’s obsessive interference and over regulation damages both jobs and growth and we fail to see how buzz words and corporate speak will change that.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. In this text, there is no provision to support the principle of labelling (innovative companies) or to address the thorny problem of patents and industrial espionage, which are nevertheless major issues for the future of the economies of our Member States. It should also be noted that the SRI-SI strategy promotes thematic concentration, which has the effect of relying exclusively on large "clusters" or research centres without supporting small structures and innovation clusters.  More generally, the SRI-SI strategy is being used to strengthen direct relations between the European Commission and the regions that have become the management authorities of the ERDF, as well as trans-European cooperation, to the detriment of cooperation between nation states.  I therefore objected to this text.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In view of the challenges faced by many regions of Europe in the context of a globalisation that exacerbates international competition and carries with it an unsustainable batch of closures and relocations, I voted in favour of this initiative report, which notably supports smart specialisation strategies (SRI-SI) but also other good practices such as the promotion of clusters or better synergies between funds and the tools available. As ESI funds are the main instrument of the EU's investment policy with a budget of EUR 454 billion for the period 2014-2020, it is indeed essential that we ensure that the share of these allocated to cohesion policy is used as intelligently and as specifically as possible.  It seems crucial to enable the regions to specialize in sectors of the future and high growth that best suit them in terms of their specific assets, their capabilities but also the skills present in their territories, thus allowing to recreate a sustainable economic fabric and above all the direct and indirect employment they so desperately need.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 Research and innovation strategies for smart specialization represent an essential tool for innovation as well as to boost growth and employment in Europe. I found this report very balanced, and stresses the necessary simplification and coordination of the programmes put in place, which is important for their proper implementation.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Valcárcel Siso report on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation. This is an important text that stresses the need to step up efforts to create smart, sustainable and inclusive economic growth. This is a forced choice, especially at a time when Europe still seems to be suffering from the effects of the global economic crisis. The report reaffirms the central role of RIS3 in achieving the Europe 2020 objectives, without forgetting to highlight those aspects that should be considered of particular importance, I am thinking first of all of the correct analysis of the priorities, strengths and potential of the different regions, but also of the use of appropriate methodologies involving the development of periodic quantitative and qualitative monitoring. The development of participatory processes and the creation of synergies between public and private actors is another crucial point that is closely linked to the issue of multi-level governance. A serious bottom-up approach must be relaunched as soon as possible in order to foster the creation of new synergies and innovation-based growth.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report which supports cohesion policies and research and innovation strategies for smart specialization (RIS3). RIS3 contributes to the strategic programming of the Cohesion Funds and can play a key role in meeting the Europe 2020 targets, in the pursuit of balanced and sustainable development and in the creation of quality jobs. It also proposes support for multi-level governance and greater participation at all levels in aid programmes, as well as the creation of positive synergies in the different regions to determine their strengths. Although the report contains many 'wind odes' I am in favour of technological and social innovation, the evaluation of the aid system, the strengthening of the strengths of each region and SMEs, in order to achieve more sustainable development.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report because I believe that synergies between homogeneous areas in knowledge, productive fabric and specialization have proven to be more effective in stimulating and supporting innovation. The areas of development associated with cross-border cooperation, for example, demonstrate this reality and the results that regions, such as the Basque Country that have opted for this model, demonstrate that this way of organizing support for innovation is more effective.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which purports to provide a favourable framework for research and innovation without really addressing the real problems that are holding back the growth of this sector. In line with the Juncker plan, the 'smart' specialisation prepared by Brussels should supposedly boost the competitiveness of the 'European economy', in particular by the use and reframing of part of the ERDF. In addition to the duplication of national research policies and state-region plan contracts, it mostly misses the strategic issues for this sector: nothing about the patent problem or the problems of industrial espionage. Moreover, the remedy is prescribed by ignoring the cause of the evil since no mention is made of the disastrous consequences of the austerity policies imposed by Brussels on the research and innovation sector, a strategy which will only favour the major research centres at the expense of small structures, and which has the sole aim of consolidating the European Commission's grip on the regions at the expense of major national strategies.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation is well thought out and I support it, which is why I wanted to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The goal of RIS3 strategies is to drive intelligent, sustainable and knowledge-based inclusive growth capable of generating quality jobs in all regions, not just developed areas. These strategies contribute to the thematic concentration and strategic programming of the European Structural and Investment Funds (EIE Funds) and lead to greater focus on results on the ground. Two years after the start of its implementation, this report focuses on the main areas of ris3 improvement. In particular, it underlines the need to promote coordinated and complementary use of the EIE Funds with the Horizon 2020 programme and the European Fund for Strategic Investments to drive innovation at regional, national and Union level, increasing the attractiveness of investments in research and innovation in order to attract private capital as a complement to public funding , for which local and regional authorities are asked to make the most of the possibilities for combining these instruments. It also stresses the need to improve coordination between all levels of governance and to give civil society a more active role. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has given Parliament its position on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for the Smart Specialisation Initiative. Strengthening research, development and innovation is one of the investment priorities under the provisions of the European Regional Development Fund 2014-2020. However, support for innovation varies greatly from one EU country to another, particularly when it comes to the use of knowledge and technology in the field of innovation. During this programming period, Member States are obliged for the first time to develop national and regional smart specialisation strategies, involving national and regional managing authorities and higher education institutions, industry and social partners in the entrepreneurship process. In this report, Parliament therefore stresses that the aim of these strategies is to ensure knowledge-based sustainable growth, sustainable development and high-quality jobs in all regions, not only in developed areas, but also in transition regions, as well as in less developed and rural regions and islands. Parliament also demands full compliance with the new ex ante provisions on the conditions for the allocation of ESI Funds in order to ensure the functioning of smart specialisation strategies.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I firmly believe that research and innovation strategies (RIS3) contribute to the efficient use of EU funds, affect all Member States and regions of the European Union and unlock the potential of all regions, thereby helping the Union to overcome both internal and external innovation gaps in order to become more competitive at global level. It is right that these regional strategies focus on energy, health, information and communication technologies, modern materials, food, services, tourism, sustainable innovation and transport, the bio-based economy, manufacturing systems and the cultural and creative sectors. It is regrettable, however, that many strategies are not detailed enough, and I believe that support for national observatos of smart specialisation strategies can help to build better indicator systems for monitoring RIS3, in particular as regards methodology and training. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. If this report has the merit of looking at the competitiveness of businesses in the European Union, particularly from the point of view of innovation and specialisation, it forgets what makes up the main problem, namely the shackles of the single currency and the lack of economic protection at the borders.  It is these factors that make corporate margins so low and do not allow them to invest enough in research and innovation. On the other hand, I am in favour of leaving research policy within the competences of the Member States, whereas this report tends to put these states under the commission's tutelage. For all these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 National or regional Innovation Strategies for Smart Specialisation (RIS3) are a key element of the reform of the European Union's cohesion policy, which aims to bring innovation to the regions, encouraging them to create synergies between themselves and with the territory, as well as strengthening strategic planning which is an even more important element in times of crisis and lack of resources available to many territories. If we want the European Union to become an intelligent, sustainable and inclusive economy, we must involve the regions and local authorities, supporting an innovation that starts from the territories and gives strength to all those realities, local and regional, that produce wealth and work despite the crisis and on whose prosperity, today as tomorrow, a significant part of the national and European gross domestic product depends.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report extols the merits of the Smart Specialisation (SRI-SI) research and innovation strategy, a strategy that is supposed to be part of the new European investment policy with the Juncker Plan.  This framing document guides the implementation of cohesion policy and the payment of the European Regional Economic Development Fund (ERDF). He believes that the EU's economic strategy must focus on specialisation and innovation in order to improve the competitiveness of our SMEs. Overall, the IRS-SI duplicates national research policies and, above all, state-region plans. It makes no criticism or questioning of austerity policies on public and private budgets to support research and innovation policies.  Moreover, these strategies are based on a multi-level governance model at the expense of national governments. The European Union is using the SRI-SI strategy to strengthen its direct relations with local authorities. Finally, it should be noted that the SRI-SI strategy promotes thematic concentration, which has the effect of relying exclusively on large clusters or research clusters without supporting small structures and innovation clusters.  So I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In a European context marked by economic and social crises, the European Union is designed to foster sustainable economic growth by harnessing the potential for innovation. The development of smart specialisation strategies comes in response to current challenges, with these strategies having a significant impact in improving the competitiveness of the European economy. Thus, the role of RIS3 is a fundamental one in the context of the contribution of cohesion policy to the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. This tool boosts job creation and economic growth, but also helps to tackle the innovation gap. Given the importance of these strategies, careful monitoring is needed to achieve the expected results, but also to strengthen cooperation between regions in order to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. I was in favour of this report because I believe that smart specialisation strategies are an essential tool for strengthening research, stimulating innovation and encouraging sustainable economic growth.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. In order for the EU to become a smart, sustainable and inclusive economy by 2020, regions must put in place research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation. It is important for regions to use structural funds such as the ERDF to invest in research, development and innovation.  Such a strategy will stimulate entrepreneurship, education and innovation. The regions will then be able to identify their potentials and assets in order to develop and specialize. The Smart Specialization Platform (S3) has a key role in this process. It is imperative that strategies be properly monitored in order to assess their true benefits.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because strengthening research, technological development and innovation is of fundamental importance for achieving the objectives of cohesion policy. In particular, national or regional innovation strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3) are necessary to facilitate a more efficient use of the European Structural and Investment Funds and to support the transition to an intelligent and sustainable economy.  Within the framework of innovation strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3), I believe that regions need to develop innovative support service schemes that complement or replace existing support services, in order to enable a given region to fully exploit its competitive potential, to help businesses absorb new knowledge and technologies to remain competitive, and to ensure that research and innovation resources reach a critical mass.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this own initiative report, which covers the innovation objective of the Europe 2020 Strategy. Each Member State has adopted its own national targets in each of these areas (employment, innovation, education, social inclusion and climate/energy). National and regional authorities across Europe will design smart specialisation strategies in entrepreneurial discovery process, so that the European Structural Investment Funds (ESIF) can be used more efficiently and synergies between different EU, national and regional policies, as well as public and private investments can be increased. There are some good points in the report, including a broad view of innovation, support for technological as well as practice-based and social innovation, and a monitoring and evaluation system. It also provides investment choices for regions with a limited number of priorities, particularly knowledge-based investments and/or clusters. However, the report focuses very heavily on using cohesion policies to meet the Europe 2020 objectives, places a strong emphasis on public-private funding and financial mechanisms, and identifies competitiveness is the main overarching goal of the innovation strategy. For these reasons I could not support the report entirely, so abstained.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ At a time of economic recession and resulting budget constraints, and in an increasingly competitive global environment, I believe that it is important that the European Union keeps improving its capacity to innovate. RIS3 strategies are a valuable tool to tackle the innovation gap, and boost jobs and growth in Europe. Simplification, as well as coordination of the existing programmes, is also essential in contributing to a good implementation of those strategies in the years to come. A review of the strategies after 2017 is essential to boost the efficiency and effectiveness of RIS3 strategies, taking into account the lessons learned from the initial years of their implementation. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are several positive ideas contained in the report on "RIS3" (Research, Innovation and Smart Specialisation Strategy), i.e. on smart specialisation. First, it is recalled that public funding remains a powerful engine of innovation. The authorities concerned are urged to be cautious in focusing more on financial instruments as innovation should not only focus on grants, but should also be able to identify alternative means of financing, such as loans and guarantees. The importance of consulting businesses and SMEs in particular is highlighted, as the 'innovation vision' will only be successful if companies also realise their potential. Finally, local and regional decision-makers are stressed the importance of their commitment to using RSI3 as an instrument of economic transformation in their region and thus, ("optimistically"), to influence EU policy. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the final text.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In response to the economic crisis and in an effort to promote smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, strengthening technological development and innovation has become one of the European Union's investment priorities. To this end, cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3) aims to make the Union economy more competitive by developing European added value in these areas.  In this respect, I believe that RIS3 policy should be based on joint participation and multi-level governance. The Member States must not miss the opportunity to involve regional and local authorities, closer to small and medium-sized enterprises and start-ups, which are pioneers of innovation, in the development of strategies. There is also a need for regular monitoring of the implementation of RIS3 strategies and for the participation of civil society, which is all too often limited, to be stimulated through collaborative platforms and partnerships.  Finally, the synergy between the Structural and Investment Funds (EIS) and the other EU financial instruments available under RIS3, such as the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), must be considered necessary to exploit the potential of research and innovation in enterprises and maximise their results. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and stress that the continuous improvement of the EU's capacity for innovation is crucial. RIS3s need to be constantly reviewed as they relate to a space that is constantly changing.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation. I believe that such procedures are positive for the development and improvement of education practices, which supports the prospects of European citizens. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Valcarcel Siso's report on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3). It is indeed an excellent report which highlights how RIS3 strategies contribute to Europe's growth in both innovation and employment, in line with the Europe 2020 objectives. Calling for RIS3 strategies to be ex ante conditionality for the allocation of EIS funds, the report proposes balanced, knowledge-based growth not only in well-developed regions, but also in less developed or transitioning areas. I congratulate him on his excellent work.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3) and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. Research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3) are a key vector for knowledge-based economic growth, increasing the EU's innovation capacity and building a cohesion policy based on the Europe 2020 objectives. As such, they are an "ex ante" condition for Member States and regions to benefit from european structural and investment funds (EFSI), leading to the design of a RIS3 strategy in each of the regions, which is a good thing. I follow the concern with the need to reduce bureaucratic bottlenecks to speed up the implementation of the strategies and the need to ensure a continuous review of them, considering the constant evolution in this area. I would stress that the implementation of these strategies should seek to promote interregional cooperation, while also promoting synergies between EU research infrastructures in the context of cohesion policy 2014-2020. The full implementation of the Urban Agenda, focusing on the creation of smart cities, should be a priority, as well as the areas of renewable energy, the digital agenda or public health, according to the SWOT analysis of each region. From the foregoing, I support the report.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The proper functioning of a digital single market requires high-quality skilled jobs with smart specialisation that could lead to new skills, knowledge, innovation and employment in order to better exploit research results and take advantage of all forms of innovation. I support therefore the call upon the EU and the Member States to use existing tools such as the Community Innovation Survey (CIS) to carry out periodic (annual and mid-term) monitoring – both quantitative and qualitative on of the implementation of the strategies, and to involve all stakeholders, including civil society in the exercise.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted abstention in this report, because despite containing positive aspects it promotes the logic of markets as de facto rulers of States and their citizens, and enhances public-private financing in cohesion policy. The report deals with the objective of innovation within the 2020 Strategy. It treats innovation from a very broad perspective, supporting technological development as well as experience-based social innovation. It promotes regional innovation and its adaptability to the particular circumstances of the environment. It also promotes better accountability and evaluation systems. There is a lack of reflection and pronouncement on the relocation of jobs destroyed by technological innovation, as well as on the phenomenon of the concentration of wealth generated by intelligent specialization.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 SMEs are essential to the economy of the EU regions in terms of employment and competitiveness. Over the past ten years, SMEs have created 85 % of European jobs and in 2015 contributed up to 71 % of employment growth in the non-financial commercial economy. Through the ESI funds, in particular Policy Objective 3, we can help to further improve the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises and their ability to generate good employment.  For the period 2014-2020, EUR 63 billion is expected to support over 800 000 SMEs. The financial part, however, is only one aspect. In fact, there are still some bottlenecks that prevent its full potential from being developed, starting with the difficulties that, at Member State level, exist in accessing credit. Furthermore, the report rightly stresses the need to simplify administrative procedures and the role that local authorities must play, in particular by offering the necessary technical assistance. With closer cooperation between all levels we can certainly improve both the absorption of resources and the ability of SMEs to contribute to European socio-economic growth.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With a global economy in constant transformation and marked by recessions, but also budgetary constraints, the EU is obliged to improve its innovation potential. Strategies need to be constantly reviewed when discussing an ever-changing area. I voted to increase the synergy between European instruments in order to make the most efficient use of resources. It is essential that local and regional authorities develop their own views, as well as ensure wider cooperation between regions, in order to avoid duplication of efforts and inefficient expenditure.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – Strengthening technological development and innovation is one of the European Regional Development Fund's investment priorities for the period 2014-2020. The positive effects of supporting innovation and research are indisputable. Smart specialisation strategies can have a positive impact on making the European economy more competitive, creating jobs and entrepreneurship. Strategies promote knowledge-based, sustainable growth, balanced development and quality job creation. In addition, the development of basic infrastructure should not be neglected, as proper interconnection of infrastructure is also a prerequisite for the functioning of the single internal market. I supported the report.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support the cohesion policy and innovation strategy for smart specialisation that some Member States have yet to take to meet the ex ante RIS3 requirements. The findings of the ERDF (European Regional Development Fund) on the targeting of investments (for the 2014-2020 programming period) in the areas of research, technological development and innovation through smart specialisation strategies are very important. I fully understand that RIS3 is an ex ante condition to receive support for the above investments.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I agree with the main areas outlined, where improvement for RIS3 should be carried out. The coordinated and complementary use of ESI Funds together with Horizon 2020 and EFSI, provides excellent options for boosting innovation at regional, national and EU levels. This strategy is fundamentally important to create a knowledge-based economy, sustainable growth and balances development and high quality jobs in all regions.  This increases performance and also contributes to the achievement of the Europe 2020 objectives.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider it necessary to use complementarity between the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF) and the European Funds for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and the potential to combine these funds in order to make full use of the European Union's guarantees for financing investment platforms.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report gives the first conclusions as well as the European Parliament's position on research and innovation strategies for intelligent specialisation.  A key element of the new Cohesion Policy 2014-2020, SRI-SI strategies aim to better mobilise European funds by encouraging regions to invest in their assets to promote growth and jobs. Among the main measures, the report proposes to initiate a reflection for the improvement of the implementation of these strategies.  Considering that the specifics of the territories are essential components of the economic development model of the regions, following the example of mountain areas, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this report because as usual, it was filled with buzz words and phrases that sound impressive but which will do nothing to create growth and jobs. The EU’s obsessive interference and over regulation damages both jobs and growth and we fail to see how buzz words and corporate speak will change that.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for Intelligent Specialisation (SRI-SI). In order to ensure the best efficiency in the use of EU funds towards priority actions, it is essential that intelligent specialisation strategies (SRI-SI) are put in place.  These intelligent specialisation strategies must then develop under conditions conducive to improving competitiveness and innovation in Europe, which must be encouraged by a synergy of the various instruments at our disposal.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Strengthening technological development and innovation is one of the European Regional Development Fund's investment priorities for the period 2014-2020. Smart specialisation strategies can have a positive impact on making the European economy more competitive, creating jobs and entrepreneurship. Strategies promote knowledge-based, sustainable growth, balanced development and quality job creation. The positive effects of supporting innovation and research are indisputable, which is why I voted in favour of this report in the plenary vote. However, I think it is important to note that basic infrastructure development should not be neglected either, because infrastructure is often deficient in more developed Member States, the necessary development cannot always be solved on a market basis, and proper infrastructure interconnection is also a prerequisite for the functioning of the single internal market.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important for the European Union to continue to strengthen its capacity to innovate in the face of increasing global competition. In addition, I support investment in research and smart specialisation strategies to provide innovative and competitive services, ensure economic growth and new jobs.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This text serves as a common thread in the implementation of the European Economic and Regional Development Fund (ERDF). The latter aims to establish a direct relationship between the European Union (the Commission) and the communities, thus ignoring the Member States.  Moreover, this framework programme, which is in line with the 'Europe 2020' strategy, does not in any way call into question the austerity policies imposed in Europe on both public and private budgets. Also, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report as it highlights the role of multi-level governance in the strategy-making process, the role of the EU urban development agenda in creating synergies and strong resource efficiency links, as well as the role of monitoring and evaluation as an important part of smart specialisation strategies in the 2014-2020 programming period.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy, apart from being non-functional in general, does not lead to the creation of quality positions. On the contrary, it has caused a great loss of valuable human resources both in our country and in all the other economically weak countries of the Union.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Strengthening technological development and innovation is one of the European Regional Development Fund's investment priorities for the period 2014-2020. Smart specialisation strategies can have a positive impact on making the European economy more competitive, creating jobs and entrepreneurship. Strategies promote knowledge-based, sustainable growth, balanced development and quality job creation. The positive effects of supporting innovation and research are indisputable, which is why I voted in favour of this report in the plenary vote. However, I think it is important to note that basic infrastructure development should not be neglected either, because infrastructure is often deficient in more developed Member States, the necessary development cannot always be solved on a market basis, and proper infrastructure interconnection is also a prerequisite for the functioning of the single internal market.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. RIS3 strategies are a valuable tool for bridging the innovation gap and boosting jobs and growth in Europe. Public authorities should try to pay particular attention to monitoring and revising strategies in order to maximise their results and, on the other hand, interregional cooperation, with the aim of developing ambitious projects that create added value for the economy. The organisation of a European-wide conference and the development of a policy-oriented document incorporating the main lessons of experience in this area are very useful tools for continuous improvement.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: it should be noted that the SRI-SI strategy promotes thematic concentration, which has the effect of relying exclusively on large clusters or research clusters without supporting small structures and innovation clusters

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), in support of Thematic Objective 1, has established that regions should channel their investments into IDI (research, development and innovation) through smart specialisation strategies in the 2014-2020 programming period. RIS3 is therefore an 'ex ante' condition for EU Member States and regions to benefit from the European Structural and Investment Funds. All European regions have a RIS3 Strategy. These strategies were shaped and began to be implemented during 2014 and 2015. While the report is linking to the achievement dimension of EU objectives (notably through the EU 2020 strategy, which we reject), the logic of targeting IDI strategies in Member States and regional and local bodies allows for a more realistic definition of needs and more sustained (not enforced) development prospects, and the logic seems to be that achieving the local objective could contribute to the overall objective). The mobilisation of structural and investment funds linked to social and territorial cohesion, framed in a RIS logic, could contribute to investment in economic growth, in particular in support for SMEs, which, especially in the context of economic depression that austerity and neoliberal asphyxiation policies have imposed, seem positive.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 At a time of economic recession and budgetary constraints and in a context of increasing global competition, it is vital that the European Union continues to strengthen its capacity to innovate. I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation, because it highlights the aspects to which strategies should pay particular attention, such as: the analysis of the priorities, strengths and potential of each region; the development of periodic quantitative and qualitative monitoring; the development of participatory processes; the creation of synergies between public and private actors; coordination between all levels of governance and services. Each EU country should do its utmost to promote synergies between these instruments and to use resources in the most efficient way.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: writing \u2012 The RIS3 strategy, which is based on cohesion policy, strategy and research and innovation for smart specialisation, aims to improve the strategy of smart specialisation in all areas – not only in economically strong areas but also in transition regions as well as in less developed, rural and remote areas – on the basis of knowledge, sustainable growth, balanced development and high-quality jobs in all areas – not only in economically strong areas, but also in regions in transition, as well as in less developed, rural and remote areas – to improve the strategy of smart specialisation of promoting thematic focus and strategic planning for better use of the European Structural Funds and Investment Funds , increase the focus on performance on the ground, thereby contributing to the achievement of the objectives set out in the EUROPA2020 strategy.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report because I am in favour of greater and continuous monitoring of the innovation strategy for smart specialisation.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3), because cohesion policy beyond non-functional in general does not lead to the creation of quality positions, on the contrary, it has caused a great loss of valuable human resources in our country, as in all other economically weak countries of the Union.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ During the year 2014, regions have started to develop and publish their RIS3 strategies. The aim of these strategies is to create knowledge-based, sustainable growth, balanced development and high quality jobs in all regions, not only in well-developed areas but also in regions in transition as well as in less developed, rural and island regions. Smart specialisation strategies support thematic concentration and strategic programming of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds) and lead to increased performance orientation on the ground, thus contributing to the achievement of the Europe 2020 objectives. I therefore support the report.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Strengthening technological development and innovation is one of the European Regional Development Fund's investment priorities for the period 2014-2020. Smart specialisation strategies can have a positive impact on making the European economy more competitive, creating jobs and entrepreneurship. Strategies promote knowledge-based, sustainable growth, balanced development and quality job creation. The positive effects of supporting innovation and research are indisputable, which is why I voted in favour of this report in the plenary vote. However, I think it is important to note that basic infrastructure development should not be neglected either, because infrastructure is often deficient in more developed Member States, the necessary development cannot always be solved on a market basis, and proper infrastructure interconnection is also a prerequisite for the functioning of the single internal market.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the PEOPLE's Party position, as it is vital for the EU to sustainably improve its capacity to innovate in times of economic recession and, consequently, severe budgetary constraints and increasing global competition. RIS3 plays a central role in contributing cohesion policy to the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, so RIS3 is a preliminary condition for Member States and EU regions to benefit from the European Structural and Investment Funds. All European regions have RIS3 strategies which need to be constantly reviewed. It is about innovation, i.e. an area that is constantly changing, so it is essential that strategies are constantly adapted to changes in the field of specialisation. In addition, particular attention should be paid to the areas to which the strategies should pay particular attention: analysis of priorities, strengths and potential of each region, involvement of the quadruple spiral in the definition of strategies, use of methodology, development of periodic quantitative and qualitative monitoring, development of participatory procedures, invitation of stakeholders, in particular with regard to the private sector, development of public-private synergies, coordination between all management levels and departments , and to find alternative sources of funding.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour entirely convinced that it is necessary, at a time of economic recession and budgetary constraints, and in an increasingly competitive global environment, for the European Union to continue to improve its capacity to innovate. We are talking about innovation, an area that is constantly changing. It is therefore essential that strategies are constantly adapted to changes in the field of expertise. All European regions have a RIS3 strategy, and these strategies have begun to be implemented throughout 2014 and 2015.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. – This is a very important report and it aims to increase the impact of the ESI funds on for example job creation and growth. The report outlines that the regions should develop RIS3 strategies based on analyses of competences, assets and more. It is important that these RIS3 strategies are developed on a regional level so that no growth opportunities are not lost. I also support the report in its assessment that more synergies are needed across different EU funding instruments, such as ESI. These obstacles hinders the coordination and the coherence of EU funding and reduces their overall impact.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Better coordination of resources from Europe is a crucial need for growth. The role of local and regional authorities is essential to this objective. The report that we have adopted stresses that a strategic specialisation for innovation must also and necessarily be matched by complementarity between all the funds available. The economic and financial crisis and the resulting reductions in public budgets require the territories to make an effort to rationalise investment capacities for innovation; With this report, we hope that the foundations will be laid for a more common and effective approach.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3) because I firmly believe that in these times of economic, financial and social crisis the EU must step up its efforts to create smart, sustainable but above all inclusive economic growth.  Innovation must be the key to strengthening synergies between Member States for growth and job creation, and EU urban areas must play a key role in this process, becoming catalysts for smart specialization strategies. Regions and cities, as they did in Puglia, must act as poles for various actors and sectors, declining the challenges and opportunities for smart growth, and being pioneers of the integrated territorial approach.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3) because I believe that we need to further integrate regional and research funding, particularly to the benefit of structurally weak regions. That's where we create work. Examples of existing regional research and innovation strategies prove this – for example in Thuringia.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the European Union's cohesion policy. Especially in these times of economic recession, tight budgets and intensifying global competition, it is absolutely essential that the European Union expands its innovative capacity and strengthens the European regions. Support will focus on promoting employment and interregional exchanges. I particularly welcome the fact that cohesion policy recognises economic growth in rural areas as a key objective.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because innovation is an area that is continuously evolving. It follows therefore that RIS3 strategies should be constantly revised. In order to achieve this, a review of the strategies after 2017 seems mandatory so as to boost efficiency and effectiveness, also taking into account the lessons learned from the initial years of their implementation.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report which supports cohesion policies and research and innovation strategies for smart specialization (RIS3). RIS3 contributes to the strategic programming of the Cohesion Funds and can play a key role in meeting the Europe 2020 targets, in the pursuit of balanced and sustainable development and in the creation of quality jobs. It also proposes support for multi-level governance and greater participation at all levels in aid programmes, as well as the creation of positive synergies in the different regions to determine their strengths. Although the report contains many 'wind odes' I am in favour of technological and social innovation, the evaluation of the aid system, the strengthening of the strengths of each region and SMEs, in order to achieve more sustainable development.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation, the so-called RIS3. RIS3 strategies are a valuable tool for minimising the innovation gap and increasing employment and boosting economic growth in Europe. The strategy still needs to be improved and public authorities should continuously monitor strategies in order to maximise their performance and ensure the most effective interregional cooperation possible. Furthermore, simplification and coordination of existing programmes is essential for the proper implementation of these strategies in the coming years. In this context, the review of the post-2017 strategy should be mandatory in order to increase the effectiveness and effectiveness of the RIS3 strategy, taking into account the experience gained in the first years of its implementation.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my EPLP colleagues I voted in favour of this report because innovation is an area that is continuously changing, RIS 3 strategies should be constant revised. For this purpose, a review of the strategies after 2017 seems mandatory in order to boost the efficiency and effectiveness of them, taking also into account the lessons learned from the initial years of their implementation.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. RIS3 strategies are a valuable tool to tackle the innovation gap, and boost jobs and growth in Europe. Simplification, as well as coordination of the existing programmes, is also essential in contributing to a good implementation of those strategies in the years to come.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – We voted in favour of the report as it promotes the development of innovation by providing a wide range of options for balanced development through investment in unfavourable regions, regions as well as less developed, rural and island regions.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because within cohesion policy, the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) established that regions were required to concentrate their investments within four priorities including R&D and Innovation via smart specialisation strategies (RIS3) in the 2014-2020 programming period. Therefore, RIS3 is an ex-ante condition for Member States and EU regions for receiving European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF). I was happy that the report focused on the RIS3 and its central role within cohesion policy and its contribution to the Europe 2020 goals.
