Moreover, the report highlights that the implementation of RIS3 can only be successful if based on local and regional assets. In addition, the report asks for better synergies for growth and job creation between funding instruments, ESIF, EFSI and Horizon 2020. Finally, the report acknowledges the importance of Smart cities as catalysts for RIS3 and presents the main lessons for the future of RIS3.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Strengthening technological development and innovation is one of the European Regional Development Fund's investment priorities for the period 2014-2020. Smart specialisation strategies can have a positive impact on making the European economy more competitive, creating jobs and entrepreneurship. Strategies promote knowledge-based, sustainable growth, balanced development and quality job creation. The positive effects of supporting innovation and research are indisputable, which is why I voted in favour of this report in the plenary vote. However, I think it is important to note that basic infrastructure development should not be neglected either, because infrastructure is often deficient in more developed Member States, the necessary development cannot always be solved on a market basis, and proper infrastructure interconnection is also a prerequisite for the functioning of the single internal market.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of these strategies is to create sustainable growth, balanced development and high quality jobs in all regions. Smart specialisation strategies support thematic concentration and strategic programming of the EFSI funds in order to increased performance. This report deals with the areas where improvement for RIS3 should be carried out and underlines the fact that the use of ESI Funds, together with Horizon 2020, provides excellent options for boosting innovation at national and EU levels. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Cohesion Policy Report and the Smart Specialisation Research and Innovation Strategies (RIS3), given the central role of the RIS3 strategy in contributing cohesion policy to the Objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, and given that RIS3 strategies should help to strengthen the competitiveness of the European economy, develop European added value in innovation and create more high-quality jobs.  The development of the RIS3 strategy includes a process of developing governance mechanisms that identify specific areas with the highest strategic potential and prioritise strategic priorities. Smart specialisation strategies support thematic concentration and strategic programming under the ESI Funds, improving on-the-spot impact.  Under the S3 platform in Seville, particular attention should be paid to lagging regions and assisted in shaping and guiding their strategies. There is a problem that some Member States have put in place RIS3 national strategies so that they have not given local and regional authorities a chance to shape their own views.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The strategy presented in this report is part of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (The Juncker Plan). This framing document guides the implementation of cohesion policy and the payment of the European Regional Economic Development Fund (ERDF). He believes that the Eu's economic strategy must focus on specialisation and innovation in order to improve the competitiveness of our economy.  However, nothing is planned to support the principle of labeling (innovative companies) or to address the problem of patents and industrial espionage, subjects that are strategic. Moreover, there is no criticism or questioning of austerity policies on public and private budgets to support research and innovation policies.  The French state, caught between the European Union and the regions, is not leading the implementation of this strategy which responds to the guidelines decided by the European Commission.  The European Union is using the SRI-SI strategy to strengthen direct relations between the European Commission and the regions that have become the management authority of the ERDF, as well as trans-European cooperation at the expense of cooperation between nation states. So I voted against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution because RIS3 will allow our regions to remain competitive, create more quality jobs and achieve sustainable growth by helping them develop in the areas of their strength. Put differently, smart specialisation means that these regions will be able to focus in priority sectors where they have the biggest competitive potential. I believe in the participatory approach of this strategy that concentrates on targeted research and innovation programmes but at the same time offers support for regions and businesses to take full advantage of the new technologies and knowledge. This way we will be able to bridge the development and innovation gap in Europe.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Ramon Luis Valcircel Siso's report on research and innovation strategies for intelligent specialisation. These strategies encourage different European regions to identify their strengths in order to best guide European funds and thus maximise their contribution to growth. The report draws the first lessons from the implementation of these strategies and makes several common-sense recommendations for the future. For example, it stresses the importance of better adapting teaching and research to real needs, so that innovation meets demand and leads to growth. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Valc-rcel Siso report, which supports smart specialisation strategies and calls for lessons to be learned from the implementation of these strategies in order to achieve better results in the future.  Indeed, research and innovation strategies for intelligent specialization (SRI-SI) are an ex-ante conditionality for the allocation of ESI funds.  IRS-SISs promote thematic concentration and strategic programming of funds. Depending on the strengths and benefits of each region, these strategies aim to generate growth in all European regions.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report of Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso on Cohesion policy and research and innovation has been focusing on the importance of certain aspects of our policies that I align with. At a time of economic recession and resulting budget constraints, and in an increasingly competitive global environment, it is crucial that the European Union keep improving its capacity to innovate. The rapporteur is of the opinion that RIS3 strategies are a valuable tool to tackle the innovation gap, and boost jobs and growth in Europe. For the time being, we can see that creation of the strategies still leaves room for changes to be made. Public authorities should try to pay special attention to the monitoring and review of the strategies in order to maximise its output on the one hand, and interregional cooperation on the other hand, in order to develop ambitious projects that create added value for the economy. Simplification, as well as coordination of the existing programmes, is also essential in contributing to a good implementation of those strategies in the years to come.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report. In its balance, it puts forward proposals to the Commission to further promote smart specialisation in cohesion policy and RIS3 in order to create greater added value for recipients.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as innovation is an area that is continuously changing. Therefore, a review of the strategies after 2017 seems mandatory in order to boost the efficiency and effectiveness of them, taking also into account the lessons learned from the initial years of their implementation.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Strengthening technological development and innovation is one of the European Regional Development Fund's investment priorities for the period 2014-2020. Smart specialisation strategies can have a positive impact on making the European economy more competitive, creating jobs and entrepreneurship. Strategies promote knowledge-based, sustainable growth, balanced development and quality job creation. The positive effects of supporting innovation and research are indisputable, which is why I voted in favour of this report in the plenary vote. However, I think it is important to note that basic infrastructure development should not be neglected either, because infrastructure is often deficient in more developed Member States, the necessary development cannot always be solved on a market basis, and proper infrastructure interconnection is also a prerequisite for the functioning of the single internal market.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. – I supported the report on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for the Smart Specialisation Initiative (RIS3), as I believe that technology and innovation are an essential prerequisite for economic growth for both regions and the EU. Cohesion policy provides tools to promote research and innovation development using local and regional assets that can overcome differences in innovative progress between regions.  I believe that regional focus, strategic and effective planning and use of investment for public research and innovation will support not only well-developed areas, but also less developed and rural areas, boost employment and growth at local level and help strengthen administrative capacity at local and regional level.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Research and innovation strategies for Smart specialisation are particularly important in times when the EU needs to create smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in order to tackle financial and social crises across the Union. I supported the resolution and it is important to note that for the 2014-2020 programming period, Member States are required, for the first time, to develop national and/or regional smart specialisation strategies by involving national and regional managing authorities and stakeholders such as higher education institutions, industry and social partners, in an entrepreneurial discovery process. Therefore, research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation should be designed by a strong governance system and should stimulate private investment in research, technology and development.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The following motion for a resolution aims to achieve sustainable growth based on knowledge, harmonious development and job creation, not only in well-developed areas, but also in regions in transition and in less developed, rural and island regions. With regard to this thematic objective, the ERDF foresees that, during the period 2014/2020, regions should concentrate investment in CSS, through smart specialisation strategies. In this context, RIS3 is implemented, which is the condition by which it is possible to grant the EU Member States and regions, which have their own RIS3 strategy, European Structural and Investment Funds (the so-called EIS Funds). I therefore believe that these strategies are an instrument capable of promoting European employment growth and, in order to contribute to the proper implementation of these strategies, simplification and coordination of existing programmes are essential.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it does not want to challenge austerity policies on public and private budgets for support for research and innovation policies.  On the other hand, I regret that the European Union is using the SRI-SI strategy to strengthen direct relations between the European Commission and the regions that have become the management authorities of the ERDF, to the detriment of cooperation between nation states.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation.  This text extols the merits of the research and innovation strategy for intelligent specialization. It does not include any criticism or questioning of austerity policies on public and private budgets to support research and innovation policies.  The governance of the strategy must be multi-level and compatible with the Europe 2020 strategy. This means that the French state is not leading the implementation of this strategy which responds to the guidelines decided by the European Commission. The European Union is using the SRI-SI strategy to strengthen direct relations between the European Commission and the regions that have become the management authority of the ERDF, as well as trans-European cooperation at the expense of cooperation between nation states.  In the text, there is no provision to support the principle of labelling (innovative companies) or to address the thorny problem of patents and industrial espionage, which are major issues for the future of the economies of our Member States.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This report extols the merits of the research and innovation strategy for smart specialization. It considers that, in terms of economic strategy, the EU must focus on specialisation and innovation in order to improve European economic competitiveness.  Nevertheless, behind these poncifs are several negative elements. First of all, the text does not provide support for the labeling, does not address the issue of industrial patents and espionage.  Moreover, it tends to exclude the national level in favour of a direct relationship between the Commission and the regions, which have become the management authority of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF).  Finally, there is no question of the monetary policy of the European Central Bank and the austerity policies pursued for years. For all these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it has focused on the main areas of ris3 improvement. In particular, the report underlines that the coordinated and complementary use of the EIE Funds with the Horizon 2020 programme and the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIES), in line with the guidelines on complementarities between the EIE and the EIE Funds published by the Commission in February 2016, offers excellent opportunities to drive innovation at regional, national and Union level , increasing the attractiveness of investments in research and innovation in order to attract private capital as a complement to public funding.  In this regard, the report calls on local and regional authorities to make the most of the possibilities for combining these instruments. The report calls for a review of RIS3 strategies after 2017 with the aim of improving their efficiency and effectiveness, taking into account what was learned in the early years of their implementation.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted abstention in this report, because despite containing positive aspects it promotes the logic of markets as de facto rulers of States and their citizens, and enhances public-private financing in cohesion policy. The report deals with the objective of innovation within the 2020 Strategy. It treats innovation from a very broad perspective, supporting technological development as well as experience-based social innovation. It promotes regional innovation and its adaptability to the particular circumstances of the environment. It also promotes better accountability and evaluation systems. There is a lack of reflection and pronouncement on the relocation of jobs destroyed by technological innovation, as well as on the phenomenon of the concentration of wealth generated by intelligent specialization.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. At a time of economic recession and budgetary constraints, and in an increasingly competitive global environment, the work of this report which is committed to innovation and cohesion policies is crucial. As already established, the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) should be used by the different European regions to define their investment in R&D&I through smart specialization strategies. RIS3s are an ex ante condition for Member States and regions of the Union to receive the European Structural and Investment Funds (EIE Funds). In this way we contribute to the thematic concentration and the strategic programming of them, leading to a greater orientation of the results on the ground.  I give my positive vote for the adoption of this report, which, in addition to the above, promotes sustainable knowledge-based growth, which drives balanced development and the creation of quality jobs in all regions.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that aims to bolster knowledge-based growth equally in developed and less-developed regions.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. This is an unhelpful resolution full of nonsensical proclamations, such as that "smart specialisation strategies should be an effective tool to tackle social, environmental, climate and energy challenges." Nor do I agree with 'national authorities investing in regional intelligence and in-depth big data analysis, which will enable them to understand trends in regional businesses in the global value chain'. I don't think that's what national authorities are supposed to do.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the report’s idea to develop Strategies for Smart Specialisation on the basis of analyses of each region’s existing capabilities, assets and competences, to focus on entrepreneurial discovery in order to detect emerging niches or comparative advantages for smart specialisation, and to enhance a stronger partnership between public and private sectors.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Cohesion policy must focus on the efficient and efficient use of resources in achieving the europe 2020 objectives. Increasing competitiveness naturally requires focusing on the development and increase of support for research, development and innovation and on high value-added activities that will boost employment growth and regional development. The Research and Innovation Strategy for Smart Specialisation (RIS3) is the basis for the development of operational programmes and requires all actors involved not only to have a thorough knowledge of the regions and to cooperate with each other, but also to control, monitor and evaluate the results in achieving the objectives. RIS3 is an important tool for tackling innovation gaps and increasing employment and growth in Europe.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. In the framework of 'Europe 2020', each Member State defined its national and regional innovation strategies for Intelligent Specialisation (SRI-SI) in 2014. The latter aim to increase synergies between different European, national and regional policies, in order to invest in key areas such as education, innovation, social inclusion and energy. This report primarily identifies areas where improvements can be made in smart specialization. It also reminds us of the necessary complementarity between the European Structural Funds, the Horizon 2020 strategy and the European Fund for Strategic Investments (The Juncker Plan) in order to stimulate innovation.   I vote for this report which promotes the optimization of the use of European funds for local growth.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3), because it is comprehensive and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This document serves as a common thread in the implementation of the European Economic and Regional Development Fund (ERDF).  In its implementation, it aims to establish a direct relationship between the European Union (the Commission), thereby ignoring the Member States.  Moreover, this framework programme, which is in line with the 'Europe 2020' strategy, does not in any way call into question the austerity policies imposed in Europe on both public and private budgets.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. – Regarding the Report on Cohesion Policy and Research and Innovation Strategies for Smart Specialisation, I voted in favour, as the report highlights the need to develop sustainable and inclusive economic growth. The European Union has room for improvement, and, therefore, I find essential the need for technological development, education, specialisation strategies, and innovation, during these times of economic, financial, and social crisis the union is undergoing. Only by improving these areas is the EU able to develop a more competitive economy, allowing for the creation of more and better high-quality jobs.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The Union needs to take measures to help promote sustainable and inclusive economic growth, as well as quality employment, which is one of the most important objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. That is why the report which we have adopted, with my full support, is so important in which my colleague Ramón Luis Valcárcel advocates strengthening the competitiveness of the regions. To this end, we propose to promote smart specialization strategies, which must become indispensable tools to create quality and future jobs, giving our regions the opportunity to modernize and transform into innovative poles that can compete in this globalized world.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Improving the EU's capacity for innovation and specialisation is fundamental. Better strategies should be developed in RIS3-related areas and adapted to changes in the specialisation sections. In order to implement these strategies effectively, it is necessary to facilitate and simplify the various administrative procedures. There are several ways to stimulate research and innovation that can contribute to job creation. Finally, the importance of assessing these innovations and the process leading to research and specialisation must not be ignored, it is necessary to use qualitative and quantitative measures correctly for proper evaluation and to publish valid reports analysing the impact of RIS3 strategies.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. It reports on the strengthening of the economy through the efficient use of EU funds under RIS3. More innovation is needed to create high-quality jobs. I can only support that.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Strengthening research, development and innovation is one of the investment priorities under the provisions of the European Regional Development Fund 2014-2020. However, support for innovation varies greatly from one EU country to another, particularly when it comes to the use of knowledge and technology in the field of innovation. During this programming period, Member States are obliged for the first time to develop national and regional smart specialisation strategies, involving national and regional managing authorities and higher education institutions, industry and social partners in the entrepreneurship process. In this report, Parliament therefore stresses that these strategies aim to ensure knowledge-based sustainable growth, sustainable development and high-quality jobs in all regions

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Smart Specialisation aims to better mobilise all structural funds for "smart, sustainable and inclusive growth" by encouraging regions to adopt economic development models adapted to their strengths and by strengthening synergies between European policies for research and innovation.  These research and innovation strategies promote the thematic concentration and strategic programming of European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI funds).  The report welcomes the implementation of these strategies, while stressing the role of public services in the effectiveness of these strategies. "The administrative capacity of the authorities and the stability of the public service are crucial to the effective implementation of the strategies."  A less pontificating chatter than usual, with a recognition of the role of the state. I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. In this text, there is no provision to support the principle of labelling (innovative companies) or to solve the problem of patents and industrial espionage, which are major issues for the future of the economies of our Member States. The whole strategy put in place stems from the Europe 2020 strategy, directly attributable to the Commission. As such, the French state is not in control of its own destiny in this matter. Finally, the SRI-SI strategy promotes thematic concentration, which has the effect of focusing exclusively on exclusive research clusters without supporting small structures and innovation clusters. As a result, I voted against this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In this time of economic, financial and social crisis, the EU must step up its efforts towards smart, sustainable and inclusive economic growth. Actors need to develop RIS3 on the basis of the analysis of each region's capacities, resources and competences, with the aim of identifying emerging niches or comparative advantages for smart specialisation, avoiding forced and artificial over-specialisation and strengthening a stronger partnership between the public and private sectors, while avoiding possible conflicts of interest between the public and private sectors. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which focuses on delivering research and innovation funds to less-developed and rural regions. The report expresses Parliament’s support for the RIS3 platform and points out ways that they can improve through greater oversight, planning and participation.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. This report is relevant because it provides lessons to be learned from the gradual implementation at the regional level of "research strategies and innovation for intelligent specialisation" (SRI-SI).  We will only remain globally competitive if we create the conditions for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth; which presupposes the improvement of our ability to innovate. To achieve this, ISRS must be designed within a strong governance system, based on swoft analysis (assets, weaknesses, prospects), monitored and provide measures to stimulate investment.  Only in this way can Europe claim European know-how that will enable it to increase its competitiveness, to renew its skills, to create jobs, in a word to continue to exist at the global level.  In this context, I would like to stress the essential role played by the Platform for Intelligent Specialization (the "S3 Platform") in disseminating information, methods, skills and advice to policy-making authorities at all levels of power and within the framework of transnational cooperation.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – In the previous period, the European Regional Development Fund for Thematic Objective 1 provided for regions in the programme statement to focus investments on R&D&I through smart specialisation strategies. RIS3 strategies are a precondition for EU states and regions to draw on European funds, all regions have them and their implementation started during 2014 and 2015. RIS3 strategies are an important tool for addressing innovation gaps and increasing employment and growth. As these are innovations and therefore an area that is constantly changing, it is essential that strategies are constantly adapted to the changes that are taking place in the field of specialisation. There is a need for public authorities to pay particular attention to monitoring and reviewing strategies, on the one hand, to maximising their output and interregional cooperation, and, on the other hand, to develop projects bringing added value to the economy. The proposal also emphasises the simplification and coordination of existing programmes, the review of post-2017 strategies in order to enhance the effectiveness and efficiency of RIS3 strategies. The organisation of a stakeholder dialogue forum and the drafting of a policy document covering the main lessons learned from real experience in this area are a useful tool, and I will therefore vote in favour of the proposal in favour.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on Cohesion Policy and Research and Innovation Strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3), which aims to create knowledge-based, sustainable growth, balanced development and high quality jobs in all regions, not only in well-developed areas but also in regions in transition as well as in less developed, rural and island regions. Smart specialisation strategies support thematic concentration and strategic programming of the European Structural and Investment Funds and lead to increased performance orientation on the ground, thus contributing to the achievement of the Europe 2020 objectives. A review of the strategies after 2017 seems mandatory in order to boost the efficiency and effectiveness of them, taking also into account the lessons learned from the initial years of their implementation.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In times of economic recession and consequently severe budgetary constraints and increasing global competition, it is vital for the EU to sustainably improve its capacity to innovate. The European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) has identified the need for regions to concentrate their investments in R&D&I through smart specialisation strategies during the 2014-2020 programming period. Therefore, RIS3 is a preliminary condition for Member States and EU regions to benefit from the European Structural and Investment Funds. All European regions have RIS3 strategies. The strategies were developed and published by the regions in 2014. After the strategies are published and their implementation begins, lessons must be learned and we must try to focus more on the measures to be implemented in the coming years in order to make RIS3 strategies more effective and effective. The Report of the Committee on Regional Development reviews key aspects of the strategy and focuses on the main areas where improvements for RIS3 should be made. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report extols the merits of the research and innovation strategy for smart specialization. It makes no criticism or questioning of austerity policies and their impact on public and private budgets to support research and innovation policies.  The French state is not leading the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy, which responds to the guidelines decided by the European Commission. The European Union is using the SRI-RI strategy to strengthen direct relations between the European Commission and the regions that have become the management authorities of the ERDF and trans-European cooperation at the expense of cooperation between nation-states. The SRI-RI strategy promotes thematic concentration, which has the effect of focusing exclusively on large clusters or research clusters without supporting small structures and innovation clusters.  Unfavorable vote.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. I endorse the rapporteur's position in this era of economic downturn and, consequently, a scarcity of budgetary resources and increasingly close global competition, it is crucial for the EU to sustainably improve its capacity for innovation. I believe that RIS3 strategies are a valuable mechanism for reducing innovation asymmetries and boosting jobs and growth in Europe.  I believe that RIS3 strategies must adapt continuously, as innovation is constantly evolving and thus it is vital that strategies are subject to continuous review. I believe that simplification and reduction of bottlenecks in administrative procedures is essential in order to ensure the proper implementation and effective implementation of strategies.  For the for eson, and for identifying that smart specialisation strategies are valuable tools for addressing challenges in the EU, this report deserves my vote in favour.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report praises the research and innovation strategy for smart specialisation as part of the new European investment policy.  This report ignores the disastrous austerity policies imposed on research and national budgets. This strategy responds to guidelines decided by the European Commission and not by the states.  I have therefore decided to vote against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my EPLP colleagues I voted in favour of this report because innovation is an area that is continuously changing, RIS 3 strategies should be constant revised. For this purpose, a review of the strategies after 2017 seems mandatory in order to boost the efficiency and effectiveness of them, taking also into account the lessons learned from the initial years of their implementation.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation.  The establishment of new and sustainable growth, based in particular on research and innovation, is fundamental in a European Union hit by unemployment and unfair competition from emerging countries.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Valc-rcel Siso report on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for Intelligent Specialisation (SRI-SI).  IRS-SISs promote thematic concentration and strategic programming of structural and investment funds and lead to a more effective approach to their implementation.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ability to innovate is essential for the Union's economic recovery, in light of the complex economic downturn and increasing competitive pressures on global markets. Smart specialisation strategies aim to achieve sustainable knowledge-based growth and create quality jobs across the Union, with special attention being paid to those regions in transition or less developed. The report proposed by the European Parliament, which identifies the main opportunities for improvement in smart specialisation strategies and therefore aims to exploit its full potential, is therefore to be welcomed. In particular, the report highlights the need for constant monitoring of RIS3 strategies in order to keep them up to date, given the high dynamism of the innovation sector.  Given that smart specialisation strategies support Structural Investment Fund programmes and contribute to achieving the Strategic Objectives of Europe 2020, it is important that synergies are achieved between the union's various financial instruments. In presenting this report, the European Parliament is also promoting a necessary change of mentality in order to promote a bottom-up approach, as the multi-level governance system has not so far been properly exploited.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure because I believe it is important for the European Union to continue to invest and to strengthen research and innovation, given also the current period of economic recession and consequent budgetary constraints. Through the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), regions will concentrate investment in RIS through smart specialisation strategies. Therefore, RIS3 is an ex ante condition for the granting of European Structural and Investment Funds (EIS Funds) to EU Member States and regions. Following the publication of the strategies, it is necessary to better identify the actions to be taken in the coming years to make RIS3 strategies more effective and efficient. This report focuses on the main areas where improvements should be made to RIS3.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this report because I believe that the RIS3 system contributes greatly to a sustainable, intelligent and inclusive economy. The system combines industrial, educational and innovative policies in a completely new way. It uses a triple spiral-based approach, for example, in urban development, based on sustainable connectivity and cooperation between business operators, research centres and cities. Cities play a key role in the economic and social development of the Union, as they serve as centres for different actors and sectors. The report points out that the development and operation of appropriate strategies in smaller regions is a problem, and that the innovation of the RIS3 system contributes to the good functioning and knowledge of the appropriate strategies in these regions on the basis of the exchange of best practices.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Improving the European Union’s capacity to innovate is crucial during these times of economic recession. I have voted for this report which through the RIS3 strategy will, amongst others, stimulate private investment in research, technology and development.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – I supported this resolution calling on EU countries to improve the implementation and monitoring of 'smart specialisation strategies' (RIS3 or S3) because I am of the opinion that S3 can fill some of the shortcomings of cohesion policy.   While EU cohesion policy is a crucial mechanism whose main objective must be to eliminate existing socio-economic inequalities between different European regions, a large part of the ESI Funds fail to attract rural and other less developed regions that are struggling to develop and implement regional strategies.  In this context, I stand firmly behind the appeal of this resolution to develop the administrative capacity of disadvantaged regions. It is through improvements in administrative capacity that rural and less developed regions, such as Bulgaria in my country, will be able to identify their strengths and priority development areas in a way that exploits the maximum potential of their population, creating new skills, knowledge, innovation and jobs.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3) should help improve the competitiveness of the European economy, develop a European added value in innovation and create new high-quality jobs. Smart specialisation strategies can also be powerful tools to address energy challenges, resource efficiency and energy security.  I stress the importance of adapting education and research to the real needs of the market in an effort to ensure that new innovations meet demand and lead to economic growth. I support the new European Innovation Council, aimed at creating a one-stop shop for innovators, linking scientific successes to the needs of Europe's business and public authorities.  Given that research, technological development and innovation are investment priorities under the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) for the period 2014-2020, I voted for the European Parliament resolution on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3).

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I abstained on this own-initiative report, which covers the innovation objective of the Europe 2020 Strategy. Each Member State has adopted its own national targets in each of these areas (employment, innovation, education, social inclusion and climate/energy). National and regional authorities across Europe will design smart specialisation strategies in entrepreneurial discovery process, so that the European Structural Investment Funds (ESIF) can be used more efficiently and synergies between different EU, national and regional policies, as well as public and private investments can be increased. There are some good points in the report, including a broad view of innovation, support for technological as well as practice-based and social innovation, and a monitoring and evaluation system. It also provides investment choices for regions with a limited number of priorities, particularly knowledge-based investments and/or clusters. However, the report focuses very heavily on using cohesion policies to meet the Europe 2020 objectives, places a strong emphasis on public-private funding and financial mechanisms, and identifies competitiveness is the main overarching goal of the innovation strategy. For these reasons I could not support the report entirely, so abstained.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With increasing global competition, it is crucial for the EU to continue to improve its innovation potential. RIS3 contribute to the efficient use of EU funds and unlock the potential of all regions, support the EU in combating innovation gaps and increase its competitiveness.  The report underlines the need for a regional approach in the implementation of RIS3 and calls on the EU and the Member States to monitor the implementation of the strategies on a regular period. RIS3 strategies are a valuable tool to close innovation gaps and boost employment and growth in Europe.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report, as it reports on the strengthening of the economy through the efficient use of EU funds under RIS3. More innovation is needed to create high-quality jobs.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In this period of economic recession and financial and social crisis, we want the EU to develop into a smart, sustainable and unrestricted economy in the context of the Europe 2020 strategy. In the context of the 2014-2020 programming period, it was therefore stipulated that regions should focus their investments on research, development and innovation through smart specialisation strategies (RIS3). These strategies, drawn up by national and regional authorities across Europe, contribute to making the use of EU structural and investment funds more efficient and increasing synergies between different national and regional policies at EU level, as well as between public and private investment. In addition, RIS3 will help to make the European economy more competitive, create European added value in innovation, create more and better high-quality jobs and add a wide range of new experiences; It is very positive that RIS3 supports job creation not only at important poles of research and innovation but also in less developed and rural areas. I voted in favour of the report which focuses on the main points that need to be improved with a view to better shaping the strategies.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this report because as usual, it was filled with buzz words and phrases that sound impressive but which will do nothing to create growth and jobs. The EU’s obsessive interference and over regulation damages both jobs and growth and we fail to see how buzz words and corporate speak will change that.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour because one of my priorities is to encourage innovation at all levels. I believe that RIS3 aims to create knowledge- based growth not only in well-developed areas, but also in less-developed and rural regions. The report sends a support signal from the EU to RIS3 strategies, calls for them to be improved and also to for lessons to be learned from the strategies already initiated in order to achieve the best results in the forthcoming years in this area.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. One of the priorities of cohesion policy is to develop research, technological development and innovation, which focuses on RIS3 strategies. The ultimate goal of these strategies is to create sustainable and inclusive economic growth, which is imperative for the EU because it is in an economic, financial and social crisis.  I support this resolution because of these views and provisions. The resolution makes it clear that RIS3 strategies are aimed at strengthening the competitiveness of the European economy and contribute to developing an entrepreneurial spirit, achieving balanced development and creating high-quality jobs. In addition, these strategies contribute to the efficient use of EU funds and therefore affect all Member States with a view to unleashing the potential of all regions. In this regard, the resolution proposes certain standards and guidelines such as complying with the new provisions on ex ante conditions for the allocation of ESI funds and supporting the role of the S3 platform. The resolution also underlines the importance of the top-up process, which is why each Member State should give local and regional authorities a chance to shape their views.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The report touts the research and innovation strategy for smart specialisation, which is supposed to be part of the new European Investment Policy with the European Fund for Strategic Investments (The Juncker Plan). It guides the implementation of cohesion policy and the payment of the European Regional Economic Development Fund (ERDF). He believes that the Union's economic strategy must focus on specialisation and innovation.  Nothing is planned on the principle of labeling (innovative companies) or the thorny problem of patents and industrial espionage. There is no criticism of austerity policies.  The governance of the strategy must be multi-level and compatible with the Europe 2020 strategy. The guidelines are decided by the European Commission, not by the states. The European Union is using the SRI-SI strategy to strengthen direct relations between the European Commission and the regions, which have become the management authorities of the ERDF, at the expense of cooperation between nations.  It should also be noted that the SRI-SI strategy promotes thematic concentration, which has the effect of relying exclusively on large clusters or research clusters without supporting small structures. For all these reasons, I am voting against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ As in these times of economic, financial and social crisis, the EU must make more efforts to generate smart, sustainable and inclusive economic growth, and that the timely and successful development of RIS3 strategies in the Member States largely depends on their growing administrative capacity to programme, prepare budgets, implement and evaluate within the policy framework to increase private investment in R&D and innovation.  This development should take into account the fact that initial assessments of smart specialisation strategies gave a vague picture, in particular as regards the choice of priorities that were often considered too general or insufficiently linked to regional economic and innovation structures, which means that smart specialisation strategies need to be improved in this regard. For all of the above, I support the adoption of the proposed report.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) stipulates that, in the 2014-2020 programming period, regions should concentrate investment in RIS, through smart specialisation strategies. Within this framework, RIS3 is an ex ante condition for the granting of European Structural and Investment Funds (EIS Funds) to EU Member States and regions. These funds can only be granted, quite rightly, as a result of the achievement of certain objectives, including: the development of regular quantitative and qualitative monitoring; the development of participatory processes; stakeholder involvement, with a particular focus on the private sector; the creation of synergies between public and private actors; coordination between all levels of governance and the identification of alternative financing arrangements. I believe that it is vital that the European Union continues to strengthen its ability to invest in research and development. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of adopting this resolution.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 During the last mandate, the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) agreed in the context of supporting the first thematic objective that regions must target investment in research, technological development and innovation through smart specialisation strategies during the 2014-2020 programming period. RIS3 is therefore an ex ante condition for EU Member States and regions to receive support through the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF). All European regions have a RIS3 strategy. These strategies were developed and implemented in 2014 and 2015. The application of the ex ante condition has proved to be an important step forward, as most regions have already adopted the RIS3 strategy. However, some of them must continue their work to meet the requirements of the ex ante RIS3 condition. The report highlights the key importance of RIS3 for the contribution of cohesion policy to the europe 2020 objectives, the role of multi-level governance in the strategy-setting process, the role of the EU Urban Agenda in creating synergies and strong links for the efficient use of resources, the role of supervision and evaluation. I hereby supported this report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for Smart Specialisation (SRI-SI).  These strategies, which are a precondition for the allocation of European structural funds and investments, promote the thematic programming and concentration of funds.  This text draws conclusions from the initial implementation of these strategies and reaffirms its support for the European Union to strengthen SRI-SI strategies in the years to come.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this report because as usual, it was filled with buzz words and phrases that sound impressive but which will do nothing to create growth and jobs. The EU’s obsessive interference and over regulation damages both jobs and growth and we fail to see how buzz words and corporate speak will change that.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because in my view it is increasingly fundamental to bet on sustainable innovation as a way of tackling the scarcity of budgetary resources as well as competition worldwide. RIS3 strategies, because of their importance in contributing Cohesion Policy to the Europe 2020 objectives, should be the result of constant revision. Since innovation is constantly evolving, it is also important to highlight the areas in which strategies should focus, through the analysis of priorities, strengths and potentialities of each region, quantitative and qualitative periodic monitoring, the creation of synergies between public and private actors, also allowing the reduction of bottlenecks in administrative procedures, enabling advice to regions in order to define and refocus their strategies. Innovation should be used to strengthen the administrative capacity of public authorities, especially at local and regional level, using new technologies and focusing on streamlining procedures to better serve the public. It is essential that regions develop their innovative ideas and work together to avoid duplication of effort and misuse of resources.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In an era of economic downturn and scarcity of budgetary resources, as well as increasingly close competition at global level, it is crucial for the EU to sustainably improve its capacity for innovation in research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation. We will have to look with particular attention to the continuous review of these same strategies; analyzing priorities, strengths and potentialities of each region; developing participation processes; creating synergies between public and private actors; coordinating across all levels of governance and departments and identifying alternative funding pathways and, finally, simplifying and reducing administrative procedures.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The goal of RIS3 strategies is to drive intelligent, sustainable and knowledge-based inclusive growth capable of generating quality jobs in all regions, not just developed areas. These strategies contribute to the thematic concentration and strategic programming of the European Structural and Investment Funds (EIES) and lead to greater focus on results on the ground. Two years after the start of its implementation, this report focuses on the main areas of ris3 improvement. In particular, it underlines the need to promote coordinated and complementary use of EMSEs with the Horizon 2020 programme and the European Fund for Strategic Investments to drive innovation at regional, national and Union level, increasing the attractiveness of investments in research and innovation in order to attract private capital as a complement to public funding , for which local and regional authorities are asked to make the most of the possibilities for combining these instruments. It also stresses the need to improve coordination between all levels of governance and to give civil society a more active role. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for Smart Specialisation (SRI-SI).  Indeed, the development of research and innovation for intelligent specialisation should be encouraged, as these should increase European economic competitiveness and create more quality jobs.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which discusses the benefits and major challenges of cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies. It should be noted that these strategies are important as they can address the innovation gap in Europe, boost jobs and growth. However, not everything has been done in cohesion policy. Interregional cooperation needs to be increased, especially in the case of large, value-added projects for the economy. Equally important is the idea in the document that better coordination at all levels of governance can be achieved by promoting a top-down vision of regional strategies. I believe that this is the principle of activity that can lead to much better results.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3) are an ex-ante conditionality for the allocation of funding through the EEI Funds (European Structural and Investment). In fact, RIS3 strategies support the thematic concentration objectives and strategic programming of the EEI Funds, promoting their 'performance orientation'. This report, which examined the relationship/inclusion of these strategies under cohesion policy, reflects Parliament's position on them in the implementation of the current Multiannual Financial Framework, demonstrating the European Parliament's support for the implementation 'on the ground' of RIS3 strategies, calls for their deepening and a permanent learning process with the projects that have been approved or in the implementation phase, simplification of procedures and greater coordination in the implementation of the current programmes. The report, which I voted in favour of, underlines that ris3 strategies are not aimed exclusively at the most developed regions. On the contrary, they aim to be an intelligent, innovative and effective means of enhancing the strengths and opportunities of the less developed regions, creating synergies for the development of a more knowledge-based economy, creating value and added value for the population.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which gives the first conclusions and the position of the European Parliament on SRI-SI strategies.  SRI-SI strategies mean research and innovation strategies for intelligent specialization and are an ex ante conditionality for funding. They promote the thematic concentration and strategic programming of ESI funds and lead, on the ground, to a more effective approach to their implementation.  I voted in favour of this text, which sends a signal of support from the European Union for SRI-SI strategies, calls for some improvements and thus lead to better results in the coming years.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report which supports cohesion policies and research and innovation strategies for smart specialization (RIS3). RIS3 contributes to the strategic programming of the Cohesion Funds and can play a key role in meeting the Europe 2020 targets, in the pursuit of balanced and sustainable development and in the creation of quality jobs. It also proposes support for multi-level governance and greater participation at all levels in aid programmes. Although the report contains many 'wind odes' I am in favour of technological and social innovation, the evaluation of the aid system, the strengthening of the strengths of each region and SMEs, in order to achieve more sustainable development.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of cohesion policy and smart specialisation research and innovation strategies, as this is an important signal for a Europe of solidarity. Cohesion policy is designed to strengthen economic, social and territorial cohesion. It is necessary to reduce differences between the different regions and the backwardness of the least-favoured areas. Research and innovation strategies are a condition for the allocation of funds from the European Structural and Investment Fund (ESI). They aim to create growth based on knowledge based on each region's respective strengths and potential, not only in advanced areas, but also in less developed and rural areas.

name: María Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted abstention in this report, because despite containing positive aspects it promotes the logic of markets as de facto rulers of States and their citizens, and enhances public-private financing in cohesion policy. The report deals with the objective of innovation within the 2020 Strategy. It treats innovation from a very broad perspective, supporting technological development as well as experience-based social innovation. It promotes regional innovation and its adaptability to the particular circumstances of the environment. It also promotes better accountability and evaluation systems. There is a lack of reflection and pronouncement on the relocation of jobs destroyed by technological innovation, as well as on the phenomenon of the concentration of wealth generated by intelligent specialization.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The existence of research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3) is one of the ex ante conditions for granting European Structural and Investment Funds to EU Member States and regions for the 2014-2020 programming period. In order to successfully pursue this new strategic approach, it is important that the implementation of these strategies is based on local and regional strengths. The regions are well placed to choose the right priorities, starting with the strengthening of their respective characteristics, potential and competitive advantages. Research and innovation are important factors in reviving growth. Some 121 RIS3 strategies are currently in place at national and regional level. A total of EUR 250 billion is expected to be mobilised by 2020. To continue in this direction, innovative policy approaches need to be promoted in order to boost interregional cooperation, simplify procedures and reduce bottlenecks in the administrative process of strategies, improve synergies between EIS funds and other EU financial instruments and provide more support for SMEs and start-ups. These are some of the recommendations made in the report with which I fully agree. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. Cohesion policy is the distinctive mark of the European Union, reflecting the practice of solidarity that underlies its construction. Cohesion policy serves as a catalyst for national public policies aimed at fostering economic development and growth, employment opportunities, more and better education and social inclusion. This is of particular relevance in regions of Europe where there are greater social, economic and territorial disparities and which inevitably have less resilience in the face of economic crisis.  The outermost regions are part of this context. I therefore call for cohesion policy to remain part of the EU's political priorities, resulting in its adequate funding. I dispute any attempt to penalise Member States suffering from major macroeconomic imbalances by suspending policy instruments with an impact on cohesion, which are rightly central to relaunching investment, the economy and job creation. The possibility of suspending the Structural Funds implies a double penalty which follows a logic that deviates from the principle of founding solidarity of the Union and which approaches before a strategy of absolute strangulation of economies suffering from additional weaknesses. This is a logic I can only repudiate.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this report due it being an EU Commission project and we do not recognise their competency in this area.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 At a time of constant fighting against the effects of the crisis and the associated budgetary constraints, as well as increasing global competition from countries such as the US, China and South Korea, it is crucial for the EU to continuously increase its innovation capacity. Europe 2020 is the EU's growth strategy for the period up to 2020. In a changing world, we want the EU to become an intelligent and sustainable and inclusive economy. The Union wants to achieve five ambitious targets for employment, innovation, education, social inclusion and climate/energy by 2020. In each of these areas, each Member State has also set its own national targets. This strategy is behind concrete actions at national and EU level. National and regional authorities across Europe will develop smart specialisation strategies to make more efficient use of the European Structural and Innovation Funds and to increase synergies between different EU, national and regional policies, as well as public and private investment. These strategies should contribute to bridging the innovation gap and increasing employment and boosting economic growth in Europe. It is now clear that a number of improvements can be made to the strategy. Public authorities should endea prudence to monitoring and reviewing strategies in order to maximise their results.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – With my EPLP colleagues I voted in favour of this report because innovation is an area that is continuously changing, RIS 3 strategies should be constant revised. For this purpose, a review of the strategies after 2017 seems mandatory in order to boost the efficiency and effectiveness of them, taking also into account the lessons learned from the initial years of their implementation

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I see the Cohesion Policy Strategy and the Research and Innovation Strategy for Smart Specialisation (RIS3) as a very valuable tool for addressing innovation disparities and increasing employment and growth across Europe. I also consider strengthening research, technological development and innovation to be one of the investment priorities under the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) for 2014-2020. Although the RIS3 strategy is currently developed by all European regions and their implementation began in 2014 and 2015, I would like to point out the disparity in promoting innovation in the EU and within member states, which varies considerably, especially as regards the use of knowledge and technology in promoting innovation. I am of the opinion that RIS3 needs to be constantly reviewed and constantly adapted to the changes that are taking place in the field of specialisation. I supported the resolution mainly because it comes with measures that can significantly help make RIS3 strategies more efficient and effective. I also expect the report to improve the quality of cooperation between administrations and relevant actors in the regions, which will have a decisive impact on the RIS3 strategy, and to clearly reduce the risk of mis-selection of priorities.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Smart specialisation can help guide investment and concentration of research and innovation in areas where most regional and local competences are present.  The differences that arise between European regions in the field of research and innovation suggest that there is a need for policies that will be tailor-made according to local needs. Smart specialisation offers the possibility of differentiation and economic transformation based on innovation, based on local resources and comparative advantages. Efforts and investments will thus focus on a limited number of priorities identified in a process in which entrepreneurs and researchers will play a major role. Smart specialisation has become a major principle and a prerequisite for the european Regional Development Fund (ERDF) to be obtained.  The report thus reiterates the important role of smart specialisation played by it in cohesion policy. I believe that this is the right direction for development in this area, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: writing \u2012 Innovative practices and the use of modern technologies help to increase economic growth, reduce unemployment and reduce costs as much as possible. On the basis of the principle of subsidiarity, we are proceeding to involve municipalities as closely as possible in these processes, especially in underdeveloped regions. The optimal setting of cooperation between European institutions, national governments, schools, municipalities and the business environment will be crucial.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3). I reject cohesion policy as a purely redistributing instrument. The AfD stands for independent and strong local authorities in Germany. We want to enable regional and local self-government and guarantee subsidiarity, so that regional peculiarities and peculiarities can be maintained. We want to give more weight to federalism. The AfD is thus already somewhat sceptical about a policy of regional balance within Germany. At EU level, it has nothing to do with it. We stand for strong and independent nation states. I reject the specialisation of the regions, which is centrally planned and promoted by cohesion policy, which will enable them to identify and select priority areas for their development and related investments.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Research and innovation strategies for smart specialisations (RIS3) are a condition of funding from the European Structural and Investment Funds. RIS3 supports thematic concentrations and strategic programming of european social fund funds and aims to improve implementation on the ground.  This report provides us with the first indicators of the implementation of the 2014-2019 strategy. In times of economic, financial and social crisis, the EU must make more efforts to create smart, sustainable and inclusive economic growth.  I support this proposal for a Resolution on Cohesion Policy and Research and Innovation Strategies for Smart Specialisation, as I think it is important that smart specialisation combines and links different policies, in particular entrepreneurship, education and innovation policies, so that regions can identify and select priority areas for their development and link investments by focusing on their strengths and relative strengths.  The ultimate goal is to create more high-quality jobs and contribute strategies to expanding good practices and developing a new entrepreneurial spirit.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation.  I support Europe's efforts to create knowledge-based and sustainable growth, balanced development and high-quality jobs in all regions. This is particularly important in times of economic crisis. It is cohesion policy that is the concern that Europe is growing steadily, that there are no excessive disparities in development between the different regions in the EU.  I support the call for regions to develop innovative support service schemes that complement or replace existing services in order to enable individual regions to achieve their full competitive potential.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report as it promotes the development of innovation by giving a wide range of options for balanced development through investments in unfavourable regions, regions as well as less developed, rural and island regions. It also places particular emphasis on harnessing technological development to create new quality jobs and support SMEs.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy, apart from being non-functional in general, does not lead to the creation of quality positions. On the contrary, it has caused a great loss of valuable human resources in our country, as in all the other economically weak countries of the Union.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 Finland has always been the leading country in innovation, and this has created economic growth. This report pointed out that innovation should be supported effectively throughout the European Union in the future, which is an absolutely essential enabler of economic growth. For these reasons, among others, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ During the year 2014, regions have started to develop and publish their RIS3 strategies. The aim of these strategies is to create knowledge-based, sustainable growth, balanced development and high quality jobs in all regions, not only in well-developed areas but also in regions in transition as well as in less developed, rural and island regions. All this shall contribute to the achievement of the Europe 2020 objectives. I agree with the main areas identified by the report, where improvement for RIS3 should be carried out. Moreover, this report provides excellent options for boosting innovation at regional, national and EU levels. Because innovation is an area that is continuously changing, I believe that RIS 3 strategies should be constant revised. Therefore, I support the review of the strategies after 2017, which seems mandatory in order to boost the efficiency and effectiveness of them, taking also into account the lessons learned from the initial years of their implementation.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. IRS-SI is a valuable tool to close the innovation gap and to boost jobs and growth in Europe.  For the time being, there is still room for improvement in the development of strategies. The authorities should endeavour to pay particular attention to monitoring and revising strategies in order to maximise the results achieved and, on the other hand, inter-regional cooperation, in order to develop ambitious projects and create added value for the economy.  The simplification and coordination of existing programmes is also essential to contribute to the successful implementation of strategies in the years to come.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In an increasingly competitive global environment, it is crucial that the EU keeps improving its capacity to innovate. I voted in favour of the report on Cohesion Policy and Research and Innovation Strategies for smart specialisation, as these strategies will be valuable to overcome Europe’s innovation gap and encourage growth. In fact, by combining and bringing together different policies, including those for entrepreneurship, education and innovation, RIS3 enables regions to identify and select priority areas for their development and investments. RIS3 is also a condition for receiving European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF), and therefore contributes to an increased performance orientation on the ground. Moreover, I am very supportive of including a review of the strategies after 2017, in order to ensure their continuing relevance and maximise their output.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Cohesion Policy Report and the Smart Specialisation Research and Innovation Strategies (RIS3), as it encourages job creation, namely high-quality jobs that need to be created not only in developed areas but also in transitionally less developed regions.  I believe that the proposed social innovations will contribute to the establishment of new business models and cultures. I believe that this report is a good path to the successful development of Europe and the Member States, primarily less developed regions.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal on cohesion policy and research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3).  The aim of the latter is to create knowledge-based and sustainable growth, balanced development and high-quality jobs in all regions, including less developed, rural and island regions. RIS3 strategies are an important tool for closing the innovation gap and promoting employment and growth in Europe.  For the time being, we can see that the establishment of strategies still gives amp; potential for change. Public authorities should endeavour to pay particular attention to the monitoring and review of strategies in order to maximise their impact and interregional cooperation, thereby creating ambitious projects that create added value for the economy.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report which supports cohesion policies and research and innovation strategies for smart specialization (RIS3). RIS3 contributes to the strategic programming of the Cohesion Funds and can play a key role in meeting the Europe 2020 targets, in the pursuit of balanced and sustainable development and in the creation of quality jobs. It also proposes support for multi-level governance and greater participation at all levels in aid programmes, as well as the creation of positive synergies in the different regions to determine their strengths. Although the report contains many 'wind odes' I am in favour of technological and social innovation, the evaluation of the aid system, the strengthening of the strengths of each region and SMEs, in order to achieve more sustainable development.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report extols the merits of the research and innovation strategy for smart specialisation, a strategy that is supposed to be part of the new European Investment Policy with the European Fund for Strategic Investments (The Juncker Plan).  This framing document guides the implementation of cohesion policy and the payment of the European Regional Economic Development Fund (ERDF). Overall, the SRI-SI duplicates national research policies and, above all, state-region plans. This report does not present any criticism of austerity policies on public and private budgets to support research and innovation policies.  The governance of the strategy must be multi-level and compatible with the Europe 2020 strategy. This means that the French state is not leading the implementation of this strategy which responds to the guidelines decided by the European Commission. It should also be noted that the SRI-SI strategy promotes thematic concentration, which has the effect of relying exclusively on large clusters or research clusters without supporting small structures and innovation clusters. So I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 RIS3 strategies are an important factor in the economy as they fill innovation gaps, strengthen investment efficiency and provide an stimulus for employment growth. Public institutions, which monitor interregional cooperation and support regional specialisations, can ensure stable growth and economic development across Europe. Given the experience gained in the first years of the project, in order to be able to increase the relevance of the bottom-up initiative and to highlight the importance of civil society, it is important to listen to the local authorities of the different areas involved in the project.  The strategy is an important element in shaping economic development and strengthening the strength of the regions, which is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In times of economic recession and consequently severe budgetary constraints and increasing global competition, it is vital for the EU to sustainably improve its capacity to innovate. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I vote in favour of this report which supports cohesion policies and research and innovation strategies for smart specialization (RIS3). RIS3 contributes to the strategic programming of the Cohesion Funds and can play a key role in meeting the Europe 2020 targets, in the pursuit of balanced and sustainable development and in the creation of quality jobs. It also proposes support for multi-level governance and greater participation at all levels in aid programmes, as well as the creation of positive synergies in the different regions to determine their strengths. Although the report contains many 'wind odes' I am in favour of technological and social innovation, the evaluation of the aid system, the strengthening of the strengths of each region and SMEs, in order to achieve more sustainable development.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for, as smart specialisation can help channelling investment and concentrate research and innovation on areas which are linked to local or regional competences, qualifications and assets regardless of their size.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on Cohesion Policy and Research and Innovation Strategies for Smart Specialisation (RIS3).
