The RIS3 supports a broad definition of innovation as signifying the transformation of an idea into a new or improved product or service introduced on the market, into a new or improved operational process used in industry and commerce, or into a new approach to a social service. I strongly believe that in these times of economic, financial and social crisis the EU must step up its efforts to create smart, sustainable and inclusive economic growth. I voted in favour because I am of the opinion that RIS3 should help make the European economy more competitive, develop European added value in innovation, create more and better high-quality jobs, and take on board a wide range of new experiences.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Research and innovation strategies for smart specialization are a fundamental tool to combat the economic crisis and high unemployment in Europe. The knowledge economy is a vital tool for promoting quality employment in the Union and being able to give our young people the opportunities they deserve. This report has taken into account the opinion of the experts in the area, as well as that of the vast majority of the political groups in the chamber and aims to give a clear signal of support from this Parliament to these strategies, emphasizing the need for data to assess their current implementation, in order to , be able to learn from possible mistakes and improve them for the future. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'This report focuses on the role of research and innovation strategies. Europe is using financial resources to promote innovation as an engine for growth in employment and investment in the future of EU industrial policy. I voted in favour of this report because, in these times of economic, financial and social crisis, the EU must make additional efforts to create smart, sustainable and economic growth.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In a period of economic recession, and as a result of the constraints of the Euro, it should be crucial for the EU to sustainably improve its capacity for innovation.  In practice, none of this happens. Cohesion policy is even becoming an asymmetric element. Indeed, today, it is the rich countries that absorb research support and poor countries that are left with ESF crumbs to reduce austerity data.  Portugal forms the thousands of researchers who migrated to other countries due to the discontinuity of research projects. These are crimes we are committing, the consequences of which will last for many years.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report sees RIS3 as an important tool for addressing the innovation gap and for promoting jobs and growth in Europe. In principle, it is a very balanced report on and on smart specialisation. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Innovation is, by definition, a cross-cutting concept. I therefore welcome the effort made in this report to build synergies across policy areas and better coordinate funding tools that are crucial for the sustainable development of regions, in both urban and rural areas. I attended the European Symposium on Science (ESOF) 2016 last July in my region in Manchester, and where I co-hosted with my Greek S&D colleague Eva Kaili a session on the natural links between the Arts and Science. This session confirmed that there is a demand in both communities to work beyond the obvious and to change the mentality of working in silos. Attending businesses, scientists and artists all argued in favour of a more global approach to innovation, and to jointly explore their common impact on societies. For me this should be the essence of ‘smart specialisation’ strategies. Smart specialisation should not only be seen as a tick box exercise for jobs and growth, but help us answer ecological, social, economic and cultural challenges. And we must invest in creative thinking and transferable skills if the EU wants to be at the forefront of innovation in a fast changing world.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the own-initiative report on Cohesion Policy and Research and Innovation Strategies for Smart Specialisation (RIS3). The rapporteur believes that at a time of economic recession and inevitable budgetary constraints, as well as increasing global competition, it is essential that the EU continually improves its innovation potential. In its view, RIS3 is a valuable tool to close the innovation gap and boost job creation and growth in Europe.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 As a condition for companies receiving financial support through the European Structural Funds, EU Member States and regions have priorly targeted investment in research, technological development and innovation through smart specialisation strategies. This strategy is an instrument for the implementation of development policy and aims to support EU countries in developing their own economic development pathways, boosting business development and ensuring their further growth.  The limited EU budget, as well as the economic recession around the world, have forced companies to increase their competitiveness by increasing their innovation capacity. Today, all European regions have a smart specialisation strategy. They were developed and started in 2014 and 2015. The report promotes support for companies by stimulating their development, which consequently increases their international competitiveness.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report analyses the role of smart growth and innovation in multi-level governance. It also lays down the necessary conditions for the effective implementation of smart strategies. Finally, it encourages synergies aimed, inter alia, at boosting employment and creating new jobs. I voted in favour.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Research and innovation strategies for smart specialization (RIS3) are an ex ante condition for the allocation of funding for the EIE Funds. RIS3 supports the thematic concentration and strategic programming of the EIE Funds and gives rise to a greater focus on the performance of their implementation on the ground. It aims to create knowledge-based growth, not only in developed areas, but also in less developed areas and rural regions.  This report is the first by the European Parliament in the 2014-2019 legislative period in which it expresses its support for RIS3 strategies. It advocates an improvement of the strategies already initiated and greater learning from them, in order to achieve better results in the coming years. I am in favour of this report because it not only favours the less favoured regions but is also positive for all Europeans.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Valcárcel Siso report because I believe that the proposals put forward for smart specialisation strategies contribute to achieving the Europe 2020 objectives through knowledge-based sustainable growth, balanced development and high-quality job creation. I underline the role of the S3 platform, created by the Commission's DG REGIO and located in the SEIC JRC, which plays an essential role in advising regions and defining benchmarks for their innovation strategies, strengthening multi-level governance and synergies between regions, by providing information, methodologies, expertise and advice to national and regional policy makers.  I also advocate that the S3 platform in Seville pays special attention to the less developed regions, and in particular should help them to set up and guide their strategies.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on Cohesion Policy and Research and Innovation Strategies for Smart Specialisation (RIS3). I agree that, in these times of economic, financial and social crisis, the European Union must step up its efforts for smart, sustainable and inclusive economic growth.  I therefore believe that research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3) will contribute to making the European economy more competitive, developing European added value in innovation, creating more high-quality jobs and gaining a wide range of new experiences.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we recognise the potential of territorial cooperation. A significant part of the European population lives in cross-border areas and, in turn, these cross-border regions are mostly depressed regions, often suffering from the problems inherent in the interiority and remoteness of large centres.  We regret, however, all the propaganda around the successive Interreg programmes, as if it were possible to do something tangible with just a few crumbs. It is perhaps not by chance that there is no minimally objective balance on the impact of 25 years of territorial cooperation. There is no visible impact on the socio-economic development of these regions, much less on cross-border permeability, whether on trade or on infrastructure sharing.  But the criticism we make extends to cohesion policy at the global level, which is, of course, extended to territorial cooperation. This cohesion policy which has led to a substantial cut in the current multiannual framework is unfortunately increasingly a mirage and is increasingly on the backof the European Union's neoliberal agendas. Cohesion policy is today conditioned not on the needs of local regions and development strategies, but rather on the neoliberal agenda of the European Union.  The most serious policy, cohesion policy, in the implementation, tends to become an element of asymmetries, when we see funds to support innovation centralised in the richest countries in the North, and funds to support long-term unemployment are drained to the South with the aim of alleviating the consequences of liberalisation policies imposed by the European Union. We need to put an end to this situation by breaking with this model and strering for a new Europe of peace and cooperation. If we really want social and territorial cohesion, we challenge the European institutions to double the cohesion budget and to completely change their costumes in order to give the regions freedom to choose their development strategies according to their characteristics, and then, yes, we can actually fight against regional asymmetries.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this report because I believe that territorial cooperation is fundamental to the implementation of cohesion policy, and cooperation with border countries cannot be separated. For border regions, such as my own, Sicily in southern Italy, cooperation with neighbouring regions is essential to grow and pursue development results based on the exploitation of the same resources: a common culture, a tradition and above all shared stories.  The objective of territorial cooperation is to grow together, which is a concept that border regions are very familiar with, as well as to face the same difficulties. That is why the Commission should certainly extend and encourage territorial cooperation programmes and place them in the broader context of the new challenges facing the Union: first of all, as we know, migration and terrorism.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, 38% of the European population lives in cross-border regions and cooperates from all points of view: people live together, and this cooperation is a key element for stability in those regions, for jobs, for development, for investment. That is why I supported this report and I stress the emphasis on developing investments and sending funds to these regions precisely to ensure their further development and to ensure their stability. Again, regional integration is important, because there is also the issue of the migration crisis and immigrants who arrive in such regions, how they are integrated or if they are integrated. Therefore, very much attention to this regional cooperation and, once again, funds commensurate with the efforts that those there are making.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, with regard to territorial territorial cooperation, I would like to say that this is indeed a prerequisite for a cohesion policy to work. I think we should promote cohesion policy more, not just the stars. I think that cohesion policy, in this form of territorial cooperation, should show how regions can work together and bring other benefits, whether it be eliminating disadvantages or creating jobs. The creation of regional GDP is very important. In this sense, it is important that territorial cohesion is part of a cohesion policy that will also be a firm part of European regional development policy. I believe that it is not good for us to weaken cohesion policy with some special instruments, which has a strong place on the EU agenda and I am very happy that we can support it.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 European Territorial Cooperation (CEA) is one of the objectives of the Cohesion Policy of the Europe 2020 strategy. It plays a key role in research and development. That is why it is necessary to introduce monitoring systems and evaluation plans that ensure greater transparency useful for achieving the objectives in terms of territorial integration. At the same time, however, I believe that wider use of financial instruments, together with subsidies, is not really adequate for the implementation of European territorial cooperation programmes. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain from voting.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We voted against this report because it enshrines the EU principle of harmonising everything and refusing to allow different regions and territories to have their own way of developing. This report will not help the situation.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this own initiative report focusing on improving the effective use of the Interreg initiative (a Community Initiative in place since 1990) in order to develop European Territorial Cooperation (ETC). The overarching objective of ETC is to lessen the influence of borders in order to reduce disparities between regions, removing the remaining obstacles to investment and cooperation across borders. The report calls for increased funds to be directed towards ETC, for cross-border innovation policy and research cooperation, and for a focus on projects that promote the adaptation of social and mobility infrastructure to demographic change and migratory flows.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, believing that European territorial cooperation is fully involved in improving the economic, social and territorial potential of our regions.  I regret the outcome of the negotiations on the 2014-2020 multi-year financial framework with regard to the credits for European territorial cooperation which have been greatly reduced.  In this resolution we call on the Commission and the Member States to maintain European territorial cooperation as an instrument of European integration.  We also call for a more specific role in cohesion policy after 2020 to be given a more specific role for European territorial cooperation, and finally to increase its budget for the next programming period.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on European territorial cooperation (ETC). ETC so far has made a significant contribution to strengthening the EU’s objective of territorial cohesion through integrating diverse sectorial policies on a territorial scale. However, the ETC budget of EUR 10.1 billion represents only 2.8% of the total cohesion policy budget; therefore, an increased budget for ETC in the next programming period will boost the added value of cohesion policy. The report also calls for greater respect for Article 174 TFEU on territorial cohesion (rural areas, islands, cross-border and mountains regions, outermost regions). The report underlines the lack of reliable data on cross-border cooperation and thus calls on the Commission, Eurostat and other managing authorities to cooperate with the aim to set up common criteria and a common database. The ETC programmes have proved to be effective; however, their potential should be further developed in areas beyond regional policy such as the single market, the digital agenda, employment, mobility, energy, research, education, culture, health and the environment. The report calls on the Commission and the Member States to consider preserving ETC as an important instrument.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on European territorial cooperation (ECA) because, regardless of the small budget, ECA projects have important results in areas such as transport, education, energy, healthcare, training and employment.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Since the launch of the ETC (Interreg) programme some 25 years ago, it has become one of the most important instruments for territorial cohesion. A whole series of programmes with high European added value and a special impact on the European border regions have already been supported under this programme. In this context, value could be created in important sectors such as networking, innovation and knowledge, culture or education. Cross-border cooperation is a key instrument for the development of border regions. In particular, as a resident and representative of a border region, I support these measures, which are intended to contribute to improving territorial cooperation.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report encourages the use of territorial cooperation to finance the reception of illegal immigrants, in particular through Interreg programmes; these programmes are also intended to facilitate labour mobility within the Union.  In addition, territorial cooperation is used to finance the European Union's neighbourhood and enlargement policies. It focuses on the thematic concentration that shifts away from more local projects, leading to an increase in regional disparities. In addition, the report calls for a rapid increase in the budget for territorial cooperation, which already amounts to EUR 10.1 billion for the 2014-2020 programming period, or 2.8% of the cohesion policy budget, while acknowledging that there is no reliable quantitative data demonstrating the effectiveness of these territorial cooperation programmes. Therefore, I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of transparency and democracy I voted against this report. I believe that the UK should be good neighbours to the European Union. However there is a difference in being willing to share best practices with other countries and other countries, although the EU forcing us to do so.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation by my colleague Iskra Mihaylova because this report clearly shows that "Interreg" has proved its effectiveness.  It also highlights its potential beyond regional policy, in areas such as the single market, digital agenda, employment, mobility, culture, health and the environment.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which aims to continue to promote European territorial cooperation (ETC) activities, which have become one of the two equivalent objectives of cohesion policy for 2014-2020. ETC is an effective tool for developing potential in areas such as the Single Market, the Digital Agenda, employment, mobility, energy, research, education, health and environmental protection, and it is therefore necessary to preserve ETC as an important instrument beyond 2020 and to substantially increase its budget.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this report because it enshrines the EU principle of harmonising everything and refusing to allow different regions and territories to have their own way of developing. This report will not help the situation.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which aims to strengthen European territorial cooperation by promoting 'welcoming migrants' by increasing the budget, which already stands at EUR 10.1 billion.  The place of illegal immigrants is not in reception centres, it is in charters back home.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have approved this initiative report which underlines the added value of European territorial cooperation, particularly in areas such as environmental protection and mobility.  Territorial cooperation has also enabled multiple collaborations between cities, improving many regional and local policies. In particular, the report calls on Member States to make greater use of cross-border cooperation programmes. It stresses the importance of creating cross-border innovation policy approaches such as joint research and mobility programmes. Finally, it stresses the need to further simplify the implementation of territorial cooperation programmes.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. The Interreg initiative has an absolutely European spirit, i.e. solving problems that cross national administrative boundaries and require common solutions. I voted in favour of this report because I think it is essential that after more than 25 years of action in regional cooperation we reflect on best practices and future challenges.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 European territorial cooperation has as its general objective to reduce the influence of national borders in order to reduce disparities between regions and the remaining obstacles to cross-border investment and cooperation activities. The Mihaylova report, which I supported with my vote, effectively underlines the role of CTE in cohesion policy, while stressing its tight funding, which does not live up to the high added value it can bring in areas such as transport, the environment, health and innovation. In the near future, CTE needs to be strengthened by further strengthening its innovative dimension. The involvement of more private actors must be called for, generating successful public-private cross-border partnerships and enabling integrated approaches to be implemented and disseminated. The harmonisation of planning instruments, administrative procedures and cross-border legal provisions is a further step that can ensure a real strengthening of cohesion and an effective promotion of the economic, social and cultural development of the Union as a whole.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I think it is crucial to reduce disparities between border regions and to promote peace, stability and regional integration in these areas. In addition, this dossier supports social adaptation and infrastructure mobility, with the aim of creating demographic change and promoting migration flows. It also supports the creation of jobs for the elderly, women and migrants in order to contribute to greater social integration.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 To promote the capacity and possibilities of regions to collaborate on a cross-border vertebra regime and builds Europe because it stimulates development, promotes coexistence in diversity and generates potential and possibilities that cannot curb old borders. We are also committed to simplifying the procedures and bureaucracy affecting this cooperation mechanic and we are committed to giving these policies a stellar role in cohesion policy beyond 2020.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I vehemently opposed this report, which uses the well-known dialectic of inherently positive concepts - here cooperation - for misguided objectives. Indeed, under the pretext of improving European territorial cooperation, this is in fact a lever towards the federalisation of the EU. So-called cooperation would therefore further erase national borders in favour of insinquitic projects such as the financing of the endless reception of migrants; the movement of workers in the mode of seconded workers, which is known to promote social dumping and the precariousness of national workers; or thematic concentration that will further increase the exclusion of rural areas in favour of maximum regions of the State Europe. In the details itself, this report is scandalous, since it also calls for an increase in the budget dedicated to territorial cooperation, when it already amounts to EUR 10.1 billion, and at the same time national public policies are under pressure from the austerity policies pursued by Brussels. The highlight of the show lies in these institutionalised platforms that would use taxpayers' money for pro-EU propaganda purposes.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report analysing best practices with regard to funding for territorial cooperation is balanced and acceptable. Our northern regions have already proved capable of exploiting these development opportunities by working with partners such as Austria and Slovenia; That is why I wanted to vote in favour of this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. European territorial cooperation (CTE) must be a key element of cohesion policy. It should be remembered that approximately 38% of the European population lives in border regions, so this policy is shown to be fundamental in promoting greater economic, social and territorial development in these regions. However, the CTE budget represents only 2.8% of the cohesion policy budget, so, as the report points out, it does not live up to the great challenges facing the CTE and does not reflect its high European added value. Hence the call for greater budgetary allocation for the next programming period, given the need to devote special attention to the most disadvantaged areas of the Union from a geographical and demographic point of view. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has given Parliament its position on European territorial cooperation, best practices and innovative instruments. The overarching objective of European territorial cooperation is to reduce the impact of national borders in order to reduce regional disparities, remove remaining barriers to investment and cooperation across borders, strengthen cohesion and promote sustainable economic, social, cultural and territorial development across the Union. Unfortunately, today, not enough Citizens of the European Union are making use of all the opportunities offered by the EU's internal market and free movement. The European Parliament therefore underlined that around 41% of the eu-20% in the period 2014-2020. The European Regional Development Fund will be invested in measures to improve the environment, 27% to strengthen smart growth, including research and innovation, and 13% will focus on promoting inclusive growth through employment, education and training activities, and 33 programmes will aim to improve cross-country connectivity in general.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The overall objective of European territorial cooperation is to reduce the impact of national borders, reduce regional disparities, remove remaining barriers to cross-border investment and joint work, strengthen cohesion and promote harmonious economic, social, cultural and territorial development of the Union as a whole. As some 38% of the European population lives in border regions and the EU is facing a major economic, financial and social crisis, the key policies must take these facts into account. I believe that European territorial cooperation has demonstrated its effectiveness, but its potential needs to be further explored. It is important that the report highlights its opportunities beyond regional policy in areas such as the single market, the digital agenda, employment, mobility, energy, research, education, culture, health and the environment. That is why I call on the Commission and the Member States to consider maintaining European territorial cooperation as an important instrument and even to give it a more prominent role in the post-2020 cohesion policy, while significantly increasing its budget. At the same time, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report, as the report contains a number of paragraphs (in addition to useful ideas) that would use cohesion funds to integrate immigrants.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Although it is always useful to question and share good practices, this report aims to weaken the role of states in favour of the EU's supranational power. In particular, it deals with eu enlargement, the reception of migrants, and promotes links with local authorities. Without justifying at any time the effectiveness of this policy, it calls for an increase in the already very large budget and calls on the States to promote it. For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 If we are aware that the European Union is the common home of all of us, it is natural to promote mutual cooperation and cooperation between the smaller administrative institutions of the Member States. The quality of this cooperation has important consequences both in terms of the efficiency of the institutions and services to the citizen, and in terms that are directly economic. Eurobarometer data show that greater cross-border cooperation is needed for the implementation of joint programmes, the way in which funds are used and accessed and how the programme is to be run simplified. All too often, citizens are not aware of the work of the programmes on their territory, of their activation, of the possible positive repercussions as services offered and as job opportunities. We must realise that the first step towards a Europe that is closer to its citizens is a Europe that communicates better and makes the results of its work comprehensible.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to strengthen territorial cooperation aimed at reducing the influence of national borders within the European Union.  Although territorial cooperation can encourage the proliferation of cross-border projects, it is another step towards the federalisation of the European Union. That is why I have opposed this report, which encourages the use of territorial cooperation to finance not only the Union's neighbourhood and enlargement policy but also the reception of illegal migrants, in particular through interreg programmes.  In addition, these new guidelines will require an increase in the budget for territorial cooperation, which already amounts to more than 10 billion euros for the period 2014-2020.  While there is no reliable quantitative data to demonstrate the effectiveness of territorial cooperation programmes, Member States are being asked to promote this policy by funding the creation of institutionalised communication platforms.  Finally, the implementation of territorial cooperation programmes is based on multi-level governance with increased participation of local authorities in decision-making bodies at the expense of national governments.  So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 European territorial cooperation makes a significant contribution to strengthening the Union's territorial cohesion objective, stimulating both economic growth and territorial development of the regions. Following the restructuring of the OTE in line with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, there is an increased positive impact, with the role of the TEC being a key one in the continuation of regional priorities. This instrument is present both at the level of cities and regions and outside national borders, encouraging the strengthening of regional cooperation and integration, especially in island regions. In terms of best practices, it is noted to improve regional connectivity, mobility and accessibility of services by overcoming cross-border problems with regard to the mobility of persons. I also welcome the strengthening of institutional capacity and social capital, the strengthening of cross-border network structures and the creation of new partnerships. I have expressed myself in favour of this report because I believe it is a valuable tool in ensuring regional stability and integration, making an important contribution to enlargement and neighbourhood policy.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. European territorial cooperation allows regions to cooperate and exchange best practices. They will then be able to pursue the objectives of cohesion policy as effectively as possible.  European territorial cooperation is divided into three parts: cross-border, transnational and inter-regional cooperation. This gives project owners the opportunity to partner to finance their projects in different areas such as employment, the environment or tourism.  It is important that this cooperation receives appropriate political and financial support to achieve its objective.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because European territorial cooperation (CTE) has been rethought in order to achieve greater impact and more effective use of investment through the focus on thematic concentration and result orientation. I believe that the new European territorial cooperation (CTE) is of primary importance because it can contribute to increasing the economic, social and territorial potential of the regions, reflecting and integrating different sectoral policies on a territorial scale, transcending national borders. However, I think it is necessary to make the implementation and management of programmes and projects for European territorial cooperation less bureaucratic. On the one hand, the Commission should harmonise the rules and models relating to European territorial cooperation programmes. On the other hand, Member States should simplify their national provisions in order to avoid unnecessary administrative burdens not attributable to Community legislation.  I believe that it is essential to promote European territorial cooperation in the field of research and innovation, such as joint research and cooperation projects between research institutes and businesses, the establishment of cross-border international universities, cross-border research centres, cross-border training institutes, the creation of cross-border business clusters and networks, cross-border incubators and consultancy services for SMEs.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this own initiative report focusing on improving the effective use of the Interreg initiative (a Community Initiative in place since 1990) in order to develop European Territorial Cooperation (ETC). The overarching objective of ETC is to lessen the influence of borders in order to reduce disparities between regions, removing the remaining obstacles to investment and cooperation across borders. The report calls for increased funds to be directed towards ETC, for cross-border innovation policy and research cooperation, and for a focus on projects that promote the adaptation of social and mobility infrastructure to demographic change and migratory flows.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The survey Flash Eurobarometer ‘Cross-border cooperation in the EU’ (2015) established that the majority of the people living in EU border regions are not aware of EU-funded cross-border cooperation activities in their region falling under the umbrella of European Territorial cooperation (ETC). Therefore, I agree that more effective communication on the results and achievements from completed projects is needed and also to enhance synergies with the other EU-funded programmes/initiatives. I also believe that all parties involved in ETC should provide critical analysis of project thematic achievements in order to provide recommendations for post-2020, and at the same time ensuring for projects a high level of quality, transparency and closeness to citizens. I agree with this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report makes a rather complete and detailed state of the art of the objectives, aims and criticality of the new framework for European territorial cooperation (CTE), with a number of positive points and others, on the other hand, which I do not entirely agree with. The most controversial aspects include the use of financial instruments from CTE programmes, particularly when a wider use of financial instruments as flexibility mechanisms to be used in parallel with grants is encouraged, or when it is stated that financial instruments should form an integral part of European territorial cooperation programmes. I do not agree with a single paragraph on private investment, but with a recommendation on the possible benefits of public-private partnerships, the risk of conflict of interest is highlighted, which should be adequately addressed through binding and non-binding legal instruments. For these reasons, I preferred to abstain on the final vote.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 European territorial cooperation (CTE) is one of the two pillars of EU cohesion policy, as well as a key initiative in promoting peace, stability and integration between European regions, and allows full benefit from the benefits of the internal market. In the 25 years of its existence it has given important added value, especially in addressing cross-border challenges, and can represent an opportunity for European regions, especially those most exposed to the migration crisis, which through the exchange of good practices can find common solutions and approaches.  In view of these positive results and the potential of the programme, I believe that the budget of EUR 10.1 billion (representing only 2.8% of the cohesion policy budget) will not be able to rise to the great challenges facing the CTE.  As with many complex programmes, the success of CTE depends very much on the administrative procedures required for its implementation. That is why we have called on the Commission to reduce the administrative burden and harmonise the procedures of the CTE programmes. In the light of these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and agree with the rapporteur's position on the need to reduce red tape in the management and implementation of ECA programmes and projects. The implementation of the ECA programmes remains complex and we therefore ask the High Level Group of Independent Experts to monitor simplification for beneficiaries of the European Structural and Investment Funds to consider measures to simplify and reduce the administrative burden on beneficiaries.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on European territorial cooperation and best practices and innovative measures concerns complex and different areas of cooperation between EU Member States. As we need improvements in this cooperation, I think the report is a good step and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of what is stated in Mrs Mihaylova's report, since the European Territorial Cooperation has enabled a great deal of progress to be made in terms of connectivity and innovation, especially in the Union's border regions. Territorial cooperation is one of the Europe 2020 objectives for cohesion and provides a framework for the implementation of joint actions and political exchanges between national, regional and local actors in the different Member States. I believe that it is essential to adequately support a project that for 25 years has implemented the most harmonious economic, social and territorial development possible, since this is one of the priorities for my territory.  The added value brought by the ETC emerges in many respects, ranging from an improvement in the regional connection to greater accessibility to services for citizens, thus allowing a speeding up of the transfer of knowledge and innovation, which in turn translates into greater competitiveness for our companies. In this way, in addition to giving rise to numerous entrepreneurial and institutional partnerships, it has nevertheless contributed to increasing the regional image and identity itself.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on European territorial cooperation – best practices and innovative measures, and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 European Territorial Cooperation (ETC) comprises the dimensions of cross-border, transnational and inter-regional cooperation and is one of the two objectives of cohesion policy.  Interreg's significant financial dimension for the period 2014-2020 (EUR 10.1 billion), which, in addition to these dimensions, includes the co-financing of regional development cooperation programmes outside the EU, attests to its importance, but also the need to debureaucratise and streamline processes in order to concentrate resources on priority objectives, strengthen the achievement of the Europe 2020 strategy and improve economic potential , social and territorial regions, integrating their sectoral policies. I believe that, in the 25 years of INTERREG, best practices for guiding funding in the fields of connectivity, mobility and accessibility should be put together; support for innovation and science; increasing the competitiveness of SMEs; prevention of natural disasters; promoting inclusive growth based on jobs, education and training; sustainable management of environmental and energy resources. I follow the alert to the need to better coordinate ETC's financing mechanisms with strategic and investment funds, eliminating overlaps and ensuring governance more consistent with territorial cohesion objectives. From the foregoing, I support the report.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – I agree with the rapporteur in advocating greater respect for territorial cohesion, in particular islands when implementing cohesion policy. There are intrinsic peculiarities which need to be addressed through this funding tool. In this sense it is disappointing to note the outcome of the negotiations on the MFF 2014-2020 regarding the cut in appropriations for ETC. I agree that an increased budget for ETC in the next programming period will boost the added value of cohesion policy. Member States need to simplify national provisions urging the implementation of e-cohesion and streamlining of administrative procedures.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it contains some positive aspects of relevance to improving the conditions of the reference population. It recommends that special attention be paid to projects striving to adapt municipalities and regions to the new demographic situation, such as: adapting social and mobility infrastructure to demographic change and migration flows, supporting the search for employment for the elderly, women and migrants, contributing to better social inclusion. It reinforces the idea of the simplification of programmes and the involvement of civil society, taking into account transparency and accountability. It calls for the local and regional institutions to play a greater role in the proposal, management and evaluation of European territorial cooperation programmes.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 For the period 2014-2020, a clear orientation was marked in the allocation of funds for the cross-border development of strategic priorities. These changes have contributed to the growth of the economic, social and territorial potential of the regions, going even beyond national borders.  I voted for the debureaucratisation of THE PROGRAMME programmes and projects. A structured public debate at EU level on the future of cohesion policies for the post-2020 period is needed. These projects with concrete results in removing impediments to the development of security, transport, education, energy or health must continue.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. –European territorial cooperation has been an independent objective of cohesion policy since the 2007-2013 programming period, yet this area is not getting sufficient attention. However, several paragraphs have the idea that cohesion funds and territorial development instruments should also be used to support the social integration of migrants, to address the challenges posed by the refugee crisis, and to measures in the areas of migration and asylum. This proposal ignores the original objective of cohesion policy set out in Article 174 TFEC, which is to 'reduce inequalities between the levels of development of the different regions and the lagging behind of the worst-off regions', 'strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion'. I cannot agree that cohesion funds, which are so important for European regions, should be used for migration-related purposes.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I support the Report on European Territorial Cooperation (Interreg) as it addresss very important issues such as the description of best practices, the contribution to territorial cohesion, simplification and EU added value. Interreg provides a framework for the implementation of joint actions and the exchange of policy experience between national, regional and local actors from different Member States.  I supported this report because it is very important for me to implement cohesion policy and interreg, as mentioned in the report, is part of it.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report as it highlights the importance for the Commission and Member States of working towards preserving European territorial cooperation. I strongly believe that this cooperation is a fundamental basis for the European integration process and that it should be given a more distinct role within cohesion policy.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that good cooperation between the EC, the EIB and local and regional authorities is an essential element in ensuring the success of the use of financial instruments in territorial development and throughout cohesion policy.  In this context, I believe that there is a need to increase the exchange of experience and knowledge between the EC and the EIB, on the one hand, and local and regional authorities, on the other.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report takes stock of the European Territorial Cooperation Policy (Interreg), which aims to strengthen and develop neighbourhood relations between communities or territorial authorities in several states.  In particular, the report recommends the development of several key sectors such as connectivity, innovation, knowledge, culture and education.  Considering that cooperation between countries belonging to the same geographical area, such as mountainous regions, is a key element in establishing a real policy of territorial development, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this report because it enshrines the EU principle of harmonising everything and refusing to allow different regions and territories to have their own way of developing. This report will not help the situation.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text on good practices related to European territorial cooperation. The Interreg programme undeniably contributes to strengthening territorial cohesion in Europe, in particular by promoting inter-regional and cross-border connectivity.  It was particularly important to stress the need to pay particular attention to projects targeting island regions, outermost and sparsely populated areas, as well as mountain and rural areas, in order to meet our cohesion policy targets for 2014-2020.  Finally, cross-border innovation policies, including joint research and mobility programmes, must be encouraged to promote competitiveness and growth in Europe.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 During the plenary vote, I was unable to support the report on European territorial cooperation. The report contains a number of valuable ideas. There is no doubt that, although European territorial cooperation has been an autonomous objective of cohesion policy since the 2007-2013 programming period, this area is not getting sufficient attention. However, several paragraphs have the idea that cohesion funds and territorial development instruments should also be used to support the social integration of migrants, to address the challenges posed by the refugee crisis, and to measures in the areas of migration and asylum. This proposal ignores the original objective of cohesion policy, which is to 'reduce disparities between the levels of development of the different regions and the lagging behind of the most disadvantaged regions', 'strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion' (Article 174 TFEI). It is not about much-talked-about solidarity, but about an investment policy, of which net contributors benefit as much as the countries receiving aid. I cannot agree that cohesion funds, which are so important for European regions, should be used for migration-related purposes. It is time to recognize that the mandatory reception quota for resettlement is not working. Migrants and refugees should be helped in their countries of origin and not brought to EU Member States.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report because I am convinced that better connectivity at EU, national and regional level is indispensable for the development of the EU. The text sets as one of its objectives an increase in the quality of transport, health and education and a greater common commitment to safeguarding the safety of citizens.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union's territorial policy already absorbs EUR 10.1 billion, or 2.8% of the Cohesion Policy Budget for the period 2014-2020.  Apart from the fact that its effectiveness has never been demonstrated, it relies on an ever-increasing regionalisation of the Union at the expense of nation states. In this case, the multi-territorial cooperation programme is based on increased community involvement in decision-making bodies.  Finally, this programme encourages many of the policies we are challenging, in particular the financing of the reception of migrants, or the policy of neighbourhood and enlargement of the European Union.  I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported Mrs. Iskra Mihaylova's report on European territorial cooperation – best practices and innovative measures, as this policy is part of the Cohesion Policy of the European Union, which is of utmost importance for Bulgaria and its economic and social development. With the eur 10.1 billion allocated for the 2014-2020 programming period, the Objective of European Territorial Development is to support overall cooperation between national, regional and local actors, with a focus on cross-border cooperation and support for border regions. Ms Mihaylova's report is important for two reasons. First, it calls for a significant increase in the budget in the next programming period in order to increase investment in border regions, as they are extremely affected by the current refugee crisis. Secondly, the report calls for the implementation of territorial cooperation programmes to be simplified in order to make them more accessible to different actors and thereby increase the effect of the funds invested.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the report, the primary role of European Territorial Cooperation is to reduce the impact of national borders, which poses a direct threat to the national sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 During the plenary vote, I was unable to support the report on European territorial cooperation. The report contains a number of valuable ideas. There is no doubt that, although European territorial cooperation has been an autonomous objective of cohesion policy since the 2007-2013 programming period, this area is not getting sufficient attention. However, several paragraphs have the idea that cohesion funds and territorial development instruments should also be used to support the social integration of migrants, to address the challenges posed by the refugee crisis, and to measures in the areas of migration and asylum. This proposal ignores the original objective of cohesion policy, which is to 'reduce disparities between the levels of development of the different regions and the lagging behind of the most disadvantaged regions', 'strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion' (Article 174 TFEI). This is not about much-stated solidarity, but about an investment policy, of which net contributors benefit as much as the countries receiving aid. I cannot agree that cohesion funds, which are so important for European regions, should be used for migration-related purposes. It is time to recognize that the mandatory reception quota for resettlement is not working. Migrants and refugees should be helped in their countries of origin and not brought to EU Member States.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 CtE currently benefits 28 Member States. The amount allocated to ETC amounts to EUR 10.1 billion: 74.1 % for cross-border cooperation - 60 programmes, 20.4 % for transnational cooperation - 15 programmes and 5.6 % for interregional cooperation - 4 programmes. Interreg also co-finances regional development cooperation programmes outside the EU: cross-border collaboration programmes of the Instrument for Pre-Access Assistance (242 million specifically for cross-border cooperation) and 16 cross-border collaboration programmes of the European Neighbourhood Instrument (634 million specifically for cross-border cooperation). I therefore agree that CTE has a great leverage effect.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: acknowledges that there is no reliable quantitative data demonstrating the effectiveness of these territorial cooperation programmes.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Our position on European Territorial Cooperation (ETC) has been critical, based on the understanding that it pursues the objective of overcoming the remaining obstacles to the functioning of the EU single market, in particular those which have to do with the barriers to the free movement of goods and migration of workers between countries, based not on their interests and aspirations (and taking advantage of the lack of life imposed on them) , but the labour needs of capital. CTE does not correspond to cooperation based on mutual benefit, solidarity and on the basis of the sovereignty and complementary interests of the countries concerned, with which we would undoubtedly agree, but rather with the intention of hindering the obstacle they consider to be the models of development of sovereign and national basis. Cooperation and integration are a reality and a need enhanced by the development of productive forces, particularly technological and scientific development. This report, in emphasising the issue of financial instruments and by favouring public-private partnerships, notes that, as at other times, tax cooperation is promoted with a view to facilitating the concentration and centralisation of (monopolistic) capital throughout the EU.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour as this report stresses the need for greater integration and complementarity between interreg programmes and other programmes financed at both national and EU level, such as Horizon 2020, the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and the European Investment Bank.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report and also calling for greater cooperation with private individuals.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the report, the primary role of European Territorial Cooperation is to reduce the impact of national borders, which poses a direct threat to the national sovereignty of the Member States. That is why I am voting against the report on European territorial cooperation - best practices and innovative measures.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Having in view that ETC has made a significant contribution to enhancing the economic, social and territorial potential of regions, Parliament expressed its disappointment concerning the outcome of the negotiations on the MFF 2014-2020 regarding the cut in appropriations for ETC. Thus, one of the important goals of this report was to call on the Commission and Member States to work towards preserving ETC as an important and positive instrument for the European integration process, through allocating ETC a more distinct role within Cohesion policy post-2020 and increasing its budget for the next programming period. I supported the report in the Plenary.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 During the plenary vote, I was unable to support the report on European territorial cooperation. The report contains a number of valuable ideas. There is no doubt that, although European territorial cooperation has been an autonomous objective of cohesion policy since the 2007-2013 programming period, this area is not getting sufficient attention. However, several paragraphs have the idea that cohesion funds and territorial development instruments should also be used to support the social integration of migrants, to address the challenges posed by the refugee crisis, and to measures in the areas of migration and asylum. This proposal ignores the original objective of cohesion policy, which is to 'reduce disparities between the levels of development of the different regions and the lagging behind of the most disadvantaged regions', 'strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion' (Article 174 TFEI). This is not about much-stated solidarity, but about an investment policy, of which net contributors benefit as much as the countries receiving aid. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I do not agree with the use of cohesion funds so important for European regions for migration-related purposes. It is time to recognize that the mandatory reception quota for resettlement is not working. Migrants and refugees should be helped in their countries of origin and not brought to EU Member States.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the finding that there is a need to continue to work to improve and expand territorial cooperation within the EU. European territorial cooperation currently benefits the 28 Member States and has become one of the objectives of cohesion policy. It has a budget of EUR 10.1 billion: 74.1% for cross-border cooperation (60 programmes), 20.4% for transnational cooperation (15 programmes) and 5.6% for interregional cooperation (4 programmes). European territorial cooperation contributes to strengthening the economic, social and territorial potential of regions, crossing national borders and removing barriers to improving security, transport, education, energy, health, training and employment. We must therefore continue to make a strong commitment to improving and extending EU territorial cooperation.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to approve this reports as it outlines several possible improvements in the area of ETC and aims to strengthen the program and its role in supporting cross-border initiatives. Cross—border cooperation and initiatives are one of the things that lie at the heart of what the EU is as they bring citizens of different Member States together in cooperation. The ETC is also important when it comes to closing the gaps in cross-border governance and regulation, an issue that makes it harder to do business and to facilitate investment to these regional cross-border areas.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Strengthening European territorial cooperation means investing in broad, democratic and intelligent growth, aspire to a plan of solidarity and socio-economic inclusion, support small and medium-sized enterprises, respond to the needs of different areas and territories but with common emergencies. That is why I believe that Europe cannot accept further cuts in cohesion policies, but rather must confirm with total conviction the need for investment in the growth of individual territories in order to strengthen the entire European project.  Cohesion policies are crucial to achieving the objectives of Europe 2020, which is why I believe I must give my full support to the report, believing that in the synergy between local and national governments and between metropolitan cities, regions and the different States lies the true soul of Europe, which finds its true driving force in respect of different identities.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on European territorial cooperation – best practices and innovative measures, because I am strongly convinced of the European added value of the territorial cooperation instrument and specific programmes such as the Interreg programme, which has been supporting the development of territories since 1990. It is indeed essential to have an effective framework for cross-border cooperation given the large number of citizens living in cross-border regions with similar economic, financial and social difficulties. Territorial cooperation is the answer to traditional challenges such as research, innovation, adaptation to climate change and the promotion of sustainable mobility and transport, but also to new challenges such as managing migratory flows and scarleting of young people.  I therefore share Parliament's concerns about the lack of sufficient resources in the 2014-20 budget in favour of territorial cooperation, as well as the need to increase its funds if we are to regard cross-border regions as laboratories of European integration. Finally, I consider the link between the Interreg programme and macro-regional strategies to be very important, and I believe that it can become the financial arm for the development of the Adriatic-Ionian Macro-Region.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the 'European Territorial Cooperation Report - Best Practices and Innovative Actions'. European territorial cooperation is an important part of the European Union's cohesion and structural policy and promotes cross-border cooperation between the regions of Europe. Its aim is to strengthen harmonious, balanced and sustainable development, as well as the cohesion and competitiveness of Europe. A landlocked country such as Germany in particular benefits from this in its border regions – and it should remain so.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. European Territorial Cooperation (ETC) should be further promoted as a key component of the Europe 2020 strategy. In this respect, the ETC makes an important contribution to improving the economic, social and territorial potential of the regions. This is particularly evident in the area of knowledge and innovation transfer and transregional transport links.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it calls on the Commission and Member States to work towards preserving European Territorial Cooperation (ETC) as an important and positive instrument for the European integration process, by allocating ETC a more distinct role within cohesion policy post 2020 and increasing its budget for the next programming period.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. What is the purpose of European territorial cooperation, if not to blur the borders of States even more blurred and to serve, as the rapporteur says, as 'laboratories of European integration'? This is a pungent formula at a time when the euro and European policies are fostering divergence of economies and increasing social and territorial disparities. Even more pungent is the enthusiasm for the effectiveness of cross-border cooperation and its added value, which is accompanied by the admission of a lack of reliable data and evidence. In short, this report is above all an act of faith that calls for even more investment in projects that do not work well, are useless or even harmful and create windfall effects. I voted against it.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I think it is crucial to reduce disparities between border regions and to promote peace, stability and regional integration in these areas. In addition, this dossier supports social adaptation and infrastructure mobility, with the aim of creating demographic change and promoting migration flows. It also supports the creation of jobs for the elderly, women and migrants in order to contribute to greater social integration.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on European territorial cooperation – best practices and innovative actions.  In order to achieve better results and make more efficient use of investment, European territorial cooperation (Interreg) has taken a new shape in the 2014-2020 programme. This was made possible by focusing on thematic areas and focusing on results. It is now very important to raise public awareness and greater public awareness of European regional cooperation, as the majority of people living in eu border regions are unaware of cross-border cooperation funded by the European Union in their regions.  Therefore, in my opinion, it is very important both to publicly publicly publicisation the results of completed projects and to better coordinate activities between the Commission, the managing authorities and all stakeholders in the implementation of cross-border programmes. This will ensure a critical analysis of projects in terms of their achievements in the different thematic areas and facilitate the further implementation of the programmes after 2020, while ensuring high quality and transparency of projects.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it calls on the Commission and Member States to work towards preserving ETC as an important and positive instrument for the European integration process, through allocating ETC a more distinct role within Cohesion policy post-2020 and increasing its budget for the next programming period.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of the progress made through European territorial cooperation (the Interreg programme), which is very useful especially in the border regions.  This programme brings together a series of high-value-added, cross-border projects in the key areas of connectivity, cultural innovation or education.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. European Territorial Cooperation represents high value for money and has future potential beyond regional policy. It makes a significant contribution to boosting integrated and sustainable territorial development, including implementation and dissemination of integrated approaches, development of governance approaches, harmonisation of planning instruments, administrative procedures and legal provisions across borders.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – In 1990, Interreg was developed as a Community initiative with a budget of only EUR 1 billion covering exclusively cross-border cooperation and with beneficiaries from 11 Member States. Later, Interreg was extended to transnational and interregional cooperation. During the period 2014-2020, a specific regulation covering ECA actions supported by the ERDF was adopted. Currently, the ECA has 28 beneficiary Member States and has become one of the 2 cohesion policy objectives. We voted in favour of the report as it ensures: - Better regional connectivity, mobility and accessibility to services, - Transfer of knowledge and innovation, strengthening the competitiveness of SMEs, - Addressing environmental challenges, better risk management and disaster response, - Strengthening the development of institutional capacity and social capital, establishing cross-border network structures and creating new partnerships while also contributing to territorial cohesion.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the report of my colleague Iskra Mihaylova. I believe that European Territorial Cooperation should facilitate better regional connectivity, mobility and accessibility to services throughout Member States. Already it has helped to support research, innovation and the knowledge economy, adapting to climate change, and promoting sustainable transport and mobility through transnational approaches, and has contributed to enhancing institutional capacity of cities in the EU. Equally, cross-border labour markets are becoming an increasingly important element of ETC. I support the initiative of the Luxembourg Presidency, which proposed a specific legal tool for border regions, as well as the Commission’s initiative of carrying out, by the end of 2016, an analysis of the barriers to cross-border cooperation that will look at solutions and examples of good practices. I agree that potential of the European Territorial Cooperation should be further developed, especially in areas such as the single market, the digital agenda, employment, mobility, energy, research, education, culture, health and the environment.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. This own-initiative report deals with European Territorial Cooperation (ETC). This financial instrument was developed in 1990 as a Community initiative under EU cohesion policy and includes EUR 10.1 billion for the current Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). The aim is to improve cross-border or transnational and interregional cooperation within the EU. On the positive side of the report are the calls for more results-oriented, better implementation of ETC programmes, more data and monitoring systems, more coordination, synergy and complementarity. It also calls for a better link with efforts to address the current migration crisis. However, the statement that "only" EUR 10.1 billion is available for 2014-2020, as well as the blanket demand to spend more money on the ETC after 2020, without at the same time pushing for savings in other areas, is negative. The fact that, in addition to meaningful projects under EU cohesion policy, a number of activities are not being implemented in a targeted, sustainable or efficient manner, and that available funds cannot be called up in individual Member States due to the lack of professional administrative capacity, a blanket demand for more funding for a cohesion policy instrument is a complete mockery of European taxpayers. That is why I am opposed to this report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to discord and strife in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 During the plenary vote, I was unable to support the report on European territorial cooperation. The report contains a number of valuable ideas. There is no doubt that, although European territorial cooperation has been an autonomous objective of cohesion policy since the 2007-2013 programming period, this area is not getting sufficient attention. However, several paragraphs have the idea that cohesion funds and territorial development instruments should also be used to support the social integration of migrants, to address the challenges posed by the refugee crisis, and to measures in the areas of migration and asylum. This proposal ignores the original objective of cohesion policy, which is to 'reduce disparities between the levels of development of the different regions and the lagging behind of the most disadvantaged regions', 'strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion' (Article 174 TFEI). This is not about much-stated solidarity, but about an investment policy, of which net contributors benefit as much as the countries receiving aid. I cannot agree that cohesion funds, which are so important for European regions, should be used for migration-related purposes. It is time to recognize that the mandatory reception quota for resettlement is not working. Migrants and refugees should be helped in their countries of origin and not brought to EU Member States.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls on the Commission and Member States to work closely towards preserving European Territorial Cooperation as an important instrument for the European integration process. European Territorial Cohesion receives a more distinct role within Cohesion policy post 2020 and has its budget increased for the next programming period. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted for the Report on European Territorial Cooperation – best practices and innovative measures, since I know the value of territorial cooperation programmes especially for new and future member states from the experience of the prefects of Istria County.  At one time, Istria County was the most successful Croatian region in the use of EU funds, especially those from cross-border cooperation programmes with Slovenia and cross-border cooperation in the Adriatic.  In particular, these programmes helped us prepare institutions and citizens for the EU, but also in adopting advanced development solutions along the lines of developed regions in the Member States at the time. Territorial cooperation programmes are an excellent instrument in overcoming differences between members in particular regions in the cross-border area and achieving social and economic cohesion.  Unfortunately, territorial cooperation has only 2.8% of the total cohesion policy funding. There is a current problem of weaker implementation due to the late adoption of operational programs, but also a permanent problem of numerous obstacles in implementation that are often associated with the bureaucratic approach of working in managing bodies.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to strengthen territorial cooperation, the overall aim of which is to reduce the influence of national borders within the European Union.  This objective is neither legitimate nor timely. The report also opens the door to auxiliary abuses: it encourages the use of territorial cooperation to finance the reception of illegal migrants, in particular through Interreg programmes. Finally, with regard to social dumping, these programmes are also intended to facilitate labour mobility within the Union.  So I voted against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on ETC because it is important to further develop and support the large number of programmes that play a crucial role in achieving our cohesion policy goals. Such programmes will further improve our cross-border cooperation in many policy domains. Besides transportation, we will see a positive impact in healthcare, research and innovation, and even environment. As it has great potential to enhance the economic, social and territorial development across European regions and boost competitiveness of our small and medium enterprises (SMEs), it will positively affect our citizens and businesses, and I am pleased to support such a decision.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Iskra Mihaylova's report on European territorial cooperation.  This objective of regional policy promotes cooperation between different regions of the Union by enabling projects that go beyond national borders in the areas of employment, transport, the environment and tourism.   Because of its geographical position, France is very involved in territorial cooperation. The Loire region participates in two transnational programmes ("North-West Europe" and "Atlantic Area") and one interregional (Interreg Europe). The Mihaylova report takes stock of the progress made by territorial cooperation and points to several areas for improvement, particularly in the area of simplification. It calls for further and further cooperation, which is why I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of European territorial cooperation.  Established about 25 years ago, European territorial cooperation remains a key instrument for achieving territorial cohesion through a series of programmes and projects with high European added value, with greater benefits in the 60 European border regions.  It has made significant progress in a range of key sectors - connectivity, innovation and knowledge, culture and education.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The rapporteur stresses the need for the management and implementation of European territorial cooperation (ETC) programmes and projects to become less bureaucratic. Irrespective of the separate regulation, the implementation of ETC programmes remains too complicated, and the report therefore urges the High Level Group of Independent Experts on Monitoring Simplification for Beneficiaries of ESI Funds to consider measures for significantly simplifying and reducing the administrative burden on beneficiaries. As I am of this opinion I supported the report.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Territorial cooperation within the European Community is an essential element of cohesion policy. It develops a number of programmes aimed at facilitating transport by building transnational communication networks, which is an important aspect in border areas where many people cross borders every day to commute to work. In addition, it facilitates the transport of goods, thereby reducing delivery costs and contributing to the development of tourism.  Countries cooperating on border areas have greater opportunities to deal with environmental challenges. Many of the areas at risk lie on the territory of several Member States, so cooperation in their protection offers much greater opportunities than the actions taken separately by each country. The same applies to the seas and the control of water pollution.  Territorial cooperation also results in increased innovation and research undertaken by research institutes and companies from different countries, as well as the possibility of cooperation between international border universities. It is also important to make these areas more attractive to commercial enterprises.
