Harnessing human, regional and cross-border potential creates opportunities for the development of border areas and creates new jobs, preventing depopulation.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. A well-differentiated report that shows the best examples of territorial cooperation in order to create real added value for European citizens. The proposed measures are innovative yet realistic. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it calls on the Commission and Member States to work towards preserving ETC as an important and positive instrument for the European integration process.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. This own-initiative report deals with the European Territorial Cooperation (ETC), also known as Interreg. That is why I am opposed to this report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 13 September 2016, we voted in plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on a report on European territorial cooperation – best practices and innovative measures.  Around 38% of europe's population lives in border areas. Since I am actively involved in the programme of cooperation of the Moravian-Silesian Region with its border regions and I am aware of the various problems that often plague this cooperation, this topic is quite close to me. The fundamental objective of European territorial cooperation is to reduce the influence of borders in order to reduce regional disparities, remove remaining barriers to investment and enhance cross-border cooperation, strengthen cohesion and promote the harmonious economic, social, cultural and territorial development of the Union as a whole. In my opinion, European territorial cooperation contributes to peace, stability and regional integration. The rapporteur has managed to incorporate in the report the need to develop a common approach to cross-border innovation, such as joint research, mobility programmes, common research infrastructure, etc. The report mentions that cultural cooperation should be one of the objectives of European territorial cooperation and points out the need to promote cultural and educational cooperation in border areas, as people living on opposite sides of the border often share cultural and linguistic heritage. I consider the report to be quite balanced, which is why I was happy to support it.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 During the plenary vote, I was unable to support the report on European territorial cooperation. The report contains a number of valuable ideas. There is no doubt that, although European territorial cooperation has been an autonomous objective of cohesion policy since the 2007-2013 programming period, this area is not getting sufficient attention. This proposal ignores the original objective of cohesion policy, which is to 'reduce disparities between the levels of development of the different regions and the lagging behind of the most disadvantaged regions', 'strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion' (Article 174 TFEI). This is not about much-stated solidarity, but about an investment policy, of which net contributors benefit as much as the countries receiving aid. I cannot agree that cohesion funds, which are so important for European regions, should be used for migration-related purposes. It is time to recognize that the mandatory reception quota for resettlement is not working. Migrants and refugees should be helped in their countries of origin and not brought to EU Member States.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this report is to lessen the influence of borders in order to reduce disparities between regions. Around 38% of Europe’s population lives in border regions. Through these measures presented in this report we should manage to reinforce cohesion, promote the economic, social, cultural and territorial development of the Union as a whole. One innovative measure is also the mention of the cultural cooperation, promote cultural and educational cooperation for a common cultural heritage. Last but not least to contribute to peace, stability and regional integration. For all these reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on European territorial cooperation – best practices and innovative measures, as I believe that ETC is an important instrument of cohesion policy aimed at resolving problems that go beyond administrative boundaries and require common solutions. For the period 2014-2020, an amount of over ten billion euros has been allocated under cross-border, transnational and interregional cooperation programmes. Their funds have contributed to better regional connectivity, mobility and access to services, knowledge transfer and innovation, increased competitiveness of SMEs, and enhancing regional identity.  Very good results are seen in addressing environmental challenges, better risk management and disaster response, as well as strengthening institutional capacity building and social capital, strengthening cross-border network structures and creating new partnerships. I support the call on the Commission and the Member States to work towards preserving ETC as an important and positive instrument for the European integration process, with ETC given a more important role in cohesion policy after 2020.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the text because European territorial cooperation (ETC) is one of the most important goals of cohesion policy for 2014-2020. The ETC makes a significant contribution to strengthening the EU’s objective of territorial cohesion through integrating diverse sectoral policies on territorial scale. In this regard, it could be argued that the ETC has a significant European added value. It contributes to peace, stability, economic development and regional integration not only in Europe but also in the world (in the framework of enlargement and neighbourhood policy). Therefore, ETC’s potential should be further developed beyond regional policy in areas such as the single market, the digital agenda, employment, mobility and energy, research, education, culture, health and environment. The Commission and Member States should consider preserving ETC as an important instrument, allocating it a more distinct role within cohesion policy post-2020 and significantly increasing its budget.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. – Territorial cooperation, for the period 2014-2020, has been considered with the aim of achieving greater impact and appropriate use of investments. At least 80 % of the budget for each cooperation programme must be based on at least four thematic objectives, thereby contributing to the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy. The CTE thus contributes to the economic, social and territorial growth of the regions by representing and integrating the various policies on a territorial scale. It therefore remains a fundamental instrument for territorial cohesion, designed to solve problems that transcend administrative borders and require common solutions. For these reasons, I welcome the adoption of a new strategy aimed at applying best practices and innovative measures for our country.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because, under the pretext of strengthening European territorial cooperation, it calls for an increase in the budget, which already amounts to EUR 10.1 billion for 2014-2020.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The stated aim is to strengthen territorial cooperation, and thus reduce the incidence of national borders within the EU.  The following aspects can be found in this report: the use of territorial cooperation to finance the reception of illegal migrants; increased participation of local authorities in decision-making bodies, to the detriment of national governments; the desire to create institutional platforms for cooperation to make European propaganda at the taxpayer's expense, etc.  All this, even though there is no reliable quantitative data demonstrating the effectiveness of these territorial cooperation programmes. I logically voted against this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because in view of the view that European Territorial Cooperation (CTE) is a fundamental instrument for the economic, social and territorial development of the regions, the report recalls Parliament's disappointment at the outcome of the 2014-2020 MFF negotiations on the cut in the endowment for the CTE.  In addition, the report calls on the Commission and the Member States to preserve the CTE as an important and positive instrument for the European integration process, assigning the CTE a clearer role within the post-2020 cohesion policy. In this context, a larger budget is requested for the CTE in the next programming period.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it contains some positive aspects of relevance to improving the conditions of the reference population. It recommends that special attention be paid to projects striving to adapt municipalities and regions to the new demographic situation, such as: adapting social and mobility infrastructure to demographic change and migration flows, supporting the search for employment for the elderly, women and migrants, contributing to better social inclusion. It reinforces the idea of the simplification of programmes and the involvement of civil society, taking into account transparency and accountability. It calls for the local and regional institutions to play a greater role in the proposal, management and evaluation of European territorial cooperation programmes.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Territorial Cooperation (CTE) has been adapted to make a greater impact through a thematic concentration effort and results-oriented orientation. It is a fundamental instrument for the development of border regions, considered true laboratories of European integration. I support the adoption of this report as I believe that interregional and transnational cooperation allows different European cities and regions to cooperate on the various issues concerning them, thereby exchanging good practices while supporting joint research, innovation and the knowledge economy.  I give my positive vote for approval because it offers considerable European added value by contributing to regional stability and integration, within the framework of enlargement and neighbourhood policy.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. This own-initiative report deals with the European Territorial Cooperation (ETC), also known as Interreg. This financial instrument was developed in 1990 as a Community initiative under EU cohesion policy and includes EUR 10.1 billion for the current Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). The aim is to improve cross-border or transnational and interregional cooperation within the EU. On the positive side of the report are the calls for greater results-oriented, better implementation of ETC programmes, more data and monitoring systems, more coordination, synergy and complementarity, as well as simplification of programmes and a reduction in the administrative burden required to do so. It also calls for a better link with efforts to address the current migration crisis. However, the statement that "only" EUR 10.1 billion is available for 2014-2020, as well as the blanket demand to spend more money on the ETC after 2020, without at the same time pushing for savings in other areas, is negative. The fact that, in addition to meaningful projects under EU cohesion policy, a number of activities are not being implemented in a targeted, sustainable or efficient manner, and that available funds cannot be called up in individual Member States due to the lack of professional administrative capacity, a blanket demand for more funding for a cohesion policy instrument is a complete mockery of European taxpayers. That is why I am opposed to this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which seeks to achieve territorial cohesion through programmes and projects with an important impact on border regions.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. This is an unhelpful resolution full of nonsensical proclamations, such as that "smart specialisation strategies should be an effective tool to tackle social, environmental, climate and energy challenges." Nor do I agree with 'national authorities investing in regional intelligence and in-depth big data analysis, which will enable them to understand trends in regional businesses in the global value chain'. I don't think that's what national authorities are supposed to do.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report that encourages the Member States to make greater use of Integrated Territorial Investment and Community-Led Local Development, and its recommendation that special focus be placed on projects that strive to adapt localities and regions to the new demographic situation and counteract the inequalities resulting from it. I think that the implementation of territorial cooperation programmes should be further simplified.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 European territorial cooperation is a cohesion policy instrument that, with efficient and sensible use, will help to balance regional disparities, strengthen the development of regions, especially in cross-border cooperation, while contributing to increasing territorial cohesion. EUR 10.1 billion is earmarked for the implementation of the policy's objectives for 2014-2020, of which 74.1% goes to cross-border cooperation, 20.4% to transnational cooperation and 5.6% to interregional cooperation. I appreciate that a new bridge between Austria and Slovakia will be built from these sources and that these resources will help to strengthen small and medium-sized enterprises in increasing their competitiveness.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. European territorial cooperation aims to solve the common problems of the whole EU through the implementation of shared objectives and the exchange of good practices between regions. With a budget of 10 billion euros for the period 2014-2020, it is one of the two objectives of the current cohesion policy programming.  Despite its importance, this policy has suffered budget cuts during negotiations on the 2014-2020 multi-year financial framework. This report reminds the Commission and The Member States of the importance of preserving European territorial cooperation and giving it a distinct role in post-2020 cohesion policy. The latter should be accompanied by an increase in the budget allocated to it for the next programming period. I therefore vote in favour of this report which supports this powerful tool of European integration, which is territorial cooperation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on European territorial cooperation - best practices and innovative measures, because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. The European Union's territorial policy already absorbs EUR 10.1 billion, or 2.8% of the Cohesion Policy Budget for the period 2014-2020.  In addition to its effectiveness, it has never been demonstrated, it relies on an ever-increasing regionalisation of the European Union at the expense of nation states. In this case, the multi-territorial cooperation programme is based on increased involvement of local authorities in decision-making bodies.  Finally, this programme encourages many of the policies we are challenging, in particular the financing of the reception of migrants, or the policy of neighbourhood and enlargement of the European Union.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. – I have voted in favour of the Report on European Territorial Cooperation, as I consider being of extreme importance the EU’s goal to make gender equality the main element in all policies and practices that relate to European Territorial Cooperation. The report emphasises the principles of shared management, multi-level governance and partnership, all relevant to manage the migration crisis, and contribute to peace, stability, and regional integration.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report on territorial cooperation in the EU. The report notes that around 38% of the European population lives in border regions and stresses the importance of cross-border cooperation under cohesion policy. Cross-border cooperation is a key instrument for the development of border regions. It focuses on better connectivity and accessibility, enhancing knowledge transfer and innovation, as well as solving environmental problems. I agree that better coordination, synergies and complementarity should be sought and cooperation and integration of wider strategic areas within the regions should be improved. I supported the report in the vote.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the report on practical improvements and innovative measures to improve European territorial cooperation. We have an immense challenge ahead of us to improve this cooperation, as much progress has been made but a long way remains to be made, given that approximately 38% of the European population lives in border regions. That is why we must continue to work to reduce the influence of national borders in order to reduce regional differences, remove remaining barriers to investment and cooperate across borders, strengthen cohesion and promote the harmonious economic, social and cultural development of the Union as a whole.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of European Territorial Cooperation (ECA) because it strengthens the economic, social and territorial potential of the regions and leads to cross-border and transnational cooperation since it completes different sectoral policies beyond national borders. It also promotes security and helps overcome barriers related to education, health care, transport and energy. Undoubtedly, the ECA achieves best practices in areas such as better regional connectivity, mobility and accessibility to services, knowledge transfer and innovation, addressing many environmental challenges by applying best practices to environmental issues. Finally, the ECA supports research and innovation since research processes can be carried out on a larger scale. For all the above reasons, I am voting in favour of this resolution.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This improves regional brand development and the strengthening of regional identity, as well as risk management and civil protection. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The concept of European territorial cooperation encompasses cooperation between regions, between cross-border regions and between large economic zones or basins such as the 'Alpine region'. But it is the territorial formula of generalized competition.  The report calls for reducing regional disparities and developing such cooperation. Incredible! That already exists; it's called the state or the nation. It calls for more joint research and culture programmes to support job creation, especially for seniors, women and migrants.   At this level of generality, who could be against it? But this is a dressing-up on the consequences of the Commission's policy of 'competition of territories'.  To counter the economic crisis and unemployment, the underlying idea is to encourage the unemployed to "mobility" to look for work elsewhere. As a seconded worker?  When the Structural Funds need more budget, the policy is to promote public-private partnerships that ruin and empty public authorities of their powers, to promote private loans (Juncker funds) at the expense of cohesion policy.  I note the good will of the report but denounce this general framework for competition; I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to strengthen territorial cooperation, the overall aim of which is to reduce the influence of national borders within the European Union.  Although territorial cooperation can encourage the proliferation of cross-border projects, it is above all a further step towards the federalisation of the European Union.  As a result, I voted against this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The overall objective of ETC is to reduce the influence of national borders with a view to reducing disparities between regions, reducing remaining barriers to investment and work based on cooperation at national borders, strengthening cohesion and promoting harmonious economic, social, cultural and territorial development throughout the Union. So we have to continue to find the best practices to achieve the objectives outlined. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it notes the successes that have been brought about through the interregional cooperation facilitated by European Territorial Cooperation programmes. However, it also notes that that these programmes do not have enough visibility amongst the Union’s citizens and that more needs to be done for these programmes to be used to their greatest effectiveness and reach.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Territorial cooperation benefits all Member States. With a budget of EUR 10.1 billion, it is essential as an instrument of cohesion at European level.  To improve its efficiency and contribute to the implementation of the 2020 strategy, it was necessary to bring together all cooperation programmes around major themes and, on the other hand, allocate funds to more strategic cross-border development priorities. This strategy has identified good practices in areas as diverse as connectivity, mobility and accessibility of services at the regional level, knowledge transfer, innovation development and hence the development of THE competitiveness of SMEs, the enhancement of the regional brand image, the response to environmental challenges, the improvement of risk management. , disaster response, etc.  It is absolutely essential to preserve territorial cooperation as a vehicle for European integration. In the context of post-2020 cohesion, we must focus on strengthening its innovative dimension and fostering transnational and cross-regional public-private partnerships, which presupposes harmonizations of administrative procedures and legal provisions.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – European Territorial Cooperation (Interreg) is a key tool for achieving territorial cohesion through various programmes and projects with European added value and impact on 60 European border regions. Currently, 28 Member States use European territorial cooperation and is one of the two objectives of cohesion policy. For the 2014-2020 programming period, Interreg supports cross-border, transnational and interregional cooperation from the European Regional Development Fund. Despite a small budget, cross-border cooperation projects are producing positive results, be it the removal of obstacles to better security, transport, education, energy, healthcare, training and employment. For the ETS to function better in the future, it will be important to focus on more efficient absorption of funds, on establishing appropriate coordination mechanisms, cutting red tape in the management and implementation of European territorial cooperation, as well as greater involvement of the financial private sector in ETS projects.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on European territorial cooperation since it is important to share best practices and innovative measures. One of the important elements of this report is that it calls on the Commission and Member States to work towards preserving European territorial cooperation as an important and positive instrument for the European integration process by allocating ETC a more distinct role within cohesion policy post 2020 and increasing its budget for the next programming period.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Interreg was established in 1990 as a Community initiative with a budget of EUR 1 billion to support cross-border cooperation only, with 11 beneficiary Member States, one of four Community initiatives of the European Union.  Its initiatives are areas of cooperation essential for the development and cohesion of the whole European area. It was later extended to transnational and interregiocial cooperation. For the period 2014-2020, a specific regulation was adopted for European territorial cooperation actions supported by the ERDF. All 28 Member States are currently involved in European territorial cooperation and this has become one of the two objectives of cohesion policy. The Report of the Committee on Regional Development reviews the added value of European territorial cooperation, the contribution to the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and takes into account best practices and makes recommendations for the future. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The Interreg, established in 1990, was developed as a Community initiative with a budget of EUR 1 billion, covering exclusively cross-border cooperation and benefiting 11 Member States. It was later extended to transnational and interregional cooperation. In 2015, European Territorial Cooperation (ETC) stood out as an important instrument of cohesion policy, designed to solve problems that transcend administrative boundaries and require common solutions. ETC has numerous examples of the advantages in the following best practices: overcoming border challenges in terms of transport and movement of people, supporting smart transport solutions and multimodal transport hubs; simplify travel across borders; improve interconnectivity with an emphasis on road infrastructure, improve maritime accessibility, making improvements in regional ports, specialised services such as health care for the elderly, cross-border health solutions, investment plans to build structures for the elderly, with a view to keeping them active in society and providing them with as healthy and rewarding lives as possible, among others.  I endorse the rapporteur's position on the need to make the management and implementation of ETC programmes less bureaucratic. I defend the importance of ETC as a vital tool for the Process of European Integration.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on European territorial cooperation aims to strengthen territorial cooperation, the overall aim of which is to reduce the influence of national borders within the European Union by multiplying cross-border projects. It is therefore a question of making nations disappear in the name of European interest in order to complete European federalism (it encourages cooperation to finance the reception of migrants, EU neighbourhood policies, etc.).  This budget is already 10.1 billion euros, but its increase is required. In light of these elements, I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it calls on the Commission and Member States to work towards preserving ETC as an important and positive instrument for the European integration process, through allocating ETC a more distinct role within Cohesion policy post-2020 and increasing its budget for the next programming period.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on this report on European territorial cooperation. This text takes stock of this positive policy for the development of the European Union.  However, I regret the presence of a provision calling for measures to support job creation for migrants. Such a provision is once again a call for air to illegal immigration.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Mihaylova report on European territorial cooperation, in particular good practice and unprecedented measures.  The aim is to take stock of a cooperation established 25 years ago that has led to considerable progress in 60 border regions. The position of the EPP group is well reflected in this report.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 European territorial cooperation is a cornerstone of cohesion policies and therefore contributes to the development of the economic, social and territorial potential of European regions. However, this strategic importance is not reflected in the funds allocated in the 2014-2020 budget, which are lower than in the previous period, representing only 2.8 % of the resources earmarked for cohesion policies. We are therefore in favour of the report on European territorial cooperation because, through it, the European Parliament explicitly calls on the Commission and the Member States to give a greater role to European territorial cooperation in the context of cohesion policies in the future. The report clearly underlines the added value generated by initiatives under territorial cooperation, especially those in the field of support for research and innovation, as well as to enhance the competitiveness of SMEs and the management of environmental challenges. The report also, by identifying best practices precisely, recognises the impact of these projects and the greater potential of cross-border and transnational cooperation. If European integration is to be promoted at the service of citizens, it is essential to continue to support territorial cooperation policies and the European Parliament is committed to this through the proposed report.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 European territorial cooperation is an important instrument for cohesion policy designed to solve problems that transcend administrative borders and require common solutions. For 2014-2020, a specific regulation on European Territorial Cooperation (CTE) actions was adopted, supported by the ERDF, and was redesigned in order to achieve greater impact and more effective use of investments through the focus on thematic concentration and result orientation, achieving concrete progress in key areas such as connectivity, innovation and knowledge, culture and education. I therefore voted in favour of the measure.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on European territorial cooperation has my full support. Born some 26 years ago in a modest financial framework, the programme now enables one of the main objectives of EUROPEAN Union cohesion policy to be achieved. Programmes supported by European territorial cooperation help to improve the state of the environment and increase the level of research and innovation in such a way that the inhabitants of the areas directly feel it. Slovakia has also benefited from a number of european cooperation programmes. As an example, I would like to mention the project to build a bridge linking Slovakia and Austria to the Moravian River, providing a simple crossing for both cyclists and pedestrians. The project also produced long-term results: as a result of the tourism boom, rest areas and restaurants were needed, leading to the start-up of businesses and thus the new birth of jobs. Our country has re-joined a number of projects, with Austria, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Romania and Ukraine as our number one partners in the coming period.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that aims at achieving a greater impact and more effective use of investments by focusing on thematic concentration and results-orientation.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – European territorial cooperation is one of the two important cohesion policy objectives for the period 2014-2020, although only 2.8% of the cohesion policy budget is earmarked for this purpose. I supported Mrs Mihaylova's report aimed at supporting member states' territorial cooperation, also taking into account that 38% of the European population lives in border areas.  The overarching objective of cross-border cooperation is to reduce the impact of social borders in order to reduce disparities between regions and remaining barriers to investment. I believe that better cooperation between Bulgaria and the neighbouring Member States would contribute to improving the economic, social, cultural and territorial development not only of the Balkan region, but also of the EU as a whole.  The importance of cross-border labour markets, which are highly dynamic about job creation, is also growing. Member States should make use of the Interreg programmes to facilitate cross-border labour mobility and promote, if necessary, the adaptation of the administrative and social regulatory framework, as well as strengthen dialogue at all levels of government.  European territorial cooperation needs to be improved as a small number of European citizens still take advantage of all the opportunities provided by the EU internal market and freedom of movement.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cross-border cooperation is an essential tool for the development of border regions with great potential in areas beyond regional policy, such as: the Single Market, digital agenda, employment, mobility, energy, research, education, culture, health and the environment. The Commission and the Member States should consider the prospect of continuing cross-border cooperation as an important tool, allocating a more distinct role in post-2020 cohesion policy, as well as a much more consistent budget. The implementation of territorial cooperation programmes should be simplified by reducing administrative complications for beneficiaries. At the same time, Member States should simplify their national provisions and avoid over-regulation, in particular by implementing e-cohesion and streamlining administrative procedures.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ European Territorial Cooperation (ETC) is an instrument with which to promote equal development and territorial integration across the regions of the EU. The resolution draws on examples of best practices of ETC from the periods 2000-2006 and 2007-2013, finding that there have been great cross-border collaboration achievements made in areas such as mobility and regional connectivity, handling environmental challenges, education, employment as well as knowledge transfer and innovation. The resolution stresses the importance of continuing the development of such good results for the 2014-2020 period while evaluating certain issues that need improvement to reach full efficiency of ETC, such as simplifying the management and absorption of ETC programmes and raising public awareness about its positive contributions to EU regional cohesion. As such, I can only offer it my full support.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this own initiative report focusing on improving the effective use of the Interreg initiative (a Community Initiative in place since 1990) in order to develop European Territorial Cooperation (ETC). The overarching objective of ETC is to lessen the influence of borders in order to reduce disparities between regions, removing the remaining obstacles to investment and cooperation across borders. The report calls for increased funds to be directed towards ETC, for cross-border innovation policy and research cooperation, and for a focus on projects that promote the adaptation of social and mobility infrastructure to demographic change and migratory flows.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I also supported this report, as it improves regional brand development and the strengthening of regional identity, as well as risk management and civil protection.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on European territorial cooperation (ECA) because, in this way, the importance of the ECA as an important instrument of planning cohesion policy is stressed to solve problems that go beyond administrative borders and that require common solutions. The ECA makes an important contribution to strengthening the economic, social and territorial capacities of the regions, as it reflects and completes different sectoral policies at territorial level, going beyond national borders (cross-border and transnational cooperation), as well as in individual cities and regions (interregional cooperation). Regardless of the small budget, ECA projects have tangible results: removing barriers to better security, transferring knowledge and innovation, improving regional connectivity, enhancing the competitiveness of SMEs and addressing environmental challenges. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this report because it enshrines the EU principle of harmonising everything and refusing to allow different regions and territories to have their own way of developing. This report will not help the situation.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I supported this Resolution as for 25 years the ETC has been a key instrument to achieve territorial cohesion through support of a number of programmes and projects with strong European added value. It has made significant progress in a number of key sectors – connectivity, innovation and knowledge, to mention a few. The report in question takes the measure of these developments.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒European territorial cooperation has become one of the most important objectives of EU cohesion policy and therefore rightly deserves not only full attention, but also support for new plans created by EU cohesion policy.  Interregional cooperation at international level between EU member states, but also outside the EU, it has so far proved to be a very fertile field of cooperation: it has also contributed to better cooperation and rapproome between Member States, the progress of the economy, the improvement of institutional capacities, adaptation to climate change, etc. European territorial cooperation is also important for a number of other factors, such as eu enlargement, fostering the development of islands and other less frequently populated regions and the refugee crisis. In all this, European territorial cooperation can help greatly.  The motions for a resolution to increase the budget of European territorial cooperation, to overcome obstacles to border cooperation, to simplify administrative requirements and to, above all, not to delay programmes related to this field, but to implement them effectively on time, are good and praiseworthy, and therefore I support the resolution.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to strengthen territorial cooperation, the overall aim of which is to reduce the influence of national borders within the European Union.  Although territorial cooperation can encourage the proliferation of cross-border projects, it is above all a further step towards the federalisation of the European Union.  I am, of course, voting against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ As around 38% of Europe's population lives in border regions and the EU is facing a major economic, financial and social crisis affecting women in all areas in particular, and there is a need to jointly review the structure of European territorial cooperation after 2020, the full added value of european territorial cooperation programmes cannot only be assessed by quantitative indicators. For this reason, I join calls on the Commission to develop more qualitative indicators to better bring to the fore the results achieved through territorial cooperation, and I support the adoption of this report.  Effective cross-border and transnational cooperation leads to greater attractiveness of a specific geographical area for companies, by using local, regional and cross-border potential and human capital as efficiently as possible to better meet the needs and expectations of companies and avoid phenomena such as the relocation of businesses to third countries, depopulation of EU regions and increased unemployment.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ European Territorial Cooperation, also known as Interreg, has been essential in cross-border, transnational, and interregional cooperation. ETC currently services 28 Member States’ and regional development cooperation programmes outside of the EU. As ETC now only represents 2.8% of the cohesion policy budget, I am disappointed in the budget cuts. These cuts will negatively impact areas like the single market, the digital market, mobility, energy, research, education, health, the environment and culture. I hope to preserve ETC post-2020 by increasing its funds because of its important role and positive impact on the European integration project. It has played a significant part in enhancing economic, social and territorial potential of the regions, so increasing its future funding is integral in maximising the regions’ full utility.  I call on the Commission and Member States to work together with Parliament towards preserving European Territorial Cooperation as an important tool in the European integration process.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Territorial cooperation between the different regions that make up the European Union is, in my view, one of the most important objectives of cohesion policy. For 2014-2020, a specific regulation on European Territorial Cooperation (CTE) actions was adopted, supported by the ERDF. At present, the 28 Member States benefit from the CTE, which has become one of the two objectives of cohesion policy. The total amount allocated is EUR 10.1 billion. The added value of European territorial cooperation is found above all in the exchange of good practices in transport management, the transfer of knowledge and innovation and the strengthening of the competitiveness of SMEs. I strongly believe in cooperation between the different local authorities and, in particular, I believe that it is essential to invest in the capacities of our local administrators by providing them with appropriate tools and resources. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Interreg European territorial cooperation is one of the two objectives of cohesion policy and provides a framework for the implementation of joint actions and the exchange of policy experience between national, regional and local actors from different Member States. The report focuses on issues relating to the description of best practices and the contribution to territorial cohesion. A number of paragraphs concern the next period after 2020 and contain concrete proposals in this regard. calls for an increase in the budget for European territorial cooperation in the next programming period and expresses the view that cross-border cooperation can add value to the management of the migration crisis; It also encourages the use of Interreg programmes and calls for them to be implemented in order to meet the challenges of the refugee crisis.  It is of the opinion that European territorial cooperation has proven its effectiveness, but regrets that the full potential of this initiative has not been fully exploited. The report is of the opinion that cross-border cooperation is a key tool for the development of border regions, which are recognised as genuine laboratories for European integration, and underlines the fact that, notwithstanding the existence of a separate Regulation on European territorial cooperation, the implementation of territorial cooperation programmes should be further simplified.  I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of the progress made possible by European territorial cooperation.  As part of the policy of supporting the regions of the Member States, the EU promotes cooperation between countries (whether cross-border, transnational or inter-regional), which is characterized in particular by joint projects in employment, transport, tourism or the environment.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this report because it enshrines the EU principle of harmonising everything and refusing to allow different regions and territories to have their own way of developing. This report will not help the situation.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because, in my view, CTE, through its results orientation, contributes significantly to improving the economic, social and territorial potential of the regions by reflecting and integrating various sectoral policies at territorial scale and by crossing national borders, also affecting municipalities and regions in individual terms. The desire to overcome border challenges has enabled SMEs to participate in concrete innovative activities: networking between companies, knowledge-promoting institutes and service providers, access to cutting-edge technologies to test product ideas, use appropriate manufacturing techniques and market their products worldwide such as tourism development, among others. ETC has also enabled joint responses to environmental problems such as joint monitoring of river basins, better use of marine resources and by-products, creating artificial reefs to improve biodiversity, joint cooperation in harmonising flood prevention activities and improving water quality and improving territorial planning and risk management in the Alps , as well as the resolution of other environmental challenges such as coastal pollution, the risk of forest fires and improving the monitoring of ports, etc.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Report on European Territorial Cooperation, because thanks to the Regulation adopted for the period 2014-2020, which includes the actions of the European Territorial Cooperation (ECC), financed by the ERDF, it will result in greater economic, social and territorial development for the regions. However, it is necessary to preserve the ETE as an important instrument for the Process of European Integration, as well as to provide it with a larger budget for the next programming period. This will strengthen the Union's territorial cohesion objective.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for greater territorial cooperation as it aims to reduce disparities and promote harmonious economic, social and cultural development for the Union as a whole.  Indeed, it is necessary to assign territorial cooperation a more specific role in the context of post-2020 cohesion and to significantly increase its budget.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the best experiences and instruments for European territorial cooperation. The impact of European territorial cooperation brings significant economic benefits. At the same time, it is a potential for future projects. The report therefore calls on the European Commission and the Member States to strive to preserve ETC as an important, positive tool in the Process of European Integration and in the post-2020 cohesion policy. However, the management and implementation of ETC programmes and projects must become less bureaucratic in the future. At the same time, there is still a lack of private sector input in the implementation of ETC. It is therefore necessary to develop financial instruments to involve private stakeholders and to promote public-private partnerships.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 From 1990 the INTERREG - at the origin of European Territorial Cooperation (ETC), was developed with the aim of promoting cross-border cooperation, benefiting 11 Member States and was subsequently extended to the transnational and interregional cooperation strand. In the previous Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), ETC has been shown to effectively serve the objectives of cohesion policy as a programme designed to solve problems that go beyond administrative borders - but require common solutions involving several Member States or even third countries. In this MFF, CTE has been restructured to become more targeted and efficient. It was also intended to make the use of investments more effective through thematic concentration and results orientation.  It is thus verified that ETC contributes significantly to the improvement of the economic, social and territorial potential of the regions by reflecting and integrating diverse sectoral policies at territorial scale and by promoting cross-border/transnational cooperation as well as interregional cooperation. Recognising the importance of ETC in the strategic areas mentioned and considering that the report systematically and quite clearly shows its added value, best practices, support for research and innovation and its contribution to the Europe 2020 strategy, I voted in favour of it.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with European territorial cooperation and more specifically on new practices and measures.  European territorial cooperation, also known as 'Interreg', was established about 25 years ago and remains a key instrument for achieving territorial cohesion through a series of programmes and projects with high European added value, including greater benefits for border regions.  I therefore voted in favour of this report which supports European territorial cooperation and recalls that it has made considerable progress in a range of key sectors such as innovation, knowledge, culture and education.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I think it is crucial to reduce disparities between border regions and to promote peace, stability and regional integration in these areas. In addition, this dossier supports social adaptation and infrastructure mobility, with the aim of creating demographic change and promoting migration flows. It also supports the creation of jobs for the elderly, women and migrants in order to contribute to greater social integration.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of extending the European Territorial Cooperation (ETC) programme as it is one of the most important instruments for THE EU's territorial cohesion. The programme was launched 25 years ago and since then a number of projects with high European added value have already been supported, with a particular impact on the EU's many border regions. Significant progress has been made in sectors such as networking, innovation and knowledge, as well as culture and education.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it contains some positive aspects of relevance to improving the conditions of the reference population. It recommends that particular attention be paid to projects striving to adapt municipalities and regions or nations to the new demographic situation, such as: adapting social and mobility infrastructure to demographic change and migration flows, supporting the search for employment for older people, women and migrants, contributing to better social inclusion. It reinforces the idea of the simplification of programmes and the involvement of civil society, taking into account transparency and accountability. It urges that local and regional or national institutions play a greater role in the proposal, management and evaluation of European territorial cooperation programmes.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report makes some welcome recommendations for the future of European territorial cooperation in order to increase the economic, social and territorial potential of eu regions. The European added value of European territorial cooperation has been demonstrated in many areas: connectivity, mobility and regional accessibility to services; knowledge transfer and innovation; management of environmental challenges and disaster response; consolidation of cross-border network structures and the creation of new partnerships. It is clear, however, that there is a need to simplify and make less bureaucratic the implementation and management of Interreg programmes and projects in order to make full use of the potential of this instrument. I therefore hope that this European Parliament initiative will help to launch a structured debate among all stakeholders at EU level on the future of European territorial cooperation, with a view to preparing cohesion policy after 2020. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 These new European Territorial Cooperation practices are primarily aimed at strengthening, promoting and promoting the actions of the territorial area of the Member States of the European Union in collaboration at transnational and interregional level. This transnational and interregional level collaboration immediately benefits macro-regions and cross-border areas, immediately increasing their level of integration and economic and social cohesion in the European strategic area. The importance of public-private partnerships for harmonising these good cooperation practices, facilitating political and economic issues, should also be stressed. Clearly, this will have to be linked to ensuring transparency and correctness in all planning, approaches and procedures.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this report due it being an EU Commission project, and we do not recognise the Commission’s competency in this area.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it calls on the Commission and Member States to work towards preserving European territorial cooperation (ETC) as an important and positive instrument for the European integration process by allocating it a more distinct role within cohesion policy post 2020 and increasing its budget for the next programming period.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I see European territorial cooperation (ETC) as the cornerstone of European integration, which plays an extremely important role in the creation of a common European area. I am glad that the EUS has been demonstrating its effectiveness for a long time, but on the other hand, I regret that due to the lack of resources, its potential has not yet fully developed in some areas (single market, mobility, employment, research, education...). I voted in favour of the resolution because the report not only talks about achievements, but comes up with ideas and innovative measures that can contribute to achieving balanced integration of the various territories of the EU. Although more flexibility has recently been introduced into European territorial cooperation and the implementation of cooperation programmes has reduced the administrative burden on the authorities responsible for programmes, there are still significant differences between rural and urban areas. I therefore expect that the link and consistency of ETC programmes with national and regional programmes will be strengthened in a more significant way. I also expect greater attention to be paid to geographically and demographically disadvantaged areas when implementing cohesion policy.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 European territorial cooperation is an important instrument in cohesion policy. It is designed to overcome administrative boundaries, reduce the impact of national borders and remove barriers to cooperation and territorial integration. Cross-border cooperation between 2000 and 2006 and 2007 to 2013 has developed good practices in the areas of better connectivity and accessibility, knowledge transfer and innovation, strengthening regional identity, addressing environmental challenges and more.  European territorial cooperation provides significant added value for the European Union by contributing to peace, stability and regional integration in the context of enlargement policy and neighbourhood policy. Cross-border cooperation can also bring added value to managing the migration crisis.  Parliament analysed the implementation of the European Territorial Cooperation as presented in the 2014-2020 programming period. Parliament has always supported this kind of policy, thus asking for more resources to this end.  The report proposes some new ways of regulating this mechanism, such as thematic focus and focus of action. It is also important to point out that around 41% of the European territorial cooperation budget under the European Regional Development Fund is earmarked for environmental improvement measures. For all these reasons, I supported the report.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. This own-initiative report deals with the European Territorial Cooperation (ETC), also known as Interreg. This financial instrument was developed in 1990 as a Community initiative under EU cohesion policy and includes EUR 10.1 billion for the current Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). The aim is to improve cross-border or transnational and interregional cooperation within the EU. On the positive side of the report are the calls for greater results-oriented, better implementation of ETC programmes, more data and monitoring systems, more coordination, synergy and complementarity, as well as simplification of programmes and a reduction in the administrative burden required to do so. It also calls for a better link with efforts to address the current migration crisis. However, the statement that "only" EUR 10.1 billion is available for 2014-2020, as well as the blanket demand to spend more money on the ETC after 2020, without at the same time pushing for savings in other areas, is negative. The fact that, in addition to meaningful projects under EU cohesion policy, a number of activities are not being implemented in a targeted, sustainable or efficient manner, and that available funds cannot be called up in individual Member States due to the lack of professional administrative capacity, a blanket demand for more funding for a cohesion policy instrument is a complete mockery of European taxpayers. That is why I am opposed to this report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ border regions are natural natural, economic and sociological units, which in the past have often been divided by political decisions. Many of them represent the poorest regions within their country as well as in Europe. The European Union seeks to promote their natural cooperation, both financially and through the sharing of know-how and information.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution on 'European territorial cooperation – best practices and innovative measures'. European Territorial Cooperation (ETC) is an integral part of cohesion policy as it strengthens the Union's territorial cohesion. Its aim is to reduce the impact of national borders in order to reduce imbalances between regions, to remove the obstacles to investment and cross-border cooperation, to strengthen cohesion and to promote the harmonious economic, social and territorial development of the Union as a whole. I reject cohesion policy as a purely redistributing instrument. The AfD stands for independent and strong local authorities in Germany. We want to enable regional and local self-government and guarantee subsidiarity, so that regional peculiarities and peculiarities can be maintained. We want to give more weight to federalism. The AfD is thus already somewhat sceptical about a policy of regional balance within Germany. At EU level, it has nothing to do with it. We stand for strong and independent nation states.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Interreg is a key instrument for achieving territorial cohesion through the support of a number of programmes and projects with strong European added value, with particular impact on 60 European border regions. This report gives us an overview of the measures and added value of European territorial cooperation, best practices and contributions to the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy.  Cross-border cooperation projects show concrete results: they remove barriers to progress in the areas of security, transport, education, energy, health, training and employment. I support this proposal for a resolution on European territorial cooperation – best practices and innovative measures, as I think cross-border cooperation is essential for the progress of border regions.  However, cooperation between different funding and cooperation mechanisms such as macro-regional strategies should be strengthened and links and coherence with national and regional programmes should be strengthened. Countries and regions must enhance cooperation and develop common, integrated strategies with implementing provisions on a mechanism for coordinating cross-border and transnational programmes that will allow for a better coordinated and long-term solution to challenges.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on European territorial cooperation – best practice and innovative measures.  I support European territorial cooperation, which is part of cohesion policy and which helps to reduce the impact of national borders, in order to reduce disparities between regions and to remove barriers to investment that would work across borders. I agree with the report that, if we wanted to make full use of the potential of European territorial cooperation, we should devote more resources to it within cohesion policy, as it currently represents 2.8% of the cohesion policy budget.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the report, the primary role of European Territorial Cooperation is to reduce the impact of national borders, which poses a direct threat to the national sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Territorial Cooperation (Interreg) established 25 years ago remains a key tool for achieving territorial cohesion between more than 60 European border regions. Over the last quarter of a century, progress has been made in many key sectors such as transport, innovation, knowledge, culture and education.  Moreover, interregional cooperation has allowed cities and regions to establish cooperation in a wide range and in a variety of thematic areas, including the exchange of experience and best practices, which has improved the effectiveness of many regional and local policies. Despite these achievements, many obstacles remain for further approximation, as m.in. divergent national rules in the fields of employment, health care and social security. The report properly identifies the current problems of territorial cooperation and the objectives on which we should focus in the coming years. Research and innovation, joint research projects, the creation of international border universities, cross-border clusters and networks of companies, and the joint attracting of foreign investors are challenges that need to be given particular attention.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 European Territorial Cooperation (ETC) is one of the essential components of the European Union, stemming from its very founding principles. It has been covered since 1990 by the Interreg Community initiative, which, in addition to cross-border cooperation, has now come to include transnational cooperation and interregional cooperation (between cities and regions).  THE TEC brings definite added value to the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy by improving regional connectivity, mobility and accessibility of services (including in transport), knowledge transfer and innovation, increasing the competitiveness of SMEs, the quality mark and strengthening regional identity, countering environmental challenges, better risk management and disaster response, strengthening institutional capacity and social capital , strengthening the structures of cross-border networks and creating new partnerships.  All these dimensions contribute to alleviating regional development gaps within the EU by providing a platform for local development closely linked to the immediate interests of European citizens. They also allow for proper support for research and innovation, coordination of government policies and simplification of bureaucratic mechanisms.  For all the above reasons, the financing of this policy must be maintained at least at the same level as before, in conjunction with better information to citizens and increased visibility.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. The best practices have clear added value: joint preparation of a proposal to list the German-Czech mining region on the UNESCO World Heritage List [Germany (Saxony)-Czech Republic]; development of "green" tourism activities to preserve the region's outstanding natural heritage (Germany/Bavaria-Austria); development of local strategies based on the results of specific programme projects (Norway, Sweden, Denmark), Ramsar Eco NaTour project, creation of leisure spaces for the urban cities of Vienna and Bratislava and improved local awareness and regional cooperation on climate change and biodiversity protection (Austria, Slovakia), etc.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which looked at best practices and innovative measures for European Territorial Cooperation (ETC), an important instrument of cohesion policy designed to solve problems which transcend administrative borders and require common solutions. While the ETC has been proven to be an effective instrument, best practice and particularly innovative measures have the potential to develop the fund even further by encouraging synergies between actors and programmes, reduce the administrative burden on beneficiaries, and simplify the implementation of its programmes. However, the ETC budget of EUR 10.1 billion represents 2.8% of the cohesion policy budget, which does not match the great challenges that ETC has to meet.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report on European territorial cooperation aimed at removing remaining barriers to investment and cross-border cooperation, strengthening cohesion and fostering the economic and social development of the Union. I believe that European territorial cooperation is of utmost importance for strengthening regional cooperation and integration in island regions, outermost regions, poorly developed regions and mountainous and rural areas. In particular, I support the call on Member States to make more use of integrated territorial investment (ITI) and community-led local development (CLLD), new tools in cohesion policy.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for European Territorial Cooperation – best practice and innovative measures.  European territorial cooperation was redesigned in 2014-2020 to achieve greater impact and more efficient use of investment, with a focus on thematic and results orientation. European territorial cooperation makes an important contribution to increasing the economic, social and territorial opportunities of regions by addressing and integrating different sectoral policies at territorial level. Cooperation between the various funding and cooperation mechanisms, such as macro-regional strategies, should be increased and links and coherence with national and regional programmes should be strengthened.  Member States and regions should develop common integrated strategies with implementing provisions for the coordination mechanism between relevant cross-border and transnational programmes and their territorial character, which can address the challenges posed in an integrated and more coordinated and long-term perspective.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I think it is crucial to reduce disparities between border regions and to promote peace, stability and regional integration in these areas. In addition, this dossier supports social adaptation and infrastructure mobility, with the aim of creating demographic change and promoting migration flows. It also supports the creation of jobs for the elderly, women and migrants in order to contribute to greater social integration.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to strengthen territorial cooperation, the overall aim of which is to reduce the influence of national borders within the European Union. Although territorial cooperation can encourage the proliferation of cross-border projects, it is above all a further step towards the federalisation of the European Union.  I voted AGAINST.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The resolution identifies effective territorial cooperation decisions in the Member States and focuses on important future plans. Success is ensured by: cooperation in the territorial and communication field, ensuring competitiveness and supporting the SME sector, achievements in the field of research and innovation, promoting regional identity, territorial cohesion and increasing institutional capacity and social capital. European territorial cooperation is an important instrument that has a positive impact on European integration, which is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Interreg was established as a Community initiative in 1990, with a budget of only EUR 1 billion, to support cross-border cooperation only with 11 beneficiary Member States. It was later extended to transnational and interregiocial cooperation. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour in this report because I think it is crucial to reduce disparities between border regions and to promote peace, stability and regional integration in these areas. In addition, this dossier supports social adaptation and infrastructure mobility, with the aim of creating demographic change and promoting migration flows. It also supports the creation of jobs for the elderly, women and migrants in order to contribute to greater social integration.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for as European Territorial Cooperation (ETC) is an important instrument in cohesion policy, designed to tackle challenges that transcend administrative borders, lessen the influence of national borders, and remove obstacles to cooperation and territorial integration. An appropriate budget is needed to meet this crucial tool of European added-value and to re-focus on real cooperation among citizens and actors especially in the closest border areas.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on European Territorial Cooperation – best practices and innovative measures. The overarching objective of ETC is to lessen the influence of national borders in order to reduce disparities between regions, removing the remaining obstacles to investment and cooperative working across borders, reinforce cohesion, and promote the harmonious economic, social, cultural and territorial development of the Union as a whole. The report emphasises that efficient cross-border and transnational cooperation makes a geographical area more attractive for trading companies, by using local, regional and cross-border potential, as well as human capital, as effectively as possible. I voted in favour because I believe that cross-border cooperation is a key tool for the development of border regions, which are considered true laboratories of European integration.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The rapporteur is right to deal with the important work that the European Territorial Cooperation (Interreg) has done over the past 25 years through the support of European programmes and projects with great added value. It also rightly addresses the challenges and challenges of this tool in the medium and long term of cohesion policy, stressing the need to further promote interregional cooperation through cooperation and coordination between local, regional, national and European authorities where appropriate in order to promote increased synergies, the use of various European programmes , the promotion of multi-level governance and the exchange of good practices and the more efficient use of public money. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. About 38% of the European population lives in a border region. The EU is facing a serious economic, financial and social crisis, which is particularly hampering women on all fronts in these regions. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that greater coordination, synergy and complementarity between cross-border and transnational dossiers should be pursued. Some of these regions also face major migration challenges. We call for the speedy implementation of Interreg programmes to address, among other things, the refugee crisis and to ensure the exchange of proven practices between local and regional authorities in border areas.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report notes that the ETC has become one of the two equivalent objectives of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. Interregional cooperation enables cities and regions to work together on a wide range of issues. The ETC also allows for enhanced cooperation in sparsely populated areas. The report is very well differentiated, and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012I voted in favour of the report on European territorial cooperation – best practices and innovative measures. One of the main objectives of the report is to recall the interest of the Member States and the Commission in preserving the ETC as a significant and positive tool for the European integration process, by giving the ETC a key role in post-2020 cohesion policy and by increasing its budget for the next programming period.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it calls on the Commission and Member States to work towards preserving ETC as an important and positive instrument for the European integration process, through allocating ETC a more distinct role within Cohesion policy post-2020 and increasing its budget for the next programming period.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With this initiative, which I supported, the European Parliament is helping to create a flexible and simplified framework to support European Territorial Cooperation. The text highlights its contribution to territorial cohesion, support for research and innovation, better policy coordination and pays particular attention to informing citizens.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I decided to support this report because I consider European territorial cooperation to be one of the important instruments of cohesion policy, which helps to reduce disparities between eu regions and promotes balanced territorial development. In my opinion, European territorial cooperation contributes to improving cross-border cooperation and to the potential of different territories. At the same time, however, it also promotes education and cultural exchange. From the point of view of the Czech Republic, research institutions, universities and universities and SMEs can be suitable partners for the EUS.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ European territorial cooperation as one of the two objectives of cohesion policy provides a framework for the implementation of the actions linked and the exchange of policies between national, regional and local actors from different Member States, playing an important role at all these levels and currently benefiting all 28 Member States. Cross-border cooperation is generally a key instrument in the development of border regions. Interregional cooperation also enables cities and regions to cooperate on a number of topics. That is why I believe that European territorial cooperation offers significant European added value and contributes to stability and integration. This cooperation is particularly important in isolated regions or sparsely populated and rural areas, which Mrs Mihaylova's report correctly identified and encouraged that the potential of this territorial cooperation be fully exploited. For all these reasons, as well as because of the balance of the report, I have decided to give it my vote.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on European Territorial Cooperation – Best Practice and Innovative Measures. Cross-border cooperation is a key tool for the development of border regions, which are often at their most geographically and demographically disadvantaged. I agree with the recommendation that the potential of European territorial cooperation should be further developed in areas such as the single market, digital agenda, employment, mobility, energy, research, education, culture, health and the environment.  The Commission and the Member States should thus maintain European territorial cooperation as an important instrument and establish a more pronounced role for it within cohesion policy after 2020 and significantly increase the budget.

name: Curzio Maltese (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of the interim report in order to support the difficult work of the Committee of Inquiry, but we must not hide the reality. Two trends have already come into conflict in this committee: one, determined to clarify a scandal that was born in Europe and discovered in America, in a matter that further deprives the European institutions of their credibility. The other tendency is to water down facts and evidence in order to achieve self-absorption that is convenient for certain political groups.  First of all, we need to answer public questions, for example: was the Commission aware of the discrepancies between laboratory tests and road tests, as the former Italian Commissioner, Mr Tajani, himself admitted? And, if you knew, why did you keep quiet and didn't do anything for years?  It is about the health and work of European citizens. We cannot tolerate other ambiguities, let alone indulge in an silence that in my country calls itself a mafia.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I listened very carefully to the debate here this morning on this issue, and I am pleased to support this report, in which this extremely important committee of inquiry has asked for support on all the measures needed for it to fulfil its mandate.
