It is important that Parliament gives support to the committee to ensure they can hold hearings, bring the relevant people before them and get the right insights into the automotive-sector emissions scandal from last year. The hearings that the committee has held thus far have managed to provide some very interesting insights, as we heard this morning. I am pleased that it is working to get to the bottom of the scandal. Ensuring that the rules we make at EU and national level are adhered to is vital, and the fitting of the so-called defeat devices by Volkswagen is a clear breach of those rules. We must ensure that companies who cheat the system are found out and exposed, not least because they undermine our efforts to limit our carbon emissions and to ensure high-quality ambient air for our citizens.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I support the Committee of Inquiry in regard to the investigation of emissions in the automotive sector. This work of course is triggered by the Volkswagen scandal, but the European Parliament is not the only place in Europe where Volkswagen’s actions are being questioned.  Despite the fact that the Volkswagen legal team walked out, a case is proceeding in Castlebar court in County Mayo in Ireland on this issue. The case seeks to make public the original expert opinion and technical evidence VW used to develop a fix for the affected engines. The case brings to the fore the fact that there is no mechanism at European level for citizens to take a class action, and that is something we have to deal with. Volkswagen settled on a figure of USD 15 billion in relation to a class action taken in the US. EU citizens deserve no less than US citizens when it comes to defending their rights. So I say well done to those who took the case, and those who decided to hear it in the Castlebar court.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cooperation between the Member States and the Commission is an essential element for the proper conduct of the investigation which verifies possible maladministration, both at European and national level, in the application of the current legislation on car emissions. In order to encourage and encourage this cooperation, I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. Without prejudice to the jurisdiction of the courts, a commission of inquiry into allegations of infringement and mismanagement in the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector was established on 17 December 2015. The scope of the investigation is limited by Article 226 TFEU and the Decision on the right of investigation of the EP, according to which it should focus on investigating the compliance of the Commission and States with the obligations of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007. In addition to collecting and analysing information on the implementation of Directive 2007/46/EC, determine whether they had evidence of the use of deactivation devices and make any recommendations it deems necessary. While the final report will take place in March 2017, this vote refers to the interim report which, by its nature, cannot advance conclusions before all witnesses are heard and quite evidence gathered.  It is therefore purely technical in nature, emphasizing procedural aspects. The principles of parence and good cooperation between institutions are recalled and all actors involved are requested to provide the necessary assistance for the fulfilment of the mandate of the EMIS Commission. That is why I vote in favour of the report.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We believe that national parliaments should be responsible for all investigations related to maladministration in the application of environmental law.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I supported the report on the automotive emissions measurement survey. This interim report sets out the methods and hearings that constitute Parliament's investigation into the Volkswagen scandal.  It is a report that encourages representatives of the institutions and the authorities of the Member States to work with loyalty to bring together all the elements necessary for a neutral and effective investigation.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for resolution, which is the interim report of the Committee of Inquiry that was established in December to investigate alleged contraventions or maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to emission measurements in the automotive sector (Volkswagen scandal). The inquiry is ongoing and the report does not include any conclusions or recommendations. It calls for ongoing support and cooperation for the inquiry by the Commission and national governments, such as providing swifter access to requested documents.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to keep up the pressure on the Member States and the European Commission, which are dragging their feet to come and explain themselves to the European Parliament. The results of surveys carried out in the various Member States are also still waiting. While it is important to determine the responsibilities of the various institutions in the scandal, the challenge is also to identify the dysfunctions that have allowed it.  European legislation clearly defines what is prohibited, but its effective implementation and control of its proper application sometimes leave something to be desired: the Commission sends the ball back to the Member States, which are turning the ball over to the manufacturers, demonstrating that Europe is sorely lacking in a coherent global framework to ensure compliance with standards that limit pollution. If Europe is able to produce legislation for harmonised control for railways, it should be able to do so for automobiles.  We remain mobilised with the imminent revision of the European vehicle registration framework: setting and enforcing high emission standards is a priority. It's about saving lives!

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the interim report on the inquiry into emission measurements in the automotive sector. The report encourages the Committee of Inquiry to pursue its work and to implement fully the mandate given by Parliament in its decision of 17 December 2015; it asks the Conference of Presidents and the Bureau to support all measures needed to enable the Committee of Inquiry to fulfil its mandate. The interim report asks the Commission to ensure prompt support and full transparency in assisting the work of the Committee of Inquiry, and requires that the governments, parliaments and competent authorities of Member States assist the Committee of Inquiry in its tasks with full respect for the principle of loyal cooperation established in the Union law. I fully support the approach taken and look forward to the hearings to take place later this year.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the interim report on the examination of emission measurements in the automotive industry, because it recalls the principle of good cooperation between the institutions, insists on full transparency and finally calls on all stakeholders to provide the necessary assistance to fulfil the mission of the EMS Committee.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. In the wake of the revelations about rigged emissions tests on diesel cars, the European Parliament has set up a committee of inquiry into emissions measurements in the automotive industry (EMIS). This EMIS committee is investigating whether the EU Commission or national officials were aware of the fraud, or at least suspected, before this illegal practice was discovered in the US, and why they were not more active – consciously or unconsciously – of the problem, given the differences in the different types of measurement. Parliament has now been presented with the committee's interim report. I voted in favour of the text because I fully support full clarification of this matter and I would like to see measures to prevent such practices at the expense of the consumer in the future. I therefore also support the call for the Commission to cooperate transparently and loyally and to provide much-needed additional information.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. In 2015, revelations by U.S. researchers about rigging software to mask nitrogen dioxide emissions from diesel engines led to the Volkswagen scandal. This process allowed the world's largest automaker to export to the United States despite strict limits on nitrogen dioxide emissions. On 17 December 2015, a commission of inquiry to examine allegations of breaches of EU law or maladministration in the application of EU law was set up in the European Parliament. This interim report sets out the method and hearings that make up Parliament's inquiry into emissions in the automotive sector. The actual hearings will continue "until autumn 2016," after which MEPs will work on the final report.  This brief and very neutral text encourages the Committee of Inquiry to continue its work, calls on the Conference of Presidents and the Commission and the authorities of the Member States to work with loyalty, so that no element of the investigation escapes the committee.  I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interests of transparency and democracy I voted against this report. I believe that national parliaments should be responsible for all investigations related to maladministration in the application of environmental law. Although the report is broadly OK I oppose it because it urges Member States too assist the EU Committee of Inquiry. I think the UK automotive industry has been through enough already.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 17 December 2015, the European Parliament set up a Committee of Inquiry composed of 45 Members to investigate alleged irregularities or maladministration in the implementation of Union legislation on emissions measurements. I support the call that the Committee of Inquiry must continue its work and fully implement its mandate.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We believe that national parliaments should be responsible for all investigations related to maladministration in the application of environmental law.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which encourages the Committee of Inquiry to continue its work, which consists of examining allegations of infringement of EU law concerning the world's leading car manufacturer Volkswagen, which allegedly used rigging software to mask nitrogen dioxide emissions in order to export more to the United States.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Following the scandal over the falsification of pollution tests for Volkswagen cars in September 2015, the European Parliament decided to set up a commission of inquiry into allegations of infringement of EU law in relation to the measurement of emissions in the 45-member automotive sector to examine these allegations of infringement.  For obvious environmental and public health reasons, but also for simple reasons of honesty towards citizens and fair competition between manufacturers, we cannot accept the idea that economic actors feel entitled to falsify their emissions in the face of a possible inadequacy of controls or a misapsed application of EU law in this area.  Convinced of the need to send a strong message and to be able to improve existing legislation to prevent this kind of behaviour in the future, I voted in favour of this interim report of the Committee of Inquiry which encourages the Committee of Inquiry to continue its work and fulfil its mandate and supports all actions and initiatives aimed at the achievement of the latter.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 It is necessary to continue the progress in the investigation by the parliamentary committee on Emissions Measurement in the Automotive Sector in order to assess the most political aspects of the Volkswagen scandal. In addition, we are considering updating existing Union regulations to ensure that measurements are closer to real driving circumstances. The parliamentary committee investigating the measurements of car emissions determines that the German manufacturer and its subsidiaries have to undertake the review of 8.5 million units in Europe, 2.4 million of them in Germany alone. The report denounces the lack of cooperation of Member States in clarifying how this consumer fraud could occur. European Internal Market Commissioner Elzbieta Bienkowska he has announced the intention to open files to those Member States which failed to fulfil their control obligations for failing to take appropriate sanctioning measures.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the scandals following the revelations about rigged devices used to reduce pollutant emissions during official car tests, the European Parliament decided last December to set up a committee of inquiry. The aim is to examine complaints of infringement and maladministration in the application of Union legislation on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector. The EMIS Committee began its work in March, setting a precise timetable for the final report scheduled for spring 2017. The interim report presented to Parliament today, which I have decided to support with my vote, calls on the Committee of Inquiry to continue its work, supporting all actions and initiatives aimed at ensuring that its mandate is carried out. The text calls on the Member States and the Commission to provide all necessary technical and political support and calls in particular on the Commission to submit rapidly the required documentation on vehicle emission measurements, including the work carried out by the Joint Research Centre (JRC) and all records of the activities of the various expert groups dealing with legislation on vehicle type-approval procedures.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution urging the Committee of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector, in the wake of the VW scandal, to fully implement the mandate given by Parliament in its Decision of 17 December 2015. It requests the Conference of Presidents and the Bureau to support all necessary measures, in particular with regard to the authorization of extraordinary hearings and meetings, reimbursement of the costs of experts and witnesses, missions and any other duly justified technical means. Requests the European Commission to ensure immediate support and full transparency, providing as much political and technical support as possible, in particular by presenting the requested documentation more promptly; expects the full cooperation of Commissioners and relevant general management, both those currently in office and those who were currently in office during previous mandates. It calls on the governments, parliaments and competent authorities of the Member States to assist the Committee of Inquiry in their work with full respect for the principle of fair cooperation laid down in EU law.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report because I agree with three basic issues it contains: to ask the Commission for more information and to improve cooperation with it, to strengthen the preventive aspects of this emissions work, to prevent such a case from being repeated and also to examine the responsibilities incurred by Member States which cannot be unaware that much of their inspector functions are responsible for them.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I supported this interim report which details the method and timetable for this special commission on the investigation into emissions measurement in the automotive sector. Recall, this commission was created in the wake of the Volkswagen scandal revealing the "fraud" of the first car manufacturer for export purposes. This report does not mention the substance, as MEPs will be working on the final report until the end of the year. I can therefore only support the rapporteurs' stated desire for genuine cooperation between the Commission and the competent authorities of the Member States, in order to shed light on this matter.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report takes stock of progress in the work of the Committee of Inquiry into the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector and sets out the future work programme on time. I believe that the text is clear, acceptable and without any critical issues, which is why I wanted to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Without prejudice to the jurisdiction of the courts, on 17 December 2015 a Commission of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector was established.  The scope of the investigation is limited by Article 226 TFEU and the Decision on the right of investigation of the EP, according to which it should focus on investigating compliance by the Commission and the States with the obligations of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007. In addition to collecting and analysing information on the implementation of Directive 2007/46/EC, it should determine whether they had evidence of the use of deactivation devices and make any recommendations it deems necessary. Since the final report will be presented in March 2017, this vote refers to the interim report which, by its nature, cannot advance conclusions before all witnesses are heard and sufficient evidence is gathered.  It is therefore purely technical in nature, as it emphasizes procedural aspects. The principles of transparency and good cooperation between institutions are recalled and all actors involved are requested to provide the necessary assistance for the fulfilment of the mandate of the EMIS Commission. That is why I vote in favour of the report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has been advocated by Parliament on measuring emissions in the automotive sector. In 2015, the European Parliament decided to set up a Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged irregularities in the implementation of Union law in the automotive sector and decided that it would make recommendations that it would consider necessary in this regard. With this report, Parliament asks the Commission to ensure urgent support and full transparency in the work of the Committee of Inquiry to carry out its work, taking full account of the principle of sincere cooperation, with all possible technical and political support, in particular by speeding up the submission of the required documents. Parliament also asks the Member States to provide the Committee of Inquiry with the necessary technical and political support, in full respect of the principle of sincere cooperation, in particular by enabling the Commission to provide the required documents more quickly and, where the submission of documents requires the consent of the Member States, by accelerated internal procedures for granting such consent.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The activities of the EMIS Committee were in line with the mandate and accepted methodology of work, in particular in the organisation of hearings of witnesses and experts, which is the core activity of the committee. All EMIS committee members are made available to all witness and expert testimonies through the website, which contributes to taking all relevant information into account in the committee's final report. Investigative actions in collecting written documentation were carried out in detail and comprehensively through the involvement of the widest circle of relevant institutions. Transparency in the work and availability in the collection of evidence is made possible, by setting up a special committee website. In further work, while respecting the principle of close cooperation, the EMIS Committee should be provided with all possible technical and political support by the competent institutions, which is why I voted at the session to confirm the report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The exhaust scandal is actually an attack on the health and consumer rights of citizens and the economy of the European Union and the Member States.  "Damage" is the release of nitric oxides, which are especially harmful to the liver, lungs and blood count of citizens. They were cheated into selling more expensive cars that were supposedly less harmful to the environment. I support this report and hope that the work of EMIS will contribute to shedding light on the affair and preventing new ones.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Indeed, it is particularly wise to question the practices of car manufacturers in relation to carbon dioxide emissions and the possible cheating of manufacturers in relation to controls in this area. This report, which encourages the Commission of Inquiry appointed for this purpose, to continue its work inviting the Committee and the Member States to work with loyalty, is a step in the right direction. I therefore voted for this text.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 16 December 2015, the European Parliament decided to set up a committee of inquiry to investigate cases of infringement and maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector. The Committee of Inquiry was set up following the revelation that the Volkswagen Group had circumvented NOx (nitrogen oxide) emission limits for diesel vehicles. Its mandate must be respected and it is important that the citizens of Europe are informed of what has happened and that the truth is established. The laws must be the same for everyone, and those who have made a mistake must be held to account, both because of the principle of justice and in order not to undermine citizens' confidence in the impartial role of guarantee and control played by the institutions.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. On September 18, 2015, the Volkswagen scandal broke, following revelations by US researchers about rigging software to mask nitrogen dioxide emissions from diesel engines.  This process allowed the world's largest automaker to export to the United States despite strict limits on nitrogen dioxide emissions. Parliament then decided on 17 December 2015 to form a commission of inquiry to examine allegations of breaches of EU law.  This interim report details the method of Parliament's inquiry into emissions in the automotive sector. It is only after the close of the hearings, in the autumn of 2016, that MEPs will work on the drafting of the final report.  I voted in favour of this report, which simply encourages the Committee of Inquiry to continue its work and calls on the Conference of Presidents and the Commission and the authorities of the Member States to work together so that no element of the investigation escapes the Commission.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The establishment of a commission of inquiry to investigate alleged infringements or cases of maladministration in the application of Union law with regard to the measurement of emissions in the motor vehicle sector is a timely initiative to ensure environmental protection and to carefully monitor the legislation in force. The work of this committee of inquiry is complex and is based on the collection and analysis of information with a view to determining whether Member States had at their disposal evidence of the use of defeat devices, as well as information on the implementation by Member States of Directive 2007/46/EC.  I welcome this interim report on the Investigation on the measurement of emissions in the motor vehicle sector because I am convinced that the results of the investigation will contribute to the improvement of the European Union's type-approval framework, and the actions of this Commission will contribute to compliance with the legislation in force on emission measurement in the motor vehicle sector.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. Without prejudice to the jurisdiction of the courts, a commission of inquiry into allegations of infringement and mismanagement in the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector was established on 17 December 2015. The scope of the investigation is limited by Article 226 TFEU and the Decision on the right of investigation of the EP, according to which it should focus on investigating the compliance of the Commission and States with the obligations of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007. In addition to collecting and analysing information on the implementation of Directive 2007/46/EC, determine whether they had evidence of the use of deactivation devices and make any recommendations it deems necessary. While the final report will take place in March 2017, this vote refers to the interim report which, by its nature, cannot advance conclusions before all witnesses are heard and quite evidence gathered.  It is therefore purely technical in nature, emphasizing procedural aspects. The principles of parence and good cooperation between institutions are recalled and all actors involved are requested to provide the necessary assistance for the fulfilment of the mandate of the EMIS Commission. That is why I vote in favour of the report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, I voted in favour of the interim report on the work carried out so far by the Committee of Inquiry set up by the European Parliament in the wake of the Volkswagen scandal on breaches of EU standards for measuring car emissions. The Committee of Inquiry will work for a year (we are in the middle of its term of office), with the task of investigating the alleged failure to verify the test cycles used by the Commission, the alleged failure of the Commission and the Authorities of the Member States to take appropriate measures to make effective the application of the explicit prohibition of 'handling devices' and the Commission's alleged failure to introduce evidence reflecting the actual driving conditions. The European Union is a world leader in the fight against environmental pollution. Just think of the driving role it played in achieving the Paris climate agreement or what it is playing within the ICAO for an extension of the ETS scheme worldwide. The credibility of the European Union in the eyes of the world also depends, and very much, on this inquiry.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for resolution, which is the interim report of the Committee of Inquiry that was established in December to investigate alleged contraventions or maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to emission measurements in the automotive sector (Volkswagen scandal). The inquiry is ongoing and the report does not include any conclusions or recommendations. It calls for ongoing support and cooperation for the inquiry by the Commission and national governments, such as providing swifter access to requested documents.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it sets out the need for cooperation from all those entities involved in order to be able to implement its mandate effectively. Amongst others it asks the Commission to ensure prompt support and full transparency in assisting the work of the Committee of Inquiry, in particular through swifter submission of requested documentation; expects full cooperation from the relevant current Commissioners and Directorate-Generals as well as from those who were in charge during past terms. It asks the Member States, to provide the Committee with the necessary technical and political support, by enabling the Commission to submit documents that are requested more swiftly and, if necessary by accelerating their internal proceedings for the granting of such consent.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is the half-term report by which the EMIS Special Committee of Inquiry informs Parliament of the progress of the work. There is no direct reference to the merits of the investigation – that is, the verification of the conditions under which the EU and the Member States are applying the legislation on the control of car emissions – but the report calls on the Member States and the Commission to cooperate fully in providing all relevant information to the investigation. I certainly voted in favour.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the work of the Committee of Inquiry into the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector (EMIS) is indispensable to examine alleged infringements of Union law or cases of maladministration in the field of emissions measurement in the automotive sector. The recent scandals in the car market and undermined European consumer confidence require us to establish whether the Commission and the Member States were aware of the use of defeat devices and also to collect reliable data on the application of the directive by the Member States. I have decided to vote in favour of the interim report because I hope that the Committee of Inquiry will continue its work and complete the mandate it has been given. To this end, the report calls on the European Commission to ensure all technical and political support to the members of EMIS in full transparency. Finally, I believe that the governments, national parliaments and competent authorities of the Member States must cooperate with the Committee of Inquiry in carrying out its tasks, in full respect of the principle of loyal cooperation.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and welcome transparency for the public in relation to the work of the committee, subject to the maintenance of confidentiality, where necessary, as through the special website of the EMIS Committee, the members of the committee and the public can find there all relevant information related to the work of the committee.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The interim report on the examination of emission measurements in the automotive industry, which we voted on today, is one of the steps we are called upon to take to upgrade the regulatory framework in a very important area, such as that of pollutant emissions. Following the revelations a few months ago about falsified emissions results in the car industry, I believe that this report is a proper attempt to correct the problems and shortcomings that exist. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of more support for the Committee of Inquiry into Emissions in the Automotive Sector, given the seriousness and importance of this sensitive issue for Europe, its citizens and its industries. We are at an historic moment where growth can only be sustainable, therefore full of implications for everyone: from stockholders to citizens, from workers to the environment. In order to allow effective evolution, it is necessary to ascertain the extent of the emissive phenomenon and its multi-level bequests.  In the face of the scandals that have arisen, it is all the more necessary to speed up the flow of information and documents between Parliament and the Member States in order to ensure transparency and justice. While I am firmly convinced of this need, I hope that this cooperation between European and national bodies will develop within the boundaries of respect for the different jurisdictions and their competences. Pending the final report, scheduled for 2 March 2017, I hope that the outcome of the inquiry will shed light as soon as possible on the right and wrong behaviour in order to avoid a repetition of situations harmful to citizens in the future.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the Inquiry into emission measurements in the automotive sector and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following complaints made in September 2015 by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) that the Volkswagen group was making vehicles capable of cheating pollution controls, the European Parliament decided on 17 December 2015 to set up a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged misdemeanors or mismanagement in the application of Community law in relation to the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector. The aim of this EMIS Commission progress report is to provide an overview of the Commission's activities since its establishment on 2 March 2016 and a perspective on the next work plan on the first half of the Commission's mandate. I congratulate the Commission for meeting the deadline for submitting this preliminary report and for setting up a website where members and the public can obtain all relevant information relating to the Commission's activities, helping to ensure that the Commission's work is as transparent as possible, without prejudice, where necessary, to the preservation of confidentiality.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – There are alleged failures in the application of Union law in relation to emission measurements in the automotive sector which need to be investigated. I agree that the results of the ongoing investigation could bring added value to the Union’s type-approval framework support all measures needed to enable the Committee of Inquiry to fulfil its mandate.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this resolution because, although I cannot object to its content, it lacks political significance. It is my view that the well-known information on the emissions scandal (and in particular the scandal involved in the disclosure that European regulations were implemented to allow serious discrepancies between actual and fictitious emissions, so many systems for handling broadcasts similar to the software developed by Volskwagen-Bosch were legally used with the approval and knowledge of national and European authorities) should have been reflected in it , rather than waiting another six months to present the final conclusions.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 17 December 2015, the European Parliament set up a committee to investigate alleged maladministration in the application of EU legislation on emissions from the automotive sector. The Commission shall collect and analyse the information to determine whether the Member States had evidence of the use of defeat devices.  I voted for the inclusion of the supplementary meetings in Brussels and Strasbourg, for the exchange of views and for further investigations into emissions from the motor vehicle sector.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I fully support the content of the mid-term report on emission measurements in the automotive sector. I welcome the fact that, as promised, the report has a fully technical rather than a political dimension. It focuses on the need for cooperation between EU bodies (Conference of Presidents, EP Bureau, European Commission) and national authorities of each Member State.  I believe that reports that focus on important aspects of life should be supported, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Following the outbreak of the Volkswagen scandal, the European Parliament set up the Committee of Inquiry into the Emission Measurements of the Automotive Sector. This report represents the committee’s first six months of work. The report pushes for transparency and asks for assistance from actors involved. Together with my colleagues of the EMIS committee, I have been working to reform the emission measurements in the automotive sector while also ensuring that Europeans’ health is safeguarded. I believe that as the work of this committee progresses, more evidence is collected and the picture becomes more clear, these elements are crucial to have effective and reliable emissions measurements which is crucially important in safeguarding the health of our citizens. This is why I have voted in favour of this report, which will be a stepping stone into the second half of the inquiry committee’s mandate.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst we must await the eventual final outcome of the EMIS Committee’s investigation I can support this interim technical summary of progress made so far.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 More than six months after the establishment of the Committee of Inquiry, decided in December 2015 following the discovery of the Dieselgate scandal, the European Parliament today approved the interim report on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector.  The work that awaits us in the coming months will be to go even deeper, in order to shed full light on the technical and political responsibilities and thus to be able to correct the shortcomings that in recent years have allowed not only the use of defeat devices, but also the continuous exceeding of the emission limits of motor vehicles provided for by Community law. I am confident and convinced that the results of the ongoing investigation will bring added value and provide a basis for establishing a more stringent, integrated and, above all, transparent European regulatory framework. We must now look to the future and be able to restore European rules that will finally guarantee an adequate level for the health and safety of European citizens, so as to regain their full confidence. We absolutely cannot allow fraud of this magnitude to happen again and for the unfair behaviour of some car manufacturers to harm millions of European consumers and citizens.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report presents a mid-term review of the Commission of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector (EMIS), of which I am an alternate member.  This commission was set up last March, in the wake of the Volkswagen scandal, to shed light on the overshooting of vehicle emissions limits in Europe.  The co-reporters of the EPP and ALDE groups report on the work carried out during the first six months, during which 37 hearings of political representatives, representatives of the automotive sector and members of civil society were conducted.  The report also sets out the work programme until spring 2017, when we will present our findings. Supporting these objectives, I supported this interim report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We believe that national parliaments should be responsible for all investigations related to maladministration in the application of environmental law.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this interim report on the european Parliament's investigation into the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector following the Volkswagen scandal.  In order to carry out this investigation into allegations of breaches of European law, the European Union and its Member States must be transparent so that the commission in charge of the investigation can have access to the necessary information.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of measuring emissions as I believe that the number of machines on the road should be monitored and regulated with legislation limiting air pollution. The dialogue on emissions must continue to be a priority for the European Union in order to protect the environment and the health of its citizens.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is quite clear that mid-term, The Parliamentary Committee of Inquiry on Car Emissions (created in the wake of the revelations about fraud devices used by the Volkswagen Group to reduce polluting emissions during official car tests) needs more information from the European Commission, including on emissions measures as well as details of the expert working groups on vehicle registration procedures.  Although cooperation with the European Commission appears to have improved since this summer, it is essential that the Committee of Inquiry be able to determine whether the European Commission and national representatives suspected or were aware of the fraud before it was discovered in the United States.  It is equally necessary to understand why European and national authorities have not been more cautious about the divergences in emissions measures between certification tests and conduct in real-world conditions.  That is why I fully support the call to the Commission and the Member States to facilitate the investigation in accordance with the principle of 'fair cooperation' set out in European rules.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This is an interim methodological report by the European Parliament on the survey of emissions in the automotive sector. The formation of this commission of inquiry follows the "Volkswagen scandal".  On 18 September 2015, the multinational was revealed to be using fraudulent schemes to falsify the emission of nitrogen dioxide by the diesel engines of its vehicles.  This subterfuge allowed Volkswagen to comply with U.S. law, making its products suitable for export to that country. This progress report paves the way for the commission of inquiry to continue its work, including hearings until the autumn of 2016.  So I voted for this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the interim report on the investigation of emissions in the automotive sector, the case of the committee of inquiry dealing with the case. I support the fact that the report is based on technical information and data and does not contain any political findings and statements. I agree that full cooperation between the European institutions and national governments is needed in order to achieve better results.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the devastating effects of air pollution annually, the health and safety of European citizens must be a priority.  For this reason, Member States should help to ensure the work of the Committee of Inquiry in order to ensure the effectiveness of control systems and to investigate any infringements.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The positive vote on this interim report on the work of the Committee of Inquiry in the automotive sector is mainly due to the nature of the report itself, which is purely technical and procedural. The significant elements which have emerged during the first six months of witness hearings and which will emerge in the coming months will be dealt with in the final report. With this report, the European Parliament refers to the need for cooperation on the part of the Member States and the Commission in providing the information necessary for the investigation.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this interim report it is possible to have a clear view of how car manufacturers were able to claim that their cars polluted much less than they actually do in real driving conditions. According to the same document, the European Commission has difficulty acting against the growing discrepancy between emissions under driving conditions and those generated in test cycles and Member States have neither supported nor been rigid in implementing and implementing car emissions legislation. So this is a good opportunity to improve the tests.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote for: this short and very neutral text simply encourages the Committee of Inquiry to continue its work, invites the Conference of Presidents as well as the Commission and the authorities of the Member States to work with loyalty, so that no element of the investigation escapes the committee.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 17 December 2015, the European Parliament decided to set up a 45-member committee of inquiry to investigate alleged violations and mismanagement in the application of EU law in relation to emissions measurements in the automotive sector following the Volkswagen scandal. A scandal that confirms the promiscuity between political power and economic power in the EU. The EMIS Commission was set up on 2 March 2016 and its mandate provides for an interim report in the first 6 months and a final report within 12 months of the start of its work.   The work of the EMIS Committee of Inquiry is still ongoing and several hearings of different witnesses and experts have already been held, which will continue during the autumn period. This interim report does not contain any results or recommendations. In the report, the committee calls for support for its work from the Conference of Presidents and the Bureau of Parliament, the European Commission and the Authorities of the Member States, in a transparent manner, while respecting the principle of cooperation. Having supported the establishment of this committee and supported its continuation in office, we again express the reservations we have about the scope and practical consequences of its work.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the draft report by the Committee of Inquiry into The Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector, which urgently needs further information from the European Commission. I think it is of fundamental importance to direct the work of the Committee of Inquiry, not only to investigate what has happened in the past, but also to make proposals to prevent something like this from happening again in the future. In order for this to happen, the inquiry must focus on the responsibilities of the national authorities, because European democracy also means the responsibility of national ministers in Europe. This crisis is also an opportunity to adapt the European car industry to the twenty-first century and to ensure a better future for the millions of families of workers in the automotive sector.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the emissions scandal brought about the disclosure of several global car manufacturers about their deliberate misrepresentation of the emissions data of passenger and commercial vehicles. It has also caused a fall in consumer confidence. The European Parliament has therefore set up a committee of inquiry in an attempt to restore it. It deals with the measurement of emissions in the automotive industry and compliance with the rules in force, whether by the European Commission or by the competent authorities within the Member States. The Committee of Inquiry is currently collecting and analysing information concerning the use of defeat mechanisms in the measurement of emissions by individual carmakers. This should continue during the autumn of this year. In particular, the follow-up report and the resulting recommendations will be important. Their observance should help to ensure that similar situations do not occur on such a large scale in the future. The functioning of the automotive industry is a significant factor in economic growth and employment. The emissions case has shown the importance of greening the whole sector. There is also a need to focus on limiting the use of heavy metals and other pollutants in individual components and components in cars. Member States have already committed themselves to this in 2003. Nevertheless, to this day, there are a number of exceptions. However, many of them are no longer needed thanks to modern materials and progress. This applies, for example, to the use of lead in car batteries. Already today there are proven technologies that can fully replace classic lead-acid batteries.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the interim report on the investigation into the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the devastating consequences of air pollution annually, the health and safety of European citizens must be a priority.  That is why I am voting in favour of the interim report on the examination of emission measurements in the automotive industry. Member States should help to ensure the work of the Committee of Inquiry in order to ensure the effectiveness of control systems and to investigate any infringements.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This interim report is a purely technical report as at this point in time it is premature to draw any definite conclusions from the work of the Inquiry Committee. However, it is interesting to understand the progresses of the work of the Committee, since as more and more evidence emerges the picture becomes more and more clear. All these elements have to become part of the final report. Several countries around the globe have opened investigations into whether car manufacturers respect vehicle emission limits on the road, as opposed to under test conditions. Investigations have shown that most manufacturers switch off or turn down their emission-control technologies at temperatures and conditions outside those of the lab test. It is important to re-establish confidence in the consumer and to ensure that this situation will not happen again. I welcome the good methodology and the transparency of the investigation of the Committee of Inquiry.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the EMIS Committee of Inquiry, I voted positively in favour of the interim report on the testing of emissions measurements in the automotive industry. This is a very important matter for European citizens, both in terms of improving air quality and in detecting the Volkswagen scandal. It is indisputable that Volkswagen has deceived consumers, so our main objective must be to regain the trust of European consumers. The legislation should be enforced by manufacturers along the lines of the establishment of an emission test cycle experienced by national authorities under appropriate real-world driving conditions and an effective market surveillance system. With regard to the diesel scandal, it must be stressed that various economic interests cannot be above the sound public interest. In addition, we must strongly draw the attention of the European Commission and the Joint Research Centre (JRC) to provide the panel with all relevant documents that could assist the committee of inquiry. All communication on this subject within the JRC and between the JRC and the European Commission's Directorate-General for the Internal Market, DG Environment, the national authorities of the Member States and the type-approval authorities may be useful. Furthermore, all documents relating to the activities of the various expert groups, in addition to all official and informal correspondence carried out by the Commission with the European Auto industry association (ACEA). Similar fact-finding and gathering of evidence are essential for restoring consumer confidence.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the EMIS Commission's interim report, which details the activities of that committee since its establishment on 2 March 2016, and presents the future work programme for the first half of its mandate. It is important to keep in mind that the EMIS Commission should collect and analyse the information to determine whether the Commission and the Member States had evidence of the use of deactivation devices, and also collect and analyse information on the implementation by Member States of Directive 2007/46/EC. However, we should not focus our attention only on past events, but ensure that legislation on this issue is respected and implemented correctly, always trying to balance the environment, economic competitiveness and the protection of citizens.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. Without prejudice to the jurisdiction of the courts, a commission of inquiry into allegations of infringement and mismanagement in the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector was established on 17 December 2015. The scope of the investigation is limited by Article 226 TFEU and the Decision on the right of investigation of the EP, according to which it should focus on investigating the compliance of the Commission and States with the obligations of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007. In addition to collecting and analysing information on the implementation of Directive 2007/46/EC, determine whether they had evidence of the use of deactivation devices and make any recommendations it deems necessary. While the final report will take place in March 2017, this vote refers to the interim report which, by its nature, cannot advance conclusions before all witnesses are heard and quite evidence gathered.  It is therefore purely technical in nature, emphasizing procedural aspects. The principles of parence and good cooperation between institutions are recalled and all actors involved are requested to provide the necessary assistance for the fulfilment of the mandate of the EMIS Commission. That is why I vote in favour of the report.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – Without prejudice to the jurisdiction of the courts, on 17 December 2015 a commission of inquiry was established on allegations of infringement and mismanagement in the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector. The scope of the investigation is limited by Article 226 TFEU and the Decision on the European Parliament's right of inquiry. The research aims to collect and analyse information on the implementation of Directive 2007/46/EC, as well as to determine whether there was evidence of the use of deactivation devices and to make recommendations deemed necessary. While the final report will take place in March 2017, this vote refers to the interim report which, by its nature, cannot advance conclusions before all witnesses are heard and evidence gathered. It is therefore purely technical in nature, emphasizing procedural aspects. The principles of parence and good cooperation between institutions are recalled and all actors involved are requested to provide the necessary assistance for the fulfilment of the mandate of the EMIS Commission.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the preliminary report presented by my colleagues in the Special Committee of Inquiry into emissions in the passenger car sector, whose constructive tone I appreciated with the aim of shedding light and ensuring transparency on certain situations of great importance for environmental sustainability and industrial production in the European Union.  I support the call for the European Commission to ensure timely support and full transparency in assisting the work of the Committee of Inquiry, while fully respecting the principle of loyal cooperation between the European institutions. It will be essential to ensure that Parliament has effective and rapid access to the documents requested; I hope that this cooperation will be a prerequisite for an approach of ever greater transparency and openness on the part of the Council towards Parliament.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the interim report on the investigation into the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector by my colleagues Pablo Zalba Bidegain and Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, because I agree with the importance of the parliamentary inquiry and the call on the European institutions all to support the Work of the Commission constructively. Last year's emissions scandal in the automotive sector is a bad one that deserves to be investigated in detail in order to clarify any political responsibilities, and that is why the Group of Socialists and Democrats immediately pushed for the formation of a parliamentary body that, in compliance with national judicial systems, would verify any responsibilities of public regulators. I think that after six months the work of the Committee of Inquiry can be assessed positively and I hope that, thanks also to the cooperation of the political and administrative staff of the European Commission, the investigation can be concluded quickly and with excellent results.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the interim report on the study into emissions measurements in the automotive industry. It is part of an important parliamentary investigation into the emissions scandal. It is important to me that both the management of all the car brands concerned and those responsible for politics – the EU and Germany – are held accountable.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. There is an election campaign in the Committee of Inquiry into Emissions. I have this impression, at least in the mid-term interim report of the Committee of Inquiry into Emissions. In committee, accusations keep coming up, which later turn out to be baseless. Some colleagues in the SPD claim that the Commission has long known about cheating software in the automotive industry. The former Environment Commissioner, Mr Potosnik, would even have informed mr Tajani in a letter. I have received this letter and I cannot see any content in it that would give rise to these accusations. This would also be surprising, because Potosnik himself testified before the Committee of Inquiry that he did not suspect any cheating software. Perhaps some people here would like to use the Committee of Inquiry for their own election campaigns. Finally, important parliamentary posts will soon be filled. We should refrain from such political games and focus on the substantive work. I voted in favour of the interim report.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament decided in December 2015 to set up a Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged contraventions or maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to emission measurements in the automotive sector. This interim report is not of a political nature, rather it outlines the working methods and the plan adopted so far by the EMIS committee and does not include any political assessments or policy conclusions. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. This report is merely a progress report, essentially technical, of the committee of inquiry set up by Parliament after the so-called Volkswagen scandal, or the 'Dieselgate'. It is an opportunity to recall the weakness of the powers of a European Parliament's Committee of Inquiry, which fortunately is not the US Congress, and therefore has neither the capacity to compel individuals to testify nor to sanction them in the event of non-appearance or partial or misleading statements. Perhaps that is why his investigations are primarily technical. For, beyond the real responsibilities of the German manufacturer, the Volkswagen case is part of what can be considered a real economic war with the United States, against the backdrop of the negotiations of the transatlantic treaty. The battle of sanctions is raging today on both sides of the ocean: Apple and Amazon, against BNP, Volkswagen and Deutsche Bank... Such a case could have killed a less solid company. It will no doubt have the skin of diesel, which is very popular with Europeans, and will have a cost for the entire automotive sector. These aspects must also be taken into account.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution urging the Committee of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector, in the wake of the VW scandal, to fully implement the mandate given by Parliament in its Decision of 17 December 2015. It requests the Conference of Presidents and the Bureau to support all necessary measures, in particular with regard to the authorization of extraordinary hearings and meetings, reimbursement of the costs of experts and witnesses, missions and any other duly justified technical means. Requests the European Commission to ensure immediate support and full transparency, providing as much political and technical support as possible, in particular by presenting the requested documentation more promptly; expects the full cooperation of Commissioners and relevant general management, both those currently in office and those who were currently in office during previous mandates. It calls on the governments, parliaments and competent authorities of the Member States to assist the Committee of Inquiry in their work with full respect for the principle of fair cooperation laid down in EU law.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the preliminary report on the investigation of emission measurements in the automotive sector.  On 17 December 2015, the European Parliament decided to set up a 45-member committee of inquiry to investigate allegations of infringement or maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to emission measurements in the automotive sector, without prejudice to the jurisdiction of national courts or Union courts.  The scope of this investigation is limited by the mandate of the committee and must focus on compliance by the Commission and the Member States with the obligations imposed by Regulation (EC) No 715/2007. Furthermore, it is for the EMIS Committee to collect and analyse information to determine whether the Commission and the Member States have evidence of the use of defeat devices and to collect and analyse information on the implementation by Member States of Directive 2007/46/EC. Finally, the committee is also required to make any recommendations it considers necessary in this regard.  Given the importance of the subject and its impact on the environment, and therefore the health and life of EU citizens, I supported this report.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this interim report on the inquiry into emission measurements in the automotive sector which outlines the working methods and plan adopted so far by the EMIS committee.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. This interim report of the Commission of Inquiry provides an overview of the hearings conducted.  It is important to continue work on this topic in order to understand the reasons for the delay in implementing the new tests to reduce the difference between actual emissions on the road and emissions tested in the laboratory.  But it is already clear that the priority given to the fight against CO2 emissions has long overshadowed the fight against NOx, which is also very harmful to health. It has to evolve! Innovation will also help us meet the new standards.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the interim report. The interim report is factual and methodological in nature, aiming to provide an overview of the work programme of the EMIS Committee. As the investigation of Volkswagen case is still ongoing, it does not draw any conclusions. However, it is rather critical to provide it with all the technical and political support possible, in particular through swifter submission of requested documentation.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. Without prejudice to the jurisdiction of the courts, a commission of inquiry into allegations of infringement and mismanagement in the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector was established on 17 December 2015. The scope of the investigation is limited by Article 226 TFEU and the Decision on the right of investigation of the EP, according to which it should focus on investigating the compliance of the Commission and States with the obligations of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007. In addition to collecting and analysing information on the implementation of Directive 2007/46/EC, determine whether they had evidence of the use of deactivation devices and make any recommendations it deems necessary. While the final report will take place in March 2017, this vote refers to the interim report which, by its nature, cannot advance conclusions before all witnesses are heard and quite evidence gathered.  It is therefore purely technical in nature, emphasizing procedural aspects. The principles of parence and good cooperation between institutions are recalled and all actors involved are requested to provide the necessary assistance for the fulfilment of the mandate of the EMIS Commission. That is why I vote in favour of the report.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. Following the VW emissions scandal, the Committee of Inquiry into emissions measurements in the automotive industry was set up on 2 March 2016 to examine alleged breaches of Union law and maladministration in its application in relation to emission measurements in the automotive industry, without prejudice to the competences of national or Union courts. In addition to the final conclusions, the Committee also decided to produce an interim report after the first half of the hearings. This has now been put to the vote. ALFA has worked hard to ensure that the report remains purely technical and does not constitute early findings or political messages. That is why I was able to vote in favour of the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to discord and strife in Europe.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The interim report is a purely technical one at this point, it is early to draw any definite conclusions. While the work of the Inquiry Committee is in progress, more evidence emerges, all of which will be included in the final report.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 lessons must be learned from the mistakes that preceded the Volkswagen scandal. Emissions measurements must be harmonised, circumvention of the rules must be more strictly sanctioned and taxation must be directed away from support for diesel cars. At the same time, we need to look more boldly to the future. The internal combustion engine is not the final stage of human development.  I hope that the work of the Committee on Research will proceed smoothly and that it will receive all the information it needs from all relevant bodies.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒I voted for a proposal for a Resolution from the European Parliament on the investigation into emission measurements in the automotive sector, as I strongly support the continuation of the Committee's work in order to contribute concretely to the Union's type-approval framework. In this context, unconditional support from the European Commission is needed through political and technical assistance.  It is also necessary to approve the necessary hearings, extraordinary sessions, reimbursements and any other technical means necessary for the smooth operation of the Committee. It must be clearly and unequivocally established what irregularities and infringements were committed in the implementation of European law. While the Committee acts on the work plan, it is necessary to continue to investigate all the points included in its mandate more strongly and decisively, and I therefore support this interim report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This brief and very neutral text simply encourages the Committee of Inquiry to continue its work, calls on the Conference of Presidents and the Commission and the authorities of the Member States to work with loyalty, so that no element of the investigation escapes the committee.  However, I reiterated in the plenary debate that our report must be political and not just technical. Indeed, diesel engines are the subject of an economic war that the United States is fighting the European automotive industry, and particularly Germany.  I voted in favour of the interim report.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Pablo Zalba Bidegain's report on the work of the Commission of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector.  This report provides an overview of the hearings and outlines the commission's work programme for the coming weeks. This is an important work that needs to be done to shed light on Volkswagen's cheating and above all to put forward solutions so that such a scandal does not happen again.  To this end, my political group will be vigilant so that the Commission of Inquiry is not used or diverted from its objectives. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this interim report on the work of the Commission of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector (EMIS).  Indeed, in the wake of the Volkwagen scandal, the European Parliament decided in December 2015 to set up a 45-member commission of inquiry to examine allegations of breaches of EU law or maladministration in its application of emissions measurement in the automotive sector.  In its final report, the Commission of Inquiry will be required to make all the recommendations it deems necessary in this area. It is important that Parliament gets involved in bringing this scandal to light.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it is absolutely necessary that the EMIS Committee has the necessary backing to continue its work. It is crucial that all involved parties play their part in a constructive way.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The interim report of the EMIS Committee has been based on the technical nature of the issue, refrains from political statements and provides an objective overview of the Committee's work. I am therefore voting in favour of the report.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the interim report on the investigation into emissions measurements in the automotive sector because I believe that it is necessary to come to concrete proposals to improve air quality in European cities. The committee's work began with the Volkswagen scandal, which also triggered the issue of air quality problems in European cities. It is diesel cars that produce a large proportion of harmful emissions, several times higher than the legal permitted norms.  Former and current Commissioners, technical experts, representatives of automotive companies and non-governmental organisations have now been heard. We will also listen to the representatives of the Member States in the coming months. The Committee's work will conclude with an extensive final report and recommendations.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it outlines the working methods and plan adopted so far by the EMIS Committee.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. Following the VW emissions scandal, the Committee of Inquiry into emissions measurements in the automotive industry was set up on 2 March 2016 to examine alleged breaches of Union law and maladministration in its application in relation to emission measurements in the automotive industry, without prejudice to the competences of national or Union courts. In addition to the final conclusions, the Committee also decided to produce an interim report after the first half of the hearings. This has now been put to the vote. ALFA has worked hard to ensure that the report remains purely technical and does not constitute early findings or political messages. That is why I was able to vote in favour of the report. However, with regard to the committee's future conclusions, I must express my serious concern. As repeatedly warned by my colleague and ALFA MEP Hans-Olaf Henkel, some parliamentarians from other groups, such as Paloma Lopez Bermejo (United European Left/Nordic Greens) and Bas Eickhout (Greens), are trying to steer the investigation in an unacceptable direction and to arrest the entire car industry for technical manipulation at a manufacturer (VW). ALFA, as one of the industry and technological advances close to the German party, strongly rejects similar politically motivated conclusions.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution because there is no doubt that the Committee of Inquiry should have full support from the Conference of Presidents and the Bureau, the Commission and the governments, parliaments and competent authorities of Member States. All support is needed for Committee’s actions and initiatives leading to the accomplishment of the mandate given by Parliament in its decision of 17 December 2015.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. On 17 December 2015, the European Parliament set up a Committee of Inquiry into The Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector (EMIS). Following the scandal resulting from the Volkswagen case, we decided to be clear and understand how it was possible for that company to use mechanisms capable of circumventing the rules on car approvals in relation to emission levels. Specifically, its function appears to be to collect and analyse information on whether the Commission and the Member States had any evidence to establish whether manipulation mechanisms capable of altering the real results of car emissions had actually been used. I believe it is essential that we continue to carry out an investigation that is as transparent and thorough as possible, in order to establish what really happened and to prevent this from happening again thanks to the new legislation, to the detriment of our consumers and to the detriment of the environment.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it simply encourages the Committee of Inquiry to continue its work, and calls on the Conference of Presidents as well as the Commission and the authorities of the Member States to work with loyalty, so that no element of the investigation escapes the committee.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This interim report by the Commission of Inquiry into the Volkswagen scandal calls for better cooperation from the Commission in the provision of documents. These could shed light on the responsibilities in the scandal of toxic gas emissions from diesel engines. With it becoming increasingly clear that the Commission was aware of software rigging laboratory pollution tests, the European Parliament's Committee of Inquiry is now looking into who blocked the revelations in the Commission. To this end, the Commission of Inquiry has held several hearings. Some of these are seen in the Commission sounding the alarm about these softwares long before the scandal broke, while some Commissioners seem to have sought to silence these concerns. All this confirms the need to continue the work of this parliamentary committee of inquiry in order to clear the responsibilities for the political coverage of this huge industrial and health scandal. That is why I supported this interim report.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the automotive emissions measurement survey.  This interim report sets out the method and hearings that make up Parliament's inquiry into emissions in the automotive sector. The actual hearings continue until the autumn of 2016, after which MEPs will work on the drafting of the final report. Therefore, no funding guidance is given in this text voted in committee on 13 July.  This text simply encourages the Committee of Inquiry to continue its work, calls on the Conference of Presidents and the Commission and the authorities of the Member States to work with loyalty, so that no element of the investigation escapes the committee.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. In the wake of the Volkswagen scandal, the European Parliament set up the ad hoc committee in December 2015 to investigate Volkswagen's fraudulent practices in calculating the nitrogen dioxide emissions of its diesel engines.  This interim report, which is very neutral, simply encourages this commission of inquiry to continue its work. It also calls for maximum cooperation between the European Commission and the competent authorities of the Member States, so that nothing escapes the investigation.  I supported this initiative of transparency and justice by voting for this text.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. Without prejudice to the jurisdiction of the courts, a commission of inquiry into allegations of infringement and mismanagement in the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector was established on 17 December 2015. The scope of the investigation is limited by Article 226 TFEU and the Decision on the right of investigation of the EP, according to which it should focus on investigating the compliance of the Commission and States with the obligations of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007. While the final report will take place in March 2017, this vote refers to the interim report which, by its nature, cannot advance conclusions before all witnesses are heard and quite evidence gathered.  It is therefore purely technical in nature, emphasizing procedural aspects. The principles of parence and good cooperation between institutions are recalled and all actors involved are requested to provide the necessary assistance for the fulfilment of the mandate of the EMIS Commission. That is why I vote in favour of the report.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. Without prejudice to the jurisdiction of the courts, a commission of inquiry into allegations of infringement and mismanagement in the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector was established on 17 December 2015. The scope of the investigation is limited by Article 226 TFEU and the Decision on the right of investigation of the EP, according to which it should focus on investigating the compliance of the Commission and States with the obligations of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007. In addition to collecting and analysing information on the implementation of Directive 2007/46/EC, determine whether they had evidence of the use of deactivation devices and make any recommendations it deems necessary. While the final report will take place in March 2017, this vote refers to the interim report which, by its nature, cannot advance conclusions before all witnesses are heard and quite evidence gathered.  It is therefore purely technical in nature, emphasizing procedural aspects. The principles of parence and good cooperation between institutions are recalled and all actors involved are requested to provide the necessary assistance for the fulfilment of the mandate of the EMIS Commission. That is why I vote in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this resolution because, although I cannot object to its content, it lacks political significance.
