It is my view that the well-known information on the emissions scandal (and in particular the scandal involved in the disclosure that European regulations were implemented to allow serious discrepancies between actual and fictitious emissions, so many systems for handling broadcasts similar to the software developed by Volskwagen-Bosch were legally used with the approval and knowledge of national and European authorities) should have been reflected in it , rather than waiting another six months to present the final conclusions.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. As a substitute member of this committee and having followed all the progress of this committee very closely, I give my positive vote to the draft interim report of the EMIS Commission. The objective of the commission is only to provide a brief description of the activities of that committee since its establishment on 2 March 2016. In committee, we have focused on investigating and clarifying whether both the Commission and the authorities of the Member States properly implemented the obligations imposed by Regulation (EC) No 715/2007.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. Following the VW emissions scandal, the Committee of Inquiry into emissions measurements in the automotive industry was set up on 2 March 2016 to examine alleged breaches of Union law and maladministration in its application in relation to emission measurements in the automotive industry, without prejudice to the competences of national or Union courts. In addition to the final conclusions, the Committee also decided to produce an interim report after the first half of the hearings. This has now been put to the vote. ALFA has worked hard to ensure that the report remains purely technical and does not constitute early findings or political messages. That is why I was able to vote in favour of the report. However, with regard to the committee's future conclusions, I must express my serious concern. As repeatedly warned by my colleague and ALFA MEP Hans-Olaf Henkel, some parliamentarians from other groups, such as Paloma Lopez Bermejo (United European Left/Nordic Greens) and Bas Eickhout (Greens), are trying to steer the investigation in an unacceptable direction and to arrest the entire car industry for technical manipulation at a manufacturer (VW). ALFA, as one of the industry and technological advances close to the German party, strongly rejects similar politically motivated conclusions.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this interim report, which documents the workings of the EMIS Committee so far.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I disagreed with the establishment of a committee of inquiry. If Volkswagen cheated, this should be dealt with by the German police and courts, not by the European Parliament's committee. I do not agree with the call for the Committee of Inquiry to continue its work.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ From my point of view it is very important to collect and analyse information to ascertain whether the Commission and the Member States had evidence of the use of defeat mechanisms, as well as to collect and analyse information on the implementation by the Member States of Directive 2007/46/EC. Transparency and coordinated actions are the best weapons against abuses in the automotive sector.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the European Parliament set up a temporary committee of inquiry in December 2015 in accordance with Article 226 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU. Its role is to investigate shortcomings in the application of Union legislation on emission measurement in the automotive industry. The Committee shall draw up an investigative report and make any recommendations it deems necessary in this matter. As the results of the investigation may provide a basis for the added value of the Union type-approval framework, it requires more time to investigate in fulfilling the mandate of the Interim Committee. It is therefore necessary for the Commission and the Member States to cooperate with the European Parliament and to provide the Committee with the utmost cooperation.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. The current interim report by the European Parliament's Committee of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector (EMIS) comes in the wake of the Volkswagen scandal that broke at the end of 2015.  Indeed, a vast system of software enabling FRAUD on EU pollution tests had been discovered on 11 million diesel vehicles worldwide. In view of the issues of public interest, public health and the environment, I vote in favour of this report of the EMIS Commission of Inquiry, so that all the light is shed on this scandal of anti-pollution test fraud.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting on the interim report on the examination of emission measurements in the automotive industry, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 13/9/2016, and because this interim report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text. This is an interim methodological report by the European Parliament on the survey of emissions in the automotive sector. The formation of this commission of inquiry follows the "Volkswagen scandal" which, on 18 September 2015, revealed the multinational's use of fraudulent schemes aimed at falsifying the emission of nitrogen dioxide by the diesel engines of its vehicles.  This subterfuge allowed Volkswagen to comply with U.S. law, making its products suitable for export to that country. This progress report paves the way for the commission of inquiry to continue its work, including hearings until the autumn of 2016.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Union is on a regular process of improvement. We all in the EPP group certainly want a better and smarter Europe, but only by correcting our mistakes we will be able to accomplish the aforementioned goal. The promised investigation is important and any objections to carrying it out would only go against the principle of loyal cooperation established in Union Law. Therefore, I voted in favour of the Report on the Inquiry into Emission Measurements in the Automotive sector.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we have acquainted with the first interim conclusions of the work of the Committee investigating alleged violations or maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to the measurement of emissions in the automotive industry. It is a special body of the European Parliament which does not interfere in any way with the competences of national judicial or executive bodies. The EMIS Committee is tasked with collecting and analysing information and data. In today's vote, we supported the further work of the EMIS Committee, promising all possible synergies and cooperation. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The first report submitted to the plenary by the European Parliament's Committee of Inquiry on the measurement of pollutant emissions in the automotive sector makes it clear that something has been done wrong and that action must be taken to prevent something like this from happening again.  I vote in favour of this report, which shows that the current legislation is sufficient. And I ask the members of the Commission for an effort to come up with solutions in the final report, since Europe is very much in the face of solving a fundamental problem for a sector as important as the automotive industry and also for the environment.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. A parliamentary inquiry into the emissions scandal is to be launched. The committee's work should be as transparent as possible to the public. I therefore support this committee of inquiry.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the ep's report on studies on measuring emissions in the automotive sector. This report gives an overview of the prospects for the work plan of the EMIS Committee's first half of the term of office. In addition, the Committee is invited to collect and analyse information to determine whether the Commission and the Member States had evidence on the use of defeat devices and to collect and analyse information on the implementation of Directive 2007/46/EC by The Member States.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. On 17 December 2015, the European Parliament decided to set up a 45-member commission of inquiry to examine allegations of breaches of EU law or maladministration in the application of EU law with regard to the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector, without prejudice to the competences of national or EU jurisdictions.  The purpose of the report before us is to give a brief overview of the activities of that committee since its establishment on 2 March 2016, as well as an idea of the work plan for the first half of the commission's mandate.  The commission has already conducted numerous hearings whose reports are accessible to the public via a dedicated website. I vote for this report and encourage the Committee of Inquiry to continue its work rigorously.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Following the Volkswagen scandal, Parliament decided to form a commission of inquiry. This is a brief and neutral interim report which aims to ensure good cooperation between the various competent authorities. So I voted for this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is necessary to ensure immediate support and full transparency in supporting the work of the Committee of Inquiry, fully respecting the principle of sincere cooperation, providing all possible technical and political support, in particular through faster submission of the required documentation. The full cooperation of the current commissioners and directors-general relevant, as well as those who have worked in previous mandates, is fundamental to the success of this Committee of Inquiry. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it is essential that Parliament’s committees, especially its committees of inquiry, receive the necessary support for them to fulfil their mandates. It is important for Member States and for the Commission to comply with the committee’s requests for information in a prompt and transparent manner.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – Last year, Europe was rocked by the finding that cars emit far more harmful gases than is permitted and that many car manufacturers had built in the vehicles to pass the official controls undisturbed. On 17 December last year, Parliament was right to launch the creation of a parliamentary committee of inquiry. The aim of this EMIS Committee is to investigate infringements and mismanagement in the application of EU law in the field of emissions measurements in the automotive sector. On the basis of the interim report, it is premature to attach conclusions to the mandate of this committee, but the EMIS Committee is expected to present the necessary recommendations at the end of its work. In order to ensure that the Committee can do its job properly, it is necessary that it has all relevant information on the use and knowledge of defeat mechanisms in the automotive sector. It is therefore appropriate that all parties involved provide the necessary technical and political support to the EMIS Committee's investigation. In this way, we can improve our car industry in the future while guaranteeing better air quality to all the inhabitants of Europe.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – On 17 December 2015, the European Parliament decided to set up a committee of inquiry into emission measurements in the automotive industry to investigate alleged infringements or maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to emission measurements in the automotive industry, without prejudice to the jurisdiction of national or Community courts. With this interim report, the Committee requested support for all measures necessary for the fulfilment of its mandate, the scope of which is governed by Article 226 TFEU and by decision of Parliament, the Council and the Commission. The Committee's request concerned ensuring full support, transparency and sincere cooperation, ensuring technical and political assistance from the European institutions and the Member States. I am voting in favour of the draft interim report of the EMIS Committee.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which recalls the principle of good cooperation between the institutions, insists on full transparency and asks all actors involved to provide the necessary assistance for the fulfilment of the Committee’s mandate. The interim report is a purely technical report as at this point in time it is premature to draw any definite conclusions from the work of the Inquiry Committee.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 17 December last year, the European Parliament adopted a decision setting up a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged infringements of EU law and alleged maladministration in relation to emissions measurement in the automotive industry, while calling on the Committee of Inquiry to submit an interim report six months after the start of work. At the expiry of the time limit, the Panel shall, on the basis of oral and written testimony submitted to it and examined by it, conclude in its interim report that further investigations are necessary in all aspects covered by its mandate. It therefore proposes that Parliament instruct the Committee of Inquiry to continue its work and to support all measures and initiatives aimed at fulfilling its mandate, and to ask the Conference of Presidents and the Bureau to support all necessary measures to ensure that the Panel is able to fulfil its mandate. It also calls for Parliament to set out the expectation of the governments, parliaments and authorised authorities of the Member States to support the Committee of Inquiry in the performance of its tasks, in full respect of the principle of good faith cooperation engraved in EU law. I supported the adoption of the interim report.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. On September 18, 2015, the Volkswagen scandal broke following revelations by US researchers about rigging software to mask nitrogen dioxide emissions from diesel engines. This process allowed the world's largest automaker to export to the United States despite strict limits on nitrogen dioxide emissions.  Parliament then decided on 17 December 2015 to form a commission of inquiry to examine allegations of breaches of EU law or maladministration in the application of EU law.  This interim report sets out the method and hearings that make up Parliament's inquiry into emissions in the automotive sector. The actual hearings continue "until autumn 2016" after which MEPs will work on the drafting of the final report.  Therefore, no substantive guidance is given. This brief and very neutral text simply encourages the Committee of Inquiry to continue its work, invites the Conference of Presidents and the Commission and the authorities of the Member States to work with loyalty, so that no element of the investigation escapes the committee.   Vote in favour.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The Automotive Commission of Inquiry has not failed to examine various business areas in order to further the ongoing investigation. To this end, it sent a number of questionnaires to the Member States, the Union institutions and other bodies and opened a public call for evidence on its website. I am voting in this report and I believe that we must evolve into an electric car industry, which contributes to increasing the sustainability of cities and improving the living conditions of all citizens.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This interim report on the automotive emissions measurement survey sets out the method and hearings that constitute Parliament's inquiry into emissions in the automotive sector set up in the wake of the Volkswagen scandal.  These hearings will continue until the fall of 2016. The text simply encourages the Commission of Inquiry to continue its work. I voted in favour of this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which outlines the working methods and plan adopted so far by the EMIS Committee, without introducing any political assessment or anticipating policy conclusions or recommendations.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This text relates to the work of the Commission of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector.  It is an overview of the Commission's hearings and has no normative scope. I voted for it.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the automotive emissions measurement survey (EMIS), which is responsible for collecting information on errors or malfeasations in the application of the European directive. This interim report outlined the measures already adopted and those planned, referred to the fair cooperation of this commission in its work and called on States to provide the political and technical support it needs to carry out its mission.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, which seeks to strike a reasonable balance between health and the competitiveness of the European Union. This is about the future of European industry. The aim is to reduce CO2 emissions. At present, the European Union applies the strictest rules on emissions of harmful substances. It is very important that we formulate harmonised rules. Our aim is to further improve the quality of the environment, thereby improving the health of European citizens. In my opinion, every step must be taken to maintain the competitiveness of industry so that employment continues to grow.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that offers a brief overview of the activities of the EMIS Committee and also provides an outlook on the upcoming working plan of the Committee. The EMIS Committee has been set up since the 2nd of March 2016 to investigate alleged contraventions or maladministration relating to emission measures in the automotive sector.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Temporary Commission of Inquiry was set up in 2015 to investigate alleged gaps in the application of Union law in terms of emission measurement in the motor vehicle sector, with this committee to make any recommendations. I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on the investigation into the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector because I believe that this committee must continue its work and fulfil its full mandate by Parliament. The results of the ongoing investigation could lead to an improvement in the Union type-approval framework. We call on the Commission to ensure prompt support and full transparency when assisting the Committee of Inquiry in its work, in full compliance with the principle of loyal cooperation, ensuring all possible technical and political support, in particular by providing the requested documentation more quickly.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this motion for resolution, which is the interim report of the Committee of Inquiry that was established in December to investigate alleged contraventions or maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to emission measurements in the automotive sector (Volkswagen scandal). The inquiry is ongoing and the report does not include any conclusions or recommendations. It calls for ongoing support and cooperation for the inquiry by the Commission and national governments, such as providing swifter access to requested documents.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. A parliamentary inquiry into the emissions scandal in the automotive industry is being launched. The work of the Committee will become as transparent as possible to the public, while respecting confidentiality. That is why I support this report.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. This resolution on the investigation into the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector, created as a result of the Volkswagen Group's diesel engine emissions scandal, comes six months after the start of its mandate, with the sole aim of showing a description of the activities carried out since its establishment on 2 March 2016.  By the nature of that committee, it is not permitted to draw conclusions before the end of his term of office. What we do know through this report is that evidence of the work done so far confirms the need for further work, and for this it is necessary for the Governments, the competent authorities and the parties involved to show fair cooperation which will show their commitment to citizens. That's why I've decided to vote for it.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report which provides for the continuation of the committee's efforts to investigate allegations of infringements or mismanagement in the application of Community law in relation to emission measurements in the automotive industry. The Committee is now invited to gather and analyse the information in order to verify whether the Commission and the Member States have had evidence of the use of suspension mechanisms and to make any recommendations it deems appropriate in this regard. In addition, the transparency of these measurements is an issue that needs to be clarified as soon as possible, which, with the enhanced action of the committee, after the resolution, is further reinforced.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We believe that national parliaments should be responsible for all investigations related to maladministration in the application of environmental law.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the interim report that highlights several important issues regarding NOx emissions and steers the EMIS Committee’s work in the second half of its mandate. We need to better explore what happened during the relevant period, both in the Commission as well as in the Parliament that lead eventually to vague legislation, which partially enabled the situation we are facing today. The confidence in the industry has been damaged and in order to regain trust, the testing regime clearly needs to reflect the real world more accurately.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the work of the Automotive Emissions Measurement Committee on the investigation into emission measurement. This report recalls that we are monitoring the fact-finding to shed light on all the causes and circumstances that led to one of the biggest scandals in recent European history. Apart from its measurable economic impacts for all automotive employees, this scandal simultaneously ruins the reputation of European industry, especially the vehicle industry, which faces strong competition on the global market.  The most severe consequences this scandal has, however, are those that affect citizens' trust in the EU institutions and national countries. Citizens' trust in the Union's joint project, in the correctness, suitability and consistency of European policies, is undermined. Our credibility as well as the credibility of the EU institutions can only be recovered if the commission fulfils the fully defined mandates - determine compliance with the obligations prescribed by Regulation (EC) No 1000/2013. 715/2007 (type-approval) by Member States and the Commission, whether the Commission and the Member States had evidence of the use of jamming devices and also information on the implementation of Directive 2007/46/EC (type-approval implementation) by Member States.  While the European Parliament has no jurisdiction over the judiciary, it is important that states also be credible and carry out appropriate judicial activities if criminal liability of individual persons or interested groups is found.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This interim report sets out the method and hearings that make up Parliament's inquiry into emissions in the automotive sector. The actual hearings continue "until autumn 2016" after which MEPs will work on the drafting of the final report. Therefore, no substantive guidance is given in this text voted in committee on 13 July.  This brief and very neutral text simply encourages the Committee of Inquiry to continue its work, calls on the Conference of Presidents and the Commission and the authorities of the Member States to work with loyalty, so that no element of the investigation escapes the committee. So I'm voting for him.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒The purpose of the explanatory statement of reasons for the draft interim report of the EMIS Committee is to provide a summary overview of the activities of that Committee since its establishment on 2 March 2016 and to present in the main lines the forthcoming work plan for the first half of the EMIS Committee's mandate.  Since Article 226 The TFEU for the European Parliament is the legal basis for establishing an interim Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged breaches or irregularities in the implementation of Union law, without prejudice to the jurisdiction of the national or EU courts, and as this is an important component of Parliament's supervisory powers, I agree with the view that the Committee of Inquiry will continue its work and fully fulfil the mandate entrusted to it by Parliament in its Decision of 17 December 2015 and support all measures initiatives leading to the fulfilment of the mandate.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am very glad that in December 2015 the European Parliament decided to set up a committee of inquiry composed of 45 Members to investigate alleged offences or maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to emissions measurement in the automotive industry. The EMIS investigation shall focus on compliance with the obligations laid down in Regulation (EC) No 715/2007, shall collect and analyse information in order to assuage whether the Commission and the Member States have had evidence of the use of defeat devices, as well as to collect and analyse information on the implementation of Directive 2007/46/EC by the Member States. As a Social Democrat, I am ought for greater transparency in today's world, so I appreciate that it will be possible to monitor the testimonies given by experts and witnesses using the verbarbial record of the Hearing in English, which will also be published on the EMIS website. I believe that the final report of the Committee of Inquiry will bring new findings that will be useful not only for the evaluation of this case around emissions in the automotive industry, but also for the judicial authorities.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 17 December 2015, the European Parliament decided to set up a 45-member committee of inquiry to examine complaints of infringement or maladministration in the application of Union legislation in relation to the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector. I am convinced that one of the most important prerogatives of the European Parliament is to monitor the work of the other institutions of the Union, representing the interests of European citizens. With regard to the substance of this investigation, I believe it is right to contribute to the restoration of full consumer confidence and to ascertain individual responsibilities without harming the entire automotive sector, which is a European excellence. I voted in favour of adopting this interim report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On the basis of Parliament's decision of 17 December 2015 to set up a commission of inquiry on emission measurements in the automotive sector, the Committee is to present a mid-term report within 6 months of its establishment. The report will be put to the vote on 13 September 2016. Given that EMIS hearings are still ongoing, the coordinators agreed that the report would not contain any political content. It is therefore purely technical and describes the time frame and stresses the need for full cooperation between the Conference of Presidents, the EP Bureau, the European Commission and national authorities. I hereby supported this report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the interim report of the Commission of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector (EMIS), of which I am a member.  The text voted here refers to the mid-term work, which is mainly technical because it traces the expert hearings carried out so far. The commission was set up in December 2015 in the wake of the Volkswagen scandal.  Through the work of this committee, my aim is to remind motorists and citizens of this kind of practice and to improve testing procedures, in harmony with the ongoing struggle to maintain European competitiveness and automotive know-how, particularly in France.  This is in line with the recommendations made in my CARS 2020 report on the future of the automobile.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We believe that national parliaments should be responsible for all investigations related to maladministration in the application of environmental law.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. The Commission of Inquiry into Vehicle Emissions Fraud is only halfway through its work, but one element is already needed in the eyes of its members: the problem is not so much the European legislation that regulates emissions as its effective implementation and control of its proper implementation. As legislators, it is our responsibility to shed light on the Dieselgate scandal because the confidence of our fellow citizens in Europe is eroding a little more every day.  We must restore this confidence, it is essential for cohesion in Europe. To do this, it is essential to uncover all the political and institutional dysfunctions that have enabled such a scandal. More broadly, the challenge is to ensure cleaner mobility, while respecting public health and the environment, while sustaining jobs, ultimately to promote sustainable development that benefits all.  In my work as shadow rapporteur of the EMIS Committee for the Group of Socialists and Democrats, the defence of the general interest is my main motivation, and I will continue to work in this direction until the end of the parliamentary inquiry.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of the report is to give a brief overview of the activities of the EMIS Commission since its establishment, as well as to provide an overview of the next work plan on the first half of the mandate. On 17 December 2015, Parliament decided to set up a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged misdemeanors or maladministration in the application of Community law relating to the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector, without prejudice to the powers conferred on national or Union courts. In addition, the EMIS Commission is called upon to collect and analyse information to verify whether the Commission and the Member States had evidence of the use of manipulative mechanisms and to collect and analyse information on the implementation. EMIS coordinators adopted the timetable for EMIS meetings for 2016, taking into account the need to limit overlap with standing committees and agreed to limit the number of commission missions to the minimum necessary, request an in-depth analysis of legal obligations regarding emissions measurement in the EU automotive sector, among other measures. In view of the above, I voted in favour.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Without prejudice to the jurisdiction of the courts, a commission of inquiry into allegations of infringement and mismanagement in the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector was established on 17 December 2015. The scope of the investigation is limited by Article 226 TFEU and the Decision on the right of investigation of the EP, according to which it should focus on investigating the compliance of the Commission and States with the obligations of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007. In addition to collecting and analysing information on the implementation of Directive 2007/46/EC, determine whether they had evidence of the use of deactivation devices and make any recommendations it deems necessary. While the final report will take place in March 2017, this vote refers to the interim report which, by its nature, cannot advance conclusions before all witnesses are heard and quite evidence gathered.  It is therefore purely technical in nature, emphasizing procedural aspects. The principles of parence and good cooperation between institutions are recalled and all actors involved are requested to provide the necessary assistance for the fulfilment of the mandate of the EMIS Commission. That is why I vote in favour of the report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the interim report on the survey on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector, because it is essential that the Commission be fully transparent on this issue.  The fraud that has come to light only confirms the need to strengthen standards control systems and ensure that they are overseen by an independent body at European level.  Member States must also provide support, including the technical and political assistance needed to continue the work.  This cheating is not only unacceptable, but also has a cost. The cost of non-Europe, because it is damaging the image of the automotive industry - particularly the German industry, and it will be more difficult tomorrow to lecture other major world powers who are reluctant to contribute to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which discusses the work of the Special Committee of Inquiry on emissions in the automotive sector. I am a member of this committee and I must admit that it is working in very difficult conditions. First of all, it is not so easy for its members to recover the necessary documents, there are persistent delays in their submission. Nevertheless, the possible results of the committee's work are already emerging, which should reveal that, until now, there are reasons for incompetent officials who did not want to investigate the increase rather than decline in actual emissions.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In December 2015, following the so-called 'emissions scandal in the automotive sector', the European Parliament set up a 45-member Commission of Inquiry to investigate alleged infringements in the application of Community law relating to the measurement of gas emissions in the automotive sector (without prejudice to the powers conferred on national or EUROPEAN Union courts). This progress report mentions the importance of the proper conduct of the evaluation actions envisaged, and for this the Committee of Inquiry should continue its work in order to be able to fully fulfil the obligations assigned to it under its mandate. In addition, the European Commission too, Member States, through their governments, national parliaments and competent authorities, should ensure support for the work of the Committee of Inquiry, fully respecting the principle of sincere cooperation and providing all possible technical and political support. In view of the foregoing, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which was drawn up by the Parliamentary Committee of Inquiry on Car Emissions, created by The Parement on 17 December 2015 and set up on 2 March, in the wake of the Volkswagen scandal.  Since its inception, the EMIS Commission of Inquiry has held 12 meetings and heard 37 experts; a study was also commissioned on the discrepancies in emissions measurements between probate tests and conduct in real-world conditions.  This text, which is a report halfway through the work of the EMIS committee, once again calls on the Commission and the Member States to facilitate the investigation in accordance with the principle of fair cooperation defined by European rules.  It is important that the safety and health of our citizens and motorists are ensured and that is why we need to improve testing procedures.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution urging the Committee of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector, in the wake of the VW scandal, to fully implement the mandate given by Parliament in its Decision of 17 December 2015. It requests the Conference of Presidents and the Bureau to support all necessary measures, in particular with regard to the authorization of extraordinary hearings and meetings, reimbursement of the costs of experts and witnesses, missions and any other duly justified technical means. Requests the European Commission to ensure immediate support and full transparency, providing as much political and technical support as possible, in particular by presenting the requested documentation more promptly; expects the full cooperation of Commissioners and relevant general management, both those currently in office and those who were currently in office during previous mandates. It calls on the governments, parliaments and competent authorities of the Member States to assist the Committee of Inquiry in their work with full respect for the principle of fair cooperation laid down in EU law.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report and the work of Parliament’s special Committee of Inquiry into the car emissions scandal. Public trust in the car manufacturers has been seriously eroded, as has confidence in the authorities tasked with regulating this industry. We should take every opportunity to improve legislation where necessary, but we also need an effective enforcement regime with appropriate oversight. Type approval authorities must have the necessary powers and resources to enforce the law and deter criminal activities, otherwise any improvements to legislation will be meaningless. I hope this report marks the beginning of long-lasting changes to improve environmental standards and restore public trust.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the interim report of the Committee of Inquiry into emissions measurement in the automotive industry. Expert information on emission measurement was collected and former commissioners were consulted to find out the motives for their actions.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The interim report on the investigation of emissions measurements in the automotive industry confirms the mandate and continuation of the work of the Committee of Inquiry after the middle of its term of office. It also calls for timely support and full transparency of the investigation process from stakeholders, in particular the European Commission. I therefore supported the report. In view of the ongoing process of hearing invited guests, this is a purely technical document, as the Committee does not want to anticipate any, albeit partial, conclusions before the conclusion of its own investigation. A summary of the committee's factual work and the resulting findings will be the content of the final report to be adopted by the European Parliament in accordance with the mandate given after the year of operation.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this resolution because, although I cannot object to its content, it lacks political significance. It is my view that the well-known information on the emissions scandal (and in particular the scandal involved in the disclosure that European regulations were implemented to allow serious discrepancies between actual and fictitious emissions, so many systems for handling broadcasts similar to the software developed by Volskwagen-Bosch were legally used with the approval and knowledge of national and European authorities) should have been reflected in it , rather than waiting another six months to present the final conclusions.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since March 2016, following the Volkswagen scandal, the EMIS Committee of Inquiry has been investigating alleged violations of European standards and cases of maladministration in relation to the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector. The interim report provides an overview of the committee's work programme: so far EMIS has held 12 meetings, for a total of about 50 hours, and 37 hearings with experts from research institutes and non-governmental organisations, industry representatives and the European Commission. As the investigation is still ongoing, the report does not draw any conclusions. I therefore voted in favour of the text in which Parliament merely asked the Member States and the European Commission to provide the technical and political support necessary for the performance of the committee of inquiry's mandate.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as the commission is calling on Member States to follow the lead of the European Parliament. We believe that the EU should not instruct Member States in any way.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – On 17 December 2015, the European Parliament decided to set up a Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged contraventions or maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to emission measurements in the automotive sector. I voted in favour of the interim report which sets up working methods for the committee.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing \ u2012 I voted in favour. I support the idea of a technical interim report and its proposals. The Commission should ensure support and full transparency in assisting the work of the Committee of Inquiry and fully respect the principle of sincere cooperation, while ensuring all possible technical and political support.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution because I consider it very important that we have regular information on how the investigation into emissions measurements in the automotive industry is continuing. The Committee of Inquiry was set up on 2 March 2016 and, according to the decision, also presents provisional law after six months of operation. It shall submit the final report to Parliament within 12 months. Over the past six months, the Committee of Inquiry first exchanged views with Commission officials on how they would proceed with the investigation during the year. He then held several hearings with relevant witnesses and experts in the automotive industry. The work of the Commission of Inquiry is not easy, because members, fellow Members, in the majority have to rely on expert reports and witness statements, which do not always have to correlate with true data. We all believe that Volkswagen has broken the law, but I consider it important that a similar case of infringement and consumer misleading never happens again in the future.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. In April 2016, the European Parliament's Committee of Inquiry on Emission Measurements (EMIS) began working with representatives of the European Commission, followed by a hearing of relevant witnesses and experts. The Committee also set out the views of expert laboratories measuring emissions and decided to commission several professional studies in this field. A 2-page website has been set up where Members and the public can find all relevant information relating to the work of the Committee. A programme of hearings in the second part of the committee's term of office is also under preparation. These hearings will continue until at least autumn 2016, after which the committee will focus on preparing a final report, which must be prepared within 12 months of the start of the work.  As I believe it is necessary to investigate unfair practices linked to emissions in the automotive sector, I supported the interim report.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. Following the VW emissions scandal, the Committee of Inquiry into emissions measurements in the automotive industry was set up on 2 March 2016 to examine alleged breaches of Union law and maladministration in its application in relation to emission measurements in the automotive industry, without prejudice to the competences of national or Union courts. In addition to the final conclusions, the Committee also decided to produce an interim report after the first half of the hearings. This has now been put to the vote. ALFA has worked hard to ensure that the report remains purely technical and does not constitute early findings or political messages. That is why I was able to vote in favour of the report. However, with regard to the committee's future conclusions, I must express my serious concern. As repeatedly warned by my colleague and ALFA MEP Hans-Olaf Henkel, some parliamentarians from other groups, such as Paloma Lopez Bermejo (United European Left/Nordic Greens) and Bas Eickhout (Greens), are trying to steer the investigation in an unacceptable direction and to arrest the entire car industry for technical manipulation at a manufacturer (VW). ALFA, as one of the industry and technological advances close to the German party, strongly rejects similar politically motivated conclusions.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: writing \u2012 To clarify the background of the emissions scandal, we are one step closer. Cooperation with the European Commission has improved, but we have encountered complications on the part of some Member States that refuse to provide key information. As a member of the EMIS Committee, I will be satisfied if we jointly set realistic rules that companies will abide by and will not hinder the development of the automotive industry in Europe. The European institutions, together with the Member States, should also make every effort to obtain compensation for deceived customers similar to that in the US.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the motion for an EU Parliament resolution on the inquiry into emission measurements in the automotive sector. Given the EU’s penchant for regulatory harmonisation the outcome of such an inquiry can only result in further calls for more stringent regulations on Member States. Monitoring and enforcement of emissions standards should be left to the Members States in which best practices will be adopted through regulatory competition. Furthermore, the inquiry requires that the governments, parliaments and competent authorities of Member States assist the Committee of Inquiry in its tasks. I find the legal basis for this demand lacking.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. On the basis of a proposal from the Conference of Presidents, Parliament decided in December 2015 to establish a Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged failures in the application of Union law concerning emission measurements in the automotive sector. The Committee of Inquiry's work plan relates to the hearing of relevant witnesses and experts, written evidence, business trips, commissioned summaries and expert opinion studies, and the official written opinion of the European Parliament's Genuine Service on the reference to the testimony of persons who may have to participate in legal proceedings.  The future results of the ongoing investigation could add value to the Union approval framework. I support the interim report on the investigation into emission measurements in the automotive sector in order to fully fulfil the mandate of the Committee of Inquiry entrusted to it by Parliament with the support of the Conference of Presidents, The Bureau and the Commission and the assistance of governments, parliaments and competent authorities of the Member States.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of the interim report on the investigation into emission measurement in the automotive sector.  The Committee of Inquiry on Emission Measurements in the automotive sector, together with the EC, is carrying out an important task. It is more than obvious that we have poor market control over what is happening in the automotive sector in the EU. The scandal that has been uncovered in VW is not isolated, and we find this after defeat devices in the European Union have been officially banned for 18 years.  Diesel vehicles with inadequate defeat devices are still driving on our roads, thus polluting our atmosphere. Reducing CO2 emissions is an important task for all, and it is therefore necessary to react more decisively to such scandals, including by detecting and properly sanctioning those responsible. The European Regulation is too vague in this area, as, despite the legal prohibition on the use of defeat devices, it leaves too many possibilities for interpretation as to the use of these devices, and it is therefore necessary to regulate this as soon as possible. It is also important that the Member States cooperate in this investigation, in addition to the European Commission and the European Parliament.  Last but not least, it is about consumer confidence in European products.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report as it is limited to the description of the work programme and makes no political assessment because the investigation is ongoing. However, this does not mean that the first conclusions have not already been drawn. On the contrary, after many hours of hearings and the study of internal documents, it is now clear that there are serious political responsibilities. Both the 2010 estimates and the study of the Commission's Joint Research Centre in 2013 confirmed that measurements could be altered and no action was taken. The Commission was aware of the possibility of fraud but did nothing on the grounds that it was not aware of specific cases. And the Member States, although informed, also did not do any checks. There have therefore been significant omissions by both the Commission and the Member States in the application of Union law as well as in the imposition of sanctions. Loopholes in legislation, strong pressures on the car industry and the network to protect multinational companies have led to the political scandal over emissions measurements.  We will continue the investigation and put further pressure on them. Our aim is to end all practices which, with a view to unfair profit, cause serious consequences for public health and the environment.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the devastating effects of air pollution annually, the health and safety of European citizens must be a priority.  Member States should therefore assist in securing the work of the Committee of Inquiry in order to ensure the effectiveness of control systems and to investigate any infringements.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The establishment of the Commission of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Motor Vehicle Sector (EMIS) was the European Parliament's institutional response to the outbreak of the scandal of counterfeiting of polluting emissions tests for European car manufacturers.  The purpose of this report derives from the commission's mandate, which is to present an interim document in the middle of its one-year period of activity.  Thus, EMIS's work has in recent months focused on exchanges of views with representatives of the European Commission, hearings of relevant witnesses and experts, the organisation of fact-finding missions at the Institute for Energy and Transport of the Joint Research Centre (JRC-IET), the Motor Vehicle Emissions Measurement Laboratory (VELA) and the Luxembourg type-approval authorities and the Lambsheim Vehicle Testing Facility (Germany). To these were added a number of studies, briefings and point notes, as well as requests for documents, questionnaires and appeals to relevant witnesses. A special website has also been created for the transparency of EMIS activity, where all information relevant to the public can be accessed.  All these measures will help to find out the truth and determine those responsible for the present situation. It is about carrying out one of the fundamental tasks of the EP, to defend the interests of citizens.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We demand that the Commission provide swift support and ensure full transparency by assisting the Committee of Inquiry in its work, in full compliance with the principle of fair cooperation, by providing all possible technical and political assistance, including by presenting the requested documents more promptly.  We count on the full cooperation of the current Commissioners and Directorates-General concerned as well as those previously responsible. Finally, we call on the Member States, in full compliance with the principle of fair cooperation, to provide the Committee of Inquiry with the necessary technical and political assistance, including by allowing the Commission to submit the required documents more quickly and, if the disclosure of documents is subject to Member States' approval, by speeding up their internal procedures in this area.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the draft interim report on the EMIS Committee, a committee which was set up in March this year to investigate alleged contraventions or maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to emission measurements in the automotive sector. I believe that the work done by this Committee is crucial to establish the facts and clearly identify the figures responsible for the alleged offenses, but also to restore the credibility not only of the European automotive sector but also of our inquiry authorities. I hope that the committee’s work will continue being done in full transparency and in closer cooperation with the Commission. I am looking forward to the Committee’s final report in March next year.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. The parliamentary committee of inquiry set up following the discovery of the extent of emissions fraud in road vehicles has issued its first interim report.  The 'Dieselgate' scandal has highlighted serious administrative and institutional dysfunctions, because in this case European legislation exists and clearly defines what is prohibited. But it was its effective implementation and proper application that did not follow. As a legislator, the European Parliament must determine the responsibility for this scandal, with Member States and manufacturers blaming each other.  It is a matter of the credibility of the European Union in its action against pollution, for a better living environment, and consequently, the confidence it generates among citizens.  What is the point of framing, legislating, regulating, if our efforts are not followed by effects? This commission of inquiry must shed light and keep the pressure on the other institutions to cooperate. I showed my support for him by voting in favour of this report.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I support the interim report on the automotive emissions measurement investigation. In my view, the results of such investigations could add value to the EU approval framework without prejudice to the jurisdiction of national or EU courts.  Also, the interim report of the EMIS Committee also provides a summary overview of the Committee's activities since its establishment and presents in the main lines the forthcoming work plan for the first half of the mandate. In my view, investigations into alleged infringements or irregularities in the application of Union law concerning emission measurements in the automotive sector will be of great benefit to eu citizens.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the investigation of emissions measurement in the automotive sector.  On 17 December 2015, the European Parliament set up an EMIS Committee of Inquiry with 45 members to investigate alleged infringements or irregularities in the implementation of Union legislation on emission measurements in the automotive sector, without prejudice to the jurisdiction of national or Union courts. It is therefore right to support the work of the committee of inquiry and to ensure full transparency.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution urging the Committee of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector, in the wake of the VW scandal, to fully implement the mandate given by Parliament in its Decision of 17 December 2015. It requests the Conference of Presidents and the Bureau to support all necessary measures, in particular with regard to the authorization of extraordinary hearings and meetings, reimbursement of the costs of experts and witnesses, missions and any other duly justified technical means. Requests the European Commission to ensure immediate support and full transparency, providing as much political and technical support as possible, in particular by presenting the requested documentation more promptly; expects the full cooperation of Commissioners and relevant general management, both those currently in office and those who were currently in office during previous mandates. It calls on the governments, parliaments and competent authorities of the Member States to assist the Committee of Inquiry in their work with full respect for the principle of fair cooperation laid down in EU law.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support this report. With this report and vote, we ask the Commission to ensure prompt support and full transparency in assisting the work of the Committee of Inquiry, with full respect for the principle of loyal cooperation, providing all the technical and political support possible, in particular through swifter submission of requested documentation; we expect full cooperation from the relevant current Commissioners and Directorate-Generals as well as from those who were in charge during past terms. We ask the Member States to provide the Committee of Inquiry with the necessary technical and political support, in particular by enabling the Commission to submit documents that are requested more swiftly and, if the submission of documents requires the Member States’ consent, by accelerating their internal proceedings for the granting of such consent. All clarification and information should be made public and fully transparent.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. On September 18, 2015, the Volkswagen scandal broke, following revelations by US researchers about rigging software to mask nitrogen dioxide emissions from diesel engines. This process allowed the world's largest automaker to export to the United States despite strict limits on nitrogen dioxide emissions. Parliament then decided on 17 December 2015 to form a commission of inquiry to examine allegations of breaches of EU law or maladministration in the application of EU law. This interim report sets out the method and hearings that make up Parliament's inquiry into emissions in the automotive sector. The actual hearings continue "until autumn 2016" after which MEPs will work on the drafting of the final report. Therefore, no substantive guidance is given in this text voted in committee on 13 July.  This brief and very neutral text simply encourages the Committee of Inquiry to continue its work, calls on the Conference of Presidents and the Commission and the authorities of the Member States to work with loyalty, so that no element of the investigation escapes the committee.  I voted for this text.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The work of the Committee of Inquiry, which aims to investigate allegations of infringement or maladministration in the application of European Union law to emission measurements in the automotive sector, is valuable for the proper management of climate policy and the automotive industry. These fact-calling missions, the established work schedule, the constant collection of documentation and the provision of information to the public convince me of the importance of the committee's discussion of the issue, which is why I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the draft interim report of the EMIS Committee is to provide a brief overview of the activities of the EMIS Committee since its establishment on 2 March 2016 and to provide an insight into the forthing work plan for the first half of EMIS's mandate. I supported him.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour as the Resolution urges the Committee of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector, in the wake of the VW scandal, to fully implement the mandate given by Parliament in its Decision of 17 December 2015. It requests the Conference of Presidents and the Bureau to support all necessary measures, in particular with regard to the authorization of extraordinary hearings and meetings, reimbursement of the costs of experts and witnesses, missions and any other duly justified technical means. Requests the European Commission to ensure immediate support and full transparency, providing as much political and technical support as possible, in particular by presenting the requested documentation more promptly; expects the full cooperation of Commissioners and relevant general management, both those currently in office and those who were currently in office during previous mandates. It calls on the governments, parliaments and competent authorities of the Member States to assist the Committee of Inquiry in their work with full respect for the principle of fair cooperation laid down in EU law.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Interim report on the inquiry into emission measurements in the automotive sector. On the basis of a proposal by the Conference of Presidents, Parliament decided on 17 December 2015 to set up a Committee of Inquiry to investigate the alleged failures in the application of Union law in relation to emission measurements in the automotive sector. According to the mandate, the Committee’s investigation has to focus on the compliance by the Commission and Member States’ authorities with the obligations imposed by Regulation (EC) No 715/2007. The Committee is required to make any recommendations that it deems necessary in the matter. I voted in favour because I believe that the results of the ongoing investigation could bring added value to the Union’s type-approval framework.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This interim report reflects the steps taken by the EMIS Commission of Inquiry since its establishment on 17 December 2015 to resolve whether there were possible non-compliance or misre administration practices in the application of European legislation on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector. In order to carry out the necessary investigations (and thus fulfil the mandate given to it by the European Parliament), EMIS needs to collect and analyse important amounts of information of various kinds, so that it has been convening hearings in which Officials of the European Commission and representatives of national technical services and approval authorities are convening , among others. In order to complete its task, the achievements of which will be condensed into a final document to be presented in March 2017, through this report the EMIS committee requests the Bureau and the Conference of Presidents to support the measures necessary to enable it to complete its task. So, in support of the work being done by this committee, I voted in favour of it.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'Following the finding that not all cars that arrive on the road meet the emission standards set out in the purchase brochure and/or manual, the European Parliament has set up a committee of inquiry to investigate the true extent of the so-called emissions fraud in new cars. The decision establishing this Committee of Inquiry required an interim report. The committee itself has already indicated that it is working hard to obtain information and hear from those involved, but that it is not yet able to draw any conclusions in terms of content. I agreed to allow the committee to continue its work and to provide those involved (such as companies, witnesses and governments) with the necessary information to arrive at a clear picture of the situation.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 17 December 2015, the European Parliament decided to set up a 45-member committee of inquiry to investigate alleged violations and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to emissions measurements in the automotive sector following the Volkswagen scandal.  The EMIS committee was set up on 2 March 2016, and its mandate provides for the committee of inquiry to submit an interim report within the first 6 months and a final report within 12 months of the start of its work. The work of the EMIS committee of inquiry is still ongoing, and several hearings have already been held of different witnesses and experts which will continue during the autumn period. This progress report therefore does not contain any results or recommendations.  We underline the need for further support in full respect of the principle of cooperation established in Union law, facilitating access to all relevant documentation, thereby giving full meaning to the supervisory function of the European Parliament.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This interim report is very uncritical and was also adopted unanimously in committee. That is why I voted in favour of the report here too.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the inquiry report on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector. In December 2015, Parliament decided to set up a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged infringements and maladministration in the application of EU emission law in the automotive sector, requesting reporting within six months of the start of work. Given the nature of the Committee of Inquiry, it cannot give definitive conclusions until it has heard all the witnesses and has gathered sufficient evidence. It is therefore too early for the Commission to comment on it. The interim report is purely technical in nature, but stresses the procedural aspects and reaffirms the principle of good cooperation between the institutions, insisting on greater transparency.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The report clearly reflects on what has been done and where we are at this stage. To mention just a few, the committee has planned fact-finding missions, it has requested and taken into account numerous studies and it has gathered a significant amount of facts and information. In addition, a great number of involved stakeholders has been heard, such as the relevant current and former Commissioners, representatives from the industry itself as well as consumer organisations, etc. As is stated in the resolution, it is too early to draw final conclusions. Much more work is to be done. I therefore welcome its call to the European Commission, the Member States and all other competent authorities to ensure full transparency and exchange of information in order to support the Committee in performing its duties.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On 17 December 2015, the European Parliament set up a 45-member committee of inquiry to verify allegations of maladministration in the application of Union law to emission measurements in the automotive sector. The report put to the vote is the mid-term result of the committee's work, in which it asks the Conference of Presidents and the Bureau to support all measures enabling extraordinary hearings and meetings to be organised, for the reimbursement of costs incurred by experts and witnesses, for missions and for any other duly justified technical measures. It also asks the EC to guarantee support for the work of the Committee of Inquiry.  I voted in favour of the report in order to smoothly continue the work of the Committee of Inquiry.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the rapporteurs' proposal. This report was adopted unanimously by the Committee of Inquiry responsible for emission measurements in the automotive industry.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have today approved the half-term report by which the Special Committee of Inquiry into the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector informs Parliament of the progress of the work. This report does not yet contain any direct reference to the substance of the investigation – that is, to verify possible maladministration by the European institutions and the Member States in the application of existing legislation on the control of car emissions – but stresses, albeit rather generally, the need for greater cooperation between the Member States and the Commission in order to provide the information necessary for the investigation.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I supported this interim report by the Special Committee for the Investigation of Emissions Measurement in the Automotive Industry, which was issued half a year after its establishment. As the investigation into this matter is still ongoing, the report does not contain any preliminary conclusions or political statements, but is of a purely technical nature. It therefore contains, in particular, timetables for individual hearings and a detailed description of the committee's work. It also calls for the most effective cooperation and the fastest possible response to requests for information or documents so that all necessary facts can be properly investigated.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Zalba and Gerbrandy report because I agree with the outlines of this progress report which lists the activities of the EMIS Committee of Inquiry, where I am an effective member. Indeed, as an active member of this Committee of Inquiry, in addition to the need to eradicate the culture that has enabled potential fraud, I have been confirming the inevitability of the European Union taking a leading role in the transition to intelligent mobility.  This technological transition is in the interests of Europeans, their industry and their knowledge centres, as it saves lives, improves quality of life and opens up new prospects for competitiveness.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Report on the investigation into the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector.  I support all the measures and initiatives leading to the fulfilment of the mandate of the Committee of Inquiry, which Parliament gave to it in its decision of 17 December 2015, with a view to examining the alleged inappropriate application of Union legislation on emission measurements in the automotive sector, and to make any recommendations that it considers necessary in this case.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking into account the requirements of European law on parliamentary immunity, together with what is indicated by Hungarian law, I have decided to vote in favour of waiving the parliamentary immunity of the Hungarian Member of the European Parliament, Istvàn Ujhelyi.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs voted to uphold the waiver of immunity as Ujhelyi was not a Member of the European Parliament at the time the incident took place.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Hungarian S&D MEP István Ujhelyi. In Hungarian law defamation is treated as a criminal offence, and criminal proceedings have been taken against the MEP over comments he made on Hungarian TV in April 2014 in which he opposed Tamás Sneider’s application for the post of Vice-President of the Hungarian Parliament by saying about Mr Sneider that ‘he stated that he had a fight with a gipsy Mafioso and hit him with… baseball bats’, and that ‘everyone else says he was the local boss of a Mafia-style organisation, a skinhead organisation’. The comments were made before he was elected as MEP but while he was a candidate. In November 2014 the Hungarian court suspended the procedure and moved that the EP waive his immunity. István Ujhelyi believes the EP should defend his immunity because under Hungarian law candidates for European elections have parliamentary immunity. But under European law only MEPs are covered, so the interpretation by JURI is that immunity should be waived as he wasn’t acting in his capacity as MEP when he made the comments. I believe this is the correct interpretation, so voted in favour.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. Istvan Ujhelyi was not a member of the European Parliament at the time of the alleged offence. Therefore, he could not legally avail himself of any immunity from our Parliament.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. As part of the programme "Egyenes Beszéd" broadcast on 25 April 2014 by the Hungarian television channel ATV, Mr. Istvon 'jhelyi stated that he opposed the candidacy of Mr. Tamus Sneider for the post of Vice-President of the National Assembly, saying, with regard to the person of Tamus Sneider, that "he stated that he had fought with a mafia gypsy and that he had beaten him with I don't know what , a baseball bat", and that "everyone says that he was the local leader of a mafia organization, a bunch of skinheads". The pest court has requested the lifting of Istvon Ujhelyi's parliamentary immunity. The court's application relates to criminal proceedings for defamation of an individual in Hungary. Considering that the charges against Istvon Ujhelyi do not relate to opinions expressed or votes cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, the immunity is therefore not applicable. Nevertheless, Ujhelyi argues that the European Parliament should not lift its immunity on the grounds that, under Hungarian law, candidates for The European elections in Hungary enjoy parliamentary immunity. So I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of transparency and democracy I voted in favour of this waiver. I voted to waive the immunity. The event took place before Ujhelyi was even an MEP.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the Committee on the merits

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. The President of Parliament announced that he had received on 15 July 2015 a letter from the Hungarian Permanent Representative to the EU, ordering the order of the Central District Court of Pest on the request for waiver of the immunity of Mr István Ujhelyi, a Member of the European Parliament, for defamation. Since the allegations were made before István Ujhelyi became a member of the European Parliament, I therefore support the decision to waive the immunity of István Ujhelyi.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEP's voted to uphold the waiver of immunity as Ujhelyi was not a Member of the European Parliament at the time the incident took place.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The Central District Court of Pest has requested the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Istvon Ujhelyi, the immunity provided by Article 8 of Protocol 7 is not applicable, because, at the time of the alleged facts, he was not yet an MP but simply in campaign. However, Ujhelyi argues that the European Parliament should not lift its immunity on the grounds that a Hungarian law allows candidates in The European elections in Hungary to already enjoy parliamentary immunity. I therefore abstained, respecting Hungarian law in this matter and leaving this Member the benefit of the doubt.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted to lift Mr Ujhelyi's immunity following the decision of the Committee on Legal Affairs

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. I abstained from the vote to withdraw parliamentary immunity from Hungarian MEP István Ujhelyi of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats Group. This request comes as a result of an accusation of defamation of another public office in Hungary. Although these events occurred before he became a Member of the European Parliament after the 2014 European Parliament elections, that is, outside the parliamentary activity for which he enjoys immunity, I believe that the elements of judgment do not allow me to take a resounding position in this case. At the same time, being a Hungarian MEMBER opposing Viktor Orbán's government, characterized in recent years by his growing authoritarianism, is yet another reason to be cautious about this request for withdrawal of parliamentary immunity, which was also promoted by the parliamentary spokesman for the far-right Jobbik party, Tamás Sneider, which has been embroiled in several violent episodes and racist connotations.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the recommendations of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Mr István Ujhelyi. This request was made on the basis of a decision of 26 November 2014 of the Central District Court of Pest (Hungary) in relation to criminal defamation proceedings.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity, as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I agree with the legal assessments which consider that the statements which gave rise to Mr Uhjelyi's complaint, were made when he was not a European parliamentarian, has nothing to do with his status as such, nor with the roles of Members of the European Parliament and has a channel to clarify himself in the field of Hungarian justice.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Hungarian Socialist MP Istvan Ujhelyi. Mr. Ujhelyi is in fact the subject of criminal proceedings in Hungary for defamation offences. As a reminder, in 2014 he allegedly accused the candidate for the post of vice-president of the Hungarian National Assembly of being the local leader of a mafia organization, a "band of skinheads". As these words in themselves have not been made in the course of his duties as MEPs, immunity does not hold.
