However, it would appear that a Hungarian law provides that this immunity is applicable to all candidates in the European elections. If in doubt and until competent authorities unravel this legal imbroglio, it was therefore better to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of István Ujhelyi's parliamentary immunity in the light of the report prepared by the Committee on Legal Affairs, which finds that the Central District Court of Pest has requested a stay in connection with an ongoing criminal proceeding for a defamation offence linked to the statements made by that parliamentarian on 25 April 2014 on a person from Hungary , when he was not a Member of the European Parliament, and therefore the charges against him do not concern an opinion expressed or a vote by him cast in the exercise of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has led Parliament to waive the immunity of The Hungarian MEP István Ujhelyi. The Central Regional Court of Pest has requested the waiver of the immunity of István Ujhelyi, a Member of the European Parliament, in connection with a defamation case pending before that court, namely the 2014 allegations of a private individual in Hungary by István Ujhelyi. The accusations against István Ujhelyi do not concern an opinion or vote made by him as a Member of the European Parliament and therefore the protection of absolute immunity under Article 8 of Protocol No 7 cannot be applied.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support the request to lift István Ujhelyi's immunity.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. As part of the television programme broadcast in April 2014 on the Hungarian channel ATV, MEP Istvon Ujhelyi said he opposed Tamas Sneider's candidacy as Vice-President of the National Assembly. According to him, the candidate had stated that he had fought with a Gypsy, whom he had subsequently beaten. Tamas Sneider was the local leader of a mafia organization in the past, according to Istvon Ujhelyi.  With these comments, the Hungarian MEP is accused of defamation and is therefore the subject of a request by the Central District Court of Pest to waive parliamentary immunity. Considering that the charges against Istvon Ujhelyi do not relate to opinions expressed or votes cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, the immunity provided by Article 8 of Protocol 7 is therefore not applicable.  Nevertheless, Ujhelyi argues that the European Parliament should not lift its immunity on the grounds that candidates for the European elections in Hungary enjoy parliamentary immunity under Hungarian law. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because, in criminal proceedings before the Pest court, István Ujhelyi is accused of committing the offence of defamation under Article 226(1) of Law C of 2012 of the Hungarian Criminal Code. According to the court's decision, István Újhelyi, during the "Let's Talk Clear" programme, broadcast on hungarian broadcaster ATV on 25 April 2014, stated that he opposed Tamás Sneider's candidacy for the post of Vice-President of the Hungarian Parliament.  According to István Újhelyi, vice presidential candidate Sneider "claimed to have fought a Gypsy mobster by hitting him with i don't know what kind of instrument, baseball bats" and "everyone says he was the local boss of a mafia-style organization, a shaved-head organization." On 26 November 2014, the Central Court of Pest suspended the prosecution of István Ujhelyi and asked the European Parliament to waive his immunity. István Ujhelyi, for his part, believes that the European Parliament should safeguard its immunity because candidates in Hungarian elections to the European Parliament enjoy parliamentary immunity.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Hungarian S&D MEP István Ujhelyi. In Hungarian law defamation is treated as a criminal offence, and criminal proceedings have been taken against the MEP over comments he made on Hungarian TV in April 2014 in which he opposed Tamás Sneider’s application for the post of Vice-President of the Hungarian Parliament by saying about Mr Sneider that ‘he stated that he had a fight with a gipsy Mafioso and hit him with… baseball bats’, and that ‘everyone else says he was the local boss of a Mafia-style organisation, a skinhead organisation’. The comments were made before he was elected as MEP but while he was a candidate. In November 2014 the Hungarian court suspended the procedure and moved that the EP waive his immunity. István Ujhelyi believes the EP should defend his immunity because under Hungarian law candidates for European elections have parliamentary immunity. But under European law only MEPs are covered, so the interpretation by JURI is that immunity should be waived as he wasn’t acting in his capacity as MEP when he made the comments. I believe this is the correct interpretation, so voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The statements by István Ujhelyi were made on 25 April 2014, when he was not a Member of the European Parliament, but a Member of the Hungarian Parliament. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of waiving parliamentary immunity.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as the facts arising from the request for waiver of immunity and the hearing of István Ujhelyi show that the statements were made at a time when he was not a Member of the European Parliament. Consequently, according to the Commission, when István Ujhelyi made the statements at question he was not acting in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. The fact that Hungarian legislation recognises that candidates in elections to the national or European Parliament enjoy parliamentary immunity under national procedures does not in any way affect that conclusion for the purposes of the procedure in the European Parliament.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the waiver of istván Ujhelyi's immunity. As this process is not related to its action in the European Parliament, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the Request for waiver of the parliamentary immunity of István Ujhelyi and noted no objections.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of waiving this immunity because the statements in question were made before Mr István Ujhelyi was elected to the European Parliament and consequently cannot be considered to have been made in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The waiver was requested for parliamentary immunity of a Member of the European Parliament, István Ujhelyi, in connection with proceedings before it. The report grants the waiver on criminal proceedings relating to the crime of defamation, which I support.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of withdrawing istván Ujhelyi's parliamentary immunity as he has been charged with making defamatory and racist statements on Hungarian television, when he was not yet an MEP. Because of the nature of the offence against him, I have decided to vote in favour of withdrawing his parliamentary immunity so that the courts of his country can continue the judicial process.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support the request for waiver of mr István Ujhelyi's immunity. The MEP was accused in a Hungarian court of defaming Mr Sneider, claiming that he was the head of a mafia organisation. Mr Ujhelyi believes that he should be protected by immunity, even though he was defamatory at a time when he was not yet an MEP. It is clear that this had nothing to do with the performance of the duties of being an MEP. The rapporteur recommends the lifting of immunity, and I believe exactly the same.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour for the waiver of the immunity of István Ujhelyi, because in this way he can prove his innocence or otherwise in full compliance with the rule of law.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted to uphold the waiver of immunity as Ujhelyi was not a Member of the European Parliament at the time the incident took place.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. On 25 April 2014 on Hungarian television, Mr. Istvon 'jhelyi stated that he opposed the candidacy of Mr. Tamus Sneider for the post of Vice-President of the National Assembly, saying that Tamus Sneider had had a violent altercation with a Gypsy. For the purposes of criminal defamation proceedings, it is necessary to lift the parliamentary immunity of Istvon Ujhelyi. In this case, parliamentary immunity is not applicable anyway, but he argued a particular provision of Hungarian law, which confers it on candidates in European elections. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis third parties with regard to the application of the law and the administration of justice.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. It is established that members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or prosecuted for their opinions or votes in the exercise of their duties; it must be noted that the statements for which this matter was initiated were made when Mr Ujhelyi was not yet a Member of the European Parliament, and therefore, in making those statements, he did not act in the exercise of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.  That is why the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that the European Parliament suspend the parliamentary immunity of István Ujhelyi

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of criminal proceedings brought before the Central District Court of Pest, István Ujhelyi was charged with the crime of defamation. According to the Court's judgment, the facts at the origin of the criminal proceedings are as follows: on a television programme the Member commented on Tamás Sneider's candidacy for Vice-President of the Hungarian Parliament. The facts of the case, as set out in the request for waiver of immunity and the hearing of István Ujhelyi, indicate that the statements were made when he was not yet a member of the European Parliament. I agree with the lifting of istván Ujhelyi's parliamentary immunity.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Abstention: this is a criminal proceeding for defamation of an individual in Hungary.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This request for waiver of parliamentary immunity is based on proceedings pending before the Central District Court of Pest. The case relates to a crime of defamation related to statements made by István Ujhelyi about a person in Hungary, in particular saying that he was not in a position to hold a particular public office for relations he had with criminals. These statements were made when István Ujhelyi was still a member of the Hungarian national parliament and not of the European Parliament. The declarations are not subject to proceedings relating to opinions or votes cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, which consequently makes the absolute immunity provided for in Article 8 of Protocol No 7 not applicable. As such and in the face of the facts, we are voting in favour of the waiver of immunity.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of István Ujhelyi. Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis third parties in terms of law enforcement and the administration of justice.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The committee unanimously followed the rapporteur’s recommendation to waive the immunity.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the request for the waiver of the immunity of Istvan Ujhelyi in order to allow for a transparent procedure in a case against him before Hungarian courts. According to the court order, the criminal proceedings have the following background: Istvan Ujhelyi had taken part in the broadcast egyenes Beszéd ("Direct Speech") of the Hungarian TV channel ATV of 25 May. On 1 April 2014, he was defeated by Tams Sneider for the post of Vice-President of the Hungarian Parliament because he had said that he had beaten himself with a gypsy mafioso and beat him with baseball bats or "who knows what". Moreover, according to Istvan Ujhelyi, it is generally claimed that he was the local head of a mafia organisation, a skinhead organisation.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agreed with the stated reasons to waive immunity.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity, as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – We voted in favour of the report on the waiver of István Ujhelyi's parliamentary immunity since the case under consideration for which his immunity is being sought took place before he was elected as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the waiver of the immunity of István Ujhelyi. Considering that Mr. Ujhelyi made the defamatory states at a time when he was not a Member of the European Parliament, it must be noted that when making the statements in question, István Ujhelyi was not acting in the performance of his duties as Member of the European Parliament. The fact that under national Hungarian legislation candidates standing in elections to the national parliament or to the European Parliament may enjoy parliamentary immunity in accordance with national procedures does not alter this conclusion for the purposes of the procedure in the European Parliament.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on a request to lift István Ujhelyi's immunity on the basis that this was the position of the ALDE Group.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The Central District Court of Pest has requested the lifting of Mr. Istvon Ujhelyi's parliamentary immunity. The court's application relates to criminal proceedings for defamation of an individual in Hungary. The MP attacked a majority politician in a radio interview, accusing him of an extremist and violent political past. I am cautious in these matters, and have abstained.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Tadeusz Zwiefka's report on the request to waive Ujhelyi's parliamentary immunity. This procedure is a formality which, without deciding on the merits of the case, is intended to enable the judicial authorities to carry out their investigative work.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. As advocated by the JURI Commission, I voted in favour of lifting the parliamentary immunity of Mr Istvon Ujhelyi, who is being sued for defamation because his comments did not refer to opinions related to his parliamentary mandate.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of waiving Mr Ujhelyi's immunity. The facts he was accused of all happened before or outside his mandate, so that the waiver of his immunity did not hinder him in the exercise of his mandate.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agree with the reasons for the proposal to waive the immunity.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report. Although Mr Ujhelyi was accused of defamation before his term of office, he had doubts about the intention to harm him despite a Hungarian law providing for the defence of his immunity in Hungary.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Istvon 'jhelyi, accused of defaming a Hungarian National MP. Considering that the charges against Istvon Ujhelyi do not relate to opinions expressed or votes cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, the immunity provided by Article 8 of Protocol 7 is therefore not applicable.  However, Ujhelyi argues that the European Parliament should not lift its immunity on the grounds that, under Hungarian law, candidates for the European elections in Hungary enjoy parliamentary immunity.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The charges against Istvon Ujhelyi do not relate to opinions expressed or votes cast in the course of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, the immunity provided by Article 8 of Protocol 7 is not applicable.  Nevertheless, Ujhelyi argues that the European Parliament should not lift its immunity on the grounds that, under Hungarian law, candidates for The European elections in Hungary enjoy parliamentary immunity. Therefore, I abstained.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of withdrawing istván Ujhelyi's parliamentary immunity as he has been charged with making defamatory and racist statements on Hungarian television, when he was not yet an MEP. Because of the nature of the offence against him, I have decided to vote in favour of withdrawing his parliamentary immunity so that the courts of his country can continue the judicial process.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of waiver of Mr Ujhelyi's immunity. The incident in question (another MEMBER's alleged defamation of cooperating with the mafia) happened before his parliamentary mandate was created, so let the Hungarian authorities deal with the matter.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am opposed to the waiver of the immunity of István Ujhelyi. He was charged with having committed the crime of defamation. I am in principle against such kind of articles in the Criminal Codes. Especially I am sceptical when such articles are used against journalists and politicians. Sometimes it is a very useful instrument against political opponents, especially when it was used against opponents of Hungarian regime leader Mr Orbán.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the Central District Court in Budapest accused MEP István Ujhelyi of the crime of defamation he should have committed before obtaining the mep's mandate. At the same time, in accordance with Hungarian law, the COURT of the EP asked for his parliamentary immunity to be waived. Since Mr Ujhelyi's statements and statements do not concern his views and those in the performance of the MEP's mandate, the EP has decided, in accordance with the Rules of Procedure, to waive his immunity. Of course I believe in a fair investigation of the whole case.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on istván Ujhelyi's request for waiver of immunity, following the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report.  On 25 April 2014 on Hungarian television, Mr. Istvon 'jhelyi stated that he opposed the candidacy of Mr. Tamus Sneider for the post of Vice-President of the National Assembly, claiming that Tamus Sneider had had a violent altercation with a Gypsy.  For the purposes of criminal defamation proceedings, it is necessary to lift the parliamentary immunity of Istvon Ujhelyi.  In this case, parliamentary immunity is not applicable anyway, but he argued a particular provision of Hungarian law, which confers it on candidates in European elections.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is about waiving the immunity of Istvan Ujhelyi MEP. He was charged with defamation in criminal proceedings under Article 226(1) of Law C/2012 on the Hungarian Criminal Code. It is for the courts to assess whether the facts are satisfied. That is why I support this motion.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP's report proposing the elimination of the legal immunity of Mr Ujhelyi, a Member of the European Parliament. I believe that this will help law enforcement to investigate the criminal case of defamation more quickly.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report calls for the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Hungarian Social Democrat MP Istvon 'jhelyi' Istvon 'jhelyi' In a television programme, Istvon Jhelyi said of his far-right opponent as vice-president of the National Assembly, Mr. Tamus Sneider, that he was "the local leader of a mafia organization, a band of skinheads". The Central District Court of Pest has asked the European Parliament to lift the immunity so that it can be sued for defamation.  I am voting against it because it is clearly a political opinion in the context of the exercise of the no less political mandate of Istvon Jhelyi.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Considering that the charges against Istvon Ujhelyi do not relate to opinions expressed or votes cast in the course of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, the immunity provided by Article 8 of Protocol 7 is not applicable, but Istvon Ujhelyi argues that the European Parliament should not lift its immunity on the grounds that under a Hungarian law , candidates for the European elections in Hungary enjoy parliamentary immunity. Therefore, I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of the independence of the Mandate of the European Parliament is the responsibility of the European Parliament and that independence cannot be called into question. In accordance with Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties.  In this case, the Central District Court of Pest requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of a Member of the European Parliament, István Ujhelyi, as part of proceedings pending before that court. The court's request relates to criminal proceedings brought for the crime of defamation, related to statements made by István Ujhelyi about a person in Hungary. The accusations against István Ujhelyi are not related to opinions or votes cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament and that, therefore, the absolute immunity provided for in Article 8 of Protocol No 7 does not apply, so I voted in favour of the waiver of his immunity.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Istvon Ujhelyi, whose request was made by the Central District Court of Pest (Hungary) in a criminal proceeding referred to by Istvon Ujhelyi for defamation in connection with statements made by the concerned against an individual in Hungary.  Parliamentary immunity is granted to Members of the European Parliament in order to protect them from pressure in connection with opinions or votes cast by them in the performance of their duties, in accordance with Article 8 of Protocol 7.  The offending statements were made on 24 April 2014, when Istvon Ujhelyi was not a Member of the European Parliament but a Member of the Hungarian National Parliament. Immunity therefore does not apply in this case.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the request for the waiver of the immunity of István Ujhelyi, since he was brought before the Central District Court of Pest criminal proceeding and was charged with having committed the crime of defamation pursuant to Article 226(1) of Act C of 2012 on the Hungarian Criminal Code.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In an order of 26 November 2014, the Central District Court of Pest requested the waiver of the immunity of István Ujhelyi, accused of committing a defamation offence. The statements on which the charge was based were made by István Ujhelyi on 25 April 2014, before he was elected to the European Parliament in the 2014 Elections to the European Parliament. The Committee on Legal Affairs therefore considers in its report that István Ujhelyi was not a Member of the European Parliament when he made the statements in question, and thus proposes that the European Parliament suspend the immunity of István Ujhelyi. In the view of István Ujhelyi, on the other hand, under the Hungarian Act XXXVI of 2012 on the Parliament, the candidate running for elections to the European Parliament in Hungary also has immunity and should therefore be maintained by the European Parliament. For my part, I consider István Ujhelyi's position to be well founded, so I voted against the proposal for a decision of the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. As part of a Hungarian television programme ATV, Mr. Istvon Ujhelyi stated that he opposed the candidacy of Mr. Tamus Sneider for the post of Vice-President of the National Assembly, saying, with regard to the person of Tamus Sneider, that "everyone says that he was the local leader of a mafia organization, a band of skinheads".  The Central District Court of Pest has requested the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Istvon Ujhelyi. The court's application relates to criminal proceedings for defamation of an individual in Hungary.  Considering that the charges against Istvon Ujhelyi do not relate to opinions expressed or votes cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, the immunity provided by Article 8 of Protocol 7 is not applicable.  However, Ujhelyi argues that the European Parliament should not lift its immunity on the grounds that, under Hungarian law, candidates for The European elections in Hungary enjoy parliamentary immunity.  If in doubt, this request calls for abstention.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deserves my vote in favour, once all the legal procedures required have elapsed and because the offence in question is not in any way related to the performance of the duties of a Member and that there is no evidence or suspicion that, at the origin of the criminal proceedings, the intention to harm the Member concerned is politically impaired.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Zwiefka report concerns the prosecution of Istvan Ujhelyi, by the Hungarian channel ATV, for making defamatory statements.   This prosecution is unrelated to his parliamentary activity not being driven by political considerations. However, Mr Ujhelyi argues that the European Parliament should not lift its immunity on the grounds that, under Hungarian law, candidates for The European elections in Hungary enjoy parliamentary immunity. I have therefore decided to abstain on this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the lifting of Mr Istvon Ujhelyi's parliamentary immunity. Any request made to the President of the European Parliament by the authorities of a Member State to waive a Member's immunity is heard by the relevant Parliamentary Committee. I voted in accordance with the opinion of this committee.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the request for the waive of the immunity of Mr Ujhelyi. On the basis of the request for waive of immunity and the hearing of István Ujhelyi, according to the facts of the case, the statements were made at a time when István Ujhelyi was not yet an MEP. By the way, in my opinion, Mr Ujhelyi's statements on the title of extremist politicians did not go beyond the limits of personal protection, and I am therefore sure that my colleague Ujhelyi will be given the truth by the Hungarian court.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report according to the evaluation made by the JURI Committee.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This is a request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Hungarian S&D MEP István Ujhelyi. In Hungarian law defamation is treated as a criminal offence, and criminal proceedings have been taken against the MEP over comments he made on Hungarian TV in April 2014 in which he opposed Tamás Sneider’s application for the post of Vice-President of the Hungarian Parliament by saying about Mr Sneider that ‘he stated that he had a fight with a gipsy Mafioso and hit him with… baseball bats’, and that ‘everyone else says he was the local boss of a Mafia-style organisation, a skinhead organisation’. The comments were made before he was elected as MEP but while he was a candidate. In November 2014 the Hungarian court suspended the procedure and moved that the EP waive his immunity. István Ujhelyi believes the EP should defend his immunity because under Hungarian law candidates for European elections have parliamentary immunity. But under European law only MEPs are covered, so the interpretation by JURI is that immunity should be waived as he wasn’t acting in his capacity as MEP when he made the comments. I believe this is the correct interpretation, so voted in favour.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This is about waiving the immunity of Istvan Ujhelyi MEP. He was charged with defamation in criminal proceedings under Article 226(1) of Law C/2012 on the Hungarian Criminal Code. It is for the courts to assess whether the facts are satisfied. That is why I support this report.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted to uphold the waiver of immunity as Ujhelyi was not a Member of the European Parliament at the time the incident took place.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Considering that the charges against Istvon Ujhelyi do not relate to opinions expressed or votes cast in the course of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, the immunity provided by Article 8 of Protocol 7 is therefore not applicable. But Ujhelyi argues that the European Parliament should not lift its immunity on the grounds that, under Hungarian law, candidates for the European elections in Hungary enjoy parliamentary immunity.  So I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Since the allegations against istván Ujhelyi's colleague are not related to the expression of an opinion or its vote in the performance of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament and therefore absolute immunity in accordance with Article 8 of the Regulation, the Protocol No. 7 is not applicable, I support the decision to lift immunity.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. On 26 November 2014, a request for waiver of István Újhelyi's parliamentary immunity was entered in the Pest District Court.  At the origin of the request are statements made by the Member on a local television programme. Újhelyi allegedly made a number of statements and accusations against Tamás Sneider, who were laid down and punished under the rules of the Hungarian Penal Code as a defamation crime. The statements in question were allegedly made on 25 April 2014, before the elections for the current parliamentary term of the European Parliament, which resulted in the election of István Ujhelyi as an MEP. In other words, I would like to point out that the facts indicate that the statements were made when he was not yet a member of the European Parliament. So, on the basis of the recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted to uphold the waiver of immunity as Ujhelyi was not a Member of the European Parliament at the time the incident took place.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of the proceedings brought before the Central District Court of Pest, István Ujhelyi was charged with the crime of defamation. According to the Court's judgment, the facts at the origin of the criminal proceedings are as follows: in the Egyenes Beszéd programme ('Frank'and Office'), on 25 April 2014, István Ujhelyi stated that he opposed Tamás Sneider's candidacy for Vice-President of the Hungarian Parliament, stating that 'he declared that he had a disagreement with a Gypsy mobster and gave him no known what kind of instruments he had , baseball bats" and that "everyone else says that he was the local head of a mafia-type organization, an organization of shaved heads". The statements in question were made on 25 April 2014, before the 2014 European Parliament elections, which resulted in the election of István Ujhelyi as an MEP. In view of the fact that the judicial procedure does not concern opinions or votes cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament and that there is no reason to suppose that the intention underlying the legal action is to undermine the political activity of the Member, this request, which I voted in favour of, decides to lift the immunity of Mr Ujhelyi.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The charges against István Ujhelyi are not related to opinions or votes cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of istván Ujhelyi's parliamentary immunity in the light of the report prepared by the Committee on Legal Affairs, which finds that the Central District Court of Pest has requested a stay in relation to an ongoing criminal proceeding, for an offence of defamation linked to the statements made by that parliamentarian on 25 April 2014 on a person from Hungary , when he was not a Member of the European Parliament, and therefore the charges against him do not concern an opinion expressed or a vote by him cast in the exercise of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting Mr. In order for the Hungarian justice system to carry out its work, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, on the understanding that the facts in question (proposed on the occasion of a Hungarian television programme) are not directly related to the office of MEP of Mr Ujhelyi - who was then a national member - and are not motivated by any desire to harm.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. István Ujhelyi is accused of defamation in a criminal case pending before the Central District Court of Pest. 2014 On 25 April, in the show "Straight Pale", István Ujhelyi stated that he opposed tamás Sneider's candidacy for vice-president of the Hungarian Parliament and said that Mr Sneider had "clashed with a member of the Roma mafia and gave him, I do not know what kind of tool, a baseball bat" and that "everyone says that he led a mafia-style organisation at local level (shastagalvi organization)". Despite the fact that these statements were made at a time when the person in question was not a member of the European Parliament, it was nevertheless necessary to withdraw the immunity of István Ujhelyi in order to investigate the event.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Ujhelyi. This is a request made by the Central District Court of Pest on 26 November 2014 concerning proceedings pending before that Court in connection with an alleged defamation offence, of which István Ujhelyi was accused under Article 226(1) of Law C 2012 on the Hungarian Criminal Code. Since this is an alleged conduct carried out outside his mandate as an MEP (istván Ujhelyi, at the time of the facts giving rise to this judicial proceedings, the functions of a Member of the National Parliament) and there is no reason to believe that there are intentions underlying the legal action to undermine his political activity, I voted in favour of this request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity, as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of withdrawing istván Ujhelyi's parliamentary immunity as he has been charged with making defamatory and racist statements on Hungarian television, when he was not yet an MEP. Because of the nature of the offence against him, I have decided to vote in favour of withdrawing his parliamentary immunity so that the courts of his country can continue the judicial process.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to waive the immunity, as this event took place before the subject was an MEP.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the Central District Court in Pest asked the EP to waive the parliamentary immunity of MEP István Ujhelyi in connection with the defamation offence that the MEP was due to commit back in April 2014. According to the court's decision, the fact is that István Ujhelyi made statements during a televised debate about a candidate for vice-president of the Hungarian Parliament, describing him, among other things, as a local boss of a mafia organisation, and saying that he had a fight with a gypsy mob,... Under Hungarian criminal law, anyone who puts before others a fact capable of endangering a person's seriousness, disseminates unverified reports or uses an expression directly referring to such a fact will commit the crime of defamation. These statements should have been made by Mr Ujhelyi at a time when he was not yet in office as an MEP, so, in order to investigate this, I supported the motion for resolutions for István Ujhelyi to be waived of his immunity.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the European Parliament cannot prevent the lawful and duly justified prosecution of its member. A Member of the European Parliament represents not only himself, but also his country and the entire European Union. It should therefore always avoid inappropriate behaviour, such as insulting and insulting its political opponents. All the more so when it comes to public appearances.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of waiving immunity because it is not a mandate-related issue.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ During the Egyenes Beszed programme aired on Hungarian TV channel ATV on 25 April 2014. István Ujhelyi stated that he was against Tamás Sneider's application as Vice-President of the Hungarian Parliament and cited mr Sneider's alleged disputed statements in this regard.  I support the report on the application for waiver of István Ujhelyi's immunity in accordance with Article 226(1) of the EIA. Law C of 2012 of the Hungarian Criminal Code, according to which any person who presents in front of others as a fact something that may harm one's reputation or honour, spreads rumours or directly refers to such a claim, commits a criminal offence of defamation which is punishable.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We voted in favour of lifting immunity so that this person could explain himself before the courts of his country.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of the Member of the European Parliament István Ujhelyi, who is being accused of defamatory statements made during a talk show broadcasted by a Hungarian TV Channel, towards an applicant for the post of Vice-President of the Hungarian Parliament. Waving the immunity will facilitate the enquiry in connection to criminal proceedings, as the statement was made at a time when István Ujhelyi was not a Member of the European Parliament, but a Member of the National Parliament. It therefore cannot be covered by the immunity provided by his status of Member of the European Parliament.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. I support the request to lift István Ujhelyi's immunity. I consider this justified, since his statement was made during the period when he was not a Member of the European Parliament. The charge against István Ujhelyi is not related to the expression of an opinion or its vote in the performance of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament and I therefore consider that the competent authorities should investigate a possible criminal offence.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a decision on the request for waiver of the immunity of István Ujhelyi.  In court proceedings before the Central District Court of Pešti, István Ujhelyi was charged with a criminal offence of defamation under Section 226(1) of Law C of the Hungarian Penal Code 2012.  The offence has nothing to do with the work of an Mp, so I support the waiver of immunity.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity, as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity, as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the request for waiver of the immunity of István Ujhelyi.  In criminal proceedings brought before the Central District Court of Pest, István Ujhelyi was charged with having committed the crime of defamation pursuant to Article 226(1) of Act C of 2012 on the Hungarian Criminal Code. Since the statements in question were made on 25 April 2014, they were made before István Ujhelyi became a Member of the European Parliament following his election during the 2014 European Parliament elections. I voted in favour of the report because when making the statements in question, István Ujhelyi was not acting in the performance of his duties as Member of the European Parliament.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. 'Mr István Ujhelyi has been asked to lift parliamentary immunity in proceedings pending before the Central District Court of Pest.  The case relates to a crime of defamation, related to statements made by István Ujhelyi about a person in Hungary, in particular saying that he was not in a position to hold a particular public office for relations he had with criminals. These statements were made when István Ujhelyi was still a Member of the Hungarian National Parliament and not of the European Parliament. The statements under review are not related to opinions or votes cast in the performance of your duties as a Member of the European Parliament, which consequently makes the absolute immunity provided for in Article 8 of Protocol No 7 not applicable. As such, and in the face of the facts, we are voting in favour of the waiver of immunity.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion because the events took place before or outside his position as an MEP.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. The report or case of immunity being lifted is a purely dissenting offence. Since the parliamentary immunity of a Member is precisely intended to protect his freedom of expression, the lifting of immunity demanded here runs counter to the spirit of parliamentary democracy, which is why a 'no' was in place here.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ Many times a request is made to the plenary of the European Parliament to waive the immunity of Members of the European Parliament on the basis of various facts. My view on these reports is that, as regards the request for waiver of immunity as a result of an act that took place at a time when the Member concerned was already a member of the European Parliament and at the same time the act in question took place in connection with the exercise of his mandate (for example, concerning his statements in plenary), parliamentary immunity should not be waived. However, as regards events unrelated to the exercise of a Member of the European Parliament's mandate or occurred before a Member took up his mandate, I see no reason to vote against such a request. I believe that the rules are sufficiently clear in the case of the waiver of members' immunity, which is why, even in this case , as it was not yet a Member of the European Parliament at the time of the incident, I voted in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the request for waiver of the immunity of István Ujhelyi.  As is apparent from the report, the allegations against István Uighhlyi are not connected with the opinion or vote that that Member would have expressed in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament and is therefore not subject to absolute immunity within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol No 7.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In January 2016, the President received a request from Rosario Crocetta, a former Member of the European Parliament, concerning the defence of his parliamentary immunity in criminal proceedings pending before the Court of Palermo.  In that case, Rosario Crocetta is charged with defamation crimes related to organized crime during a political debate on October 2, 2012. According to the Court, a statement made by a Member outside the European Parliament may constitute an express opinion in the performance of his duties, within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol No 7, giving relevance not to the place where the declaration was given, but to the nature and content.  In order to be understood on the spectrum of immunity, an opinion of an MEP must have a direct and obvious relationship with his parliamentary duties. The facts of the process, as evidenced by the documents and the hearing held, show that the statements have an obvious relationship with the parliamentary activities of Rosario Crocetta.  In the light of the foregoing, and because I agree with the premises of the CJEU, I cannot fail to consider that Rosario Crocetta, in making the statements at issue, acted in the context of the performance of her duties. Therefore, in accordance with the recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I am voting in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted to uphold the defence of parliamentary privilege as Crocetta was a Member of the European Parliament at the time the incident took place and was fulfilling his role.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. At the request of the injured party, the public prosecutor's office before the Palermo Court charged Rosario Crocetta with the crime of defamation, punishable by Article 595 of the Italian Penal Code. The Committee on Legal Affairs considers that the facts of the case, as evidenced by the documents provided and the Rosario Crocetta hearing, show that the statements in question have a direct and obvious link with Rosario Crocetta's parliamentary activities. In view of the circumstances of the case and the content of the statements, Rosario Crocetta's allegations are therefore capable of presenting a direct and obvious link with her activities as a Member of the European Parliament. In the light of the foregoing, Rosario Crocetta, in making the statements in question, may be regarded as acting in the course of her duties as a Member of the European Parliament. On the basis of Article 9(3) of the Rules of Procedure, after examining the arguments for and against the defence of Rosario Crocetta's immunity, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that the European Parliament upright Rosario Crocetta's immunity and privileges. In this regard, I voted in favour of this request.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ Many times a request is made to the plenary of the European Parliament to waive the immunity of Members of the European Parliament on the basis of various facts. My view on these reports is that, as regards the request for waiver of immunity as a result of an act that took place at a time when the Member concerned was already a member of the European Parliament and at the same time the act in question took place in connection with the exercise of his mandate (for example, concerning his statements in plenary), parliamentary immunity should not be waived. However, as regards events unrelated to the exercise of a Member of the European Parliament's mandate or occurred before a Member took up his mandate, I see no reason to vote against such a request. I believe that the rules are sufficiently clear in the case of the waiver of members' immunity, which is why I voted in favour of maintaining immunity here too , as the facts indicate that an event has taken place in connection with the exercise of a parliamentary mandate.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The prosecutor of the Greek Supreme Court has requested the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, a Member of the European Parliament, in connection with prosecution relating to an alleged infringement, and on the understanding that the prosecution to be initiated is not manifestly related to the status of Member of the European Parliament, but to his previous term as Councillor for Thessaloniki.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The action brought relates to the attribution, in 2011, by the Municipality of Thessaloniki, of authorizations, allegedly illegal, of occupation of public space for the purpose of installing terraces in pedestrian areas and where Sotorios Zarianopoulos is accused in his capacity as former councillor of this municipality. This action is in no way related to the status of a Member of the European Parliament, but to his previous term as councillor of the Municipality of Thessaloniki. I therefore agree with the lifting of parliamentary immunity.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote for: there is no reason to assume that the proposed prosecution would be motivated by the intention to interfere with the MP's political activity (fumus persecutionis).

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Greek Supreme Court Prosecutor has requested the waiver of parliamentary immunity for Sotirios Zarianopoulos, who is a Member of the Greek Communist Party in the European Parliament. The action brought relates to the allocation, in 2011, by the Municipality of Thessaloniki, of allegedly illegal authorizations for the occupation of public space for the purpose of installing terraces in pedestrian areas. Sotirios Zarianopoulos is accused, in his capacity as a former councillor of this municipality, of helping this situation. It is considered that there is no reason to suspect that the intention underlying the criminal proceedings is to harm the political activity of the deputy even more so that the said action involves all, at the time, councilors of the municipality.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos as parliamentary privileges must in no way lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis third parties in terms of law enforcement and the administration of justice.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. Considering that the Public Prosecutor's Office has asked the Greek Supreme Court to waive the parliamentary immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, a Member of the European Parliament, in connection with the prosecution of an alleged offence, I voted today in favour of a report in Parliament to enable a transparent procedure.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the request for waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity, as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – We voted in favour of the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Costas Zarianopoulos (KKE) after the MEP mentioned also stated that he would vote in favour of the waiver of his immunity in order to clear the case.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this waiver of immunity. I believe that there is no reason to suspect that the intention underlying the proposed proceedings is to cause political damage to the MEP concerned. It is evident that the proposed proceedings do not concern opinions expressed or votes cast in the performance of the duties of the Member of the European Parliament in question and therefore a waiver is appropriate.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's decision on a request to lift Sotirios Zarianopoulos' immunity on the part of the alleged crime. Namely, it is an illegal issuance of permits of the Municipal Council in Thessaloniki, and Mr. Zarianopoulos is covered by the aforementioned procedure as a former member of the Municipal Council.  Since this criminal procedure is not related to the performance of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament and does not concern the expression of opinions or votes, I support this report which lifts Mr Zarianopoulos' immunity.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Sotirios Zarianopoulos' request for the lifting of immunity relates to the issuance in 2011 by the Local Council of Salonika of allegedly illegal authorizations to occupy the public domain for the purpose of installing terraces on pedestrian pathways. Sotirios Zarianopoulos is being prosecuted as a former member of this city council. This charge of prevarication concerns all municipal councillors who voted for the authorizations. As the matter was not a matter for him as a member of parliament, I voted to waive immunity.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting the immunity of my colleague, Mr Zarianopoulos, who is being prosecuted as part of an investigation into the granting of allegedly illegal authorisations to occupy public space. This case is unrelated to the mandate of the parliamentarian.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of waiving Mr Zarianopoulos' immunity. The facts he was accused of all happened before or outside his mandate, so that the waiver of his immunity did not hinder him from exercising his mandate.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to lift Mr. Zarianopoulos' parliamentary immunity because he is being prosecuted for acts (committed in 2011 as a member of a city council) that have nothing to do with his current duties. He agrees with that himself. It should be noted that I am the author of this report.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to lift sotirios Zarianopoulos' parliamentary immunity. The proposed prosecution is clearly unrelated to Sotirios Zarianopoulos' status as a Member of the European Parliament, but rather in relation to his previous mandate as a member of the Salonika City Council.  Nor does it concern an opinion or vote cast by the Member in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union.  There is thereby no reason to assume that the proposed prosecution would be motivated by the intention to interfere with the member's political activity, especially since the lawsuit concerned all members of the City Council at the time.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to lift Mr. Zarianopoulos' parliamentary immunity because he is being prosecuted for acts (committed in 2011 as a member of a city council) that have nothing to do with his current duties. He agrees with that himself. It should be noted that the rapporteur of this text is a Member of our ENL group, Gilles Lebreton.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 The current MEP of the Greek Communist Party is being charged in Greece for the alleged granting of illegal permits for the use of public property, for the establishment of rest zones on the streets of Thessaloniki when he was a councillor. Since the existence of fumus persecutionis cannot be considered to harm it politically, since the case is directed at all councillors at that time, and since Zarianopoulos himself expressed his willingness to have his parliamentary immunity withdrawn, I voted in favour of the lifting of it.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of waiver of Mr Zarianopoulos' immunity. His prosecution has nothing to do with the function of a Member, let his case be handled by the competent Greek authorities.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the prosecutor of the Greek Supreme Court has filed a request to waive the immunity of MEP Sotirios Zarianopoulos on account of his prosecution as a former member of the Thessaloniki City Council for allegedly illegally allowing the occupation of public space by thessaloniki city council. In accordance with the Rules of Procedure, the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the EU, and given that the investigation does not concern the statements, opinions and activities of p. Zarianopoulos, in the exercise of his mandate as an MEP, the EP decided to waive his immunity. I supported this proposal.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the request for waiver of the immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, following the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this request. Sotirios Zarianopoulos is being prosecuted as a former member of the Local Council of Salonika, concerning allegedly illegal authorizations to occupy the public domain. There is no link between these prosecutions and the parliamentary mandate of Sortirios Zarianopoulos. Furthermore, there is no reason to suggest that these prosecutions would be motivated by the desire to interfere with this Member's activity.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted to waive the immunity of a fellow KKE, S. Zarionopulos. We have already seen his case at the hearing of the Committee on Legal Affairs. After personal consultation with his office, I was informed that Comrade Zarianopulos himself wished to be deprived of his parliamentary immunity in order to defend himself properly and defend himself in proceedings before the national authorities. Because I wanted to comply with him, he voted to waive his immunity.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is about waiving the immunity of Mep Sotirios Zarianopoulos. Whether the conditions for doing so are met is a matter for the courts to assess. That is why I support this motion.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report calls for the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, a Greek Communist MP. The Greek authorities are considering prosecuting Sotirios Zarianopoulos for the issuance in 2011 by the Local Council of Salonika of allegedly illegal authorizations for the occupation of the public domain for the purpose of installing terraces on pedestrian pathways.  Sotirios Zarianopoulos is being prosecuted in his capacity as a former member of this city council, so the proposed prosecution is clearly unrelated to his status as a Member of the European Parliament.  Moreover, the prosecution does not concern an opinion or vote cast by the Member in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union.  I'm voting to lift immunity.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. There is no reason why the proposed prosecution should be inspired by the intention to interfere with the member's political activity, especially since the lawsuit concerned all members of the City Council at the time. So I voted to lift his immunity

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of the independence of the Mandate of the European Parliament is the responsibility of the European Parliament and that independence cannot be called into question. In accordance with Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. In this case the action brought is related to the attribution, in 2011, by the Municipality of Thessaloniki, of authorizations, allegedly illegal, of occupation of public space for the purpose of installing terraces in pedestrian areas and that Sotorios Zarianopoulos is accused in his capacity as former councillor of this municipality.  Thus, the action brought is in no way related to the status of a Member of the European Parliament of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, but which is instead related to his previous term as councillor of the Municipality of Thessaloniki. I therefore vote in favour of the request for waiver of immunity.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote in favour of the lifting of parliamentary immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, whose request was made by the prosecutor to the Greek Supreme Court following the issuance of allegedly illegal authorisations for occupation of the public domain for the purpose of the installation of terraces on pedestrian paths by Sotirios Zarianopoulos in his capacity as a former member of the municipal council.  Since the prosecution of Sotirios Zarianopoulos does not concern an opinion or vote cast by the Member in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union, the lifting of parliamentary immunity is recognised.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In his application of 28 March 2016, the Greek Attorney General requested the waived of the parliamentary immunity of Mep Sotirios Zarianopulos in connection with the investigation procedure for the alleged commission of an illegal act. The Greek authorities intend to prosecute Sotirios Zarianopoulos on charges that he did not comply with his legal obligations as a member of the Thessaloniki municipality in 2011. According to the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, it is clear that the proposed procedure is not related to the mandate of Sotirios Zarianopoulos as a Member of the European Parliament, but to his previous membership of the Thessaloniki Municipality, and there is no reason to believe that the underlying intention of the proposed procedure is to impede the political activities of the Member, if only because the procedure covers all persons who are members of the Thessaloniki Municipality during that period. The Committee therefore proposes that the European Parliament suspend the member's immunity. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The proposed lawsuit relates to the issuance in 2011 by the Salonika City Council of allegedly illegal authorizations to occupy the public domain for the purpose of installing terraces on pedestrian pathways. Sotirios Zarianopoulos is being prosecuted in his capacity as a former member of this municipal council, clearly unrelated to the status of a Member of the European Parliament, but rather in connection with his previous mandate as a member of the Municipal Council of Salonika.  Nor does it concern an opinion or a vote cast by the Member in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. There is thus no reason to assume that the proposed prosecution would be motivated by the intention to interfere with the member's political activity, especially since the lawsuit concerns all members of the City Council at the time against 34 municipal councillors who voted in favour. The lifting of immunity cannot therefore be opposed.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deserves my vote in favour, once all the legal procedures required have elapsed and, because the offence in question is not in any way related to the performance of the duties of a Member and because there is no evidence or suspicion that, at the origin of the criminal proceedings, the intention to harm the Member concerned is politically impaired.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Lebreton report concerns the prosecution of Mr. Zarianopoulos, a former member of the Salonika City Council accused of illegal occupation of the public domain for the purpose of installing terraces on pedestrian pathways.  As this prosecution is unrelated to its parliamentary activity, I decided to vote for this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the lifting of Mr Zarianopoulos' parliamentary immunity. Any request made to the President of the European Parliament by the authorities of a Member State to waive a Member's immunity is heard by the relevant Parliamentary Committee. I voted in accordance with the opinion of this committee.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The request for waiver of the immunity of Mr Sotirios was forwarded to the European Parliament by the Chief Prosecutor of the Hellenic Republic. He is accused of issuing illegal licences, which is therefore not related to his mandate in the European Parliament, but to his previous membership of the Thessaloniki Municipality. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report according to the evaluation made by the JURI Committee.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This relates to an MEP from the Greek Communist Party, Sotirios Zarianopoulos. The Greek authorities are proposing to prosecute him jointly with others in his capacity as a former member of Thessaloniki City Council for failing to comply with legal obligations. The case concerns the issuing in 2011 by Thessaloniki City Council of allegedly illegal permits to use public property for the purpose of setting up outside seating areas on pavements. Zarianopoulos himself informed MEPs that he would vote in favour of the report that will result in the waiving of his immunity. Because the proposed proceedings do not concern opinions expressed or votes cast in the performance of the duties as MEP, and the proceedings involve all those who were members of the city council at the time, I voted in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. In connection with the prosecution of offences in Thessaloniki, which the Public Prosecutor's Office is seeking, a request has been made for the waiver of parliamentary immunity. I voted in favour of the deprivation of liberty at the expense of Sotirios Zarianopoulos and Am in favour of waiving parliamentary immunity until this case is resolved and no more accusations are made.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted to uphold the waiver of immunity as Zarianopoulos was not fulfilling his role as a Member of the European Parliament: this incident took place when Zarianopoulos was a member of Thessaloniki City Council.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The proposed lawsuit relates to the issuance in 2011 by the Salonika City Council of allegedly illegal authorizations to occupy the public domain for the purpose of installing terraces on pedestrian pathways. Sotirios Zarianopoulos is being prosecuted as a former member of this city council.  The proposed prosecution is clearly unrelated to Sotirios Zarianopoulos' status as a Member of the European Parliament, but rather in relation to his previous mandate as a member of the Salonika City Council. Nor does it concern an opinion or vote cast by the Member in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union.  There is thus no reason to assume that the proposed prosecution would be motivated by the intention to interfere with the political activity of the Member (fumus persecutionis), especially since the prosecution concerned all members of the municipal council at the time (joint prevarication prosecutions (Article 13bis, 45 and 259 of the Penal Code) against 34 municipal councillors who voted for it. I therefore vote in favour of the report, which calls for the lifting of immunity.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 Since there is nothing to suggest that the criminal proceedings in the case were initiated with the intention of harming the political activities of members (fumus persecutionis), especially bearing in mind that all the members of the Municipal Council at the time were covered by this procedure, I support the decision to lift the immunity of my colleague Sotirios Zarianopoulos.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. On 28 March 2016, the Prosecutor before the Supreme Court of Justice of Greece requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos. The Greek judicial authorities accuse Zarianopoulos of, with alleged unlawfulness, granting authorisations to occupy public space for the purpose of installing terraces, while zarianopoulos exercised the mandate of councillor of the Municipality of Thessaloniki.  I believe that the action brought is not related to zarianopoulos' membership of the European Parliament, but rather to his previous term as a municipal councillor. In that sense, without antantiating or commending with any form of fumus persecutionis, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted to uphold the waiver of immunity as Zarianopoulos was not fulfilling his role as a Member of the European Parliament: this incident took place when Zarianopoulos was a member of Thessaloniki City Council.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. The Greek Supreme Court's Attorney General has requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, a Member of the European Parliament, as part of the initiation of an investigation into an alleged offence. The action brought relates to the attribution, in 2011, by the Municipality of Thessaloniki, of authorizations, allegedly illegal, of occupation of public space for the purpose of installing terraces in pedestrian areas and that Sotorios Zarianopoulos is accused in his capacity as former councillor of this municipality. Given that the judicial procedure does not concern opinions or votes cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament and that there is no reason to suppose that the intention underlying the legal action is to undermine the political activity of the Member, this request, which I voted in favour of, decides to lift the immunity of Mr Sotirios Zarianopoulos.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The action brought is not related to the status of Member of the European Parliament of Sotirios Zarianopoulos.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, in the light of the report prepared by the Committee on Legal Affairs, which finds that the prosecutor of the Greek Supreme Court has requested the suspension of the report in relation to facts that occurred in 2011 - allegedly illegal authorisations for the occupation of the public use area , for the installation of terraces on pedestrian roads carried out by the City Council of Thessaloniki, when Sotirios Zarianopoulos was a councillor of that City Council-, events that are unrelated to his status as a Member of the European Parliament

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting Mr. Sotirios Zarianopoulos, in order for the Greek justice system to carry out its work, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, on the understanding that the alleged facts (non-fulfilment of legal obligations in meetings and allegedly illegal authorisations to occupy the public domain for the purpose of installing terraces on pedestrian pathways) have no direct link with the office of MEP Of Mr Zariansopoulo , who was then a member of the local council of Salonika, and are not motivated by any desire to harm.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. In the light of the request made on 28 March 2016 by the Prosecutor of the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic to waive the immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, which relates to the proceedings which the Public Prosecutor intends to initiate in connection with the criminal offences committed in Thessaloniki, and Mr S.  When Zarianopoulos was given the opportunity to serve his version of events to an EP committee, the European Parliament decided to deprive the said Member of Parliament of its immunity.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of The Member of the European Parliament Sotirios Zarianopoulos. This is a request made by the Prosecutor of the Greek Supreme Court, which relates to a case relating to an alleged offence in which the MEP was involved in 2011 in the Municipality of Thessaloniki with regard to allegedly unlawful authorisations to occupy public space for the purpose of installing terraces in pedestrian areas when he held the post of Councillor of this Municipality. However, since this is conduct allegedly practised outside his mandate as an MEP, but with his previous term of office as Councillor of the Municipality of Thessaloniki and there being no reason to believe that there are other intentions underlying the legal action to prejudice political activity, I voted in favour of this request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity, in view of the verification of the conditions listed in Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the Union European.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity, as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 The current MEP of the Greek Communist Party is being charged in Greece for the alleged granting of illegal permits for the use of public property, for the establishment of rest zones on the streets of Thessaloniki when he was a councillor. Since the existence of fumus persecutionis cannot be considered to harm it politically, since the case is directed at all councillors at that time, and since Zarianopoulos himself expressed his willingness to have his parliamentary immunity withdrawn, I voted in favour of the lifting of it.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the Prosecutor of the Greek Supreme Court has requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Sotirios Zarianopoulos in connection with criminal proceedings in relation to an alleged offence. The planned prosecution concerns the issuance of an allegedly illegal permit to occupy public space by Thessaloniki City Council for the purpose of establishing terraces on pedestrian pavements, and since Soltirios Zarianopoulos is being prosecuted as a former member of that city council. Since the envisaged prosecution has no connection with sotirios Zarianopoulos's status as a Member of the European Parliament, but rather relates to his previous mandate as a member of the Thessaloniki City Council, we have decided, as MEPs, to waive the immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos so that suspicions in connection with criminal proceedings in relation to the alleged offence can be investigated.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 The activities of Members of the European Parliament which are not directly related to the exercise of their mandate, including decisions they have taken as members of local representative bodies, are always subject to review by the competent national authorities.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of waiving immunity because it is not a mandate-related issue.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The prosecutor at the Greek Supreme Court requested that MEP Sotirios Zarianopoulos be granted parliamentary immunity in connection with the planned criminal proceedings in relation to the Offences in Thessaloniki (CASE ABM A2015/1606) and published in plenary on 27 April 2016. I support the report on the request to lift Sotirios Zarianopoulos' immunity, as the criminal proceedings in question are in no way related to Sotirios Zarianopoulos' status as an MEP, but to his previous term as a member of the Thessaloniki Municipal Council.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We voted in favour of lifting immunity so that this person could explain himself before the courts of his country.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of waving the immunity of the Member of Parliament Sotirios Zarianopoulos, as requested by the public prosecutor at the Greek Supreme Court. The proposed proceedings concern the fact that in 2011, the Thessaloniki City Council, which Zarianopoulos was member of in that time, allegedly issued illegal permits to use public property for the purpose of setting up outside seating areas on pavements. The proposed proceedings are thus clearly unrelated to Sotirios Zarianopoulos’s status as a Member of the European Parliament. He should therefore not be granted the immunity provided by that position, but be prosecuted in his capacity as a former member of that city council.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
