text: Written. ‒ I supported the request for the waiver of the immunity of Representative Sotirios Zarianopoulus concerning the non-fulfilling of legal obligations at the meeting and the alleged illegal issuance of permits by the Municipal Council in Thessaloniki for the use of public areas in the form of the installation of terraces in the pedestrian zone.  Since the criminal proceedings at issue do not relate to the opinion expressed or the vote of members in the context of the performance of its duties as a Member of the European Parliament, it can be concluded that the proceedings were not initiated with the intention of harming the political action of the Member. This procedure covers all members of the Municipal Council at the time and I believe it is necessary to enable the competent institutions to conduct a full investigation in order to establish any liability for these acts.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for the waiver of immunity of Sotirios Zarianopulos because, in accordance with Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union, Members of the European Union enjoy in the territory of their State the immunity granted to members of the Parliament of that state and, in accordance with Article 62 of the Greek Constitution, members may not be subject to criminal proceedings against members during their term of office, deprived of their liberty, deprived of their liberty, and under Article 62 of the Greek Constitution, members of the Constitution may not be brought before members during their term of office, deprived of their liberty, deprived of their liberty. , to close them or otherwise withheld without the permission of the Chamber of Deputies.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity, as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the request forwarded by the Greek Attorney General on 28 March 2016 and notified in plenary on 27 April 2016, the Chief Prosecutor requests the waivey of the immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos in connection with the investigation procedure to be initiated by the Thessaloniki prosecutor in connection with the illegal act. In my decision, I followed the group's position.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity, as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the request for waiver of the immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos. The public prosecutor at the Greek Supreme Court has requested the waiver of the immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos MEP in connection with proceedings relating to an alleged offence. The proposed proceedings concern the issuing in 2011 by Thessaloniki City Council of allegedly illegal permits to use public property for the purpose of setting up outside seating areas on pavements, and Sotirios Zarianopoulos is to be prosecuted in his capacity as a former member of that city council. I voted in favour because I believe that the proposed proceedings are clearly unrelated to Sotirios Zarianopoulos’s status as a Member of the European Parliament, but are related to his former mandate as a member of Thessaloniki City Council.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Greek Supreme Court Prosecutor has requested the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, who is a Member of the Greek Communist Party in the European Parliament.  The action brought relates to the allocation, in 2011, by the Municipality of Thessaloniki, of allegedly unlawful authorisations for the occupation of public space for the purpose of installing terraces in pedestrian areas and that Sotorios Zarianopoulos is accused, in his capacity as former councillor of this municipality, of helping this situation. It is considered that there is no reason to suspect that the intention underlying the criminal proceedings is to harm the political activity of the deputy, all the more so since the said action involves all those who, at the time, were councilors of the municipality.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion because the events took place before or outside his position as an MEP.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ Many times a request is made to the plenary of the European Parliament to waive the immunity of Members of the European Parliament on the basis of various facts. My view on these reports is that, as regards the request for waiver of immunity as a result of an act that took place at a time when the Member concerned was already a member of the European Parliament and at the same time the act in question took place in connection with the exercise of his mandate (for example, concerning his statements in plenary), parliamentary immunity should not be waived. However, as regards events unrelated to the exercise of a Member of the European Parliament's mandate or occurred before a Member took up his mandate, I see no reason to vote against such a request. I believe that the rules are sufficiently clear in the case of waiver of members' immunity, which is why, even in this case , as on the basis of the information available, events are not related to the exercise of a parliamentary mandate, I voted in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. As is clear from the report, criminal proceedings are not related to the status of Sotirios Zarianopoulos as a Member of the European Parliament, but to his previous term as a member of the Municipal Council of the City of Thessaloniki, and I therefore support the request for waiver of the immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the negotiations imposed by the World Trade Organisation, the following changes were made to the EU-China tariff framework: an increase in the tariff quota for certain food products and a reduction in tariff rates for other categories of products such as footwear and split systems. Since this agreement is necessary for the adjustment of the tariff framework, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We abstained on this as it was merely a technical update to reflect the fact that Croatia has joined the EU since the original agreement was signed with China.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. Following Croatia's accession, the EU had to renegotiate tariffs with China in accordance with the rules of the World Trade Organisation. While China makes no concessions, the European Commission has once again had to give in on tariffs and quotas.  I therefore opposed this agreement because it is an unbalanced relationship in which the EU and France lose out.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which will slightly amend quotas on trade with China following the accession of Croatia to the EU without affecting the Irish economy. Under the WTO rules, the EU has to negotiate with its trade partners new conditions due to the accession of Croatia to the EU. The Commission negotiated new conditions on industrial goods – slightly lower EU tariffs on footwear and air-conditioners. On agriculture quotas, the Commission will propose a regulation to increase the tonnage allocation for garlic and mushrooms from China (while maintaining the same percentage).

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this technical report, which aims to conclude the EU-China agreement, taking into account Croatia's accession to the EU, in accordance with WTO requirements. The Commission has negotiated with China the issue of withdrawing specific concessions related to the withdrawal of Croatia's annex as part of its EU membership. These negotiations resulted in a draft agreement in the form of an exchange of letters, which was signed on 7 October 2015. The agreement must now be concluded.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of an Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the People's Republic of China, as the agreement includes proportionate amendments to concessions and is in line with previous WTO practice and framework.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a recommendation of a proposal by the Council to grant the conclusion of the agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and the People's Republic of China under Article XXIV, paragraph 6, and Article XXVIII of the 1994 General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) on the modification of concessions in the Republic of Croatia's list of commitments , as part of its accession to the European Union. Following Croatia's accession, the EU had to renegotiate tariff agreements with China in accordance with WTO rules. As a result, the European Commission has made several concessions on tariffs and quotas: shoes, air conditioning, garlic, mushrooms. China has made no concessions. As EU tariffs on China are already very unfavourable (France's foreign trade with China is very loss-making), this new list of concessions is not welcome. This type of relationship is not balanced. That is why I objected to this report.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation because with the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union has expanded its customs union. Therefore, it was required, under World Trade Organization (WTO) rules (Article XXIV, paragraph 6, of the 1994 GATT), to open negotiations with WTO members with negotiating rights with respect to Croatia's list of commitments in order to eventually agree on compensation.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. The EU Customs Union has expanded following the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. The European Union was therefore obliged, in accordance with World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, to open negotiations with wto negotiating members on croatia's tariff list with a view to finally agreeing a compensatory settlement. Such adjustment is mandatory if, following the adoption of the EU's external tariff regime, customs tariffs increase compared to the duties for which the acceding country has committed itself to the WTO. I support this recommendation that this agreement be concluded on behalf of the Union with the People's Republic of China.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this as it was merely a technical update to reflect the fact that Croatia has joined the EU since the original agreement was signed with China.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Following Croatia's accession, the EU had to renegotiate tariff agreements with China in accordance with WTO rules. The European Commission has made several concessions on tariffs and quotas; on the other hand, China has not done anything, even though the EU's tariffs on China are very favourable to China. That is why I consider that this list of new concessions is not welcome, especially since the Commission has no plans to protect us from Chinese dumping: next December, 15 years after its accession to the WTO, China will indeed be automatically granted market economy status...

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this report on the Council's proposed decision authorising the conclusion of the agreement in the form of letter exchanges between the EU and China under certain provisions of the GATT concerning the modification of concessions in Croatia's list of commitments in the context of its accession to the Union.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. As a result of Croatia's accession to the European Union and due to WTO rules, the Union must negotiate with the remaining WTO members who have negotiating rights on Croatia's tariff list.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Winkler report, a technical measure approving the EU-China agreement that allows the Asian country to see its trade rights re-established, slightly reduced following the enlargement of the EU Customs Union for Croatia's accession in July 2013. World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules have required the Eu ropean Union to enter into negotiations with WTO member countries, which have negotiating rights linked to Croatia's tariff list, with a view to agreeing a compensatory adjustment.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report necessary to formalise Croatia's access to the European Union.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. The adoption of this report is consistent and as a result of Croatia's accession to the European Union. With this entry, the Union has expanded its customs union and it is appropriate, in accordance with WTO rules, to negotiate on the tariff list of this Republic of the Union. In this case with respect to the People's Republic of China.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which aims to take into account Croatia's accession to the EU in the context of tariff agreements with China. If at first glance this text could be regarded as a mere legal compliance aimed at taking Croatia into account in the agreements, it turns out that the EU took the opportunity to renegotiate the so-called agreements with the Chinese power, in a sense eminently unfavourable to European countries. The EU has accepted multiple concessions, and on tariffs, and on quotas, particularly on shoes, but also on food products such as garlic or mushrooms. The Chinese giant, meanwhile, has not admitted any compromises. Even though France's foreign trade is already in deficit with China, these new concessions risk exacerbating the imbalance in our trade balance. As usual, the fact that the EU is responsible for trade policy for all its Member States does not allow us to defend our economic and strategic interests.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Winkler report analyses the AGREEMENT between the EU and China to compensate for its trade preferences with Croatia prior to its accession to the EU. Although there are no direct consequences for the Italian production sector, I believe that the EU should provide greater protection for its internal market vis-à-vis China, which is continually proving to be an extremely fierce trading competitor, always ready to put in place unfair competition practices in order to gain market share at the expense of the quality production of our territories. That is why I voted against this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting approval for the conclusion of the Agreement between the Union and China on the amendment of concessions to Croatia's WTO tariff list as a result of its accession to the Union. With Croatia's accession, the Union has expanded its customs union. Accordingly, in accordance with WTO rules, the Union is required to enter into negotiations with WTO members who have negotiating rights on Croatia's tariff list to agree on a countervailing adjustment. Thus, the Commission has negotiated with WTO members, in this case China, who have negotiating rights with respect to the abolition of specific concessions in relation to the withdrawal of Croatia's tariff list for their entry into the Union.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it seeks harmonisation of EU legislation. With this report, Parliament approves the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the People's Republic of China concerning the 1994 General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) on the modification of concessions in the schedules of the Republic of Croatia in the context of its accession to the European Union.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Customs Union of the European Union was enlarged. Consequently, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union is obliged to enter into negotiations with wto member states for which Croatia has so far held a so-called concession tariff wall. This will be necessary if, as a result of accession to the Union tariff system, the increase in the tariff level for this reason exceeds the level agreed by the acceding country in the WTO. The mandate to open negotiations was given to the Commission by the Council on 15 July 2013, which is based on Article XXIV(6) of the GATT. As a result of these negotiations, the Commission proposed to sign the Agreement on behalf of the Union. In view of the above, I voted in favour of Parliament's agreement on the draft Council Decision.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this recommendation, which is technical in nature. It aims to conclude a treaty between the EU and China, taking into account Croatia's accession to the EU and adjustments to customs tariffs, as well as WTO requirements.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Following Croatia's accession, the EU had to renegotiate tariff agreements with China in accordance with WTO rules and the Commission made a number of concessions (shoes, garlic, mushrooms) while China made none. Considering an unbalanced and damaging relationship for France, I voted against this text.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is right that the Republic of Croatia, now that it is fully part of the European Union, should also participate in the trade agreements that the EU signs with foreign states. We consider this to be a due act.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Following Croatia's accession, the European Union renegotiated tariff agreements with China in accordance with World Trade Organization (WTO) rules. It is in this context that the European Commission has granted China, without the slightest reciprocity, new tariff concessions, including imports of shoes, air conditioning equipment, garlic or mushrooms.  Instead of introducing intelligent protectionism to combat China's social and environmental dumping, the European Union prefers to grant it new tariff concessions that will strengthen the current account deficit of the Member States. With the same causes having the same effects, this crazy trade policy will help accelerate the deindustrialization that has plagued Western countries since the early 1980s, resulting in the destruction of thousands of jobs in the commercial sector.  That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Agreement between the European Union and China aims to amend tariff concessions related to Croatia's accession to the Union. Given that the European Union has expanded its customs union with the accession of the Republic of Croatia, it becomes mandatory to initiate negotiations with the members of the World Trade Organisation on the Tariff of Croatia precisely in order to reach an agreement on compensatory adjustment. This compensation agreement is evidence of the Union's attachment to the multilateral rules-based trade regime, once again being marked the primacy of the purpose of the establishment of customs unions and free trade zones. I welcome the agreement reached with the People's Republic of China on the amendment of tariff concessions related to Croatia's accession to the European Union because I believe that this Agreement contains amendments proportionate to the concessions and is in line with previous practice.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation today because I think it is right that trade rights should be restored to the People's Republic of China. These, in fact, following the enlargement of the EU customs union, with the accession of Croatia, have been reduceed to some. World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, in particular Article XXIV(6) of GATT 1994, require the European Union to open negotiations with WTO member countries with the negotiating rights linked to Croatia's tariff list, in order to allow for a compensatory adjustment. This adjustment is necessary if the adoption of the EU's external tariff regime results in a higher increase in duties than the level at which the acceding country has committed itself in the light of the WTO framework. In order to compensate for the losses, the Commission has identified two particular measures for the Chinese products concerned: the first provides for an increase in the tariff quota and the second, instead, aims at reducing consolidated tariff rates.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which will slightly amend quotas on trade with China following the accession of Croatia to the EU without affecting the Irish economy. Under the WTO rules, the EU has to negotiate with its trade partners new conditions due to the accession of Croatia to the EU. The Commission negotiated new conditions on industrial goods – slightly lower EU tariffs on footwear and air-conditioners. On agriculture quotas, the Commission will propose a regulation to increase the tonnage allocation for garlic and mushrooms from China (while maintaining the same percentage).

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ As a consequence of the accession of Croatia, the customs union of the EU has grown and consequently in line with WTO rules, the EU had to enter into negotiations with other WTO members, in this particular case, China, having negotiated rights related to the tariff schedule of Croatia. I give my consent to the proposal to conclude the Agreement as it includes proportionate modifications to the concessions and is consistent with earlier practice and WTO framework. It has also taken note of the Commission reports stating that the relevant compensatory adjustments to China are proportionate and do not exceed China’s rights as affected by the withdrawal of Croatia’s concessions to China.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following negotiations on Croatia's accession to the European Union, and related concessions, the trade agreement with China has undergone changes with regard to trade in certain products. The report aims to approve these amendments, which do not raise any problems. I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We welcome the agreement with the People's Republic of China and believe that the latter is entitled to restore its previous trading rights, which have been slightly limited by the enlargement of the EU customs union with the accession of Croatia.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China amending the concessions provided for in the table of the Republic of Croatia in the context of its accession to the European Union is a positive step and as such procedures favour the smooth development of the accession path, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with the economic principles that have animated the spirit of the European Union since its inception, I very much welcome the trade agreement reached with China on Croatia's accession. The negotiations, which began on 7 October 2015, were successfully concluded as a demonstration of the excellent relations enjoyed by European diplomacy with the People's Republic of China. I hope that, by virtue of this type of agreement, we will be able to achieve a better degree of international cooperation and economic integration that will reflect on the well-being of their peoples.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the EU-China Agreement relating to the accession of Croatia and noted no objections.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Eu ropean Union customs union has expanded and negotiations have therefore begun with some partners of the World Trade Organisation, including China, to define a compensatory adjustment of the tariff regime. I voted in favour of the agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China, because its aim is to facilitate and regularise trade, avoiding the emergence of obstacles to Community trade with third countries. This compensation agreement represents the European Union's commitment to the promotion of a multilateral trade regime, based on clear rules compatible with the regulatory system of the World Trade Organisation.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In line with my previous opposition to the EU-China Agreement on the World Trade Organization for its defence and promotion of a neoliberal model of international trade, I have also voted against Croatia's accession to it.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, the latter expanded its customs union, which led to an increase in tariffs above the level that the accession country has committed to comply with. I voted to reduce the current strengthened EU tax to support economic stabilisation. The compensatory adjustments to China are proportionate and do not go beyond China's rights affected by the withdrawal of concessions from Croatia.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Customs Union of the European Union has been enlarged. As a result, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the EU is obliged to enter into negotiations with wto member states for which Croatia has so far had a so-called concession tariff list. This will be necessary if, as a result of accession to the Union tariff system, the increase in the tariff level for this reason exceeds that undertaken by the acceding country in the WTO. The mandate to open negotiations was given to the Commission by the Council on 15 July 2013. As a result of these negotiations, the Commission proposed to sign the Agreement on behalf of the Union. I voted in favour of Parliament's agreement on the draft Council decision.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I fully support the agreements with the Chinese Republic relating to Croatia's accession to the structures of the European Union, which has directly affected the enlargement of the customs union. I welcomed the news that the EU has started negotiations with WTO members to agree on price equalisation, to reduce current EU tariffs on footwear and window or wall air conditioners, and to increase import quotas for garlic and mushrooms. In my opinion, if we want the customs union to work smoothly, we should vote in favour, which I have also done.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-China Agreement relating to the accession of Croatia as I believe that the trading rights should be restored. This fullfills the purpose of a customs union as rightly outlined in GATT.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement; as an important actor in global trade it is important that the EU continues to set an example in abiding by WTO rules and adopts a flexible approach in trade negotiations with third countries, particularly with growing markets such as China.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In today's plenary I voted in favour of the draft resolution in question, which, being strictly technical in nature, aims to define the agreement with China on the modification of concessions on Croatia's list, in view of croatia's accession to the EU.  Following the acquisition of the European membership of the Republic of Croatia, the EU has further expanded the customs union. This involved opening negotiations with the member countries of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) with negotiating rights in relation to Croatia's tariff list in order to agree on a compensatory adjustment, including China. By adopting this measure, the European Parliament is therefore helping to ensure the certainty and consistency of the rules on trade with third countries.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report presents the European Parliament's recommendation on the protocol for updating the EU-China agreement following Croatia's accession to the European Union and deals with possible compensation to the EU partner country as long as the EU expands its market to a new member. The rapporteur proposes to support the Commission's proposal for this negotiation. Considering that the enlargement of the single market is changing the conditions of trade with partner countries, and that these conditions need to be redefined, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this as it was merely a technical update to reflect the fact that Croatia has joined the EU since the original agreement was signed with China.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The adoption of this text allows the conclusion of the agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and China under the 1994 General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) on the modification of concessions in Croatia's list of commitments as part of its accession to the European Union. I voted in favour of this text in order to take into account the fact that, with Croatia's accession, the European Union has expanded its customs union, which obliges us to adjust our trade agreements accordingly.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union has renegotiated its tariffs with China following Croatia's accession. While the European Union's foreign trade is already largely in deficit with China, this renegotiation acts a new round of concessions. The ENF group denounces this unbalanced trade relationship, which does not correspond in any way to French economic interests. So I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation on the EU-China agreement on croatia's accession. This technical report reflects the need to bring the agreement after Croatia's accession to the EU and the enlargement of the customs union. This update concerns the reduction of European duties on certain product types and an increase in the import quota for other agricultural products.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This agreement will result in the restoration of the previous trading rights of the People's Republic of China, which were limited by the enlargement of the EU customs union with the accession of Croatia. In other words, the galloping growth of China's highly competitive (for European economies) economy will be further strengthened.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Customs Union of the European Union was enlarged. Consequently, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union is obliged to enter into negotiations with wto member states for which Croatia has so far held a so-called concession tariff wall. This will be necessary if, as a result of accession to the Union tariff system, the increase in the tariff level for this reason exceeds the level agreed by the acceding country in the WTO. The mandate to open negotiations was given to the Commission by the Council on 15 July 2013, which is based on Article XXIV(6) of the GATT. As a result of these negotiations, the Commission proposed to sign the Agreement on behalf of the Union. In view of the above, I voted in favour of Parliament's agreement on the draft Council Decision.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union has extended its customs union. It was for the European Union to open negotiations with WTO members who hold negotiating rights related to Croatia's customs tariff in order to agree on any compensatory adjustment. Such adjustment is necessary if the adoption of the EU external tariff regime results in an increase in customs duties exceeding the level to which the acceding country has been linked within the WTO. I believe that the European Parliament should approve the agreement because the People's Republic of China is entitled to the re-establishment of its previous trade rights, which have suffered a slight degradation due to the extension of the customs union when Croatia accession to the Union.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: EU tariffs on China are already very unfavourable (France's foreign trade with China is also very loss-making), this new list of concessions is not welcome. This type of relationship is not balanced.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union has extended its customs union. Consequently, in accordance with world trade organisation (WTO) rules [Article XXIV(6) of gatt 1994], it was for the EU to open negotiations with WTO members who hold negotiating rights related to Croatia's customs tariff in order to agree on any compensatory adjustment. On 15 July 2013 the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations pursuant to Article XXIV(6) of gatt 1994. The Commission has negotiated with WTO members who hold negotiating rights the issue of the withdrawal of specific concessions arising from the withdrawal of the customs tariff of the Republic of Croatia in the context of croatia's accession to the EU. Despite the eminently technical nature of this report, our position is inextled by the principled position on the grounds for its need, which highlight the EU's exclusive competence in the field of trade policy conferred on it by the Treaty of Lisbon. We believe that countries should be able to establish, in full, the trade agreements they sovereignly understand.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation as I approve of the proposal for the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the amendment of concessions on the list of the Republic of Croatia in the context of its accession to the European Union. This agreement provides for appropriate changes to concessions and is consistent with the line taken in previous cases and with the Framework of the World Trade Organisation (WTO).

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \u2012 In this particular case, this is an agreement of a purely technical nature. Its main objective is to conclude an agreement between the European Union and China, taking into account Croatia's accession to the European Union, in line with world trade organisation requirements. The European Commission has negotiated with China the issue of the abolition of special concessions in connection with the completion of Croatia's accession plan to the European Union.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation as I have never been in favour of trade preferences towards China.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the EU-China agreement on Croatia's accession, as this agreement will result in the restoration of the previous trading rights of the People's Republic of China, which have been limited by the enlargement of the EU customs union with the accession of Croatia. In other words, the galloping growth of China's highly competitive (for European economies) economy will be further strengthened.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a file of technical nature. It aims to conclude the EU-China agreement, taking into account the accession of Croatia to the EU, as per the WTO requirements. The Commission has negotiated with China the issue of the withdrawal of specific concessions in relation to the withdrawal of the schedule of Croatia in the course of its accession to the EU. These negotiations resulted in a draft Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters that was initialled on 7 October 2015. It is now appropriate to conclude the Agreement. No amendments were tabled in the Committee on International Trade (INTA). I support the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Customs Union of the European Union was enlarged. Consequently, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union is obliged to enter into negotiations with wto member states for which Croatia has so far held a so-called concession tariff list. This will be necessary if, as a result of accession to the Union tariff system, the increase in the tariff level for this reason exceeds the level agreed by the acceding country in the WTO. The mandate to open negotiations was given to the Commission by the Council on 15 July 2013, which is based on Article XXIV(6) of the GATT. As a result of these negotiations, the Commission proposed to sign the Agreement on behalf of the Union. In view of the above, I voted in favour of Parliament's agreement on the draft Council Decision.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation. With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Customs Union of the European Union was enlarged. Consequently, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union was obliged to enter into negotiations with WTO members which have negotiating rights in respect of Croatia's concession lists in order to establish a possible compensatory adjustment. This adjustment had to be made as the increase in tariff levels resulting from the takeover of the EU external tariff system exceeds the level agreed by Croatia in the WTO. After the Commission has proposed to sign the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters with China on behalf of the Union, Parliament should also give its consent. The People's Republic of China has the right to restore its former trade rights after being somewhat eroded as a result of the expansion of the EU customs union following Croatia's accession to the EU. The Commission did the right thing by pro proposeing, as a means of compensating for the Chinese products concerned, 1) an increase in tariff quotas and 2) a reduction in the current fixed tariffs to offset losses.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. Accordingly, in accordance with World Trade Organization rules, the European Union is required to enter into negotiations with WTO members who have negotiating rights on Croatia's tariff list to finally agree on a countervailing adjustment.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and the People's Republic of China, in accordance with Article XXIV(6) and Article XXVIII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) 1994, on the amendment of concessions in the list of the Republic of Croatia in the context of its accession to the European Union. The EU, with the accession of Croatia, has in fact expanded its customs union and it has therefore become necessary to make a compensatory adjustment with the Member States of the MGO which have negotiating rights. I therefore believe that China has the right to have its trade rights recognised proportionally, reduced as a result of Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the EU-China Agreement on Croatia's accession to the EU, as it is a technical update of an important agreement following Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report necessary to formalise Croatia's access to the European Union.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the People's Republic of China pursuant to Article XXIV(6) and Article XXVIII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) of 1994 relating to amendments to the Concession Lists of the Republic of Croatia following its accession to the European Union. The accession of the Republic of Croatia resulted in the enlargement of the customs union by the European Union, and this in turn made the European Union obliged to open negotiations with WTO members who have negotiating rights in the scope of Croatia's concession list, in order to agree on the compensation that is due if the adoption of the EU's external tariff system increases rates above the level to which the acceding state has committed itself within the WTO.  In my opinion, the European Parliament should give its consent to this agreement, as it restores to the People's Republic of China trade rights, which have been restricted as a result of the enlargement of the EU customs union following croatia's accession.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the conclusion of this agreement. Under WTO rules China has the right to have its previous trading rights restored, following their slight erosion due to the enlargement of the EU Customs Union with Croatian EU accession.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. I welcome the Agreement with the People’s Republic of China and believe the European Parliament should give its consent. The People’s Republic of China has the right to have its previous trading rights restored, following their slight erosion due to the enlargement of the EU Customs Union with Croatian EU accession.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – The accession of the Republic of Croatia has resulted in the enlargement of the Customs Union of the European Union. The European Union was therefore obliged under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules to negotiate with WTO members who have negotiating rights on Croatia's tariff table in order to finally reach agreement on a compensatory adjustment. In this context, the Commission proposes to the Council that the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters with the People's Republic of China be signed on behalf of the Union. At the same time, a separate proposal for the conclusion of this Agreement is also submitted to the Council. We voted in favour of the proposal because the report was balanced.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this EU-China agreement. The People’s Republic of China has the right to have its previous trading rights restored, following the slight erosion due to the enlargement of the EU customs union with Croatian EU accession. The purpose of a customs union or of a free-trade area should be to facilitate trade between the constituent territories and not to raise barriers to the trade of other contracting parties with such territories. This compensatory agreement can therefore be seen as yet another sign of the EU’s attachment to the multilateral rules-based trading regime, with the world trade organisation at its centre.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ After the EU enlarged its customs union with the accession of Croatia, it was required to negotiate the tariff schedule of Croatia with WTO members for a possible compensatory adjustment. Negotiations with China focused on lower EU duties on footwear and air conditioning machines and higher import quotas of garlic and mushrooms. My group and I are strong supporters of trade, and we have therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Customs Union of the European Union was enlarged. Consequently, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union is obliged to enter into negotiations with wto member states in which Croatia has so far held a so-called concession tariff wall. This will be necessary if, as a result of accession to the Union tariff system, the increase in the tariff level for this reason exceeds that undertaken by the acceding country in the WTO. On 15 July 2013, the Council gave the Commission the necessary set-up for the opening of negotiations, a mandate based on Article XXIV(6) of the GATT. As a result of these negotiations, the Commission proposed to sign the Agreement on behalf of the Union. In view of the above, I voted in favour of Parliament's agreement on the draft Council Decision.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union enlarged its Customs Union with the accession of Croatia. This file aims to conclude the EU-China agreement, taking into account the accession of Croatia to the EU, as is required under WTO rules.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒I voted to recommend the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and the People's Republic of China in accordance with Article XXIV paragraph 6 and Article XXVIII. The 1994 General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) regarding the amendment of preferences on the List of the Republic of Croatia as part of its accession to the European Union, as I believe that the proposal for the inclusion of the Agreement should be supported as it contains proportionate amendments to the preferences and is in line with earlier wto practice and framework.   It took into account Commission reports leading the relevant compensatory adjustments to China to be proportionate and did not exceed Chinese rights affected by the abolition of Croatian preferences to China. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade rightly stresses that the purpose of the Customs Union or the free trade area should be to 'facilitate trade between stand-alone areas and not to raise barriers to trade between other Member States and those areas'.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is an update of tariff agreements, in accordance with WTO rules. The EU had to renegotiate its position with China following Croatia's accession.  For example, the European Commission has made several concessions on tariffs and quotas (shoes, air conditioning, garlic, mushrooms), while China has made no concessions. I voted against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Following the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the EU customs union expanded and a compensatory settlement with the members of the World Trade Organisation had to be negotiated, as the EU's external tariff led to an increase in customs duties. I decided to support the resolution on the conclusion of the agreement with China, because this settlement is not only proportionate, but also in line with previous WTO practice and framework and the EU's efforts to comply with the rules of the multilateral trade regime.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Iuliu Winkler's report on Croatia's accession to the EU-China agreement. The agreement with China that was concluded in 2015 is mainly about trade arrangements. It is normal and necessary that these arrangements should now be extended to Croatia following its accession to the customs union. A decision that satisfies me and that goes in the direction of a stronger internal market.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes into account Croatia's accession under the agreement between the European Union and China. With Croatia's accession, the EU has expanded its customs union. As a result, Croatia was required, under WTO rules, to open negotiations with WTO members with negotiating rights in order to eventually agree on compensation.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this agreement as it merely modifies the existing rules with regard to Croatia's accession to the EU and does not involve any substantial changes.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the conclusion of this agreement. Under WTO rules China has the right to have its previous trading rights restored, following their slight erosion due to the enlargement of the EU Customs Union with Croatian EU accession.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Customs Union of the European Union was enlarged. Consequently, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union is obliged to enter into negotiations with wto member states for which Croatia has so far held a so-called concession tariff list. This will be necessary if, as a result of accession to the Union tariff system, the increase in the tariff level for this reason exceeds that undertaken by the acceding country in the WTO. On 15 July 2013, the Council gave the Commission the necessary set-up for the opening of negotiations, a mandate based on Article XXIV(6) of the GATT. As a result of these negotiations, the Commission proposed to sign the Agreement on behalf of the Union. In view of the above, I voted in favour of Parliament's agreement on the draft Council Decision.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for an agreement with the People's Republic of China on the amendment of concessions in the List of the Republic of Croatia in the process of its accession to the European Union, as it is in line with EU practice in previous enlargements and in accordance with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). I support the compensatory adjustments provided for by the Commission for China in relation to losses from the withdrawal of concessions by Croatia, as they are proportionate and in line with previous PRACTICES within the FRAMEWORK of the WORLD.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ With Croatia’s accession on 1 July 2013, the EU enlarged its customs union. The European Parliament gave its consent to the compensatory agreement with the People’s Republic of China and I supported the resolution. The agreement will respect the trading rights of the People’s Republic of China and on the other hand is a sign of the EU’s attachment to the WTO’s multilateral rules-based trading regime. The compensatory agreement will enable Croatia to benefit fully from trade relations between the EU and the People’s Republic of China (EU and China now trade well over EUR 1 billion a day). Last but not least, the compensatory agreement could serve as a basis and a proof that China meets its WTO obligations and trades.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. This report analyses the agreement negotiated between the EU and China on Croatia's accession. With this agreement, the EU has enlarged its customs union, providing for the possibility of starting negotiations with WTO members, who have the right to negotiate in accordance with Croatia's tariff. The aim is to agree on a compensatory adjustment. In turn, this adjustment will become necessary if the adoption of the EU's external tariff regime results in an increase in duties above the level to which the acceding country has committed itself within the framework of the WTO.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it grants additional concessions to China. This is further evidence of the EU's irresponsibility.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the EU-China agreement on Croatia's accession. Following Croatia's accession, the EU had to renegotiate tariff agreements with China in accordance with WTO rules. As a result, the European Commission has made several concessions on tariffs and quotas (shoes, air conditioning, garlic, mushrooms.  China has made no concessions. As EU tariffs on China are already very unfavourable (France's foreign trade with China is very loss-making), this new list of concessions is not welcome. This type of relationship is not balanced.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. Indeed, following Croatia's accession to the European Union, The European Union had to renegotiate tariff agreements with China, in accordance with rules set out by the World Trade Organization (WTO). Not surprisingly, the European Commission has made several concessions on tariffs and exchange quotas (shoes, air conditioning, garlic, mushrooms, etc.).  Not surprisingly, China has made no concessions. The customs barriers between the EU and China were already largely unfavourable to us. This series of new agreements will therefore accentuate the deficit balance of our foreign trade with that country. Therefore, I could not agree with such a text.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting approval for the conclusion of the Agreement between the Union and China on the amendment of concessions to Croatia's WTO tariff list as a result of its accession to the Union. With Croatia's accession, the Union has expanded its customs union. Accordingly, in accordance with WTO rules, the Union is required to enter into negotiations with WTO members who have negotiating rights on Croatia's tariff list to agree on a countervailing adjustment. Thus, the Commission has negotiated with WTO members, in this case China, who have negotiating rights with respect to the abolition of specific concessions in relation to the withdrawal of Croatia's tariff list for their entry into the Union.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In line with my previous opposition to the EU-China Agreement on the World Trade Organization for its defence and promotion of a neoliberal model of international trade, I have also voted against Croatia's accession to it.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of modernising EU concessions with China to take into account the most recent enlargement to included Croatia in the Union.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. I do not object to Croatia's allocation to the agreement with China, which increases the relevant import quotas in connection with the enlargement of the EU to Croatia.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this report is to conclude an Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and China pursuant to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade relating to the modification of concessions in the schedule of Croatia in the course of its accession to the European Union. I support the position of Parliament to give its consent to the conclusion of the Agreement.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the European Parliament has approved the conclusion of an agreement reducing the contractual tariffs fixed in the Common Customs Tariff for selected industrial products in the context of Croatia's accession to the Union and adjusting quotas for selected agricultural products from China. The proposal is in line with WTO rules and the interests of the Parties in balanced mutual trade.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision concerning the conclusion of an Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the People's Republic of China, in accordance with Article XXIV(6) and Article XXVIII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GSP) of 1994 amending the concessions provided for in the Table of the Republic of Croatia in the context of its accession to the European Union , because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. The European Union has renegotiated its tariffs with China following Croatia's accession. While the European Union's foreign trade is already largely in deficit with China, this renegotiation acts a new round of concessions. The ENF group denounces this unbalanced trade relationship, which does not correspond in any way to French economic interests.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. – Croatia is the youngest member of the European Union. Even though the country’s economy has not reached the successful levels of those belonging to other Member States, Croatia is located in a strategic geographical position that can be beneficial to foreign investors. The EU’s greatest trading partners, China included, should not underestimate Croatia’s potential and capability. As stated in the report, Croatia needs to make some major changes to adapt its economy to the EU, but as a bloc, we will make sure that the country has all the necessary instruments to achieve the following goal.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. The Aim of the Winkler Report was to convey to the Council the Recommendations of the European Parliament on the approach to adjust, following Croatia's accession to the European Union, the concessions offered to China by the EU in the WTO. If it foreshadows the type of adjustments (reverses) that the EU will have to make following Brexit, the issue is mainly technical since it is a matter of changing, according to established practice, tariffs on industrial products and quotas on agricultural products, in proportion to the size of the Croatian market, to take account of the enlargement of the European single market. The changes are minor: tariffs on entering the European market for rubber shoes from China will increase from 17 to 16.9%. Similarly, China will have the opportunity to export an additional 650 tonnes of mushrooms to Europe. I voted for this report because I do not think it is appropriate to engage in an unnecessary confrontation with China. On the other hand, I will continue to fight at parliamentary level for the European Union to increase its tariffs on the dumped products that Beijing dumps in Europe: steel, ceramics, chemicals, paper, etc.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union expanded its customs union. Under the agreement, the Commission will harmonise tariffs by means of an implementing regulation and adjust commodity quotas. I am in favour of that.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. The EU Customs Union has expanded following the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. The European Union was therefore obliged, in accordance with World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules (Article XXIV(6) of GATT 1994), to open negotiations with wto negotiating members on croatia's tariff schedule with a view to finally agreeing a compensatory adjustment. Such adjustment is mandatory if, following the adoption of the EU's external tariff regime, customs tariffs increase compared to the duties for which the acceding country has committed itself to the WTO.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The People's Republic of China and the EU had customs agreements for the export and import of certain goods, agreed under the WTO's General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). Following Croatia's accession in July 2013, these quotas and tariff quotas must be adapted to a 28-state Union. That is what this decision proposes. I am not only opposed to these latest waves of enlargement but also to the FREE trade model of the WTO. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. As EU tariffs on China are already very unfavourable (France's foreign trade with China is very loss-making), this new list of concessions runs counter to our interests. This type of relationship is not balanced and in fact damaging. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union has extended its customs union. Consequently, in accordance with world trade organisation (WTO) rules [Article XXIV(6) of gatt 1994], it was for the European Union to open negotiations with WTO members who hold negotiating rights relating to croatia's customs tariff in order to agree on any compensatory adjustment. Such adjustment is necessary if the adoption of the EU external tariff regime results in an increase in customs duties exceeding the level to which the acceding country has been linked within the WTO. The People's Republic of China is entitled to the re-establishment of its previous trade rights, which have suffered a slight degradation due to the extension of the customs union when Croatia's accession to the Union. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it is important that Croatia, the newest member of our Customs Union, is included in existing conventions and agreements.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. On 1 July 2013, the Republic of Croatia became the 28th Member State of the European Union. At the same time, the European customs union has expanded.  However, under World Trade Organization (WTO) rules, in accordance with Article XXIV, paragraph 6, of the 1994 GATT, the European Union was obliged to open negotiations with the People's Republic of China on Croatia's list of commitments in order to eventually agree on compensation. This is necessary if the adoption of the EU external tariff regime results in an increase in tariffs beyond the level for which the accession country has committed itself to the WTO.  The European Parliament has thus given its approval to the EU-China agreement on Croatia's accession. The results were negotiated by the Commission in agreement with WTO members with negotiating rights and concerning industrial products and agricultural quotas. It was with this in mind that I voted for this recommendation.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which aims to conclude the EU-China Agreement, taking into account the accession of Croatia to the EU, as per the WTO requirements. The Commission has negotiated with China the issue of the withdrawal of specific concessions in relation to the withdrawal of the schedule of Croatia in the course of its accession to the EU. Therefore, I supported the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Agreement, which is a necessary step in order to ensure compliance with WTO rules. After the accession of Croatia, the EU had to launch negotiations with WTO Members holding negotiating rights, amongst which China, in order to agree on compensatory adjustments linked to the fact that the EU has enlarged its customs union and Croatia has adopted the EU’s external tariff regime, which led to an increase in tariff beyond the level for which Croatia had previously bound itself at the WTO. The outcome of the negotiations with China is a balanced one, the number of products affected and the actual level of the compensation being quite limited, i.e. EU duty on footwear was reduced from 17% to 16,9% and on certain air conditioning machines from 2.7% to 2.5%, additional 2 150 tonnes of garlic were added under the EU tariff rate quota of 9.6% and additional 650 tonnes were added to the EU tariff rate quota for mushroom.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Customs Union of the European Union was enlarged. Croatia has thus taken over the EU's external tariff system, resulting in some eroding of the former trade rights of the People's Republic of China, according to a report by the Committee on International Trade. On the restoration of China's former trade rights, the Commission initiated negotiations on the basis of the council's empowerment on 15 July 2013 and proposes to sign the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters with the People's Republic of China on behalf of the Union. The Council must also obtain the agreement of the European Parliament to do so. In its report, the Committee on International Trade recommends that Parliament agree to the conclusion of the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Following Croatia's accession, the EU had to renegotiate tariff agreements with China in accordance with WTO rules. The European Commission has made several concessions on tariffs and quotas (shoes, air conditioning, garlic, mushrooms). China has made no concessions. As EU tariffs on China are already very unfavourable for European companies (France's foreign trade with China is very loss-making), this new list of concessions is not welcome. This type of relationship is not balanced. Unfavorable vote.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union has extended its customs union. The People's Republic of China is entitled to the re-establishment of its previous trade rights, which have suffered a slight degradation due to the extension of the customs union when Croatia's accession to the Union. In accordance with World Trade Organisation rules, it was for the EU to open negotiations with WTO members who hold negotiating rights related to Croatia's customs tariff. The Commission has chosen to increase tariff quotas and lower tariff levels for the Chinese products concerned in order to compensate for losses as compensatory instruments.  As the proposal to conclude the agreement proportionately alters the concessions and is consistent with previous practice and the WTO framework, I am in favour of concluding this Agreement.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the EU-China agreement on Croatia's accession to the EU. The latter had to renegotiate tariff agreements with China in accordance with WTO rules. Considering that this agreement is very favourable to China, which has made no concessions, and therefore unbalanced, I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as Labour MEPs support the conclusion of this agreement. Under WTO rules China has the right to have its previous trading rights restored, following their slight erosion due to the enlargement of the EU Customs Union with Croatian EU accession.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to give Parliament's approval to Croatia's accession to the EU-China agreement. Since Croatia joined the European Union only from 1 July 2013, it was not a party to the Convention, although as a Member State it has a full place in it. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the agreement between the European Union and China on the modification of concessions in the list of commitments of the Republic of Croatia as part of its accession to the European Union. The Customs Union of the European Union was enlarged by the integration of Croatia in 2013. It was then necessary to negotiate compensation with China to bring the country in line with its WTO commitments.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Eu ropean Union customs union has expanded and negotiations have therefore been opened with a number of WTO partners, including China, to establish a compensatory adjustment of the tariff regime. The aim of the agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China is to facilitate and regularise trade, and I therefore voted in favour of the measure.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I accepted the recommendation because we voted to take a step that is entirely natural after Croatia's accession to the European Union. With the new Member State, the EU customs union has also been enlarged, which has an impact on the rest of the WTO, including China. I believe that we have succeeded in set favourable conditions for both sides on this subject.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) is part of the rules of the World Trade Organisation and regulates international trade. I have voted for this report that will start negotiations with the World Trade Organisation’s Member, China, regarding the tariff schedule of Croatia following its accession to the European Union thus enlarging its customs. The agreement, in the form of an Exchange of Letters with the People’s Republic of China, will be signed by the European Council on behalf of the European Union, and in the meantime proposal is being submitted by the European Commission regarding the conclusions of the Agreement.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which will slightly amend quotas on trade with China following the accession of Croatia to the EU without affecting the Irish economy. Under the WTO rules, the EU has to negotiate with its trade partners new conditions due to the accession of Croatia to the EU. The Commission negotiated new conditions on industrial goods – slightly lower EU tariffs on footwear and air-conditioners. On agriculture quotas, the Commission will propose a regulation to increase the tonnage allocation for garlic and mushrooms from China (while maintaining the same percentage).

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union expanded its customs union. Under the agreement, the Commission will harmonise tariffs by means of an implementing regulation and adjust commodity quotas. I am in favour of this.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Union expanded its customs union, which requires, in accordance with World Trade Organization (WTO) rules, negotiations with WTO members who have negotiating rights on Croatia's tariff list to agree on a countervailing adjustment. This is the case of China and is the objective of this Agreement. I therefore give my approval to this report and to the granting of approval to the conclusion of the Agreement.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this as it was merely a technical update to reflect the fact that Croatia has joined the EU since the original agreement was signed with China.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – As a member of Parliament’s Delegation for Relations with China, I am following closely the relationship between the European Union and China. The EU is China’s largest trade partner and China is the EU’s second largest partner. With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union enlarged its Customs Union. Consequently, the European Union was required under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules to enter into negotiations with WTO Members having negotiating rights related to the tariff schedule of Croatia in order to eventually agree on a compensatory adjustment. That is why I am fully supporting the agreement.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the agreement in the form of an amendment to letters between the European Union and the People's Republic of China. With Croatia's accession to the European Union, the People's Republic of China has had trade rights reduced to a lesser extent due to the enlargement of the EU Customs Union. In accordance with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the People's Republic of China has the right to renew its previous trade rights. With this compensatory agreement, the preferences of both parties have been proportionately amended and are in line with earlier practice and the Framework of the World Trade Organisation.  With its accession to the EU, the Republic of Croatia has certainly contributed to the expansion of this market, and as a Croatian representative, I hope that the Republic of Croatia will also be able to benefit from this compensation agreement. The purpose of the Customs Union itself should be to facilitate trade between stand-alone areas and not to raise barriers to trade between other Member States and those areas.  The agreement was viewed from several sides and the Foreign Affairs Committee supported the proposal and stated that the relevant compensatory adjustments to China were proportionate and did not exceed Chinese rights affected by the abolition of Croatian preferences to China. This agreement is further proof that the EU supports the multilateral trading system but also respects ETO's commercial rules.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Following Croatia's accession, the EU had to renegotiate tariff agreements with China in accordance with WTO rules. The European Commission has made several concessions on tariffs and quotas (shoes, air conditioning, garlic, mushrooms). China has made no concessions. As EU tariffs on China are already very unfavourable (France's foreign trade with China is very loss-making), this new list of concessions is not welcome. This type of relationship is not balanced. I therefore vote against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union has expanded its customs union. That is why, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules (Article XXIV(6) of the GATT of 1994), the European Union had to initiate negotiations with WTO member states that have negotiating rights related to Croatia's customs tariff in order to eventually agree on a compensatory adjustment.  Such an adjustment shall take place where the adoption of the EU external tariff system leads to an increase in tariffs above the level to which the accession country has committed to the WTO. On 15 July 2013, the Council authorised the Commission to initiate negotiations under Article XXIV(6) of the GATT of 1994. The Commission negotiated with WTO member states which have negotiating rights relating to the abolition of certain privileges relating to the abolition of the list of the Republic of Croatia as part of its accession to the European Union.  Taking into account the Agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and the People's Republic of China in accordance with Article XXIV(6) and Article XXVIII. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) of 1994 with regard to the amendment of the preferences on the list of the Republic of Croatia as part of its accession to the European Union (15562/2015), I agree with the recommendation to conclude this Agreement.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU has extended its customs union with the accession of Croatia. Under WTO rules, it is now obliged to negotiate with its members on rule change and compensation. This compensation is necessary in view of the increase in duties above the level to which Croatia has undertaken with the WTO. I voted in favour of this technical report, which formally allows the revised agreement between China and the European Commission to enter into force.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union has expanded its customs union. As a result, world trade organisation (WTO) rules (Article XXIV(6) of GATT 1994) required the European Union to open negotiations with WTO member countries with negotiating rights linked to Croatia's tariff list with a view to finally agreeing a compensatory adjustment. This adjustment is necessary if the adoption of the EU's external tariff regime results in an increase in duties above the level to which the acceding country has committed itself within the framework of the WTO. I voted in favour of approving this recommendation in order to promote the development of opportunities for international trade in Croatia as well.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union has expanded the customs union. Therefore, in accordance with World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union was required to open negotiations with WTO members who have negotiating rights on Croatia's concession list in order to agree on a compensation. Such compensation shall be due if the adoption of the EU external tariff system results in an increase in rates above the level to which the acceding country has committed itself within the WTO. These adjustments concern in particular the reduction of current EU tariffs on footwear and window or wall-type air conditioners, as well as the increase in import quotas for garlic and mushrooms. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report, which is part of Croatia's accession to the European Union. With an additional Member State, the EU has expanded its customs union and has therefore been required to clarify technical rules, formalised by an agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and China.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. On 1 July 2013 Croatia became the 28th Member State of the Union, thus extending the number of countries that are part of today's customs union. In accordance with World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, it is for the Union to renegotiate the terms of the trade agreements underlying WTO tariffs in the event of an increase in its customs union. To this end, the Commission has negotiated with the People's Republic of China the application of some compensatory instruments on some commercial rights. This agreement guarantees the proportionality of the concessions of each party and is also consistent with the WTO framework. In compliance with Article XXIV(4) of the GATT, in so far as a customs union or free trade area should aim to facilitate trade between the constituent territories and not create barriers to their trade, as well as because I believe that compensatory adjustments are appropriate, I voted in this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this as it was merely a technical update to reflect the fact that Croatia has joined the EU since the original agreement was signed with China.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is only a technical document on the EU-China agreement, taking into account Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting approval for the conclusion of the Agreement between the Union and China on the amendment of concessions to Croatia's WTO tariff list as a result of its accession to the Union. With Croatia's accession, the Union has expanded its customs union. Accordingly, in accordance with WTO rules, the Union is required to enter into negotiations with WTO members who have negotiating rights on Croatia's tariff list to agree on a countervailing adjustment.
