Thus, the Commission has negotiated with WTO members, in this case China, who have negotiating rights with respect to the abolition of specific concessions in relation to the withdrawal of Croatia's tariff list for their entry into the Union.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Following Croatia's accession, the European Union has expanded its customs union. It was then required, under World Trade Organization (WTO) rules, to open negotiations with WTO members with negotiating rights in the lists of one of the member countries in order to agree compensation. Like the vast majority of MEPs, I consider the outcome of these negotiations with China and Uruguay acceptable, which is why I have decided to vote in favour of these acts.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. Following the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, the EU's customs union has expanded. The European Union was therefore obliged to open negotiations with wto negotiating members on croatia's tariff list with a view to finally agreeing a compensatory adjustment. The relevant compensatory adjustment applicable to China shall be proportionate and shall not exceed China's rights in so far as they relate to the impact on that country from the withdrawal of Croatian concessions.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I was in favour of the adoption of the proposal for a recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the AGREEMENT between the EU and China, taking into account Croatia's accession to the EU and, consequently, to the Customs Union. As the rapporteur points out, this agreement will restore the previous trade rights of the People's Republic of China with the EU, facilitating trade and avoiding barriers to trade. To that extent, it is a compensatory agreement, which complies with the rules of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) and its multilateral trade regime.  I would like to point out, in this regard, that China is now the second largest economy in the world and the main country supplying goods to the EU and, to that extent, the compensatory instruments that make up this Agreement are perfectly proportional and consistent with the practice prior to Croatia's accession and the WTO framework, so i have given my venom to the adoption of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union has expanded its customs union. Therefore, it was required, under World Trade Organization (WTO) rules (Article XXIV, paragraph 6, of the 1994 GATT), to open negotiations with WTO members with negotiating rights with respect to Croatia's list of commitments in order to eventually agree on compensation. It is in this sense that I supported this report on the agreement between the European Union and China on the modification of concessions in the list of commitments of the Republic of Croatia as part of its accession to the EU.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report necessary to formalise Croatia's access to the European Union.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the EU-China agreement with a view to amending the concessions in the list of specific commitments of the Republic of Croatia. The background is that Croatia's accession to the EU in 2013 extended the customs union, thus obliging the EU, in accordance with WTO rules, to open negotiations with WTO Member States on compensatory arrangements if they have negotiating rights with regard to Croatia's tariff. Such compensation must be made if the adoption of the EU customs tariff results in tariffs exceeding the level to which the acceding country originally committed to the WTO.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In line with my previous opposition to the EU-China Agreement on the World Trade Organization for its defence and promotion of a neoliberal model of international trade, I have also voted against Croatia's accession to it.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as it is a technical update to an already established agreement.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – I supported the conclusion of this agreement. Under WTO rules, China has the right to have its previous trading rights restored, following their slight erosion due to the enlargement of the EU customs union with Croatian accession to the EU.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing – I voted in favour of agreeing to the agreement. With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union has extended its customs union. The People's Republic of China has the right under gatt to restore its original trade rights. This compensatory agreement can therefore be seen as another sign that the EU is part of the rules-based multilateral trading system at the heart of which the WTO is located. The Commission opted for an increase in tariff quotas as well as a reduction in the current binding duty rates as a tool to compensate for the losses of the Chinese products concerned.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ taking into account the opinion of the Committee on International Trade, I have decided to support the conclusion of an EU-China agreement amending the tariff and quota concession in the context of Croatia's accession to the Union. I agree with the view that the People's Republic of China has the right to restore its original trade rights, which have been weakly disrupted as a result of the enlargement of the EU customs union by the accession of Croatia. With this agreement, the EU fulfils the articles of the GATT Agreement laying down rules for the functioning of free trade. This applies the principles of the multilateral trading system at the heart of which is the WTO. Moreover, this agreement concerning croatia's accession is part of the normal practice that the EU has also applied to previous enlargements. It concerns several tariff lines for which import quotas are used. For certain industrial and agricultural products imported into the EU by China, the linked duty rate will either be reduced or the import quota increased. The adaptation of these rules due to the accession of Croatia is thus based on China and should therefore be adopted positively in mutual trade relations.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 The essence of the common market, which is the basis for European economic cooperation, is the principle that the agreed rules also apply to states that have acceded to the European Union only after the relevant directive, regulation or international agreement has been adopted. China is an important partner for the European Union, and extending cooperation to the new Member States strengthens our position.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I abstained from the European Parliament's resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and the People's Republic of China in accordance with Article XXIV(6) and Article XXVIII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) 1994 in connection with the amendment of the concessions in the list of specific obligations of the Republic of Croatia in the course of its accession to the European Union. I am opposed to the extension of the EU to include other Member States, so that I cannot, in any case, agree to the adaptation of the various international treaties to Croatia's accession.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union has expanded the customs union. Under World Trade Organisation rules, the European Union had to launch negotiations with WTO member states that have negotiating rights related to Croatia's customs tariff in order to eventually agree on the compensatory adjustment that takes place if the adoption of the EU external tariff system leads to an increase in tariffs above the level to which the accession country has committed itself to the WTO. I support the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and the People's Republic of China in accordance with Article XXIV(6) and Article XXVIII. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) of 1994 with regard to the amendment of the preferences on the list of the Republic of Croatia as part of its accession to the European Union.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the People's Republic of China pursuant to Article XXIV:6 and Article XXVIII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) 1994 concerning the modification of the concessions in the list of concessions of the Republic of Croatia in the context of its accession to the European Union.  Croatia's accession to the European Union has also extended the customs union. As this has increased customs tariffs more than the rate that the accession country has undertaken with the World Trade Organisation, we need this adjustment.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's consent to the conclusion of an AGREEMENT between the EU and China in connection with Croatia's accession to the EU, thereby extending the EU customs union, and was therefore obliged under EU WTO rules to open negotiations with China on the Charter of Tariff Concessions of Croatia. This is a beneficial step which will result in a reduction in the contractual duty rate fixed by the Common Tariff or an increase in the quota for certain agricultural products.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This agreement will result in the restoration of the previous trading rights of the People's Republic of China, which were limited by the enlargement of the EU customs union with the accession of Croatia. In other words, the galloping growth of China's highly competitive (for European economies) economy will be further strengthened.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Customs Union of the European Union was enlarged. Consequently, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union is obliged to enter into negotiations with wto member states for which Croatia has so far held a so-called concession tariff list. This will be necessary if, as a result of accession to the Union tariff system, the increase in the tariff level for this reason exceeds the level agreed by the acceding country in the WTO. The mandate to open negotiations was given to the Commission by the Council on 15 July 2013, which is based on Article XXIV(6) of the GATT. As a result of these negotiations, the Commission proposed to sign the Agreement on behalf of the Union. In view of the above, I voted in favour of Parliament's agreement on the draft Council Decision.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote aims to conclude the EU- China agreement, taking into account the accession of Croatia to the EU, as per the WTO requirements. The vote is necessary, as the European Parliament’s consent to a Council Decision is a mandatory component in the completion of the ratification process of the Additional Protocol. I support this agreement, as it is now appropriate to conclude it.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament followed the Foreign Affairs Committee, which issued an opinion in the form of a letter; it considers that the draft conclusion of the agreement should be approved, as it makes proportionate changes to the concessions and is in line with previous WTO practices. It takes note of the Commission's reports that the compensation in question is proportionate and does not exceed China's rights concerned with the withdrawal of Croatia's concessions from Croatia.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-China Agreement relating to the accession of Croatia, which will restore China’s previous trading rights. In fact, these had been slightly eroded due to the enlargement of the EU customs union when Croatia joined the EU in 2013. In order to compensate for the losses, the agreement will therefore increase tariff rate quotas, and lower the current bound tariff rates as the instruments of compensation for the Chinese products that were involved. I believe it is important that multilateral rules-based trading regime, with the WTO at its centre, are upheld and further developed.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Agreement between the European Union and China regarding the amendment of the preferences on the list of the Republic of Croatia as part of its accession to the European Union.  According to World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union must initiate negotiations with WTO member states that have negotiating rights related to Croatia's customs tariff in order to agree on compensatory adjustment. Since I believe that the Agreement contains proportionate amendments to the privileges and is in line with the earlier practice and framework of the WTO, I voted to adopt it.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the EU-China agreement related to croatia's accession.  Following the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union expanded the customs union. Therefore, in accordance with World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules (Article XXIV:6 of GATT 1994), it had to enter into negotiations with WTO members holding negotiating rights on croatia's customs tariff in order to agree on a compensatory adjustment. Such adjustment is necessary if the adoption of the EU external tariff regime increases customs tariffs more than the rate for which the acceding state has undertaken to the WTO.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report necessary to formalise Croatia's access to the European Union.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Following Croatia's accession, the European Union had to renegotiate tariff agreements with China in accordance with WTO rules. The European Commission has therefore made several concessions on these tariffs and on quotas (shoes, air conditioning appliances, garlic, mushrooms). China has made no concessions. As EU tariffs on China are already very unfavourable (France's foreign trade with China is very loss-making), this new list of concessions is not welcome. I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 As a result of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, under WTO rules, it was necessary to compensate the People's Republic of China for the withdrawal of concession lists and the increase in tariffs as a result of the EU's external tariff. Facilitating trade by removing barriers is an important objective of international trade policy, which is why I supported the above-above resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Customs Union of the European Union was enlarged. Consequently, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union was obliged to enter into negotiations with WTO members which have negotiating rights in respect of Croatia's concession lists in order to establish a possible compensatory adjustment. Such an adjustment shall be made if, as a result of the takeover of the EU external tariff system, the increase in the tariff level exceeds that undertaken by the acceding country in the WTO. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report necessary to formalise Croatia's access to the European Union.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the agreement with the People's Republic of China and believe that the European Parliament should support it. The People's Republic of China has the right to reclaim its previous trade rights, given the slight deterioration of the situation as a result of the enlargement of the EU Customs Union following croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the People's Republic of China pursuant to Article XXIV: 6 and Article XXVIII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) 1994 relating to the modification of concessions in the schedule of the Republic of Croatia in the course of its accession to the European Union. With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union enlarged its customs union. Consequently, the European Union was required under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules to enter into negotiations with WTO Members having negotiating rights related to the tariff schedule of Croatia in order to eventually agree on a compensatory adjustment. Such adjustment is due if the adoption of the EU’s external tariff regime results in an increase in tariff beyond the level for which the acceding country has bound itself at the WTO. I believe that the People’s Republic of China has the right to have its previous trading rights restored, following their slight erosion due to the enlargement of the EU Customs Union with Croatian EU accession.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Following Croatia's accession, the Union, under the rules of the World Trade Organization, has agreed on a number of compensation adjustments in the Agreement between the Union and China. We are talking about a balanced agreement which has been reached by the Commission and I think it is necessary to vote in favour of its proposal.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 Croatia's accession to the Union de facto expanded the customs union. The People's Republic of China is entitled to the restoration of its former trade rights, following its slight erosion by the enlargement of the EU customs union with Croatia's accession to the EU. I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union has extended its customs union. Consequently, in accordance with world trade organisation (WTO) rules [Article XXIV(6) of gatt 1994], it was for the European Union to open negotiations with WTO members who hold negotiating rights relating to croatia's customs tariff in order to agree on any compensatory adjustment.  On 15 July 2013 the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations pursuant to Article XXIV(6) of gatt 1994. The Commission has negotiated with WTO members who hold negotiating rights the issue of the withdrawal of specific concessions arising from the withdrawal of the customs tariff of the Republic of Croatia in the context of croatia's accession to the European Union. While these free trade agreements deserve our repudiation of their consequences on local economies, we believe that countries should be able to establish fully the trade agreements they sovereignly understand. For this reason, our vote of abstention.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Croatia's accession to the EU has also expanded the Customs Union. This proposal is a technical agreement which re-regulates quotas for certain agricultural products between the EU and China following the accession of Croatia. I have therefore voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Recommendation on the EU-China Agreement on the accession of Croatia, of which I am rapporteur, comes at a time when the EU, with the accession of the Republic of Croatia, has expanded its customs union. The EU is therefore obliged, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, to open negotiations with WTO members who have negotiating rights with regard to Croatia's customs tariff in order to finally reach an agreement on a compensatory adjustment. As rapporteur, I welcome the agreement reached with the People's Republic of China and consider it appropriate for the European Parliament to approve it.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the content of this report, which has already been adopted by the relevant Committee on International Trade by an increased majority, which also underlines its wider acceptance by the political groups.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it is necessary to adapt the current tariff regime with the People's Republic of China. Parliament has fulfilled its obligation and the Union once it shows that it complies with WTO rules.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 China is a strong economic partner for the EU, which is why I voted in favour of this agreement, which will help the EU and China to continue to have good and functioning trade relations. With Croatia's access among the Member States of the European Union, the European Customs Union has been extended. Therefore, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the EU had to renegotiate the rights relating to Croatia's customs tariff in order to allow for a possible levelling of customs duties.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ Since Croatia's accession to the European Union also increased in 2013, negotiations on compensatory settlements need to be opened under World Trade Organisation rules. Such negotiations must take place when, as a result of the enlargement of the Customs Union, the duties originally agreed change. And since such a change has taken place in the case of China, namely for footwear, air conditioners, mushrooms and garlic, I supported the agreement.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the EU-China agreement related to Croatia's accession.  Following the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union expanded the customs union. Therefore, in accordance with World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules (Article XXIV:6 of GATT 1994), it had to enter into negotiations with WTO members holding negotiating rights on croatia's customs tariff in order to agree on a compensatory adjustment. Such adjustment is necessary if the adoption of the EU external tariff regime increases customs tariffs more than the rate for which the acceding state has undertaken to the WTO.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As a result of the negotiations imposed by the World Trade Organisation after the entry of the Republic of Croatia into the customs union, changes were made to the tariff quotas on beef and veal. As the compensatory adjustment of tariffs outside the EU is a necessary process, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We abstained on this as it was merely a technical update to reflect the fact that Croatia has joined the EU since the original agreement was signed with Uruguay.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. Following Croatia's accession, the EU had to renegotiate tariffs with Uruguay in accordance with World Trade Organization rules. I objected to this agreement because, once again, the Commission gave in on quotas, particularly on beef, when it did not ask the other side for the same.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. Under the WTO rules, the EU has to negotiate with its partners new conditions due to the accession of Croatia to the EU. The Commission proposes modifications related to tariff rate quotas on bovine meat. The Commission is also preparing an implementing Regulation regarding several tariff rate quotas. The amendment to the Agreement is mainly technical, but because there is a possibility that the modification of the tariff rate quotas on beef may have a small effect on European farmers, including in Ireland, I did not vote in favour but abstained.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this technical report, which aims to conclude the EU-Uruguay agreement taking into account Croatia's accession to the EU and adapting the tariff schedule, in line with WTO requirements. The agreement must now be concluded.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of an Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay, because the EU has extended its customs union and in accordance with WTO rules, must negotiate on croatia's tariff table.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is a recommendation on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay under Article XXIV, paragraph 6, and Article XXVIII of the 1994 General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) on the modification of concessions in the Republic of Croatia's list of commitments as part of its accession to the European Union. After Croatia's accession, the EU had to renegotiate tariff agreements with Uruguay in accordance with WTO rules. The European Commission took the opportunity to make two concessions on quotas on beef. In any negotiation, the European Union makes tariff or quota concessions without the opposing party doing the same. This type of relationship is not balanced. I therefore objected to this report.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I support the conclusion of an agreement between the EU and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay, which would agree on a compensatory settlement.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this as it was merely a technical update to reflect the fact that Croatia has joined the EU since the original agreement was signed with Uruguay.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Following Croatia's accession, the EU had to renegotiate tariff agreements with Uruguay in accordance with WTO rules. As a result, the European Commission has made two concessions on quotas on beef. Tariff concessions must come from both sides. I am against this vote, which will therefore increase this unbalanced relationship.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this report on the Council's proposed decision authorising the conclusion of the agreement in the form of letter exchanges between the EU and Uruguay under certain provisions of the GATT concerning the modification of concessions in Croatia's list of commitments as part of its accession to the Union.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. As a result of Croatia's accession to the Union and due to WTO rules, the Union must negotiate with the remaining WTO members who have negotiating rights on Croatia's tariff list.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Zalba Bidegain report, a technical measure approving the agreement between the EU and Uruguay, which allows the South American country to see its trade rights re-established, slightly reduced following the enlargement of the EU customs union for Croatia's accession in July 2013. World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules have required the Eu ropean Union to enter into negotiations with WTO member countries, which have negotiating rights linked to Croatia's tariff list, with a view to agreeing a compensatory adjustment.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report necessary to formalise Croatia's access to the European Union.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. The adoption of this report is consistent and as a result of Croatia's accession to the European Union. With this entry, the Union has expanded its customs union and it is appropriate, in accordance with WTO rules, to negotiate on the tariff list of this Republic of the Union. In this case with respect to the Eastern Republic of Uruguay.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I refused to vote in favour of this report on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay under Article XXIV, paragraph 6, and Article XXVIII of the 1994 General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) on amending concessions in the Republic of Croatia's list of commitments as part of its accession European Union. As in the case of China, in fact, under the pretext of taking into account Croatia's accession to the EU, the agreements with Uruguay have been renegotiated, in a very unfavourable sense, since the EU has focused on quotas on beef. It is unacceptable that the EU should continue to make such one-way concessions, to the detriment of our economy but also of our agriculture, which is already in perilous situation at the moment.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although this procedure is a direct consequence of Croatia's recent accession to the EU, I do not agree with the contents of this report, which I believe could open up some critical issues for the European production sector. That is why I voted against this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting approval for the conclusion of the Agreement between the Union and Uruguay on the amendment of concessions to Croatia's WTO tariff list as a result of its accession to the Union. With Croatia's accession, the European Union has expanded its customs union. Accordingly, in accordance with WTO rules, the Union is obliged to enter into negotiations with WTO members who have negotiating rights on Croatia's tariff list, in order to agree on a countervailing adjustment. Thus, the Commission has negotiated with WTO members, in this case Uruguay, who have negotiating rights with respect to the abolition of specific concessions, in relation to the withdrawal of Croatia's tariff list for their entry into the Union.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it seeks harmonisation of legislation in the EU. With this report, Parliament approves the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay concerning the 1994 General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) on the modification of concessions in the schedules of the Republic of Croatia in the context of its accession to the European Union.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Customs Union of the European Union was enlarged. As a result, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union is obliged to enter into negotiations with wto member states for which Croatia has so far held a so-called concession tariff list. This will be necessary if, as a result of accession to the Union tariff system, the increase in the tariff level for this reason exceeds that undertaken by the acceding country in the WTO. As a result of the negotiations, the draft agreement was corked in Nairobi on 18 December 2015, after which the Council took a decision on the signature of the draft on 11 April 2016. I voted in favour of this report because the European Parliament's agreement with this Council decision is necessary for the ratification of the Additional Protocol.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this recommendation, which is technical in nature. It aims to conclude a treaty between the EU and Uruguay, taking into account Croatia's accession to the EU and the adjustment of customs tariffs, as well as WTO requirements.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Following Croatia's accession, the EU had to renegotiate tariff agreements with Uruguay in accordance with WTO rules and the Commission made concessions on beef quotas. Considering that this relationship is unbalanced, I voted against this text.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is right that the Republic of Croatia, now that it is fully part of the European Union, should also participate in the trade agreements that the EU signs with foreign states. We consider this to be a due act.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Following Croatia's accession, the European Union renegotiated tariff agreements with Uruguay in accordance with World Trade Organization (WTO) rules. It is in this context that the European Commission has granted Uruguay, without the slightest reciprocity, new tariff concessions on beef import quotas. Instead of protecting our farmers and farmers, who are already suffering from the fall in the price of raw materials, through intelligent protectionism, the European Union is locked in dogmatism and ideology in this mad policy of widespread free trade. In the coming months, these new tariff concessions will be added to the transatlantic free trade agreement with the United States, which will definitively sign the death warrant for our agriculture. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Agreement between the European Union and Uruguay aims to amend tariff concessions related to Croatia's accession to the Union. Given that the European Union has expanded its customs union with the accession of the Republic of Croatia, it becomes mandatory to enter into negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay on the tariff of Croatia precisely in order to reach an agreement on compensatory adjustment. This compensation agreement is proof of the Union's attachment to the trade regime, and marked once again the primacy of the purpose of the establishment of customs unions and free trade zones. I welcome the agreement reached with Uruguay on amending tariff concessions related to Croatia's accession to the European Union because I believe that this Agreement contains changes commensurate with the concessions and is in line with previous practice.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay, because with the accession of the Republic of Croatia and the related enlargement of the customs union, the EU is obliged to start negotiations with Uruguay on Croatia's tariff. This adjustment stems from the obligations laid down in WTO rules, in particular Article XXIV(6) of gatt in 1994. Negotiations with Uruguay led to a draft agreement signed in Nairobi on 18 December 2015. The European Union will have to include in its list for customs territory the amendments relating to the tariff quotas on beef and veal. With regard to the agreement, the European Commission is drawing up an implementing regulation on the various tariff quotas. Approval by the European Parliament is essential for the completion of the process of ratifying the Additional Protocol.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. Under the WTO rules, the EU has to negotiate with its partners new conditions due to the accession of Croatia to the EU. The Commission proposes modifications related to tariff rate quotas on bovine meat. The Commission is also preparing an implementing Regulation regarding several tariff rate quotas. The amendment to the Agreement is mainly technical, but because there is a possibility that the modification of the tariff rate quotas on beef may have a small effect on European farmers, including in Ireland, I did not vote in favour but abstained.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ As a consequence of the accession of Croatia, the customs union of the EU has grown and consequently in line with WTO rules, the EU had to enter into negotiations with other WTO members, in this particular case, Uruguay, having negotiated rights related to the tariff schedule of Croatia. I give my consent to the proposal to conclude the Agreement. The EU will incorporate in its schedule for the customs territory of the EU 28 that of the EU 27 with modifications related to tariff rate quotas on bovine meat. In connection to the Agreement, the European Commission is also preparing an implementing Regulation regarding several tariff rate quotas.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union has expanded its customs union. As a result, World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules have required the EU to open negotiations with WTO member countries with negotiating rights related to Croatia's tariff list, with a view to agreeing a compensatory adjustment. My vote was positive.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report in order to complete the process of ratifying the Additional Protocol.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Uruguay amending the concessions provided for in the Table of the Republic of Croatia in the context of its accession to the European Union is a positive step and as such procedures favour the smooth development of the accession process, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The trade agreement signed by the European Union with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay following croatia's accession welcomes my assent as it results in a further development opportunity for European companies. The development of trade relations between relatively young countries from very distant economic backgrounds is a success of the economic project embodied by the Union. Until twenty years ago, it would have been unthinkable to agree to a partnership between a Latin American country and a country belonging to Yugoslavia, for reasons not only geographical, but mainly linked to the economic and political ideology embraced by one and the other. Today, thanks to the contribution of the European Union, bringing together what was once very far away is possible and I am proud to be able to participate and support this historic turning point.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the EU-Uruguay Agreement relating to the accession of Croatia and noted no objections.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of concluding the trade agreement between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay because, following the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the Union, the customs union has expanded and compensatory adjustments to the tariff system should now be made. The aim of this agreement is to simplify and promote trade between the European Union and third countries, in this case the Republic of Uruguay, in full compliance with the rules of the World Trade Organisation.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The EU will incorporate in its schedule for the customs territory of the EU 28 that of the EU 27 with modifications related to tariff rate quotas on bovine meat. In connection to the Agreement, the European Commission is also preparing an implementing Regulation regarding several tariff rate quotas. I concord with the rapporteur to grant European Parliament’s consent.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In line with my previous opposition to the EU-Uruguay Agreement on the World Trade Organization for its defence and promotion of a neoliberal model of international trade, I have also voted against Croatia's accession to it.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the EU expanded its customs union and was obliged, in accordance with the rules in force, to start negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay on the customs tariff applied to Croatia in order to reach an agreement on a compensatory adjustment, as the external tariff regime of the European Union leads to an increase in tariffs. These negotiations led to the signing of the draft agreement on 18 December 2015. I voted for the ratification of this Additional Protocol, the Council's decision being a mandatory component in the completion of the ratification process.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – With the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU, the EU customs union has been enlarged and, as a result, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union is obliged to enter into negotiations with wto member states for which Croatia has so far held a so-called concession tariff list. This will be necessary if, as a result of accession to the Union tariff system, the increase in the tariff level for this reason exceeds the level agreed by the acceding country in the WTO. As a result of the negotiations with Uruguay, the draft agreement was corked on 18 December 2015 and subsequently the Council took a decision on the signature of the draft. I supported this report because the European Parliament's agreement with this Council Decision is necessary for the ratification of the Additional Protocol.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support the agreement between Croatia and Uruguay to equalise tariff quotas for bovine meat. This is an important agreement, given that the customs union was automatically enlarged when Croatia joined the EU. The opening of negotiations between Croatia and Uruguay is an important step to establish an EU external tariff so that these rates are not high. These are the submarines for which I voted 'in favour'.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-Uruguay Agreement which takes into account the accession of Croatia to the EU and adapting the tariff schedule as per the WTO requirements. I support this agreement, which represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Uruguay.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement. As an important actor in global trade, it is important that the EU continues to set an example in abiding by WTO rules and adopts a flexible approach in trade negotiations with third countries.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the accession of Croatia, the EU expanded its customs union and was therefore obliged, in accordance with the rules established within the FRAMEWORK of the WTO, to open negotiations with Uruguay on Croatia's tariff with a view to reaching an agreement on compensatory adjustment, due to the changed external tariff regime of the EU. The measure, which is strictly technical in nature and similar to that adopted with regard to the People's Republic of China, is essential for the completion of the process of ratifying the Additional Protocol.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report presents the European Parliament's recommendation on the protocol for updating the EU-Uruguay agreement following Croatia's accession to the European Union and deals with possible compensation to the EU partner country as long as the EU expands its market to a new member. The rapporteur recommends supporting the Commission's proposal for this negotiation. Considering that the enlargement of the single market is changing the conditions of trade with partner countries and that these conditions need to be redefined, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this as it was merely a technical update to reflect the fact that Croatia has joined the EU since the original agreement was signed with Uruguay.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the conclusion of an agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay under the 1994 General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) on the modification of concessions in Croatia's list of commitments as part of its accession to the EU. As the customs union of the European Union was enlarged as a result of Croatia's accession, it was necessary to adapt our trade agreements accordingly.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report follows Croatia's accession, the European Union had to renegotiate its tariffs with Uruguay. These renegotiations have resulted in new tariff and quota concessions (beef), without consideration from Uruguay. We denounce these unbalanced trade relations. So I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation for an AGREEMENT between the EU and Uruguay on the amendment of concessions in the List of the Republic of Croatia in the process of its accession to the European Union. The report is technical and reflects the need to adapt existing agreements following the enlargement of the European Customs Union following the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This agreement will result in the restoration of Uruguay's previous trading rights, which have been affected by the enlargement of the EU customs union with the accession of Croatia.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Customs Union of the European Union was enlarged. Consequently, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union is obliged to enter into negotiations with wto member states for which Croatia has so far held a so-called concession tariff list. This will be necessary if, as a result of accession to the Union tariff system, the increase in the tariff level for this reason exceeds the level agreed by the acceding country in the WTO. As a result of the negotiations with Uruguay, the draft agreement was corked in Nairobi on 18 December 2015, after which the Council adopted a decision on the signature of the draft on 11 April 2015. I voted in favour of this report because the European Parliament's agreement with this Council decision is necessary for the ratification of the Additional Protocol.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament shall give its consent to the conclusion of the draft decision of the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay concerning the amendment of concessions provided for in the customs tariff of the Republic of Croatia in the context of croatia's accession to the European Union. Negotiations with Uruguay resulted in a draft agreement initialled on 18 December 2015 in Nairobi. The EU will include the EU-27 tariff on the EU-28 customs territory with changes to tariff quotas applied to beef.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: in any negotiation, the European Union makes tariff or quota concessions without the opposing party doing the same. This type of relationship is not balanced.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the EU has extended its customs union, complying with WTO rules (Article XXIV(6) of gatt 1994) to initiate negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay on croatia's customs tariff in order to reach agreement on possible compensatory adjustment. Negotiations with Uruguay resulted in a draft agreement initialled on 18 December 2015 in Nairobi. A proposal on the signing of this agreement was also presented and the Council Decision on signature took place on 11 April 2016. The adoption by the European Parliament of this Council Decision is a mandatory element in completing the process of ratification of the Additional Protocol. Despite the eminently technical nature of this report, our position is inextled by the principled position on the grounds which determine its need, which highlight the eu's exclusive competence in the field of trade policy conferred on it by the Treaty of Lisbon. We believe that countries should be able to establish, in full, the trade agreements they sovereignly understand.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation as I approve of the proposal for the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay. In fact, following the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Union expanded its customs union and was therefore obliged, in accordance with World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, to open negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay on Croatia's tariff, with a view to possibly agreeing a compensatory adjustment, since the EU's external tariff regime entails an increase in tariffs.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \u2012 In this particular case, this is a set of arrangements of a purely technical nature. The main objective of the agreement in question is to conclude an agreement between the European Union and Uruguay which takes account of Croatia's accession to the European Union and the adaptation of tariff plans as required by the World Trade Organisation.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation on the EU-Uruguay Agreement following Croatia's accession.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the EU-Uruguay Agreement on Croatia's accession as this agreement will result in the restoration of Uruguay's previous trading rights, which have been affected by the enlargement of the EU customs union with the accession of Croatia.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a file of technical nature. It aims to conclude the EU-Uruguay agreement, taking into account the accession of Croatia to the EU and adapting the tariff schedule, as per the WTO requirements. It is now appropriate to conclude the Agreement. No amendments were tabled in the Committee on International Trade (INTA). I support the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Customs Union of the European Union was enlarged. Consequently, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union is obliged to enter into negotiations with wto member states for which Croatia has so far held a so-called concessionary tariff wall. This will be necessary if, as a result of accession to the Union tariff system, the increase in the tariff level for this reason exceeds that undertaken by the acceding country in the WTO. As a result of the negotiations with Uruguay, the draft agreement was corked in Nairobi on 18 December 2015, after which the Council adopted a decision on the signature of the draft on 11 April 2015. I voted in favour of this report because the European Parliament's agreement with this Council decision is necessary for the ratification of the Additional Protocol.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I approved my fellow Member's recommendation to add Croatia to the Additional Protocol under the EU-Uruguay GATT Agreement. The European Parliament should give its consent to the conclusion of an Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay concerning the amendment of concessions on the Concessions List of the Republic of Croatia in the course of its accession to the European Union under Article XXIV and Article XXVIII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) of 1994. With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Customs Union of the European Union was enlarged. Consequently, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union was obliged to enter into negotiations with WTO members which have negotiating rights in respect of Croatia's concession lists in order to establish a possible compensatory adjustment. This adjustment had to be made as the increase in tariff levels resulting from the takeover of the EU external tariff system exceeds the level agreed by Croatia in the WTO.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay, in accordance with Article XXIV(6) and Article XXVIII of the 1994 General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) on the amendment of concessions in the list of the Republic of Croatia in the context of its accession to the European Union. Indeed, Croatia's accession to the customs union made it necessary to agree on a compensatory adjustment in order to update Croatia's tariff. With the agreement reached in Nairobi between the European Union and Uruguay last December 2015, and also thanks to the European Parliament's vote in favour, the EU will change the tariff quotas on beef.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the EU-Uruguay agreement in the context of Croatia's accession to the EU, as it is a technical update of an important agreement following Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report necessary to formalise Croatia's access to the European Union.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay pursuant to Article XXIV(6) and Article XXVIII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) of 1994 relating to amendments to the Concession Lists of the Republic of Croatia following its accession to the European Union. Following the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the EU has extended the customs union and, as the EU's external tariff system increases rates in accordance with WTO rules, the EU was obliged to open negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay on croatia's concession list. The negotiations with Uruguay culminated in the draft agreement initialled in Nairobi on 18 December 2015.  In my opinion, the European Parliament should agree to the conclusion of an Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay relating to amendments to the Lists of Concession Letters of the Republic of Croatia following its accession to the European Union.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this EU-Uruguay Agreement relating to the accession of Croatia. With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the EU enlarged its customs union and was therefore required under WTO rules to enter into negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay regarding the tariff schedule of Croatia in order to eventually agree on a compensatory adjustment as the EU’s external tariff regime results in an increase of tariffs. The EU will now incorporate its schedule for the customs territory of the EU 28 that of the EU 27 with modifications related to tariff rate quotas.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ After the EU enlarged its customs union with the accession of Croatia, it was required to negotiate the tariff schedule of Croatia with WTO members for a possible compensatory adjustment. Negotiations with Uruguay focused on adjustments of tariff rate quotes on bovine meat. My group and I are strong supporters of trade, and we have therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Customs Union of the European Union was enlarged. Consequently, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union is obliged to open negotiations with wto member states in which Croatia has so far held a so-called concessionary tariff wall. This will be necessary if, as a result of accession to the Union tariff system, the increase in the tariff level for this reason exceeds that undertaken by the acceding country in the WTO. As a result of the negotiations with Uruguay, the draft agreement was corked in Nairobi on 18 December 2015, after which the Council adopted a decision on the signature of the draft on 11 April 2015. I voted in favour of this report because the European Parliament's agreement with this Council decision is necessary for the ratification of the Additional Protocol.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union enlarged its Customs Union with the accession of Croatia. This file aims to conclude the EU-Uruguay agreement, taking into account the accession of Croatia to the EU, as is required under WTO rules.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted to recommend a draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay under Article XXIV(6) and Article XXVIII TB. the 1994 General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) with regard to the amendment of concessions in the schedule of the Republic of Croatia as part of its accession to the European Union, as this gives consent for the conclusion of this agreement.  Following Croatia's entry into the EU, the customs union was expanded and negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay were therefore needed to agree a compensatory adjustment, as the external tariff system leads to an increase in tariffs. The European Parliament's agreement on this draft Council is a mandatory part of completing the ratification process of the Additional Protocol.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report follows Croatia's accession to the EU. The latter had to renegotiate tariff agreements with Uruguay in accordance with WTO rules. As a result, the European Commission has made two concessions on quotas on beef. So I voted against this report.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Following the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the EU customs union expanded and a compensatory settlement with the members of the World Trade Organisation had to be negotiated, as the EU's external tariff led to an increase in customs duties. I voted in favour of the resolution on the conclusion of the agreement with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay, because the settlement is in line with both previous WTO practice and framework, as well as the EU's efforts to comply with the rules of the multilateral trade regime.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for my colleague Pablo Zalba's text on Croatia's accession to the EU-Uruguay agreement. In 2015, negotiations with Uruguay resulted in a trade agreement; this vote allows Croatia to also be implemented the provisions of the agreement following its accession in 2013, a decision which I am satisfied with and which allows Croatia to align its economic market with that of the other Member States. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the EU-Uruguay agreement on Croatia's accession. Following Croatia's accession, the Union has expanded its customs union and has therefore been obliged, under WTO rules, to open negotiations with Uruguay on Croatia's list of commitments in order to eventually agree on compensation, with the adoption of the EU's external tariff regime leading to an increase in tariffs.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this agreement as it merely modifies the existing rules with regard to Croatia's accession to the EU and does not involve any substantial changes.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Customs Union of the European Union was enlarged. Consequently, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union is obliged to enter into negotiations with wto member states for which Croatia has so far held a so-called concessionary tariff wall. This will be necessary if, as a result of accession to the Union tariff system, the increase in the tariff level for this reason exceeds the level agreed by the acceding country in the WTO. As a result of the negotiations with Uruguay, the draft agreement was corked in Nairobi on 18 December 2015, after which the Council adopted a decision on the signature of the draft on 11 April 2015. I voted in favour of this report because the European Parliament's agreement with this Council decision is necessary for the ratification of the Additional Protocol.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ With Croatia’s accession on 1 July 2013, the EU enlarged its customs union. In the light of this, the European Parliament should give its consent to the compensatory agreement with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay. The agreement will respect the trading rights of the Eastern Republic of Uruguay and, at the same time, it is a sign of the EU’s attachment to the WTO multilateral rules-based trading regime. It is important to note that the EU will incorporate in its schedule for the customs territory of the EU 28 Uruguay’s specific high-quality beef quota (EU Regulation 481/2012, 48 200 tons). Last but not least, the compensatory agreement will enable Croatia to benefit fully from trade relations between the EU and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay (worth EUR 1.603 million in EU exports to Uruguay and EUR 1.131 million in EU imports from Uruguay).

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. This report analyses the EU-Uruguay agreement on Croatia's accession. This is a necessary act in order to take into account, within the scope of the same, croatia's entry among the 28 Member States.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it accepts that the EU should make reckless tariff concessions.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. In Croatia, the European Union had to renegotiate tariff agreements with Uruguay in accordance with WTO rules. As a result, the European Commission has made two concessions on quotas on beef. In any negotiation, the European Union makes tariff or quota concessions without the opposing party doing the same. This type of relationship is not balanced.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. Following Croatia's accession to the European Union, Croatia had to renegotiate its tariffs with Uruguay, in accordance with WTO rules. Unfortunately, the EU has made two important concessions on beef quotas, while Uruguay has not made any. As this type of commercial relationship is not balanced and strongly unfavourable to our trade and its actors, in this case cattle producers, I logically voted AGAINST this text.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by which Parliament will grant its approval for the conclusion of the Agreement between the Union and Uruguay on the amendment of concessions in Croatia's tariff list under the WTO as a result of its accession to the European Union. Because with Croatia's accession, the Union has expanded its customs union. Accordingly, in accordance with WTO rules, the Union is obliged to enter into negotiations with WTO members who have negotiating rights on Croatia's tariff list, in order to agree on a countervailing adjustment. Thus, the Commission has negotiated with WTO members, in this case Uruguay, who have negotiating rights with respect to the abolition of specific concessions, in relation to the withdrawal of Croatia's tariff list for their entry into the Union.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In line with my previous opposition to the EU-Uruguay Agreement on the World Trade Organization for its defence and promotion of a neoliberal model of international trade, I have also voted against Croatia's accession to it.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ With the accession of Croatia, the EU’s Customs Union grew and consequently the EU was required to negotiate the tariff schedule to incorporate Croatia. I voted in favour of the results of the negotiations between the EU and Uruguay.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. I do not object to Croatia's inclusion in the agreement with Uruguay, which will extend the beef import quota in the context of Croatia's integration into the EU.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒  The purpose of this report  is to conclude an Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and Uruguay pursuant to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade  relating to the modification of concessions in the schedule of Croatia in the course of its accession to the European Union. I support the position that the European Parliament give its consent to the conclusion of the Agreement.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Croatia's accession to the Union has extended the customs union, where the external customs procedure causes tariff increases. WTO rules require compensatory settlements in such cases, which is why the European Parliament has approved the conclusion of an agreement on tariff quotas for beef. In this context, it is necessary for the Commission to submit a proposal for a Regulation adjusting the tariff quotas.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Abstained when voting on the recommendation on the draft Council Decision concerning the conclusion of an Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay, in accordance with Article XXIV(6) and Article XXVIII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GSO) of 1994 amending the concessions provided for in the Table of the Republic of Croatia in the context of its accession to the European Union , because it is not sufficiently documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This report follows Croatia's accession, the European Union had to renegotiate its tariffs with Uruguay. These renegotiations have resulted in new tariff and quota concessions (beef), without consideration from Uruguay. We denounce these unbalanced trade relations.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. – In regards to the proposal concluding an agreement in the form of Exchange Letters between the EU and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay, I voted in favour. I support the strengthening of mutual relations by cooperating in terms of trade, investment, finance and technology, especially now that the bloc welcomed its latest member back in 2013.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. Like the Winkler report, the Zalba Bidegain report, as put to the plenary vote, was intended to have the European Parliament and the Commission and The Council's approach to adjusting the concessions offered by the European Union to Uruguay to the WTO, in order to take account of Croatia's recent accession to the EU and the enlargement of the European market that it has caused. The adjustments made are relatively small, as they are proportional to the small size of the Croatian market: Uruguay will be able to export a slightly larger quantity of beef to the European Union. If I voted for this technical report, I will be very vigilant about the way negotiations between the European Union and the Mercosur countries (Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay, Paraguay) are going to play. A meeting between the relevant trade ministers will take place very soon and Uruguay has already announced its objective of obtaining generous additional export quotas for its beef. I will oppose an agreement that would be at the expense of European livestock, in the midst of a crisis

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union expanded its customs union. Under the agreement, the Commission will harmonise tariffs by means of an implementing regulation and adjust commodity quotas. I am in favour of that.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. The EU Customs Union has expanded following the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. The EU was therefore obliged, in accordance with World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules (Article XXIV(6) of GATT 1994), to open negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay on the tariff schedule for Croatia in order to finally agree on a countervailing adjustment, as the EU's external tariff regime leads to an increase in tariffs.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Uruguay and the EU had customs agreements for the export and import of certain goods, agreed under the WTO's General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). Following Croatia's accession in July 2013, these quotas and tariff quotas must be adapted to a 28-state Union. That is what this decision proposes. I am not only opposed to these latest waves of enlargement but also to the FREE trade model of the WTO. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. In any negotiation, the European Union makes tariff or quota concessions without the opposing party doing the same. This type of relationship is not balanced and is harmful to our interests. So I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the adoption of the draft decision of the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay, in accordance with Article XXIV(6) and Article XXVIII of gatt 1994, on the amendment of concessions provided for in the customs tariff of the Republic of Croatia in the context of the accession of that country to the European Union.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it is important that Croatia, the newest member of our Customs Union, is included in existing conventions and agreements.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. On 1 July 2013, the Republic of Croatia became the 28th Member State of the European Union. At the same time, the European customs union has expanded.  However, under World Trade Organization (WTO) rules, under Article XXIV, paragraph 6, of the 1994 GATT, the European Union had to open negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay on Croatia's list of commitments in order to eventually agree on compensation, as the adoption of the EU's external tariff regime led to an increase in tariffs.  The European Parliament has approved the EU-Uruguay agreement on Croatia's accession, to which I have supported it. The results were negotiated by the Commission in agreement with WTO members with negotiating rights and beef.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which aims to conclude the EU-Uruguay agreement, taking into account the accession of Croatia to the EU and adapting the tariff schedule, as per the WTO requirements. Therefore, I supported the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Agreement, which is a necessary step in order to ensure compliance with WTO rules. After the accession of Croatia, the EU had to launch negotiations with WTO Members holding negotiating rights, amongst which Uruguay, in order to agree on compensatory adjustments linked to the fact that the EU has enlarged its customs union and Croatia has adopted the EU’s external tariff regime, which led to an increase in tariff beyond the level for which Croatia had previously bound itself at the WTO. The outcome of the negotiations with Uruguay is a balanced one, with concessions limited adding 76 tonnes in the country allocated (Uruguay) EU tariff rate quota ‘boneless meat of bovine animals, fresh or chilled’ and respectively 1 875 tonnes into the EU tariff rate quota ‘Meat of bovine animals, frozen’ while maintaining, in both cases, the present in-quota rate of 20%.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Customs Union of the European Union was enlarged. Croatia has thus taken over the EU's external tariff system, resulting in a change in the concessions granted to the Eastern Republic of Uruguay on the country's concession list. The Commission initiated negotiations on the matter on the basis of the Council's authority on 15 July 2013, which resulted in an agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters with Uruguay, which was corked in Nairobi on 18 December 2015. The Council took a decision on the signing of the Agreement on 11 April 2016, but must also obtain the agreement of the European Parliament. In its report, the Committee on International Trade recommends that Parliament agree to the conclusion of the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Following Croatia's accession, the EU had to renegotiate tariff agreements with Uruguay in accordance with WTO rules. As a result, the European Commission has made two concessions on quotas on beef without the opposing side doing the same. This type of relationship is not balanced. Unfavorable vote.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union has extended its customs union. The Eastern Republic of Uruguay is entitled to the re-establishment of its previous trade rights, which have suffered a slight degradation due to the extension of the customs union when Croatia's accession to the Union. In accordance with World Trade Organisation rules, it was for the EU to open negotiations with WTO members who hold negotiating rights related to Croatia's customs tariff.  As the proposal to conclude the agreement proportionately alters the concessions and is consistent with previous practice and the WTO framework, I am in favour of concluding this Agreement.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the EU-Uruguay agreement on Croatia's accession to the EU. The latter had to renegotiate tariff agreements with Uruguay in accordance with WTO rules. Considering that this agreement is very favourable to Uruguay since the Commission has made two concessions on beef quotas without consideration, I have decided to vote against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which asks the Council to adopt a decision to conclude the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters with Uruguay.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to give Parliament's approval to Croatia's accession to the agreement between the EU and Uruguay. Since Croatia joined the European Union only from 1 July 2013, it was not a party to the Convention, whereas as a Member State it has a full place in it. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the agreement between the European Union and Uruguay on the modification of concessions in the list of commitments of the Republic of Croatia as part of its accession to the European Union. The customs union of the European Union was enlarged by the integration of Croatia in 2013. It was then necessary to negotiate compensation with Uruguay to bring the country in line with its WTO commitments.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Eu ropean Union customs union has expanded and as a result there is an obligation to open negotiations with wto partners, in this case Uruguay, in order to agree on possible compensation for the third country in order to balance the increase in tariffs. The aim of the agreement between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay is to simplify and regularise trade, and I therefore voted in favour of the measure.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has a number of external partners, which involves certain duties. It is therefore natural that the expansion with the new Member States could also have an impact on these Allies. As a member of the WTO, the Eastern Republic of Uruguay has rightly requested a review of the agreements so far. I believe that the outcome of the negotiations between the two sides is entirely acceptable to the EU, so I also see this recommendation as appropriate.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) is part of the rules of the World Trade Organisation and regulates international trade. I have voted for this report that will start negotiations with the World Trade Organisation’s Member, Uruguay, regarding the tariff schedule of Croatia following its accession to the European Union thus enlarging its customs. The agreement, in the form of an Exchange of Letters with the Uruguay, will be signed by the European Council on behalf of the European Union, and in the meantime another proposal is being submitted by the European Commission regarding the conclusions of the Agreement.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I abstained on this report. Under the WTO rules, the EU has to negotiate with its partners new conditions due to the accession of Croatia to the EU. The Commission proposes modifications related to tariff rate quotas on bovine meat. The Commission is also preparing an implementing Regulation regarding several tariff rate quotas. The amendment to the Agreement is mainly technical, but because there is a possibility that the modification of the tariff rate quotas on beef may have a small effect on European farmers, including in Ireland, I did not vote in favour but abstained.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report. With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union is expanding its customs union. Under the agreement, the Commission will harmonise tariffs by means of an implementing regulation and adjust commodity quotas.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union expanded its customs union, which requires, in accordance with World Trade Organization (WTO) rules, negotiations with WTO members who have negotiating rights on Croatia's tariff list to agree on a countervailing adjustment. This is the case in Uruguay and is the objective of this Agreement. I therefore give my approval to this report and to the granting of approval to the conclusion of the Agreement.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this as it was merely a technical update to reflect the fact that Croatia has joined the EU since the original agreement was signed with Uruguay.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the EU enlarged its Customs Union and was therefore required under WTO rules (Article XXIV:6 of the GATT 1994) to enter into negotiations to the Eastern Republic of Uruguay regarding the tariff schedule of Croatia in order to eventually agree on a compensatory adjustment as the EU’s external tariff regime results in an increase of tariffs. I voted in favour as trade is one of the key policies for the EU and for the benefit of EU citizens.
