Furthermore, this proposal has no financial impact on expenditure, but has a financial impact on revenue.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. I support the Agreement in the form of amendments to letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay. The agreement is in line with EU practice from previous enlargements and is based on EU practices that are in line with external action policy.  In an agreement concluded by the EU with WTO Member States, the EU undertakes that, at any time of enlargement, a third country importing into the European single market is entitled to higher quotas. With its accession to the EU, the Republic of Croatia has certainly contributed to the expansion of this market, and as a Croatian representative, I hope that the Republic of Croatia will also be able to benefit from this compensation agreement. With Croatia's accession to the European Union, the Union has expanded its borders, which means for the Eastern Republic of Uruguay to increase quotas when exporting products to the EU, but also additional reliefs for the EU when exporting products to Uruguay.  This agreement is further proof that the EU supports the multilateral trading system but also respects WTO commercial rules.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Following Croatia's accession, the EU had to renegotiate tariff agreements with Uruguay in accordance with WTO rules. The European Commission has made two concessions on quotas on beef. In any negotiation, the European Union makes tariff or quota concessions without the opposing party doing the same. This type of relationship is not balanced. I therefore vote against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union expanded its customs union and therefore, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules (Article XXIV(6) of gatt 1994), had to initiate negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay regarding Croatia's tariff schedule in order to eventually agree on a countervailing adjustment as the external tariff system leads to an increase in customs duties.  The negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay resulted in a draft Agreement initialled on 18 December 2015 in Nairobi. At the same time, a separate proposal on the signature of this Agreement was submitted and the Council decision on the signature was adopted on 11 April 2016. The European Union will include in its schedule for the EU customs area 28 concessions contained in eu schedule 27 with amendments related to tariff quotas for beef.  The European Commission is also preparing an implementing regulation on several tariff quotas. Taking into account the draft Agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay on the basis of Article XXIV(6) and Article XXVIII. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) of 1994 with regard to the amendment of concessions in the schedule of the Republic of Croatia as part of its accession to the European Union (06871/2016), I support the position on the conclusion of the Agreement.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU's external tariff leads to an increase in customs duties. It was therefore necessary for the European Parliament to approve this report in order to give its consent to the conclusion of an agreement between the EU and Uruguay in the form of an Exchange of Letters on amendments to concessions in the Charter of the Republic of Croatia during its accession to the European Union.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Union expanded its customs union and was therefore obliged, in accordance with WTO rules (Article XXIV(6) of gatt in 1994) to open negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay with regard to Croatia's tariff, with a view to possibly agreeing a compensatory adjustment since the EU's external tariff regime entails an increase in tariffs. I welcome the fact that the negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay have been successfully concluded because I consider Latin America to be a source of great development opportunities for the world economy and in particular for the European common market. I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the EU has expanded the customs union. It was therefore obliged to open negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay on croatia's concession list. The aim of these negotiations was to agree on a level playing field, as the EU's external tariff system increases rates. Negotiations with Uruguay led to a draft agreement in 2015 agreeing on compensation for tariff quotas for bovine meat. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report, which is part of Croatia's accession to the European Union. With an additional Member State, the EU has expanded its customs union and has therefore been required to clarify technical rules, formalised by an agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and Uruguay.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. On 1 July 2013 Croatia became the 28th Member State of the Union, thus extending the number of countries in the customs union. In accordance with World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, it is for the Union to renegotiate the terms of the trade agreements underlying WTO tariffs in the event of an increase in its customs union. To this end, the Commission has negotiated with Uruguay the application of some compensatory instruments on some commercial rights. This agreement guarantees the proportionality of the concessions of each party and is also consistent with the WTO framework. In compliance with Article XXIV(4) of the GATT, in so far as a customs union or free trade area should aim to facilitate trade between the constituent territories and not create barriers to their trade, as well as because I believe that compensatory adjustments are appropriate, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this as it was merely a technical update to reflect the fact that Croatia has joined the EU since the original agreement was signed with Uruguay

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of considering the relationship between the EU and the Republic of Uruguay important, not only, but also, with regard to the conclusion of the draft decision of the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay, pursuant to Article XXIV(6) and Article XXVIII of gatt 1994 , on the amendment of concessions provided for in the customs tariff of the Republic of Croatia in the context of croatia's accession to the European Union. The EU has extended its customs union, complying with WTO rules, and will open negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay on croatia's customs tariff in order to agree on a possible compensatory adjustment, as the EU's external tariff regime results in an increase in customs duties. The EU will include the EU-27 tariff on the EU-28 customs territory with changes to tariff quotas applied to beef. In addition, the Commission is preparing, in the context of the agreement, an implementing regulation on the different tariff quotas.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is only a technical document on the EU-Uruguay agreement, taking into account Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting approval for the conclusion of the Agreement between the Union and Uruguay on the amendment of concessions to Croatia's WTO tariff list as a result of its accession to the Union. With Croatia's accession, the European Union has expanded its customs union. Accordingly, in accordance with WTO rules, the Union is obliged to enter into negotiations with WTO members who have negotiating rights on Croatia's tariff list, in order to agree on a countervailing adjustment. Thus, the Commission has negotiated with WTO members, in this case Uruguay, who have negotiating rights with respect to the abolition of specific concessions, in relation to the withdrawal of Croatia's tariff list for their entry into the Union.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Following Croatia's accession, the European Union has expanded its customs union. It was then required, under World Trade Organization (WTO) rules, to open negotiations with WTO members with negotiating rights in the lists of one of the member countries in order to agree compensation. Like the vast majority of MEPs, I consider the outcome of these negotiations with China and Uruguay acceptable, which is why I have decided to vote in favour of these acts.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report. Following the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, the EU's customs union has expanded. The European Union was therefore obliged to open negotiations with wto negotiating members on croatia's tariff list with a view to finally agreeing a compensatory adjustment. The EU will include in its tariff list of 28 countries a tariff list of 27 countries, as amended as regards tariff quotas for beef. The European Commission is currently also preparing an implementing regulation on several tariff quotas relating to the Agreement. The consent of the European Parliament to this Council Decision shall be a binding component of the completion of the ratification process of this Additional Protocol.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. 'U2012 Croatia's accession to the European Union has resulted in an extension of its customs union, resulting in the need for compensatory adjustments to some trade agreements, bearing in mind that the EU's external tariff regime results in an increase in customs duties. This was the case under the EU-Uruguay Agreement, with changes to tariff quotas applied to beef. As a compensatory measure that meets the criteria of coherence and proportionality, as well as the rules of the World Trade Organisation and its multilateral trading regime, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Union has expanded its customs union and has therefore been obliged, under WTO rules (Article XXIV, paragraph 6, of the 1994 GATT), to open negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay with regard to Croatia's list of commitments in order to possibly agree on compensation , the adoption of the EU's external tariff regime resulting in an increase in tariffs. It is in this sense that I supported this report on the agreement between the EU and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay on the modification of concessions in the list of commitments of the Republic of Croatia as part of its accession to the EU.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report necessary to formalise Croatia's access to the European Union.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the EU-Uruguay agreement with a view to amending the concessions in the list of specific commitments of the Republic of Croatia. The background is that Croatia's accession to the EU in 2013 extended the customs union, thus obliging the EU, in accordance with WTO rules, to open negotiations with WTO Member States on compensatory arrangements if they have negotiating rights with regard to Croatia's tariff. Such compensation must be made if the adoption of the EU customs tariff results in tariffs exceeding the level to which the acceding country originally committed to the WTO.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In line with my previous opposition to the EU-Uruguay Agreement on the World Trade Organization for its defence and promotion of a neoliberal model of international trade, I have also voted against Croatia's accession to it.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as it is a technical update to an already established agreement.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – With the accession of Croatia, the EU enlarged its customs union. Consequently, it was required under WTO rules to enter into negotiations with WTO members in relation to the tariff schedule of Croatia in order eventually to agree on a compensatory adjustment.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing \ u2012 I voted in favour. With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the EU has extended its customs union and, under WTO rules (Article XXIV 6 of GATT 1994), it was therefore required to negotiate with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay the list of tariff concessions of Croatia. The aim was a possible compensatory settlement agreement, as the EU's external customs regime has resulted in tariff increases. The European Union shall include in its schedule for the customs territory of the EU-28 concessions for the customs territory of the EU-27 with changes to the tariff quotas for beef.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Following the accession of Croatia, the EU Customs Union was enlarged and trade relations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay had to be settled with regard to the tariff concessions deed. Under WTO rules, in the light of the GATT 1994, the EU was required to adjust its tariff quotas or to agree a compensatory settlement with Uruguay. The agreement with Uruguay was finally negotiated in Nairobi at the end of 2015. According to it, the EU will include in its customs territory amendments to tariff quotas, in particular for beef. In addition, the Commission is preparing an implementing regulation on several other tariff quotas. As this is about levelling the playing field between Uruguay and the EU under WTO rules, I supported the conclusion of this agreement. This will contribute to maintaining trust between countries respecting the principles of international trade relations.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 The extension of international agreements concluded by the EU with third countries to the new Member States is a practical expression of one of the pillars of the European Union, the common and single market.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I abstained from the European Parliament's resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and the Republic of Eastern Uruguay in accordance with Article XXIV(6) and Article XXVIII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) 1994, in connection with the amendment of the concessions in the list of specific commitments of the Republic of Croatia in the course of its accession to the European Union. I am opposed to the extension of the EU to include other Member States, so that I cannot, in any case, agree to the adaptation of the various international treaties to Croatia's accession.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union has expanded its customs union. In view of World Trade Organisation rules, the European Union had to launch negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay regarding Croatia's tariff schedule in order to eventually agree a compensatory adjustment, as the external tariff system leads to an increase in tariffs. I support the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay on the basis of Article XXIV(6) and Article XXVIII. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) of 1994 with regard to the amendment of concessions in the schedule of the Republic of Croatia as part of its accession to the European Union, as well as the consent for the conclusion of the agreement.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of an Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay pursuant to Article XXIV:6 and Article XXVIII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) 1994 concerning the amendment of the concessions in the list of concessions of the Republic of Croatia in the context of its accession to the European Union.  Croatia's accession to the European Union has also increased the customs union. As these tariffs increased, the EU had to agree with Uruguay on a final compensatory adjustment. That is why we need this agreement.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's consent to the conclusion of an agreement between the EU and Uruguay in connection with Croatia's accession to the EU, thereby extending the EU customs union, and was therefore obliged under EU WTO rules to open negotiations with Uruguay on the Charter of Tariff Concessions of Croatia. This is a logical step following the enlargement of the EU to croatia, which is a positive circumstance not only for Croatia, but also for the existing EU Member States.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This agreement will result in the restoration of Uruguay's previous trading rights, which have been affected by the enlargement of the EU customs union with the accession of Croatia.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the Customs Union of the European Union was enlarged. Consequently, under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union is obliged to open negotiations with wto member states in which Croatia has so far held a so-called concessionary tariff wall. This will be necessary if, as a result of accession to the Union tariff system, the increase in the tariff level for this reason exceeds that undertaken by the acceding country in the WTO. As a result of the negotiations with Uruguay, the draft agreement was corked in Nairobi on 18 December 2015, after which the Council adopted a decision on the signature of the draft on 11 April 2015. I voted in favour of this report because the European Parliament's agreement with this Council decision is necessary for the ratification of the Additional Protocol.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With Croatia's accession, the EU expanded its customs union and was therefore obliged to start negotiations with Uruguay on the Croatian State customs tariff. This document on the agreement between the EU and Uruguay takes into account Croatia's accession to the EU and provides for an adaptation of the charging programme in line with WTO requirements.  I believe that now is an opportune time for the conclusion of the new agreement and, for this reason, I am voting for its support.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I have given my approval to the conclusion of the agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay under Article XXIV, paragraph 6, and Article XXVIII of the 1994 General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) on the modification of concessions in the Republic of Croatia's list of commitments as part of its accession to the European Union.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ When the Republic of Croatia joined the EU in 2013, the EU’s customs union was enlarged. Under WTO rules, it was therefore required to enter into negotiations with Uruguay regarding the tariff schedule of Croatia in order to agree on a compensatory adjustment, as the EU’s external tariff regime had seen its tariffs increase. This is why I voted in favour of the EU-Uruguay Agreement relating to the accession of Croatia. The EU will now incorporate in its schedule for the customs territory of the EU 28 that of the EU 27, with modifications regarding the tariff rate quotas on bovine meat.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the EU-Uruguay agreement related to croatia's accession.  With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union has had to increase its customs union and, in accordance with World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules (Article XXIV:6 of GATT 1994), it had to open negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay on croatia's customs tariffs in order to agree on a final compensatory adjustment, as the EU's external tariff regime has increased tariffs.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report necessary to formalise Croatia's access to the European Union.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 As a result of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, the East Republic of Uruguay had to compensate for the withdrawal of concession lists and the increase in tariffs in connection with the EU external customs tariff, based on WTO rules. Facilitating trade by removing barriers is an important objective of international trade policy, which is why I supported the above-called resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The rapporteur considers that the European Parliament should give its consent to the conclusion of an Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay in accordance with Articles XXIV and XXVIII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) of 1994, amending the concessions on the Republic of Croatia's concession list during its accession to the European Union. I agreed with him.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report necessary to formalise Croatia's access to the European Union.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I believe that the European Parliament should approve the conclusion of an Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay pursuant to Article XXIV:6 and Article XXVIII of GATT 1994 on the amendment of concessions to the list of concessions in the republic of Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Eastern Republic of Uruguay pursuant to Article XXIV:6 and Article XXVIII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) 1994 relating to the modification of concessions in the schedule of the Republic of Croatia in the course of its accession to the European Union. With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the EU enlarged its customs union and was therefore required under WTO rules to enter into negotiations to the Eastern Republic of Uruguay regarding the tariff schedule of Croatia in order to eventually agree on a compensatory adjustment as the EU’s external tariff regime results in an increase of tariffs. Following the negotiations, the EU will incorporate in its schedule for the customs territory of the EU 28 that of the EU 27 with modifications related to tariff rate quotas on bovine meat.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Following Croatia's accession, the Union, under the rules of the World Trade Organization, has agreed on a number of compensation adjustments in the Agreement between the Union and Uruguay. We are talking about a balanced agreement which has been reached by the Commission, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour of its proposal.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this recommendation. With the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the European Union has expanded its customs union. Consequently, under world trade organisation (WTO) rules, the European Union had to open negotiations with the Republic east of Uruguay on Croatia's tariff list in order to finally agree on a compensatory arrangement, as the EU's external tariff leads to higher tariffs. As the EU expands, it must adapt to the existing situation each time it concludes previously concluded treaties or agreements. In this case, therefore, the agreement with Uruguay because of croatia's accession.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the accession of the Republic of Croatia, the EU has extended its customs union, complying with WTO rules (Article XXIV(6) of gatt 1994) to initiate negotiations with the Eastern Republic of Uruguay on croatia's customs tariff in order to reach agreement on possible compensatory adjustment. Negotiations with Uruguay resulted in a draft agreement initialled on 18 December 2015 in Nairobi. A proposal on the signing of this agreement was also presented and the Council Decision on signature took place on 11 April 2016. The adoption by the European Parliament of this Council Decision is a mandatory element in completing the process of ratification of the Additional Protocol. While these free trade agreements deserve our repudiation of their consequences on local economies, we believe that countries should be able to establish fully the trade agreements they sovereignly understand. For this reason, our vote to abstain

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Croatia's accession to the EU has also expanded the Customs Union. This proposal is a technical agreement which re-regulates quotas for certain agricultural products between the EU and Uruguay following the accession of Croatia. I have therefore voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I am very grateful for the support that this report has received. The current tariff regime needed to be adapted. Parliament has done well to give its consent to the conclusion of the agreement between the Union and the Republic of Uruguay, since as a result of the enlargement of the customs union following Croatia's accession and in compliance with WTO rules, it is necessary to examine a possible compensatory adjustment of the current tariff regime.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ Since Croatia's accession to the European Union also increased in 2013, negotiations on compensatory settlements need to be opened under World Trade Organisation rules. Such negotiations must be held when, as a result of the enlargement of the Customs Union, the duties originally agreed are mentioned. And since, even in the case of Uruguay, such a change has taken place, namely for beef, I supported the agreement.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 There is a clear gender imbalance in the composition of the members of the Court of Auditors: we have only 4 women out of 28 members. If the following candidate is nominated, this imbalance would be further accentuated. Furthermore, there is no real democratic control of appointments, as Parliament does not have binding power in this matter. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of renewing the mandate of Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a member of the Court of Auditors. The latter proved that he was competent and well qualified for the position.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is the renewal of a member of the European Court of Auditors. The European Parliament is consulted on this appointment. The candidate in question, Cypriot Lazaros Stravrou Lazarou, has been a member of the Association of Chartered Accountants since 1987, a graduate in international taxation and a member of the Court since 2010. He was successively a member of the Chambers of Conservation and Management of Natural Resources, Structural Policies, Transport and Energy, and then a non-permanent member of the horizontal chamber "Coordination, Evaluation, Insurance and Development". Since 2014, he has been a member responsible for the declaration of insurance on the accounts of the European Union. Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou, a pure product of European nomenklatura, is seeking a new mandate. I abstained.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this appointment as advocated by the committee on the merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of appointing Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a Member of the Court of Auditors. Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou member of the European Court of Auditors since 2010. As a member of the Court of Auditors, he made a constructive contribution to the Court's work and to the implementation of the 2013-2017 strategy. He also contributed to the efforts to improve the annual reports to the European Parliament.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou has been seeking a new mandate as a member of the European Court of Auditors since 2010.  I abstained on the renewal of the mandate of this pure product of the Eurocratic nomenklatura.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved Mr Lazarou's appointment to the Court of Auditors, following the recommendation of the Committee on Budgetary Control.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is an important European institution which acts as an external and independent auditor of the Union. Founded in 1977, it only became a fully-capacity EU institution in 1993 and continued to provide support for improving the management of the European budget. It shall consist of one member from each State of the Union, each of whom shall be appointed by the Council after consulting Parliament and shall remain in office for six years. On this occasion, Parliament was called upon to give its opinion on the appointment of Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou. Having taken note of the content of the report by the Committee on Budgetary Control and following the advice of my political group, the S&D voted in secret on the proposed name.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This candidacy for the Court of Auditors has been voted on. Curriculum vitae well trained. In principle, I can't find any data to object to. Despite this, it should be remembered that the institution still does not receive candidates. I vote favorably.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. We consider that we are taking the favourable opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control, that Mr Lazaros Stavrou's curriculum, as the results of his five September hearing, establish him as an appropriate candidate for his appointment as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on the appointment of Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a member of the Court of Auditors. The Cypriot has been a member since 2010. Certainly, his background shows that he has the profile, since he has a degree in international taxation and notably a member of the Association of Chartered Accountants since 1987. However, his background in the Court of Auditors attests to his membership in this European oligarchy: a member of the Chamber of Conservation and Management of Natural Resources, or of the Chamber of Structural Policies, Transport and Energy. It is difficult to see how, since 2010, his work has helped to advance the public interest.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not question the professional skills of this candidate, but I do not have sufficient evidence to give him my full support. That is why I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This morning the Plenary of the European Parliament put to the vote, in secret, the proposal to appoint Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a member of the Court of Auditors, following the evaluation of the candidate's qualifications, the hearing held on 5 September before the Committee on Budgetary Control and his favourable opinion, a vote in which I participated.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported the Council's proposal to appoint Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a Member of the Court of Auditors of Cyprus. This decision was adopted by Parliament in the light of the assessment of the qualifications of the candidate proposed by the Committee on Budgetary Control, in particular in the light of the requirements laid down in Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This text deals with the renewal of a mandate of a member of the European Court of Auditors. The European Parliament is therefore consulted for opinion in the appointment of Cypriot Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou. A member of the Association of Chartered Accountants since 1987 and then a graduate in international taxation, the candidate has been a member of the Court since 2010 and has been responsible for the european Union's account insurance declaration since 2014. Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou, a pure product of European nomenklatura, is seeking a new mandate. I abstained on this appointment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I believe that the appointment of Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a member of the Court of Auditors is relevant and appropriate. The professional qualifications of dr. Lazarou are notable: member of the Association of Certified Accountants registered in the Register (ACCA) since 1987, member of the Cypriot Institute of Public Auditors empowered since 1988, member of the European Court of Auditors since 2 November 2010, dean of Section V "Financing and Administration of the Union" and member for the annual report from the June 2016 marketing year. From February 2014 to May 2016, Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou served as a permanent member of the CEAD Section "Coordination, Evaluation, Reliability and Development" and as a member responsible for the Statement of Assurance. The personal objectives set are of considerable ambition: to contribute constructively to the work of the Court and, as Dean of Section V, to prepare and chair meetings, to coordinate tasks and to ensure that the work of the Section proceeds quickly. As a member of the Administrative Committee, the candidate would like to contribute to the implementation of the Court's strategy for 2013-2017 by establishing the annual work programme outlining the priorities, development and implementation of the 2018-2022 strategy.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the appointment of Lazarus Stavros Lazaros, as he meets all the criteria.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The appointment of Lazaros Stavros as a member of the Court of Auditors was a good step as his experience and knowledge guarantee a positive contribution to the Court's work. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I wish to respect the privacy of the secret ballot and not disclose my voting intentions.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The candidacy of Lazaros Stavrou as a member of the Court of Auditors has been successfully assessed by the Committee on Budgetary Control. Congratulating him on the appointment of Lazaros Stavrou, I wish him well in his work.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – I have no reason not to support the CONT members’ decision to grant favourable opinion on the Council’s nomination of Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a Member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I support the nomination of Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou, appointed by the Government of Cyprus, as a candidate for a member of the Court of Auditors. Mr Lazarou has been a member of the European Court of Auditors since 2 November 2010, I have no objections to his previous work, I appreciate his experience in this sector in both EU and national areas (he served as chief accounting officer of the Republic of Cyprus, head of the certification body for EU funds, head of the public procurement body and member of the Internal Audit Board of the Republic of Cyprus (January 2000 to October 2010)).

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the renewal of Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou’s mandate as a member of the Court of Auditors, as I believe that he has proved himself competent and well qualified for the post.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) has auditioned three candidates for nomination to the Court of Auditors, proposed by three Member States: Malta's Leo Brincat, Portugal's Joao Figueiredo and Cypriot Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou.  Considering that after a hearing, the members of the committee have validated these three appointments as long as the candidates meet the expectations of Parliament and the Court of Auditors, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Parliament is consulted on the renewal of the mandate of a member of the Court of Auditors. Cypriot Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou, a member of the Association of Chartered Accountants since 1987, has a degree in international taxation and has been a member of the Court of Auditors since 2010. Since 2014, he has been a member responsible for the declaration of insurance on the accounts of the European Union. I abstained on this text.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The selection of persons for positions of responsibility should be based on the integrity of their character and their proven activity with regard to the protection of public money in the broad sense.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Abstention: pure product of the European nomenklatura, Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou seeks a new mandate.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The ECA operates as a collegiate body of 28 Members, one from each Member State. The Members are appointed by the Council after consultation with the European Parliament for a renewable term of six years. Members elect one of their number as President for a renewable term of three years. The nomination of Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou (CY) is for a renewal of his current mandate – he has been a Member of the ECA since 2010. Therefore, it could be expected that the appointments procedure progresses smoothly. His hearing took place in the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) on Monday 5 September where he was approved by a large majority. I supported the candidate at the plenary stage.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the reappointment of Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a member of the Court of Auditors, as I consider the Cypriot auditor to be a suitable candidate.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report - the mandate of the Mr Lazarou should be renewed as he has proved himself competent and well-qualified in that time.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This candidacy for the Court of Auditors has been voted on. Curriculum vitae well trained. In principle, I can't find any data to object to. Despite this, it should be remembered that the institution still does not receive candidates. I vote favorably.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted for the Proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament on the proposed appointment of Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a member of the Court of Auditors, on the ground that I consider that the qualifications of the proposed candidate meet the conditions necessary to appoint Mr Lazarou as a member of the Court of Auditors.  His professional career and experience in the state bodies of the Republic of Cyprus and in international audit institutions are surely a guarantee that Mr Lazarou will continue as a member of the Court of Auditors professionally, consistently and conscientiously.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Mr. Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou has been a member of the Association of Chartered Accountants since 1987, a graduate in international taxation and a member of the Court since 2010. He was successively a member of the Chambers of Conservation and Management of Natural Resources, Structural Policies, Transport and Energy, and then a non-permanent member of the horizontal chamber "Coordination, Evaluation, Insurance and Development". Since 2014, he has been a member responsible for the declaration of insurance on the accounts of the European Union. If he seems to have the necessary skills for this job, Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou is also a member of the Brussels nomenklatura: I abstained for this vote.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Igor Soltes' report on the appointment of Mr Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a member of the Court of Auditors. This text approves the application proposed by the Council after a hearing by the Committee on Budgetary Control, attesting to the competences required to carry out this function.  This appointment was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. As recommended by the CONT committee that heard Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou, I voted in favour of his appointment.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Mr Lazarou is from Cyprus and has been a member of the European Court of Auditors since 2010. Unfortunately, Mr Lazarou has not produced a satisfactory proof of success in recent years.  That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. – I supported the report on the proposal to appoint Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a Member of the Court of Auditors, as Mr Lazarou has the necessary qualifications and experience as a member of the Court of Auditors since 2010.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The application proposed by the Council to appoint Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou Lazarou as a member of the Court of Auditors was deemed valid following a thorough analysis of the applicant's credentials and personal background.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the appointment of Mr Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou to the Court of Auditors.  He has been a member of the Court since 2010. He was successively a member of the Chambers of Conservation and Management of Natural Resources, Structural Policies, Transport and Energy, and then a non-permanent member of the horizontal chamber "Coordination, Evaluation, Insurance and Development". Since 2014, he has been a member responsible for the declaration of insurance on the accounts of the European Union. It is a pure product of European nomenklatura.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This report defends the "renewal" of the mandate of a member of the European Court of Auditors.  In this case, Mr. Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou, already a member since 2010, is seeking a new mandate. He has also been a member of the Association of Chartered Accountants since 1987 and has a degree in international taxation.  He is also an unreasable figure because he is pure product of the European nomenklatura, but he remains a member of a respectable institution, whose work is often to be commended. I opted for abstention on this report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Despite his qualification for this position, the nominee has publicly expressed himself about his political affinities, which may compromise his neutrality. That's why I abstained.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the Committee on Budgetary Control interviewed the candidate and positively assessed his/her qualifications, professional experience and experience to date, in particular as a member of the European Court of Auditors. I supported the proposal to appoint him as a Member of the Court of Auditors on the basis of a positive evaluation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposed appointment of Lazarus Lazarus as a member of the Court of Auditors, as I do not agree with key points in that report.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. The European Parliament is consulted on the renewal of the mandate of a member of the Court of Auditors. Cypriot Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou, a member of the Association of Chartered Accountants since 1987, has a degree in international taxation and has been a member of the Court of Auditors since 2010. Since 2014, he has been a member responsible for the declaration of insurance on the accounts of the European Union.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Council's proposal to appoint The Court of Auditors' Commissioner Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou from Cyprus. This decision was taken by Parliament on the basis of an assessment of the qualifications of the candidate proposed by the Committee on Budgetary Control.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou has made a career as a senior civil servant. He was general accountant of the Republic of Cyprus, responsible for constitutional and legal control as well as the management of public financial transactions.  He is not a member of any political party, has never held a representative mandate and has previously served as a member of the European Court of Auditors.  I vote against his appointment in remembrance of the shameful aggression of Cyprus by the ECB, to which this gentleman has found nothing wrong.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. A member of the Association of Chartered Accountants since 1987, a graduate in international taxation, the candidate has been a member of the Court since 2010. He was successively a member of the Chambers of Conservation and Management of Natural Resources, Structural Policies, Transport and Energy, and then a non-permanent member of the horizontal chamber "Coordination, Evaluation, Insurance and Development". Since 2014, he has been a member responsible for the declaration of insurance on the accounts of the European Union. Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou, despite a certain experience, represents a caste of the European Union that we would like to see evolve. So I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is a supervisory institution, which verifies the legality and regularity of eu revenue and expenditure, as well as good financial management, carrying out its functions with complete independence.  In this spirit, the appointment of the individualities that compose it must be governed by criteria of competence and independence.  Mr Lazaros Stravrou Lazarou presented his Curriculum Vitae, replied to a written questionnaire and was heard in the Committee on Budgetary Control, and he made sufficient arguments to justify the appointment to the Court of Auditors to carry out his duties in a competent and independent manner. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I support the candidacy of Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou following his appointment by the Council, approved by the European Parliament, to serve as a member of the Court of Auditors.  Both Mr. Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou's academic training and the professional background - dedicated to the fields of public finance, management or management control - attest to his competence in carrying out the functions of a member of the Court of Auditors with mastery. Especially since Mr Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou already has experience as a member of the Court of Auditors following his first appointment by the Council in 2010.  I am convinced that Mr Lazaros Stavrou's know-how, his sense of responsibility and his knowledge of the institution are an asset to the Court of Auditors.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou has been a member of the Court of Auditors since 2010. At the end of its mandate, the Council intends to appoint Mr Lazarou for a new term, but it must also consult the European Parliament. In its report, the Committee on Budgetary Control indicated that it had assessed the capabilities of the proposed candidate and had listened to the candidate at its meeting on 5 September 2016. On this basis, it proposes that Parliament give a favourable opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a Member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Parliament is consulted on the appointment of a member of the Court of Auditors.  A member of the Association of Chartered Accountants since 1987, a graduate in international taxation, the candidate has been a member of the Court since 2010.  He was successively a member of the chambers of "conservation and management of natural resources", "structural policies, transport and energy" and then a non-permanent member of the horizontal chamber "Coordination, evaluation, insurance and development".  Since 2014, he has been a member responsible for the declaration of insurance on the accounts of the European Union. Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou, a pure product of European nomenklatura, is seeking a new mandate.  Forbearance.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the assessment of the qualifications of the proposed candidate and his hearing of the candidate proposed by the Council for the post of member of the Court of Auditors, by the Committee on Budgetary Control, I give my assent to the Council's proposal for the appointment of Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on Mr Stavrou's appointment, as it is a pure product of the European 'establishment'.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which approves the appointment of Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a member of the Court of Auditors.  Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou was heard by the Committee on Budgetary Control. The members of this committee approved this nomination by a very large majority.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the nomination of Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of renewing the mandate of the Cypriot member, Lazaros Lazarou, who has been a member of the Court of Auditors since 2010 and I wish him good continuity in his work.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. On the basis of Mr Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou's CV, as well as those of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I support the appointment of Mr Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a member of the European Court of Auditors. His work highlights the performance of the duties of Article I of the Audit Chamber "Preservation and Management of Natural Resources", the duties of Article II of the Audit Council "Structural Policy, Transport and Energy" and the performance of the duties of interim member of the horizontal audit council CEAD "Coordination, assessment, assurance and development".  He worked with the European Commission to conduct work on quantifying public procurement errors and setting an earlier date for the publication of the annual report and monitoring progress towards this objective. In his work he has shown himself to be a professional, responsible, competent and honest person. He has outstanding auditing skills and experience as he specialises in the field of auditing.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This is the renewal of the mandate of a member of the European Court of Auditors. The European Parliament is consulted on this appointment.  A member of the Association of Chartered Accountants since 1987, a graduate in international taxation, the candidate has been a member of the Court since 2010. He was successively a member of the Chambers of Conservation and Management of Natural Resources, Structural Policies, Transport and Energy, and then a non-permanent member of the horizontal chamber "Coordination, Evaluation, Insurance and Development". Since 2014, he has been a member responsible for the declaration of insurance on the accounts of the European Union.  Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou, a pure product of European nomenklatura, is seeking a new mandate. Faced with such a profile, I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Since the Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the qualifications of the proposed candidate, in particular in terms of the conditions set out in Article 286(1) of the EIA. agreement on the functioning of the European Union and gave a positive opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Lazaros Stavro Lazarou as a member of the Court of Auditors, I support the rapporteur's position.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the case of Mr Lazarou, this is a renewal of the previous mandate. I supported his renewed nomination as a member of the European Court of Auditors, with whom we cooperate intensively within the Committee on Budgetary Control. The European Court of Auditors consists of a college of 28 members, each nominated from one EU Member State. Their mandate can be renewed. I have already supported Mr Lazarou in the committee vote, as his previous work has confirmed his excellent qualifications for the post.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. We have been asked to rule on the appointment of a member of the European Court of Auditors. This procedure demonstrates the usefulness of Parliament in exercising its control over the functioning of the European institutions.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 After the committee on budgetary control's assessment of the qualifications of Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou and after the candidate's hearing, I voted in favour and this report gives its assent to the Council's proposal for the appointment of Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. This morning the Plenary of the European Parliament put to the vote, in secret, the proposal to appoint Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a member of the Court of Auditors, following the evaluation of the candidate's qualifications, the hearing held on 5 September before the Committee on Budgetary Control and his favourable opinion, a vote in which I participated.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of appointing Mr Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a member of the Court of Auditors for a second term, in terms of his experience and objectives.  Mr Stavrou said he wanted to contribute to the implementation of the 2013-2017 strategy and to the development and implementation of the 2018-2022 strategy, with an emphasis on regular exchanges with the European Parliament (via the CONT Committee) and on the reliability of the information on which to base the annual report.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on the proposal to appoint Lazaros As A Member of the Court of Auditors. He holds a Bachelor's degree in Economics from Halo University and a master's degree in public administration from the J.F. Kennedy School of Public Administration at the University of Hull. He has been a member of the European Court of Auditors since 2 November 2010 and is seeking a further term of office. It is clear that he has the necessary expertise and experience to continue this work.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The selection procedure for this post was carried out in an open and transparent manner, and I therefore voted in favour of the appointment of Lazaros Stavrou as Member of the Court of Auditors, since at the hearing by the Committee on Budgetary Control Lazaros Stravou demonstrated that he has proven competence and professional experience for the performance of the duties to be assigned to him.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This candidacy for the Court of Auditors has been voted on. Curriculum vitae well trained. In principle, I can't find any data to object to. Despite this, it should be remembered that the institution still does not receive candidates. I vote favorably.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I have decided to support candidate Lazarou for appointment as a Member of the Court of Auditors. His hearing on the Committee on Budgetary Control went smoothly and received a great deal of support. Mr Lazarou joined the Court of Auditors back in 2010 and is now seeking renewal of his mandate. According to the information available, he has proved himself in his position and his professional experience to date also shows that he is well equipped for this task. He has been devoted to state revenues from taxes and fees since 1989 and in 2000 became head of the State Treasury of the Republic of Cyprus. In this role, he was also head of the EU Funding Certification Body, head of the public procurement body and finally a member of the Internal Audit Board of Cyprus. Since 2010, as a member of the European Court of Auditors, he has kept a number of special reports in various thematic areas, from the protection and management of natural resources, to structural policies to transport and energy. I believe that his experience will also benefit the Court of Auditors for the future. I wish him every success during his new mandate.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 The Court of Auditors is an important institution that oversees the efficient allocation of resources. Having declared, together with the European Commission, the fight against financial fraud, its importance will grow; Mr Lazarou, with his professional career, fulfils all the conditions to be of benefit to the work of the Court of Auditors.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I abstained on the nomination. I don't know the candidate.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control, assessing the qualifications of the proposed candidate, within the meaning of the conditions set out in Article 286(1) of the Code of Health. The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and after the hearing of the Council candidates for membership in the Court of Auditors, gave a positive opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Lazaros Stavro Lazarou as a member of the Court of Auditors. I support the proposal for a decision on the proposed appointment, as I consider parliament's Committee competent to give a relevant opinion on the qualifications of candidates.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The selection of persons for positions of responsibility should be based on the integrity of their character and their proven activity with regard to the protection of public money in the broad sense.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of renewing the nomination of Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a Member of the Court of Auditors. Based on his long-standing experience in public service in Cyprus as well as his valuable performance as a Member of the Court of Auditors until now, I am certain that Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou will continue to perform his job at the best of his capacity and in the best interest of the European citizens.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I have supported the reappointment of Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou as a member of the Court of Auditors, as Lazarou has been performing his duties in various positions in the Court since November 2010 to verify the correctness of the collection and use of EU funding. As Lazarou has highlighted the objectives for the future mandate, I believe he will continue to perform his duties as a member of the Court of Auditors fairly and effectively.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Budgetary Control has assessed the candidate's recommendations, in particular in the light of the requirements of Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.  I voted in my own right.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This candidacy for the Court of Auditors has been voted on. Curriculum vitae well trained. In principle, I can't find any data to object to. Despite this, it should be remembered that the institution still does not receive candidates. I vote favorably.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This is the renewal of the mandate of a member of the European Court of Auditors, Mr Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou. The European Parliament is consulted on this appointment. name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 It was necessary to appoint two new members of the Court of Auditors and extend the mandate by a third party. The procedure provides that the members of the Court of Auditors shall be chosen from among persons who are or have been members of the external audit institutions in their respective States or who have a specific qualification for that function and who must offer all the guarantees of independence. The three candidates present a rather varied curriculum, which led me to cast different votes. Despite the undoubted qualification of the Cypriot candidate, I abstained, mainly for two reasons. Firstly, there is still a lack of a certain "gender equality" in the candidates submitted. Indeed, the Court of Auditors already has a fairly marked imbalance – out of 28 Members only 4 are women – and I believe that the Member States and the Council should send out a signal to promote gender equality in all institutions and at all levels. Furthermore, the fact that Parliament's vote is not binding has in the past created friction between Parliament itself and the Council. In fact, there is no real democratic control in the choice of candidate and the nomination turns out to be purely "political".

Furthermore, there is no real democratic control of appointments, as Parliament does not have binding power in this matter. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

Mr Figueiredo is currently a judge at the Portuguese Court of Auditors and has previously worked as Secretary of State and Director-General in public administration. His extensive experience in various areas of public administration guarantees that he will benefit from the work of the European Court of Auditors. In particular, the fact that he participated in Portugal's general accounts, the planning and control of public expenditure, as well as his long-term involvement with the Portuguese Ministry of Finance, convinced me that he was well prepared for this function. I believe that he will exercise his mandate conscientiously and I keep my fingers crossed for him.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 The Court of Auditors is an important institution that oversees the efficient allocation of resources. Having declared, together with the European Commission, the fight against financial fraud, its importance will grow – Mr Figueiredo, with his professional career, fulfils all the conditions to be of benefit to the work of the Court of Auditors.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I abstained on the nomination. I don't know the candidate.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control, assessing the qualifications of the proposed candidate, within the meaning of the conditions set out in Article 286(1) of the Code of Health. The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and after the hearing of the Candidates of the Council for Membership in the Court of Auditors, gave a positive opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint João de Figueiredo as a member of the Court of Auditors. I support the proposal for a decision on the proposed appointment, as I consider parliament's Committee competent to give a relevant opinion on the qualifications of candidates.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The selection of persons for positions of responsibility should be based on the integrity of their character and their proven activity with regard to the protection of public money in the broad sense.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of nominating João Figueiredo as a Member of the Court of Auditors. In the light of his robust professional experience, I trust that he will successfully monitor the implementation of the budget of the European Union in an independent and competent manner

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Portuguese government's candidate for a member of the Court of Auditors, because I believe that his previous professional experience will be a good basis for performing audit duties. Candidate João Goncalves de Figueiredo is a lawyer by profession and has eight years of experience as a judge at the Portuguese Court of Auditors and has been State Secretary for Public Administration, the Ministry of Finance, the Government of Portugal and the Auditor General of the Portuguese Court of Auditors. That is why I believe that this candidate will successfully perform the duties of an audit judge.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Budgetary Control has assessed the candidate's recommendations, in particular in the light of the requirements of Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I voted in my own right.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This candidacy for the Court of Auditors has been voted on. Professional career as a notable lawyer, he has been sensitive to questions posed by Portuguese delegations of the GUE/NGL, responding duly. I regret that women are still not being presented for these positions, in an institution where they are underrepresented. I vote favorably.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This is the replacement of a member of the European Court of Auditors by Mr Joao Figueiredo. The European Parliament is consulted on this appointment. With a law degree, the candidate has held various positions in the public service, from which he is a graduate, since 1982. Head of department, director of the division, then chief of staff to the Minister of Justice, he was involved in the judicial world from 1983 to 2002. He even held the position of Secretary of State for the Portuguese Administration. Since 2003, he has held positions in the field of public finance. He is currently a judge at the Portuguese Court of Auditors. Although well versed in budgetary and financial control, it has essentially legal and project planning skills.  I voted for his nomination.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported his appointment in view of the candidate's professional history and preparedness and the outcome of his previous hearings.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This candidacy has been voted on for the Court of Auditors. Professional career as a notable lawyer, he has been sensitive to questions posed by Portuguese delegations of the GUE/NGL, responding duly. I regret that women are still not being presented for these positions, in an institution where they are underrepresented. I vote favorably.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the nomination of João Figueiredo as a Member of the Court of Auditors because there are no legal, political or personal reasons on the grounds of which an objection to his nomination would be founded.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Nothing has against personality into account. However, we do not recognise legitimacy to this European court, which represents yet another instrument at the service of this neoliberal and militaristic capitalist integration of Europe.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 During his term in government, Leo Brincat, a candidate for the appointment as a member of the Court of Auditors, refused, together with members of his party, to open an investigation into the Panama Papers on Minister Konrad Mizzi and Prime Minister Keith Schembri's chief of staff. That is why I have decided to vote against.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. Mr Brincat supported a Maltese government colleague in a vote of confidence related to the Panama documents of May 2016. Having not received enough information on this subject, I have decided to abstain.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the appointment of a member of the European Court of Auditors. The European Parliament is consulted on this appointment. The candidate, Léo Brincat, a former Maltese environment minister, helped set up the Maltese National Public Audit Office. After a very short stint (in 1966) by Barclays, he held various political positions throughout his career: Secretary of The Prime Minister's Office, a member of the House of Representatives Public Accounts Committee, Minister of Finance and Trade and a member of the Foreign Affairs Committee. At the same time, he was Director of Research and Strategy at HSBC Malta. Focused on the left but defending conservative positions, it is not the subject of total consensus; however, it is proposed to this post by the left and right of the Maltese Parliament.  Leo Brincat is a controversial figure. While his role is to fight corruption, he openly supported Maltese Minister Konrad Mizzi (Labour Party), whose name appeared in the Panama Papers case.  So I voted against this appointment.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interests of transparency and democracy I abstained from voting on this nomination.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted against this appointment because I do not believe that this person embodies the values of integrity and transparency necessary to carry out this function.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of appointing Leo Brincate as a Member of the Court of Auditors. Leo Brincatas was active during the term of office of the Minister for Finance and Trade in order to make the National Audit Office fully independent, becoming an integral part of the Maltese Parliamentary Service.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. While the role of a Court of Auditors includes combating fraud, Leo Brincat has openly supported Maltese Minister Konrad Mizzi, whose name appeared in the Panama Papers case. So I voted against his appointment.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved Mr Brincat's appointment to the Court of Auditors, following the recommendation of the Committee on Budgetary Control.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is an important European institution which acts as an external and independent auditor of the Union. Founded in 1977, it only became a fully-capacity EU institution in 1993 and continued to provide support for improving the management of the European budget. It shall consist of one member from each State of the Union, each of whom shall be appointed by the Council after consulting Parliament and shall remain in office for six years. On this occasion, Parliament was called upon to give its opinion on the appointment of Leo Brincat. Having taken note of the content of the report by the Committee on Budgetary Control and following the advice of my political group, the S&D, I voted in secret on the proposed name.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This candidacy for the Court of Auditors has been voted on. A person with a track record of irregularities and vested interests, both political – taking advantage of the time when the Labour Party was in government – and private economic ones. Involved in the case of Panama papers. I vote against it.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. With the consensus absent around Leo Brincat, I preferred to vote against his appointment as a member of the Court of Auditors. Of course, this former Maltese environment minister was notably involved in the establishment of the National Audit Office in Malta. Moreover, one can only recognize his political career as a form of professionalism, notably through his role as a member of the Committee on Public Accounts of the House of Representatives, or as Minister of Finance and Trade. However, his close ties to the banking community, including his time at Barclays and his position as head of the research and strategy department at HSBC Malta, make me wonder about his total impartiality.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Maltese candidate proposed as a member of the European Court of Auditors, whose role would be to fight corruption, is known in his country for helping a party colleague escape a motion of no confidence in his government. In view of this precedent, I therefore did not intend to support his appointment with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This morning the Plenary of the European Parliament put to the vote, in secret, the proposal to appoint Leo Brincat as a member of the Court of Auditors, following the evaluation of the candidate's qualifications, the hearing held on 5 September, before the Committee on Budgetary Control and his favourable opinion, a vote in which I participated.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it rejected the Council's proposal to appoint Leo Brianzat as a Member of the Court of Auditors of Malta. This decision was taken by Parliament irrespective of the assessment of the qualifications of the candidate proposed by the Committee on Budgetary Control, in particular in the light of the requirements laid down in Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Leo Brincat, a graduate of the Chartered Institute of Bankers London and a member of the same Institute, has an exemplary curriculum vitae and has decades of positive experience in the political and economic field. Both because of his sensitivity when he was Minister for Sustainable Development, Environment and Climate Change of the Republic of Malta, and because of his work as head of corporate research at HSBC Bank Malta, we see no reason to oppose his appointment as a member of the European Court of Auditors, according to our information.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This text deals with the appointment of a member of the European Court of Auditors. The European Parliament is consulted on this appointment.  Despite his experience throughout his career as the Prime Minister's Cabinet Secretary, a member of the House of Representatives Public Accounts Committee, Minister of Finance and Trade and a member of the Foreign Affairs Committee, Maltese candidate Leo Brincat remains a controversial figure. While he was to fight corruption, he openly supported the Maltese minister Konrad Mizzi, whose name appeared in the Panama Papers case, until he opposed the motion of censure filed against the minister.  This unwavering support casts a shadow over his candidacy. That is why I voted against the appointment of Leo Brincat.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of the report on the proposal to appoint Leo Brincat as a member of the Court of Auditors because I consider the profile of the candidate to be of high professional status. The former minister has many similar experiences. He was, in fact, a member of the first cross-party national committee set up in 1995 to introduce transparency and regulation in the area of political party funding, known as the Galdes Committee, and served as a founding member and chairman of the Committee on Public Accounts in the House of Representatives, a body that strengthens relations between the National Court of Auditors and Parliament.  As minister of two different ministries, Leo Brincat, he dealt with public finance issues, both during his term as Minister of Finance and Trade and as Minister for Sustainable Development, Environment and Climate Change. At the same time as its term as Minister for Finance and Trade, the Maltese Court of Auditors has assumed full independence by joining the Cabinet of the Parliament of Malta.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 After evaluating the candidacy, we vote against the report.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I wish to respect the privacy of the secret ballot and not disclose my voting intentions.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: bil-miktub. – In-nomina ta' Leo Brincat għal pożizzjoni fil-Qorti tal-Awdituri ġiet miċħuda minn 381 Membru tal-PE. Dan ifisser you dan il-vot ma kienx il-PN contra l-gvern. name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I support the candidacy of Lea Brincata, who has been nominated by the Maltese Government as a candidate for a member of the Court of Auditors. Mr Brincat is qualified to perform this function (he graduated from the London Banking Institute, then cooperated with the institute) and has a great wealth of professional experience, Served as Minister of Eco-Development, Environment and Climate Change (March 2013 to April 2016), Minister of Finance and Trade (March 1997 to September 1998), Minister of Commerce (October 1996 to March 1997), President of the National Audit Office (March 1999 to February 2003) , Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee in the House of Representatives (1998 to 2003).

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the nomination of Leo Brincat for the European Court of Auditors as he has the qualifications and experience needed for the job. Coming from Malta myself, I truly believe that Leo Brincat’s experience as a Minister for Finance and Commerce, and also as a founder member and chairperson of the Public Accounts Committee within the House of Representatives, is an asset for the European Court of Auditors. He also performed well in his hearing and proved himself to be competent and qualified to fill the role of ECA member.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) has auditioned three candidates for nomination to the Court of Auditors, proposed by three Member States: Malta's Leo Brincat, Portugal's Joao Figueiredo and Cypriot Lazaros Stavrou Lazarou.  Considering that after a hearing, the members of the committee have validated these three appointments as long as the candidates meet the expectations of Parliament and the Court of Auditors, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Parliament is consulted on the appointment of a member of the European Court of Auditors.  Former Maltese environment minister Leo Brincat has held a number of senior political positions after a brief stint at Barclays Bank. He was successively secretary of the Prime Minister's cabinet, a member of the Public Accounts Committee of the House of Representatives, Minister of Finance and Trade and a member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs.  This character is controversial, not least because of his support for maltese Minister Konrad Mizzi, who was implicated in the Panama Papers affair. So I voted against it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
