name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The selection of persons for positions of responsibility should be based on the integrity of their character and their proven activity with regard to the protection of public money in the broad sense. That is why I am voting against the report on the proposed appointment of Leo Brinkat as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Leo Brincat has been nominated by the Maltese government (Labour); he was formerly the Environment Minister in that government, playing a key role in the COP21 decisions earlier this year. He is the second candidate to be nominated for the Maltese post following the withdrawal by Toni Abela of his candidacy in April after the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) voted by a majority to reject him due to concerns relating to his political profile. The hearing of Mr Brincat took place in CONT on Monday 5 September, where his candidacy was approved with 11 votes in favour, 9 against and 1 abstention. From the perspective of the CONT rapporteur (Green) and the S&D Group, the candidate proved himself to be qualified, competent and motivated, so I supported him at committee stage.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the appointment of Leo Brincat as a member of the Court of Auditors, as I consider Malta's former management consultant and long-serving Minister for Europe to be a suitable candidate.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)

He openly supported Maltese Minister Konrad Mizzi (Labour Party), whose name appeared in the Panama Papers case.  Leo Brincat voted against the motion of no confidence against Minister Mizzi, and this case casts a shadow over his candidacy. I voted against his appointment.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)

When another member of the Maltese government was linked to the Panama Papers affair, Mr Brincat, in a vote of no confidence, protected the accused and voted against his prosecution or objectification proceedings. His candidacy must therefore be rejected.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)

Leo Brincat then distinguished himself by voting against the motion of censure filed against Mr. Mizzi. This case, in my view, is a blow to the credibility of this candidacy.  I am therefore opposed to this appointment.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this nomination on the question of the candidate's probity.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)

It is therefore now up to the Council whether it is decided that a candidate should take up this post or, in cooperation with the Member State concerned, submit another candidate.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposed appointment of Leo Brinkat as a member of the Court of Auditors, as I do not agree with key points in that report.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)

It should be noted that he has publicly defended two ministers in his government suspected of being linked to the Panama Papers case.  For a position where the main task is to fight tax evasion, this nomination is unacceptable, I vote against.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is a supervisory institution, which verifies the legality and regularity of eu revenue and expenditure, as well as good financial management, carrying out its functions with complete independence. In this spirit, the appointment of the individualities that compose it has been governed by criteria of competence and independence.  Mr Leo Brincat submitted his Curriculum Vitae, replied to a written questionnaire and was heard in the Committee on Budgetary Control and did not put forward sufficient arguments to justify the appointment to the Court of Auditors to carry out his duties there competently and independently. Hence my unfavorable vote on your nomination.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Maltese candidate for the European Court of Auditors. Mr Brincat’s capabilities and qualifications for the post were never in question. Those are what he should have been judged on and what I based my vote on.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Leo Brincat, a former minister in several previous Maltese governments, is to be appointed a member of the European Court of Auditors by the Council, but he must also consult the European Parliament. In its report, the Committee on Budgetary Control indicated that it had assessed the capabilities of the proposed candidate and had listened to the candidate at its meeting on 5 September 2016. On this basis, although it supported the appointment of the candidate by a small majority, it did not take a position on parliament's proposal to appoint Leo Brincat as a Member of the Court of Auditors. I supported the Council's proposal.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the assessment of qualifications and the hearing by the Committee on Budgetary Control of the candidate proposed by the Council, I give my assent to the proposal to appoint Leo Brincat to the post of member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against Mr Brincat's appointment to the Court of Auditors on the basis that he is a controversial figure. He openly supported Maltese Minister Mizzi, whose name appeared in the Panama Papers case.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this report which approves the appointment of Leo Brincat as a member of the Court of Auditors. Indeed, the motivations for the appointment remained too unclear for me to support.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the nomination of Leo Brincat as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Court of Auditors is one of the institutional pillars of the European Union. Among other things, we audit EU revenues and expenditures, check whether EU funding has been properly collected and used, accurately displayed and value for money, checks every person or organisation managing EU funding, including on-the-spot checks in the EU institutions (particularly the Commission), EU Member States and countries receiving assistance from the EU , presents the findings and draws up recommendations in audit reports for the European Commission and national governments, reports possible fraud, corruption or other illegal activities to the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF).  Mr. Brincat was a minister in the Maltese government. Malta was found to have sold its citizenship to non-EU nationals for 650,000 euros during that period. Members of that Government are also mentioned in an affair related to "Panama Papers", linked to tax evasion. Given the Reputation of the Court of Justice, which must be impeccable and dependent on the composition of the Honourable Representatives of the Member States, I consider that appointing Mr. Brincat as a member of the Court of Auditors, whose oversight of the spending of European taxpayers' money is the main task, would undermine the credibility of the Court.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)

Former Maltese Environment Minister Leo Brincat helped set up the Maltese National Public Audit Office. name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Since Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the qualifications of the proposed candidate, in particular as regards the conditions set out in Article 286(1) of the EIA. agreement on the functioning of the European Union, and gave a positive opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Leo Brincat as a member of the Court of Auditors, I agree with the rapporteur's recommendation.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. We have been asked to rule on the appointment of a member of the European Court of Auditors. This procedure demonstrates the usefulness of Parliament in exercising its control over the functioning of the European institutions.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 After the Committee on Budgetary Control has carried out the assessment of qualifications and the hearing of candidate Leo Brincat, I voted in favour of this report which gives its assent to the Proposal of the Council to appoint Leo Brincat to the post of member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. This morning the Plenary of the European Parliament put to the vote, in secret, the proposal to appoint Leo Brincat as a member of the Court of Auditors, following the evaluation of the candidate's qualifications, the hearing held on 5 September, before the Committee on Budgetary Control and his favourable opinion, a vote in which I participated.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against the appointment of Mr Leo Brincat as a member of the Court of Auditors, following his hearing, and in view of his previous role as Minister of Sustainable Development, Environment and Climate Change in the Maltese government, which acted inappropriately regarding the Panama Papers revelations.  Given this liability, it is preferable, both for Malta and for the European Union, for the Maltese Prime Minister to nominate another candidate, independent, rather than a former minister.  I therefore hope that today's unfavourable vote in Parliament will prompt the Council to withdraw its proposal and put forward a new candidate to Parliament.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on the proposal to appoint Leo Brianza as a Member of the Court of Auditors. He was an associate member at the Chartered Institute of Bankers London and served as Minister for Sustainable Development, Environment and Climate Change in Malta for three years. It should be noted that there were a number of doubts about the qualifications of this person, which was the position of member of the Court of Auditors. Nor did Leo Brincata's answers in the committee responsible were not validated and incomplete.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Having submitted a proposal in which the selection process was carried out in an open and transparent manner, I agree with the appointment of Leo Brincat to the post of Member of the Court of Auditors, since, at the hearing by the Committee on Budgetary Control of the proposed candidate, he demonstrated competence and proven professional experience for the full performance of these functions.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This candidacy for the Court of Auditors has been voted on. A person with a track record of irregularities and vested interests, both political – taking advantage of the time when the Labour Party was in government – and private economic ones. Involved in the case of Panama papers. I vote against it.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The Danish Social Democrats have chosen to support the Maltese Government's recommendation for appointment to the European Court of Auditors. However, we still believe it is an uncommon practice to appoint politicians to the Court of Auditors and not auditors, and would like to urge Member States to nominate auditors without any political background.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against Leo Brincat joining the court of auditors due to his pro EU stance.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ in Mr Brincat's case, we have not been convinced that he is a quality enough candidate to fill a post as responsible as that of a Member of the Court of Auditors. We therefore did not approve his nomination.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I rejected the candidate because his background and career are too political.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control, assessing the qualifications of the proposed candidate, within the meaning of the conditions set out in Article 286(1) of the Code of Health. The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and after the hearing of the Council candidates for membership in the Court of Auditors, gave a positive opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Leo Brincat as a member of the Court of Auditors. I do not support the proposal for a decision on the proposed appointment, due to the vague posture towards cabinet ministers who have been linked to the Panama Papers international financial scandal. Also, Minister Brincat was against Maltese accession to the EU and the eurozone, so I think he does not meet the profile of a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The selection of persons for positions of responsibility should be based on the integrity of their character and their proven activity with regard to the protection of public money in the broad sense.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against nominating Leo Brincat as a Member of the Court of Auditors. Despite his proven professional experience, his statements on the Panama Papers scandal disqualify him from becoming a Member of this Court, at this point in time. In the wake of the scandal, Brincat had defended a cabinet minister exposed in the Panama Papers, voting against the government’s no-confidence motion.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. I supported mr. Leo Brincat's nomination as a member of the Court of Auditors since I believe he is qualified for the position. In fact, auditors should contribute to improving the way the European Commission manages the European Union budget and report on EU finances.  Given that maltese government candidate Brincat is a member of the first cross-party committee established in 1995 to introduce transparency and regulation in the financing of political parties and one of the founders and chairman of the Public Accounts Uniform in the House of Commons, the body that strengthens ties between the National Audit Office and Parliament, I believe that this experience will help him perform his duties in his new position.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Budgetary Control has assessed the candidate's recommendations, in particular in the light of the requirements of Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I voted in my own right.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This candidacy for the Court of Auditors has been voted on. A person with a track record of irregularities and vested interests, both political – taking advantage of the time when the Labour Party was in government – and private economic ones. Involved in the case of Panama papers. I vote against it.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This is the appointment of a member of the European Court of Auditors, Mr Leo Brincat. The European Parliament is consulted on this appointment. A former Maltese environment minister, he helped set up the Maltese National Public Audit Office. After a very short stint (in 1966) at Barclays, he held various political positions throughout his career: Secretary of The Prime Minister's Office, a member of the House of Representatives Public Accounts Committee, Minister of Finance and Trade and a member of the Foreign Affairs Committee. At the same time, he was Director of Research and Strategy at HSBC Malta. Leo Brincat is a controversial figure. While his role is to fight corruption, he openly supported Maltese Minister Konrad Mizzi (Labour Party), whose name appeared in the Panama Papers case. I voted against his appointment.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported his appointment in view of the candidate's professional history and preparedness and the outcome of his previous hearings.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This candidacy has been voted on for the Court of Auditors. A person with a track record of irregularities and vested interests, both political – taking advantage of the time when the Labour Party was in government – and private economic ones. Involved in the case of Panama papers. I vote against it.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the nomination of Leo Brincat as a Member of the Court of Auditors because there are no legal, political or personal reasons on the grounds of which an objection to his nomination would be founded.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We do not recognize legitimacy to this European court, which represents yet another instrument at the service of this neoliberal and militaristic capitalist integration of Europe. However, this appointment deserves our repudiation of the fact that the personality in question is deeply linked to a government heavily implicated in the panama papers tax scandal.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 It was necessary to appoint two new members of the Court of Auditors and extend the mandate by a third party.  The procedure provides that the members of the Court of Auditors shall be chosen from among persons who are or have been members of the external audit institutions in their respective States or who have a specific qualification for that function and who must offer all the guarantees of independence. The three candidates present a rather varied curriculum, which led me to cast different votes.  I voted against the candidacy of The Maltese Leo Brincat, Minister for Sustainable Development, former Finance Minister, elected member of parliament in 1981, for obstructing certain investigations during his term in office in government. Members of his ruling political party and himself have rejected calls for an investigation into Minister Konrad Mizzi and Prime Minister Keith Schembri's chief of staff related to the Panama Papers affair. This led me not to consider it appropriate to vote in favour of the candidate.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The Commission was required to adapt the decision making rules in trade policy to the new regime of delegated and implementing acts as a consequence of the adoption of the Lisbon Treaty. Part of this includes amending the regulation on Community statistics.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation, as a balanced compromise between the interests of the co-legislators was found.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have given my consent to the recommendation concerning Community statistics relating to external trade with non-member countries (delegated and implementing acts). In the light of the changes brought by the Lisbon Treaty and by the subsequent adoption of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 (on implementing acts), the Commission was required to adapt the decision-making rules in trade policy to the new regime of delegated and implementing acts. Most of the legislation in the field of the Common Commercial Policy has been aligned to the new constitutional regime (Trade Omnibus I and Trade Omnibus II). The Commission committed to amend Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics, which is the only legislative act in the field of the Common Commercial Policy referring to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny. Following the adoption of the new Inter-institutional agreement on Better law-making in December 2015, the European Parliament and the Council were able to reach an agreement on the regulation in question, which was overwhelmingly approved by the Committee on International Trade of the European Parliament and by the Council.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. It is therefore necessary to amend Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics on external trade with third countries concerning the delegation of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures, since the final text constitutes a compromise between the Council and Parliament.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Regulation (EC) 471/2009 relates to EU statistics on foreign trade with third countries. The aim of this decision is to determine precisely the powers available to the Commission and to set the appropriate procedure for it to adopt measures for foreign trade statistics under these powers. The general objective is to remove, by the end of the seventh Parliament and in all legislative instruments, all provisions referring to the regulatory procedure with control and replace them with procedures with delegated acts and enforcement powers. Regulation (EC) 471/2009 of the European Parliament and the Council gives the Commission the power to implement some of the provisions of this regulation. In order to bring Regulation (EC) 471/2009 in line with Articles 290 and 291 of the TFUE, the enforcement powers conferred on the Commission by this regulation must be replaced by the power to adopt delegated acts and acts of enforcement. The disappearance of regulatory procedures with control and replacing them with delegated acts and enforcement powers is a technical measure made mandatory by the adoption of the TFUE. So I voted for it.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation because, in order to reduce the administrative burden on businesses, the Commission is promoting in this documentation a simplification of legislation on Community statistics. This ambition is coupled with a desire to set data collection priorities in order to better study changes in the economic world.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. I voted for the recommendation on statistics on external trade with non-EU countries. In view of the approval of the Committee on International Trade, I support the Council's first reading position without amendments.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which concerns a technical measure: the replacement in the regulation of foreign trade statistics of regulatory procedures with control by delegated acts and enforcement powers, which goes in the right direction.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this recommendation, following in the excellent work done by my colleagues in the INTA committee.  The amendments referred to in this text are basically the conformity of the statistical procedures applied, for two specific points, with EU law relating to the new regime of delegated acts and acts of execution as a result of the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Lange report, which endorses the Council's position at first reading on the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community external trade statistics with third countries.  This is a technical measure concerning the conferring of delegated and implementing powers on the Commission for the adoption of certain specific measures. The text takes into account the balance on the content that has been made possible following the approval of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Lawmaking, which has made it possible to break the deadlock in the negotiations.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report at second reading. There is already an agreement under the 'Better Regulation' framework, which establishes, inter alia, a horizontal solution relating to the consultation of experts from the Member States in the preparation of delegated acts. The adoption of the new Interinstitutional Agreement 'Better Regulation' in December 2015 allowed Parliament's negotiating teams and the Council to reach agreement on the Regulation in question.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on statistics on foreign trade with third countries. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work in seeking agreements and reaching this final text.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Council's position at first reading for the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) 471/2009 on EU foreign trade statistics with third countries with regard to the delegated powers and enforcement powers conferred on the Commission for the adoption of certain measures. In particular, the regulation provides for the disappearance of regulatory procedures with control, and this, and replace them with procedures with delegated acts and enforcement powers.  This is merely a compliance with the treaties, including the TFUE, which provide for this replacement in Articles 290 and 291.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although this is a technical measure that would not normally pose any particular problems, my scepticism remains due to the Commission's casual and opaque use of the instrument of delegated acts. I have therefore chosen to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Following the changes introduced by the Lisbon Treaty and the subsequent adoption of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011, it was necessary to adapt the trade policy decision-making rules to the new system of delegated and implementing acts. Most legislation in the field of the common commercial policy has been harmonized through the Trade Omnibus I and II General Trade Regulations and several subsequent individual harmonises. However, Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics had been pending.  Following negotiations and agreement with the Commission and the Council, the INTA Commission of the European Parliament overwhelmingly adopted the agreed text, which today was put to a vote in plenary and which I supported.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported Parliament's general position with the Council on a regulation on Community statistics relating to external trade with non-EU countries. In the light of the developments resulting from the Treaty of Lisbon and the subsequent adoption of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 (on implementing acts), the Commission had to adapt the decision-making rules applicable to trade policy accordingly. The Commission has undertaken to submit a proposal for a second stage of harmonisation in the committee procedure in order to coordinate the legislative acts providing for the regulatory procedure with scrutiny.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this report, which clears the previous Committee regime of the post-Lisbon Treaty on Entrusted and Implementing Acts, in order to enable the systematic production of Community statistics in the field of foreign trade.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. In order to bring Regulation (EC) 471/2009 in line with Articles 290 and 291 of the TFUE, the enforcement powers conferred on the Commission by this regulation must be replaced by powers to adopt delegated acts and acts of enforcement. This is a purely technical measure. I voted for it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 223/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 March 2009 on European statistics defines the European Statistical System (ESS) as a partnership between the European statistical authority, i.e. the Commission (Eurostat), the National Statistical Institutes (INS) and the other national authorities responsible, in each Member State, for the development, production and dissemination of European statistics.  The Committee of the European Statistical System (ESS Committee), set up under Article 7 of Regulation (EC) No 223/2009, shall be considered the Umbrella Committee within the ESS. It assists the Commission in the exercise of implementing powers in certain statistical areas. These sectors did not include trade and the analysis of import/export flows between the Union and third countries. This Regulation broadens the scope of statistical analysis, rationalises and standardises the method and makes the data available for public consultation more useful.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This text deals with Regulation 471/2009 on EU foreign trade statistics with third countries. This regulation aims to determine the prerogatives of the European Commission to adopt measures for foreign trade statistics.  In concrete terms, all provisions referring to the regulatory procedure with control will be abolished in all legislative instruments in order to replace them with procedures with delegated acts and enforcement powers.  I voted in favour of this technical measure, made compulsory by the adoption of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFUE).

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of the amendments made by the Treaty of Lisbon and by the subsequent adoption of Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999, the Commission shall, in the context of the amendments made by the Treaty of Lisbon, adopt the measures necessary to ensure that the Provisions of this Regulation are adopted in the light of the amendments to this Regulation. 182/2011 (on delegated acts), the Commission was asked to adapt its rules for the adoption of trade policy decisions to the new regime of delegated acts and implementing acts. Thus, most of the legislative acts in the field of the common commercial policy were aligned with the new constitutional regime through Omnibus I and II acts on trade and several subsequent individual alignments. We have given a favourable vote, in view of the fact that, by the end of the 7th parliamentary term, the Commission has committed to draw up a second set of alignments on the committee procedure on legislative acts providing for the regulatory procedure with scrutiny.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of this report, which updates the regulation on the collection of external trade statistics with third countries. In the light of the changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon and the subsequent adoption of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 (on implementing acts), the Commission had to adapt the decision-making rules on trade policy to the new regime of delegated acts and implementing acts.  Most of the legislation in the field of the common commercial policy has been brought into line with the new constitutional regime through omnibus I and II trade instruments and various subsequent specific alignments.  The Commission has proposed amending Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics, which is the only piece of legislation in the field of the common commercial policy to refer to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The Commission was required to adapt the decision making rules in trade policy to the new regime of delegated and implementing acts as a consequence of the adoption of the Lisbon Treaty. Part of this includes amending the regulation on Community statistics.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as in its current state the agreement is essentially in line with the original Commission proposal with the exceptions of some minor changes. The agreement also now takes into consideration the outcome of the inter-institutional agreement on better law-making adopted in Plenary in March 2016. The aim of the Commission proposal is to amend Regulation 471/2009 on Community statistics relating to trade with non-member countries to the new institutional context of delegated and implementing acts.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. In line with the Treaty of Lisbon, the Commission has had to adapt the decision-making rules on trade policy to the system of delegated acts and implementing acts.  Much of the legislation in the field of the common commercial policy has been amended within the time limits required through the Omnibus I and II trade instruments (Trade Omnibus I and II) and with subsequent specific changes. The Commission has also undertaken to present a second set of amendments to the comitology procedure by the end of the seventh parliamentary term. In this context, it is proposed to amend Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics, which is the only legislative act in the field of the common commercial policy to refer to the former regulatory procedure with scrutiny. This is a necessary adjustment dictated by the Treaty, and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. In the field of the common commercial policy, it is necessary to take account of the specific rules laid down in Article 4 of Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the recommendation with a view to adopting the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. In the case of external trade statistics with third countries concerning the delegation of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures, this Regulation should be adopted. This is a formal procedure in which no objections have been raised at this stage by either side. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the Commission's proposal to amend external trade statistics with third countries.  This is a technical measure, which makes it possible to adapt the decision-making rules relating to trade policy to the new system of delegated acts and implementing acts, in line with the provisions of the Treaty of Lisbon. My vote in favour comes from the fact that, by implementing the system of delegated acts, Parliament and therefore the entire European population will be able to have greater control and awareness of the processing of data relating to the trade balance. In fact, deep knowledge and a better interpretation of export and import information are essential for the organization and planning of our industrial policy.  By recalling the excellence of our small and medium-sized enterprises and their role within the European industrial fabric, thanks to a greater awareness of the economic results achieved, it will be possible to pursue a strategy aimed at internationalization with positive repercussions for all.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the vote on statistics relating to external trade with non-member countries (delegated and implementing powers) and noted no objections.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure because, following the changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon and the consequent adoption of Regulation (EU) No. Regulation (EEC) No 182/2011 on implementing acts made it necessary for the Commission to adapt the decision-making rules on trade policy with particular reference to Regulation 471/2009 on Community statistics relating to external trade with third countries, which is the only legislative act in the field of the common commercial policy which refers to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report improves and updates foreign trade statistics with third countries, a key information for studies and economic planning. That's why I voted for it.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The purpose of the Regulation is to align Regulation (EC) No 421/2009 on statistics on external trade with third countries with the TFEU as to the delegation of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures.  Following the first reading vote in plenary on 12 March 2014, the EP and the Council negotiated with a view to concluding an agreement at an early stage of second reading on the basis of the Council's position at first reading, which the EP can approve as reflecting the compromise reached between the co-legislators and including a combination of delegated acts, implementing acts and transferring certain issues to the basic legislative act. One issue remains unresolved: consultation with experts from the Member States in the preparation of delegated acts, which the Council has insisted on. It was then that it was decided to suspend the negotiations pending the outcome of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Regulation. Following the adoption of this Interinstitutional Agreement, the draft regulation was amended accordingly.  The ECR supports the balanced outcome of the negotiations following the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-making and, consequently, the recommendation to hold a second reading without amendments. I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report as I believe that the negotiations and the outcomes further strengthen the regulation. This will lead to better decision making rules in trade policy.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of harmonising the decision-making rules on EU trade policy, with particular reference to the European Commission's new system of delegated acts and implementation. After lengthy negotiations, a compromise has finally been reached, consisting of this measure, which provides for the old 'comitology' regime to be adapted to the rules that have intervened following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon and the 2011 EU Regulation on implementing acts, which would make it possible to systematically carry out statistical surveys at Community level on external trade. A step forward, therefore, towards greater efficiency of European action in the field of trade.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report concerns EU foreign trade statistics with third countries. It focuses mainly on the rules for the practical implementation of European legislation in this area, which are enforcement acts and delegated acts.  Considering that this report harmonizes and makes foreign trade data more reliable in order to establish trade agreements with full knowledge of the facts, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text, which brings the regulation in line with Eu-market statistics on foreign trade with third countries with the new rules of the Treaty on the functioning of the European Union concerning the Commission's delegated and enforcement powers.  It is clear that we need to adapt legislation in line with the existing institutional rules.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This is the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading on EU foreign trade statistics. The purpose of this text is to determine precisely the powers available to the Commission and to set the procedures necessary for the adoption of statistical measures. Regulation (EC) 471/2009 of the European Parliament and the Council gives the Commission the power to implement certain provisions of this regulation. So I voted for this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this draft regulation as it concerns statistics on external trade with third countries and on the functioning of the EU as regards the conferring of delegated and implementing powers on the Commission for the adoption of certain measures. Importantly, an in-depth discussion has taken place. Fortunately, following the publication of the result of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making, the draft regulation has been recast accordingly.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is proposed to vote against the recommendation as it extends the delegated implementing powers to the Commission.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission had to adapt the rules of decision-making on trade policy to the new system of delegated and implementing acts and undertook to present the second phase of comitology alignments – relating to legislative acts containing the regulatory procedure with scrutiny – before the end of the seventh parliamentary term. In this context, the Commission has proposed amending the Regulation on Community statistics. The adoption of the new Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Regulation has enabled parliament and council negotiating teams to agree on the regulation in question. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote for: the disappearance of control regulation procedures and replace them with delegated acts and enforcement powers is a technical measure made mandatory by the adoption of the FUE Treaty.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the light of the amendments introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon – of which we strongly disagree – and by the subsequent adoption of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 (on implementing acts), the Commission had to adapt the rules of decision-making on trade policy to the new system of delegated and implementing acts. Most of the legislation in the field of the common commercial policy has been aligned with the new regime, through the Trade Omnibus I and II regulations and several subsequent individual alignments.  In this context, the Commission has proposed amending Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics, which is the only legislative act in the field of the common commercial policy relating to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny. Following the adoption of Parliament's position at first reading at its plenary session on 12 March 2014, formal negotiations with the Italian Presidency were initiated with a view to rapidly reaching an agreement at second reading. After several rounds of trilogues, negotiations have been suspended pending the adoption of the new Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Regulation, which provides, inter alia, for a horizontal solution for consultation of experts from the Member States when preparing delegated acts. We abstained.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 A new proposal from the European Commission will bring alignment with the situation required following the adoption of the Treaty of Lisbon in the area of statistics production. In this case, it is primarily about the production of European Union statistics in the field of foreign trade. The final compromise in this case is a combination of delegated and implementing acts.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation as it extends the delegated implementing powers to the Commission.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This file aligns the previous comitology regime to the post-Lisbon Treaty rules on delegated and implementing acts in order to enable the systematic production of Community statistics in the field of external trade. The final compromise involves a mix of delegated acts and implementing acts and also moves certain issues to the basic legislative act, a compromise that balanced the interests of the co-legislators. After the initial agreement resulting from two trilogues in December 2014, the Council refused to accept its outcome due to one unresolved issue: the consultation of Member States’ experts in the preparation of delegated acts. The negotiations were therefore suspended until December 2015, when the new Inter-institutional Agreement on Better law making was agreed and a new horizontal formulation for the issue in question had been found. The text adopted in Council is in accordance with the compromise reached with Parliament. I therefore supported the outcome.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I approved the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on statistics on EU external trade with third countries. The amendments introduced as a result of the Treaty of Lisbon called on the Commission to align the decision-making rules on trade policy with the new system of delegated acts and implementing acts. Most legislation in the field of the common commercial policy has been aligned with the new constitutional system. As the Commission is committed to implementing the second wave of comitology adjustments by the end of the 7th parliamentary term, it is proposed to amend the regulation in question on Community statistics, which is the only legislative act in the field of the common commercial policy involving the regulatory procedure with scrutiny.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the commission, bearing in mind, because of the changes introduced by the Lisbon Treaty, the Commission was asked to adapt the trade policy decision-making rules to the new system of delegated and implementing acts.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation on statistics on external trade with third countries (delegated and implementing powers). It is a question of what freedoms and powers the EU should have in comproducing such statistics, and brings the existing legislation up to date.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which aligns the former regulatory procedure with scrutiny to delegated and implementing acts in order to enable the systematic production of Community statistics in the field of external trade to the new post-Lisbon regime of delegated and implementing acts.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report at second reading. There is already an agreement under the 'Better Regulation' framework, which establishes, inter alia, a horizontal solution relating to the consultation of experts from the Member States in the preparation of delegated acts. The adoption of the new Interinstitutional Agreement 'Better Regulation' in December 2015 allowed Parliament's negotiating teams and the Council to reach agreement on the Regulation in question.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading on the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics on external trade with third countries as regards the delegation and implementing powers of delegation and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures.  Following the changes following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon and the adoption of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 (on implementing acts), the Commission had to adapt the rules for commercial policy decision-making to the new system of delegated and implementing acts. Most legislative provisions in this area have been adapted by means of an omnibus act and by several individual adaptations. The Commission has undertaken to present by the end of the seventh term of office a second set of coding adjustments for legislative acts including the regulatory procedure with scrutiny. The Commission has therefore proposed amendments to Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics, which is the only legislative act in the field of the common commercial policy relating to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny.  In my view, the Council's position in this regard can be supported.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics relating to external trade with non-member countries as regards the conferral of delegated and implementing powers on the Commission for the adoption of certain measures. In the light of the changes brought about by the Lisbon Treaty and by the subsequent adoption of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 (on implementing acts), the Commission was required to adapt the decision making rules in trade policy to the new regime of delegated and implementing acts. In this context, the Commission amended Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics which is the only legislative act in the field of the Common Commercial Policy referring to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a recommendation for a second reading on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013; 471/2009 on Community statistics concerning foreign trade with non-member countries in relation to the granting of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission in order to adopt certain measures, as I consider that, following numerous harmonisations of a large number of rules and negotiations and the adoption of the new Interinstitutional Agreement 2015 between the EP and the Council, there has been a common position and agreement.  This year, the European Parliament's International Trade Committee approved the agreed text in a vote by a large majority.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this decision is to determine precisely the powers available to the Commission and to set the appropriate procedure for it to adopt measures for foreign trade statistics under these powers. The disappearance of regulatory procedures with control and replacing them with delegated acts and enforcement powers is a technical measure made mandatory by the adoption of the FUE Treaty. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Bernd Lange's report on the Commission's powers in the area of foreign trade statistics with third countries. The purpose of this text is to abolish an old procedure (the regulation procedure with control) and to replace it with delegated and/or enforcement acts. This is part of the Better Legislation Agreement, which I support because it ensures that EU legislation best serves citizens and businesses.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Lange report on foreign trade statistics with third countries (delegated powers and enforcement powers), following the achievement of a trilogue agreement which was then approved by the Council in January 2016.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 We welcome the alignment proposed by the Commission in the field of the common commercial policy aligned with the new constitutional regime through the General Acts on Trade I and II and the Commission's commitment to implement the second round of necessary alignments.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report. Certain decision-making rules in the field of trade policy should be recast and adapted to the practice of delegated legal and implementing acts as defined in the last interinstitutional agreement.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the light of the changes brought about by the Lisbon Treaty the Commission was required to adapt the decision making rules in trade policy to the new regime of delegated and implementing acts. I voted in favour of the report as this file represents a compromise balancing the interests of the co-legislators.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. With this proposal, the Commission aims to amend the regulation on Community external trade statistics with third countries, which appears to be the only piece of legislation in the field of the common commercial policy to refer to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny. There are changes due to technical adjustments that will allow a more faithful and precise representation of the status quo, useful in determining assessments as faithful as possible to the reality of trade agreements.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on foreign trade statistics with third countries. The aim of this decision is to determine what powers the Commission has and to set the appropriate procedure for it to adopt measures for foreign trade statistics under these powers. The general objective is to remove, by the end of the seventh Parliament and in all legislative instruments, all provisions referring to the regulatory procedure with control and replace them with procedures with delegated acts and enforcement powers. This is a technical measure made mandatory by the adoption of the FUE Treaty.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The disappearance of controlled regulation procedures for their replacement by delegated and enforcement acts is a technical measure made mandatory by the adoption of the FUE Treaty. As a result, I voted for this deliberation.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of updating existing legislation on Community statistics relating to external trade with non-member countries to the new institutional context of delegating and implementing acts.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal seeks to amend Regulation No 471/2009 in order to align it with the new institutional context.  I support the position to empower the Commission to adopt delegated acts in respect of the adaptation of the list of customs procedures or provisions deriving from international conventions, changes necessary for methodological reasons.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the EP, by its resolution, forwarded to second reading the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics on external trade with non-member countries as regards the conferral of delegated and implementing powers on the Commission with a view to adopting certain measures. I support the proposal that, by applying transparently and consistently the allocation of the Commission's power to adopt delegated and implementing powers, all provisions referring to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny should be removed and that an appropriate procedure be laid down for the adoption of measures. This procedure will also lead to the simplification of the European Statistical System.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. In the case of external trade statistics with third countries concerning the delegation of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures, it is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text.  This is the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading on EU trade statistics. The purpose of this text is to determine precisely the powers available to the Commission and to set the procedures necessary for the adoption of statistical measures. The EC 471/2009 regulation of the European Parliament and the Council gives the Commission the power to implement certain provisions of this regulation.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Commission's proposal for consideration aims to bring the European Parliament and Council regulation of 6 May 2009 on EU trade statistics in line with third countries with the provisions of the Lisbon Treaty. The text delegates to the Commission the power to adopt acts with regard to: the list of customs procedures or customs destinations admitted or the exclusion of goods or movements from foreign trade statistics. Statistics are a political issue that cannot be left to the discretion of the Commission, especially since it will be on the basis of impartial statistics that we will implement solidarity protectionism. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The disappearance of control regulation procedures and replace them with delegated acts and enforcement powers is a technical measure made mandatory by the adoption of the FUE Treaty. As a result, I voted for this deliberation.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal is to amend Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 in order to align it with the new institutional context. In particular, it is a question of identifying the powers conferred on the Commission and establishing the appropriate procedure for the adoption of measures based on those powers. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this legislative resolution, following the changes to the new Inter-institutional agreement on Better Law-making which will allow the Commission to make changes to Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics relating to external trade with non-member countries.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Delegating enforcement powers to the Commission, under the control of committees of representatives of Member States in the context of 'committeeology', is justified for reasons of uniformity and has been in existence since the 1960s. However, the Lisbon Treaty introduced a major reform by distinguishing enforcement actions from delegated acts, putting the European Parliament on an equal footing with the Council and the Commission, thereby increasing the powers of the European Parliament in the executive sphere. Thus, Parliament can now put pressure on the Commission and the Council by threatening to block a legislative decision in co-decision or a budgetary decision. With the Lisbon Treaty, the legislator has the right to object for any reason, and the right to remove the delegation or an individual act outright. This is a significant pressure tool on the Commission. For my part, and within the framework of the inter-institutional agreement 'Better Regulation', I support a delegation procedure that allows the legislator to concentrate on the essentials, provided that the competence delegated to the Commission is well supervised and implemented in a completely transparent manner.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – The Treaty of Lisbon introduced a number of amendments whereby the Commission had to adapt the rules on business policy decision-making to the new regime of delegated and implementing acts. Through the Comprehensive Act on Trade I and II. most of the legislation in the area of the common commercial policy has been harmonised, further consolidation is needed in the area of legislative acts relating to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny. The only legislative act in this area is Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics. The adoption of an interinstitutional agreement on better law-making made it possible to reach agreement on this Regulation and provided a horizontal solution on the consultation of Member States' experts in the preparation of delegated acts. The agreement was approved by the Committee on International Trade (INTA) as well as by the Council, whose position I support with my vote.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which aligns the previous comitology regime to the post-Lisbon Treaty rules on delegated and implementing acts in order to enable the systematic production of Community statistics in the field of external trade, which is essential.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this uncontroversial proposal, which aims at amending the Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 in order to bring it in line with the new institutional framework applicable after the entry into force of Lisbon Treaty related to the adoption of delegated and implementing acts.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament adopted at first reading on 12 March 2014 a draft Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on statistics on external trade with third countries in respect of delegated and implementing powers to be conferred on the Commission in order to adopt certain measures. The tripartit negotiations that subsequently began were suspended after several rounds pending the adoption of a new interinstitutional agreement on better law-law. Following the adoption of this Agreement in December 2015, the negotiating groups of Parliament and the Council reached an agreement on the regulation in question. The Council adopted its position at first reading on 16 June 2016, confirming the agreement. In its report, the Committee on International Trade recommends that Parliament agree with the Council's position at first reading, thereby making the regulation final in accordance with the Council's position. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The report proposes amendments to a proposed regulation establishing a mandatory system of statistics on gas and electricity prices in residential areas. The removal of the delegation to the committee (amendments 1, 3, 6) is a good move. Some of the rapporteur's more sovereignist and pro-industry ideas, however, were put aside in the ITRE committee. Also, the Commission's proposal is not desirable because of a high level of constraint for states and businesses and an unjustified delegation to the Commission. Vote in favour.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the report in question, "Following the adoption of Parliament's position at first reading at its plenary session on 12 March 2014, formal negotiations with the Italian Presidency have begun with a view to reaching an agreement quickly at second reading. After several rounds of trilogues, negotiations have been suspended pending the adoption of the new Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Regulation, which provides, inter alia, for a horizontal solution for consultation of experts from the Member States when preparing delegated acts". I therefore vote in favour of the agreement concluded at first reading with a view to continuing the negotiation process with the Council in order to reach a fruitful and interesting understanding for both parties.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The Lange report on European statistics on foreign trade with third countries relates to a purely technical measure, namely the replacement in the Regulation on Foreign Trade Statistics of regulatory procedures with control by delegated acts and enforcement powers. So I voted for this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which aligns the former regulatory procedure with scrutiny to delegated and implementing acts, in order to enable the systematic production of Community statistics in the field of external trade to the new post-Lisbon regime of delegated and implementing acts.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on foreign trade statistics with third countries. The aim here was to approve the Council's position at first reading on the Commission's draft amendment to Regulation 471/2009. This change is for the sole purpose of aligning it with the new regime established by the Lisbon Treaty. I support all the texts which simplify the legibility of the European texts.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcomed the report on external trade statistics with third countries, as, in the light of the changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon and the subsequent adoption of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 on implementing acts, the Commission adapted the decision-making rules on trade policy to the new regime of delegated acts and implementing acts.  In particular, the Commission aims to amend Regulation 471/2009 on Community statistics on external trade with third countries, which is the only piece of legislation in the field of the common commercial policy which refers to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the recommendation. The European Union is doing extraordinary work in the field of external trade with third countries. For these works, the Commission needs the appropriate powers and powers. Contacts, accurate statistics on different goods and customs duties and customs codes are all important parts of ensuring smooth and effective responses to external trade issues.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ One of the steps toward updating the way decisions on trade policy are adopted in the European Union was the Omnibus proposal, covering over 24 regulations on trade defence instruments, Economic Partnership Agreement Market Access Regulation and Trade Barriers Regulation amongst others. I have voted for this report that aims at better law making in the EU’s trade policy.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report. The Commission was required to adapt the decision making rules in trade policy to the new regime of delegated and implementing acts as a consequence of the adoption of the Lisbon Treaty. Part of this includes amending the regulation on Community statistics.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Given that it was necessary to harmonise decision-making in trade policy with the new regime of implemented and delegated acts and bearing in mind that after the negotiations the negotiating teams of Parliament and the Council agreed on the regulation in question and that the rapporteur's proposal was also supportive, I voted positively on the recommendation for a second reading on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013; 471/2009 on Community statistics concerning foreign trade with non-member countries in relation to the granting of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission in order to adopt certain measures.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The disappearance of controlled regulation procedures for their replacement by delegated acts and enforcement powers is a technical measure made mandatory by the adoption of the FUE Treaty. Although I remain opposed to the FUE Treaty, adopted against the will of the people who elected me, I do not practice systematic obstruction and I therefore vote in favour of this purely technical measure.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Most common trade policy regulations are aligned with the new constitutional order through the Joint Trade Laws I and II and in several subsequent individual harmonisations. The Commission has undertaken to present by the end of the seventh parliamentary term the following set of adjustments under the comitology process for those legislative acts for which the regulatory procedure with control is envisaged.  In this regard, the Commission proposed to amend Regulation (EC) No 1002/2013. 471/2009 on Community statistics, the only common trade policy legislative act specifying the regulatory procedure with scrutiny. The adoption of the new Interinstitutional Agreement in December 2015 thus allowed the negotiating teams of Parliament and the Council to reach an agreement on the regulation in matter. The agreed text was presented to the INTA Committee on 21 April 2016 for a vote of approval and was then approved by a large majority of votes. On the basis of the voted approval on the same day, the Chairperson of the Committee of Permanent Representatives (COREPER) sent a recommendation that the Council's position be confirmed at first reading at plenary session without amendments. According to legal and linguistic verification, on 16 June 2016, the Council adopted its position at first reading and thereby confirmed the agreement. In light of the above, I support the rapporteur's position to approve the Council's position at first reading without amendment.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I approved this agreement between the European Commission, the Council of the European Union and the European Parliament, which makes technical changes to Regulation (EC) 471/2009 on EU foreign trade statistics with third countries, in line with the new institutional context on delegated powers and enforcement powers.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, because I believe that, in the light of the amendments introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon and the subsequent adoption of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 (on implementing acts), the Commission had to adapt the rules of decision-making on trade policy to the new system of delegated and implementing acts. Most of the legislation in the field of the common commercial policy has been aligned with the new constitutional regime, through the Trade Omnibus I and II regulations and several subsequent individual alignments.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Legislative Report on 'Community statistics on foreign trade with third countries as regards the allocation to the Commission of delegated and implementing powers to take certain measures' seeks to adapt the comitology process to the provisions of the Lisbon Treaty. This will make it possible to create statistics on the ground of foreign trade. With the approval of the 'Better law Making' implementation will be carried out horizontally, so consultation will be allowed to the experts of the Member States to prepare the delegated acts. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report. On which the European Parliament is already voting a second time. The first adoption of the report by the Italian Presidency on 12 March 2014 led to informal negotiations with a view to reaching an agreement at an early stage of second reading. However, during the preparation of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making, the trialogue negotiations were suspended. December 2015 Following the adoption of this new Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making, the negotiating teams between Parliament and the Council have been given the opportunity to agree on this Regulation.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's proposal for a second reading recommendation on the amendment to Council Regulation No 471/2009 on Community statistics on external trade with third countries.  This is an amendment that follows the amendments introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon and Regulation No 182/2011 on implementing acts on trade policy, under which the European Commission has undertaken to present a second phase of comitology alignments - the method of monitoring EU countries on how the European Commission applies European legislation. Such alignment implies the amendment to Regulation No 471/2009 on Community statistics, as it is the only legislative act in the field of the common commercial policy relating to the comitology procedure on regulated rules.  The difficulty in defining an agreement on this matter was due to the delay in the adoption of the new Interinstitutional Agreement "Better Regulation", which took place in December 2015 between the negotiating teams of Parliament and the Council, and this Regulation was subsequently adopted by a large majority in the Committee on International Trade in April 2016.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. This report deals with a second reading agreement on foreign trade statistics with third countries.  Under the previous mandate, the Commission has committed to reviewing legislation that currently includes references to the regulatory procedure with control. I therefore voted in favour of this technical text.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report at second reading. There is already an agreement under the 'Better Regulation' framework, which establishes, inter alia, a horizontal solution relating to the consultation of experts from the Member States in the preparation of delegated acts. The adoption of the new Interinstitutional Agreement 'Better Regulation' in December 2015 allowed Parliament's negotiating teams and the Council to reach agreement on the Regulation in question.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report improves and updates foreign trade statistics with third countries, a key information for studies and economic planning. That's why I voted for it.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted for the report because it aligns the former regulatory procedure with scrutiny to delegated and implementing acts in order to enable the systematic production of Community statistics in the field of external trade to the new post-Lisbon regime of delegated and implementing acts.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing \ u2012 I voted in favour. On the basis of the changes brought about by the Treaty of Lisbon, the Commission has been forced to propose amendments to Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics, which is the only legislative act in the area of the common commercial policy relating to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny. Finally, after very difficult negotiations and the adoption of an interinstitutional agreement on better law-making in December 2015, an agreement was reached between Parliament and the Council on this regulation.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the draft LEGISLATIVE RESOLUTION of the EP on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation No 471/2009 on Community statistics on external trade with non-member countries as regards the delegation of delegated and exercised powers to the Commission with a view to taking certain measures. In the light of the changes brought about by the Treaty of Lisbon, the Commission has been forced to adapt the rules for decision-making in trade policy to the new regime of delegated and implementing acts. In this context, the Commission has therefore proposed amendments to Regulation No 471/2009 on Community statistics, which is the only legislative act in the area of the common commercial policy relating to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny. Following the adoption of Parliament's position at first reading in plenary on 12 March 2014, informal negotiations were launched with a view to reaching an agreement at second reading. After several rounds of trilogues, negotiations were suspended, but the adoption in December 2015 of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making allowed parliament and council negotiating teams to reach agreement on this regulation. The text of the agreement was approved by the INTA Committee, which is why we approved the Council's position at first reading in plenary without changes.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 Economic growth is currently dependent on the exchange of goods with other countries and parts of the world. As we have seen from analytical data, its importance is still growing. It is therefore important to conclude international trade agreements, especially with those countries closest to our understanding of freedom and fair trade.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The draft EU Parliament legislative resolution on statistics relating to external trade with non-member countries was approved without a vote. However, had there been a vote I would have voted against the resolution. Such statistics will simply be another justification through which the EU will call for further regulation. And in the EU context, regulation is synonymous with harmonisation.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒In light of the amendments made to the Lisbon Treaty and then the adoption of Regulation (EU) No 182/201, the Commission had to adapt the rules on trade policy decision-making to the new regime of implementing and delegated acts. The Commission has proposed to amend Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013. 471/2009 on Community statistics, the only common trade policy legislative act specifying the regulatory procedure with scrutiny.  The adoption of the Interinstitutional Agreement in December 2015 allowed the negotiating teams of Parliament and the Council to reach an agreement on the regulation in issue. According to legal and linguistic verification, on 16 June 2016 the Council adopted its position at first reading. I support the recommendation for a second reading on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1001/2013. 471/2009 on Community statistics concerning foreign trade with non-member countries in relation to the granting of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission in order to adopt certain measures.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics on external trade with non-member countries concerning the granting of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures.  I support the proposed amendment of the Regulation on Community statistics by which the Commission proposes adaptation rules on decision-making in trade policy to the new regime, following the introduction of the Treaty of Lisbon, delegated and implementing acts.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's agreement with the Council's position, as regards Regulation No 471/2009 of the Council Regulation (EC) on Community statistics on foreign trade with third countries as regards the conferred on the Commission of delegated and implementing powers for the purpose of adopting certain measures, it is necessary to adapt the rules on decision-making procedures in trade policy to the new regime of delegated acts and implementing acts. The Commission has therefore undertaken to present by the end of the 7th parliamentary term a second wave of adaptation of the comitology procedure concerning legal acts referring to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny and has proposed an amendment to the Community Statistics Regulation. The discussion is only now taking place, as the new text now also reflects the newly concluded interinstitutional agreement on better lawmaking.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This Recommendation proposes to strengthen the Commission's implementing powers with a view to fully guiding Member States' trade with third countries.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this resolution, by which Parliament approves the results of more than two years of preparatory work carried out in the Council at first reading and through several for a and rounds of interinstitutional consultation.
