The draft legislation reflects the institutional changes that have arisen under the Treaty of Lisbon and the changes to comitology rules that have become necessary by the requirement to improve the quality of legislation ('Better Law-making'), on the basis of the Union's competence in international trade and statistical reporting.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In light of the changes brought about by the Lisbon Treaty, the Commission was required to adapt the decision-making rules in trade policy to the new regime of delegated and implementing acts. This file aligns the previous comitology regime to the post-Lisbon Treaty rules on delegated and implementing acts in order to enable the systematic production of Community statistics in the field of external trade. The final compromise involves a mix of delegated acts, implementing acts, and also moving certain issues to the basic legislative act, a compromise that balanced the interests of the co-legislators. The text adopted in the Council is in accordance with the compromise reached with Parliament. I therefore support this report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. Informal negotiations began under the Italian Presidency, following the adoption of Parliament's position in plenary and at first reading on 12 March 2014, with a view to reaching an agreement at second reading quickly. After several rounds of trilogue, negotiations have been suspended pending the new inter-institutional agreement "Better Legislation" which provides, among other things, a horizontal solution for the consultation of the experts of the Member States during the preparation of the delegated acts. The adoption of the new inter-institutional agreement "Better Legislation" in December 2015 allowed the negotiating teams of Parliament and the Council to reach agreement on the regulation under consideration. The text of the agreement was presented to the INTA committee for a vote of approval on 21 April 2016, and was approved by a very large majority. In view of this result, the Chairman of the Committee recommended that Parliament in plenary vote in force to vote in.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Lisbon Treaty introduced new decision-making rules in trade policy related to the use of delegated and implementing acts by the Commission. I voted in favour of the regulation on Statistics relating to external trade with non-member countries, as this will allow the newly negotiated decision-making rules to finally be adopted. In fact, negotiations regarding these new rules had been suspended while waiting for the Inter-institutional Agreement on Better Law-making to be adopted in 2015, which provides among other things for a horizontal solution regarding the consultation of Member States’ experts in preparation of delegated acts.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 I agree with the change in the Community statistics regulation on foreign trade with non-member countries in relation to the granting of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission in order to adopt certain measures, as I believe that the Commission needs to adapt the rules on trade policy decision-making to the new regime of implementing and delegated acts.  Most common trade policy rules are in line with the new systemic order. Given that the Commission should ensure that they do not impose additional administrative burdens on Member States and their representatives when preparing and drafting delegated acts, I voted positively.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I supported the motion for a resolution on statistics on external trade with non-member countries (delegated and implementing powers).  As a result of the amendments introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon and the subsequent adoption of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 (on implementing acts), the Commission had to adapt the rules on decision-making in trade policy to the new regime of delegated and implementing acts.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report at second reading. There is already an agreement under the 'Better Regulation' framework, which establishes, inter alia, a horizontal solution relating to the consultation of experts from the Member States in the preparation of delegated acts. The adoption of the new Interinstitutional Agreement 'Better Regulation' in December 2015 allowed Parliament's negotiating teams and the Council to reach agreement on the Regulation in question.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The disappearance of control regulation procedures and replace them with delegated acts and enforcement powers is a technical and automatic measure made mandatory by the adoption of the FUE Treaty. I voted for it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the light of the amendments introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon and the subsequent adoption of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 (implementing acts), the Commission was called upon to align the decision-making rules on trade policy with the new system of delegated acts and implementing acts. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report at second reading. There is already an agreement under the 'Better Regulation' framework, which establishes, inter alia, a horizontal solution relating to the consultation of experts from the Member States in the preparation of delegated acts. The adoption of the new Interinstitutional Agreement 'Better Regulation' in December 2015 allowed Parliament's negotiating teams and the Council to reach agreement on the Regulation in question.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics relating to external trade with non-member countries as regards the conferral of delegated and implementing powers on the Commission for the adoption of certain measures. In the light of the changes brought about by the Lisbon Treaty and by the subsequent adoption of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 (on implementing acts), the Commission was required to adapt the decision making rules in trade policy to the new regime of delegated and implementing acts. The Commission committed itself to come up with the second wave of comitology alignments – concerning legislative acts containing the regulatory procedure with scrutiny – by the end of the 7th legislature. The agreed text was presented to the Committee on International Trade (INTA) for a vote of approval on 21 April 2016, and was approved by an overwhelming majority.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this recommendation. These are institutional adjustments in the area of the competence of the European Commission's trade. In the light of the changes resulting from the Lisbon Treaty, the Commission was obliged to adapt the decision-making rules on trade policy to the new system of delegated and implementing acts.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the adoption of Parliament's position at first reading at its plenary session on 12 March 2014, formal negotiations with the Italian Presidency were initiated with a view to reaching a rapid agreement at second reading.  After several rounds of trilogues, negotiations have been suspended pending the adoption of the new Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Regulation, which provides, inter alia, for a horizontal solution for consultation of member states' experts when preparing delegated acts. The abstention vote.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the EP recommendation on the Council's position with a view to adopting an EP and Council regulation on Community statistics on external trade with third countries on the granting of delegated and implementing powers. The EP recommendation follows the amendments made by the Treaty of Lisbon, with the Commission being asked to adapt its rules for the adoption of trade policy decisions to the new regime of delegated and implementing acts. The adoption of the new Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Regulation has thus enabled the negotiating teams of Parliament and the Council to reach agreement on that regulation.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it is simply a matter of adapting to our new legal framework. Trade policy decision-making rules needed to be adapted to the new system of delegated and implementing acts.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 The Commission had to adapt the rules on decision-making in trade policy to the new regime of delegated and implementing acts in the context of the amendments introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon and the consequent adoption of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 (on implementing acts).  The Commission has undertaken to prepare a second wave of harmonisation with the comitology procedure with regard to legislative acts containing the regulatory procedure with scrutiny by the end of the 7th legislative period. In this context, the Commission has proposed to amend Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics, which is the only legislative act in the field of the common commercial policy relating to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny. In the same way, I supported the Recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 471/2009 on Community statistics on external trade with non-member countries concerning the granting of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider it essential to apply a regulation making it compulsory to communicate data to the consumer, especially with regard to gas and electricity. The consumer must always be properly informed in order to ensure perfect transparency. The confidentiality of the data provided must also be protected; That is why I voted in favour.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. The objective of this regulation is to transform the voluntary basis regarding the collection of data for natural gas and electricity prices charged to household end-users into an obligatory one. Statistics must then be provided by Member States to Eurostat. The benefits of collecting the data regarding the natural gas and electricity prices that consumers pay in different Member States include that it will enhance transparency and may help to protect households from profiteering. However, the report also states that its aim is to develop a fully-integrated internal energy market. Sinn Féin believes that more transparency and obligatory reporting in the energy market is certainly required, but we have concerns about the Energy Union and the impact of a ‘fully integrated internal energy market’, so for this reason abstained.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report concerning statistics on natural gas and electricity prices. Since the 1970s the Commission has been collecting data on natural gas and electricity prices. In 1990 the Council adopted the directive to define the procedure to improve the transparency of gas and electricity prices charged to industrial end-users. According to this directive, for household and final non-household consumers, the collection of data has been done by national authorities on a voluntary basis. I support the proposal to transform the voluntary basis into a mandatory one as serious problems in the data collection occurred as has been reported by several Member States.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not take part in this vote because the rapporteur of the report comes from the ENF group and it is the fixed position of the Group of the Socialists and Democrats not to take part in corresponding votes.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The legislative proposal to amend the current Directive 2008/92/EC was published in November 2015 as part of the State of the Energy Union package. The aim of this proposal is to create a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of comparable European statistics on gas and electricity prices for household and final customers in the EU. The aim of this regulation is now to make voluntary action a liability in order to prevent problems with data collection reported by several Member States. I agree with the Commission's proposal to regulate the collection of both types of data by means of a legal act. This is the only way to guarantee the quality of the collection of electricity and gas prices in the household sector and to ensure maximum transparency on the gas and electricity prices to be paid by the industrial final consumer. Markets must continue to be thoroughly covered and price data must remain of high quality. The best way to do this is through a Community procedure.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The proposed regulation calls for mandatory collection of statistics on electricity and gas prices issued to individuals, whereas this collection was previously voluntary. For companies, a 2008 directive already made this collection mandatory. This proposal is an accessory to the energy liberalisation packages adopted in 2004-2012. The stated aim is to make European statistics and then encourage the creation of European and then transatlantic transnational oligopolies, which, "put in competition", will "lower prices". The opposite happened, the Commission forced France to raise EDF tariffs from 2007, in order to artificially create a competitive electricity market. With regard to gas, it is a challenge to make it appear that private, non-state-backed actors will guarantee a secure and affordable supply. Beyond this general consideration, three criticisms can be made to the text: the choice of regulation over the directive; a delegation of power (Articles 9 and 10) with no term limit; an additional declarative system that will make the management of the companies involved more difficult. So I voted against this proposal.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of transparency and democracy I voted against this report. In the context of the ‘Energy Union strategy’ the Commission has committed to preparing reports about energy costs and process every two years starting in 2016. The statistical data on gas and electricity prices are needed by the Commission to monitor the internal market and will no doubt be used as the basis for more unnecessary legislation from the EU.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to move from an optional basis to a compulsory basis, so as to avoid problems in the collection of data reported by several Member States.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not vote in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on European statistics on the prices of natural gas and electricity.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this commission proposal, which wants to strengthen the obligations made to States: the level of constraint is too high for states and businesses, and this new delegation of powers to the Commission seems to me to be totally unjustified.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this regulation to establish a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of comparable European statistics on natural gas and electricity prices to residential and non-residential end customers in the EU. This text proposes that Member States collect data on natural gas and electricity prices and their sub-components (network costs, taxes, levies, charges and charges) as well as on consumption volumes. The collection of this data is currently carried out on the basis of a voluntary agreement, sometimes making it difficult to collect complete statistics that allow us to account for the reality of costs within the Union. As the increasing complexity of the internal energy market makes it increasingly difficult and increasingly important to obtain reliable and up-to-date data, a legislative act covering the collection of both types of data will be beneficial.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. This resolution aims to make it mandatory to collect data on the prices of natural gas and electricity applied to domestic users which the Commission has been collecting since 1970, in order to avoid problems in this task as several Member States have pointed out.  I believe that this measure is necessary to prevent quality from deteriorating considerably, as well as to continue to maintain broad market coverage and a high level of quality of price data.  This information is essential to ensure a high level of transparency and information following the process of harmonisation and liberalization that has taken place in the Union's internal energy market. This liberalization must also have an impact on competitive prices and quality service, avoiding the oligopolistic practices that, in the case of Spain, have resulted in a 70% increase in the invoice in the last ten years. Spain is currently the fourth country with the highest electricity bill in Europe. For these reasons I voted in favour.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Kappel report, presented to Parliament today, aims to transform the collection of natural gas and electricity price data from voluntary to compulsory, so as to avoid the problems already experienced by several Member States.  This is necessary to avoid a significant deterioration in the quality of the household data survey and to continue to maintain broad market coverage and a high quality of price information. Although I agree with the substance of the report, I have decided not to take part in the vote, in disagreement with the legitimacy of the work of the extreme right-wing Group ENF.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. If at first glance the general idea of the report may seem good: to force Member States to communicate statistics on the price of gas and electricity to Eurostat, in the end what it seeks is a way to promote the single energy market at European level. This market is in the sense of further liberalization of the energy sector, which means a more important role for the market and less power for States, so that they can regulate the sector according to environmental or social considerations. That's why I vote against it.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Unfortunately, I had to vote against my Colleague Kappel's legislative resolution on the proposed regulation on European gas and electricity price statistics. Despite an attempt by the rapporteur to amend this text in a way more favourable to the industrial sovereignty of European nations, those amendments have been emptied of their content in the ITRE committee. However, the aim of this proposal is none other than the Europeanisation of the industrial sector, since European statistics must encourage the creation of oligopolies, first European and then transatlantic, in this always similar logic of mass liberalisation. It should be remembered that this competition, which is supposed to bring down prices for the consumer, had the opposite effect when, for example, the Commission pushed France to increase EDF tariffs in 2007 in order to artificially create (where is the invisible hand?) competition in the electricity market. The Commission, by choosing to go through the regulation and not the directive, continues its attempt at full control over the Member States, without any guarantee of added value for consumers.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mrs Kappel's report on statistics on natural gas and electricity prices is balanced and acceptable. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The collection of data on natural gas and electricity prices for domestic users has been being carried out on a voluntary basis – with a response rate of 100 %. The aim is to make this voluntary character mandatory, as it is for industrial prices, which should not entail an additional burden on the notifying authorities; data will continue to be collected by the competent national authorities.  The report, among other issues, aims to clarify the objectives, to provide certain provisions for the notifying authorities and companies to provide the data and to avoid unparalleled data series.  In accordance with the guidelines of the S&D Group, I did not vote on the report when it was drafted by a rapporteur of the Group of Europe of Nations and Freedom of, among others, the far-right French National Front. However, its content is not controversial and an interinstitutional agreement was reached at first reading.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has expressed Parliament's position on the future EU regulation on European statistics on natural gas and electricity prices. Since the 1980s, the European Commission has been collecting data on natural gas and electricity prices. 1990 The Council adopted a directive setting out a procedure to increase the transparency of gas and electricity prices charged to industrial end-users, but not to household customers. Eurostat must collect and publish data. In 2007, the methodology was improved to take account of liberalised energy markets. At the same time, data on natural gas and electricity prices for final household customers were collected on a voluntary basis and the response rate was 100%. The aim of the Regulation is to make a voluntary way of making it compulsory to avoid problems in data collection, as reported by some Member States. This step is necessary in order to prevent a significant reduction in the quality of electricity and natural gas price data surveys and to continue to achieve a high market share and high quality of price data.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Based on the directives so far regulating the field of data collection on natural gas and electricity prices, data collection is voluntary for end-users in households. Such a solution has led to certain problems in the collection of data by individual Member States. This regulation now allows data collection to be mandatory, both for industrial end-users and end-users in households.  This improves and introduces complete transparency of natural gas and electricity prices for all users and enables the sustainability of high quality data in this area. The collection of price data should not put further pressure on reporting authorities, while the competent national authorities would continue to collect price data.  Also, the report pointed to several important points and proposed good solutions, relating to the problems of identifying entities responsible for price breakdown, which cannot be left to suppliers, then to preserve confidentiality of data on suppliers and consumers, as well as in the segment relating to the explanation that the general average share of transmission and distribution costs can only be distinguished at the general level of households and non-household customers. I reckon these are all premeditated solutions, which is why my support and voice go to this report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this report, which is a regulation on collecting statistics on gas and electricity prices, converting gentleman's agreement into regulations for domestic prices. Laws already exist for industrial prices. The content, therefore, is not in dispute.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Citizens have the right to make their own market choices regarding electricity and natural gas in complete freedom and awareness, to look for the supplier that offers them the best satisfaction of their personal and family needs. This is not possible if Community legislation is not up-to-date and if the real final gas and electricity prices are not transparent and comprehensible to the citizen. We need clarity both on the term 'burden' and on excise duties, specifying where they fall, how much they amount to and what the final real price of the service for the user is. It is a rule of civilisation and transparency.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to amend a proposed regulation that makes it mandatory to collect statistics on gas and electricity prices issued to individuals in residential areas. As a reminder, a 2008 directive already made this collection mandatory for businesses. According to this regulation, the development of European statistics should lead to the creation of transnational and then transatlantic European oligopolies to promote competition, and thus lower prices. As a reminder, the European Commission had imposed on France an increase in EDF tariffs in 2007 to artificially create a competitive electricity market. Therefore, it is an illusion that non-state-backed private actors will ensure a safe and affordable supply for consumers. Although this report opposes the delegation of powers to the Commission without a term limit, I voted against this text which will strengthen administrative constraints for Member States and businesses.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The objective of this regulation is to make voluntary being binding in order to avoid problems related to the collection of data reported by several Member States.  This is necessary in order not to allow the quality of the collection of data on electricity and natural gas prices for the household consumer sector to decrease significantly and to further achieve broad market coverage and high quality of price data. I voted in favour of this report which seeks to simplify the way in which price data is collected, a procedure which should not create an additional burden for the reporting authorities, which will be collected by the competent national authorities.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 1990, the Directive was adopted which defined the procedure for increasing the transparency of gas and electricity prices paid by industrial final consumers, and data on gas and electricity prices paid by final household consumers are now being collected on a voluntary basis. I support this Regulation on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on European statistics on gas and electricity prices and repealing Directive 2008/92/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council on a Community procedure to improve the transparency of gas and electricity prices applied to end-users in the industry, as I consider it necessary to make the voluntary nature binding in order to avoid problems related to the collection of data reported by several Member States. The collection of price data should be the responsibility of the competent national authorities, so as not to complicate the current situation in any way.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this regulation, which improves the collection of data on natural gas and electricity prices applied to domestic end consumers.  The methodology currently applied operates on a voluntary basis. The aim of the regulation is to transform the voluntary basis into a compulsory basis, so as to avoid problems in the collection of data, as several Member States have pointed out. This measure is necessary to avoid a significant deterioration in the quality of the household electricity and natural gas price data survey and to continue to maintain broad market coverage and high quality of price data.  Data collection will not entail an additional burden for the authorities responsible for data transmission and price data will continue to be collected by the competent national authorities.  Parliament's position aims to clarify the objectives, simplify certain provisions for the data transmission authorities and the companies that have to provide the data, and avoid misunderstandings which, in the worst case, could give rise to non-comparable data sets.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. The objective of this regulation is to transform the voluntary basis regarding the collection of data for natural gas and electricity prices charged to household end-users into an obligatory one. Statistics must then be provided by Member States to Eurostat. The benefits of collecting the data regarding the natural gas and electricity prices that consumers pay in different Member States include that it will enhance transparency and may help to protect households from profiteering. However, the report also states that its aim is to develop a fully-integrated internal energy market. Sinn Féin believes that more transparency and obligatory reporting in the energy market is certainly required, but we have concerns about the Energy Union and the impact of a ‘fully integrated internal energy market’, so for this reason abstained.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Currently, the collection of data for natural gas and electricity prices charged to household end-users has been carried out on a voluntary basis. In order to ensure high quality reporting of price data for both the household and the-household sector, the Commission considered that the collection of both types of data should be covered by a legal act. I agree with the report and believe that in order to not let the quality of the survey of the electricity and natural gas price data for the household sector deteriorate significantly, and in order to continue to achieve a wide market coverage and high quality of price data, this step is necessary.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a relatively neutral report, as it deals with the formulation of statistics, correct, without criticality, already supported in the ITRE Committee. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as we believe that the voluntary basis should be transformed into mandatory, so as to avoid problems in the collection of data from certain Member States. This step is necessary in order to avoid a reduction in the quality of electricity and gas price data research for the household sector and to continue to achieve broad market coverage and high-quality pricing data.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on European statistics on gas and electricity prices. Indeed, the proposal to collect data on natural gas and electricity prices is positive, as transparency can be enhanced, subject to conditions, and households can be protected from profiteering. However, the report states that the aim is to strengthen a complete, integrated internal energy market. We must be careful in this respect and always act in the interests of the citizens. As this has not been guaranteed, I voted against it.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the Kappel report on statistics on natural gas and electricity.  In fact, this document aims to improve the quality of data on electricity and natural gas prices by repealing Directive 2008/92/EC and introducing new measures. In particular, the shift from voluntary data communication to mandatory communication is a step forward in the field of transparency for the domestic end consumer. In addition, the report clarifies the objectives and simplifies the procedures for the transmission of data in order to avoid misunderstandings, thus facilitating the comparison of data. I understand the decision of the French delegation, which considered it appropriate to express an opinion against this report for political reasons, but I would point out that, from a practical point of view, the work carried out by Mr De Clercq, who has done a good job, is a good one. Kappel remains very good.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the Statistics on natural gas and electricity prices and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU has long collected data on the prices of natural gas and electricity collected and published by Eurostat, and its procedure has been improved but is a voluntary basis. I support the Kappel Report, which transitions from a voluntary scheme to a compulsory regime for the collection of data on natural gas and electricity prices, avoiding the occurrence of problems reported by states, benefiting the consumer and allowing for extensive market coverage with a high level of quality of price data. With the new rules set out in this report, objectives are clarified, procedures simplified and transparency increased.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution, as I agree with the need to carry out a mandatory collection of data on natural gas and electricity prices, applied to domestic consumers, in order to avoid problems in statistical surveys on the one hand and to prevent a deterioration in the quality of the survey of price data. The protection of the final consumer must be guaranteed through transparent and homogeneous detection systems.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – I support the call to define the procedure to improve the transparency of gas and electricity prices charged to industrial end-users. A good understanding of the taxes, fees, levies and charges in each Member State is essential for ensuring price transparency. The importance of a breakdown of the data on network costs, taxes, fees, levies and charges is also a must, as the report rightly underlines.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it is a step forward in the implementation of the Energy Union. While we consider harmonization in terms of price structure important, in order to improve the transparency of electricity markets and the final price paid by the consumer, this proposal is made with the sole intention of deepening the integration of energy markets. Our bet is against the Energy Union, since we consider energy to be a public good and not just a commodity. That is why and our opposition to the Energy Union is why, despite considering it necessary to harmonise statistics in the Union, I voted against this report.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has collected data on electricity and natural gas prices since the 1970s. The collection of data on gas and electricity prices paid by household consumers shall be carried out on a voluntary basis. I voted to make voluntary to compulsory, both domestic and industrial consumers. This data is to be collected by the competent national authorities. Simplification of the data collection and analysis procedure is a priority in this case. Current statistics are based on checking invoices in vendor databases. In this respect, it is important to protect the confidentiality of information on consumers and suppliers.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I agree with the regulation, which refers to the obligation imposed on Member States to collect and submit statistics on natural gas and electricity prices for industrial consumers and households. These data relate to electricity prices, network access charges, taxes and charges and their sub-components and would be reported every six months. The proposed Regulation aims to replace Directive 2008/92/EC, which imposes such an obligation on industrial customers. The collection and submission of data aims to monitor the internal energy market and the impact of different energy policies, such as the promotion of renewable energy sources. I voted in favour of the document.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report focuses on the development of statistics on the price of gas and electricity. Being opposed to the political values and principles championed by rapporteur Barbara Kappell, an Austrian MP and member of the Europhobic group 'Europe of Nations and Freedoms', I have decided not to support this report.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has been collecting data on gas and electricity prices since the 1970s. In 1990, the Council adopted a Directive defining a procedure for improving the transparency of gas and electricity prices to be paid by industrial end-users; however, this does not a problem for household consumers. The increasingly complex internal energy market has increasingly made it increasingly difficult to obtain reliable and up-to-date data on gas and electricity prices, particularly in the residential sector, due to the lack of binding rules on the provision of data. The aim of the report is to ensure that the quality of the assessment of electricity and gas prices in the household sector is not embated, that it provides an image of the wide range of markets and that the high quality of price data is maintained. Under the proposal, data collection would not impose an additional burden on reporting authorities and the collection of price data would continue to be carried out by the competent national authorities. The purpose of this report is to clarify the objectives and to clarify certain provisions for the authorities and firms responsible for providing information.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. "Since the 1970s, the European Commission has been collecting data on gas and electricity prices. In 1990, the Council adopted a Directive defining a procedure for improving the transparency of gas and electricity prices to be paid by industrial end-users; however, this does not a problem for household consumers. The increasingly complex internal energy market and the lack of binding rules on the provision of data have made it increasingly difficult to obtain reliable and up-to-date data on gas and electricity prices, particularly in the residential sector. The aim of the report is to ensure that the quality of the assessment of electricity and gas prices in the household sector is not embated, that it provides an image of the wide range of markets and that the high quality of price data is maintained. Under the proposal, data collection would not impose an additional burden on reporting authorities and the collection of price data would continue to be carried out by the competent national authorities. The purpose of this report is to clarify the objectives and to clarify certain provisions for the authorities and firms responsible for providing information.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report, but against the Commission's proposal and against the mandate of delegation. This text complements the energy liberalisation packages adopted in 2004-2012. The aim is to gather European statistics to encourage the creation of European transnational oligopolies. However, this text should logically be the subject of a directive, not a regulation. Secondly, the delegation of power in favour of the Commission knows no time limit. Finally, this system puts in place heavy administrative management, which is a source of difficulties for the companies concerned.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not support this report, although we have witnessed an in-depth consultation process in the form of dialogue not only with Member States but also with national regulators. The Regulation was interpreted in order to replace Directive 2008/92/EC. Under this Regulation, Member States will have to collect and submit price statistics for industrial consumers and households for natural gas and electricity. Price data will be reported every six months for different consumption volumes and will cover energy prices, access charges, fees and levies, as well as their subcomponents. Notwithstanding the odd first impression, this report deals only with factual reporting and imposes other obligations on Member States. Member States' sovereignty over policy therefore remains intact. This is the reason why I decided to support this initiative.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report grants super powers to the Commission, especially in the area of the adoption of delegated acts with a view to amending the text of the Regulation.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has been collecting data on gas and electricity prices since the 1970s. In 1990, the Council adopted a Directive defining a procedure for improving the transparency of gas and electricity prices to be paid by industrial end-users; however, this does not a problem for household consumers. In an increasingly complex internal energy market, the absence of mandatory legal rules on the provision of data has made it increasingly difficult to obtain reliable and up-to-date data on gas and electricity prices, particularly in the residential sector. The aim of the report is to ensure that the quality of the assessment of electricity and gas prices in the household sector is not embated, that it provides an image of the wide range of markets and that the high quality of price data is maintained. Under the proposal, data collection would not impose an additional burden on reporting authorities and the collection of price data would continue to be carried out by the competent national authorities. The purpose of this report is to clarify the objectives and to clarify certain provisions for the authorities and firms responsible for providing information. Under the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The collection of data on prices in the final consumer of natural gas and electricity was carried out on a voluntary basis — with a response rate of 100 %. The aim of this Regulation is to transform a voluntary scheme into a compulsory scheme in order to avoid problems in data collection. This step is necessary in order to avoid that the quality of the survey data on electricity and natural gas prices for the domestic consumption sector is significantly deterrised and to continue to achieve broad market coverage, as well as a high level of price data quality. This report aims to clarify the objectives, simplify certain provisions for reporting authorities and companies that have to provide the data, and avoid misunderstandings which – at worst – would lead to unmatched data sets.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against the Commission's proposal, against the negotiating mandate and for the report: even with the amendments to abolish the delegation which limits the break-up, the Commission's proposal does not look good enough to be voted on, due to a level of constraint too high for states and businesses and an unjustified delegation to the Commission.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the 1970s, the European Commission has collected data on natural gas and electricity prices. In 1990, the Council adopted the Directive setting out the procedure to improve price transparency in the final industrial consumer of gas and electricity, but not with regard to the domestic consumer. The methodology was amended in 2007 to take account of the liberalisation of energy markets. Meanwhile, the collection of data on prices in the final consumer of natural gas and electricity was carried out on a voluntary basis — with a response rate of 100%. According to the rapporteur, the "objective of this regulation is to transform a voluntary scheme into a compulsory scheme in order to avoid problems in data collection, as has been reported by several Member States". We are in favour of collecting data on gas and electricity prices with a view to transparency and protection of families and final consumers. However, this report is yet another chapter in the European Single Market specifications and the energy union, made up here and there of pretense good intentions. We voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as it is necessary to change the system for collecting data on natural gas and electricity prices, applied to domestic end consumers, from the current voluntary to compulsory survey. This change avoids a deterioration in the quality of the survey, while ensuring broad market coverage and high quality of price data.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Based on the changed methodology of 2007, the collection of data on natural gas and electricity prices charged to final customers was carried out on a voluntary basis. The objective of this Regulation is to make voluntary data collection compulsory in order not to deteriorate the quality of price surveys in the household sector and to continue to ensure high quality. The national regulatory authority or government should propose a cost breakdown methodology. The communication of price information will become mandatory for large customers outside households.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report which makes it compulsory to collect data on natural gas and electricity prices, so as to avoid problems in detection.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report as it grants super powers to the Commission, especially in the area of the adoption of delegated acts with a view to amending the text of the regulation.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as the collection of statistical data will enable Member States to plan their energy needs better. In addition, the collection of prices will enable the internal energy market to function better and ultimately lead to lower prices for consumers. I am pleased that the Commission carried out extensive consultations with the Member States governments so that the proposal put forward that was acceptable to the majority.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has been collecting data on gas and electricity prices since the 1970s. In 1990, the Council adopted a Directive defining a procedure for improving the transparency of gas and electricity prices to be paid by industrial end-users; however, this does not a problem for household consumers. The increasingly complex internal energy market and the lack of binding rules on the provision of data have made it increasingly difficult to obtain reliable and up-to-date data on gas and electricity prices, particularly in the residential sector. The aim of the report is to ensure that the quality of the assessment of electricity and gas prices in the household sector is not embated, that it provides an image of the wide range of markets and that the high quality of price data is maintained. Under the proposal, data collection would not impose an additional burden on reporting authorities and the collection of price data would continue to be carried out by the competent national authorities. The purpose of this report is to clarify the objectives and to clarify certain provisions for the authorities and firms responsible for providing information.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has been collecting data on gas and electricity prices since the 1970s. In 1990, the Council adopted a Directive defining a procedure for improving the transparency of gas and electricity prices payable by industrial end-users, but this does not apply to household customers. The increasingly complex internal energy market and the lack of binding rules on the provision of data have made it increasingly difficult to obtain reliable and up-to-date data on gas and electricity prices, particularly in the residential sector. The aim of the report is to ensure that the quality of the assessment of electricity and gas prices in the household sector is not embated, that it provides an image of the wide range of markets and that the high quality of price data is maintained. Under the proposal, data collection would not impose an additional burden on reporting authorities and the collection of price data would continue to be carried out by the competent national authorities. The purpose of this report is to clarify the objectives and to clarify certain provisions for the authorities and firms responsible for providing information.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report, considering that, since the 1970s, the European Commission has been collecting data on the prices of natural gas and electricity. The methodology was modified in 2007 to take account of the liberalization of energy markets. In the meantime, the collection of data on the prices of natural gas and electricity applied to domestic users has been carried out on a voluntary basis, with a response rate of 100%. The aim of the new Regulation is to make this voluntary nature mandatory, in order to avoid problems in data collection. There is no doubt that this measure is necessary to prevent the quality of the survey on electricity and natural gas price data for the household sector from deteriorating considerably.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Energy, both gas and electricity is the lifeblood of the modern economy and thus energy policies have a huge impact on consumers and businesses alike. In order for us policy makers to make the best possible regulations in order to support the energy market there is a natural need for up-to-date quality information and data. Given this, I supported this report, as it will help us make rules and regulations for European energy market with the most relevant information. This is key to make the market sustainable while promoting economic growth in the wider economy.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on natural gas and electricity price statistics today. What sounds very technical is of considerable importance for the daily lives of citizens and families in Europe, who are increasingly burdened with rising gas and electricity prices. By improving the comparability of national statistics in this area, the EU is ensuring better comparability and greater genuine freedom of choice in the internal market. This saves us citizens and families money!

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. A uniform statistics on natural gas and electricity prices within the European Union are to be welcomed. Such statistics, under the supervision of Eurostat, serve comparability and contribute significantly to the transparency of the energy market. I believe that this will significantly strengthen the rights of the final consumer.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. If at first glance the general idea of the report may seem good: to force Member States to communicate statistics on the price of gas and electricity to Eurostat, in the end what it seeks is a way to promote the single energy market at European level. This market is in the sense of further liberalization of the energy sector, which means a more important role for the market and less power for States, so that they can regulate the sector according to environmental or social considerations. That's why I vote against it.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Following my group position, I did not vote on this report, as this is a report drafted by an ENF Member.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The price collection is supposed to not lead to an additional burden for the reporting authorities and the price data will continue to be collected by the competent national authorities. This report aims to clarify the goals, facilitate certain provisions for the reporting authorities and the companies which have to provide the data, as well as to avoid misunderstandings which – in the worst case – would lead to incomparable data sets.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The main objective of the report is to promote reforms to enhance competitiveness and complete the single market for gas and electricity. In our view, it is very important to increase transparency with regard to the prices charged to domestic consumers for gas and electricity. Our main objective is to protect citizens from profiteering, and to ensure the security of the energy supply of households at the lowest possible prices. For these reasons, we consider this attitude of voting against appropriate.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation that will make it mandatory for the national regulatory authority or government to submit a cost breakdown methodology on the natural gas and electricity prices in their Member State, to ensure the correct and fair comparability of prices between countries. Until now, the European Commission has been collecting data on natural gas and electricity prices on a voluntary basis from Member States. However as problems in the data collection have been increasingly reported by several Member States, this regulation is being brought in to law to transform the voluntary basis of collection into an obligatory one. I believe the introduction of this regulation will help prevent any further problems in the quality of data collection.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation requires Member States to collect and submit statistics every six months on the prices charged to industrial consumers and households for natural gas and electricity. Seeing as it was proposed after consulting the Member States, and considering this reporting will not have an impact on policies of individual countries but will allow to monitor the market, I have voted favourably.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has been collecting data on gas and electricity prices since the 1970s. In 1990, the Council adopted a Directive defining a procedure for improving the transparency of gas and electricity prices payable by industrial end-users, but this does not apply to household customers. The increasingly complex internal energy market and the lack of binding rules on the provision of data have made it increasingly difficult to obtain reliable and up-to-date data on gas and electricity prices, particularly in the residential sector. The aim of the report is to ensure that the quality of the assessment of electricity and gas prices in the household sector is not embated, that it provides an image of the wide range of markets and that the high quality of price data is maintained. Under the proposal, data collection would not impose an additional burden on reporting authorities and the collection of price data would continue to be carried out by the competent national authorities. The purpose of this report is to clarify the objectives and to clarify certain provisions for the authorities and firms responsible for providing information.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on European statistics on natural gas and electricity prices and the repeal of Directive 2008/92/EC of the European Parliament and the Council on the Community procedure to improve the transparency of gas and electricity prices charged to industrial end-users, because I think it is necessary to provide quality and accurate data on gas and electricity prices for households in order to ensure high market coverage.  The collection of price data should not result in an additional burden for reporting authorities and the competent national authorities will continue to collect price data. The aim of this report is to clarify the objectives, simplify certain provisions for reporting bodies and companies providing data on natural gas and electricity prices, in order to avoid misunderstandings, inaccurate data and unclear results.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This text provides for the collection of statistics on electricity and gas prices issued to individuals, even though this collection was voluntary. For companies, a 2008 directive already made this collection mandatory. This proposal is an accessory to the energy liberalisation packages adopted in 2004-2012. The stated aim is to make European statistics and then encourage the creation of European transnational and then transatlantic oligopolies, which "compete" and "lower prices". However, the opposite happened, the European Commission forced France to increase EDF tariffs from 2007, to create, artificially a competitive electricity market. Moreover, with regard to gas, it is a challenge to make it appear that private, non-state-backed actors will ensure a secure and affordable supply. The removal of the delegation to the committee (amendments 1.3,6) is a good move. Some of the rapporteur's more sovereignist and "pro-industry" ideas were, however, emptied in the ITRE committee. If I opposed the Commission's proposal and the negotiating mandate, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report. It provides that price statistics will be collected not only for non-household customers, but also for household customers, so that information-based decisions can be taken in the area of European energy policy for the benefit of electricity and gas consumers.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Reliable statistical data are needed to ensure the functioning of the single energy market. That is why the European Commission has put forward legislation that will ensure the collection and evaluation of high-quality data on gas and electricity prices in the European Union. The Commission will, following the adoption of this law, obtain data on the prices of natural gas and electricity paid by households and businesses and will be able to carry out an in-depth assessment of the functioning of the single energy market with a view to presenting appropriate legislation to address the shortcomings if necessary. For the above reasons, I voted in favour of this law.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as its objective is to transform the voluntary basis of the collection of data for households into an obligatory one, so as to avoid problems in data collection as having been reported by several Member States.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Prices of natural gas and electricity are interesting from a number of perspectives. One of the most important reasons why these prices are to be compulsorily monitored in the long term is the comparability of the data collected. Gas and electricity supply are currently typical network sectors. Fortunately, the parameters of both electricity and gas are unified in the EU countries (voltage and frequency stability for AC, quality parameters for natural gas). However, the price for the final consumer has at least two components, the price per quantity (normal cubic meters for gas, kWh) and the price per supply. In particular, for the various 'supply prices', we see the need to define which charges will be part of the price of energy under transport and network usage respectively, and which are the amount of energy consumed. This is mainly about excise duties and variously structured network connection charges. The Regulation is intended to harmonise the methodology for the reporting of prices in order to eliminate any identified ambiguities. This is how we can get reliable statistical information. Reference periods, frequency of data transmission and possibility of granting exemptions are defined. The report is quite clear, I hope that the practical application of this regulation will not find fundamental ambiguities. Since Directive 2008/92/EC is repealed at the same time as the adoption of the Regulation, there is also no increase in the number of eu directives and regulations in force. I therefore support the adoption of the report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 13 September 2016, we voted in plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on the report on the proposal for a regulation on European statistics on gas and electricity prices. Statistics for gas and electricity prices are part of the European Energy Statistics System managed by Eurostat. The aim of this Regulation is to transform on a voluntary basis data collection for gas and electricity prices charged to end-customers – households into mandatory. Personally, I am in support of the idea of collecting data on gas and electricity prices that consumers pay in different countries, as this will increase transparency and may help protect households and final consumers from the dubious pricing practices of some energy and gas suppliers. This step is also necessary for the quality of electricity and gas price data exploration. However, the report itself is written in the spirit of the EU's direction towards a complete, common internal energy market, which I cannot agree with at all. In fact, I have long held the view that the issue of energy supply and production is purely within the sovereign competences of nation states and should certainly not be transferred to a Pan-European level. From my point of view, the very discussion of the document has also not benefited from the fact that some colleagues have tried to smuggle changes to the text to the detriment of nuclear energy. That's why I had to abstain.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has been collecting data on gas and electricity prices since the 1970s. In 1990, the Council adopted a Directive defining a procedure for improving the transparency of gas and electricity prices to be paid by industrial end-users; however, this does not a problem for household consumers. In an increasingly complex internal energy market, the absence of mandatory legal rules on the provision of data has made it increasingly difficult to obtain reliable and up-to-date data on gas and electricity prices, particularly in the residential sector. The aim of the report is to ensure that the quality of the assessment of electricity and gas prices in the household sector is not embated, that it provides an image of the wide range of markets and that the high quality of price data is maintained. Under the proposal, data collection would not impose an additional burden on reporting authorities and the collection of price data would continue to be carried out by the competent national authorities. The purpose of this report is to clarify the objectives and to clarify certain provisions for the authorities and firms responsible for providing information.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. – I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on European statistics on gas and electricity prices and repealing Directive 2008/92/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council on a Community procedure to improve the transparency of gas and electricity prices for industrial end-users, as I believe that access to data on natural gas and electricity prices is in the interest of the final household consumer.  This step would improve the quality of research into electricity and gas price data for the household sector, the inclusion of components such as excise duties, and ensuring price comparability between Member States. I believe that access to data for the household and non-household consumer sectors would help to improve the cost breakdown methodology and the accuracy of the overall average share of transmission and distribution costs.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution because the collection of the electricity and natural gas price charged to industrial consumers and households should become obligatory for all Member States. This step is necessary in order to continue to achieve a wide market coverage and high quality of price data. The price data on gas and electricity prices are needed for monitoring the internal market for energy, and the impacts of various policies in the field of energy, such as support for renewable energy sources. This is particularly important in the context of the Energy Union strategy, which obligates the Commission to prepare reports about energy costs and prices every two years, starting in 2016.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The measures contained in this report are necessary to avoid damage to the quality of the survey of electricity and natural gas price data for the domestic sector, and to continue to maintain broad market coverage and high quality of price data. It aims, among other points, to facilitate certain provisions for the responsible data transmission authorities and the companies providing the data, as well as to avoid circumstances which may give cause for misunderstanding with regard to non-comparable data. Consequently, I believe that we should support the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution, as put to the vote today.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it strengthens the obligations on states.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on gas and electricity price statistics. This text provides for mandatory collection of statistics on electricity and gas prices issued to individuals, even though this collection was voluntary. For companies, a 2008 directive already made this collection mandatory. This proposal is an accessory to the energy liberalisation packages adopted in 2004-2012. The stated aim is to make European statistics and then encourage the creation of European transnational and then transatlantic oligopolies, which "compete" and "lower prices". However, the opposite happened, the European Commission forced France to increase EDF tariffs from 2007, to create, artificially a competitive electricity market. Moreover, with regard to gas, it is a challenge to make it appear that private, non-state-backed actors will ensure a secure and affordable supply.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission's proposal does not seem acceptable to me, because of a high level of constraint for States and businesses, and an unjustified delegation to the Commission. I therefore voted against the Commission's proposal, against the negotiating mandate and for the report itself.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it is a step forward in the implementation of the Energy Union. While we consider harmonization in terms of price structure important, in order to improve the transparency of electricity markets and the final price paid by the consumer, this proposal is made with the sole intention of deepening the integration of energy markets. Our bet is against the Energy Union, since we consider energy to be a public good and not just a commodity. That is why and our opposition to the Energy Union is why, despite considering it necessary to harmonise statistics in the Union, I voted against this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of collecting data in order to be able to compare prices of natural gas and electricity in other Member States. This will ensure high quality price data.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the expansion of the mandatory reporting circuit for statistical purposes, it unnecessarily burdens companies.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The objective of this regulation is to transform the voluntary basis of collecting information about gas prices into an obligatory one to avoid problems in the data collection as has been reported by several Member States.  I fully support the adoption of this regulation, because the creation of the common European energy market needs reliable information. The way to a common EU energy market consists of a lot of steps. This important decision is one of them.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \u2012 The aim of this proposal is to make the current voluntary collection of data on natural gas and electricity prices mandatory in order to improve the quality of the survey while maintaining the protection of sensitive data on consumers and suppliers. Data collection will continue to be carried out by national authorities. I therefore support the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on European statistics on the prices of natural gas and electricity and on the repeal of Directive 2008/92/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council on a Community procedure to improve the transparency of gas and electricity prices charged to industrial final customers.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on European statistics on gas and electricity prices and on the repeal of Directive 2008/92/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council on a Community procedure to improve the transparency of gas and electricity prices for the final industrial consumer, because it is not sufficiently documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report, but against the Commission's proposal and against the mandate of delegation. This text is incidental to the energy liberalisation packages adopted in 2004-2012. The aim is to bring together European statistics and then encourage the creation of European transnational oligopolies.  I address to the texts three essential reproaches: first of all, this text should logically be the subject of a directive, not a regulation. Secondly, the delegation of power in favour of the Commission knows no time limit. Finally, this system puts in place heavy administrative management, which is a source of difficulties for the companies concerned.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. – Regarding the report on the proposal for a regulation of the EU Parliament and of the Council on European statistics on natural gas and electricity prices, I find it crucial to make the voluntary collection of data obligatory not only to avoid any sort of conflict and misunderstanding, but also to be able to provide high-quality price data. I give my full support to the transparency of prices but also assert the need of confidentiality of sensitive information of consumers and suppliers. Without further delay, I want to express my positive vote towards the resolution.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we looked at a report setting out the procedure for collecting and transmitting statistical data to the European Commission and EUROSTAT on gas and electricity prices. The regulation we have discussed today aims to make voluntary data collection mandatory to date. In principle, I would not have a problem with this, although I do not see any convincing safeguards for the protection of consumers/ customers' personal data in the Regulation. However, I do not agree that the rapporteur proposes changes to the breakdown of costs, the proposal does not specify who will be responsible for the breakdown of prices, nor does it define the term 'fee'. Because of these shortcomings, I abstained from voting.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This ensures the quality of the collection of electricity and natural gas prices in the household sector. These statistics are used to ensure price stability for private end customers. I can only support that.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Commission has been collecting data on natural gas and electricity prices since the 1970s. Nevertheless, the provision of this data remains optional for residential customer prices. The text aims to make this procedure mandatory. It also seeks to clarify the modalities so that the data collected are "quality, complete and comparable data that indicate the price of natural gas and electricity. The existence of comparable data in this area will be favourable to consumers and end-users. I vote for this text regretting the political identity of its author.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission's proposal does not seem acceptable because of too high a level of constraint for states and businesses and an unjustified delegation to the Commission. So I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. 'competitiveness, sustainability and energy security' are the overall objectives of a resilient Energy Union with a visionary climate change policy. The existence of high-quality, comparable, up-to-date, reliable and harmonised information on the prices of natural gas and electricity charged to final consumers is necessary to define energy union policy and monitor member states' energy markets. The purpose of this Regulation is to provide European statistics to support energy policies, in particular aimed at creating a fully integrated internal energy market for consumers. There should be greater transparency of energy costs and prices, as well as public support, to improve market integration. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative resolution as it seeks to ensure that the quality of data related to electricity and natural gas for the household sector remains of a high standard by making reporting obligatory.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The creation of an energy market must first involve the provision of reliable statistics for all Member States in order to be able to compare the price of gas and electricity charged to residential and non-residential end customers in the European Union. In particular, this allows us to monitor the evolution of the European market and to propose adequate responses to this issue of primary necessity. Until now, the transmission of statistics was voluntary, but it is necessary to become mandatory. This will ensure the continued reliability of the data collected in the future. This is crucial because, after all, our whole society, our daily lives, is based on the supply of energy. Being able to have access to gas or electricity is essential for the competitiveness of our businesses.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – the European Commission has been collecting data on natural gas and electricity prices through Eurostat for a long time, but for final customers – households have hitherto been on a voluntary basis. This Regulation aims to make voluntary collection compulsory. This would allow for better collection of price data for as much of the market as possible and in high quality. The collection of price data should not be a burden on the authorities active in this process; The report also points to the need to change the breakdown in the area of charges and thus the current situation, which makes it possible to shift charges from the grid to energy and vice versa. Emphasis is also placed on the responsibility of national regulatory authorities or governments to propose a cost breakdown methodology and to provide the required information for its implementation in consultation with stakeholders and after verification by Eurostat, allowing countries to be comparable. The document also emphasises increasing the protection of sensitive information data on consumers and suppliers. Current statistics are based on inspection of invoices from supply databases. However, invoiced prices should not be published if there is no minimum number of clients in a certain consumption band. I therefore support the proposal.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Through this vote, I express my support for the new regulation on statistics on natural gas and electricity prices that creates a legal requirement for data collection in each Member States. Under the old framework, Member States disclosed statistics on a voluntary basis, making systematic and updated data unavailable for regulators. Consequently, the analysis on the impact of policies in our ever-changing socio-economic environment was challenging. As required under the Energy Union strategy, the Commission must issue every two years a report on energy costs and prices, hence the new regulation will be a helpful tool for the Commission’s work.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed to the European Parliament and the Council a regulation repealing Directive 2008/92/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council on European statistics on gas and electricity prices and on a Community procedure for improving the transparency of gas and electricity prices payable by industrial end-users. In its report, the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy recommends that parliament approve the Commission's motion with a few amendments at first reading. I supported the adoption of the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. – The purpose of this Regulation is to make it compulsory to collect data on prices in the final consumer of natural gas and electricity. This change is essential in order to prevent the quality of the survey data on electricity and natural gas prices for the domestic consumption sector from significantly deterrising, and to continue to achieve broad market coverage, as well as a high level of quality of price data. The report aims to clarify the objectives, simplify certain provisions for reporting authorities and companies that have to provide the data, and avoid misunderstandings which – at worst – would lead to unparalleled data sets. As far as price sharing is concerned, it is for the national regulatory authority or the government to propose a cost-sharing methodology and to provide the information necessary to implement the allocation, subject to prior consultation of stakeholders and verification by Eurostat, in order to ensure price comparability between countries. I endorse the rapporteur's position that, by making communication mandatory, it is important to protect the confidentiality of sensitive information relating to consumers and suppliers.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on gas and electricity price statistics proposes amendments to a proposed regulation that presents a mandatory system of statistics on gas and electricity prices in residential areas. However, this report reinforces the obligations made to Member States and imposes strong constraints on businesses. I have therefore decided to vote against this text.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the 1970s, the European Commission has collected data on natural gas and electricity prices. Since 2007, the liberalisation of the energy markets has been taken into account and data collection has always been carried out on a voluntary basis with a response rate of 100 %.
