Today, the aim of this regulation is to turn the voluntary base into compulsory, so as to avoid problems in data collection, as some Member States have pointed out.  I voted in favour of this measure because I believe that it is a necessary measure to avoid a deterioration in the quality of the investigation into price developments and, above all, to continue to maintain a transparent and homogeneous survey, protecting the final consumer.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have adopted the report on European statistics on gas and electricity prices. We can only effectively compare the figures from individual Member States if we lay down common criteria before we start collecting data. In order for the European Union to be be free to produce statistics based on realistic data, we must first define exactly under what conditions this should be done.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission has been collecting data on natural gas and electricity prices charged to industrial end-users since the 1990’s but not to household consumers, these being done only on a voluntary basis. I have voted against this report that will make it compulsory to collect the data regarding the household consumers, data that will not benefit household consumers.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report in today's vote because I believe that it brings the necessary amendments to the regulation on European statistics on gas and electricity prices, thereby improving the Commission's initial proposal. I think it is very important that these statistics are as complete as possible, and the fact that the Regulation sets out the framework for continuity in the collection of this data is extremely positive. I also support this report because it underlines the importance of protecting all such confidential data in the relationship between consumers and suppliers.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the regulation, which aims to make voluntary data collection compulsory so that data are available for as much of the market as possible and in high quality. As price data should continue to be collected by the competent national authorities, there should be no additional bureaucratic burden. Some provisions concerning the collection authorities and the companies providing data are being simplified. Misunderstandings should also be avoided which, as a last resort, could lead to data sets not being comparable to each other. Furthermore, it is necessary to define a 'fee' in order to remedy the current non-appropriate situation where charges can be redirected from the grid to energy and vice versa. Approved changes in the cost breakdown should better reflect the price structure.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I abstained on this report. The objective of this regulation is to transform the voluntary basis regarding the collection of data for natural gas and electricity prices charged to household end-users into an obligatory one. Statistics must then be provided by Member States to Eurostat. The benefits of collecting the data regarding the natural gas and electricity prices that consumers pay in different Member States include that it will enhance transparency and may help to protect households from profiteering. However, the report also states that its aim is to develop a fully-integrated internal energy market. Sinn Féin believes that more transparency and obligatory reporting in the energy market is certainly required, but we have concerns about the Energy Union and the impact of a ‘fully integrated internal energy market’, so for this reason abstained.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This ensures the quality of the collection of electricity and natural gas prices in the household sector. These statistics are used to ensure price stability for private end customers. I can only support that.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The aim of the proposal for a Regulation is to change the EU's energy policy, which should allow households and businesses to buy energy safely and sustainably and at an affordable price. I support the proposal for a Regulation, as I consider it positive to create mechanisms that will lead to a more efficient acquisition of reliable data on natural gas and electricity prices.  As the internal energy market is increasingly complex and reliable data is difficult to come by, parliament and the Council considered that the area must be regulated by a legal act. This is the reason I consider justified for the emergence of this Regulation. It therefore aims to standardize certain rules on the accounting of natural gas and electricity prices across the European Union, which will lead to the establishment of a common framework and more efficient implementation. Furthermore, the Regulation asks Member States to ensure the credibility of data collection and processing systems, which will lead to greater transparency.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This text provides for the collection of statistics on electricity and gas prices issued to individuals, even though this collection was voluntary. For companies, a 2008 directive already made this collection mandatory. The stated aim is to make European statistics and then encourage the creation of European and then transatlantic transnational oligopolies, which, "put in competition", will "lower prices". However, the opposite has happened, the European Commission forced France to increase EDF tariffs from 2007, to create, artificially, a competitive electricity market. Moreover, making it appear that non-state-backed private actors will ensure a safe and affordable supply is a challenge. Beyond this general consideration, three criticisms can be made to the text: the choice of the regulation over the directive, whereas it is a text of harmonization of statistical tools. As usual, the EU wants to get its hands directly on the statistical tool of the Member States through a direct applicability regulation; a delegation of power (Articles 9 and 10) with no term limit; an additional declarative system that will further burden the management of the companies involved. Since the amendments respecting the sovereignty of the States have been rejected, I am voting against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒2012 Taking into account Article 294(2) and Article 338(1) of the EIA). treaty on the functioning of the European Union, under which the Commission submitted a proposal to Parliament (C8-0357/2015), and Article 294(3) of the Regulation. treaty on the functioning of the European Union, I support the adoption of a position at first reading.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this Regulation is to transform the voluntary basis into a mandatory basis, so as to avoid problems in data collection. This measure is necessary to avoid a significant deterioration in the quality of the household electricity and natural gas price data survey and to continue to maintain broad market coverage and high quality of price data.  I agree with the rapporteur that the collection of data should not entail an additional burden on the authorities responsible for the transmission of data. It is important to protect the confidentiality of confidential consumer and supplier information. Price transparency and clarity of consumer information are an essential prerequisite for the development of a trust-focused supplier-to-customer relationship. Only in an economic environment characterised by trust can well-being be created. I therefore voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Under this Regulation, Member States will have to collect and submit statistics on natural gas and electricity prices for industrial customers and households. Price data would be reported every six months for different consumption volumes, including electricity prices, network access charges, taxes and charges, and their downstream components. Statistics on gas and electricity prices are required to monitor the internal energy market and the impact of different energy policies, such as the promotion of renewable energy sources. In the context of the European Union strategy, the Commission has committed itself to reporting on energy costs and prices every two years from 2016 on. The Commission's preliminary proposal was presented after a comprehensive consultation and in consultation with Member States and national regulatory authorities, so that there were no significant problematic differences between Parliament's and the Council's positions. The agreement reached in the trilogue in June 2016 now needs to be approved by the plenary. I hereby supported the report.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. The main objective of this proposal is to increase the transparency of natural gas and electricity prices on the domestic consumer. Directive 2008/92/EC of the European Parliament and the Council stipulates, in this context, a common binding framework on the production, transmission and dissemination of comparable statistics on electricity and natural gas prices for industrial final consumers. However, the collection of data on such prices by domestic consumers remains on a voluntary basis. The proposal under this therefore seeks to establish a binding regime for the collection of the same data also for domestic consumers, thereby avoiding problems in the collection of them and ensuring their veracity and comparability. I voted in favour of this report because I consider it important to transparency of data on the prices actually paid by domestic consumers, as this proposal promotes social justice and the scrutiny of the energy market.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK as an independent country should be free to choose how to collect statistics on energy prices.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, because it is important that data collection is done in an exquisite way in order to avoid that the quality of data from the available surveys on electricity and natural gas prices for the domestic consumption sector is significantly deterred, and to continue to achieve wide market coverage, as well as a high level of quality of price data. For the benefit of the citizen, data collection by the competent national authorities which is correct and includes any subcomponents that have been omitted, in particular excise duties, shall be provided for the benefit of the citizen. The national regulatory authority or the government shall, after proposing a cost-sharing methodology, provide the information necessary to implement this allocation, subject to prior consultation of stakeholders and verification by Eurostat, in order to ensure price comparability between countries.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The collection of data on natural gas and electricity prices for domestic users has been being carried out on a voluntary basis – with a response rate of 100 %. The aim is to make this voluntary nature mandatory, as it is for industrial prices, which should not entail an additional burden on the notifying authorities and the data will continue to be collected by the competent national authorities.  The report, among other issues, aims to clarify the objectives, to provide certain provisions for the notifying authorities and the companies to provide the data, as well as to avoid unparalleled data series.  In accordance with the guidelines of the S&D Group, I did not vote on the report when it was drafted by a rapporteur of the Group of Europe of Nations and Freedom of, among others, the far-right French National Front. However, its content is not controversial and an interinstitutional agreement was reached at first reading.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against THE report by Mp Barbara Kappel on gas and electricity prices because I refuse, for obvious ethical reasons and in the name of values of humanism and democracy, to support any legislative work carried out under the aegis of a member of the extremist, anti-European and racist group, Europe of Nations and Freedoms.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on statistics on natural gas and electricity prices. Since 1990, there has been a procedure that promotes price transparency in industrial final consumers in these sectors, but not for the domestic consumer. For this reason, the purpose of this Regulation is precisely to transform the current voluntary system for collecting data on prices in the final consumer into a compulsory scheme as a means of avoiding difficulties in collecting and improving the quality of data on electricity and natural gas prices. I therefore endorse the amendments proposed by the rapporteur, which clarify and simplify rules and procedures, both for reporting authorities and for companies when providing data. And, of course, because I consider this change in the current paradigm to be relevant, for the sake of simplification and transparency of statistical data, without making the confidentiality of some consumer information relevant, I supported this report, giving my vote in favour.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. If at first glance the general idea of the report may seem good: to force Member States to communicate statistics on the price of gas and electricity to Eurostat, in the end what it seeks is a way to promote the single energy market at European level. This market is in the sense of further liberalization of the energy sector, which means a more important role for the market and less power for States, so that they can regulate the sector according to environmental or social considerations. That's why I vote against it.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the repeal of Directive 2008/92/EC and thus the amendment to the European natural gas and electricity price statistics. The aim of the amendment is to create a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of comparable European statistics on gas and electricity prices for household and non-household end-users in the EU.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it is a step forward in the implementation of the Energy Union. While we consider harmonization in terms of price structure important, in order to improve the transparency of electricity markets and the final price paid by the consumer, this proposal is made with the sole intention of deepening the integration of energy markets. Our bet is against the Energy Union, since we consider energy to be a public good and not just a commodity. That is why and our opposition to the Energy Union is why, despite considering it necessary to harmonise statistics in the Union, I voted against this report.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I do not wish the EU to have access to our internal energy statistics.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 Natural gas and electricity prices can be significantly reduced thanks to the application of innovative technologies, the reconstruction and interconnection of existing networks and the search for new, efficient and environmentally friendly sources.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the draft EU Parliament legislative resolution for statistics on natural gas and electricity prices. I reject the notion that the provision of such statistics should be obligatory rather than voluntary. This is counter to the spirit of interstate cooperation. The entire basis for justification, that the ‘growing complexity of the internal energy market make it increasingly difficult to obtain reliable and up-to-date price data’, is insufficient.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. Since the 1970s, the European Commission has been collecting data on natural gas and electricity prices. In 1990, the Council adopted a directive improving the transparency of gas and electricity prices charged to industrial users. End-users in households were not affected by this directive.  Data for households was collected on a voluntary basis. Price data collection will not put further pressure on reporting authorities and the competent national authorities will continue to collect price data. I support this proposal for a regulation, as I believe that the collection of data on natural gas and electricity prices charged to end-users in the household should be mandatory, as this ensures the quality of price data research for the household sector and the high quality of price data.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on European statistics on the prices of natural gas and electricity and repealing Directive 2008/92/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council on a single Community procedure for greater transparency of gas and electricity prices charged to industrial end-users.  I support the proposed amendments in the report to ensure that the data collection and regulation system provides comprehensible and comparable high-quality representative data for natural gas and electricity prices. Several Member States are facing difficulties in collecting data, so we need this regulation to transform the voluntary base into a mandatory one.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 For us it is very important to increase transparency in terms of prices charged to domestic consumers for gas and electricity. Our main objective is, of course, to protect households from profiteering, and to ensure the security of the energy supply of households at the lowest possible prices. Unfortunately, however, the report is not moving in this direction, but the main objective is to promote reforms to strengthen competitiveness and complete the single market in gas and electricity. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report grants the Commission super powers, especially in the area of the adoption of delegated acts with a view to amending the text of the Regulation, with regard to gas and electricity prices.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained during the vote because I considered the content of the report in principle to be eligible. European statistics on gas and electricity prices should be set up or included in a mandatory system, as is already the case for industrial prices. Nevertheless, even because of the identity of the rapporteur (who is anti-EU and anti-integration with his group), I believe that the subject needs to be looked at more thoroughly. I believe that only stronger integration can achieve results here and in many other areas at EU level. Whether this is comparability of energy prices or other issues. I agree that comprehensive, comparable and timely data can also mean serious control for Member States.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The report also addresses the following important points. Firstly, the Commission's proposal does not specify which agent will be responsible for providing the price allocation, a task that cannot be met by suppliers.  Second, the transmission of price information becomes mandatory for large non-residential customers.  Finally, it should be noted that the overall average share of transportation and distribution costs can only be distinguished across all residential and non-residential customers. Components of network usage loads can only be indicated across all "residential customer" and "non-residential" sectors, excluding individual consumption tranches.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on proposal for a regulation on European statistics on natural gas and electricity prices, I believe that harmonised methodology for data collection in the field of energy will help to recognize differences and disparities between the Member States. Clear and objective statistics will then be an important basis for setting up an EU-wide policies and appropriate measures in the field of energy.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒The proposed legislative act will cover the collection of data on natural gas and electricity prices for the household and non-household consumer sectors. The aim of this report is to simplify certain provisions for reporting authorities and data companies and avoid misunderstandings. As the proposed price data collection should not result in an additional burden for reporting authorities, I supported this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a regulation on natural gas and electricity price statistics.  The purpose of this Regulation is to transform the voluntary basis into mandatory in order to avoid problems in the collection of data reported by several Member States. This is necessary in order to ensure that the quality of the review of electricity and natural gas price data for the household sector does not significantly deteriorate and that it continues to ensure broad market coverage and high quality of price data.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. If at first glance the general idea of the report may seem good: to force Member States to communicate statistics on the price of gas and electricity to Eurostat, in the end what it seeks is a way to promote the single energy market at European level. This market is in the sense of further liberalization of the energy sector, which means a more important role for the market and less power for States, so that they can regulate the sector according to environmental or social considerations. That's why I vote against it.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report. I am in favour of full transparency and publication of the gas and electricity prices in all Member States so that consumers can better be aware and choose/change their providers. Since the 1970s the European Commission has been collecting data on natural gas and electricity prices. In 1990 the Council adopted the directive to define the procedure to improve the transparency of gas and electricity prices charged to industrial end-users, yet not to household consumers. The responsibility to collect and publish the data lies with Eurostat. The objective of this Regulation is to transform the voluntary basis into an obligatory one, so as to avoid problems in the data collection as having been reported by several Member States. In order to not let the quality of the survey of the electricity and natural gas price data for the household sector deteriorate significantly, and in order to continue to achieve a wide market coverage and high quality of price data, this step is necessary.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This text provides for the collection of statistics on electricity and gas prices issued to individuals, even though this collection was voluntary. For companies, a 2008 directive already made this collection mandatory. This proposal is an accessory to the energy liberalisation packages adopted in 2004-2012. The stated aim is to make European statistics and then encourage the creation of European and then transatlantic transnational oligopolies, which, "put in competition", will "lower prices". However, the opposite happened, the European Commission forced France to raise EDF tariffs from 2007, to create, artificially, a competitive electricity market. Moreover, with regard to gas, it is a challenge to make it appear that private, non-state-backed actors will ensure a secure and affordable supply. I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The collection of energy and gas price data is important for learning about a given market. The aim of the Regulation is to make voluntary data collection mandatory in order to avoid the data collection problems faced by some Member States. It is in the Union's interest to ensure high-quality data in order to prevent misunderstandings arising from different methodologies and statistical surveys. I considered the proposed amendments appropriate, which is why I drafted a resolution.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – If at first glance the general idea of the report may seem good: to force Member States to communicate to Eurostat statistics on the price of gas and electricity, in the end what it seeks is a way to promote the single energy market at European level. This market is in the sense of further liberalization of the energy sector, which means a more important role for the market and less power for States, so that they can regulate the sector according to environmental or social considerations. That's why I vote against it.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against as Greens are in favour or collecting and disseminating high quality and reliable data on the prices and cost of electricity and gas, for both households and industrial customers to bring transparency to the market and enable better energy policy making. However, the proposed framework, by simply distinguishing household and non-household consumers, remains insufficient to enable to provide a good understanding of the market for the different types of customer (ex. SMEs, energy-intensive industry, households). In addition if fails to provide a transparent picture of the cost of each energy source, by not accounting for direct and indirect subsidies that are not included in the final customer prices, for ex. for nuclear power and fossil fuels.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – The aim is to avoid additional burdens for reporting authorities in the collection of price data and to continue collecting price data by the competent national authorities. The purpose of this report is to clarify the objectives, to facilitate some of the provisions applicable to reporting authorities and companies that have to supply data and avoid misunderstandings that could make data sets incompatible in the worst case scenario.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This regulation aims to establish a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of comparable European statistics on natural gas and electricity for European households and other consumers. We are talking about a document that was widely agreed in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, so I think it is necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We are in favour of collecting data on natural gas and electricity prices that consumers pay in different countries as it will increase transparency and can help protect families and end consumers from speculation. However, this report is yet another chapter in the specifications of the European Single Market and the European Energy Union, which is made up here and there with pretense good intentions.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Data on the natural gas and electricity prices to be paid by end-users in private households are currently collected on the basis of voluntary action. The aim of this Regulation is to make voluntary a liability. This could prevent data collection problems reported by several Member States. The collection of price data would continue to be carried out by the competent national authorities. Since the adoption of this regulation would prevent the quality of the survey from falling significantly, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ For the promotion of transparency within gas and electricity prices, I will be voting in favour of the first-reading agreement regarding this issue. Comprehensible and comparable are the two main words in this context. The Member States have to guarantee to provide comprehensible and comparable high-quality data, which needs a proper system for data collection and the compilation of those statistics, to truly represent the prices of natural gas and electricity, in order to truly serve the citizens of the EU.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution with regard to statistics on prices of natural gas and electricity in Europe. It concerns an important proposal for a regulation on statistics on prices of natural gas and electricity in Europe. This resolution aims at achieving more transparency for the consumers with regard to these prices, specifically aimed at the household sector and non-household consumers. In order to achieve this objective, an obligatory collection of data is needed. This should however not create additional burdens on the relevant authorities. Therefore, the report that this resolution concerns, aims at making this transition possible and easier. It also gives specific recommendations on what still needs to be done. One important aspect is that it stresses the importance of protecting the confidentiality of sensitive information.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of a regulation aimed at collecting statistics on gas and electricity prices. Up-to-date, reliable and harmonised data are needed for the smooth monitoring of the Member States' energy market and energy policy-making. To date, such a cost statement has only worked for industrial customers in the EU, but is now to be widely available so that every EU citizen has access to reliable and comparable gas and energy prices. The Regulation does not harmonise the structure of gas and energy prices in the EU, but merely collect data in order to create statistics and ensure price transparency.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Langen's report which follows a series of European Commission documents from 2015 on the design of the electricity market in the EU internal market.  The report shall take into account, inter alia, the strengthening of investment, the security of energy supply and the integration of RES.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the proposal for a regulation under which Member States will have to collect and transmit statistics on electricity and gas prices for households and industry. In addition to the obligation laid down to collect data on energy prices, network charges or taxes, Member States will also be obliged to report these data regularly to the European Commission (or Eurostat). On the basis of these data, it will then be possible to better monitor the internal market and to tailor-made specialised policies. At the same time, as until now Member States have been obliged to collect data, with the exception of data for households, which will also be mandatory under the new regulation, this additional obligation should not impose any significant burden.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation on statistics on the prices of natural gas and electricity. I agree that it is necessary to provide a common framework for European statistics in support of energy policy, in particular to create a fully integrated internal energy market for consumers.  I believe that the proposed regulation will allow for greater transparency in terms of energy costs and prices and on the level of public support.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, a number of Spanish citizens affected by 'sun tax' and retroactive measures came to the European Parliament last week. They explained how the design of the energy market harms renewable energy self-consumptionrs. This report could have provided a solution for these people, who are living in a real social drama. This report could also have created a legal and legislative framework to help implement renewable energy, with priority of access to the grid, over energy from burning fossil fuels such as coal or gas, the leading cause of global warming. On the other hand, it assumes that all technologies are neutral, both nuclear and solar. Another step to blindly guide us through the needs of the market, i.e. the needs of large companies in the energy sector, which, by the way, will continue to receive covert subsidies for fossil fuels and their large infrastructures, as we already know—Castor, Doñana, the South Stream Corridor—through the capacity mechanisms that this report supports.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report, I consider it important. For me, building an internal energy market is not only a matter of economic advantage and strengthening the EU internal market as such, but it is also a question of energy security for me, which is particularly important for smaller countries that were previously under the influence of the Soviet Union during communism. In short, the better the internal energy market, the less dependent we will be on energy from outside the EU, e.g. from Russia, and we will be able to negotiate better terms with those external partners. The advantage of the material, why I approve and support it, is, among other things, that it remains up to individual states to choose their energy sources, including nuclear energy. Atomic energy is not forbidden here, I think that is very correct and reasonable.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the report we are voting on today is entitled 'Towards a new energy market concept'. However, I would question it. My country Bulgaria had to decommission a total of four reactors from a nuclear power plant, which met the needs of a number of countries in the region in order to enter the European Union. From a net electricity exporter, I would like to recall that in 2012 our country had to stop electricity exports due to a capacity shortage in the internal market. According to the calculations made under the Belene Nuclear Power Plant project, it is possible that about two thousand people will work at the site of the first reactor, and in total not less than four thousand are employed nationally. Any delay takes away the possibility of creating employment in one of the poorest regions in the European Union. How will economic growth be achieved in Europe if spending goes towards building new and new infrastructure instead of making full use of projects already started? This is paid for every day by the Bulgarian citizen.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (
text: PPE). Mr President, the energy union's bet is a guide for the energy policy mix to expand the security of the Member States and complementarity in supply. Especially, as far as my country, Greece, is concerned, it is vital to give us time to move on to gradual dependence on lignite and this can be done by providing pollutant rights in our country through the Modernisation Fund. Already, a group of MEPs from the European People's Party has tabled an amendment to this in the report on the pollutant trading system. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the energy mix must be based on diversified suppliers and I would like to ask a question here about the completion, within a timeframe by 2019, of the TAP pipeline carrying Azeri gas to Europe since SOCAR, as a major shareholder, warns that, because of the obstacles it faces with the privatization of THESPA, it is likely not to contribute to the project. Finally, I would like to say that it is necessary to encourage the use of biofuels in transport because in many Member States we are short of the target.

Seán Kelly (PPE). – A Uachtaráin, arís thugas tacaíocht don tuarascáil seo, curtha le chéile go healaíonta ag mo chomhghleacaí, Werner Langen. I think that putting in place a single market for electricity in the EU can bring significant benefits in terms of supply security and price, but it is important that we get it right. With the points outlined in this report, I think we are heading in the right direction and I look forward to the legislative proposals later in the year. A key point in these discussions will be the ways in which the new electricity market design can help us to meet our climate goals. The promotion of renewables will be crucial, and I think that any single market for electricity will need to ensure a favourable climate for investment in renewables and therefore send the right signals. Additionally, by ensuring that prices will reflect actual electricity supply and demand, we will allow for stronger price signals in the wholesale market and therefore encourage investment in new capacity and flexibility.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report, which deals with the transformation of the energy market, introduces some innovative and highly interesting elements, one of which is a more forward-looking approach to renewable energy. However, there are a number of points in the report that cannot be supported, such as those relating to fossil exploitation and high-efficiency gas-fired power stations. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote against.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We are against the report because we object new EU legislation in this field. We in UKIP believe that the UK should make its own energy policy and exploit and invest in lower-cost, reliable energy sources like coal, gas and nuclear.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This own initiative report focuses on the design of a new EU electricity market in light of the aim to double the percentage of electricity produced by renewables from 25% to 50% of the total by 2030. It proposes only market-based solutions to increase capacity such as incentives and rewards. GUE/NGL’s position in favour of a focus on public support for developing renewable energy, access to the grid, the right to self-generation, decentralised solutions, and energy efficiency measures, etc. have been largely ignored. The report proposes that change be based mainly on market rules whilst being ‘technology-neutral’ i.e. not favouring one form of energy over another – which is the opposite of what is required as we need a strong intervention by Member States in favour of developing renewables. I voted against the report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which is going in the right direction: to develop a clean market for the future, which works for consumers and ensures affordable energy. These must be our priorities.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on a new energy market design. The report aims to strengthen the internal market for energy and to allow electricity to move freely to where it is most needed, to reap maximum benefits from cross-border competition and provide the right signals and incentives to drive the right investments. The electricity market should enhance regional cooperation on all dimensions of energy supply and demand, and should focus on improved, more decentralised and more flexible markets, in order to ensure a well-regulated, market-based system, which is capable of delivering on all of the EU’s established energy and climate goals for 2030. The report also considers that all Member States have to implement fully the Third Energy Package and to be more proactively involved in designing a flexible and decentralised internal market on electricity. Furthermore, renewables need to be fully integrated into the electricity system by ensuring that markets are fit for renewables, promoting their participation in electricity markets on an equal footing with conventional generation.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report that precedes the legislation on the electricity market and will be proposed at the end of 2016. This report is important as it takes into account the design of the new energy market, the transition from traditional, centralised electricity generation to a system based more on renewable energy sources, often produced at a more local level, and flexibility.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The aim of this report is to strengthen the internal energy market. It is also important to continue to work towards ensuring that electricity can be freely routed to the places where it is most needed. The aim is to maximise the benefits of cross-border competition and to provide the right signals and incentives for meaningful investment. The report also calls for renewable energy to be fully integrated into the electricity supply system by ensuring that markets are equipped to do so and promoting the share of these energy sources in the electricity market to the same extent as the share of conventional energy sources. I voted in favour of the report because I take the view that a coordinated approach to adequate electricity generation and reliability standards is necessary. This will allow for greater cross-border coordination and cooperation, as well as a harmonised approach to capacity mechanisms. I also believe that regional cooperation in the field of energy policy must be strengthened and that work should be made towards a single European framework for the promotion of renewable energies.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report discusses the new energy market, induced by the guidelines adopted within the framework of the Energy Union. This relates to macroeconomic issues in the energy market (production capacity, wholesale market, interconnection), but is repeated with the Energy Union and Interconnection reports, 7 months apart. This report aims to give ACER more powers, in the name of enhanced coordination at the regional level, with the aim of gradually moving it from the coordinating role between national regulators to a supranational regulator role, although the report remains cautious on this development. The text is under the illusion of an integrated energy market and on the Energy Union (points 3 and 4), for this reason the States that do not move fast enough in change by also speaking out against national capacity mechanisms (point 9), and putting the market before security of supply, like all European texts in this area. Finally, ecology (here renewable energy) is a pretext to strengthen European federalism and to destroy national enterprises, in the name of the fluidity required by intermittent energies. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interests of transparency and democracy I voted against this report. The report aims to ensure the implementation of the Third Energy Package in all Member States. It calls for a new regulatory framework and asks Member States to increase the use of renewable energy in order to reduce CO2 emissions from electricity generation. I voted against this report because I object to any new EU legislation in this field. I believe that the UK should make its own energy policy and exploit and invest in lower-cost, reliable energy sources like coal, gas and nuclear.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which recalls the climate and energy objectives to be achieved, which will require a fundamental transformation of the European electricity system, as well as the reorganisation of the European electricity market.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the development of a new energy market model.  On 15 July 2015, a Communication on the European Single Market was published and a public consultation on the structure of the new electricity market model was launched. In the energy sector, Europe faces, among other things, challenges such as increased dependence on oil and gas imports in recent years, lack of diversification, high energy prices affected by high customs duties, overall increasing global energy demand, threats to the security of production and transit countries, the fight against climate change, slow progress in energy efficiency, a higher share of renewable energy, integration and tying of energy markets, and market distortions due to different support schemes. I therefore support the integration and coordination of a better energy market, which will provide more opportunities to achieve europe's common objectives, namely a secure, cost-effective and environmentally friendly energy supply.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We are against the report because we object to new EU legislation in this field. We in UKIP believe that the UK should make its own energy policy and exploit and invest in lower-cost, reliable energy sources like coal, gas and nuclear.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this very liberal report, which once again aims to deregulate the energy market in the name of a so-called fight against (state) monopolies.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights in particular the enormous potential for enhanced regional cooperation and the importance of long-term coordinated programming for the effective development of transport infrastructure and electricity markets in Europe. The report also regrets that there are still major gaps in interconnection within and between some Member States. Supporting the growing share of renewable energy in the European Union, the report stresses that full integration of renewable energy into the electricity market is essential. MEPs stress the importance of stable and cost-effective renewable energy support schemes for long-term investment.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The communications presented by the Commission in July 2015 set clear objectives for the future of the energy market on our continent. They revolve around three key issues: the creation of an EU-wide electricity market; the conferring of a European dimension on security of energy supply and the strengthening of regional cooperation in the field of energy policy.  The Langen report, which I supported today with my vote, examines the measures proposed by the Commission, effectively identifying the relationship between the objectives set and the means of achieving them. Today it is a priority to define a new set of rules that are adapted to the new nature of energy supply. The energy market is increasingly moving from a traditional centralised system to a more flexible one, based on renewables and local production. Europe must create intelligent distribution networks, promote new storage solutions and increase the confidence of the actors involved; Only in this way will it be able to create an energy market that can function best for both consumers and industry.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I objected to this report on the energy market, despite some positive points that should be highlighted. The need for investment in the network, the coordination of states at the regional level, or respect for the principle of subsidiarity are all ideas that I believe in, as is the reminder of national competence over the energy mix. However, once again a parliamentary report (in fact doubly with the report on the energy union, voted only 7 months ago) goes in the direction of a federal Europe by the "policy of small steps": we are trying to get the Member States to concede, little by little, whole swathes of their competences under false pretenses. Here, the technique is to give more power to the ACER (European Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators), which is increasingly looming as a transnational regulator instead of a coordinator of national regulators. In addition to this ideological aim, the report is unrealistic because it put the market before security of supply, in the name of the sacrosanct energy union.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Langen report on the new structure of the energy market is unbalanced and presents critical issues that led me to vote against it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. On 15 July 2015, the Commission presented its Communication on the new configuration of the energy market, prior to the legislation scheduled for the end of 2016. For a new design of the energy market, it is necessary to consider the changing nature of our supplies. We must have greater flexibility, incorporate renewables and those generated at the local level.  Among the many challenges we face are dependence on oil and gas, lack of diversification and efficiency progress, high prices, growing global demand, security risks or the fight against climate change. The report lays the foundations for an Energy Union based on an interconnected market at European level, which ensures electricity supply at affordable prices, with optimal use of energy resources and efficiency as pillars, integrating renewables and co-generated ones. This requires increasing inland interconnections and ending energy islands such as the Iberian Peninsula. Better market integration provides multiple opportunities for safe and efficient and sustainable sourcing for the environment. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has been advocated by Parliament on the future model of the European electricity market. European energy policy ensures the functioning of the energy market and security of energy supply, promotes energy efficiency, the development of renewable forms of energy and the interconnection of energy networks. However, insufficient production capacity is projected in several Member States, which could lead to a power outage in the near future, provided that the necessary back-up mechanisms are not put in place. Closer cooperation at regional level is therefore necessary and should help to strengthen market integration at European level. Parliament therefore welcomed the 2015 The Commission communication on a new energy market model agrees with the view that a reformed energy market and existing legislation should strengthen regional cooperation in all aspects of energy supply and demand. However, Parliament called for an adjustment of the regulatory framework for European markets in order to increase the share of renewable energy and to close existing gaps in cross-border regulation.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution we are adopting today reacts to the European Commission's communication and intends to provide guidance with a view to the expected legislative proposal.  The structure of the energy market is a key aspect of achieving a truly single market in the sector. Only with a harmonised market will it be possible to have those price signals that are essential to mobilise the investments necessary to bring us into a dimension of solid interconnections and the effective integration of energy produced from renewable sources. However, we know what the European Union's energy dependency figures are and we have seen in recent years how geopolitical imbalances can expose us in this regard. It is therefore necessary to have reliable plans to ensure the maintenance of electricity grids, also in view of the gradual technological progress for the integration of renewables.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report uses ecology to strengthen the EU's supranational power over member states. His reflections on the storage of electricity for renewable energies are part of a marked utopia. I consider the role of the state in energy, particularly on a security of supply issue, essential. For all these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2014, the energy market was the second largest market in the European Union. An important market, on which the domestic consumers of our citizens depend, industrial production, transport, large communication networks, health and welfare services, military defence and many other aspects of everyday life.  This large market needs to be reformed, with the creation of an EU-wide electricity market providing clear price signals for new investments, together with the provision of a European dimension to security of energy supply and the strengthening of regional cooperation in the field of energy policy, in particular with regard to investments in new energy production plants, interconnectors and aid schemes. , also taking care to support and promote the integration of renewable energies into the European single market.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report discusses the new energy market induced by the energy union guidelines. Although the text emphasizes the need to finance new investments in the grid, I have opposed this report which promotes the Energy Union.  On the one hand, this report aims to strengthen the powers of the Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (ACER) in the name of better coordination between national regulators. It goes without saying that the tacit objective of this report is to entrust ACER with the role of supranational regulator at the expense of the sovereignty of the Member States.  On the other hand, the European Union is using ecology as a pretext to move towards European federalism and to destroy national companies with a natural monopoly. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe's energy challenges include dependence on oil and gas imports that has increased in recent years, lack of diversification, high energy prices influenced by state-imposed energy taxes, increased global energy demand, as well as integration and interconnection of energy markets and market distortions caused by different support systems. Meeting the EU's climate change targets requires a set of measures, which involves, in addition to the use of renewable energies, the assessment of the benefits of low-carbon technologies in relation to high-emission technologies. I voted in favour of the report on a new organisation of the energy market, considering that the European Commission's proposal for an energy policy involving centralised and decentralised structures is also a fair and viable one in the current international context.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The future of the energy market in EU countries is one of the current topics at European level. Moreover, it was, from the very beginning, one of the catalysts for the founding act of the European Union, a direct act related to the management of energy resources. Due to outdated infrastructure, poorly integrated markets and uncoordinated policies, consumers, households and businesses do not benefit from a wider range of options or lower electricity prices.  On 15 July 2015, the European Commission published a series of guidelines and targets to regulate and unite the European energy market. All measures must be checked with regard to the instruments, the legal basis, the implementation and the possibilities of the Europeanisation of electricity supply.  I support the EP's motion for a resolution on the report 'Towards a new organisation of the energy market'. I believe that it is time to complete the single energy market in Europe for a safe, environmentally viable and affordable energy supply. Predictable energy prices and security of supply will increase household living standards.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. This European Parliament's initiative report is a response to the Commission's communication and public consultation on a new electricity market organisation. The fact is that we need a more interconnected European electricity market. We must also ensure greater energy independence and improve the security of electricity supply. Strengthening regional cooperation on energy policy is also essential. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reading and debate in this House, I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on 'Towards a new structure of the energy market' because I believe that our international scenario shows that energy security – both in terms of supply and regulation – helps to guarantee and consolidate the political independence of the Member States. Consequently, a dialogue should be encouraged and pursued with the aim of improving the progress of the relevant processes of energy change towards cleaner and renewable sources and of reducing market distortions. This different management of sovereignty is an important part of the challenges facing Europe in the energy sector, which ultimately requires – first and foremost – greater integration and interconnection.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This own initiative report focuses on the design of a new EU electricity market in light of the aim to double the percentage of electricity produced by renewables from 25% to 50% of the total by 2030. It proposes only market-based solutions to increase capacity such as incentives and rewards. GUE/NGL’s position in favour of a focus on public support for developing renewable energy, access to the grid, the right to self-generation, decentralised solutions, and energy efficiency measures, etc. have been largely ignored. The report proposes that change be based mainly on market rules whilst being ‘technology-neutral’ i.e. not favouring one form of energy over another – which is the opposite of what is required as we need a strong intervention by Member States in favour of developing renewables. I voted against the report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that there is a big potential to strengthen the internal market for energy and to allow electricity to move freely to also benefit cross-border competition and provide the right signals for investments. Improved integration and coordination of energy markets means that there are many opportunities to achieve the common European goal of a secure, affordable, environmentally-sound energy supply. I generally support the ideas set out in this report and voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission believes that the new electricity market should take full advantage of cross-border competition, allow distributed electricity generation, including for self-consumption, and support the emergence of innovative energy service companies.  The reform of the electricity market is crucial to achieving the EU's climate and energy targets. In particular, it must create the conditions for reducing energy consumption, better managing demand through new technologies (networks, meters and smart homes, energy storage facilities) new services by innovative companies and reliable intermediaries and the transition of consumption to alternative sources. If Mr De Clercq's report is a good one, it is not a good report. Langen is much better than the initial version, unsustainable elements have emerged (ETS, carbon leakage, fossil exploitation, high efficiency gas power plants...) so I decided to vote against it.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's energy policy must now adapt to the new structures of the global energy market in order to ensure security of supply, environmental sustainability and affordability for households and businesses. I believe that these objectives must be pursued by promoting the integration and coordination of member states' energy markets with the ultimate aim of creating a single European electricity market. I voted in favour of this report, as it calls on the Member States and the Commission to give high priority to the promotion of renewable energies and to establish wider regional markets, preferably by testing innovative projects across borders. Indeed, the Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (ACER) has highlighted that regional cooperation has enormous potential, especially with regard to cost savings. I believe that interconnections within and between certain Member States need to be strengthened because there are still gaps that cause grid bottlenecks and undermine cross-border energy trade. I hope that the Commission will ensure a level playing field for energy producers in Member States and third countries, because competition stimulates energy security. Finally, the development of new solutions for the storage of electricity in order to allow effective demand management is essential.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report that promotes the objectives of energy policy, namely security of energy supply, environmental sustainability and the setting of appropriate prices. In this context, the use of new technologies and investments should be facilitated, notably in renewable energy sources and low-carbon power plants.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on the redesign of the energy market. It is obvious that this issue concerns one of the most important sectors of European industry, with direct implications for the daily lives of European citizens. We must therefore be particularly careful, since prospects such as increasing final costs and consolidating unsustainable production capacity threaten this sector. Consumers should also be given more opportunities to participate, which is not guaranteed at the moment. I therefore voted against it.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Langen on the new design of the energy market, which is part of the series of documents on the European single market published by the Commission on 15 July 2015.  I congratulate him on the emphasis placed on the need for a single, stable energy system in order to ensure a sustainable and efficient supply. I believe that the integration of individual national markets at European level will promote not only better cooperation between the countries of the Union, but also a reduction in costs for European industries and consumers through the free movement of energy. I also agree with the report on the need to promote investment and develop long-term projects in the field of renewable sources.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, Towards a New Energy Market Design, and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The electricity market must generate the effective transformation of this market, contribute to the efficiency and security of supply, as well as to the development of renewable energy and interconnections, and ensure the completion of the Internal Market for European Energy. The European energy market, if well designed and properly applied, has the potential to substantially increase Europe's energy security and independence, particularly in the face of the main suppliers on which the Union depends. I support this report because I consider it important to review the existing regulatory framework with a view to encouraging the use of energy storage systems, with the aim of feeding the energy system with a higher proportion of energy from intermittent renewable sources, with reduced marginal costs. Better integration and coordination of energy markets brings up multiple opportunities to achieve the common European objectives of a secure, sustainable and affordable energy supply.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because it sets out the measures needed to complete the EU's single energy market. In doing so, the rapporteur has managed to maintain the balance between EU-wide regulations, such as the general abolition of price zones, superfluous subsidies and national safeguards, and subsidiarity. Responsibility for security of supply lies with the Member States, but the necessary capacities must be calculated jointly.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, in defining a new structure of the energy market, priority must be given to renewable sources, while taking into account the maintenance of lasting energy security and affordable prices for consumers. We need to ensure a market structure that facilitates the process of change, without distortion of competition and taking into account low-carbon energy sources, so that production from renewable sources can be integrated.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – As a Union we endeavour to promote energy efficiency savings, the development of renewable energy and the interconnection of energy networks. Such are essential in defining the Member States’ energy mix and the conditions governing the use of their energy resources which nonetheless remains a national competence. I support the call for proactively involving the civil society stakeholders in designing a flexible and decentralised European internal market in electricity in order to enhance coordination between national transition strategies whereby fees and taxes are to be applied fairly, avoiding double costs for the charging and discharging of energy and resulting in a market which rewards fast-reacting and flexible sources. This provides an essential contribution towards the creation of an EU-wide electricity market providing clear price signals for new investments.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it is a disappointing vision around the design of energy markets and networks in the Union, which does not provide solutions to the present problems. Our group has included amendments in support of renewables and criticizing mechanisms such as capacity mechanisms to benefit large multinationals in the electricity sector. This report does not reflect the need to support small producers of renewables, nor does it reflect the importance of enabling State intervention in the electricity sector. The report calls for the disappearance of regulated prices, which have proven to be one of the best tools to tackle the problem of energy poverty. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report lays the foundations for a reorganisation of the energy market, taking into account the changing nature of the system, which is increasingly moving away from a centralised vision, moving towards a system increasingly based on variable renewable sources that contribute to the decarbonization of our economy, often, moreover, produced locally. The proposal has three strategic objectives. Virtuous supply and demand management, which favours investment, overcoming market bottlenecks, which tend to confine energy potential to all within the respective Member States. Secondly, strengthening the energy supply system, through a truly European approach. Finally, greater interregional cooperation and integration, in particular for investment in new power stations. The text, on the whole and despite some controversial points – such as national incentives that can create price and market distortions – is an excellent starting point for the discussion with the Commission with a view to the proposed market reform, and that is why I felt it was important to support it.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – Recent changes, such as new technologies, fluctuating commodity prices or the rapid spread of renewable electricity generation, have fundamentally changed the European energy market. The report intends to achieve three objectives. First and foremost, a market for electricity throughout the Union should be established, providing clear price signals for new investments. Secondly, a European infrastructure for a secure energy supply must be created. Thirdly, regional cooperation within energy policy should be strengthened, in particular with regard to the development of new energy production equipment, interconnector and support systems, and the integration of renewable energy sources into the European internal market. Achieving these objectives is in Europe's common interest, as the integration of electricity markets will improve a secure, cost-effective and environmentally minded energy supply. The general structure of the national energy mix of the Member States should be respected in the development of the new strategy.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I do not support the policy objectives set out in the Consultative Communication on the structure of the electricity market, which is part of the report on the European internal market published by the European Commission on 15 July 2015. I am not in favour of creating an EU-wide electricity market with clear price signals for new investments. I do not consider it appropriate to solidify the European approach to energy security and to strengthen regional cooperation in the field of energy policy, in particular in investments in new power generation installations, interconnections and support systems and in the integration of renewable energy into the European internal market. The fact is that I find positive elements in the report, but the negative prevails, hence my decision to vote against.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Our electricity supply is changing – moving away from the traditional, centralised, base-load power supply towards a system which is based on variable renewables. This is why we need to move towards a new energy market design which adapts and takes into account the elements of a changing energy supply. I am in favour of this report, as I believe that we need to move towards an energy market based on consumer needs whilst ensuring affordable energy.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst there are a number of areas of this report I agree with, the fact remains that decisions over the precise energy mix in each member state are a national competence and I oppose efforts to centralise this at a European level. This has previously been a subject of significant political debate within the UK and taking that decision-making power away from British voters is not something I can support.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report follows the European Commission's communication on "a new energy market organisation" published in July 2015. The report aims to strengthen the internal market and allow the free movement of electricity. It proposes to establish a regional security of supply control as well as clear European standards for the adequacy of the system in order to determine whether a capacity mechanism is really needed. Considering that it is necessary to fully integrate renewable energies into the common electricity grid by ensuring that their specificities (for example, intermittency) are better taken into account, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We are against the report because we object to new EU legislation in this field. We in UKIP believe that the UK should make its own energy policy and exploit and invest in lower-cost, reliable energy sources like coal, gas and nuclear.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which has no binding legislative value, which calls for a new organisation of the energy market in Europe. I am particularly in favour of strengthening the integrated energy market, in particular to ensure stability conducive to investment in this area. In addition, given our environmental objectives, it is essential to encourage the European Union and its Member States to move towards better energy efficiency, allowing less consumption and encouraging the development of renewable energies.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Major changes in recent years, such as new technologies, fluctuating commodity prices or the rapid spread of renewable electricity generation, have fundamentally changed the European energy market. The report intends to achieve three objectives. First and foremost, a market for electricity throughout the Union should be established, providing clear price signals for new investments. Secondly, a European infrastructure for a secure energy supply must be created. Thirdly, regional cooperation within energy policy should be strengthened, in particular with regard to the development of new energy production equipment, interconnector and support systems, and the integration of renewable energy sources into the European internal market. Achieving these objectives is in Europe's common interest, as the integration of electricity markets will improve a secure, cost-effective and environmentally minded energy supply. It is important that the overall structure of member states' national energy mix and energy supply is respected throughout the development of the new strategy. Efficient use of energy storage facilities, network development, the construction of appropriate inter-outlets and the widest possible use of renewable sources are essential for the completement of the internal market. Better integration and coordination of electricity markets has many opportunities to achieve common European goals for a safer, more cost-effective and sustainable energy supply.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The EU has an energy and climate framework that predicts a 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 from 1990 levels, a 30% improvement in energy efficiency and a 27% increase in the share of renewable energy in the EU energy mix. These objectives cannot be achieved without a major overhaul of the European electricity sector. We need to develop clean energy, improve energy savings. This requires innovation and, above all, better coordination of our national policies.  Finally, Europe must have an autonomous energy policy, guaranteeing its independence.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – Major changes in recent years, such as new technologies, fluctuating commodity prices or the rapid spread of renewable electricity generation, have fundamentally changed the European energy market. The report intends to achieve three objectives. First and foremost, a market for electricity throughout the Union should be established, providing clear price signals for new investments. Secondly, a European infrastructure for a secure energy supply must be created. Thirdly, regional cooperation within energy policy should be strengthened, in particular with regard to the development of new energy production equipment, interconnector and support systems, and the integration of renewable energy sources into the European internal market. Achieving these objectives is in Europe's common interest, as the integration of electricity markets will improve a secure, cost-effective and environmentally minded energy supply. It is important that the overall structure of member states' national energy mix and energy supply is respected throughout the development of the new strategy. Efficient use of energy storage facilities, network development, the construction of appropriate inter-outlets and the widest possible use of renewable sources are essential for the completement of the internal market. Better integration and coordination of electricity markets has many opportunities to achieve common European goals for a safer, more cost-effective and sustainable energy supply.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite the incentive to invest in the network, the enhanced powers granted to ACER, a supranational regulator, to the detriment of state authority, may be regretted. Market ideology takes precedence over the security of supply of states. For these reasons, we cannot support this report. I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this file because, although it contains some good ideas, it refers to the universal top-down approach. When we talk about energy markets, especially with recommendations for better cooperation, we must not forget that geopolitical challenges across the European Union are widely differing. When discussing policy, these regional specificities must be taken into account without delay. Moreover, there is an even more fundamental challenge – infrastructure. Bulgaria is one of the EU Member States that is struggling with these similar challenges. The solution to overcome these obstacles is not introduced as centralised and decentralised structures. Market distortions and inappropriate investment in new facilities must be avoided and, if these are led by the EU, we will put the whole system at risk. Incorporating more renewables is a good approach and I strongly support it. Nevertheless, the EU's policy-making approach to the energy mix will ignore regional specificities and only disrupt the functioning of the whole structure.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 My approach to the issue of energy security and adequacy is completely different, I consider energy to be an infrastructure of critical importance for each State, it must have full control over its production and distribution and not be subject to controls and restrictions from abroad, with the sole exception perhaps of environmental protection issues.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Major changes in recent years, such as new technologies, fluctuating commodity prices or the rapid spread of renewable electricity generation, have fundamentally changed the European energy market. The report intends to achieve three objectives. First and foremost, a market for electricity throughout the Union should be established, providing clear price signals for new investments. Secondly, a European infrastructure for a secure energy supply must be created. Thirdly, regional cooperation within energy policy should be strengthened, in particular with regard to the development of new energy production equipment, interconnector and support systems, and the integration of renewable energy sources into the European internal market. Achieving these objectives is in Europe's common interest, as the integration of electricity markets will improve a secure, cost-effective and environmentally minded energy supply. It is important that the overall structure of member states' national energy mix and energy supply is respected throughout the development of the new strategy. Efficient use of energy storage facilities, network development, the construction of appropriate inter-outlets and the widest possible use of renewable sources are essential for the completement of the internal market. Better integration and coordination of electricity markets has many opportunities to achieve common European goals for a safer, more cost-effective and sustainable energy supply. In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The transition to decentralised energy production, based on the exploitation of renewable sources, is now under way. That is why we need a radical change in governance and legislation on the energy market, so that the existence of more and more players involved is recognised, not just large producers, on the one hand, and passive energy consumers, on the other.
