The rapporteur, Mr Langen, however, proposes a text which only apparently seems to trigger a change of structure in the energy market, focusing on renewables and decentralised production. As the Five Star Movement, we have proposed amendments aimed at introducing extremely innovative elements such as the concept of prosumer, in order to recognise the existence of a new entity, that of the increasing number of citizens who, in addition to consuming, produce energy. However, I note with regret that too many references remain in the text to the continued exploitation of fossil fuels, nuclear power and the so-called ETS or "emission trading system (which until now has coincided only with the creation of a speculative market for CO2 shares without any benefit to the climate). I note that these aspects do not really allow us to change the current paradigm in the energy market. I am therefore voting against.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The future of the electricity market must be the creation of an EU-wide electricity market that sends a clear price signal for new investments, the creation of a European approach to security of energy supply and the strengthening of regional cooperation in the energy sector, in particular with regard to investments in new power plants , interconnections and support schemes, as well as the integration of renewable energies into the European single market. Affordable energy prices and security of supply are essential for the standard of living of households, but also for job security in energy-intensive companies. To this end, the Commission is proposing a package of measures with which I agree.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution. As usual, ecology (here renewable energy) is a pretext to strengthen European federalism and to destroy national enterprises, in the name of the fluidity required by intermittent energies.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has set out three policy objectives for the future single energy market: 1. To create an EU-wide electricity market; 2. Create an EU approach to security of energy supply; 3. Strengthen regional cooperation in the energy sector, in particular with regard to investments in new power plants, interconnections and support schemes, as well as the integration of renewable energies into the single market. An inexttable agenda of the objectives of the major European groups in the sector and of the powers that defend their interests. In essence, the report advocates the liberalisation of the 'energy market', putting pressure on Member States to speed up the privatisation process of what is still public. Without acknowledging that, contrary to myrific promises, neither workers nor consumers have benefited from liberalisation. Quite the contrary! They increased profits on the account of employment, wages and workers' rights and the prices paid by consumers. Energy is a strategic sector, fundamental to the country's sovereign economic development, supported by scientific knowledge, technological progress and environmental sustainability. Sufficient reason to be kept in the public sphere, under democratic scrutiny and control. This report is incompatible with these principles. And that's reason enough for our vote against.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: In writing \ u2012 The subject of this report is the European energy market and, in particular, the presentation of the structure of what this system should look like, taking into account the ability to achieve energy policy objectives. Among the challenges we face in the field of energy are, in particular, the increased dependence on oil and gas imports, but also the lack of diversification. In addition, energy prices are also increased by state taxes and global energy demand. Safety risks are also problematic, whether in countries where mining takes place directly or in transit countries. The European Commission communication is based on 3 important policy objectives for the future of the electricity market.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report: another attack on the energy sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on "Towards the redesign of the energy market". My approach to energy security and adequacy is quite different. I believe that energy is a vital infrastructure for each state, it must have full control over its production and distribution and it must not be subject to controls and restrictions from abroad, with the sole exception perhaps of environmental protection issues.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This own-initiative report comes ahead of the expected electricity market design legislation to be proposed by the end of 2016. Part of the Energy Union, it concerns the rules for the electricity market and particularly trading, transmission and distribution of electricity. A new market design is needed to take into account the changing nature of our electricity supply, moving away from traditional, centralised, base-load power generation towards a system based more on variable renewables and flexibility, often produced at a more local level. Thus the energy markets need to adapt. We need to ensure a market design that is fit for the future, and one which works for consumers and industry, ensuring affordable energy. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Major changes in recent years, such as new technologies, fluctuating commodity prices or the rapid spread of renewable electricity generation, have fundamentally changed the European energy market. The report intends to achieve three objectives. First and foremost, a market for electricity throughout the Union should be established, providing clear price signals for new investments. Secondly, a European infrastructure for a secure energy supply must be created. Thirdly, regional cooperation within energy policy should be strengthened, in particular with regard to the development of new energy production equipment, interconnector and support systems, and the integration of renewable energy sources into the European internal market. Achieving these objectives is in Europe's common interest, as the integration of electricity markets will improve a secure, cost-effective and environmentally minded energy supply. It is important that the overall structure of member states' national energy mix and energy supply is respected throughout the development of the new strategy. Efficient use of energy storage facilities, network development, the construction of appropriate inter-outlets and the widest possible use of renewable sources are essential for the completement of the internal market. Better integration and coordination of electricity markets has many opportunities to achieve common European goals for a safer, more cost-effective and sustainable energy supply.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Major changes in recent years, such as new technologies, fluctuating commodity prices or the rapid spread of renewable electricity generation, have fundamentally changed the European energy market. The report intends to achieve three objectives. First and foremost, a market for electricity throughout the Union should be established, providing clear price signals for new investments. Secondly, a European infrastructure for a secure energy supply must be created. Thirdly, regional cooperation within energy policy should be strengthened, in particular with regard to the development of new energy production equipment, interconnector and support systems, and the integration of renewable energy sources into the European internal market. Achieving these objectives is in Europe's common interest, as the integration of electricity markets will improve a secure, cost-effective and environmentally minded energy supply. It is important that the overall structure of member states' national energy mix and energy supply is respected throughout the development of the new strategy. Efficient use of energy storage facilities, network development, the construction of appropriate inter-outlets and the widest possible use of renewable sources are essential for the completement of the internal market. Better integration and coordination of electricity markets has many opportunities to achieve common European goals for a safer, more cost-effective and sustainable energy supply.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report bearing in mind that the EU faces significant energy challenges: dependence on oil and gas imports, lack of diversification, high energy prices, rising global energy demand, security risks in producing countries and transit countries, the fight against climate change , the lack of progress in energy efficiency, the increase in the share of renewable energy, the integration and interconnection of energy markets and market distortions caused by the different aid schemes. I am convinced that better integration and coordination of energy markets in Europe is essential, enabling us to achieve the common European objectives of a safe yet cost-efficient and environmentally sustainable energy supply.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report represents a necessary move towards decentralisation in the European energy market. If the European energy market is to functions to its fullest of potential it must become more regionalised, more flexible and with a high degree of regional cooperation. It is also very important that this design is specifically market-oriented to attract investment and to drive innovation in order to achieve a sustainable energy market for European consumers and businesses. For these regional markets to bear fruit, we need a flexible regulatory framework that covers all cross-border regulatory gaps that exists today.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe made very significant commitments last year at the COP21 climate conference. In order to achieve reductions in consumption and emissions, we need a profound evolution of our energy systems, starting from everyday habits. A key factor in the distribution of emissions is heating and cooling in buildings, which alone are also an important financial commitment for many households in Europe. In order to achieve the Paris target of a 40% reduction in energy consumption, extraordinary actions are needed: we call on the Commission, within the framework of the announced proposal for a reform of the energy efficiency of buildings, to introduce ambitious and demanding measures.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on 'Towards a new energy market structure' because I believe that the integration of all stakeholders in order to achieve the objectives set by COP21 last December 2015 in Paris on safe, affordable, efficient and sustainable energy is essential. I consider it extremely necessary to strengthen regional cooperation in the field of energy policy so as to better coordinate investments in new energy production plants and maximise the effect and effectiveness of funding. The growing concerns related to climate and environmental protection, already expressed in many international for a, highlight the need to promote the development of renewable energies, without neglecting at the same time the need to guarantee sustainable and affordable energy security and supply, above all in order to support a good standard of living for families and to safeguard jobs in energy-efficient companies. Finally, I am convinced of the need to establish a more intensive dialogue and closer cooperation between the EU institutions, bodies and agencies in order to create a more favourable environment for innovation and research.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the report on the subject of 'Towards the transformation of the energy market', as the dossier is certainly well-intentioned, but in many areas it loses sight of the necessary triad of environmental friendliness, availability and price. Here I would like to see more consumer- and family-oriented decisions in the internal market.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The transformation of the European energy market is necessary to create an EU-wide electricity market with clear price signals for new investment. It is a step in the right direction to grant the ACER agency more competences in the area of cross-border coordination. 2. to establish a European approach to energy security. Energy security is a key concern not only for the European economy, but also, above all, for European consumers. Coordinated power generation and common reliability standards offer the first steps in the right direction. 3. strengthen regional cooperation in energy policy, in particular in investments in new energy generation plants, in interconnectors and support rules, and in the integration of renewable energies into the European internal market. I think it makes a lot of sense to have European-sponsored regional cooperation in the field of renewable energies, as this can lead to supra-regional synergies.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because we need to implement a market design that is fit for the future, and one which works for both consumers and industry, ensuring affordable energy.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. Parliament's energy reports follow one another and are similar: even a call for a single energy market, a nuclear deal of the exclusive competence recognized by the treaties in the choice of their energy mix;  The same mistaken belief in the market's ability to set the right price for energy, satisfying both producer and consumer and promoting long-term investment;  - even highlighting the need for a relaxation of the electrical system, a consequence of the obligation of an increasing use of intermittent energies, to suggest tracks soon to be transformed into constraints;  - and above all, even ignorance of the specific situations of States, especially with regard to the security of supply. It may or may not appeal, but France does not have the same problems or energy challenges as Germany or Lithuania. It is not innocent that it has chosen, for example, a capacity mechanism to guarantee electricity supply in the event of peak consumption, rather than strategic reserves. As usual, I voted against a text that calls into question the independence of choice of states in eminently sovereign areas.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the report because it is based on market mechanisms and not on social and environmental needs. Set aside or discuss issues of network access for self-users, system decentralization or energy efficiency.  The report is also based on technology neutrality, which implies that energy from renewable or nuclear sources is considered in the same way; when we know perfectly well that environmental impacts are considerably different. Capacity mechanisms are covert subsidies to large companies and possibly to fossil energy. In addition, there is a risk that these mechanisms lead to the construction of new large infrastructures that condemn us to continue with the current model for several more decades.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because we need to ensure a market design that is fit for the future, and one which works for consumers and industry, ensuring affordable energy.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report. It proposes to reorganize the electricity market. In particular, it is important to strengthen regional cooperation on all dimensions of supply and demand in order to be able to achieve all the energy and climate targets set by the EU for 2030. The current regulatory framework for European markets needs to be adapted to enable the share of renewable energy to increase and to fill existing gaps in regulation at the cross-border level. In an increasingly decentralized energy system, there is a need to further stimulate investment, SMEs' access to the energy market and ensure a sustainable and efficient electricity supply through an intelligent energy system.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. Improved integration and coordination of energy markets means that there are many opportunities to achieve the common European goal of a secure, affordable, environmentally-sound energy supply. Predictable energy prices and security of supply are indispensable in particular for maintaining domestic standards of living and ensuring job security at energy-intensive companies.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson Jens Nilsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: Written. We Social Democrats have today voted in favour of the report on a new market model for the energy market. The report highlights several good things, and a new market model for the energy market is necessary in view of developments in the field of renewable and flexible energy.  During the vote, we voted against a wording on coordination at European level to establish a concession system for the use of hydropower and to open up the sector to competition in order to avoid market distortions. We see no reason for an EU-harmonised measure in this area, and it can be a threat to the independence of locally owned, municipally owned energy companies with their own production. There are already EU rules that set a level playing field for Member States with regard to water activities, and the rules of the internal market promote competition. We see no need for further action. If new measures are justified, there are other major problems to be tackled on the electricity market. We have also voted against a wording in the report on what are claimed to be better market-adapted so-called investment promotion measures to promote renewable energy. The generalising wording is unclear and leaves open to interpretations of what is to be regarded as different investment measures.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report aims to abolish national policies and strengthen the Commission's powers to unify the market and create a pan-European electricity market. These policies, in our view, will have disastrous consequences for consumers. Only large companies will be the winners as they will be able to act seamlessly by increasing their profits. In our view it is clear that energy must be guaranteed as a public social good, to which everyone has equal and cheap access. Also, the provision of energy to citizens should be a matter of national policy, determined on the basis of the needs of the country and the people, always with a view to social development. Finally, the design of the electricity market should be based on a comprehensive proposal to support and develop renewable energy sources, which is also absent from the report. Since the report has the sole aim of making energy a tool to strengthen the private interest and competitiveness of the EU, we consider it an appropriate attitude to vote against it.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution ‘Towards a New Energy Market Design’ for a number of reasons. Firstly, in order for Europe to meet its 2030 climate goals, there needs to be a transformation in the way the energy market in Europe operates. This means that we need an improved integrated energy market to achieve a secure, affordable, environmentally-sound energy supply and security. We need to reduce our dependency on oil and gas imports and incentivise development of new technologies, particularly low-carbon generating facilities. This report sets out the best way to achieve a properly functioning EU energy market with market led approaches. That is why I supported the rapporteur’s call to phase-out subsidies for mature renewable technologies and I voted against an amendment which called for continuing financial support from governments to certain renewable technologies at the expense of other possibly more innovative technologies.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report is not consistent and consistent in itself. Either we completely liberalise the European energy markets and create a common European energy market, such as.B now with the Digital Single Market, or we leave the Member States to decide on their country's energy mix and to ensure energy security. This report is not a consistent advocate of deregulation and the liberalisation of energy markets, nor is it fully in favour of subsidiarity. It does not show a clear line as to how things should proceed in Europe in terms of energy policy. In line with the concept paper presented by the party's leader Ulrike Trebesius, ALFA is committed to ensuring that energy policy issues are left entirely to the Member States. That is why I rejected the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to discord and strife in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Major changes in recent years, such as new technologies, fluctuating commodity prices or the rapid spread of renewable electricity generation, have fundamentally changed the European energy market. The report intends to achieve three objectives. First and foremost, a market for electricity throughout the Union should be established, providing clear price signals for new investments. Secondly, a European infrastructure for secure energy supply must be created. Thirdly, regional cooperation within energy policy should be strengthened, in particular with regard to the development of new energy production equipment, interconnector and support systems, and the integration of renewable energy sources into the European internal market. Achieving these objectives is in Europe's common interest, as the integration of electricity markets will improve a secure, cost-effective and environmentally minded energy supply. It is important that the overall structure of member states' national energy mix and energy supply is respected throughout the development of the new strategy. Efficient use of energy storage facilities, network development, the construction of appropriate inter-outlets and the widest possible use of renewable sources are essential for the completement of the internal market. Better integration and coordination of electricity markets has many opportunities to achieve common European goals for a safer, more cost-effective and sustainable energy supply.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We need to ensure a market design which works for consumers and industry alike, ensuring affordable energy. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the "Towards a New Energy Market Model" report, as further integration of the energy market needed is also looking for new solutions to ensure a safe, low-cost, efficient and environmentally sustainable energy supply. The energy system needs to be more flexible in the future in terms of production, distribution, demand and storage.  The problem is that there is a projected lack of production capacity, national capacity markets make it difficult to integrate markets, there is a problem of insufficient cross-border physical connectivity of infrastructure and cooperation in some regions, underused demand management. A growing share of various renewable energy sources and the development of new smart grids and new decentralised generation technologies should also be properly foreseen.  New investments require combining funds from the European Fund for Strategic Investments and other specific sources of financing for energy, such as the Connecting Europe Facility. The new model should be based on a forward-looking holistic approach with a view to an integrated, stable and secure energy supply.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This text recites the EU mantras on renewable energy and long passages on storage (indispensable for intermittent solar and wind energy) (points 26 to 36) which are perfectly utopian in the current state of research. This report has a very centrist tone: states are caressed in the direction of the word on the issues settled by the treaties (energy mix), we rely on an evolutionary approach to nibble on the competences of the States and we rely on a so-called energy market, which is, whatever the rapporteur says, a natural monopoly. As usual too, renewable energy is a pretext to strengthen European federalism and destroy national enterprises, in the name of the fluidity required by intermittent energies. I voted against initiative report.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of measures that will lead to a better functioning and competitive energy market, and thus lower and more predictable energy prices for our large and small consumers. As it will also improve our cross-border cooperation on energy policy, it will help secure our energy supply and decrease our dependence on suppliers from outside the EU. As this is an important step to achieve our priorities on energy and climate issues, I gladly voted in support of this resolution.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Werner Langen's report. This report aims to promote the free movement of electricity in Europe, for a more efficient regional approach. A regional approach that will secure electricity taming and the implementation of clearer and fairer pricing. The issue of energy in Europe is central and I would like to support a text which is a first step towards a legislative proposal on the organisation of the energy market expected at the end of 2016.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to make the energy market more flexible, particularly the electricity sector. An acceptable compromise has been reached on the possibility of establishing capacity mechanisms that provide some security of supply. This report follows the Commission's communication and the public consultation on "a new energy market organisation" published in July 2015. A legislative proposal on the organisation of the energy market is expected at the end of 2016.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the redesign of the energy market because I consider it of the utmost importance, on the one hand, to create a pan-European electricity market that provides, through prices, clear indications in order to make new investments and, on the other hand, to establish a European approach to security of energy supply. Regional cooperation in energy policy should be strengthened, in particular as regards investments in new power plants, interconnections and aid rules, as well as the integration of renewable sources into the European internal market.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. A very successful report that provides for the opening up of energy markets across borders and further promotes the integration of renewable energies. At the same time, the rapporteur confirms that the Member States are autonomous in defining their energy mix. It also intends to press ahead with the integration of energy markets, without the Commission's expansion of competences. I share the rapporteur's critical opinion on capacity mechanisms and i agree with his call for price signals to arrive at the end customer. That is why I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Security, interconnectivity, inter-operability and energy efficiency form the core of European energy market, and we have to further work towards achieving a fully integrated European energy market that would be built on innovative approaches, ensuring cross-border competition and empowering consumers. Electricity must flow freely to where it is most needed and wanted.  I especially welcome that the report calls on new and innovative approaches for smart grids and interconnectivity and on empowering decentralised generators, prosumers and consumers. This will ensure diversification of supply chains, make our systems less dependent on external energy resources and also increase conscious energy consumption. I support the notion of some pilot projects across Europe that could then be applied across the Member States. We need good and new innovative approaches to production and distribution.  Lastly, a functioning internal energy market is only viable when Member States play by the same rules, act in solidarity and ensure a swift implementation of needed measures.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because we need to ensure a market design that is fit for the future, and one which works for consumers and industry, ensuring affordable energy.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Langen report is an interesting compromise between the demands of those who want to abolish any electricity generation other than that which comes from so-called renewable sources and those who are aware of the potential pitfalls of the move. Hydroelectric power plants play a key role among renewable sources in terms of installed capacity, then wind and photovoltaics at a further distance. Thus, only geothermal energy is a stable source in the long term. Due to this instability (sun, wind, water determine the unreliability of these sources), it is necessary to provide either backup sources or stabilizing capacities, which in case of lack of energy to the grid can flexibly replenish. The report notes the emergence of a new class of energy consumers who also produce this energy and notes the unconnectedness of the European electricity market both within and outside the Community. The lack of a report is little attention to the poor state of high-voltage interconnections, which is a key point in the future of ensuring a secure electricity supply. Energy must not only be produced, but also reliably transferred.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report is not consistent and inconsistent in itself. Either we completely liberalise the European energy markets and create a common European energy market, such as .B now with the Digital Single Market, or we leave the Member States to decide on their country's energy mix and to ensure energy security. This report is not a consistent advocate of deregulation and the liberalisation of energy markets, nor is it fully in favour of subsidiarity. It does not show a clear line as to how things should proceed in Europe in terms of energy policy. In line with the concept paper presented by the party's leader Ulrike Trebesius, ALFA is committed to ensuring that energy policy issues are left entirely to the Member States. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 13 September 2016, in plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, we voted on a report on 'Towards a new energy market design'.  The electricity market is constantly changing and electricity produced from renewable sources is projected to increase the current total share of electricity produced from 25% to 50% by 2030. The Commission's initiative, which is discussed in the report, aims to improve the functioning of the internal electricity market so that electricity can be move where and when it is most needed, while fully integrating the growing share of energy from renewable sources. Which, of course, is a commendable effort. Unfortunately, the Commission is going about this completely wrong again. Anyone who has been following me for a long time knows that for many reasons I am not a big fan of renewable energy. That is why I also supported the amendments calling for the phasing out of subsidies for renewable energy. I am also not very much in support of further increasing the powers of the Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators, as I believe that this area belongs purely and only to national competences. Since the final version of the report did not pass as i could agree with, I decided not to support it and voted against its text.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Major changes in recent years, such as new technologies, fluctuating commodity prices or the rapid spread of renewable electricity generation, have fundamentally changed the European energy market. The report intends to achieve three objectives. First and foremost, a market for electricity throughout the Union should be established, providing clear price signals for new investments. Secondly, a European infrastructure for a secure energy supply must be created. Thirdly, regional cooperation within energy policy should be strengthened, in particular with regard to the development of new energy production equipment, interconnector and support systems, and the integration of renewable energy sources into the European internal market. Achieving these objectives is in Europe's common interest, as the integration of electricity markets will improve a secure, cost-effective and environmentally minded energy supply. It is important that the overall structure of member states' national energy mix and energy supply is respected throughout the development of the new strategy. Efficient use of energy storage facilities, network development, the construction of appropriate inter-outlets and the widest possible use of renewable sources are essential for the completement of the internal market. Better integration and coordination of electricity markets has many opportunities to achieve common European goals for a safer, more cost-effective and sustainable energy supply.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is on the energy market design, which means the way that market actors generate, trade, supply and electricity. Among the members of GUE/NGL, we believe that new energy market design must be market-based and technology-neutral. We believe that the consumers should be more involved and allowed to participate in the market if they wish so, we promote the use of renewables and also new energy efficiency improvements. However, few of our amendments were tabled within the final report, this is why I voted against the report.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. – I supported the report on a new energy market concept, as I believe this is a successful step towards achieving and ensuring EU energy independence. It is necessary to create a long-term and transparent concept that includes and protects both national and European objectives and interests, to strike a balance between security of supply and price sustainability.  The Single Integrated Energy Market will help overcome Europe's energy dependence on gas and oil imports from Russia, which will provide a prerequisite for the implementation and negotiation of better conditions with new and potential EU energy partners. I believe that a coordinated renewable energy policy between the EU and national energy policies will promote the production and consumption of energy from renewable energy sources, help integrate the energy market, reduce the prerequisites for energy poverty and promote the fight against climate change.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this energy report because it is ultra-liberal in inspiration.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report entitled 'Towards a New Energy Market Organization'. Firstly, this report aims to give ACER enhanced powers, in the name of enhanced coordination at the regional level (points 70 and 72), with the aim of gradually moving it from the coordinating role between national regulators to a supranational regulator role. This report also remains in the illusion of an integrated energy market and on the Energy Union (points 3 and 4), for this reason the States that do not go fast enough in change. It also rules against national capacity mechanisms (point 9) and put the market before security of supply, like all European texts in this area. As usual too, ecology (here renewable energy) is a pretext to strengthen European federalism and destroy national enterprises, in the name of the fluidity required by intermittent energies.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The evolutionary approach referred to is a way of further limiting the competences of Member States, in an almost painless way. Moreover, the energy market is logically a natural monopoly, even though there is almost no room for manoeuvre on treaty issues. States, whatever the rapporteur says, are therefore always losers, regardless of the dressing and formulas used. Ecology is, as all too often, used as a pretext to strengthen European federalism and to destroy national enterprises, in the name of the fluidity required by energies. I could only vote against this resolution.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it sets up future rules for the energy market and, in particular, for its marketing and distribution. For a new design of the energy market it is necessary to take into account the changing nature of our supplies, so energy markets need to adapt, evolving from traditional models of centralized generation to systems more based on variable renewables and with greater flexibility, often also generated at a more local level.  It advocates an evolution towards a truly flexible, decentralized, integrated and open electricity market, where improving interconnections can potentially ensure that services and supplies flow freely across national borders, based on local and regional needs and advantages. In short, it is a question of promoting a design of the future energy market, at the service of consumers and industry, ensuring a supply at affordable prices.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it is a disappointing vision around the design of energy markets and networks in the Union, which does not provide solutions to the present problems. Our group has included amendments in support of renewables and criticizing mechanisms such as capacity mechanisms to benefit large multinationals in the electricity sector. This report does not reflect the need to support small producers of renewables, nor does it reflect the importance of enabling State intervention in the electricity sector. The report calls for the disappearance of regulated prices, which have proven to be one of the best tools to tackle the problem of energy poverty. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Union needs a new design of the electricity market to meet consumer expectations, bring real benefits from new technologies, facilitate investment, in particular in renewable energy and recognise member states' interdependence in energy security. I believe that in the design of this new European electricity market, national particularities must be taken into account and one of them follows the low level of interconnections.  Another challenge for the future is the integration into the market of a growing percentage of intermittent un manageable renewable energies. This requires good forecasting tools and greater implementation of demand participation flexibly. Because the European market will need to push forward measures to make it easier for the consumer to have real-time consumption information through electronic means and tools so that they can better manage their energy and improve their consumption habits, thereby reducing their energy expenditure, and for the protection of it, vote in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The report is not consistent and consistent in itself. Either we completely liberalise the European energy markets and create a common European energy market, such as.B now with the Digital Single Market, or we leave the Member States to decide on their country's energy mix and to ensure energy security. This report is not a consistent advocate of deregulation and the liberalisation of energy markets, nor is it fully in favour of subsidiarity. It does not show a clear line as to how things should proceed in Europe in terms of energy policy. In line with the concept paper presented by the party's leader Ulrike Trebesius, ALFA is committed to ensuring that energy policy issues are left entirely to the Member States. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which looks at completing the internal energy market through the efficient use of energy storage capacities, network expansions and the efficient use of interconnectors.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The report 'supports the increasing share of renewable energy sources in the EU', which I do not support. Nor do I agree with the call for "the creation of a regulatory framework that would lead end consumers to their own production and energy storage."

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The existing regulatory framework for European markets needs to be adjusted in order to allow a growing share of renewable energy sources and to close existing cross-border regulatory gaps. A new market design for electricity must be based on market principles, which would stimulate investment, ensure that small and medium enterprises have access to the energy market and unlock a sustainable and efficient electricity supply through a stable, integrated and smart energy system. But from my point of view a lower electricity price for people is the most important factor.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The Commission's proposal in the area of the internal energy market sets out three policy objectives: 1.the creation of a Pan-European electricity market with clear price signals for new investments, 2. setting a European approach to security of energy supply, 3. strengthening regional cooperation in energy policy, in particular in relation to investments in power plants and the integration of renewable energy sources into the European single market.  The consistent implementation of these objectives in all policies affecting the internal energy market will ensure the Union and its people's self-sufficiency, sustainability and sufficient affordable and secure energy to take into account environmental protection and employment in the sector.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to clarify the European Parliament's position on the European Commission's legislative proposal for a new energy market organisation to be published in December 2016. Given the evolution of our energy supply (modes and places of production, development of renewables...) the market must necessarily adapt to these changes.  This report sets out different options for achieving a more fluid, open and integrated energy market. For example, it proposes to increase interconnections so that energy services and supplies move beyond each state's borders on the basis of local and regional needs.  The energy supply of the 500 million Europeans is a crucial issue; I therefore vote in favour of this report, which brings together a broad consensus in Parliament and respects the approach of our political group.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on 'Towards the redesign of the energy market for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 12/9/2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text. Despite the incentive to invest in the grid, we criticise the enhanced powers granted to the European Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (ACER), a supranational regulator, to the detriment of the authority of states. Market ideology takes precedence over the security of supply of states. For these reasons, we cannot support this report.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the Report on Towards a New Energy Market Design because I consider that exemplary measures and initiatives must be taken in order to tackle the energy-related challenges Europe is facing. Such challenges include the dependency on oil and gas imports, high-energy prices, security risks, the fights against climate change, and poor progress in energy efficiency, among others. Only by taking the necessary measures to resolve these conflicts we will be able to achieve the common European goal of a secure, affordable, environmentally sound energy supply.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report on the subject of the new energy market design. The report places too much emphasis on the involvement of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, with which our factions have disagreed from the outset. Furthermore, it emphasises only the importance of market forces without any consumer involvement and attitudes. Strengthening the role of ACER and other European energy agencies is also not an idea I can support. A number of amendments by our faction aimed, for example, at a greater focus on renewable energy sources have not been adopted. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The energy sector is an extremely important sector that requires strategic planning. It is essential to promote renewable energies and to look at energy as a public good to which everyone must have fair access. I also believe that it is only possible to answer issues such as the development of renewable energies, energy efficiency and the sustainability of the environment with public management and control. The Langen report does not reflect these needs, so I voted against it.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. My support for the motion for a resolution on the Commission communication advancing the steps towards a new configuration of the energy market is being made. I believe that the reorganization of the electricity market, combined with the implementation of existing legislation, should strengthen regional cooperation in all areas of energy supply and demand, and should focus on improving markets and their greater decentralization and flexibility to ensure a well-regulated and market-based system , which will be able to achieve all the objectives set by the Union on climate and energy by 2030.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Here, energy security is postulated as a political objective for the future electricity market. In particular, emphasis is placed on renewable energy and low-carbon power generation plants. However, since nuclear power is not to be dispensed with at the same time, I cannot support this report.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The current approach referred to is a way of further limiting the competences of Member States in a painless manner. Moreover, the energy market is logically a natural monopoly, so the margins of manoeuvre of States are almost absent on issues settled by the treaties. States, whatever the rapporteur says, are therefore always losers, regardless of the dressing and formulas used. Ecology is, as all too often, a pretext to strengthen European federalism and to destroy national enterprises, in the name of the fluidity required by energies. I then voted against the resolution.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The integration of energy markets, linked to the integration of all market operators, including 'consumer producers', will contribute to achieving the objective of a secure, affordable, efficient and sustainable energy supply in the Treaty. In order to achieve climate and energy objectives, the energy system of the future should be more flexible, so it is necessary to invest in all flexibility solutions, i.e. flexible production, network development and flexible demand and storage. It is therefore important that the new Energy Union strategy is designed to make the EU a leader in the field of renewable energy. To achieve this goal, a fundamental transformation of the European electricity system will be necessary. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which has the interests of the Union’s customers as its main focus. It takes note of the changes in the energy market and how the Union must react in order to make changes in line with recent developments such as the increased presence of renewables with market-driven remuneration. The report also supports the need for a long-term strategy and policy in the field of energy to make the most of investments; therefore, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – How do we guarantee that energy supplies in Europe will remain secure in the near future? And how do we guarantee that energy becomes affordable and sustainable? In order to meet these challenges, this report rightly highlights the need for strengthened European energy networks The development of a well-functioning cross-border interconnection between Member States and the development of the necessary backup systems will guarantee electricity supplies in Europe. A stronger energy infrastructure in Europe would already increase our energy independence. Moreover, a new design of the energy market, which will be decentralised at the same time, would lead to cross-border competition, through the presence of multiple energy suppliers, to provide price advantages for consumers. At the same time, the growing supply of renewable energy sources, the integration of those renewable energy sources into the energy market and the development of smart grids and new technologies for decentralised generation will also enable consumers to play a more active role as consumers and energy producers. In this way, the consumer producer will be able to take part in the decision-making process on both the demand side and on the supply side of the electricity market.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – Europe faces several fundamental challenges in the field of energy, be it increased dependence on oil and gas imports, lack of diversification, high energy prices, increasing global energy demand, security risks in producer and transit countries, the fight against negative climate change, slow progress in energy efficiency, increasing the share of renewable energy, integration and interconnection of energy markets, and market distortions caused by various subsidy schemes. Better integration and coordination of energy markets brings with it many opportunities to achieve the common European objectives of a secure, affordable and green energy supply. However, energy markets, in particular electricity markets, are still heavily characterised by national responsibility for the energy mix at present. Measures to promote national energy mixes are very diverse and include, for example, significant subsidies to promote renewable energy sources and to set capacity mechanisms to ensure security of supply in some Member States. The proposal aims to strengthen the internal electricity market with clear price signals for new investments, to ensure security of energy supply and to strengthen regional cooperation in the field of energy policy, in particular with regard to investments in power plants, interconnections, support schemes, as well as the integration of renewable energy sources into the Single European Market, to which individual markets need to be adapted accordingly. I agree with the proposal and vote in the affirmative.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report towards a new energy market design because we need to ensure a market design that is fit for the future, and one which works for consumers and industry, ensuring affordable energy.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 15 July 2015, the European Commission published its Consultative Communication on Electricity Systems in Europe, in which it launched a public consultation on what the newly developed electricity market should look like in order to achieve energy policy objectives such as secure supply, environmental sustainability and value for money. Better integration and coordination of electricity markets has many opportunities to achieve common European goals for a secure, cost-effective and environmentally sustainable energy supply, while the development of energy markets, in particular electricity markets, is still heavily dominated by nation-state character. In its report, the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy proposes to adopt a resolution that is critical but fundamentally supportive of the Commission's proposed package of measures on this subject. I supported the draft resolution.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The growing dependence in recent years on oil and gas imports, lack of diversification, high energy prices, increased energy demand, security risks for producing countries, the fight against climate change, the slow process in energy efficiency, renewable energy quotas have become major challenges in Europe's energy field. On 15 July 2015, the European Commission published a series of documents alusing the European internal market with three policy objectives for the future electricity market: creating an EU-wide electricity market, creating a European approach to energy security and strengthening regional cooperation in the energy sector. I support the rapporteur's position that better integration and coordination of energy markets brings up multiple opportunities to achieve the common European objectives of a secure, sustainable and affordable energy supply. I highlight the importance of this EU-wide approach, as acceptable energy prices and security of supply are essential for the standard of living of households as well as for job security in businesses.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Langen report to a new energy market organisation deals with the new energy market induced by the changes made by the Energy Union. Some positive points are to be credited with this report (investment in the network, recall of the national competence on the energy mix ...). However, other points taint the report, such as the strengthening of the powers of the ACER, the endless promotion of the Energy Union, all tinged with liberalism. So I voted against this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because we need to ensure a market design that is fit for the future, and one which works for consumers and industry, ensuring affordable energy.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the new organisation of the energy market. In particular, I support the desire to make it more flexible and to strengthen security of supply, which is fundamental for our continent, in particular by creating an interconnected market at European level.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Werner Langen (EPP). This report highlights the desire to strengthen the internal energy market to allow for a freer flow of electricity. This includes strengthening regional cooperation and coordination on energy policies, and encouraging cross-border trade.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Energy markets, and in particular electricity markets, still remain strongly national, based on the principle of national responsibility for the energy mix. Measures for the implementation of national energy mixes differ considerably, ranging from the abandonment of nuclear energy to subsidies for renewable energies and the introduction of so-called capacity regulation mechanisms in some Member States in order to ensure security of supply. The report by Mr De Clercq on beazley is a good one. Langen aims to strengthen the European internal energy market by contributing to a secure and efficient supply through clear and concrete strategies. I therefore voted in favour of the measure.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. By redesigning the energy market, we need to move towards a sustainable model of energy production. There is a need, in particular, for the development of energy production equipment and the integration of renewable energy sources into the European internal market. I see the creation of an electricity market throughout the Union as the main objective of the redesign of the energy market, which was a key aspect for me in supporting this report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European future electricity market has three political objectives: the creation of an EU-wide electricity market providing clear price signals for new investments; provision of a European dimension to security of electricity supply; strengthening of regional cooperation on energy policy, in particular when there is investment in new energy production facilities, for interconnectors and funding rules, and for the integration of renewables into the European Single Market. I have voted for this report that will ensure that energy policy objectives of security of supply, environmental impact and value for money can be achieved.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The new Energy Union strategy provides new benefits for energy consumers, provides them with a much wider range of options for participation in energy markets and ensures better consumer protection. The full implementation of the Third Energy Package in all Member States is one of the most important steps towards a European energy market. We call for electricity and system services to be allocated in accordance with market economy principles. Such a public tender, national or cross-border, should be technologically neutral and also allow the participation of energy storage operators.  I stress the need to speed up, at all decision-making levels, the authorisation of projects targeting energy infrastructure. As the Commission's proposals for a new organisation of the energy market relate exclusively to the electricity sector, we call on the Commission to explore the possibility of revising the concept of the natural gas market in order to respond to the challenges in the gas sector.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report and i have therefore voted in favour of the new Energy Union strategy, because we must all be aware of the importance of such a union for the European market and for consumers who will ultimately have a wider range of options. At the same time, the report emphasises a practical aspect: long-term planning of infrastructure development, reiterating the importance of renewable technologies, in order to ensure the sustainability of this market.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, which I consider to be balanced, highlighting, inter alia, the right of Member States to set the conditions for the use and composition of their own energy resources. I agree with the call to strengthen ACER's role and appreciate that the promotion of digital technologies in the context of the creation of an ambitious strategy for digitising the energy sector, including the introduction of smart grids and smart meters, the development of mobile applications, internet platforms and data nodes, is an important point in the report.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This own initiative report focuses on the design of a new EU electricity market in light of the aim to double the percentage of electricity produced by renewables from 25% to 50% of the total by 2030. It proposes only market-based solutions to increase capacity such as incentives and rewards. GUE/NGL’s position in favour of a focus on public support for developing renewable energy, access to the grid, the right to self-generation, decentralised solutions, and energy efficiency measures, etc. have been largely ignored. The report proposes that change be based mainly on market rules whilst being ‘technology-neutral’ i.e. not favouring one form of energy over another – which is the opposite of what is required as we need a strong intervention by Member States in favour of developing renewables. I voted against the report.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. Here, energy security is postulated as a political objective for the future electricity market. In particular, emphasis is placed on renewable energy and low-carbon power generation plants. I can only support that.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. On 15 July 2015, the European Commission presented its Communication on a new configuration of the energy market, including a number of measures to address current challenges. Meanwhile, energy dependence continues to rise and so do prices, we continue to import 80% of oil, 100% of uranium and 60% of the gas we consume, we have lowered our energy targets by 2030, and even so the level of interconnections remains below the level of desirable, let's not mention outstanding work on energy efficiency. This report puts in the spotlight all the above-mentioned and outstanding energy challenges so that we can meet the energy and climate targets by 2030. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The redesign of the energy market in the EU is a very important issue, both for the Union and its Member States. In the context of achieving energy policy objectives, it is important to facilitate the use of new technologies and to invest, notably in renewable energy sources and low-carbon power plants. The challenges facing Europe in the energy sector can be addressed through better integration and coordination of energy markets, providing many opportunities to achieve the common European objectives of a more secure, cost-effective and environmentally sustainable energy supply. For all these reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We are against the report because we object to new EU legislation in this field. We in UKIP believe that the UK should make its own energy policy and exploit and invest in lower-cost, reliable energy sources like coal, gas and nuclear.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report focuses on the need to put into practice the "transition" of consumption to alternative sources. In fact, the structure of the European energy market needs to be harmonised with regard to the current situation of change: the transition from centralised production using mega fossil-powered plants, to relocated production with an increasing number of actors involved, and above all as the figure of the 'consumer' changes to 'producer & consumer', that is, the prosumer. However, the report does not fully accept what has been said about the role of the core of renewable energy around which the energy market must revolve, but emphasises the role of the 'self-regulating market', delegitimising incentives to support renewables and, sneakily, endorsing those in support of fossil or nuclear sources. For these reasons, I am voting against.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report that highlights that only stronger market integration can ensure more energy security for the EU. A new energy market design is strategically needed for the achievement of a true EU Energy Union and this report indicates directions for the Commission and proposes relevant solutions for the obstacles that have been hindering a common European market for energy. In the future, more electricity will be traded across borders and that requires efficient cooperation from all market actors, therefore we have to build the capacity for cross-border cooperation to reflect the increasing variability of production so that sufficient energy can flow across the EU.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal for a new energy market model and, in general, on the modernisation of the sustainability-led energy market, which is environmentally friendly. Unsustainable models in all EU Member States should be reduced as much as possible and great attention should be paid to renewables. More funds are needed to invest in new facilities to produce such energy.  The current electricity system needs to be changed, emphasis placed on low-carbon renewableness. The electricity market remains under national influences, and energy prices for standard households are too high. The price of energy products in general in the world is increasing and higher, so there is an increasing demand for an alternative way of producing energy that is more expensive in implementation, but later more profitable than previous systems. The Common Energy Policy is a good initiative, but due to the diversity of countries it will hardly be possible to implement it especially because of the disagreement between the national conditions of a particular country.  I agree that market analysis is needed and existing funding systems need to be reviewed. Promoting renewables is of utmost importance to achieve the EU's climate objectives.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report has a very centrist tone: states are caressed in the direction of the word on the issues settled by the treaties (energy mix), we rely on an evolutionary approach to nibble on the competences of the States and we rely on a so-called energy market, which is, although the rapporteur says, a natural monopoly. As usual too, ecology (here renewable energy) is a pretext to strengthen European federalism and to destroy national enterprises, in the name of the fluidity required by intermittent energies. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The integration of energy markets, together with the integration of all market players, including producer-consumers, will contribute to the achievement of the Treaty of a given objective of secure, low-cost, efficient and environmentally sustainable energy supply, and the energy system will need to be more flexible in the future in order to achieve climate and energy goals, which require investments in all four flexibility solutions, namely flexible generation , network development, demand flexibility and storage.  I support calls for the existing regulatory framework for European markets to be adapted to allow for a greater share of renewables and to address existing cross-border regulatory gaps; stresses that the new electricity market model, as part of an increasingly decentralised energy system, must be based on market principles, thereby boosting investment, enabling SMEs' access to the energy market and opening up the supply of sustainable and efficient electricity through a stable, integrated and smart energy system; believes that this framework should promote and reward flexible energy storage solutions, demand response technologies, flexible energy production, increased interconnection and further market integration, which will contribute to promoting the growing share of renewable energy and integrating them into the market.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this own-initiative report on the upcoming legislation on the scheme for the functioning of the energy market, which will be published in December. In today's Europe, the ways in which energy production and supply are being produced and this needs to be adapted to the market environment. The biggest challenge for the administration will be to define a mechanism under which national states will compensate firms for guaranteeing a certain capacity of the energy market in the event of a reduction in energy supply, e.g. in the case of a black out, while at the same time under-distorting the market environment or protecting final consumers from an inadequate increase in the price of electricity. I am glad that the proposals of our political group have already been taken into account in the ITRE committee negotiations, which have presented a set of criteria that must be met before such a mechanism is put in place.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Among the challenges facing Europe in the energy sector are dependence on oil and gas imports, which has increased further in recent years, the lack of diversification, high energy prices due to state levies, the overall growth in global energy demand, security risks for producer countries and transit , the fight against climate change, limited progress in the field of energy efficiency, the growing share of renewable energy, the integration and interconnection of energy markets and market distortions due to different aid schemes. The report aims to strengthen the internal energy market and allow electricity to move freely where it is most needed to take full advantage of cross-border competition and provide the right signals and incentives to drive the right investments. A dynamic society and economy need a secure and efficient energy supply. The European internal market can help to achieve this objective and clear and ambitious strategies are needed to achieve this. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which encourages the strengthening of the internal energy market, including the free movement of electricity, in line with cross-border competition which will stimulate appropriate investment for the sector. Regional cooperation and coordination on energy policies are needed. The report also indicates the possibility of implementing capacity mechanisms that will ensure security of supply for European citizens. The Energy Union demonstrates the value of cooperation between states in a sector where the national prism alone is not sufficient to meet the expectations and needs of citizens.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dependence on gas and oil imports, lack of diversification, increasing global energy demand, slow progress in energy efficiency and increasing share of renewable energy are some of the energy challenges facing Europe today.  In July 2015, the Commission presented a series of documents allocated to the design of a new configuration of the European energy market, and this document is following it.  The report aims to strengthen the European internal energy market on the basis of three main objectives: facilitating energy circulation, ensuring price stability for investors; efficient and safe use of energy storage capacities; regional cooperation in the sector, increased investment and improved renewable energy integration. I am voting in favour of this report, which, however, is safeguarded that Article 194 TFEU, according to which European energy policy must ensure the functioning of the energy market and the security of supply of the tfeu, must be complied with. I would also remind you that the definition of the energy mix of Member States and the conditions for the exploitation of their energy resources remains a national prerogative.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We are against the report because we object to new EU legislation in this field. We in UKIP believe that the UK should make its own energy policy and exploit and invest in lower-cost, reliable energy sources like coal, gas and nuclear.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I believe that it is necessary to continue to protect European consumers, as affordable energy prices are essential for the standard of living of households, but also for job security in energy-intensive companies. This report aims to create an EU-wide electricity market by strengthening regional cooperation in the energy sector, integrating renewable energy into the European single market and limiting dependence on oil and gas imports, with the ultimate objective of the Union's energy self-sufficiency, thereby reducing dependence on third countries.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr President, we need a new energy market design that takes into account the variable nature of an electricity supply that moves away from the traditional centralised model and moves to a more flexible system based on renewable energy produced at a local level. A new energy market configuration, coupled with the implementation of existing legislation, strengthens regional cooperation in all aspects of security of energy supply and energy demand, and should focus on improved, more decentralised and more flexible markets in order to ensure a well-regulated market-based system capable of achieving all eu energy and climate targets for 2030.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. On 15.07.2015, the Commission presented its Communication for a new configuration of the energy market, prior to the legislation scheduled for the end of 2016. For a new design of the energy market it is necessary to consider the changing nature of our supplies. We must have greater flexibility, incorporate renewables and those generated at the local level.  Among the many challenges we face are dependence on oil and gas, lack of diversification and progress in efficiency, high prices, growing global demand, security risks or the fight against climate change. The report lays the foundations for an Energy Union based on an interconnected market at European level, which ensures electricity supply at affordable prices, with optimal use of energy resources and efficiency as pillars, integrating renewables and co-generated ones. This requires increasing inland interconnections by killing energy islands such as The Iberian. Better market integration provides multiple opportunities for safe and efficient and sustainable sourcing for the environment. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution for a new organisation of the energy market to make it more integrated at European level.  It is normal for Member States to seek to ensure electricity supply to meet demand in the medium and long term. But, like the majority of MEPs, I believe that these Member States must guarantee this supply from the perspective of cross-border cooperation.  I am also in favour of renewable energy support schemes that are adapted to national circumstances. We know full well that the development of these renewable energies is a necessity for the planet and brings jobs and inclusive growth.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the framework of the Commission Communication of 15 July last year, a public consultation on the new configuration of the energy market was launched. In this Communication, three clear policy objectives are set out: an EU-wide market, which sends a clear signal on prices for new investments, a new European approach to security of supply, the strengthening of regional cooperation in the sector, in particular with regard to investments in new plants, interconnections and support schemes, and the integration of renewable energy into the European single market. Europe faces energy challenges related to increased dependence on oil and gas imports, high energy prices, increasing global demand, safety risks in producing and transit countries or combating climate change.  As Portuguese, I consider the full integration of the European market to be absolutely a priority, and obviously do not neglect the other aspects highlighted in the Commission Communication and supported by this report - such as the importance of reducing external energy dependence or lowering the price of energy. Because I have reviewed the positions advocated by this report, I voted in favour of it.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 The points in the report that promote the safety of the energy market and consumer and environmental friendliness are good. The development of the energy market is essential in order to reduce greenhouse gases. This can be achieved by creating a functioning energy market for renewable energy sources. A balanced market also supports innovation and the success of new growth companies. In many Member States, fossil fuels are still supported directly or indirectly. This will have to be addressed in the future. It is important that market interconnectation is also done by taking into account the views of the Member States. Member States often have the best picture of their own situation. They know best how to achieve, for example, the required renewable energy target.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, whose main objective is to make the energy market more flexible, particularly the electricity sector. This report argues, in fact, for a reorganized electricity market, associated with the implementation of existing legislation.  In this sense, the regulatory framework needs to be amended to allow for improvements in the share of renewable energy and to fill existing gaps in regulation at the cross-border level. Indeed, it is regrettable that there are still significant gaps in the interconnection between Member States. New approaches are needed to overcome bottlenecks and achieve an intelligent distribution network that allows for the proper integration of the various players in the energy market.  I supported this report because it reminds us of the importance of a more flexible energy market, targeting renewable energy and better integrated within the Union.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the report because it is based on market mechanisms and not on social and environmental needs. Set aside or discuss issues of network access for self-users, system decentralization or energy efficiency.  The report is also based on technology neutrality, which implies that energy from renewable or nuclear sources is considered in the same way; when we know perfectly well that environmental impacts are considerably different. Capacity mechanisms are covert subsidies to large companies and possibly to fossil energy. In addition, there is a risk that these mechanisms lead to the construction of new large infrastructures that condemn us to continue with the current model for several more decades.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The increasing diversity of energy sources and the full integration of renewable energy into power grids require a new energy market design. This will allow the EU to reduce dependence on centralised power generation and increase the use of many more localised sources of energy. This vital transition will increase our energy independence. I welcome the S&D’s approach to capacity mechanisms to ensure consumers get good value for money and to reduce the number of people living in energy poverty.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
