text: Writing. I voted in favour of the proposal to reshape the energy market in order to strengthen the internal energy market and avoid grid bottlenecks.  For this, the efficient use of energy storage capacities, the expansion of the grid and the efficient use of interconnectors are essential. In addition, renewable energy will be fully integrated into the electricity supply system.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I do share the rapporteurs approach that a ‘strengthened European internal market in electricity is possible’. Indeed, lots have been done in that regards. Today, new electricity suppliers can enter Member States’ markets, while both industrial and domestic consumers are now free to choose their own suppliers, something that was completely unthinkable some decades ago. However, the way for a complete, full-fledged internal energy market is still long, and further steps are needed. We need to continue pushing EU Member States for a full implementation of the Third Energy Package. Full and correct implementation of such legislation will bring more consumer protection, enhance the unbundling of energy networks and promote a better functioning of retails markets. However, the rapport is a good step forward and I welcome it.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it is a disappointing vision around the design of energy markets and networks in the Union, which does not provide solutions to the present problems. Our group has included amendments in support of renewables and criticizing mechanisms such as capacity mechanisms to benefit large multinationals in the electricity sector. This report does not reflect the need to support small producers of renewables, nor does it reflect the importance of enabling State intervention in the electricity sector. The report calls for the disappearance of regulated prices, which have proven to be one of the best tools to tackle the problem of energy poverty. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I am against any new legislation from the EU in this field.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because we need to ensure a market design that is fit for the future, and one which works for consumers and industry, ensuring affordable energy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Europe's electricity system is undergoing a period of fundamental change. Likewise, the electricity market has been constantly changing and today's market since what it looked like five years ago. The share of electricity produced from renewable sources should increase from the current 25 % to 50 % in 2030. In this context, I consider it extremely important that, in order to achieve the objectives of the Energy Union strategy, a fundamental transformation of the European Union's (EU) electricity system should take place, enabling network operators, producers and consumers, both in households and in industry, to make full use of new technologies. I am pleased that the EU entered 2015 with a commitment – in addition to combating the causes of climate change – to provide its citizens and businesses with a secure and affordable energy supply. I think that the adoption of the global climate agreement in Paris in December (adopted by 195 countries) has sent a clear signal to investors, businesses and policy makers that the global clean energy transition is an irreversible process, with a necessary departure from the use of polluting fossil fuels. I voted in favour of the resolution because it is important that measures towards a new concept of the energy market create sufficient conditions for a reliable and accessible energy supply for all EU citizens and businesses.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. In July 2015, the European Commission issued a series of documents on the common European market. One of them was also aimed at the electricity market and its future development, with the aim of meeting consumer expectations, bringing real benefits to new technologies and facilitating investment, especially in renewable sourcing. By the end of this year, the Commission must put forward a legislative proposal on the design of the electricity market and the security of electricity supply.  We in the European Union currently have too many conventional power plants, which is an opportunity and at the same time a challenge to further support alternative energy sources. Unfortunately, this report does not do so, but it largely maintains the situation as it has been before, as it does not provide decisive support to alternative energy sources and thus does not help to reduce the energy that would come from such sources, which is crucial for a more environmentally friendly economy.  Because of the lack of an ambitious report, I have decided to vote against it.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The report is not consistent and consistent in itself. Either we completely liberalise the European energy markets and create a common European energy market, such as.B now with the Digital Single Market, or we leave the Member States to decide on their country's energy mix and to ensure energy security. This report is not a consistent advocate of deregulation and the liberalisation of energy markets, nor is it fully in favour of subsidiarity. It does not show a clear line as to how things should proceed in Europe in terms of energy policy. In line with the concept paper presented by the party's leader Ulrike Trebesius, ALFA is committed to ensuring that energy policy issues are left entirely to the Member States. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 The Energy Union is an extremely important and ambitious project, at the end of which there will be cheaper, cleaner and safer energy for households and businesses. The removal of existing barriers and the convergence of national markets are a prerequisite for its implementation.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the motion for an EU Parliament resolution towards a new energy market design. Markets cannot be designed. Rather, they are dynamic entities, created through voluntary interactions between buyers and sellers. Furthermore, where regulations regarding energy markets may be desired by the peoples of the Member States, their institutions rather than EU should supply them.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Commission's plans must contribute to energy efficiency, security of energy supply, as well as the development of renewable energy sources. It must also ensure that the establishment of a European internal energy market is completed. The integration of energy markets will contribute to achieving the objective of a safe, low-cost, efficient and environmentally sustainable energy supply.  A properly implemented energy market has exceptional potential to increase European energy security and independence from large suppliers. It is necessary to combine the European Fund for Strategic Investments with energy funding sources in order to make market creation as efficient as possible. Today, more than half of the EU's electricity is produced without the emergence of greenhouse gases. I support this report, as I believe that the European Union needs a new energy market model that will enhance regional cooperation in all dimensions of energy supply and demand. The market will become more decentralised and flexible and will contribute to the achievement of the European Union's energy and climate objectives.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report Towards a new energy market design.  We must move towards completing the European internal market in electricity, thus contributing to efficiency, security of supply and the development of renewable energy sources. I support the call for adaptation of the existing regulatory framework of European markets in order to allow for a greater share of renewable energy sources and to bridge existing cross-border regulatory gaps. We also need a comprehensive, forward-looking approach in the new design of the electricity market.  In this context, the report rightly calls on the Commission to put itself at the fore front of a participment process aimed at achieving a common practical definition of producers.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The abolition of national policies and the strengthening of the Commission's powers to unify the market and create a pan-European electricity market, as proposed in the report, will have disastrous consequences for consumers. Only large companies will be the winners as they will be able to act seamlessly by increasing their profits. For us it is clear that energy must be guaranteed as a public social good, to which we all have equal and cheap access. It is equally important that the provision of energy to citizens is a matter of national policy, determined on the basis of the needs of the country and the people, always aiming at social development. Finally, the design of the electricity market should be based on a comprehensive proposal to support and develop renewable energy sources, which is also absent from the report. We have therefore voted against the report as it has the sole aim of making energy a tool to strengthen the EU's private interest and competitiveness.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The energy market redesign strategy is a prime example of the implementation of a poor EU economic policy. Energy is a critical infrastructure for each State, which should have full control over its production and distribution and, above all, should not be subject to external controls and restrictions, with the sole exception perhaps of environmental protection issues.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that our energy supply goals set out in the EU Treaty can only be achieved through closer integration into the energy market. It is important to ensure a secure, affordable, efficient and sustainable energy supply for the whole EU. I agree with the report that, in order to achieve the climate and energy objectives, the energy system of the future must be more flexible, so we need investments in all four flexibility solutions: flexible production, grid development, demand elasticity and storage. In redesigning the energy market, I believe that it is important not only to achieve full market integration, but also to support renewable, safe energy production and not to produce fossil or nuclear energy in any way. I must note here the unfortunate fact that Hungary, citing a lack of storage capacity and technologies, has not issued a licence for wind farms for 10 years and imposes an extra tax on solar systems. I therefore doubt that we will reach the 13% renewable target in 2020. I believe that the development of renewable (local) energy sources in the Member States should be encouraged and that we should devote more resources to R&D&I related to energy storage.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Decentralization of the energy market requires a new regulatory framework and energy governance. With the European Commission's report 'Towards a new structure of the energy market', the Commission believes that the new electricity market should make it possible, in view of the EU's climate and energy objectives, to establish a distributed electricity network (including self-consumption) and to develop innovative energy services. I am not satisfied with this report, which does not really recognise the importance of renewable energies and decentralisation in view of decarbonisation and the EU objectives in general. The role of the market is also put on a pedestal favouring fossil fuels and hindering renewables and self-consumption. I have tried to draw attention, through a number of amendments, to the importance of the renewable energy market, prosumer, for a real and inclusive energy transition. Other amendments I tabled tended to mitigate collective risks (such as the carbon bubble) and negative externalities. I voted against the problems raised in the report.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is currently facing a number of energy challenges, including dependence on oil and gas imports, lack of diversification, high energy prices influenced by state energy taxes, increased global energy demand, security risks to producing and transit countries, combating climate change, slow progress in energy efficiency , increasing the share of renewable energy, integrating and interconnecting energy markets and market distortions caused by different support systems.  In this respect, the Commission considered that better integration and coordination of energy markets is needed by creating an EU-wide electricity market, creating a genuine European dimension for security of energy supply and strengthening regional cooperation in interconnections and support systems, as well as integrating renewable energy.  However, the current situation is characterised by the predominance of the national decision-maker, which emphasises the need for consultations, in the sub-areas of prices applicable in the event of shortages, the extension of regulatory supervision at European level, the increase in interconnection, the use of renewable energies, the subsidiarity of the organisation of the European market, price liberalisation. It is a step forward to improve the situation.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the text. Indeed, among Europe's energy challenges are dependence on oil and gas imports, which has increased further in recent years, lack of diversification, high energy prices, state tariffs, growing global energy demand, security risks for producing and transit countries. , the fight against climate change, the lack of progress on energy efficiency, the increasing share of renewable energy, the integration and interconnection of energy markets and market distortions due to different aid regimes.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This own initiative report endorsed by the European Parliament is the first reaction to the Commission’s communication from July 2015. As a shadow rapporteur I supported the report on the new energy market design as proposed by the rapporteur W. Langen as a result of negotiations between the groups. I consider this text to be well-balanced, with market-based approach, covering all important issues related to the EU’s energy market including reform of ETS or role of ACER. It is not an easy task to bring forward a solution for transformation of the entire market design, but I believe this report will serve as an good first step towards this target.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 The report on the topic "Towards a new energy market model" strengthens regional cooperation in all dimensions of energy supply and demand. It also proposes the creation of a new energy market that should be well regulated and contribute to the achievement of all the european union's energy objectives.  However, while I support these elements of this report, I cannot support that the new Energy Union strategy is designed to bring the European Union to the fore-how on renewable energy. So I voted abstention.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the new energy market design.  The electricity market should be created at Union level with clear price signals for new investments. A European approach to energy security should be justified and regional cooperation in the field of energy policy should be strengthened, in particular in investments in new energy production facilities, in the interconnection lines and rules on financing, and in the integration of renewable energy sources into the European internal market.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the report because it is based on market mechanisms and not on social and environmental needs. Set aside or discuss issues of network access for self-users, system decentralization or energy efficiency.  The report is also based on technology neutrality, which implies that energy from renewable or nuclear sources is considered in the same way; when we know perfectly well that environmental impacts are considerably different. Capacity mechanisms are covert subsidies to large companies and possibly to fossil energy. In addition, there is a risk that these mechanisms lead to the construction of new large infrastructures that condemn us to continue with the current model for several more decades.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The report is not consistent and consistent in itself. Either we completely liberalise the European energy markets and create a common European energy market, such as.B now with the Digital Single Market, or we leave the Member States to decide on their country's energy mix and to ensure energy security. This report is not a consistent advocate of deregulation and the liberalisation of energy markets, nor is it fully in favour of subsidiarity. It does not show a clear line as to how things should proceed in Europe in terms of energy policy. In line with the concept paper i presented as party leader, ALFA is committed to ensuring that energy policy issues are left entirely to the Member States. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am very much concerned about the energy market situation in Spain. The renewable energy has been very penalised by the current Centre Right government and retroactive measures have been taken to penalise people who invested in renewable energy. I strongly believe that renewable energy should be supported in Spain as the national energy oligopoly companies try to limit their development. I am strongly committed to the removal of structural network bottlenecks, these are important preconditions for realising the internal market in energy and thereby stepping up competition. Full transparency of prices and offer is another crucial point to safeguard consumers Rights and best choices for energy providers.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report has a very centrist tone: states are caressed in the direction of the word on the issues settled by the treaties (energy mix), we rely on an evolutionary approach to nibble on the competences of the States and we rely on a so-called energy market, which is, although the rapporteur says, a natural monopoly. As usual too, ecology (here renewable energy) is a pretext to strengthen European federalism and to destroy national enterprises, in the name of the fluidity required by intermittent energies. I voted against it.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the Communication made by the European Commission in July 2015 on a new organisation of the energy market, this report stresses the need to reorganise the energy market and improve the regulatory framework with a view to increasing the use of renewable energies and filling in the gaps in cross-border legislation. The report argues that the organisation of the energy market should be based on market-specific principles, as this could help stimulate investment, guaranteeing SMEs market access, thereby achieving a stable, integrated and intelligent energy system. In this context, the report recommends that the Commission, in its work on the new organisation of the energy market, seek to guarantee a level playing field between European and third-country electricity producers, with a view to providing European consumers with sustainable and affordable electricity. The report insists on the importance of supporting stable and cost-effective renewable energies for long-term investments, which are adjustable in the short term and can be tailored to national needs. Therefore, taking into account their essential role in the energy market, the report calls on States to encourage their use. I therefore voted in favour of the report on the new organisation of the energy market.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The resolution on the structure of the energy market is not an attractive project from the point of view of the Polish market and Polish resources. Reducing the production and use of fossil fuels to enhance the role of renewable energy is possible for countries that have achieved a high level of economic development. The creation of an EU-wide electricity market to guarantee European security based on new installations and integration around renewable energy sources is not the best solution for the Polish energy interest, which is why I am against this resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 15 July 2015, the European Commission published a number of documents on the European internal market, including the consultative communication on European electricity systems discussed in this report. I supported this final document in accordance with the group's position.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against the report because it is based on market mechanisms and not on social and environmental needs. Set aside or discuss issues of network access for self-users, system decentralization or energy efficiency.  The report is also based on technology neutrality, which implies that energy from renewable or nuclear sources is considered in the same way; when we know perfectly well that environmental impacts are considerably different. Capacity mechanisms are covert subsidies to large companies and possibly to fossil energy. In addition, there is a risk that these mechanisms lead to the construction of new large infrastructures that condemn us to continue with the current model for several more decades.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the fact that the new Energy Union strategy is even more beneficial to energy consumers, offers them ample opportunities to participate in energy markets and ensures better consumer protection.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report entitled ‘Towards a New Energy Market Design’. In order to achieve the climate and energy targets, the energy system of the future will need more flexibility, which requires investment in all four flexibility solutions – flexible production, network development, demand flexibility and storage. The report calls for the new electricity market design to embrace a holistic, future-oriented approach. Furthermore, it emphasises that a strengthened European internal market in electricity is possible, on the basis of stronger price signals on the wholesale market through prices that reflect actual scarcity and surplus of supplies, including price spikes. I voted in favour because I believe that energy efficiency is a core principle of the Energy Union strategy, since this is an effective way of reducing emissions, generating savings for consumers and reducing the EU’s dependency on fossil fuel imports.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The Commission's proposal aims to strengthen the internal energy market and provide the free movement of energy wherever it is needed, with the aim of achieving the maximum benefits arising from cross-border cooperation in this area. In this sense, the agency for the cooperation of ACER energy regulators must take a growing role to promote regional and interregional cooperation. We are talking in general about a fairly comprehensive proposal, which has been enriched by the amendments made within the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, so I think it is necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because we need to ensure a market design that is fit for the future, and one which works for consumers and industry, ensuring affordable energy. The move away from generation in large central power plants towards decentralised production from renewable energy sources (and flexibility) requires an adaptation of the current rules of electricity trading and changes to the existing market roles.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. The completion of the European internal energy market is a demand of the Liberals in the European Parliament. With this report, we encourage the European Commission to take this to heart. A European internal energy market would entail a greater supply of affordable and renewable energy sources. To this end, we need greater integration of national markets through the development of interconnections. We must also accelerate the development of smart grids and new technology for decentralised generation. I voted in favour of this report in order to enable consumers to play a more active role as consumers and producers, and to encourage better demand-side management. In a Europe without internal borders, we should also be able to have an energy market without internal borders at the service of all EU citizens.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report aims to make the EU the world's leading producer of energy from renewable sources. That would be a good thing in itself if it were not contradicted by the facts and the deeds. If it were to really enable the development of renewable energies and to stop dependence on both nuclear and fossil fuels, I would be totally in for it. In reality, the EU is spending fabulous sums on nuclear energy and paltry on renewable energy, including research. It develops free trade agreements around the world that lead to export aberrations, particularly in terms of the carbon footprint, supposedly to break prices, but which above all break the rights of employees and employees themselves, and I am not talking about the multitude of armed conflicts to ensure the control of fossil fuels. This text does not create the slightest illusion and when it claims that the internal energy market will better protect consumers by fighting against price regulation and subsidies, my indignation has no limits as if the energy precariousness linked to the increasing increase in poverty was not a growing scourge in Europe.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Essentially, what this report is dealing with is, once again, the liberalisation of the "energy market", putting pressure on Member States to speed up the process of privatisation of what is still public. The truth is that the already known results of what happened with the liberalisation of the market, such as electricity, for example, clearly show that neither workers nor consumers have benefited from liberalisation. Contrary! It always decreases employment with rights and increases the prices paid by consumers. Energy is a strategic sector, fundamental for the economic, social and sovereign development of a country and its people, which must be used efficiently, avoiding waste, accompanying scientific and technological knowledge, with ecological sustainability, to increase the living conditions of society, and, therefore, must belong to the public and democratic sphere. This document is incompatible with these fundamental democratic principles. That's why we voted against it.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. According to the report, hydropower approvals should be more closely coordinated at EU level and the concession regime harmonised. In addition, the Member States should continue to be allowed to use nuclear power in the future. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report 'Towards a new structure of the energy market' because I am convinced that the Energy Union must be completed as soon as possible. We are experiencing a phase of transformation in the nature of electricity supply, towards more flexible and green systems. The market must adapt to the new dynamics and I hope that the Commission will be able to take on the vision of the European Parliament in drawing up future legislative proposals.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because we need to ensure a market design that is fit for the future, and one that works for consumers and industry, ensuring affordable, clean and safe energy. Building a true European Energy Union must work not only in order to be environmentally sustainable and reduce carbon emissions, but also to eliminate energy poverty, including targeted policies to ensure affordable energy for vulnerable groups, particularly vulnerable women, in line with an earlier report I co-authored on ‘Meeting anti-poverty targets in light of rising household costs’. We must make sure that our energy policy is compatible and complementary to social and environmental policy.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because it contributes to the plans of the European commission to create an EU-wide electricity market. This will be to the benefit of both companies and EU citizens. The EU’s energy market needs to become more interconnected and integrated. In order to achieve this, specific steps need to be taken. For example, I welcome the focus on decentralisation and an increased flexibility of the market. We need to empower consumers to become ‘prosumers’ of green energy, and also the future possibilities of battery storage offer a lot of opportunities to succeed in a transition to a more sustainable energy landscape in the EU.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the own-initiative report on a new organisation of the energy market.  The rapporteur considers that the European Commission's proposal for an energy policy involving centralised and decentralised structures is, in principle, correct. I welcome his view that the desired organisation of the market must therefore be designed in such a way that transformation processes can take place without causing market distortions and without leading to poor investment.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: writing \ u2012 The European Parliament resolution responds to the Commission communication on a new energy market design and advocates that a transformed energy market strengthen regional cooperation and focus on improved, decentralised and more flexible markets. The communication also gives clear price signals for new investments and security of electricity supply. In my opinion, the resolution contains some positive elements, such as more market support for renewables. On the other hand, however, as a result of negative elements for me, such as the condemnation of capacity markets or national energy mixes determined at European level instead of the national level, I have chosen to vote against this resolution.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Langen report because I believe that this initiative presents a balanced position on what the Role of the European Parliament should be in the codecision procedure on the new configuration of the energy market, which should be presented by the European Commission later this year. I believe that Member States should prepare alternative strategies for the capacity mechanisms that are currently used to adapt production capacity to the flexibility required by demand. This mechanism results in a distortion of the internal market and has repercussions on the energy bill of European consumers. I believe that the increasing focus on renewables as energy sources should, in the long term, allow these capacity mechanisms to be discontinued.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The reform of the electricity market is crucial to achieving the EU's climate and energy objectives. In particular, the conditions must be created for reducing energy consumption through better demand management. This is possible thanks to the new technologies that can be put in place in order to improve networks, meters, building smart homes and energy storage facilities but also by using new services from innovative companies, reliable intermediaries and the transition of consumption to alternative sources. This report, on the other hand, does not propose the revolution necessary to create a new structure of the energy market that would place renewables and their decentralised production at the centre. The key role that the new arrangement must play in speeding up the process of decarbonising electricity in order to contribute to the achievement of the EU's climate and energy objectives is not recognised. The role of the market is given space, leaving it free to regulate itself when it comes to interventions in favour of renewables, while all those masked interventions in support of fossil fuels and nuclear power remain justified. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report Towards a new energy market design.  I agree with the report's findings that the energy system will have to be more flexible in the future in order to achieve climate and energy objectives. Investments in all four flexible solutions – flexible production, network development, flexible demand and storage – are therefore needed.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (
text: PPE). Mr President, we consumers in Greece, but also in all the Member States, must see the bill reduced. But, for this to happen, it is necessary to upgrade the energy of the buildings. Ladies and gentlemen, I call on you to vote in favour, in the European Union budget for 2017, of my pilot proposal to upgrade buildings in the Adriatic-Ionian macro-region which was rated A excellently by the Commission and I am sure you will proceed with this. My proposal promotes the financing of regional and local initiatives to upgrade energy not only public buildings but also housing, and this in an area suffering from energy poverty at more than fifty per cent. Already in France, the Younger project, through the European Investment Bank, allocated four hundred million which contributed to the upgrading of five thousand homes, the creation of six thousand jobs and the reduction of consumption to nine thousand six hundred households per year. We know it's possible, we can do it in Greece, we can do it anywhere!

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – I believe this to be a good report, and the first step towards putting in place long-term objectives to decarbonise the heating and cooling sector. Almost half of the EU’s final energy demand is for heating and cooling, and so I think that this initiative is timely and I believe that our work on heating and cooling should go hand in hand with our work on renewables, energy efficiency, buildings and energy security. For me, technology development is a vitally important part of the strategy. When we consider the energy security situation in Europe, and our over-dependence on Russian gas, we should remember that this dependence is largely to do with our heat supply.  For this reason, it is important not only that we look to diversify our sources of natural gas, which is crucial, but also that we explore ways to support and accelerate the increased deployment of renewable heat technologies.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the EU's heating and cooling strategy presents some very innovative and important proposals for environmental protection at EU level. Among these, mention should be made of the construction of 'smart' buildings, incentives for self-handling, the need to dismantle the most obsolete power stations and, finally, the attention paid to the importance of informing and educating citizens. However, there is one thing that runs counter to what was said earlier: the production of energy from waste. It would involve the use of highly polluting incinerators. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Although the strategy does not announce any new legislative proposals, we oppose the EU strategy on heating and cooling as it will be used to reinforce the disruptive EU energy and climate policy that has already brought irreparable damage to Europe’s industry and economy.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this own initiative report which makes proposals to direct the implementation of the Commission’s strategy on the Energy Union launched in February this year. Part of the Commission’s proposal was its first ever strategy for heating and cooling to tackle the massive use of fossil fuels. This is a progressive report that emphasises the need to include specific measures for heating and cooling in the upcoming revisions of the Energy Efficiency Directive, the RES Directive and the Energy Performance of Building Directive, and the new ‘energy market design’. It suggests that high-energy efficiency measures, high-performance insulation, the use of renewable sources and recovered heat are the fundamental priorities for EU’s heating and cooling strategy.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. Heating and cooling account for about half of the EU's final energy demand. This is why it is so important to reduce demand and make the sector more efficient, in order to reduce our dependence on energy imports, reduce emissions and lower costs for consumers, especially those at risk of energy poverty.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the EU strategy on heating and cooling. In the EU, almost 50% of the EU’s final energy demand is used for heating and cooling, of which 80% is used in buildings. The share of primary energy from fossil fuels in heating and cooling remains very high at 75% and presents a major barrier to decarbonisation, thereby accelerating climate change and causing significant harm to the environment.  The heating and cooling sector should reflect the 2015 Paris Agreement on Climate Change (COP21) and be compatible with the EU’s energy and climate goal of 100% cent renewables by 2050 the latest. This issue affects in particular some EU Member States (Mediterranean countries) more than others. In order to tackle this issue, the energy efficiency of buildings must be improved and the use of renewables (including solar energy) must be increased. Reversible heat pumps may play an important role since they are energy efficient and the re-use of waste heat and cold generated by industry should be encouraged.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy on heating and cooling which refers to buildings both in the industrial sector and those intended for housing. Particular emphasis is placed on the need for architectural solutions, modernisation of the heating of buildings, e.g. through better insulation, modernisation of cooling/heating appliances and greater use of renewable sources and district heating.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The Commission has presented its first strategy to reduce high energy consumption, in particular from fossil fuels, in the field of heating and cooling. This is one of the priorities of the Energy Union. Heating and cooling is one of the most energy-intensive sectors in the EU, accounting for around 50% of energy in the EU, with a share of renewable energy sources at only 18%, while the share of fossil fuels is 75%. The strategy includes plans to increase the energy efficiency of buildings and improve the links between electricity systems and district heating networks. The aim is to significantly increase the use of renewable energy sources and to promote the re-use of waste heat and cooling produced in industry; an approach that I welcome. I also share the view that Europe will only remain competitive if it invests in innovative and sustainable approaches to research and development, especially in the field of energy. I also believe that there is still a great deal of work to be done in terms of climate protection and increasing energy efficiency.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite the good measures proposed, France does not need the EU's recommendations to define its energy policy, in this case in terms of heating and cooling. The problems of Central Europe, with often dilapidated and/or highly polluting facilities, are not the same as those in our country and the interpretation of the text may well be against our interests by imposing heavy constraints on individuals and accelerating the disfigurement or outright destruction of our heritage. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interests of transparency and democracy I would like to confirm I voted against this report. The EU ‘Heating and Cooling strategy’ is part of the European Commission´s Sustainable Energy Security Package. Its main objective is to reach 2030 climate and energy targets. Although this strategy does not announce any new legislative proposals I oppose this EU strategy as it will be used to reinforce the disruptive EU Energy and Climate policy that has already brought irreparable damages to the UK´s industry and economy.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it sets out a European Union strategy on heating and cooling, setting out proposals to reduce the use of energy in buildings. I believe that the renovation of buildings is one of the simplest ways for energy to be used more efficiently and to achieve significant reductions in CO2 emissions.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for heating and cooling. The EU's heating and cooling strategy is an integral part of the Energy Union strategy and the heating and cooling sector is therefore essential for achieving the EU's energy and climate targets for 2020, 2030 and 2050, as well as in achieving the objectives of improving security of energy supply. In addition, in the new Member States that joined the EU after 2004, the greatest efficiency gains are in the area of thermal renovation of buildings. I therefore agree with the need to increase funding for work on the thermal reconstruction of entire settlements. This must be considered a priority, especially since the owners of the buildings concerned are unable to cover the costs and the state support is not sufficient.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the strategy does not announce any new legislative proposals, we oppose the EU strategy on heating and cooling as it will be used to reinforce the disruptive EU energy and climate policy that has already brought irreparable damage to Europe’s industry and economy.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This text, authored by Polish and which concerns above all the countries of Eastern Europe, poses potentially serious threats to our architectural heritage. It certainly serves as a precaution for "historic buildings." However, in addition to the fact that the concept remains vague (given the different heritage protection laws, with only 44,000 buildings protected in France against more than 1,000,000 in Germany), paragraph 23 for example asks "local authorities" to deal with "specific problems in rural buildings, which are generally older, less energy efficient and less beneficial to health and provide less thermal comfort". That is, insulation from the outside? This risk to our heritage (in the broadest sense) is all the greater since the current trend in France is to give more and more decision-making power to local edifices, which generally do not have the necessary skills and who can hardly resist the various pressures (especially construction), to the detriment of the Architects of the Buildings of France. This is why this text risks accelerating the disfigurement, or even the outright destruction of our heritage, in the name of "energy efficiency".

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this report, which first of all reminds us that heating and cooling account for the largest share of demand in the European Union. The report calls for specific long-term strategies based on renewable energy to be developed. It also calls for higher energy efficiency standards and the Commission is called upon to provide appropriate co-financing for public building and multi-unit renovation initiatives that are characterized by low energy efficiency. At the same time, Member States are being urged to phase out the use of old boilers in urban areas that generate low-level emissions. Finally, MEPs believe that progress should be made under the Horizon 2020 framework programme in research and development on sustainable and efficient heating and cooling materials and systems.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Almost 50 % of the EU's final energy demand is used for heating and cooling, of which around 80 % is used for buildings. The agreement reached with COP21 clearly indicated the way forward. It is very much in line with the same European objectives, which provide, by 2050 at the latest, for a heating and cooling sector based entirely on renewable energies. The Gierek report, which I supported today with my vote, supports the Commission communication on the EU strategy on heating and cooling, indicating some measures to be taken to achieve the objectives set. High energy efficiency, high-performance thermal insulation and above all the use of renewable energy sources and thermal recovery energy are the key priorities together with a more decentralized and flexible energy system. The European Structural and Investment Funds can be an important instrument for the implementation of these proposals and for a more general modernisation of the continent's energy system. The new strategy must not only be a strength of the Eu ropean Union's environmental policy, but also a great opportunity for both businesses and consumers.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 The heating and cooling sectors consume half of the energy (especially fossil sources) in the Union and, a significant part of that energy is lost to lack of efficiency. There is then a significant room for improvement in the sector and, consequently, for decreased energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions. The report is in the right direction because it proposes to increase the share of renewable energy in this area, invest to improve energy efficiency by renovating buildings, accelerating the modernization of heating systems, decentralizing energy production systems, etc. If this package is in the right direction, it is too insufficient to drastically lower greenhouse gas emissions, deeply change the energy system, and meet climate targets. That's why I abstained.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the EU's heating and cooling strategy because the measures it proposes risk jeopardising our architectural heritage, particularly in rural areas. While energy efficiency is indeed a laudable objective, the text urges local authorities to take measures targeting rural buildings, which are considered "older, less energy efficient and less beneficial to health". In addition to the danger that such measures would pose to our heritage, it should be remembered that the constant change in standards poses a certain cost problem, especially for individuals who must invest, according to the report, in reversible heat pumps or in thermal insulation work. If attempts are present in the text to be cautious about "historic buildings", this precaution is fragile given the legal uncertainty around this definition. It should also be remembered that, despite the precautions included in the Energy Transition Act for the protection of old buildings in insulation operations, the implementing decree was quick to mitigate this assurance as much as possible.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Gierek report is acceptable and without any critical issues, so I supported it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Heating and cooling account for about half of the EU's final energy demand. Hence the importance of improving energy efficiency in this area, in order to reduce dependence, emissions and costs for consumers, especially those at risk of energy poverty. It is about ensuring that energy is used more efficiently and reducing CO2 emissions.  Among the measures to be taken, substantial increase in funding for thermal renovation works for complete developments is necessary. It is also necessary to replace obsolete thermoelectric plants in developments with efficient combined cogeneration plants of heat and electricity. On the other hand, in the Mediterranean countries, refrigeration is a concern. Proper architectural solutions, insulation and reversible heat pumps can play an important role in solving this problem. In addition, solar radiation is an important source of heat that has not yet been used enough.  This feeds on some of the forthcoming energy efficiency legislative initiatives planned for the end of 2016, in particular the revised Energy Efficiency of Buildings Directive. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has been advocated by Parliament on a strategy for heating and cooling buildings. Heating and cooling account for almost 50% of the FINAL EU energy demand, of which 80% is used in buildings, and each additional percentage of energy savings would reduce gas imports by 2.6%. Parliament considers that more action is needed, both in reducing demand for heating of buildings and in shifting the remaining demand from the burning of imported fossil fuels in individual boilers to sustainable heating and cooling opportunities. The report also stresses that the share of renewable energy sources has been slow, but there are still huge opportunities at all levels and should be exploited in the Member States. Parliament welcomed the Commission communication on the EU Strategy for Heating and Cooling, which took an important step towards a holistic approach to the transformation of the heating and cooling sector in the European Union and identified priority areas for action.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Resolution on the EU Heating and Cooling Strategy forms a strategic part of a very important area such as EU energy stability and security, as almost half of the EU's final energy demand is used for heating and cooling. This EU strategy recognises the key challenges and needs to increase energy efficiency and deploy renewables.  The observed problems in the worn-out and ineffiability of housing heating systems in the EU are also a great potential for increasing energy efficiency. Investing in energy savings and energy efficiency offers the largest and fastest return on investment in the energy sector. The strategy recognises the active role that consumers can play in creating a sustainable European heating and cooling system.  It highlighted the need to increase recycling rates, as waste energy production will play a very important role in the heating sector. The strategy points to one integrated approach in mobilising all key actors regarding the use of all available ESI Funds, which should be available to all actors, in particular SMEs. In addition, so in the vote all my support goes to that resolution.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 More than 40 % of europe's final energy consumption takes place in buildings, a consumption that contributes 36% to total CO2 emissions. If we consider the impact on these figures of heating and cooling systems, it is clear that action in these sectors is important in order to rationalise energy consumption and reduce pollution and emissions. In view of the Commission's presentation of legislative proposals on energy efficiency and building performance, Parliament would like to stress with this report, which I support, the importance of promoting all measures that can lead to the modernisation of heating and cooling systems. With the appropriate fiscal measures, already put in place, for example in Italy, and with integrated systems that exploit new technologies, it will be possible to achieve significant savings in terms of savings both at the level of individual dwellings and at the level of large buildings in the coming years.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this Report on the EU Heating and Cooling Strategy. Heating and cooling bills are about half of the EU's energy consumption, which tells how important it is to reduce demand and create a more efficient sector, in order to reduce dependence on energy imports, reduce emissions and bring down costs for consumers, especially those at risk of energy poverty.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This text calls on Member States and local authorities to save energy on heating and cooling. Energy saving is considered 'the first clean fuel'. In paragraph 23, he stresses rural buildings with an obvious risk to France's rural heritage. Having adopted this paragraph, I voted against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Heating and cooling of public buildings, industries and homes has an important economic and environmental impact for the whole of the European Union. The data available to us show significant differences between Eastern, Northern and Mediterranean Europe on this subject: consequently, the hierarchy of importance of individual initiatives in the various countries is also different. In the case of states that joined the EU after 2004, the main efficiency opportunities are concentrated in the thermal redevelopment of buildings, considered the easiest solution to ensure more efficient use of energy and a significant reduction in CO2 emissions. There is a need to significantly increase the financial resources allocated to the thermal redevelopment of entire blocks, in particular those built using prefabricated panel technology. To this end, a budget of at least 25 % of the total should be allocated from the European Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Fund. This objective should be high on the sector's priorities as the costs of such redevelopment exceed the possibilities of building owners while state support is insufficient. More efficient heating means a healthier environment and savings for all citizens.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to increase energy efficiency and encourages the use of renewable energy for heating and cooling with a target of 100% by 2050. To achieve this, the report proposes to rely on geothermal energy, biomethane production, priority use of local raw materials or industrial heat recovery. Although it is necessary in the Member States to tackle energy waste in order to reduce our energy bill, there is still the question of financing infrastructure to achieve this objective, such as thermal insulation and reversible heat pumps. On this point, however, it is feared that this work will be the responsibility of individuals despite the introduction of a subsidy system. The report also calls for studies on energy savings in historic buildings to improve energy performance. However, there is no guarantee that the proper work will ensure the protection and preservation of our cultural heritage. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Many European buildings are currently facing the problem of energy losses due to their inadequate insulation and old and inefficient heating systems. At the same time, energy poverty affects almost 11% of the EU population. EU policy instruments and capabilities are not yet sufficiently developed to stimulate the transformation of the heating and cooling sector, to make the most of existing potential and to develop solutions to reduce demand. It is estimated that the amount of heat produced by industrial processes and wasted in the atmosphere or water, instead of being used in a productive manner, is sufficient to fully cover the heating needs of residential and tertiary buildings in the Union. I welcome the Commission's initiative for industry, research and energy to initiate this report, considering that the correct implementation of measures to develop a comprehensive and integrated strategy for heating and cooling offers a number of significant opportunities for both businesses and CONSUMERS in the EU in terms of reducing overall energy costs for industry, boosting competitiveness and ensuring a reduction in consumer costs , which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The problem of heating and cooling has profound effects in the most different areas. It is essential to make real progress in revolutionising the heating and cooling sector as part of a wider reform of the energy system. The main way to combat energy poverty is to reduce heating prices, ensuring that energy efficiency will increase significantly. The strategy to increase the efficiency and sustainability of heating and cooling aims to address a complex issue: the distribution of heating elements in several directives and legislative instruments such as: the Energy Efficiency of Buildings Directive, the Renewable Energy Directive and the Energy Efficiency Directive. I support the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on an EU strategy for heating and cooling. I stress the importance of carrying out more extensive scientific research on the development of innovative technological solutions aimed at ensuring energy-efficient household appliances and all heating and cooling systems. An important heat source, which has not been used sufficiently, is solar radiation, which, with the help of panels that heat water or generate electricity, can be fully harnessed.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reading and discussion in plenary, I voted in favour of the report on the european Parliament's motion for a resolution on an EU strategy on heating and cooling, as I believe that the scenario of fair energy supply can no longer be separated from that relating to the more efficient use of energy and the important reduction of CO2 emissions. , following the COP 21 agreement, which has now also been ratified by the USA and China. The energy resilience of our nations and the fight against so-called 'energy poverty' must also be taken into account. With the subsequent consideration that the energy markets still maintain a highly regionalist character, on the basis of the principle of national responsibility for the energy mix, very uneven between states.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this own initiative report which makes proposals to direct the implementation of the Commission’s strategy on the Energy Union launched in February this year. Part of the Commission’s proposal was its first ever strategy for heating and cooling to tackle the massive use of fossil fuels. This is a progressive report that emphasises the need to include specific measures for heating and cooling in the upcoming revisions of the Energy Efficiency Directive, the RES Directive and the Energy Performance of Building Directive, and the new ‘energy market design’. It suggests that high-energy efficiency measures, high-performance insulation, the use of renewable sources and recovered heat are the fundamental priorities for EU’s heating and cooling strategy.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission has launched the first ever strategy to tackle heating and cooling efficiently. This is one of the priorities of the EU especially when it is consists of the EU’s biggest energy sector and I fully agree. The report points out at the local character and potential of heating and cooling. The strategy includes amongst others plans to boost the energy efficiency of buildings and the use of renewable energy. I believe it is important that there is access to finance for investments to modernising the heating and cooling system and a focus on the research and technological innovation for European industry. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Heating and cooling are responsible for half of the EU's energy consumption and much of that energy is lost. Making them more efficient and sustainable is a strategic priority of the Energy Union. While Mr Gierek's report contains many positive references ( for example, the importance of decommissioning the most obsolete power stations as soon as possible and speeding up the replacement of the most polluting domestic installations), it retains elements that do not satisfy us: for example, when it deals with district heating, on which we would like greater caution, especially in relation to new networks and infrastructures; when it comes to geothermal energy, biogas without distinguishing the sources of origin, and above all about the European Commission's strategy on the production of energy from waste involving incinerators. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that new sustainable energy strategies, such as self-generation and sustainable use of organic waste, could help us to decrease our dependency on high-carbon infrastructure and increase, on the other hand, energy efficiency in rural buildings. I would be also in favour of a new attractive financing system to promote new technologies for heating households using renewable energy sources as well as of modernisation of old and inefficient heating systems and of deep renovation of buildings with improved thermal insulation.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's energy policy on heating and cooling must aim to reduce member states' energy dependence, lower costs for consumers and reduce emissions in line with the targets set at the Paris Conference on Climate Change (COP 21). To date, almost 40 % of the EU's final energy demand is used for heating and cooling buildings. It is necessary to increase the energy efficiency of buildings through renovation and renovation, in particular by improving their thermal insulation. I voted in favour of this report because it calls on the Member States to implement strategies that allow consumers to be more involved in the energy market and to take action to control energy consumption. Support should also continue to support the construction of near-zero energy buildings. I believe that the Member States should offer incentives for the promotion and use of renewable energies. And it is essential to invest in research and innovation activities in order to develop energy-efficient technologies. Finally, I believe that the Member States must ensure that a proportion of the funding dedicated to energy efficiency is provided to households by helping them to invest in more efficient heating and cooling equipment.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and recall that in the Mediterranean countries of Europe cooling is a matter of increasing concern, and is linked to gradual climate warming. Appropriate architectural solutions, insulation and reversible heat pumps - which draw heat from a room in hot weather and channel it when heating is required - can play an important role in solving this problem.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the EU strategy for the heating and cooling sector is particularly important as it affects industrial and consumer issues. The willingness to upgrade the equipment used, as well as the strategy to rationalise the energy consumed by European society, are positive steps and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is to be welcomed that I welcome the report by the Committee on Industry, Public Health and Industrial Policy establishing an indispensable European strategy on heating and cooling, as I consider this issue to be a priority issue in the context of sustainable growth. European energy policy includes reducing the use of fossil fuels and strengthening renewable energies (which to date have a use, albeit increasing, limited to 18 %) to ensure cleaner, safer, competitive, persistent and affordable energy for all. Excessive dependence on a limited number of sources also makes countries vulnerable to supply disruptions. At a time when the affordability of energy and the competitiveness of energy prices are of growing concern to households and businesses, it is necessary to reduce our dependence on fossil fuels and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. My proposal calls on the Member States to phase out the use of set-back facilities and the disposal of wood-burning fireplaces in cities in urban areas. These measures require, during the transition, investments to be managed in accordance with the principles of efficiency and effectiveness, so cooperation with local authorities is essential.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on an EU strategy on heating and cooling and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. Heating and cooling is the largest energy sector in the European Union, with a 50% share of the EU's energy consumption. Of this half of global consumption, only 18% come from renewable sources and 75% from fossil sources. The size of this area makes it a priority of the Energy Union and this report, as the sector's first energy efficiency strategy, is of great importance. I believe that thermal renovation of buildings should be a priority, including extended interventions in large residential areas. I would remind you, in this regard, that EU funding must be balanced with national investment and the owners' initiative, with respect to the principle of subsidiarity.  In this regard, I note that heating or cooling needs are very variable in the EU (the heat requirements in the north contrast with the cooling requirements in the south, for example), so the specificities should be considered in any regulation. I believe that any comprehensive reform in this sector promotes scientific initiative and research into energy technologies and that the energy transition is therefore a sustained process based on credible and transparent cost-benefit analyses.  From the foregoing, I support the report.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, in defining the Eu ropean Union's strategy for heating and cooling, it emphasises the energy redevelopment of buildings, stressing that action by the European Energy Efficiency Fund is needed to help citizens bear the costs of modernising them by covering at least 25 % of the total cost. With regard to cooling at the heart of the strategy, there should be the search for new architectural solutions, thermal insulation and inversion heat pumps, with particular attention to the latter, given the enormous potential in terms of both heating and cooling.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, because the development of a European strategy in this area is a necessary tool for emission reduction. The warming and cooling sector, one of the main carbon emitters in the Union, to propose a strategy at European level is a first step in correcting the problems of allocating resources through market mechanisms. The report includes explicit support for the use of renewable energy in this sector, as well as improved energy efficiency of buildings, collective heating mechanisms, etc. The text supports the development of more sustainable technologies and the reduction of emissions in this sector. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution presents a European strategy for improving heating and cooling systems in premises at European level that will contribute to the achievement of the general objectives of decarbonisation and energy efficiency. The European Parliament, in its resolution, notes that the percentage of primary energy from fossil fuels used for heating and cooling of premises remains very high and represents a major obstacle to decarbonisation, thereby accelerating climate change and causing significant damage to the environment. I voted in favour of the resolution because, by voting, I intend to support this process of modernising heating and cooling systems. This process must involve the various actors at all levels: the Commission must use an important financial mechanism, for example for accelerating the rate of building renovation, and allocate a higher share of EU funds to energy efficiency programmes and the use of energy from renewable sources; Member States must take measures to provide strong incentives to improve energy efficiency; national and local authorities must ensure that consumers are fully aware and can benefit from the technical and economic benefits of new heating and cooling systems.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Gradual climate warming causes cooling that generates energy losses in buildings that do not benefit from adequate thermal insulation. I voted to reserve at least 25% of the European Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Fund for the purpose of thermal property renovation. This objective must be a priority, all the more so as the problem of heating and cooling is increasing in the Member States. The use of appropriate architectural solutions, reversible insulation and heat pumps, the replacement of outdated thermal power plants with high-efficiency ones, are concrete solutions to ease the thermal discomfort of the citizens of the Member States affected by these climate changes.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I voted in favour of the EU strategy on heating and cooling, it is the first step in analysing and addressing problems and challenges in this sector through EU energy policy. In order to achieve the EU's climate and energy targets, the sector concerned by the strategy must undergo radical change in order to reduce energy consumption and the use of fossil fuels. As much as 84% of the energy used for heating and cooling still comes from fossil fuels and only 16% from renewable sources, research confirms. In my opinion, it is important to make changes in this sector. The main objectives of the strategy are the combination of electricity systems with heating and cooling systems, as well as the recovery of waste energy from industry.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Heating and cooling is the largest energy sector especially in homes around the European Union. High efficiency cogeneration heat plants and reversible heat-cooling pumps are needed for Northern and Mediterranean countries. I am in favour of this report which highlights the need for architectural solutions, the modernisation of heating and cooling appliance as well the greater use of district heating and renewables. We need to keep in mind that heating and cooling accounts for roughly half of the EU’s final energy demand – therefore it is highly important to reduce this demand and make the sector more efficient. I voted in favour of this EU strategy which addresses energy poverty, reduces emissions and also brings down costs to consumers.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that energy efficiency policies should focus on the most cost-effective ways to improve building performance by reducing heat demand and/or connecting buildings with high-efficiency alternatives, I consider it important to carry out extensive scientific research to develop innovative technological solutions to propose energy-efficient and energy-efficient home and cooling systems.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on the European Commission's proposal to launch its first strategy to combat massive energy consumption, which is seen as one of the Energy Union's priorities. Parliament's report stresses the importance of urban energy networks and calls on Member States to reduce the use of boilers. It also stresses the importance of investments in research and innovation in this area. Considering that a more efficient use of energy must help the Union to achieve the COP21 targets and, on the other hand, European citizens to reduce their energy bills, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the strategy does not announce any new legislative proposals, we oppose the EU strategy on heating and cooling as it will be used to reinforce the disruptive EU energy and climate policy that has already brought irreparable damage to European industry and economy.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This report on the European Union's heating and cooling strategy sets out the Recommendations of the European Parliament to address the massive energy consumption in this sector. While almost 50% of the final energy demand in the European Union is used for heating and cooling, guidelines are needed to improve energy efficiency, mainly in buildings. I think it is particularly necessary to encourage research and innovation in this area in order to enable not only better insulation generating energy savings, but also to develop the use of renewable energies.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union spends 59% of its total use of natural gas and 12% of its oil consumption on heating and cooling, while every 1% increase in energy efficiency reduces natural gas imports by 2.6%. The EU will therefore pay particular attention to the development of a heating and cooling strategy in order to achieve the climate targets set and to reduce its dependence on suppliers of energy sources. The heating and cooling of our buildings consumes nearly 35% of our total energy consumption, but with serious renovation work this could be significantly reduced. The stock of walls and single-layer windows with no proper insulation remains high. To this end, the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive has been established, which sets mandatory minimum energy efficiency criteria for new investments. In the case of industry, insulation and efficiency gains can lead to lower emission reductions, as heating to the right temperature is often an integral part of the production process. Nevertheless, the aim is to decarbonise processes as fully as possible. At the same time, heating with electricity from renewables cannot be the solution for processes at really high temperatures, so fossil fuels are needed. The EU's priority is to make the most of the resulting excess heat, or even cold excess. Finally, it is important to highlight the role of LNG import terminals as a source of remote cooling.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This strategy is a useful opportunity as well as an important commitment to the development of renewable energy and the reduction of CO2 emissions. In addition, in order to combat the phenomenon of global warming, it is becoming increasingly important to invest in technologies and in the management of new heat-insulating plants and constructions, such as inversion heat pumps and prefabricated panels. The report takes today's climate challenges seriously and protects the well-being of citizens and respect for the environment, which is why I have decided to support it.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Union spends 59% of its total use of natural gas and 12% of its oil consumption on heating and cooling, while every 1% increase in energy efficiency reduces natural gas imports by 2.6%. The EU will therefore pay particular attention to the development of a heating and cooling strategy in order to achieve the climate targets set and reduce its dependence on energy suppliers. The heating and cooling of our buildings consumes nearly 35% of our total energy consumption, but with serious renovation work this could be significantly reduced. The stock of walls and single-layer windows with no proper insulation remains high. To this end, a Directive on the energy performance of buildings has been established, which sets mandatory minimum energy efficiency standards for new investments. In the case of industry, insulation and efficiency gains can lead to lower emission reductions, as heating to the right temperature is often an integral part of the production process. Nevertheless, the aim is to decarbonise processes as fully as possible. At the same time, heating with electricity from renewables cannot be the solution for processes at really high temperatures, so fossil fuels are needed. The EU's priority is to make the most of the resulting excess heat, or even cold excess. Finally, it is important to highlight the role of LNG import terminals as a source of remote cooling.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This text extends the Pieper report voted in Brussels in June on energy efficiency. The stated goal is to achieve 100% renewable energy. Despite this seemingly laudable objective, there are fears of a form of energy austerity imposed on the peoples of Europe. In addition, this text poses a significant risk to our heritage, advocating an improvement in their energy performance at the expense of preserving their heritage value. So I voted against the resolution.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this dossier because it represents a good ideological approach to overcoming heating and cooling problems across the EU. I have some concerns about the possibility of getting some significant short-term effects, but in the long run this is the only viable strategy if we are to improve the system and protect the environment, given the resources. It is obvious that the situation will have to be assessed for each Member State, as the challenges vary dramatically.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Energy should be the sole responsibility of each State, the Union should be limited to environmental pressures.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union spends 59% of its total use of natural gas and 12% of its oil consumption on heating and cooling, while every 1% increase in energy efficiency reduces natural gas imports by 2.6%. The EU will therefore pay particular attention to the development of a heating and cooling strategy in order to achieve the climate targets set and reduce its dependence on suppliers of energy sources. The heating and cooling of our buildings consumes nearly 35% of our total energy consumption, but with serious renovation work this could be significantly reduced. The stock of walls and single-layer windows with no proper insulation remains high. To this end, the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive has been established, which sets mandatory minimum energy efficiency criteria for new investments.
