In the case of industry, a lower reduction in emissions can be achieved by insulation and efficiency gains, as heating to the right temperature is often an integral part of the production process. Nevertheless, the aim is to decarbonise processes as fully as possible. At the same time, in the case of processes at really high temperatures, heating with electricity from renewables cannot be the solution, so fossil fuels are needed. The EU's priority is to make the most of the resulting excess heat, or even cold excess. Finally, it is important to highlight the role of LNG import terminals as a source of remote cooling. In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Improving heating and cooling systems must be at the heart of our efforts to achieve the objective of energy efficiency within the Union. This objective becomes even more important in a historical climate and in an economic, climatic and environmental context that call on Europe to break the chains of its energy dependence and to exploit, as widely as possible, renewable energy sources, responding virtuously to the growing needs of households and businesses. I note that the strategy proposed by the rapporteur incorporates many of the M5S instances. For example, I find myself in the need, highlighted in the text that has now come to plenary, to decentralise energy production and to redevelop the building stock as a whole. I do not entirely agree with some aspects of the strategy. I am thinking, for example, of certain references to geothermal energy, district heating and waste production (by incineration) as methods of contributing to decentralised and efficient energy production. I believe that the Strategy does not take sufficient account of the environmental problems that can be triggered by the use of these technologies. However, the approach emerging from the heating and cooling strategy is generally appreciable. That is why I voted in favour.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The issue of heating and cooling does not affect all Member States in the same way. For this reason, the order of priority of the measures taken varies from country to country. It is in the thermal renovation of buildings that the greatest gains in energy efficiency can be made in the countries that joined the Union after 2004. It is essential to substantially increase the financing of thermal renovation works for entire residential areas, in particular those built using the large panel construction method. At least 25% of the total resources of the European Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Fund should be dedicated to this.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The issue of heating and cooling affects Member States in a variety of ways. For this reason, the order of priority of the measures taken varies from country to country. It is in the thermal renovation of buildings that major gains in energy efficiency can be achieved, ensuring a considerable reduction in CO2 emissions. It is essential to substantially increase the funding of thermal renewal works for entire residential areas, an objective which the current allocation of relevant EU programmes is not in a position to meet. The report makes progress with a number of proposals and considerations that, in general terms, deserve our agreement, whether on heat production or refrigeration – a growing concern in Mediterranean countries – including with regard to appropriate architectural solutions such as thermal insulation and reversible heat pumps, which remove heat from buildings during warmer periods and pump heat inwards when heating is needed. Solar radiation is an important source of heat, although it is still underutilized and can be used through solar panels for water heating or electricity generation. Relatively contained in the political assessment aspect, the report develops above all more technical considerations. We voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report on an EU strategy on heating and cooling. It has the merit of adequately addressing the issue, prioritising the achievement of objectives such as: a strategy for decarbonisation, renovation of existing buildings to allow less energy consumption, integration of electricity systems with those of cooling and heating.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Geographical diversification of the European Union also raises questions in relation to the issue of heating and cooling. In some countries, this topic is more important than in others, and therefore there are also different priorities and approaches regarding the measures that will have to be taken in the future. From the point of view of environmental protection, it should be stressed that in many countries outdated thermal power plants still operate today, which need to be replaced as soon as possible by new highly efficient cogeneration plants. It is also important to use alternative natural resources, where, for example, sunlight is still not sufficiently used.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report because it is right to take account of climate differences within Europe and to support new instruments for energy efficiency.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on an EU strategy on heating and cooling. Energy should, in my view, be the sole responsibility of each State and the Union should be limited to environmental pressures.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Heating and cooling accounts for roughly half of the EU’s final energy demand – which is why it is so important to reduce demand and make the sector more efficient, in order to reduce dependence on energy imports, reduce emissions, and bring down costs to consumers, especially those at risk of energy poverty. The report is in response to a Commission communication on the heating and cooling strategy. Heating and cooling refers to heating and cooling of buildings both in the residential and industrial sectors. It will feed into some of the upcoming legislative initiatives on energy efficiency, in particular the revised Energy Performance of Buildings Directive to be proposed in the autumn. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report fully aware of its importance, as the issue of heating and cooling is relevant in many Member States. However, there are differences in the order of priorities that these countries have in terms of the action to be taken. We must work to ensure in the simplest way that energy is used efficiently and achieve significant reductions in CO2 emissions. It is therefore necessary to increase funding for thermal renovation works, because, in general, the owners of the buildings concerned cannot afford the costs in entail, and State aid is insufficient.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this very important report by Mr Gierek. If we wish to move to a more energy efficient and effective society, we must not forget that heating and cooling stands for close to 50% of the EU’s final energy demand. Given this, action from our part in increasing the efficiency and sustainability of heating and cooling in the EU will play a major role in the overall effectiveness of the energy market. Due to the importance of this topic, I think that a modern solution to the financing of research and new methods is needed; this should include a magnitude of actors including EU research instruments such as Horizon 2020 as well as private investors.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe made very significant commitments last year at the COP21 climate conference. In order to achieve reductions in consumption and emissions, we need a profound evolution of our energy systems, starting from everyday habits. A key factor in the distribution of emissions is heating and cooling in buildings, which alone are also an important financial commitment for many households in Europe. In order to achieve the Paris target of a 40% reduction in energy consumption, extraordinary actions are needed: we call on the Commission, within the framework of the announced proposal for a reform of the energy efficiency of buildings, to introduce ambitious and demanding measures.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on an EU strategy on heating and cooling because I believe that today one of the main challenges for our planet is to protect the environment, reduce energy consumption and sustainability of energy sources. If we consider that around 50 % of final energy demand in the EU relates to heating and cooling, it is crucial that these sectors are compatible with the EU's climate and energy targets, which provide for the total use of renewable energy by 2050. I believe that these objectives are an excellent starting point for starting to discuss a serious and effective global strategy that brings concrete results and offers important job opportunities for businesses and consumers in the EU. Indeed, I welcome the Commission communication on the EU's heating and cooling strategy, which sets out a holistic line to dictate priorities and objectives. Finally, I support the need to develop new technologies relating to renewable energy sources, including incentives from Member States and facilities for the withdrawal of obsolete heating systems.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for heating and cooling. Europe can encourage producers and retailers in Europe to do more for energy-saving products – thereby helping citizens and families across Europe to save money. I support that.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome a renewed EU strategy in the field of heating and cooling. Currently, half of the energy produced in the EU is used for heating or cooling. 18% of this energy is generated only from renewable energy sources and 75% is generated by fossil energy sources. Change is therefore overdue. The proposed increase in the energy efficiency of buildings and the better interconnection of electricity systems and district heating networks are a good approach. In particular, promoting the better use of waste heat from industry and agriculture opens up new opportunities in rural areas.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Heating and cooling accounts for roughly half of the EU’s final energy demand – the report seeks solutions to reduce demand and make the sector more efficient in order to decrease dependence on energy imports, reduce emissions, and bring down costs to consumers, especially those at risk of energy poverty.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. 2012 40% of eu energy consumption is used for heating and cooling buildings. While I am convinced that this is an important source of energy savings and probably short-term savings in the long term, I voted against this report. Because hell is paved with good intentions, but also with many of the proposed measures. "Smart boilers", for example, are reminiscent of the controversies generated by the meters of the same name, especially around health problems, privacy concerns, untimely power outages and without even the assurance of real savings. Germany has decided to do without it. It's a sign. Or the recommended renewal of equipment, which will inevitably have a significant cost for households. And there is also the encouragement, even the obligation of the external insulation of old buildings. This obligation already exists in French law, via a very controversial decree of application of the energy transition law. It risks the disappearance of many picturesque facades that are the charm and beauty of many towns and villages in France. No guarantee of efficiency. This juicy market could bring in 800 million euros to professionals. It's paying dearly for ugliness.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 The heating and cooling sectors consume half of the energy (especially fossil sources) in the Union and, a significant part of that energy is lost to lack of efficiency. There is then a significant room for improvement in the sector and, consequently, for decreased energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions. The report is in the right direction because it proposes to increase the share of renewable energy in this area, invest to improve energy efficiency by renovating buildings, accelerating the modernization of heating systems, decentralizing energy production systems, etc. If this package is in the right direction, it is too insufficient to drastically lower greenhouse gas emissions, deeply change the energy system, and meet climate targets. That's why I abstained.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy on heating and cooling.  The issue of heating and cooling affects member states to varying degrees. The hierarchies of importance of the different actions in these countries are therefore differentiated. The largest efficiency reserves for the new EU countries that joined the EU after 2004, including Polish, lie in the thermomodernisation of buildings as the easiest way to use energy efficiently and to severely reduce CO2 emissions. Significant increases require funding for thermomodernization works of entire settlements, especially those that were erected in the technology of a large plate. For this purpose, at least 25% of the total appropriations should be allocated from the European Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Fund. It is also necessary to replace outdated district heating plants with high-efficiency combined heat and power plants. A different problem, which is currently growing in the European Mediterranean countries, is cooling, which is linked to the gradual warming of the climate.  Architectural solutions such as thermal insulation and reverse heat pumps can play a major role in solving both problems, and intensive research is needed on new innovative solutions in this area.  In my opinion, the adoption of an EU strategy on heating and cooling is essential.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because the issue of heating and cooling is increasingly being raised by the EU Member States.  I support finding and using innovative and appropriate architectural solutions, such as thermal insulation of buildings. Cooling is an increasingly worrying problem directly linked to the gradual warming of the climate. Thus, I believe that, under the Energy Efficiency Directive, Member States should draw up state plans for the renovation of buildings with a view to their transformation into energy-efficient buildings, not least by providing incentives for the renovation of buildings owned by individuals, and that these plans should also include specific measures for the most vulnerable groups , to help combat energy poverty.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Heating and cooling accounts for roughly half of the EU's final energy demand – I voted in favour of this report which is looking for solutions to reduce demand and make the sector more efficient, in order to decrease dependence on energy imports, reduce emissions, and bring down costs to consumers, especially those at risk of energy poverty.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report. We need a real strategy for the heating and cooling sector. This sector accounts for almost half of Europe's energy consumption! It is therefore essential to take targeted measures for this sector and to strongly encourage improvements in energy efficiency through a better heating and cooling system. Under the Energy Efficiency Directive, Member States must immediately implement national plans for building renovation. Let's not waste time!

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. There needs to be a substantial increase in the funding for work on the thermal renovation of entire housing estates, especially those built using large-panel system building methods. At least 25% of the European Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Fund needs to be set aside for this purpose. This objective must be given high priority, particularly since on the whole the owners of the buildings concerned are unable to meet the costs involved and support from the state is insufficient.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the report there are many positive proposals regarding the promotion of renewable energy sources, the need to combat energy poverty and support vulnerable groups, to strengthen funding for renovations of settlements as well as for households located outside areas with central heating and cooling systems.  However, there is a problematic assessment that the key to combating energy poverty is to increase energy efficiency to reduce overall costs. This proposal seeks to disorient as it silences the main cause of energy poverty, which are the neoliberal policies of harsh austerity.  Despite this, we voted in favour of the report by submitting our disagreement to the above point.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this own initiative report on an EU Strategy on Heating and Cooling and was very happy that it got the majority support of the Parliament. The report sets out key proposals for the Commission to reduce the use of energy in buildings. For example, the report highlights the need for greater improvement in efficiency standards and renovation of old homes. It is striking that private and public buildings account for 40% of final energy use and 36% of CO2 emissions in the EU, with a huge 85% of the energy consumption of buildings used for space and water heating alone. I support the rapporteur in their call for further energy renovations which will lead not only to job creation and investment but it will also help to cut CO2 emissions in the EU. We must do much more to renovate existing housing stocks, which often have very low energy efficiency standards. If we are to achieve this, it is important the European Commission presents an ambitious review of energy efficiency legislation in the coming weeks and takes into consideration the proposals made in this report.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on an EU strategy for heating and cooling buildings in the residential and industrial sectors. This will improve the revised energy performance and efficiency of the buildings to be proposed in the autumn.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the REPORT on the EU Heating and Cooling Strategy, as I believe that genuine progress is needed in Member States in transforming heating and cooling, which are parts of the wider energy system.  Given that almost 50 % of final energy demand in the EU is used for heating and cooling, and these sectors vary greatly between Member States due to the different energy structure, climatic conditions, building efficiency levels and industry intensity, flexibility should be ensured in selecting appropriate strategic solutions to make these systems more efficient, sustainable and profitable.  The EU Heating and Cooling Strategy prioritises areas of action and aims to achieve an efficient sector that increases energy security and facilitates the cost-effective achievement of the EU's climate and energy objectives.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This text extends the Pieper report voted in Brussels in June on energy efficiency. Encouraging the development of renewable energies, with a target of 100% for heating and cooling by 2050, it is above all "energy efficiency" that it advocates, i.e. energy savings considered "first fuel" (considering A).  To do this, in addition to encouraging geothermal energy, the production of biomethane (explicitly in paragraphs 52 and 100) and more generally "priority use of local raw materials" (93), but also to emphasize the recovery of industrial heat, the report recommends above all "appropriate architectural solutions".  These recommendations are mixed with the very demagogic aspect of 'fighting energy poverty'.  Overly restrictive rules will pose a significant risk to our heritage (in the broadest sense), all the more so since the current trend in France is to give ever more decision-making power to local edifices, who generally do not have the necessary skills and who can hardly resist the various pressures (especially construction), to the detriment of the architects of the buildings of France. I voted against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this new strategy because cooling and heating represent the largest part of the demand for energy services in the EU and increasing efficiency in their use is essential to reduce the costs associated with them while reducing CO2 emissions and improving energy security. One of the key steps of this strategy is to financially encourage building owners to carry out a wide-scale heat renovation of buildings. This strategy is therefore not only favourable to these owners, but also to their tenants and, last but not least, to the environment.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Gierek report for an EU strategy on heating and cooling. The text calls for a more targeted strategy by encouraging local energy initiatives. My vote was encouraged by the local approach to the text, emphasizing energy efficiency and stressing the importance of research and innovation on European territory. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Heating and cooling consume half of the EU's energy and much of it is wasted. Although the heating and cooling sector is moving to clean low carbon energy, 75% of the fuel it uses still comes from fossil fuels, while overall renewable energy accounts for 18% of primary energy consumption in the heating and cooling sector and there is a significant potential to increase its share. In the new strategy, the Commission, and this report, aim to address five key areas: making it easier to renovate buildings; integrating electricity systems with heating and cooling systems; increasing the share of renewables used in heating and cooling; recovering wasted energy from industry; and getting consumers and industry involved in the process. EH Bildu does agree on those points, but regrets the role and according to the report potential given to Waste to Energy.  In EH Bildu we oppose the incineration of recyclable materials as it poses a risk to the environment and to human health, as dioxins, the highly toxic chemicals produced by waste incineration and industrial processes have shown to be lingering in the bodies of people all over the planet, and have been identified as the cause of many cancers.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the GIEREK report on a European Union strategy on heating and cooling, which calls for a more targeted strategy for this sector, which accounts for 50% of the EU's energy consumption, with renewable energy accounting for only 18% of this consumption, compared with 75% for fossil fuels. This is one of the energy union's priorities.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Gierek's report. The issue of heating and cooling is more topical in some Member States than in others. This also means that there are differences in the order of priority that exists in terms of the action to be taken in these countries. Emphasis should also be placed on the greater opportunities to increase the efficiency to be found in the new countries that joined the EU after 2004 in the thermal renovation of buildings. It is the simplest way to ensure that energy is used more efficiently and to achieve a significant reduction in CO2 emissions. Also, solar radiation is an important source of heat that has not yet been sufficiently exploited. It can be exploited by using panels that heat water or generate electricity and my country Greece has comparatively much more potential for the development of solar energy.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report contains some very innovative ideas to make energy consumption for heating and cooling more sustainable. But in some respects it overshoots the mark, which runs the risk of being regulated into citizens' heating and cooling habits. These include forced measures for buildings in rural areas, the abolition of certain categories of furnaces or the requirement for comprehensive district heating. I am therefore abstaining on this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which is looking for solutions to reduce demand and make the sector more efficient, in order to decrease dependence on energy imports, reduce emissions, and bring down costs to consumers, especially those at risk of energy poverty.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 13 September 2016, we voted in plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on a report on the EU heating and cooling strategy. I was shadow rapporteur on the ENVI sub-report on this document, for which the ITRE Committee was primarily responsible. That's why I watched the next fate of the documentary very closely. The issue of heating is a key factor in ensuring air purity, especially in the region where I come from.  Heating and cooling consume half of the EU's total energy generated, and much of it is wasted. Of the new strategy presented by the Commission, the most important and crucial areas for me are the areas on which the EU intends to focus in the coming years: facilitating the renovation and renovation of buildings; integration of electrical systems with heating and cooling systems into a single functional unit and increased use of waste heat and cold produced by industry. However, what I consider to be the biggest positive of this report is that the rapporteur also understood the local nature and potential of heating and cooling and stated directly in the report that more decentralised and flexible energy systems with energy and heat sources located closer together and to the place of consumption can facilitate and streamline overall energy production. For these reasons, I was happy to support the report.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU's Heating and Cooling Strategy and share the thesis of the need for a significant increase in funding for thermal renovation activities for entire residential complexes, especially those built using large-panel systems as construction methods. More funds from the European Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Fund need to be earmarked for this purpose. It must become a priority, especially in view of the fact that, in general, the owners of the buildings concerned cannot bear the associated costs and support from the national state is insufficient. Emphasis should also be placed on the fact that the greatest opportunities for efficiency gains in the new countries that joined the EU after 2004 offer precisely the thermal renovation of buildings. This is a good way to ensure that energy is used more efficiently and to achieve a significant reduction in CO2 emissions. Outdated thermal power plants in residential complexes need to be replaced with small, highly efficient heat and power plants.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Among the European Union's priorities, the Commission has designed the first strategy that aims to support the correct and moderate use of energy and fossil fuel in a specific sector, such as heating and cooling. It is the most common use of energy consumption, accounting for 50 %, of which only 18 % are renewable and 75 % coal. This strategy, therefore, aims to optimise energy efficiency, increase the use of renewable energy, and encourage the reuse of energy waste from heating and cooling in industries. On a practical level, Member States are being asked to eliminate all obsolete heating systems and to promote a phase of disposal of inefficient wood-burning fireplaces. Finally, the importance of research and technological innovation and access to investment funds for the modernisation of the heating and cooling sector are stressed.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because France does not need the EU's recommendations to define its energy policy.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the EU's heating and cooling strategy. Despite some good measures proposed, France does not need the recommendations of the European Union to define its energy policy, in this case in terms of heating and cooling. The problems of Central Europe, with often dilapidated and/or highly polluting facilities (particularly in Poland, the rapporteur's country), are not the same as those facing us, and the interpretation of the text may well be against our interests (by imposing heavy constraints on individuals... and accelerating the disfigurement or outright destruction of our heritage).

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. Encouraging the development of renewable energy is the "energy efficiency" that the report advocates. Moreover, these constant calls for energy efficiency can be seen as a form of 'energy austerity'. Moreover, it is feared that this text will serve certain interests of the construction industry, to the detriment of our heritage. This risk to our heritage (in the broadest sense) is all the greater since the current trend in France is to give more and more decision-making power to local executives, who generally do not have the necessary skills and who can hardly resist the various pressures (especially construction), to the detriment of the architects of the buildings of France. In general, despite some good measures proposed, France does not need the EU's recommendations to define its energy policy, in this case in terms of heating and cooling. The problem of Central Europe is also not the same as in Western Europe and the interpretation of the text can come at the expense of the interests of the French. For all of these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because a Union strategy in the field of heating and cooling is needed. It is important to improve efficiency in this area, in order to reduce energy dependence, emissions and costs for consumers, especially those at risk of energy poverty. It is about ensuring that energy is used more efficiently and achieving significant reductions in CO2 emissions. While there are differences in the order of priorities that Member States have in terms of the actions to be taken in this area.  Measures to be taken include that substantial increase in funding is needed for thermal renovation works in complete developments. At least 25% of the European fund for energy efficiency and renewable energy must be reserved for this purpose. It is also necessary to replace the obsolete thermoelectric plants of the developments, with efficient combined cogeneration plants of heat and electricity. On the other hand, in the Mediterranean countries, refrigeration is a concern. Proper architectural solutions, insulation and reversible heat pumps can play an important role in solving this problem.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, because the development of a European strategy in this area is a necessary tool for emission reduction. The warming and cooling sector, one of the main carbon emitters in the Union, to propose a strategy at European level is a first step in correcting the problems of allocating resources through market mechanisms. The report includes explicit support for the use of renewable energy in this sector, as well as improved energy efficiency of buildings, collective heating mechanisms, etc. The text supports the development of more sustainable technologies and the reduction of emissions in this sector. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This report emphasizes ensuring that energy is used more efficiently and achieving significant reductions in CO2 emissions. This requires a substantial increase in funding for thermal renewal works and to replace obsolete thermoelectric plants in developments as soon as possible with efficient combined heat and electricity cogeneration plants. Cooling is a cause for concern and is linked to gradual climate warming. That is why the architectural solutions, insulation and reversible heat pumps proposed by this report can play an important role in solving this problem. With this in mind, I believe that further research is vital in order to develop new and innovative solutions. For all of the above, I give my positive vote for the adoption of this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Heating and cooling represents 50% of the EU’s energy consumption. I support this report that aims to include more renewable energy sources and to encourage reuse of waste heat.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The report contains nonsensical proclamations, such as, "that a systemic approach to cooling is necessary, both in terms of buildings and the transport of chilled goods." Let everyone handle the cooling in their refrigerated cars and at home according to their own. The report also calls for the introduction of new subsidies to support renewables, which I do not agree with.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This strategy provides a framework for integrating efficient heating and cooling into EU energy policies. I support the opinion that we have to ensure that a share of energy efficiency funding has to be dedicated to improvements for energy-poor households, to work with stakeholders, to raise consumer awareness of household energy efficiency aspects and to stimulate the take-up of the recommendations of company energy audits.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The Union's 2050 energy and climate target is to use 100% renewable energy. At the same time, up to 50% of the EU's current final energy consumption is used for heating and cooling, 80% of which is used in buildings. The Union's objectives can therefore only be achieved if we reduce energy consumption and consistently apply the principle of energy efficiency. My work experience confirms to me that the best way to reduce energy intensity in this area is by warming buildings. It is therefore necessary to increase the amount of funding for the warming of residential buildings and complexes, but also for the use of innovative ways of obtaining the necessary energy.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Referring to the reasons I pointed out in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 12/9/2016 I abstained when voting on the report on an EU strategy on heating and cooling.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the report on an EU strategy for heating and cooling, in which I reiterated the importance of developing EU systems that provide incentives for the energy-efficient rehabilitation of public buildings, personal housing and social housing, as well as for the construction of green buildings. In the same report, we stressed the need to use the Structural Funds to modernise the construction system, in particular in the form of preferential loans, which would facilitate a much-needed modernisation of existing buildings, especially in the less developed parts of the EU. The amount of heat produced from industrial and commercial processes lost in air or water could fully cover the heat requirement in European residential buildings. The EU must find a technological solution and a viable legal framework to recover this energy loss. Member States need to speed up the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive, with boosting energy efficiency in buildings being a key point that would help improve households affected by energy poverty. State plans for the renovation of buildings should provide for relief measures for people living in the most deprived areas and for vulnerable groups facing energy poverty.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution. This text extends the Pieper report voted in Brussels in June on energy efficiency. The stated goal is to achieve 100% renewable energy. Despite this seemingly laudable objective, there are fears of a form of energy austerity imposed on the peoples of Europe. In addition, this text poses a significant risk to our heritage, advocating an improvement in their energy performance at the expense of preserving their heritage value.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Heating and cooling is a big problem. Many buildings in the EU as well as in the Czech Republic are obsolete and heat escapes from them during heating. This is a waste of energy, while many EU citizens are facing energy poverty. In the report, we call on the Commission to put forward a strategy to combat energy waste. It is necessary to invest in research and development of new more savings heating techniques in order to avoid unnecessary losses, which could ultimately lead to lower prices for the end consumer. I supported the report in the vote.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I think it is very important that this report talks about reducing, although gradual but significant, the use of fossil fuels, because I believe that we should move towards a smarter and more sustainable use of resources, namely the increased use of renewable energy. However, this report refers to the production of energy from waste (incinerators) with which I do not agree, which is why I abstained.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The Union Strategy on Heating and Cooling is an important step towards a holistic approach to the transformation of heating and cooling in the Union and the identification of priority areas of action. That is why in this Parliament we have approved the proposal which fully supports the Commission's intention to recognise and take advantage of synergies between the heating and electricity sectors, with a view to achieving an efficient sector that increases energy security and facilitates the achievement of the Union's climate and energy objectives in a cost-effective manner. In addition, we call on the Commission to consider the heating and cooling sectors as part of the configuration of the European energy market.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue of heating and cooling is more topical in some Member States than in others. Especially in the Mediterranean countries, cooling is an issue that should worry us since it is directly linked to the gradual climate warming. Solutions such as proper building architecture and insulation and reversible heat pumps could play an important role in solving the problem. I am voting in favour of the EU strategy on heating and cooling because it is an integral part of the Energy Union strategy and to achieve the EU's energy and climate targets by 2020, 2030 and 2050. It should also be stressed that the amount of heat generated by the various industries is sufficient to cover all the heating needs of residential buildings. Furthermore, I support the EU's strategy on heating and cooling as it provides significant opportunities for EU businesses and consumers if properly implemented. Consumers should be at the heart of this strategy through the use of modern technologies and innovative solutions.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This report has positive approaches as it correctly diagnoses the lack of energy efficiency. However, this problem cannot be solved by regulating heating habits. So I am abstaining from voting.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the report drawn up by the EP, as it proposes a significant increase in funding for the renovation of entire settlements, especially those built using large-scale structures. This is to call for at least 25% of the European Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Fund to be allocated. This objective must be considered an important priority, since the owners of such buildings cannot cover the costs involved and the state support is not sufficient. I also agree with the report's point that outdated boiler houses operating in settlements must be replaced as soon as possible by small but highly efficient cogeneration plants.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Gas remains the main source of energy for heating and cooling homes, public and industrial buildings. While this report is committed to promoting renewable energy, it first points out that 75% of the existing housing stock is energy inefficient. And it is rural homes or modest households that are first affected by huge bills. As a result, the report calls on the Commission to plan aid to the most vulnerable consumers on EU funds and to phase out fossil fuel subsidies. It underlines the potential of the rehabilitation of these dwellings in terms of creating local jobs that can not be relocated in the insulation and building sector. It pushes for the development and research (without reference to the private sector) of clean alternative methods, such as geothermal energy. But, despite an interesting analysis that should logically enable general and effective strategic planning, it remains in the logic of a new market for energy efficiency products and services, or the support of the EU's emissions quota system. Again and again the metaphysics of the market. I am therefore obliged to abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Encouraging the development of renewable energy is the "energy efficiency" that the report advocates. Moreover, these constant calls for energy efficiency can be seen as a form of 'energy austerity'. Moreover, it is feared that this text will serve certain interests of construction at the expense of our heritage. This risk to our heritage (in the broadest sense) is all the greater since the current trend in France is to give more and more decision-making power to local executives, who generally do not have the necessary skills and who can hardly resist the various pressures (especially construction), to the detriment of the architects of the buildings of France. In general, despite some good measures proposed, France does not need the EU's recommendations to define its energy policy, in this case in terms of heating and cooling. The problem of Central Europe is also not the same as in Western Europe and the interpretation of the text can come at the expense of the interests of the French. It is for all of these reasons that I voted against this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. Additional efforts are needed to reduce the heating needs of buildings and to replace the remaining needs of imported fossil fuels used in individual boilers with sustainable heating and cooling options, in line with the Union's 2050 objectives. Buildings account for a huge percentage of total final energy consumption, and increased energy efficiency of buildings and demand response programmes can play a central role in balancing energy demand and coverage of needs in peak demand periods, enabling reduced overcapacity and reduced production costs , operation and transport. The strategy for heating and cooling should give priority to sustainable and cost-effective solutions that enable Member States to achieve the Union's climate and energy policy targets. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is essential that cooling is given the same level of importance as heating, especially as our summers are becoming warmer each year. The report also consistently highlights the need to tackle CO2 emissions and the importance of green technologies in the areas of heating and cooling, as they make up the major share of the Union’s energy demand.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – Half of the eu's final energy demand is still used for heating. 80% of this is intended for heating or cooling buildings. At the same time, our buildings emit 13% of all CO2 emissions in Europe. This is because the share of fossil fuels for cooling and heating of buildings is still 75%. These are disturbing figures. Such bad grades have an advantage. If we act now, we can achieve enormous results in the very short term in terms of reducing CO2 emissions. First, by urgently working on the renovation and insulation of old buildings. Isolating remains the fastest way to energy efficiency and – nicely – renovation and insulation projects give a boost to our economy and employment. In addition, the share of renewable and recovered energy needs to be increased. In the industry, too much heat is still lost in the atmosphere. This energy can be captured and used for the heating of homes. That is why I support the proposals to support local authorities and individuals through the existing structural and investment funds in the intelligent modernisation of the energy systems of public buildings, residential areas and private homes.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – Up to 50% of final energy consumption within the EU goes to heating and cooling, with up to 75% of the fuels used in the EU being of fossil origin and only 18% of primary energy supplies for heating and cooling coming from renewable sources. Tackling the increasing use of energy, especially fossil fuels, is also one of the objectives of the EU's Energy Union. The European Union's heating and cooling strategy aims to increase the energy efficiency of buildings by modernising their outdated heating systems, refurbishing and ensuring thermal innovation. Improving the links between electrical systems and remote central heating would help to make greater use of renewables. Emphasis is placed on sustainable heating and cooling. Other instruments include scientific research, technological innovation, the modernisation of European industry, as well as the need to set up an attractive financial system to support new technologies for household heating using renewable sources. I am voting in favour of the report in favour.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Heating and cooling accounts for roughly half of the EU’s final energy demand - which is why it is so important to reduce demand and make the sector more efficient, in order to reduce dependence on energy imports, reduce emissions, and bring down costs to consumers, especially those at risk of energy poverty. That is why I have voted in favour of the report.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the Commission’s strategy and fully support Parliament’s report on the EU strategy on heating and cooling that seeks to improve our citizens’ comfort and progressively decrease their energy bill. The Parliament sent through this report a strong political signal to the Commission to accelerate investments in the right direction and equally challenge the industry to find innovative retrofitting technologies.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 16 February this year, the Commission published a Communication entitled 'The European Union's Thermal Strategy'. The draft resolution of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy focuses essentially on three issues. It notes that in the countries that joined the EU after 2004, thermal renovation of buildings is the easiest way to ensure that energy is used more efficiently and that CO2 emissions are significantly reduced. To this end, it also calls for financial action. It points out that cooling is the biggest problem in europe's Mediterranean countries due to gradual warming, which can be solved by proper architectural solutions, insulation and reversible heat pumps that extract heat in the heat but allow heat in the cold. Finally, it will look out for the sunshine, which is a significant source of heat, but which has yet to be sufficiently exploited, with the help of elements that heat water or generate electricity. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This text extends the Pieper report voted in Brussels in June on energy efficiency. It encourages the development of renewable energy, with a 100% target for heating and cooling by 2050. It is feared that this text will serve certain interests of construction at the expense of our heritage. Energy efficiency must not be the eternal alibi of the construction lobby to destroy our living environment, especially the old, rural and historic building, too often neglected in favor of the turnover of the major building signs.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The growing dependence in recent years on oil and gas imports, lack of diversification, high energy prices, increased energy demand, security risks for producing countries, the fight against climate change, the slow energy efficiency process and renewable energy quotas have become major challenges in Europe's energy field. On 15 July 2015, the European Commission published a series of documents alusing the European internal market, with three policy objectives for the future electricity market: creating an EU-wide electricity market, creating a European approach to energy security and strengthening regional cooperation in the energy sector. I support the rapporteur's position that better integration and coordination of energy markets brings up multiple opportunities to achieve the common European objectives of a secure, sustainable and affordable energy supply. I highlight the importance of this EU-wide approach, as acceptable energy prices and security of supply are essential for the standard of living of households as well as for job security in businesses.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This text on the EU's heating and cooling strategy is an extension of the Pieper report voted in Brussels in June on energy efficiency. It encourages the development of renewable energies to achieve energy savings (geothermal, biomethane, priority use of local raw materials, etc.). However, this report could, if interpreted extensively, pose a threat to our rural heritage. I have therefore decided to abstain in the vote on this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Heating and cooling accounts for roughly half of the EU’s final energy demand – I voted in favour of this report which is looking for solutions to reduce demand and make the sector more efficient, in order to decrease dependence on energy imports, reduce emissions, and bring down costs to consumers, especially those at risk of energy poverty.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This report relates to the implementation of a European heating and cooling strategy. This sector, which accounts for half of Europe's energy consumption, needs special attention. That is the purpose of this text. So I voted for it.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the EU's heating and cooling strategy. This is an invitation to Member States to modernise their heating systems. Research and technological innovation can bring a lot to this area and investments in modernizing heating and cooling facilities must be encouraged.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU's heating and cooling strategy, which is a very important issue for ensuring more efficient use of energy and a significant reduction in CO2 emissions. I believe it is necessary to significantly increase the financial resources allocated to the thermal redevelopment of entire blocks, in particular those built using prefabricated panel technology. To this end, a budget of at least 25 % of the total should be allocated from the European Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Fund. We also need to address the specific problems faced by buildings in rural areas, which tend to be older, less energy efficient, less healthy and less thermally comfortable.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The importance of heating and cooling differs between Member States. For Member States that joined the Union after 2004, the easiest way to use energy effectively to reduce CO2 emissions lies in the thermal renovation of buildings. New, innovative solutions are needed, mainly using solar energy. Its potential and this alternative path should be exploited in the future. I voted in favour of this report because the report looks to the future and we need the solutions it offers, both in terms of the environment and in terms of health.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A number of differences have been identified in the order of priority regarding of actions to be undertaken as part of the EU strategy on heating and cooling, taking into consideration that heating and cooling is more pertinent in some Member States than in others. I have voted for this report that will ensure that energy is used more efficiently thus achieving CO2 emissions reductions.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for Parliament's resolution on the EU strategy for heating and cooling because the establishment of appropriate policies in the planning and implementation of heating and cooling infrastructure will have a direct impact on the energy system, energy efficiency and the economy in general. Industry needs clear signals to make the necessary investments in achieving the EU's energy objectives. I stress the need for ambitious and binding targets and a regulatory framework that stimulates innovation, without creating unnecessary administrative burdens, with a view to optimally promoting cost-effective and environmentally sustainable heating and cooling solutions.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ My endorsement for this report stems from its commitment to meet the goal of the EU’s greenhouse gas emission reduction under the climate agreement reached at the COP21 climate conference in Paris. The report outlines the strategy to reduce the EU’s energy dependency on fossil fuel imports by integrating heating and cooling into the electricity system. The report emphasises that half of the EU’s heating and cooling usage stems from residential buildings, and thus provides a practical framework to decarbonise the energy sector by helping households access finances to invest in renewable and energy efficient technology. I am also in support of this report because of its focus on consumers as the centre of its strategy and its goal to create an energy efficient market.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on a heating and cooling strategy that, through sustainable and cost-effective solutions, will enable Member States to achieve the EU's climate and energy policy objectives. Effectively achievable energy savings are an essential way to achieve climate goals. Given that the heating and cooling sectors in the Member States are very diverse due to their different energy mixes, climatic conditions, energy efficiency levels of buildings and industrial intensity, flexibility should be ensured in selecting appropriate solutions according to the strategy set out. The main focus should be on the security of energy supply issues to the EU related to the security of heat supply. In this respect, the Commission should therefore examine ways to further promote the diversification of heating sources and accelerate the wider use of renewable heat sources technologies.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this own initiative report which makes proposals to direct the implementation of the Commission’s strategy on the Energy Union launched in February this year. Part of the Commission’s proposal was its first ever strategy for heating and cooling to tackle the massive use of fossil fuels. This is a progressive report that  emphasises the need to include specific measures for heating and cooling in the upcoming revisions of the Energy Efficiency Directive, the RES Directive and the Energy Performance of Building Directive, and the new ‘energy market design’. It suggests that high-energy efficiency measures, high-performance insulation, the use of renewable sources and recovered heat are the fundamental priorities for EU’s heating and cooling strategy.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This report has positive approaches as it correctly diagnoses the lack of energy efficiency. However, this problem cannot be solved by regulating heating habits. That is why I am abstaining from voting on this report.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Energy Union Strategy promises to supply all Europeans with safe, sustainable and competitive energy which requires a substantial change in our energy landscape. Among the package of measures to achieve this is the EU's strategy on heating and cooling. Heating and cooling of buildings and industry consume half of the EU's energy. This means not only more energy consumption than is needed, but also an economic burden for many families in Europe. The proposed heating and cooling strategy focuses on removing obstacles to decarbonisation of buildings and industry. Also, increasing energy efficiency and using renewable energy sources will have an impact on security of energy supply.  I voted in favour of the report which calls for ambitious reforms in the energy sector to make it more efficient, environmentally responsible and socially oriented. There is an urgent need to take measures to reduce CO2 emissions and avoid a dangerous global warming. That is why the EU must set a binding target of reducing energy consumption by 40% by 2030.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the strategy does not announce any new legislative proposals, we oppose the EU strategy on heating and cooling as it will be used to reinforce the disruptive EU energy and climate policy that has already brought irreparable damage to Europe’s industry and economy.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Heating and cooling account for 40 % of all primary energy and 50 % of all energy that can be used in the form of heat, and much of this is lost. However, the heating and cooling system and the electricity system can support each other in their efforts to reduce carbon emissions. In February, the Commission proposed an 'EU heating and cooling strategy' with the aim of proposing actions to eliminate the energy dispersion of buildings, maximising the efficiency and sustainability of heating and cooling systems, also thanks to the use of advanced technologies. The own-initiative report on heating and cooling contains a number of important points that I fully support, such as the decommissioning of obsolete power stations, the replacement of more polluting domestic installations, an increase in the rate of building renewal, especially in view of the targets for having 0-emission buildings for 2050, etc. However, the report retains some ambiguous elements in relation to district heating, geothermal energy, and the committee's strategy on energy production, which seems to support the use of incinerators. For the reasons given above, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I accept the proposal for an EU heating and cooling strategy and support any form of energy efficiency and sustainability. Due to the climate change affecting us recently, it is important that we make each activity "green" as soon as possible and try to come up with the best possible solutions for a sustainable environment. I am committed to using renewable energy sources as much as possible in order to contribute to a better state of nature and the environment.  More investment is needed to explore advanced heating and cooling systems as well as eliminate all inefficient and environmentally harmful heating and cooling modes. Larger campaigns and examples are needed in the practice of sustainable energy systems, bringing the advantage of such a system closer to consumers. Energy renovation of all buildings that do not have an efficient energy system is needed.  Buildings of particular importance, i.e. old buildings that are under a certain type of architectural protection, should also be renovated taking into account energy efficiency without impairing the original appearance of the building. I hope that EU citizens and all authorities will see the need for the best possible energy solutions to ensure a sustainable environment for future generations.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite some positive measures, this text has some prohibitive flaws. It treats all the countries of the European Union in the same way, while the state of the facilities has nothing to do with the countries of Western Europe and those of Eastern Europe. There is a very high risk that the text will be interpreted in an exaggerated way in France, imposing very heavy constraints and directly threatening the survival of our precious architectural heritage. I therefore vote against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Almost 50 % of final energy demand in the EU is used for heating and cooling, of which 80 % are in buildings; whereas the 2015 Paris Agreement on Climate Change (COP21) should be reflected in the heating and cooling sector. The heating and cooling sector, in order to comply with the EU's energy and climate objectives, needs to be based on 100 per cent renewable energy sources at the latest by 2050, which can only be achieved by reducing energy consumption and making full use of the 'energy efficiency first' and 'energy efficiency as a first choice fuel'.  Each 1% increase in energy savings reduces gas imports by 2.6%. As the market in the HEATING and cooling sector in the EU is fragmented due to its local nature and the different technologies and economic actors involved in the process, and that the local and regional dimensions are essential for the introduction of appropriate policies in the heating and cooling sector for the planning and implementation of heating and cooling infrastructure and for consultation with consumers in order to remove barriers , and have made heating and cooling systems more efficient and sustainable, I support the rapporteur's position and the adoption of this report.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Energy efficiency is a topic that I have been dealing with for a long time, I have tabled a number of my amendments to this report and supported the final text in plenary. Almost 50% of the eu's final energy demand is used for heating and cooling purposes, of which 80% is used in buildings. Moreover, taking into account that any further 1% increase in energy savings reduces gas imports by 2.6%, it is natural that this is intended to encourage Member States to develop long-term heating and cooling strategies based on an integrated approach, harmonised mapping and evaluation in accordance with Article 14 of the Energy Efficiency Directive. It is important to remember that, although, on the one hand, a large proportion of current buildings in Europe suffer from energy waste due to poor quality of their insulation and outdated and inefficient heating systems, on the other hand, energy poverty affects almost 11% of the EU population. As the best solution to this problem, I see investment in thermal renovation of buildings, which is the way to use energy most effectively and reduce CO2 emissions. In addition, obsolete heating plants on the subdimities should be replaced as soon as possible by small, high-performance cogeneration plants.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The problem of heating and cooling affects the various Member States differently. I agree with the rapporteur on the need to significantly increase the financial resources allocated to the thermal redevelopment of entire blocks, in particular those built using prefabricated panel technology. To this end, a budget of at least 25 % of the total should be allocated from the European Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Fund. In addition, I think it is essential to replace the old thermal power stations with small cogeneration and high-performance thermal power stations. The draft report stresses the importance of the energy district network, underlines the local character and the potential for heating and cooling, calls on the Member States to phase out the use of obsolete heating systems in urban areas and, where possible, to facilitate the disposal of inefficient wood-burning fireplaces in cities. I voted in favour of adopting this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In February 2016 The Commission presented an EU strategy on heating and cooling. This is the first step in analysing the problems and challenges in this sector and solving them through EU energy policy. In view of the heating and cooling strategy on 9 September 2015, The Commission organised an ad hoc consultation forum meeting. Overall, 84% of the energy used for heating and cooling still comes from fossil fuels and only 16% from renewable sources. In order to meet the EU's climate and energy targets, the heating and cooling sector must drastically reduce energy consumption and the use of fossil fuels. The main focus is on decarbonising heating and cooling, renovating existing buildings, combining electricity systems with heating and cooling systems, increasing the share of renewable energy in heating and cooling, recovering waste energy from industry. It is also important to involve consumers and industry in this process. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. As part of the Energy Union, the European Commission has launched a strategy to combat massive energy consumption. I voted in favour of this report which calls on Member States to gradually reduce the use of obsolete heating systems in urban areas in particular. Research and innovation must lead to the renovation of energy networks and the modernization of heating and cooling systems must be a priority.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. In the European Union today, half of the final energy demand is aimed at sustaining the needs of Europe's largest energy sector: the heating and cooling sector. However, only 18% of the energy that sustains this sector comes from renewable energy sources, with the remainder being supplied by means of fossil fuels.  The vast majority of energy in this sector, more precisely 80%, is used in buildings, thus making it important to increase energy efficiency in household consumption, the reuse of wasted energy, high-performance thermal insulation and the use of renewable energies. The diversity of member states' energy needs underlies the idea of technological neutrality, ensuring flexibility in choosing the appropriate solutions for each user. This report also stresses the importance of ensuring funding for the modernisation of the sector, as well as promoting ways of achieving the best cost-benefit in the energy transition. Considering the objectives outlined by the Paris Agreement, the road to energy independence through fossil energy sources is long and therefore the heating and cooling sector needs sustained and appropriate action as this report underlines. So my vote is in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the strategy does not announce any new legislative proposals, we oppose the EU strategy on heating and cooling as it will be used to reinforce the disruptive EU energy and climate policy that has already brought irreparable damage to Europe’s industry and economy.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that any change benefiting the environment is an asset for the EU. Thus, it is necessary to take into account new technologies and techniques that may result in greater energy efficiency, such as the thermal renovation of buildings or the use of solar panels for water heating or electricity generation that is still infrequent. In Mediterranean European countries, refrigeration is a growing concern due to the gradual warming of the climate. Proper architectural solutions, thermal insulation and reversible heat pumps, which remove heat from buildings during the hottest periods and pump heat inwards when heating is needed, can play a major role in solving this problem.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr President, the issue of heating and cooling does not affect all Member States in the same way. For this reason, the order of priority of the measures taken will have to vary from country to country, as well as the implementation deadlines. We all believe that it is in the thermal renovation of buildings that the greatest gains in energy efficiency can be made, which is the simplest way to ensure more efficient use of energy and a considerable reduction in CO2 emissions. It is essential to increase the financing of thermal renovation works in residential areas.  In Mediterranean European countries, such as mine, Portugal, this is a growing concern. Proper architectural solutions, thermal insulation and reversible heat pumps, which remove heat from buildings during the hottest periods and pump heat inwards when heating is needed, can play a major role in solving this problem.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Heating and cooling account for approximately half of the Union's final energy demand. Hence the importance of improving energy efficiency in this area, in order to reduce dependence, emissions and costs for consumers, especially those at risk of energy poverty. It is about ensuring that energy is used more efficiently and reducing CO2 emissions.  Among the measures to be taken, there is a need for a substantial increase in funding for thermal renovation works in complete developments. It is also necessary to replace the obsolete thermoelectric plants of the developments, with efficient combined cogeneration plants of heat and electricity. On the other hand, in the Mediterranean countries, refrigeration is a concern. Proper architectural solutions, insulation and reversible heat pumps can play an important role in solving this problem. In addition, solar radiation is an important source of heat that has not yet been used enough.  This is fueled by some of the forthcoming energy efficiency legislative initiatives planned for the end of 2016, in particular the revised Energy Efficiency in Buildings Directive. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Like most members of this House, I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the European Union's strategy on heating and cooling. In particular, this strategy should help to reduce the energy poverty that still affects many European citizens today. Among the avenues supported is the European Parliament's desire to see renewable energy more integrated into neighbourhood networks. I welcome Commissioner Canete's statement promising an initiative for access to funding. Case to follow.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report. It has very good ideas - such as the emphasis on the need for energy efficiency, the promotion of renovation of buildings, the call to address the specific problems of rural buildings, which are often older, less energy efficient, less beneficial to health and less thermal comfort. However, at the time of the report, it was decided not to include important green proposals- the text deals very sleekly with the development and integration of renewable electricity sources into the common framework. Proposals for stricter regulation of the translation of garbage for energy, and for more efficient decentralised production of energy were also rejected.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report follows the Commission Communication "EU Strategy for Heating and Cooling", which represents - as highlighted in the report - an important step towards developing a comprehensive approach to heating and cooling in the European Union (EU) and to identify priority policy areas in these areas. In fact, 50% of the final energy demand in the EU is for heating and cooling, representing fossil fuel generation 75% of this figure. The report highlights the importance of implementing the plan to improve the energy efficiency of buildings, especially in the thermal renovation of existing buildings and in the construction of small, more efficient heat and electricity cogeneration plants that should replace obsolete power plants. I also consider it important to focus on refrigeration, due to global warming, a problem felt mainly in Southern Europe, so I agree with stressing the importance of appropriate architectural solutions, thermal insulation and the use of reversible heat pumps. The rapporteur also stresses the benefits of research and innovation in European industry, underlining the importance of ensuring access to finance. Because I agree with the content of the report, I voted in favour of it.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 Combining renewable energies and energy markets with heating and cooling policies is a top priority in preventing global warming. The proposal also leaves room for member states' own regulation. This will also make the transition towards a more sustainable heating and cooling strategy more effective, taking into account the specific circumstances of the Member States. It is precisely national and regional specificities that will be very important for the success of this plan. Geothermal heat should also be better taken into account in the strategy, as it is a cost-effective and environmentally friendly heating and cooling solution.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for a more targeted strategy on heating and cooling, which accounts for almost half of Europe's energy consumption. The report highlights the need to take specific measures for heating and cooling when revising the energy efficiency, renewable energy and energy performance guidelines. Long-term strategies for this sector need to be defined and implemented, with a particular focus on renewable energy. I supported this report because it identifies certain priorities such as modernizing outdated and inefficient heating systems, accelerating the gradual removal of outdated heating systems or renovating buildings. An attractive financing system must promote new technologies for heating European citizens using renewable energy sources.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 The heating and cooling sectors consume half of the energy (especially fossil sources) in the Union and, a significant part of that energy is lost to lack of efficiency. There is then a significant room for improvement in the sector and, consequently, for decreased energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions. The report is in the right direction because it proposes to increase the share of renewable energy in this area, invest to improve energy efficiency by renovating buildings, accelerating the modernization of heating systems, decentralizing energy production systems, etc. If this package is in the right direction, it is too insufficient to drastically lower greenhouse gas emissions, deeply change the energy system, and meet climate targets. That's why I abstained.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report on the EU Strategy on Heating and Cooling. Heating and cooling account for a significant proportion of household energy bills and approximately half of the EU’s final energy demand. The modernisation of infrastructure and appliances could significantly increase energy efficiency, reducing pollution and energy dependence. It is critical that cost savings are passed on to the final consumer, especially those who are already in energy poverty and those at risk.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the EU strategy for heating and cooling proposed by the Commission, as reducing high energy consumption is a priority of the Energy Union. The strategy includes plans to increase the energy efficiency of buildings and improve the links between electricity systems and district heating networks, which significantly increase the use of renewable energy sources and promote the re-use of waste heat and cooling produced in industry. Member States are also called upon to abolish outdated heating facilities in urban areas.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, because the development of a European strategy in this area is a necessary tool for emission reduction. The warming and cooling sector, one of the main carbon emitters in the Union, to propose a strategy at European level is a first step in correcting the problems of allocating resources through market mechanisms. The report includes explicit support for the use of renewable energy in this sector, as well as improved energy efficiency of buildings, collective heating mechanisms, etc. The text supports the development of more sustainable technologies and the reduction of emissions in this sector. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I believe it would be used as a way of bringing in new EU legislation.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which is looking for solutions to reduce demand and make the sector more efficient, in order to decrease dependence on energy imports, reduce emissions, and bring down costs to consumers, especially those at risk of energy poverty.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing \ u2012 Heating and cooling account for the largest share of EU energy demand. Waste energy will continue to play an important role in heating, as its alternative is often only landfills and the use of fossil fuels. Under the Waste Energy Programme, the Commission should develop a plan to promote and exploit the potential benefits of sustainable use of organic waste for heating and cooling connected to district heating and cooling systems. I voted in favour.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Europeans spend an average of 6% of their consumer expenditure on heating and cooling, 11% of which cannot afford to heat their homes sufficiently in winter.
