Unfortunately, consumer choice is constrained by a lack of information on actual energy consumption and costs, and often by a lack of funding for investments in the most efficient technologies. I supported the resolution because I consider the development of a strategy on heating and cooling to be a priority for the Energy Union, which can lead to energy savings and costs for both companies and citizens. I also consider it positive that this strategy builds on a solid basis of EU legislation and identifies areas where change or reform is needed in order to take account of future developments and achieve the objectives of the Energy Union. I appreciate that the 2014-2020 budget has significantly increased the contribution to this area; I therefore expect the proposed strategy to help reduce energy imports and energy dependency, reduce costs for households and businesses and meet the EU's greenhouse gas reduction target and the climate change commitment concluded at the COP21 climate change conference in Paris.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The report represents a good start to regulating this area, where, unfortunately, fossil fuels still dominate. Nevertheless, the language of the report remains rather loose and gives fossil fuels the possibility to remain the main source of heating and cooling for a long time to go.  In February 2016, the EU heating and cooling strategy was adopted for the first time, which aimed to reduce dependence on fossil fuels in this area and to move consumption within the agreed commitments of the recent Paris agreement, and to move to more efficient and sustainable resources, while reducing the EU's dependence on fuel imports.  The report also talks, inter alia, on the insulation of buildings, the exploitation of energy from waste materials and the potential for greater synergies between the electricity market and the heating and cooling market.  Despite the important theo and the problems that are open in this way, I believe that this is a missed opportunity, because Parliament should be much more ambitious with europe's huge potential for energy savings, the creation of new local jobs and the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.  For this reason, I abstained.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 Reducing costs and increasing efficiency is one of the basic prerequisites for the successful implementation of the Energy Union. It is important not only to reconstruct existing facilities and prevent heat losses, but also to support research and development of new technologies.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the motion for an EU Parliament resolution on an EU strategy on heating and cooling. The report says that the Commission should promote renewables. Markets should determine which energy types should be used rather than what bureaucrats find is currently fashionable. Furthermore, the report advises using the European Structural and Investment Fund in order to finance the modernisation of the heating and cooling sector. They cite its job creation potential and the inability of building owners to cover the necessary costs. With regards to job creation via stimulus, whether spent on energy efficiency or digging holes, it does not create jobs. Instead of individuals and companies deciding on how best to allocate their wealth such government stimulus programs make the decision for them. The funds should be returned to the Member States and the European Structural and Investment Fund should be scrapped.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒50% of the eu's final energy demand is used for heating and cooling. For the heating and cooling sector to be in line with the EU's energy and climate targets by 2050, it must be based on 100% renewables. A 1% increase in energy savings reduces gas imports by 2.6%.  The share of renewables in the heating and cooling sector is increasing, but there is huge potential at all levels to be used even more, especially in residential buildings whose sector is responsible for 13 % of all CO2 emissions in the Union. I support the Report on the European Union's Heating and Cooling Strategy, as I believe that the guidelines set out there are of high quality and will contribute to reducing emissions and saving energy. I also believe that the implementation of these guidelines will increase the share of renewables in the building sector, which will contribute to reducing overall CO2 emissions at EU level.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy on heating and cooling.  I agree with the report that the EU Strategy for Heating and Cooling is an important step towards ensuring an integrated approach to the transformation of heating and cooling in the European Union and to identify priority areas for action. In the EU, almost 50% of final energy consumption is heating and cooling, of which 80% is heating and cooling of buildings. The strategy should prioritise sustainable and cost-effective solutions that enable Member States to achieve their climate and energy policy objectives. The heating and cooling sectors in the Member States are very diverse.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report as it contains many positive proposals on the promotion of renewable energy sources, the need to combat energy poverty and support vulnerable groups, to strengthen funding for renovations of settlements as well as for households outside areas with central heating and cooling systems. However, we separate our position from the misestimation recorded that supposedly the key to combating energy poverty is to increase energy efficiency to reduce overall costs. Unfortunately, this position seeks to disorient as it silences the main cause of energy poverty, which are the neoliberal policies of harsh austerity.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The interconnection of energy production and distribution sectors and the development and adoption of innovative technologies should not be financed by overtaxation measures for Union citizens. They can be financed by taxation of large energy production and distribution companies, especially those that do not invest in renewable and environmentally friendly sources.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Different priorities have been established in the Member States with regard to the carrying force of the heating and cooling issue and the steps to be taken. Overall, however, around 50% of the EU's final energy demand is used for heating and cooling. I therefore agree that the countries that joined the EU after 2004 have the greatest potential for improving efficiency in the thermal renovation of buildings. This is the simplest way to ensure that energy is used more efficiently and that CO2 emissions are significantly reduced. I consider it an important proportion that 1% energy savings will reduce natural gas imports by 2.6%, and I hope that, in addition to energy efficiency, the fossil rate will also be drastically reduced. I also agree with the need to significantly increase the funds for the thermal renovation of entire housing estates, in particular buildings built with panel technology. In taxed Hungary, for example, residents have livelihood problems, but modernisation is a umist issue for them. I consider the system of reversible heat pumps to be good, especially energy efficient and have huge potential for heating and cooling. I share the view that the heating and cooling sector should reflect the 2015 Paris Agreement on climate change (COP21), and I can only hope that the heating and cooling sector, compatible with the Union's energy and climate goals, will be based on 100% renewable energy sources by 2050 at the latest. Against this background, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Heating and cooling is for the processing of approximately 40% of total primary energy at approximately 50% of total usable energy in the form of heat energy. While electricity generation can be harmonised in the single energy market, heating and cooling require local solutions. However, the dependence of heating and cooling on the energy market is increasing, which, for example, on a local scale, uses cogeneration for both electricity and heat (cold) production. The diversity of the need to ensure thermal comfort for Union citizens is demonstrated by the fact that the annual energy consumption span per square metre of heated area varies from 60 to even 300 kWh in the Member States. The EP's report focuses on a number of important issues, including the pursuit of the decommissioning of outdated, small, non-organic district heating plants and the transition to heat from high-performance cogeneration systems. The need to take into account the differences between the West and the East of the EU in the use of more efficient gas for heating purposes has rightly been emphasised. In the coming years, Member States and the EU should focus decisively on architectural and urban cooling and heating activities, as well as on the use of natural heat and cooling sources and on intensifying the development of innovative research and the creation of new thermal insulation materials for the entire industry.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 Finland is the leading country in the use of district heating and cooling and combined heat and power production. I voted in favour of the EU strategy because it will help to promote combined heat and power production and the use of biomass in Europe. However, I did not support Article 23 because I think it says the wrong thing about rural buildings, which in Finland, for example, are often very energy efficient.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. In the field of heating and cooling, the European strategy should move towards an increase in the share of renewable energy, while to date 75 % of the fuels used in this sector are still of fossil origin. Currently, existing technology would allow for a smarter and more sustainable use of resources, contributing to a transition to the green economy. The improvement could come with new investment, wealth creation and reduced spending on fossil fuels. The amendments proposed by the M5S to the Gierek report have directed towards the decentralisation of energy production, a greater share of renewables in heating and cooling and energy redevelopment in the industrial sector. The report has some elements with regard to certain forms of district heating, biogas without specifying its origin and, above all, the generic production of energy from waste ( which involves the use of incinerators) which I disagree with. For these reasons, despite the very many positive elements and the excellent cooperation with the rapporteur, I abstained.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Heating and cooling systems cover about half of the energy consumption in the European Union. In this context, it is very important that the European institutions contribute to the efficiency of this field, both in terms of industrial and domestic consumers. In particular, the energy efficiency of buildings is concerned by means of thermal insulation of older buildings, modernisation and even replacement of old thermal power plants, i.e. the modernisation of heating and cooling devices (including boilers and air conditioners). This process is already under way in many Member States, but there is a need for coordination of efforts at European level to avoid gaps between regions and to avoid the vulnerability of certain social groups. National resources are not sufficient and individual citizens' investments are unthinkable. To address these problems, a substantial increase in European funding is needed, covering the thermal renovation of residential lots and the construction of innovative installations, as well as an increase in the use of renewable energies (especially solar energy). This is an absolutely necessary initiative, which I fully support.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. Solar radiation is an important source of heat that is not yet sufficiently exploited. One way to do this would be to use water panels or photovoltaic cells to generate electricity. Given the particularly high energy efficiency of reversible heat pumps and their great potential for heating and cooling, intensive research on new and innovative solutions in this area is needed.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission has published its´ strategy for heating and cooling in February 2016 as a part of so-called winter package. This strategy does not include any legislative measures, it is however important to focus on this area as the heating and cooling in buildings and industry accounts for more than 50% of total energy consumption in the EU. I supported the report by the rapporteur A. Gierek, I believe he presented vital ideas for future heating and cooling systems. I however don´t agree that there should be a role for the European Commission to play in the field of training and certification of practitioners in the field of energy efficiency, therefore I abstained on Article 98 and I also do not support the vision that the EU and European Commission should be made responsible for measures related to the energy poverty in certain Member States.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. I supported this report because high energy efficiency, high-efficiency thermal insulation and the use of renewable energy sources are listed as priorities of the Strategy. The aim is to facilitate decentralised energy production and thereby enable consumers and communities to become more involved in the energy market and control their own energy consumption.  As there are differences in countries' priorities, I agree with the rapporteur's position that different measures need to be taken to achieve more efficient energy use and to achieve a significant reduction in carbon dioxide emissions.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution of the EU strategy on heating and cooling, as I believe that efforts should be made to increase funding for the thermal renovation of whole residential settlements, especially those built from large elements.  It is also important to replace outdated heat plants in residential settlements with highly efficient combined plants for cogeneration of electricity and heat as soon as possible.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 The heating and cooling sectors consume half of the energy (especially fossil sources) in the Union and, a significant part of that energy is lost to lack of efficiency. There is then a significant room for improvement in the sector and, consequently, for decreased energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions. The report is in the right direction because it proposes to increase the share of renewable energy in this area, invest to improve energy efficiency by renovating buildings, accelerating the modernization of heating systems, decentralizing energy production systems, etc. If this package is in the right direction, it is too insufficient to drastically lower greenhouse gas emissions, deeply change the energy system, and meet climate targets. That's why I abstained.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This text encourages the development of renewable energy, with a target of 100% for heating and cooling by 2050. However, in addition to the constant calls for energy efficiency that can be seen as a form of 'energy austerity' which is not likely to allow the 'recovery' so often announced, it is feared that this text will serve certain interests of the construction industry at the expense of our heritage... not to mention the perennial problems associated with the financing of certain "standard-" work, especially for individuals, even if the text speaks of various aids. In France, the Energy Transition Act had taken into account in Article 14 the need to protect the old building from external insulation operations. However, an implementing decree published in the Official Journal on 31 May has virtually removed this necessary precaution. This risk to our heritage (in the broadest sense) is all the greater since the current trend in France is to give more and more decision-making power to local edifices, which generally do not have the necessary skills and who can hardly resist the various pressures (especially construction), to the detriment of the architects of the buildings of France. I voted against it.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Heating and cooling account for the bulk of energy consumption at European level. In this respect, this report underlines the need for a specific long-term strategy with renewable energies at its heart. The report thus highlights the major role played by new technologies based on water, air, solar energy, geothermal energy, etc., and calls on the Member States to provide for incitement measures to promote and adopt these technologies. In this context, it is estimated that the modernisation of out-of-date and ineffective heating systems, better use of heat by urban heating systems, and an in-depth renovation of buildings are some of the essential elements that can enable a safer and more sustainable approach to heat supply. An attractive financing system is thus proposed, favouring the use of new technologies for heating households on the basis of renewable energies. Furthermore, the report underlines the importance of scientific research to develop innovative technical solutions for energy-effective and renewable energy-based heating devices and systems. I therefore voted in favour of the report entitled 'EU Strategy for Heating and Cooling'.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The committee's work on heating and cooling strategies is important for the Energy and Climate Union and security of energy supply. The use of modern heating and cooling technologies, the use of biogas, biomass, implementation of high-quality insulation in buildings and modernization of older buildings, investment in small, high-efficiency heating plants – these activities increase the efficiency of energy management. I voted in favour of the proposed resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The volume of heating and cooling issues differs between Member States. This means that different priorities have been established in these countries with regard to the steps to be taken. It should also be stressed that in the countries that joined the Union after 2004, the greatest potential for improving efficiency lies in the thermal renovation of buildings. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The heating and cooling sectors consume half of the energy (especially from fossil sources) in the Union and a significant part of that energy is lost because of a lack of efficiency. There is then a significant room for improvement in the sector and, consequently, for decreased energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions. The report is in the right direction because it proposes to increase the share of renewable energy in this area, invest to improve energy efficiency by renovating buildings, accelerating the modernization of heating systems, decentralizing energy production systems, etc. If this package is in the right direction, it is too insufficient to drastically lower greenhouse gas emissions, deeply change the energy system, and meet climate targets. That's why I abstained.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the Commission's intention to develop a package of measures to facilitate the renovation of multi-apartment buildings; I believe that a harmonised and comprehensive set of urban energy planning measures should be developed in order to assess the potential for local heating and cooling, to carry out optimised and integrated renovation of buildings and to develop heating and cooling infrastructure.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on an EU Strategy on Heating and Cooling. Almost 50% of the EU’s final energy demand is used for heating and cooling, of which 80% is used in buildings. The report underlines the necessity to take along specific measures for heating and cooling when revising the Energy Efficiency Directive (2012/27/EU), the Renewable Energy Directive (2009/28/EC) and the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive (2010/31/EU). Moreover, the report calls for specific sustainable heating and cooling strategies to be developed at national level, giving special attention to combined heat and power. I am of the opinion that the heating and cooling sector should reflect the 2015 Paris Agreement on Climate Change (COP 21).

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about the European Commission's first strategy to combat mass energy consumption in the field of heating and cooling. A sector representing 50% of the Union's energy consumption and, where renewable energy accounts for only 18% of that consumption, compared to 75% of fossil fuels. The report notes, inter alia, the importance of progressively reducing obsolete boilers and the importance of further increasing innovation and new technologies in the area. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Heating and cooling accounts for roughly half of the EU’s final energy demand – I voted in favour of this report which is looking for solutions to reduce demand and make the sector more efficient, in order to decrease dependence on energy imports, reduce emissions, and bring down costs to consumers, especially those at risk of energy poverty.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this very broad report. Since "heating and cooling" account for the largest share of energy demand in the EU, it is important that we deal with it with a very targeted and meticulous way. We call on national, local and European authorities to create a favourable framework for tenants and people living in multi-dwelling buildings to also enable them to benefit from their own production, use of renewable "heating and cooling" and energy efficiency measures. We also point out that energy extraction from waste will continue to play an important role in heating, as landfilling and the use of fossil fuels are often the alternative. Many of the measures being requested have already been implemented in Flanders, but not yet in the rest of Europe. Flanders is often at the forefront in this area.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. It is essential to substantially increase the financing of thermal renovation works for entire residential areas, in particular those built using the large panel construction method. The means of the European Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Fund should be applied for this purpose. This objective should be a priority, in particular given that the costs of such projects normally exceed the capacities of building owners. Obsolete heat-producing plants in residential areas should also be replaced as a matter of urgency by small, high-efficiency heat and electricity cogeneration plants. In Mediterranean European countries, refrigeration is a growing concern due to the gradual warming of the climate. Suitable architectural solutions, such as thermal insulation and reversible heat pumps, which remove heat from buildings during warmer periods and pump heat inwards when heating is needed, can play a relevant role in solving this problem. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Basically, the report contains some innovative ideas. However, I do not think much of intervening directly in people's heating habits. This includes, among other things, the demand for district heating in terms of area and that models of furnaces fuelled with solid heating fuels should be phased out of circulation. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU's heating and cooling strategy. The report seeks to remedy the current energy consumption in the European Union: more than half of the demand for energy goes into heating and cooling buildings, not only by consuming more energy than is necessary but also by creating a financial burden for many households in Europe. A change in the energy sector is therefore needed to make it more efficient, environmentally responsible and socially oriented.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Heating and cooling accounts for roughly half of the EU’s final energy demand – I voted in favour of this report which searches for solutions to reduce demand and make the sector more efficient, in order to decrease dependence on energy imports, reduce emissions, and bring down costs to consumers, especially those at risk of energy poverty. Together with fellow Socialist MEPs I have worked to advance a comprehensive European strategy to end energy poverty, while targeting those who are most vulnerable, particularly women facing social exclusion and single mothers.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – A substantial part of the EU’s energy is used to heat and cool houses and buildings across the EU. Therefore, if the EU wants to increase its energy-efficiency we will have to work on the infrastructures that provide these. I voted in favour of this resolution, because it recognises the importance of thermal renovation and the efficiency gains that it can bring. I welcome its specific recommendations with regard to the renovation and insulation of buildings, as well as the use of new technological solutions and renewables. Finally, becoming more energy-efficient also means that we become less dependent on third countries for our energy supply, for example, with regard to our gas supply.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy has taken into account the differences and views that exist in the Member States, and underlines the measures to be taken, particularly in the newer Member States, for the thermal renovation of buildings.  I voted in favour.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing \ u2012 The new heating and cooling strategy was presented by the European Commission in February 2016 and is part of the Energy Union strategy. It is with regard to the Energy Union strategy that this report has been produced that responds to the main challenges of the strategy. According to the report, one of the biggest problems is that up to 84% of heating and cooling is generated from fossil fuels and the potential of renewable energy sources is not sufficiently exploited. This can negatively affect climate and energy objectives. The resolution therefore proposed, in particular, the decarbonisation of heating and cooling, the conversion of pre-existing buildings into buildings with low energy consumption, the exploitation of energy potential from waste, but also, for example, the inclusion of consumers and industry in the process of generating and providing energy.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Gierek report because I agree with the proposed strategy for heating and cooling. About 40% of energy consumption originates from an ageing housing stock that accounts for 36% of our total carbon dioxide consumption. In this regard, I believe that, in addition to public buildings, we will extend our legislative scope on heating and cooling to private individuals, while creating access to finance so that they can carry out the necessary reforms. I particularly support the call for the development, at national level, of specific and sustainable heating and cooling strategies, paying particular attention to the combined production of heat and electricity, cogeneration and urban heating and cooling systems, always giving preference to renewable energy sources.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Heating and cooling are responsible for half of the EU's energy consumption, but a lot of the energy produced to heat and cool is lost. One of the Union's strategic priorities in the field of energy can only be to make these two major items of consumption more efficient and sustainable. This will make it possible to reduce dependence on energy imports and costs for households and businesses, but also to contribute to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and to the commitments made in the Paris CLIMATE AGREEMENT COP21. It should be thought that 75 % of the fuels used in the heating and cooling sector continue to be of fossil origin, about half of which is gas consumption. We at the M5S have succeeded in obtaining in this report that energy production for heating and cooling is increasingly derived from renewable sources and that it is pushing for an energy redevelopment of existing buildings, both private and industrial. However, the report maintains elements that I do not agree with, such as the strategy on the production of energy from waste, which involves the use of incinerators. I therefore abstained.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution of the EU strategy on heating and cooling. As the report points out, the heating and cooling sector, which is consistent with the EU's energy and climate objectives, must be based on 100% renewable energy sources by 2050 at the latest, which can only be achieved by fundamentally reducing our energy consumption and by making full use of the principle that energy efficiency is the most important fuel.  I agree that more needs to be done to reduce the demand for heating of buildings and to shift residual demand from fuel to imported fossil fuels in individual sources to sustainable heating and cooling options consistent with the EU 2050 targets.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, SMEs generate 71 % of employment in the European Union, which is why we believe it is essential to move forward in relation to measures to support these companies.  I voted in favour of this report because we think it is positive that it identifies austerity as one of the causes of the weakening of SMEs and also because it insists on the need to facilitate access for SMEs to the European Union's structural and investment funds. But I would like to highlight our revulsion at the European Commission's threat to freeze these funds for the Spanish State and Portugal, because, in addition to considering the use of funds to blackmail peoples intolerable, we believe that both adjustments to avoid freezing funds, such as freezing funds themselves, will create even more difficulties for SMEs and , therefore, the high levels of unemployment, poverty, marginalisation and social exclusion that have been caused by austerity policies, especially in the peoples of southern Europe, will increase even more. We also believe that the Capital Markets Union is not the solution for SMEs – in fact, it could create new difficulties – and that free trade agreements are also not alternative, which put SMEs on a path of reducing production costs, while reducing wages and prices at source, destroying jobs and causing many SMEs to close. This report also refers to the strengthening of SMEs in the agricultural, fisheries and aquaculture sector through thematic objective 3. We believe that in order to maintain these SMEs, which are fundamental to ensuring our food sovereignty and food security, they are also fundamental policies for regulating production and markets, as well as a fair distribution of production rights and fishing rights.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D).
text: – Mr President, SMEs account for 99% of all EU businesses and provide about two-thirds of employment in Europe. This makes them an indispensable sector in stabilising the European economy and creating jobs and growth in Europe. One of the biggest challenges SMEs encounter on a daily basis is that of difficult access to affordable finance. Unfortunately, the current instruments are insufficient and do not provide SMEs, especially micro and small enterprises, with the necessary means to finance investment. We must put in place the right environment and create the right opportunities for our SMEs to thrive and invest in the future. Therefore, I support the report, which not only underlines the importance of better access to financing for SMEs but also highlights the need to simplify relevant administrative procedures for continuous information and training on projects, and stresses the crucial role of local government in the proper utilisation of EU funds.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this document, I am glad that we are also adopting documents here in plenary aimed at supporting small and medium-sized enterprises, supporting business, and not just documents that regulate fathers' parental leave and other things that, in my opinion, should be adapted by individual Member States. The promotion of small and medium-sized businesses is generally very important for the prosperity of our continent and it is good that this material clearly calls on individual national governments to remove the bureaucratic burden, to simplify access to entrepreneurship, which I think is very important. And an important passage is also important, in my opinion, which concerns the financing of small and medium-sized enterprises, because access to credit is an extremely important issue for a budding small entrepreneur. From this point of view, I therefore agree with the document, it is good that the money also goes to cohesion policy, precisely to promote entrepreneurship, i.e. that the money will be reproduced and not only spent.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, it is often said that SMEs constitute the keystone in the economies of our Member States, and thus, in initiatives such as the cohesion policy and the Euro 2020 strategy, careful consideration has been given to the role of SMEs in the economy, both now and in the future. As this report highlights the key economic concerns and priorities of the European Union, I support its proposals in the sphere of resource efficiency, growth and, above all, competitiveness, as well as the reflections on the relation to regional policy. The report acknowledges the impact that the economic downturn had on SMEs throughout Europe, acknowledging the stifling of demand which was experienced. This is something I understand, given the obstacles that the Irish economy has faced: thankfully we are now recovering. The recommendation for more and more efficient financial instruments is a good one, and I think that, if we implement these measures in a balanced way, we will ensure that SMEs can continue to innovate, compete and grow, and that, in conjunction with the digital single market, SMEs can thrive into the future.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2014-2020 Structural and Investment Funds programming period has 11 thematic objectives, including promoting the competitiveness of SMEs. This report recognises the fundamental importance of SMEs for the European economic and social fabric and in this regard calls on the Commission to: simplify existing legislation in order to facilitate SME access to credit (with specific mention of microcredit and the need to find a lasting solution to the backlog of regional policy payments); take into account the added value of SME projects for the development and innovation of traditional sectors, stifled by the austerity policies implemented by the European Union; take into account the principles of the circular economy package in order to promote more sustainable economic growth; ensure the transparency of public procurement in order to avoid possible fraud. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The EU is being hypocritical when it talks about SMEs. Far from helping SMEs, its red tape and over-regulation makes the life of small business owners a misery. Fortunately Brexit means this will not be our problem for much longer, and we look forward to a positive and lighter regulatory climate in post-Brexit Britain.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to strengthen the competitiveness of SMEs, which generate 100 million jobs in the European Union, or one third of private sector jobs. There are a few good ideas to note: reducing payment delays and simplifying administrative payments for beneficiaries of structural funds, simplifying access to credit for SMEs. Although cohesion policy is at best effective at mitigating the negative effects of EU policies on employment and investment in SMEs, the massive injection of public funds is not a sustainable solution to the difficulties faced by SMEs. In this context, I abstained on this report. I do not consider that it really addresses the roots of the problems faced by SMEs in terms of competitiveness, financing and cash flow.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This implementation report calls for simplified and easier access to credit for SMEs. It emphasises that each ESI Fund (ESF, ERDF, Cohesion fund, EFMM and EARDF) supports 11 thematic objectives and the thematic objective 3 is about ‘enhancing the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises, the agricultural sector and the fisheries and aquaculture sector’ and the related investment priorities for the ERDF. While it was a generally good report, it also made positive reference to the Capital Markets Union aimed at developing non-bank lending (shadow banking), which Sinn Féin strongly opposes. Because of this call being included, I did not vote in favour of the overall report but abstained

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which stresses the need for simplification of administrative procedures, better access to SME financing, and stresses the fundamental role of local governments, which - directly or indirectly - are involved in programme monitoring committees. SMEs are essential to the development and prosperity of our economy.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on enhancing the competitiveness of SMEs. Under the theme ‘competitiveness of SMEs’ the ESI funds have allocated more than EUR 63 billion (plus EUR 31 billion of national co-financing for a total amount of EUR 94 billion) in the 2014-2020 programme. In the EU there are 23 million SMEs, which account for around 99% of all businesses, make a fundamental contribution to economic growth, social cohesion, innovation and high-quality job creation, providing over 100 million jobs. However, only a small percentage of the EU’s SMEs are currently able to identify and exploit the opportunities offered by international trade, trade agreements and the global value chains, and only 13% of them have been active at international level outside the EU over the past three years. While voting in favour of this report I also call for a less regulated access to funding. I also invite the Commission and the Member States to ensure enhanced coordination and consistency among all EU investment policies targeted at SMEs and Member States to exchange data and best practices. I also encourage the European Commission to make serious efforts and to encourage the long-awaited internationalisation of SMEs.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The thematic objective 'Strengthening the competitiveness of SMEs' (TZ 3) is of the utmost importance for achieving the objectives of cohesion policy and the Europe 2020 strategy. The introduction of thematic concentration in cohesion policy programming for 2014-2020 has created an effective tool for the design of operational programmes with an improved focus on investment priorities. The report provides an early assessment of this thematic objective and the initial reporting on the overall implementation of the strategy in the 2014-2020 financial planning period, which both measures what has been achieved so far and attempts to draw conclusions for the future. Small and medium-sized enterprises are of the utmost importance for the economies of the EU's regions, both in terms of employment and competitiveness. They are the backbone of our economy and create the most jobs in Europe. I therefore support the creation of a wide range of measures and financial instruments to promote and strengthen the competitiveness of SMEs.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. There are more than 23 million SMEs in the EU, or 99% of businesses. These SMEs generate 100 million jobs, or two-thirds of private sector jobs. 14% of the available EU funds are allocated to SMEs, or more than 140 billion euros for the 2014-2020 programming period. This report does not address the roots of SMEs' competitiveness, financing or cash flow difficulties, namely: - unfair international competition exacerbated by social, environmental, fiscal and monetary dumping by emerging countries and some Member States; The single currency that deprives states of monetary leverage to reduce competitiveness gaps with their trading partners; Banning economic patriotism in EU treaties, including prioritizing resident companies in awarding public contracts; The tightening of credit conditions caused by the Basel III agreements. Under no circumstances will the massive injection of public money, particularly through subsidies, make it possible to make a lasting solution to the difficulties faced by SMEs. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interests of transparency and democracy I would like to confirm I abstained on this report. Of course I want the EU to enhance the competitiveness of SMEs but as usual the EU´s strategy for this is more EU legislation. More paperwork and red tape. Far from helping SMEs the EU´s red tape and over regulations makes the lives of small business owners a misery. Fortunately Brexit means this will not be the UKs problem for much longer. I look forward to a positive and lighter regulatory climate post-Brexit.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because, like the European Parliament, I have always made SMEs the indispensable basis for job creation in Europe. As a reminder, "SMEs form the backbone of the European Union economy and have enormous potential for job creation, creating 85% of new jobs; 20.7 million SMEs account for more than 67% of private sector employment in the European Union, 30% of which come from micro-enterprises." Parliament also believes that 'SMEs are the main drivers of long-term European economic growth and opportunities for sustainable job creation in the 28 Member States'.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the achievement of the thematic objective of increasing the competitiveness of SMEs referred to in Article 9(3) of the Common Provisions Regulation. During the economic and financial crisis, poverty and social exclusion have increased in many Member States, as well as long-term unemployment, youth unemployment and social inequalities, thus playing an important role for SMEs in promoting Europe's recovery. Each European Structural and Investment (ESI) Fund supports 11 thematic objectives. By focusing support on themes, operational programmes have been more adapted to a specific number of strategic objectives, in particular those relating to the potential of SMEs, including micro-enterprises, to boost growth and create high-quality jobs. However, while SMEs are essential to succeed in cohesion policy, they face many challenges such as legal, institutional and technical obstacles. I therefore agree that the resulting barriers for SMEs must be removed and that the planned support from the ESI Funds should be further strengthened.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report submitted by the Committee on Regional Development is about the implementation of the thematic objective of improving the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises. It calls on the Member States to support the development of SMEs, including simplifying the conditions for access to credit and ensuring enhanced coordination of all EU investment policies targeting SMEs. In addition, the report calls on the Commission, together with member states and managing authorities, to encourage the development of a network of universities, research centres, social and economic actors and public institutions to support the development of entrepreneurship. As a quarter of SMEs are currently trading abroad, the report also proposes progress and corresponding support in this area (using the Structural and Investment Funds more effectively). SMEs should receive a greater part of cohesion policy resources in order to increase their international competitiveness. Increased support for SMEs is an objective that I agree with and voted in favour of. At the same time, I would note that SMEs can develop when aggregate demand in the economy increases.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is being hypocritical when it talks about SMEs. Far from helping SMEs, its red tape and over-regulation makes the life of small business owners a misery. Fortunately Brexit means this will not be our problem for much longer, and we look forward to a positive and lighter regulatory climate in post-Brexit Britain.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Cohesion policy is at best used to mitigate the negative effects of EU policies on employment and investment in SMEs. In no way will the massive injection of public money, particularly through subsidies, make it possible to make a lasting solution to the difficulties faced by SMEs (unfair competition, non-optimality of the euro area, ban on economic patriotism): I therefore abstained.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. – In the 2014-2020 programming period, more than EUR 63 billion has been allocated from the EIE Funds (European Structural and Investment Funds) for the overall objective of 'SME competitiveness'. I am voting in favour of this report because I consider it essential to support almost 1 000 0000 companies and therefore the direct creation of more than 300 000 jobs. In addition, it is expected to provide funding to micro-enterprises, with special attention to cooperatives and enterprises in the social economy.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe's 23 million small and medium-sized enterprises account for around 99 % of all EU businesses. While offering more than 100 million jobs and being a central element of the continent's economic growth, innovation and social cohesion, only 13 % of them are engaged in commercial activities and investment in global markets. The austerity policies implemented by the Member States and the European Union in recent years have stifled demand and created numerous difficulties for businesses. I voted in favour of the D'Amato report because I strongly agree with the need to relaunch the competitiveness of European SMEs, including at international level, through investments and, in particular, through the proper use of EIS funds. The text effectively underlines some guidelines for getting out of these issues starting from simplifying administrative procedures and improving access to credit for businesses. There is a need to ensure greater involvement of local authorities and an improvement in their administrative capacity in the monitoring committees of programmes for the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), the European Social Fund (ESF) and other funds. SMEs are a crucial factor in the development and prosperity of our economy, and we must not forget that.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of this report which highlights the importance of SMEs in the European economy. It proposes to simplify and reduce bureaucracy, regulation and legislation in access to aid and credit for SMEs.  We stress that the report refers to economic mismanagement and that austerity measures that paralyze demand have a tougher impact on SMEs; and which supports the creation of innovation networks, and the exchange of positive experiences, as well as technical support. To bet on investment in SMEs is to bet on the future, employment and a more sustainable economy.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. With regard to this report on strengthening the competitiveness of SMEs, I have chosen to abstain. Of course, I agree on many points with the objectives desired by the rapporteur. Thus, I have always fought in favour of administrative simplification for SMEs and in particular the beneficiaries of the European structural funds that are covered in this report. Furthermore, I would also like to see a minimum of delays in payment related to cohesion policy funds, as well as, as a fundamental necessity, the simplification of access to credit for SMEs. However, I regret that this report does not address the roots of 'evil' in terms of competitiveness or financing for SMEs. Thus, the text fails to point the finger at the problem of unfair competition, the result of the social, environmental, fiscal and monetary dumping that European companies suffer. Similarly, there is no questioning of the single currency, which prevents Member States from being able to boost their exports. In general, Brussels' ban on real economic patriotism that would favour businesses, allowing them to be given priority in the awarding of public contracts, for example.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is acceptable and balanced. I believe it is essential to support small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the economic strength of our territory; That is why I have chosen to support this text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. •u2012 Cohesion policy is the main instrument for investment and job creation in the Union. Throughout this crisis it has become the only investment policy in certain regions.  There are 23 million SMEs in the EU – 99 % of all enterprises – that contribute fundamentally to economic growth, social cohesion, innovation and quality job creation. Through the Structural Funds for the SME Competitiveness Improvement Programme, in the period 2014-2020 we hope to increase job creation and invest in the development of people's capacities, while developing and implementing new business models, developing new products and services and supporting internationalization. That is why the report, which I have supported, calls on the Commission and Member States to take into account the added value of SME projects for the development and innovation of traditional sectors in order to promote their adaptation to digitisation processes by improving their ICT qualifications, and calls on Member States and regional entities to study and apply to their full extent the possibilities offered by financial instruments.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has been advocated by Parliament on improving the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the European Union. Today, the EU has 23 million people in the EU. SMEs, representing about 99% of all enterprises. They contribute substantially to economic growth, social cohesion, innovation and high-quality job creation: SMEs provide over 100 million jobs. 2 out of 3 private sector jobs, while employment growth rates are twice as high as the rate of larger enterprises. And, however, SMEs eligible for ESI Funds are particularly adversely affected by complex and volatile rules and related bureaucratic burdens, and in particular that administrative costs are completely disproportionate in terms of funding, the duration of the examination of applications for funding and the need for advances. In this report, Parliament therefore calls on the Commission and the Member States to take into account the added value of SME projects in terms of traditional sector development and innovation, which would not only encourage job creation but also preserve the specificities of local and regional businesses, while respecting sustainability principles.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is right that the Commission pays particular attention to good governance and high-quality public services. A transparent, consistent and innovative public procurement system is important for SMEs, and it is therefore important to remove as far as possible the obstacles to SMEs' participation in tenders, to eliminate excessive bureaucratic burdens, to avoid the impose of additional conditions at national level, while at the same time implementing as soon as possible the provisions of the existing legislative framework for the settlement of public procurement disputes. At the same time, I do not believe that SMEs can facilitate the integration of immigrants with the right incentives.

name: David Borrelli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012I voted in favour of Mrs D'Amato's report on the implementation of the thematic objective 'promoting the competitiveness of SMEs' because it highlights the economic contribution made by small and medium-sized enterprises, we are talking about more than 100 million jobs in Europe, and it identifies the difficulties faced today by SMEs themselves due to the austerity policies implemented by the Member States and the Union. The report pays particular attention to issues of great importance such as employment growth through the promotion of more sustainable economic prosperity, the resolution of the serious problem of late payments by the Commission and support for self-employment through micro-credit, so that obstacles to access to traditional banking services can be overcome. Finally, I would like to stress the importance of the direct participation of citizens who, through the Rousseau Platform, have contributed to the drafting of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Although I am in favour of supporting SMEs and although all the wishful thinking of this text goes in this direction, I note once again in this report that the true roots of evil are not identified, let alone fought (single currency, borders open to all kinds of dumping and prohibition of the practice of economic patriotism). Therefore, I abstained.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EIS funds are used to promote the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises in the European Union. They are an important source of funding for 801,500 companies for the direct creation of 354,300 new jobs, which means that 5 % of all SMEs in the EU and 8 % of new businesses will receive European funding. EIS funds are good and to be supported instruments, funding 11 thematic objectives, including promoting the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises in the agricultural sector (for the EAFSR) and the fisheries and aquaculture sector (for the EFF), as well as related investment priorities for the ERDF: all useful actions to support the implementation of the EU's Europe 2020 strategy for smart growth , sustainable, inclusive and supportive of Europe.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to strengthen the competitiveness of the 23 million SMEs in the European Union. We share most of the ideas promoted in this report, such as administrative simplification for beneficiaries of European structural funds, increased synergies between European structural funds and simplification of access to credit for SMEs. On the other hand, we note that the rapporteur is not putting forward any concrete steps to achieve these wishful thinking. Moreover, this report does not address the roots of SME financing, cash flow or competitiveness problems. No questioning of the directive on the secondment of workers which exacerbates unfair competition within the Union, no comment on the European treaties which prohibit Member States from awarding public contracts to their SMEs. In fact, cohesion policy is at best able to mitigate the negative effects of European policies on employment and investment in SMEs. Under no circumstances will the massive injection of public money, particularly through subsidies, make it possible to make a lasting solution to the difficulties faced by SMEs. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 After the rise of recent decades, small and medium-sized enterprises are expected to be the main driver of economic progress in the coming period, both in developed and transition countries. Improving the competitiveness of SMEs is an essential area of intervention, as SMEs account for around 99% of all businesses, with a decisive contribution to creating new jobs and ensuring cohesion. Improving the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises is a priority objective in the Regional Operational Programme 2014-2020, with approximately EUR 63 billion of ESI funds allocated to this framework for this period. I support the EP resolution proposal on the implementation of the thematic objective 'improving the competitiveness of SMEs', as I believe that the programme will focus on financial instruments and support for the internationalisation of businesses and will be simplified to make it easier for small businesses to benefit from. During the new programming period, investments in SMEs will be made through OT 3, while also allowing investments in SMEs to be made under other thematic objectives. The development of the Competitiveness Strategy focuses on capitalising the potential of competitive industries and services, attracting SMEs into the value creation chain, promoting technological innovation and supporting the internationalisation of SMEs.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Small and medium-sized enterprises are the backbone of the European economy. They represent 100 million jobs and contribute enormously to the economic growth of the Union. The European Union's cohesion policy through its structural and investment funds contributes to the financing of SMEs. It is therefore essential that cohesion policy offers instruments adapted to the specifics of these companies. With this in mind, it is important to strengthen support for SMEs from structural and investment funds. There is also a need to remove bureaucratic and regulatory barriers that prevent SMEs from accessing this financial support. I voted in favour of this initiative report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I believe that SMEs are the driving force of the European economy. Member States and regions should provide effective information and support mechanisms to enable SMEs to benefit from European funds, as well as adopt ambitious measures combining EU budgetary resources from in particular the COSME and Horizon 2020 programmes and the European Structural and Investment Funds. The lives of SMEs must also be simplified by speeding up procedures for access to European funding and by lightening the eu's heaviest legislative acts, in order to support the competitiveness of SMEs and the absorption of European Structural and Investment Funds. I also think that access to credit should be simplified and less regulated, taking into account the particular characteristics of micro-enterprises, new businesses and the regions in which they operate. I note that, unfortunately, investors and banks are often reluctant to finance companies in the start-up and early expansion phases and that many SMEs, especially new small businesses, find it difficult to gain access to external financing.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This implementation report calls for simplified and easier access to credit for SMEs. It emphasises that each ESI Fund (ESF, ERDF, Cohesion fund, EFMM and EARDF) supports 11 thematic objectives and the thematic objective 3 is about ‘enhancing the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises, the agricultural sector and the fisheries and aquaculture sector’ and the related investment priorities for the ERDF. While it was a generally good report, it also made positive reference to the Capital Markets Union aimed at developing non-bank lending (shadow banking), which Sinn Féin strongly opposes. Because of this call being included, I did not vote in favour of the overall report but abstained.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are essential for the economy of EU regions, both in terms of employment and competitiveness and the Report underscores the importance of doubling the support offered through Cohesion Policy to SMEs for the 2014-2020 period. In the new programming period, among other possibilities, investments in SMEs will be made also through the ESI Funds under the broad theme of ‘competitiveness of SMEs’. It is important to increase funding for the strengthening of the competitiveness of SMEs. I voted in favour of this Report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2014-2020 Programming Period of the Structural and Investment Funds has 11 thematic objectives: the thematic objective (TOs) 3 concerns the promotion of the competitiveness of SMEs and has a budget of over 63 billion euros (94, if national co-financing is added). The report by our colleague Rosa D'Amato contains several positive aspects: the definition of the process of internationalisation of SMEs, which should be based on corporate social responsibility, respect for human rights and workers' rights and the highest possible level of environmental protection, in order to ensure fair competition and an increase in quality employment; the emphasis on the difficulties encountered by SMEs, with the clear mention that the austerity policies implemented by the Member States and the European Union have stifled demand; the detection of the lack of factual data on the effects and results produced by financial instruments, as well as the weak link between these financial instruments and the EU's overall objectives and priorities; the mention of microcredit, aimed mainly at micro-entrepreneurs and disadvantaged people wishing to take up self-employment, is crucial to overcome obstacles to access to traditional banking services. For these reasons, I am voting in favour.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In view of the fact that there are 23 million SMEs registered within the European Union providing more than 100 million jobs, I voted for this report. I am very much in favour of implementation of measures that will enhance their competitiveness. I believe that this can be achieved through financial support provided by European Structural and Investment Funds, by providing SMEs with microcredits, by simplifying mechanism that will help the business environment and speeding up the process of setting up of new businesses and by decreasing excessive bureaucracy that prevents SMEs from applying for the available funds. I would be in favour of Member States exchanging more data, knowledge and best practices in this regard. Thank you.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 SMEs are the key driver of the growth of the EU economy in terms of both employment and competitiveness. More than 23 million EU SMEs provide around 100 million jobs. Promoting their development is a key objective for the European Union.  At a time of difficult economic crisis such as the one still under way, SMEs must be helped to promote their competitiveness and innovation, and in this respect the EIS Funds are effective tools for achieving this objective. As this House has repeatedly argued, however, we need simplified procedures for access to funds, together with coordination with all EU investment policies for SMEs.  Only in this way and through synergistic action will it be possible to maximize the impact and effect of investments to create a positive ecosystem of development and growth.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and underline that small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are essential to the economy of the EU regions, both in terms of employment and competitiveness.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on the implementation of the thematic objective 'improving the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises'. In particular, during the period of economic crisis that Europe continues to face, the development of strategies to improve the position of small and medium-range enterprises is working for the benefit of citizens and I have therefore voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the D'Amato report on promoting the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), as these are fundamental to the European Union economy, both in terms of employment and competitiveness. They make up 99 % of European companies and provide about two thirds of jobs in the private sector. Furthermore, this issue is essential for achieving the objectives of cohesion policy and the Europe 2020 strategy. As cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 will double the funds for SMEs for the period 2007-2013 to EUR 140 billion, I welcome the proposal to simplify European, national and regional legislation in order to facilitate SME access to finance.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on enhancing the competitiveness of SMEs and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises is one of the priorities of the Europe 2020 strategy. The programming of cohesion funds at thematic level is a welcome innovation, as it allows for greater scrutiny of their implementation, allowing us to conclude that their allocation has contributed to increased growth and job creation, including in micro-enterprises. This theme is of particular importance for Portugal, where most of the business fabric are SMEs. This resolution makes a good diagnosis of the difficulties encountered. It should be noted, however, that under the cohesion funds of the previous period - contrary to what happened in the rest of Europe - Portugal had one of the best executions at European level. I welcome the adoption of this resolution, reinforcing the importance of increased scrutiny and greater linkto SMEs in the planning of the next multiannual funding framework.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I supported the doubling of funding for the current 2014-2020 programming period. But the increase in the budget alone is not enough: I also supported the proposed measures, which will identify existing obstacles to the effective use of funds by SMEs and, for example.B, reduce them through information and support mechanisms. The proposals to create potential synergies within the ESI Funds and between the ESI Funds and other funds that are important for SMEs are also important measures for me to consistently develop and strengthen the competitiveness of SMEs.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Promoting business competitiveness is a priority to achieve the objectives of cohesion policy and the Europe 2020 strategy. Small and medium-sized enterprises are crucial to the economic development of EU regions, because they promote both competitiveness and employment. In the period 2007-2013, through cohesion policy, businesses received EUR 70 billion to support their activities. The objective for the period 2014-2020 is to double the quota, including through the contribution of financial instruments. I voted in favour of implementing the thematic objective of promoting SMEs within cohesion policy, because I believe it is an effective instrument for the implementation of operational programmes focused on investment policies, capable of setting specific objectives in terms of economic growth and employment. It is important to emphasise that this approach recognises the importance of local authorities in the territorial dimension of operational programmes and aims to simplify and reduce administrative burdens, so that EU financial instruments can be accessed and used.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – We have 23 million small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the EU, which account for around 99% of all businesses; making a fundamental contribution to economic growth, social cohesion, innovation and high-quality job creation. Having said that we only have 13% of European SMEs which are engaged in commercial activities and investments in the global markets. I share the concern expressed in this report on a skills gap with regard to ICT skills that should be dealt with by placing more emphasis on relevant training and education; improving access to finance, providing more information, simplifying legislation, cutting red tape and promoting e-cohesion amongst society stakeholders. In this sense, operational programmes should be fine-tuned to support research and development, particularly SMEs to increase their capacity to submit patent applications to the European Patent Office. These require viable and user-friendly financing schemes to achieve the scopes aimed at.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it helps to strengthen the capacities of small and medium-sized enterprises, through improving their accessibility to finance, and therefore helping to set jobs and enhance the creation of new opportunities. The report calls for access to simplified and less regulated credit for SMEs, and stresses that SMEs are essential in the economy of the Regions of the Union. It emphasizes that a good part of the problems suffered by SMEs were and are due to austerity policies implemented by Member States.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that the promotion of entrepreneurship is an important incentive for the growth of SMEs on national and international markets. It is well known that SMEs are the engine for the economic growth of eu regions, both in terms of employment and competitiveness. With this in mind, cohesion policy 2014-2020 is an effective catalyst for investment to promote and support, through a range of innovative financial instruments, the start-up and development of SMEs. However, the complex management of the Structural Funds and administrative burdens, as well as the limited access of SMEs to finance, have so far led to insufficient absorption of funds and it is necessary to speed up this direction. It is therefore essential that Member States and regions provide effective information and support mechanisms to enable SMEs to benefit from European funds. Strong synergy between the EIS Funds and other financial policies and instruments for SMEs will maximise the impact of investments and make the results of cohesion policy investments tangible, helping to shape the current and future growth of regions in the Member States.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Europe 2020 strategy foresees smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. Small and medium-sized enterprises are essential for the economy of the Member States, both for employment and for increasing competitiveness. More than EUR 70 billion was allocated in the period 2007-2013 to support businesses through cohesion policy. This amount shall be doubled for the period 2014-2020. I voted for the continued help of SMEs to successfully integrate into global value chains. These businesses are the backbone of the EU economy, accounting for 85% of newly created jobs. They are key factors in Europe's long-term economic growth.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – I abstained from voting on the report on improving the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises. The report contains many useful ideas. SMEs can play an important role in Europe's recovery, with some 23 million small and medium-sized enterprises making a significant contribution to economic growth, social cohesion, innovation and job creation, making up 99% of all businesses. However, in a paragraph of the report, the integration of refugees and migrants will be reflected, for which, as the report explains, adequate support and incentives for small businesses can provide an innovative opportunity. The original contractual vocation of cohesion policy was 'to reduce the disparities between the levels of development of the different regions and the lagging behind of the most disadvantaged regions'. Therefore, I cannot agree that cohesion funds, which are so important for European regions, should be used for migration-related purposes.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I support the report because it highlights several key aspects. Both the role that SMEs should have in the EU economy and their role in implementing cohesion policy. Another aspect is the need to cut red tape and diversify funding sources, as well as early involvement in discussions on investment priorities in future funding rounds, as well as the exchange of best practices between Member States. I would just like to point out that I do not believe that support for SMEs should be linked to the opportunity to integrate refugees and migrants.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls the Commission amongst others, to consider the circular economy package and COP21, to consider reduction of austerity policies, raising awareness on financial sources of SMEs, coordination among all EU investment policies, acceleration of cohesion policy and sharing of best practices between Member States. It also underlines the need to reduce administrative burdens and better access to financing. I am in favour of this report as it really and truly enhances the competitiveness of SMEs which I believe are the future of development and economic prosperity.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that cohesion policy is the main instrument for growing investment and jobs in the European Union, I believe that more close monitoring needs to be done to accelerate implementation, in particular the creation of projects with sustainable growth and quality job creation potential, with a focus on projects also launched in rural areas , to create new services and to help avoid depopulation of rural areas.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to establish a strategy to achieve the objectives of the Cohesion Policy and the Europe 2020 Strategy. The report proposes a thematic consultation in the establishment of cohesion policy with clear objectives, in particular that of strengthening growth and creating quality jobs in SMEs. Considering that small and medium-sized enterprises, which are at the heart of the European Union's economic model, should benefit from EU support for their competitiveness, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is being hypocritical when it talks about SMEs. Far from helping SMEs, its red tape and over-regulation makes the life of small business owners a misery. Fortunately Brexit means this will not be our problem for much longer, and we look forward to a positive and lighter regulatory climate in post-Brexit Britain.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text. The adoption by a large majority of this report on the implementation of the thematic objective 'strengthening the competitiveness of SMEs' is an extremely positive sign sent to the 23 million SMEs in the European Union, the true heart of our economies. While the development and prosperity of these companies undeniably determine European growth, but also enable social cohesion, it is essential to strengthen their competitiveness, notably through an adequate contribution from the FSIE (European Structural and Investment Funds). The importance of access to finance is rightly underlined in this report.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I took a position in the vote on the report on improving the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises. The report contains many useful ideas. SMEs can undoubtedly play an important role in Europe's recovery, with some 23 million small and medium-sized enterprises making up 99% of all businesses making a significant contribution to economic growth, social cohesion, innovation and job creation. However, in a paragraph of the report, the integration of refugees and migrants will be reflected, for which, as the report explains, adequate support and incentives for small businesses can provide an innovative opportunity. The original contractual vocation of cohesion policy was "to reduce the disparities between the levels of development of the different regions and the lagging behind of the most disadvantaged regions" (Article 174 TFEI). I cannot agree that cohesion funds, which are so important for European regions, should be used for migration-related purposes. It is time to recognize that the mandatory reception quota for resettlement is not working. Migrants and refugees should be helped in their countries of origin and not brought to EU Member States.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of promoting the competitiveness of SMEs as I believe that they are of fundamental importance to the EU economy. In addition, the competitiveness of SMEs promotes sustainable and economically and environmentally responsible growth, both at Community, national and regional level.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Today, 14% of the European funds available are allocated to the 23 million SMEs, or more than 140 billion euros for the 2014-2020 programming period. The report points to the administrative burden of the European Structural Fund subsidy systems, frequent payment delays and difficulties in accessing credit. Apart from the findings, to which we agree, this report does not propose any concrete solution. In particular, it does not in any way call into question unfair competition, the non-optimal nature of the euro area and the tightening of credit conditions caused by the Basel III agreements. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report as I believe it contains many positive elements. Particular attention is paid to the role of small and medium-sized enterprises in the European economy and cohesion policy, cutting red tape and promoting funding. I do not agree solely with the fact that support for small and medium-sized enterprises should be linked to the integration of migrants and refugees.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Aid for small and medium-sized enterprises in no way goes through the Union's additional lending or hazy practices.
