What is needed is a favourable tax policy for both workers and businesses, their protection from competition from third countries and an emphasis on growth opportunities with their own capital rather than loans that will once again strengthen the sinful banking system.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I took a position in the vote on the report on improving the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises. The report contains many useful ideas. SMEs can undoubtedly play an important role in Europe's recovery, with some 23 million small and medium-sized enterprises making up 99% of all businesses making a significant contribution to economic growth, social cohesion, innovation and job creation. However, in a paragraph of the report, the integration of refugees and migrants will be reflected, for which, as the report explains, adequate support and incentives for small businesses can provide an innovative opportunity.  The original contractual vocation of cohesion policy was "to reduce the disparities between the levels of development of the different regions and the lagging behind of the most disadvantaged regions" (Article 174 TFEI). I cannot agree that cohesion funds, which are so important for European regions, should be used for migration-related purposes. It is time to recognize that the mandatory reception quota for resettlement is not working. Migrants and refugees should be helped in their countries of origin and not brought to EU Member States.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is a key instrument for promoting investment in the Territory of the Union. Mrs D'Amato's first signature report on the M5S focuses on promoting the competitiveness of Europe's small and medium-sized enterprises, europe's real economic and employment structure with over 100 million jobs, and identifies critical issues and room for improvement in the design of the new programming. Firstly, a strong and decisive reference to austerity policies and the economic crisis as a cause of the stifling of domestic demand. In addition, bureaucracy and regulatory jungle as additional obstacles to doing business and investing in the real economy. The report calls for greater transparency in public procurement and the use of European funds, attention and rigour in payments by the Commission and the Member States, greater access to credit for SMEs. We need to rethink the entire production system so that concrete steps can be taken towards the circular economy and the energy transition, while at the same time creating jobs and green work. I voted in favour.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are essential for the economy of eu regions, both in terms of employment and competitiveness. In the period 2007-2013, with the support of cohesion policy, EUR 70 billion was used to support businesses, especially SMEs, and in the period 2014-2020 the aim is to double this amount. Under the broad theme of 'Competitiveness of SMEs', more than €63 billion of ESI Funds were allocated to the 2014-2020 programming period. Support will be given to around 801 500 companies to create 354 300 new direct jobs. 396 500 micro, small and medium-sized enterprises will receive funding to invest in the development of human capital and in the skills of workers. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Abstention: Cohesion policy is at best used to mitigate the negative effects of EUROPEAN policies on employment and investment in SMEs.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the current economic and social context, support for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) is essential. We therefore support a report to draw attention to this essential fact, especially if this report calls for an increase in support from the EU budget. But this central issue cannot hide deep and serious differences that we have on some of the aspects addressed in this report. We do not review ourselves either on the neoliberal agenda of the EU2020 strategy, to which the EU's structural and investment funds are subordinated (principle advocated by the rapporteur), nor in the conditionality rules (or thematic "bottleneck") that share the action of Member States (and SMEs) in determining their real investment needs and priorities. Generally agreeing with the need to increase the efficiency of SMEs by promoting circular economy practices and, in general, by increasing the environmental sustainability of enterprises), promoting the creation of new jobs, we cannot agree on the overly prescriptive and imposing nature of many guidelines underlying the implementation of EU funds. As far as we are aware, the development of SMEs is inseparable from the strategic development framework of the Member State in which they are part. We demarcated ourselves from the exaltation of the benefits of the Single Market.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that improving the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises means supporting a key element of the European economy and a successful cohesion policy. Without prejudice to certain reservations about the link between support for SMEs and the management of migrants, policies that should indeed remain distinct, this report adequately addresses key issues for SMEs such as cutting red tape, simplified access to credit for SMEs and the exchange of best practices between Member States.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ More than €70 billion from the Structural Funds have been invested in the development of small and medium-sized enterprises throughout the European Union over the past programming period. This amount should be significantly increased in the current 2014-2020 period. It is therefore essential to facilitate access to these funds for SMEs. In particular, the aim is to further increase the competitiveness of SMEs. They have long been the back bone of the European economy. They are responsible for creating more than 85 percent of new jobs. In the previous programming period, thanks to the European money invested, around 260 000 jobs were created in the European Union. In the years to come, it should be almost 100,000 more. At the same time, companies will be able to invest in the development of skills and education of their current employees. It is important to streamline the existing regulatory framework and the rules in force.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report because I consider small and medium-sized enterprises to be important to our economy and must be helped.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the implementation of the thematic objective 'improving the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises' – Article 9(3) of the Regulation laying down common provisions, as I believe that aid for small and medium-sized enterprises in no way goes through the Union's additional lending or hazy practices. What is needed is a favourable tax policy for both workers and businesses, their protection from competition from third countries and an emphasis on growth opportunities with their own capital rather than loans that will once again strengthen the sinful banking system.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as job growth and the competitiveness of business should be the focus of the EU. There are many thousands of SMEs in my constituency which must compete against big corporations to gain a share of the market. In calling for the reduction of red tape, easier access to credit and diversification of finance I hope this report will enable businesses to thrive in a competitive market.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ SMEs are key to the future development and prosperity of our economy. They are essential for the economy of EU regions, in terms of employment and competitiveness. ESI funds – through their Thematic Objectives (TO) – contribute to enhancing the competitiveness of the SMEs. For the 2014-2020 financing period more than EUR 63 bn have been allocated to the TO 3 ‘Enhancing the competitiveness of SMES’ which – together with the national co-financing – will amount to EUR 94 bn. I support the need for simplification of administrative procedures and a better access to financing of SMEs. Furthermore, I also consider important the role of local governments which – directly or indirectly – are involved in programme monitoring committees. However, many of the local authorities are still lacking the administrative capacity to properly participate in the OPs. Therefore technical assistance and their early involvement in the discussions regarding the OPs are crucial.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I took a position in the vote on the report on improving the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises. The report contains many useful ideas. SMEs can undoubtedly play an important role in Europe's recovery, with some 23 million small and medium-sized enterprises making up 99% of all businesses making a significant contribution to economic growth, social cohesion, innovation and job creation. However, in a paragraph of the report, the integration of refugees and migrants will be reflected, for which, as the report explains, adequate support and incentives for small businesses can provide an innovative opportunity. The original contractual vocation of cohesion policy was "to reduce the disparities between the levels of development of the different regions and the lagging behind of the most disadvantaged regions" (Article 174 TFEI). As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I cannot agree that cohesion funds so important to European regions should be used for migration-related purposes. It is time to recognize that the mandatory reception quota for resettlement is not working. Migrants and refugees should be helped in their countries of origin and not brought to EU Member States.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of the comprehensive report and congratulated the rapporteur on his work. SMEs are immensely important to the economies of EU regions, both in terms of employment, competitiveness and sustainable growth in the UNION. The fundamental objective of the Europe 2020 strategy is to implement smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. SMEs account for 85% of the new jobs created; 20.7 million SMEs make up 67% of private sector employment in the EU, of which 30% are from micro-enterprises. I therefore support all reports that, by supporting cohesion policy, increase the competitiveness of businesses, especially SMEs. EU cohesion policy is the main instrument for investment to help member states' regions, including Hungary and future growth. As SMEs received €70 billion in cohesion policy support in the period 2007-2013, the aim is to double this figure in 2014-2020 with the help of our financial instruments. A business environment favourable to SMEs is necessary to achieve their objectives, to which, for example, re-production, recycling and ecodesign would make a significant contribution in order to move towards a circular economy. The EU's international commitments in areas such as climate change cooperation or the Neighbourhood Policy offer specific opportunities for SMEs, but this requires a more effective support framework and closer international cooperation.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report with the aim of continuing to support European SMEs. The common objective is to support the implementation of the EU's Europe 2020 Strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. SMEs are essential to the EU economy, both in terms of employment and competitiveness. For the period 2007-2013, with the support of cohesion policy, EUR 70 billion was earmarked to support companies, mainly SMEs, and for the period 2014-2020 the objective is to double this amount.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ SMEs represents 99% of businesses in the EU, is of huge importance to the European economy and stand for large parts of innovation and economic growth in the EU. Linked to this is also that those SMEs provide around 100 million jobs in the EU and that they maintain double the employment growth compared to larger companies. This report touches on many topics that I think are very important; such as simplifying and deregulate SMEs access to credit, enchanting support to SMEs from ESI funds and removing obstacles against SMEs in public procurement. SMEs are the backbone of our economy and I support this report and its objective to make business easier for them.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The main potential for socio-economic growth in individual regions and the European Union as a whole lies in the momentum for small and medium-sized enterprises. And SMEs are the main source of development, innovation and employment in the EU, ensuring employment gains and new labour market prospects, the development of fields such as research and innovation capable of promoting new professions and businesses and alternatives to the pre-existing market threatened by saturation, the opening up to simplification, training and the creation of partnerships to make access to dedicated funds wider, more participated and more democratic. In addition to our roots, Europe's small and medium-sized enterprises have the most ambitious prospects for economic recovery in the future. That is why I think it is important to fully support this report.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the implementation of the thematic objective of 'promoting the competitiveness of SMEs', because I am aware of the fundamental and irreplaceable role of SMEs for the economy of eu regions and territories and their role in terms of employment and competitiveness. I firmly believe that as a result of the economic and financial crisis, levels of poverty and social exclusion have increased in many Member States, along with long-term unemployment, youth unemployment and social inequalities. In certain areas, however, only small and medium-sized enterprises can generate economic recovery and guarantee the future of our young people, and so I firmly believe that cohesion policy is the main instrument for investment in EU territories. I therefore agree with the call to defend cohesion policy in the next financial period as well and to continue the simplification process which makes it easier for local and regional authorities to access available funding. Finally, I believe that Thematic Objective 3 'promoting the competitiveness of SMEs' can and should have more resources given the number of SMEs in Europe and their percentage weight in the number of people employed in the EU.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the thematic objective 'Improving the competitiveness of SMEs'. Small and medium-sized enterprises are the main economic force that creates work. That is why Europe must do everything it can to promote small and medium-sized enterprises. As an expert on small and medium-sized enterprises in the ECR Group, I support this approach.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The promotion of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) is one of the core issues to which the EPP is committed. It is SMEs that are the backbone of our European economy. Not only are 99% of enterprises in the European Union SMEs, But SMEs also create 85% of new jobs. The programme to improve the competitiveness of SMEs foresees an investment volume of EUR 94 billion for the period 2014 to 2020. The aim is to create 354 000 jobs immediately. The programme will also provide financial support to SMEs to continue to invest in innovative projects and the training of their employees.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with my S&D colleagues in favour of this report, which underlines the need for simplification of administrative procedures and better access to financing for SMEs. Furthermore, it stresses the role of local governments which -directly or otherwise – are involved in programme monitoring committees. However, many of the local authorities are still lacking the administrative capacity to properly participate in the Operational Programmes (OPs). Therefore technical assistance and their early involvement in the discussions regarding the OPs are crucial.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of this report which highlights the importance of SMEs in the European economy. It proposes to simplify and reduce bureaucracy, regulation and legislation in access to aid and credit for SMEs.  We stress that the report refers to economic mismanagement and that austerity measures that paralyze demand have a tougher impact on SMEs; and which supports the creation of innovation networks, and the exchange of positive experiences, as well as technical support. To bet on investment in SMEs is to bet on the future, employment and a more sustainable economy.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because I believe that SMEs are an important pillar for the EU economy and a job generator, being responsible for 67% of the EU's private sector jobs and 58% of the added value in the sector. Their role is essential for regional economies, to ensure competitiveness and smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. The EU will provide financial support for 5% of all SMEs and 8% of all new businesses in the EU, in the form of non-refundable aid or practices such as loans, interest rate subsidies and guarantees. Optimising efficiency in the allocation and use of resources by SMEs will result in lower production costs and increased productivity, and European industry could achieve potential savings of EUR 630 billion per year. It is therefore necessary to develop a favourable framework, together with strengthening international cooperation, in order to ensure the integration of European SMEs into global value chains.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with my S&D and EPLP colleagues in favour of this report because it underlines the need for simplification of administrative procedures and a better access to financing of SMEs. Furthermore, it stresses the role of local governments which – directly or indirectly – are involved in programme monitoring committees. However, many of the local authorities are still lacking the administrative capacity to properly participate in the OPs. Therefore technical assistance and their early involvement in the discussions regarding the OPs are crucial.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Improving resource efficiency in SMEs offers enormous potential for the reduction of production costs and for productivity gains. A better use of resources is calculated to represent an overall savings potential of EUR 630 billion per year for European industry. SMEs need a favourable business environment in which green ideas can be easily developed, financed and brought to the market.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the SME report. The report calls for simplification of procedures for granting credit to SMEs. The report has also included reports condemning austerity policies that have caused a number of problems for small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted strongly in favour of this report. There are 23 million SMEs in the EU, which account for around 99% of all businesses, they are responsible for providing over 100 million jobs, which generate two out of every three private sector jobs, and they maintain double the employment growth rate of larger enterprises. SMEs are pivotal to the EU economy, However in order to maintain and further enhance their fundamental contribution to economic growth, social cohesion, innovation and high-quality job creation we need simplified and less regulated access to credit, particularly with regard to microenterprises and start-ups and the regions in which they operate. I hope that the information provided by this report will highlight to the Commission the need to make greater use of ESI Funds to help SMEs seize new trading opportunities by supporting them more to address adjustment costs and the negative impacts of increased international competition.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is centred on the involvement of SMEs in the European Structural and Investment Funds. Although some parts of the report were not aligned with my group’s position (such as the overly critical points on austerity policies), it did contain many positive elements such as simplified access to credit, cutting red tape and exchange of best practices. This is why I have voted in favour of this report.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I took a position in the vote on the report on improving the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises. The report contains many useful ideas. SMEs can undoubtedly play an important role in Europe's recovery, with some 23 million small and medium-sized enterprises making up 99% of all businesses making a significant contribution to economic growth, social cohesion, innovation and job creation. However, in a paragraph of the report, the integration of refugees and migrants will be reflected, for which, as the report explains, adequate support and incentives for small businesses can provide an innovative opportunity. The original contractual vocation of cohesion policy was "to reduce the disparities between the levels of development of the different regions and the lagging behind of the most disadvantaged regions" (Article 174 TFEI). I cannot agree that cohesion funds, which are so important for European regions, should be used for migration-related purposes. It is time to recognize that the mandatory reception quota for resettlement is not working. Migrants and refugees should be helped in their countries of origin and not brought to EU Member States.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report underlines the need for simplification of administrative procedures and a better access to financing of SMEs. It also stresses the role of local governments which are involved in programme monitoring committees. Technical assistance and their early involvement in the discussions regarding the Operational Programmes are crucial. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Implementation Report on the thematic objective 'strengthening the competitiveness of SMEs' - Article 9(3) of the EIA. Regulation on common provisions, given the importance of 23 million SMEs in the EU, accounting for around 99% of all businesses, and realising more than 100 million jobs or two thirds of private sector jobs, and where cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period ensured support for SMEs by doubling the support provided in 2007-2013, amounting to EUR 140 billion.  On a positive note, the thematic objective is to 'strengthen the competitiveness of SMEs' with 13.9% one of the thematic objectives for which the highest percentage of the total amount of funding available is earmarked and is essential to achieve the objectives of cohesion policy and the Europe 2020 strategy. Better absorption should be achieved compared to 2007-2013 and barriers should be removed due to unnecessary administrative burdens, complex management of structural funds, complexity of regulations.  Better coordination and greater consistency of all EU investment policies targeting SMEs is needed. The successful implementation rule is expected to support 801 500 companies and enable over 350 000 new jobs to be created.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Cohesion policy is at best used to mitigate the negative effects of EU policies on employment and investment in SMEs. Under no circumstances will the massive injection of public money, particularly through subsidies, make it possible to make a lasting solution to the difficulties faced by SMEs. I abstained on this text.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because increasing the competitiveness of SMEs is essential for the European economy, both in terms of employment and competitiveness, and is an important element of cohesion policy. It is therefore right to support this thematic objective of the EU Europe 2020 strategy, as in the end the funds concerned will help to provide support to around 801 500 companies and it is estimated that 354 300 new jobs will be created.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the D'Amato report on strengthening the competitiveness of SMEs, which is a priority objective of European regional policy. The report in question takes stock of the results achieved so far through European funds and learns from them for the future. It echoes the proposals I made in the Committee on Regional Development, aimed in particular at providing a stable framework for SMEs and drastically reducing the administrative burden on entrepreneurs. As I argued in my report on THE financing of SMEs, the D'Amato report also calls for a profound simplification of access to European funds for these companies, which are too often discouraged by the complexity of procedures. I believe that the financing and competitiveness of SMEs and SME's must be at the heart of the European Union's priorities, which is why I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides an early assessment of the thematic objective 'Strengthening the Competitiveness of SMEs'. This is the first report on the implementation of this policy for the 2014-2020 fiscal programming period, measuring the achievement of the objectives to date and striving to draw conclusions for the future.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported the report of MEP D’Amato as it moves towards the direction of enabling SMEs to grow and develop. Such an objective requires the creation of a competitive environment that will allow SMEs to flourish. It is, of course, essential to take into consideration the requirements that they have.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report. In order to strengthen the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises, the backbone of the European economy, it identifies some very good and innovative proposals.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it underlines the need for simplification of administrative procedures and a better access to financing of SMEs. Furthermore, it stresses the role of local governments which are involved in programme monitoring committees.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 13 September 2016, we voted in plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on a report on the implementation of the thematic objective 'increasing the competitiveness of SMEs'. SMEs are essential for the economy of EU regions, both in terms of employment and competitiveness. Moreover, it should be noted that cohesion policy is one of the main instruments for investment in growth and job creation in the EU. Given that my colleagues have managed to make explicit reference to the report, inter alia, that, as a result of the economic and financial crisis, not only the level of poverty and social exclusion has increased in many Member States, but also long-term unemployment, youth unemployment and social inequality, and that the problems currently faced by SMEs are partly due to this that the austerity measures implemented by the Member States had dampened demand, I was finally able to support its wording. Furthermore, I consider it a positive change to better incorporate criticism of financial instruments, with the text pointing to the lack of conclusive data on the outputs and results of financial instruments and the very loose link between these financial instruments and the EU's overarching objectives and priorities, and calls on the Commission to further improve the provision of grants and not to promote the use of financial instruments as the primary method of financing.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I took a position in the vote on the report on improving the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises. The report contains many useful ideas. SMEs can undoubtedly play an important role in Europe's recovery, with some 23 million small and medium-sized enterprises making up 99% of all businesses making a significant contribution to economic growth, social cohesion, innovation and job creation. However, in a paragraph of the report, the integration of refugees and migrants will be reflected, for which, as the report explains, adequate support and incentives for small businesses can provide an innovative opportunity. The original contractual vocation of cohesion policy was "to reduce the disparities between the levels of development of the different regions and the lagging behind of the most disadvantaged regions" (Article 174 TFEI). I cannot agree that cohesion funds, which are so important for European regions, should be used for migration-related purposes. It is time to recognize that the mandatory reception quota for resettlement is not working. Migrants and refugees should be helped in their countries of origin and not brought to EU Member States.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerns access to credit for SMEs. Each fund ESI (ESF, EGF, Cohesion fund, EFMM and EARDF) are about ‘enhancing the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises’. SMEs are essential for the economy of EU regions for employment and competitiveness especially with the crisis and austerity measures that the EU is still facing. I voted in favour of this report

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. – I support the report on the implementation of the thematic objective of 'enhancing the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises'. It is fundamental to achieving the cohesion policy and Europe 2020 objectives. It accurately presents the focus on cohesion policies and provides an effective tool for the establishment of operational programmes with a better focus on investment priorities. Last but not least, it also explains the importance of SMEs as the main generator of vacancies, the basis of Member States' economies and an industry that best develops the field of services.  We continue to push for less red tape, easier access to a variety of sources of funding and greater refinement of criteria and the choice of SMEs for support. Although this is the fastest adapting sector, it is also the most vulnerable because it does not have large turnovers. Cohesion policies would further support the growth of regions in the Member States. It is also important to create prerequisites for specialized trainings in order to ensure sustainability and management capacity.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the proposal to promote the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). A fund to promote SMEs was already available during the period 2007-2013, which has been very successful in the field of employment and competitiveness. In fact, according to the Commission's 2014/2015 Annual Report, SMEs contributed almost 70 % to the increase in employment, creating jobs for almost 90 million people. In view of the excellent results, we now want to double the amount of funds intended to promote the competitiveness of SMEs. Taking into account the current situation in which we find ourselves, that is, a period of crisis characterised by an increase in youth unemployment, and also considering that SMEs are essential channels for the development of the economy of European countries, I consider it essential to invest and intervene to promote the growth and competitiveness of SMEs.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report because the cohesion policy it supports is at best a way to mitigate the negative effects of European policies on employment and investment in SMEs. Under no circumstances will the massive injection of public money, particularly through subsidies, make it possible to remedy the difficulties faced by SMEs in a sustainable way (unfair competition, the failure of the euro area, the prohibition of economic patriotism).

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the report on strengthening the competitiveness of SMEs. There are more than 23 million SMEs in the European Union, or 99% of businesses. These SMEs generate 100 million jobs, or two-thirds of private sector jobs. I share most of the ideas in this report, but it does not address the roots of SMEs' difficulties in terms of competitiveness, financing or cash flow. I will mention unfair international competition exacerbated by social, environmental, fiscal and monetary dumping by emerging countries and some Member States; the non-optimality of the euro area, which does not allow for the control of external asymmetric shocks, the single currency which deprives Member States of monetary leverage to reduce competitiveness gaps with their trading partners; and a ban in european treaties on the implementation of economic patriotism, including prioritizing resident companies in the awarding of public contracts.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. Cohesion policy can, at best, mitigate the negative effects of European policies on employment and investment in SMEs. On the other hand, the massive injection of public money, particularly through subsidies, cannot in the long run overcome the difficulties faced by SMEs. I therefore abstained on this issue.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are essential for the economy of the Regions of the Union, both in terms of employment and competitiveness. The European Structural and Investment Funds (EIE) - through their thematic objectives (OT) - contribute to improving the competitiveness of SMEs.  The report calls for simplification of administrative procedures and better access to SME funding. It also emphasizes the role of local entities that — directly or indirectly – are involved in the management of the EIE Funds. However, most local entities lack the administrative capacity to participate appropriately in operational programs. In this regard, technical assistance and early participation in discussions on investment priorities in future funding rounds represent two crucial aspects.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it helps to strengthen the capacities of small and medium-sized enterprises, through improving their accessibility to finance, and therefore helping to set jobs and enhance the creation of new opportunities. The report calls for access to simplified and less regulated credit for SMEs, and stresses that SMEs are essential in the economy of the Regions of the Union. It emphasizes that a good part of the problems suffered by SMEs were and are due to austerity policies implemented by Member States.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In 2014-2020, operational programmes have been geared towards a number of strategic objectives, in particular as regards the potential of SMEs, including micro-enterprises, to contribute to high-quality growth and job creation. I support the adoption of this report as I consider SMEs and entrepreneurs need a supportive environment to move towards a circular economy. The European Commission, the European Investment Bank and the European Investment Fund have worked to promote operational programmes that boost credit, at a time of credit constraints in the banking sector.  The idea of this report is to pursue the common objective of investment under the ESI Funds, supporting the implementation of the Union's Europe 2020 Strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that introduces thematic concentration in cohesion policy programming to encourage growth enhancement.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The report tout subsidies for SMEs and calls for them to be increased. I believe that small, medium-sized or large enterprises should compete honestly with each other in the market, without subsidies.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The thematic objective of this report is to enhance the competitiveness of SMEs. To reach this goal we have to honestly analyse existing problems and after that to make recommendations. From my point of view, the important recommendation of this report is to gain simplified and less regulated access to credit, enhancing support from the European funds to SMEs, reducing complexity of implementation of support schemes.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises are both a driver of development and a stable element of economic growth.  In the EU, they account for 99% of all businesses with more than 100 million jobs. Cohesion policy allocates €140 billion to SMEs for 2014-2020, which should prioritise strengthening and increasing their competitiveness. The Commission and the Member States must remove unnecessary administrative barriers, aim at creating simplified but effective legislation and a flexible financial environment that will create better conditions for the establishment of SMEs, promote research and innovation and wider involvement of SMEs in trade. Such an environment will enable them to increase the creation of added value, economic growth and employment.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are essential to the economy of European regions in terms of employment and competitiveness. For the period 2014-2020, more than EUR 63 billion has been allocated to improve the competitiveness of SMEs through European Structural and Investment Funds. In particular, this report calls for a simplification of administrative procedures and easier access to financing for these SMEs. It also underlines the important role that local authorities must play in creating regional strategies for the development of high-performing SMEs. I support this report which encourages the competitiveness of Europe's 23 million SMEs, which are essential tools for the EU's economic development.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the implementation of the thematic objective 'improving the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises' – Article 9(3) of the Regulation laying down common provisions, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. While we agree with most of the ideas in the text, we see no action to achieve this. Moreover, the text does not challenge unfair international competition, the single currency depriving Member States of monetary leverage to reduce competitiveness gaps with their trading partners, or the tightening of credit conditions caused by the Basel III agreements. This cohesion policy is at best effective in mitigating the negative effects of European policies on employment and investment in SMEs, but settling for massive injections of public money will not make a lasting solution to the difficulties encountered. It is, as is often the case, addressing the consequences, not the causes.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. – Regarding the report on implementation of the thematic objective ‘enhancing the competitiveness of SMEs,’ I voted in favour since I believe that in these times of uncertainty, a large number of citizens will benefit from the direct creation of 354 300 new jobs resulting from the support that will be given to companies and enterprises. On the other hand, I also voted favourably because I truly consider that cohesion policy represents the main tool for investment in growth, which in the long-run can have potentially outstanding effects in the development of Member States.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we discussed the situation of SMEs in the EU. It is a sector that creates 2 out of 3 private sector jobs and provides about 100 million jobs in total. In the report, we look in particular at how to facilitate access to finance for SMEs, e.g. through cohesion policy, and better credit policy settings. In the report, we also stress the need for transparency of all financial instruments, as well as the need to focus on reducing unnecessary administrative burdens and simplifying SME entrepreneurship legislation. I supported the report.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises remain the engine of growth, employment and competitiveness in Europe.  From the Union we must do everything we can to improve the conditions under which these companies work, to facilitate their access to finance and to remove bureaucratic obstacles that hinder their activity. My support for the report discussed in this regard, because we must give our full support from Parliament and from all the institutions of the Union so that these entities continue to improve their capacity and their activity.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the implementation of the thematic objective to improve the competitiveness of SMEs because SMEs are undoubtedly essential and essential for the economy of the EU regions in matters relating to employment and competitiveness. SMEs are the backbone of the EU economy and are essential for job creation, they are the main levers for creating sustainable jobs for all Member States. Support, establishment and development of small and medium-sized enterprises as well as micro-enterprises are the main job creation actors in the EU. Local administrations should undoubtedly participate in and monitor all programmes supported by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the European Social Fund (ESF). Bank lending to SMEs should be encouraged and promoted. Finally, SMEs must have a favourable business environment where environmental damage can be avoided and environmental damage can be avoided and green ideas developed. SMEs and entrepreneurs themselves need a supportive environment to gradually move into a circular economy. For these reasons I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This report calls for better conditions for small and medium-sized enterprises. It is important to me that this creates jobs. I can therefore only support the report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report points out that SMEs are essential for the economy of the REGIONS of the Union, both in terms of employment and competitiveness. And it "underlines that the problems faced by SMEs are partly due to the fact that the austerity policies implemented by the Member States have stifled demand". To remedy this, it calls for simplified and less regulated access to credit for SMEs, notably through the ESI Funds (ESF, FEDER, Cohesion Fund, EFMM and FEADER). I regret, however, that there is still reference to the Capital Markets Union, which aims to develop non-bank lending (shadow banking) as a source of financing for SMEs, which can increase the risk of banking dominoes in the event of crises. I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Cohesion policy is at best used to mitigate the negative effects of EU policies on employment and investment in SMEs. Under no circumstances will the massive injection of public money, particularly through subsidies, make it possible to make a lasting solution to the difficulties faced by SMEs. I therefore abstained on this issue.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. Cohesion policy is the main instrument for investment in growth and jobs in the EU, with a budget of over €350 billion by 2020. The concrete results of cohesion policy investment can help to define the current and future growth of regions in the Member States. As a result of the economic and financial crisis, levels of poverty and social exclusion have increased in many Member States – such as long-term unemployment, youth unemployment and social inequalities – and smes can therefore play a relevant and important role in Europe's economic recovery. It is therefore necessary to look at SMEs as a major driver of economic development and growth. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it reiterates Parliament’s commitment to SMEs. The report urges further action, using existing measures, to support our SMEs, namely by making them aware of possible financing opportunities, investment from Member States and implementation of the cohesion policy areas related to SMEs.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. SMEs and start-ups make up most of our industrial fabric. They are essential for the jobs and competitiveness of all regions of the Union. SMEs are the largest employer in Europe. They represent more than 99% of businesses (or 22 million businesses in the EU) and employ more than 100 million Europeans. They are the engine of our economy and must be strong, competitive and innovative. To achieve this, access to financing is an essential prerequisite. The European Investment Fund (EIF) is responding to this demand by making venture capital available. Creating a business and sustaining it is the best way to create jobs. Europe will only return to the path of growth if those who want to invest and create are given the means to do so. Improve access to finance, help flexibility, transparency, professionalisation, increasing funding needs and, of course, entrepreneurship.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: writing – In the area of employment and competitiveness, small and medium-sized enterprises are of great importance to the EU economy. SMEs are the main driver of European long-term economic growth and opportunities for sustainable job creation in the 28 Member States. They account for up to 85% of the creation of new jobs in the EU. The thematic objective of increasing the competitiveness of medium and small enterprises is of primary importance for achieving the objectives of cohesion policy and the Europe 2020 strategy. The report assesses the implementation of this thematic objective, the achievements achieved so far, and focuses on future prospects and expectations. Under the theme 'SME competitiveness', more than EUR 63 billion of ESI Funds were earmarked for programming in 2014-2020 (together with almost EUR 31 billion of national co-financing totalling EUR 94 billion). Around 801 500 companies will receive financial support for the direct creation of 354 300 new jobs and around 396 500 micro, small and medium-sized enterprises will receive funding to invest in the development of people's human capital and skills.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Each of the European Structural and Investment Funds supports a thematic objective. Increasing the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises is the objective of the thematic objective No 3. The Draft Resolution of the Committee on Regional Development states that SMEs account for 85% of the new jobs created and that 20.7 million SMEs account for 67% of private sector employment in the EU, of which 30% is from micro-enterprises. It recalls the EP's earlier finding that "SMEs are the main engines of long-term growth and sustainable job creation in Europe in the 28 Member States" and the EP's position in the negotiations on the thematic objective 3. It takes into account the financial instruments available to support the competitiveness of SMEs and the expected results in the 2014-2020 programming period. It reviews the specific operational programmes for the period 2007-2013, for which most of the funding (more than 80%) has been spent on research, innovation and SME-related areas, including the Hungarian Economic Development Operational Programme. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. We share most of the ideas defended in this report, which, on the other hand, does not put forward any serious and concrete avenues of reflection to achieve these wishful thinking (administrative simplification, access to credit, etc.). This report does not address the roots of SMEs' difficulties in terms of competitiveness, financing or cash flow, namely the euro, the lack of transmission of accommodative monetary policies to the real economy, administrative complexity, etc. In summary, cohesion policy is at best able to mitigate the negative effects of European policies on employment and investment in SMEs. Under no circumstances will the massive injection of public money, particularly through subsidies, make it possible to make a lasting solution to the difficulties faced by SMEs.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that cohesion policy is one of the main public policy instruments to support and strengthen the competitiveness of SMEs. With a budget by 2020 of more than €350 billion, cohesion policy can help define the current and future growth of regions in the Member States. I am voting in favour of this report to strengthen support for SMEs, stressing the importance of doubling support for the period 2007-2013 to EUR 140 billion, the existence of a future participatory platform and the creation of an ecosystem including universities, research centres, social and economic actors and public institutions.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the implementation of the thematic objective "Strengthening the Competitiveness of SMEs" makes no serious and concrete way of thinking to achieve certain broadly shared objectives. Thus, while we can only agree with administrative simplification, the reduction of late payments, or the facilitation of access to credit, this report does not address either the unfair competition that the Union imposes in fact (the detachment directive, etc.), nor the increase in heterogeneity due to the single currency, nor the union's ban on the necessary economic patriotism...

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with my S&D and EPLP colleagues in favour of this report because it underlines the need for simplification of administrative procedures and a better access to financing of SMEs. Furthermore, it stresses the role of local governments which – directly or indirectly – are involved in programme monitoring committees. However, many of the local authorities are still lacking the administrative capacity to properly participate in the OPs. Therefore technical assistance and their early involvement in the discussions regarding the OPs are crucial.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report on strengthening the competitiveness of SMEs. If this objective is essential, especially in the economic context as we know it, I regret the presence in this text of a provision that calls for more integration for migrants. It is essential to distinguish between refugees, who have a special status legally, migrants who may be persons who have been denied asylum and who continue to remain illegally on our territory. The latter are therefore not intended to be integrated, but to be deported.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has always maintained that small and medium-sized enterprises are the backbone of the Union's economy and have enormous potential in terms of job creation. I therefore voted in favour of Mr McDerman's report. D'Amato on the implementation of the thematic objective of promoting the competitiveness of SMEs, as I believe they are the engine of Europe's long-term economic growth as well as the opportunity to create sustainable jobs in the 28 Member States. In the period 2007-2013, through cohesion policy, businesses received EUR 70 billion to support their activities. The objective for the period 2014-2020 is to double the quota, including through the contribution of financial instruments.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Boosting small and medium-sized enterprises is a major objective of the European Structural and Investment Funds. The role of SMEs has undeniably increased in recent years, thanks above all to their positive impact on society and the economy. Small and medium-sized enterprises are mainly supported by the European Union through the financing of operational programmes, thereby encouraging entrepreneurship and the dynamic development of the quality and capacity of services. I would consider it useful to draw up a strategic plan to help EU-supported programmes finally become more ingrained in the European public consciousness.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Structural and Investment funds are the main investment policy tool with a total budget of EUR 454 billion for 2014-2020. I have voted for this report that will allocate more than EUR 63 billion from the European Structural and Investment funds to improve competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises with the expectation of offering support to over 800 000 companies for the creation of over 300 000 jobs during the 2014-2020 programming.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the resolution on the implementation of the thematic objective 'improving the competitiveness of SMEs'. The EU's 23 million SMEs, which account for around 99% of all businesses, make a fundamental contribution to economic growth, social cohesion, innovation and the creation of high-quality jobs, providing more than 100 million jobs. Access to simpler and less regulated credit must take into account the specific characteristics of micro-enterprises and start-ups, as well as those of the regions in which they operate. The Commission, The Member States and regional authorities should pay particular attention to improving access to finance for micro and start-ups wishing to develop. We call on the Commission to increase funding to strengthen the competitiveness of SMEs when it develops cohesion policy for the period after 2020. At the same time, we call on the managing authorities to take into account the specific characteristics and competences of each territory, paying particular attention to underdeveloped, depopulated and high unemployment territories, with a view to promoting both traditional and innovative economic sectors.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ SMEs create jobs and economic growth for the regions of Europe and remain therefore a key priority of the Cohesion Policy. I support this resolution because investment in the SME sector is fundamental for keeping the economy of Europe strong, and the resolution sets out how to achieve this through increased spending on SMEs, using ESI Funds, for the 2014-2020 period. Importantly, it highlights the positive impact of involving local public authorities directly in the management of the ESI Funds in order to create more local awareness about the opportunities that the funds represent for entrepreneurs and SMEs. This should help ensure an efficient and targeted use of the funds.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, which highlights, among other things, the difficulties for SMEs in accessing diversified sources of funding. Coordinated action by the European Investment Bank and the European Investment Fund would help to improve the situation. Another problem is the obstacles to the widespread disclosure of ESI Funds to SMEs, which include administrative burdens, a high number of support schemes, complexity of regulations and procedures, delayed issuance of administrative regulations and the risk of adopting unnecessary additional regulations (gold plating). Measures should therefore be taken to reduce the administrative burden and simplify the procedures for managing the ESI Funds on the part of SMEs, with particular emphasis on audit requirements, flexibility of management, risk assessment and interim evaluation, control system and compliance with competition rules and other EU policies. The bottom point is that some Member States are substantially increasing the burden on these businesses by inadequately high regulatory costs. High costs for fulfilling statistical, tax or other obligations are common. From the EU level, this direction – that is, to reduce these costs – can only be done indirectly.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This implementation report calls for simplified and easier access to credit for SMEs. It emphasises that each ESI Fund (ESF, ERDF, Cohesion fund, EFMM and EARDF) supports 11 thematic objectives and the thematic objective 3 is about ‘enhancing the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises, the agricultural sector and the fisheries and aquaculture sector’ and the related investment priorities for the ERDF. While it was a generally good report, it also made positive reference to the Capital Markets Union aimed at developing non-bank lending (shadow banking), which Sinn Féin strongly opposes. Because of this call being included, I did not vote in favour of the overall report but abstained.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are essential for the economy of EU regions in terms of both employment and competitiveness. During the 2014-2020 programming period, cohesion policy will provide additional support to SMEs, with support for 2007-2013 doubling to EUR 140 billion.  By 2020, SMEs are expected to provide industrial production amounting to at least 20% of Member States' GDP. The report calls on the Commission, when formulating cohesion policy post-2020, to increase funding to strengthen the competitiveness of SMEs.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This report creates better conditions for small and medium-sized enterprises. It is important to me that this creates jobs. That is why I support this report.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. For the 2014-2020 programming period, more than EUR 63 billion has been allocated from the European Structural and Investment Funds for the overall objective of 'SME competitiveness'. This funding is expected to support SMEs in direct job creation and invest in human capital development and people's capacities. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are the backbone of the European economy. The Union has around 23 million SMEs, representing approximately 99% of all enterprises. They contribute to economic growth, social cohesion, innovation and high-quality job creation.  For a more efficient and effective implementation of the objectives described and, to make access to finance easier, this Parliament calls through this report for the simplification of administrative procedures, better access to SME funding and emphasises the role of local entities and the improvement of their technical assistance. That is why I support this report without mitigation.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are essential for the economy of EU regions in terms of employment and competitiveness, which is why I voted in favour of the report on improving the competitiveness of SMEs. This report underlines the need to simplify administrative procedures and improve ACCESS to finance for SMEs. It also underlines the role of local governments which - directly or indirectly - participate in monitoring committees for the programme. However, many of the local authorities still lack the administrative capacity to participate normally in operational programmes (CPs). Therefore, technical assistance and their timely participation in the discussions on OPs is vital. Finally, bank lending to SMEs should be encouraged and promoted.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is being hypocritical when it talks about SMEs. Far from helping SMEs, its red tape and over-regulation makes the life of small business owners a misery. Fortunately Brexit means this will not be our problem for much longer, and we look forward to a positive and lighter regulatory climate in post-Brexit Britain.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution as I believe that it is favourable to SMEs. The report introduces thematic concentration in the cohesion policy programming 2014-2020. Through thematic concentration, operational programmes appeared to be better targeted towards a limited number of strategic goals, in particular in terms of growth enhancement and high quality job creation potential for SMEs.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report because SMEs, which form the backbone of Europe’s economy, need more financing options after the financial crisis caused banks to cut back on lending. As SMEs have more limited financing options and are in need of macroeconomic stability and a stable regulatory environment, this report urges the EU’s proposed Capital Market Union to help SMEs gain access to other financing sources like investment capital and crowdfunding. Besides, it also calls for a one-stop shop to help SMEs get financing and to avoid heavy regulation in getting that financing, so that SMEs can fulfil their job creation potential.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Investing in increasing the competitiveness of SMEs is one of the main objectives of EU cohesion policy 2014-2020, and strong SMEs are a guarantor of society's development.  As an MEP, I will always give my voice and accept proposals to facilitate the development and strengthening of SMEs, both through the delivery of financial support and the easing of administrative burdens, as they are the main drivers of the EU economy. SMEs employ the most of our citizens, ensure job creation and thus play a significant role in ultimately overcoming and recovering from the economic crisis. We need to foster the competitiveness of all forms of SMEs, facilitate their access to finance and credit, simplify legislation, reduce red tape, facilitate access to information, encourage SMEs to export and internationalise. Here, it is particularly important to emphasise the encouragement of "green" businesses creating "green jobs" by contributing to sustainable development as well.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. I share most of the ideas defended in this report, which, on the other hand, does not put forward any serious avenue of reflection to achieve these wishful thinking: - administrative simplification in favour of the beneficiaries of the European Structural Funds; - reducing late payments related to Cohesion Policy Funds; - simplification of access to credit for SMEs... This report does not address the roots of the difficulties faced by SMEs: - unfair competition through social, environmental, fiscal and monetary dumping of certain emerging countries or Member States; - a single currency that deprives Member States of monetary leverage to reduce competitiveness gaps with their trading partners; - prohibiting in European treaties the implementation of economic patriotism (priority for national companies in the awarding of public contracts); - tougher credit conditions caused by the Basel III agreements. Cohesion policy barely mitigates the negative effects of EU policies on employment and investment in SMEs. Under no circumstances will the massive injection of public money, particularly through subsidies, make it possible to make a lasting solution to the difficulties faced by SMEs. I therefore prefer to refrain from dealing with this text, which is incapable of addressing the causes of the problems it raises.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ 23 million SMEs in the EU, accounting for around 99% of all businesses, offer more than 100 million jobs or two-thirds of private sector jobs and continue to see double the rate of employment growth compared to larger companies, contributing substantially to economic growth, social cohesion, innovation and the creation of high-quality jobs.  All this despite the fact that only 13% of European SMEs engage in commercial activities and investments on global markets. SMEs eligible for ESI Funds (ESI Funds) funding, as they operate in a competitive environment and have to deal with a number of constraints, such as cash flow constraints, are greatly affected by complex and unstable rules and administrative burdens, in particular the fact that administrative costs are completely disproportionate to the financial resources allocated to them , deadlines for processing funding applications and the need to pay advances. For all of the above, I strongly support the adoption of this report.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Statistics show that small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are essential for the economy of EU regions, both in terms of employment and competitiveness. It is precisely in support of the predominantly Small and Medium-sized Enterprises that EUR 70 billion was devoted in the period 2007-2013, with the help of cohesion policy. In the period 2014-2020, the aim is to double this amount. I support the intention to support SMEs with around EUR 94 billion in the 2014-2020 programming period, but I believe that even more support needs to be given to SMEs. If the objectives set out in this report were to be met, inter alia, to provide support to more than 800,000 companies that will directly create more than 350,000 new jobs, I would consider this extremely successful for the European Union's employment policy. Personally, I would like this legislation to achieve one equally important objective, i.e. to reduce production costs and the associated increase in productivity, which would prevent environmental damage and lead to a transition to a low-carbon economy.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have always been convinced that the priority of EU action must be job creation. In order to create jobs, it is necessary to adequately support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). They are crucial to the economy of the EU regions, both in terms of employment and competitiveness. For the period 2007-2013, €70 billion was allocated, with the help of cohesion policy, to support businesses, in particular SMEs, and the target for the period 2014-2020 is to double this amount. The achievement of these ambitious targets must be properly monitored by the European Parliament. Our task must be to avoid wasting resources but, above all, to support the Commission's action in formulating the most appropriate proposals. With regard to promoting the competitiveness of SMEs, I believe it is essential to invest in employee training and to encourage the recruitment of talented and talented young people. I am convinced that the human factor is the determining factor for the success of companies. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 As the programming phase of the ESI Funds comes to an end, the REGI own-initiative report focuses on the first conclusions of the involvement of SMEs and, more specifically, on the implementation of the third of the eleven thematic objectives contained in the Common Provisions Regulation (Article 9), strengthening the competitiveness of SMEs. This report contains a number of positive elements, including an emphasis on the key role of SMEs in the EU economy and in the successful implementation of cohesion policy, cutting red tape and encouraging the use of financial instruments, simplified access to loans, diversification of funding sources, the importance of technical assistance and early involvement in discussions on investment priorities in future funding rounds, as well as the exchange of best practices between Member States. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Strengthening the competitiveness of SMEs is a major thematic objective of the European Cohesion Policy and the Europe 2020 strategy. The thematic focus has had the beneficial effect of better guiding investment priorities, and here in favour of European SMEs. I therefore voted in favour of this report which assesses the achievement of the objectives related to this thematic objective in the context of the 2014-2020 financial programme.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. Recent and as a consequence of the economic and financial crisis, levels of unemployment, poverty, exclusion and social inequality have evolved worryingly in many Member States. Considering that the Union's 23 million SMEs account for around 99% of all enterprises, and whereas these SMEs generate two out of three jobs in the European single market, it is logical to assume that their role is important in the economic and social recovery of the Member States. Framed in the 3rd thematic objective of the European Structural Investment Funds (ESIF), the strengthening of the competitiveness of SMEs is of great importance in achieving the objectives of cohesion policy and the objective of the so-called Europe 2020. Among the various suggestions made, this report stresses the importance of increasing the effectiveness of sme support mechanisms through simplification of procedures, as well as through better coordination and coherence between European investment policies. For the above and because I believe that SMEs are the driving force of the European economy, I agree that the support of The ESI Funds for SMEs should be strengthened and i am voting in favour of this report.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 In recent years, the Union has paid particular attention to SMEs in the Member States, by running numerous programmes aimed at both attracting citizens, and in particular young people, in the creation and strengthening of new SMEs and by encouraging better development of senior SMEs on the market. I believe that the most thoughtful thing we can do is to focus on the programmes that are already under way, and to ensure that they achieve their objectives.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is being hypocritical when it talks about SMEs. Far from helping SMEs, its red tape and over-regulation makes the life of small business owners a misery. Fortunately Brexit means this will not be our problem for much longer, and we look forward to a positive and lighter regulatory climate in post-Brexit Britain.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I think it is imperative to strengthen the competitiveness of SMEs in the fisheries and aquaculture sectors. SMEs are essential for the economy of eu regions, both in terms of employment and competitiveness, and it is expected that by 2020 support will be able to reach around 801 500 companies for the creation of 354 300 new direct jobs. Companies (including cooperative enterprises and the social economy) will receive funding to invest in the development of human capital and in the skills of workers. SMEs form a very significant part of the EU economy and have a huge capacity to create real jobs. Investing in the more efficient management of SME resources offers enormous potential for reducing production costs and increasing productivity, boosting savings of EUR 630 billion per year for European industry. It is necessary to allow SMEs to develop a green environment (remanufacturing, repair, maintenance, recycling), thereby contributing to the resolution of environmental challenges, while promoting economic growth and job creation.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The Commission's annual report on European SMEs for 2014/2015 indicates that in 2014 SMEs accounted for 71.4% of the increase in employment in the non-financial business sector and employed around 90 million people – i.e. 67% of total employment. Small and medium-sized enterprises are therefore essential for the economy of the EU regions, both in terms of employment and competitiveness. I believe that if local authorities want to participate more in the management of ESI Funds, central administrations should give them the possibility of receiving more decision-making powers, starting with the selection of projects. Technical assistance and early participation in discussions on investment priorities in future funding phases will contribute to this process. As most countries and regions have only just begun to launch the programmes, there is scope for managing authorities and the Commission to apply more systematically the partnership principle enshrined in the Regulation and the Code of Conduct.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of the Report on improving the competitiveness of SMEs, as they are essential for the economy of all regions of the Union. In the period 2014-2020, it is expected to achieve, with the EIE Funds for the programme, to increase job creation and invest in the development of human capital and people's capacities.  They are also indicated as objectives to promote entrepreneurship, develop and apply new business models, support the creation and expansion of capacities for product and service development and support market growth.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. SMEs account for 99% of all businesses and make a vital contribution to the economic growth of the European Union by providing more than 100 million jobs, or two thirds of private sector jobs.  I therefore voted in favour of this report which encourages the Commission to further integrate the financing of the competitiveness of SMEs in the preparation of the cohesion policy after 2020.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The thematic objective "Strengthening the competitiveness of Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs)" is of paramount importance in achieving the objectives of cohesion policy and the Europe 2020 strategy. Between 2007 and 2013, €70 billion was allocated under cohesion policy to support companies that created 263 000 jobs, with this target expected to be doubled for the period 2014-2020. The introduction of these thematic objectives in cohesion policy programming for the period 2014-2020 provided an effective tool for designing operational programmes with a more focus on investment priorities.  By the reason of the thematic concentration and particularly of this objective, there was a better orientation of the operational programmes, directing them to a more limited number of strategic objectives, with repercussions on improving growth and the quality of job creation for SMEs.  In this sense, I consider this report to be quite important in that it makes, on the one hand, a positive assessment of this thematic objective, and, on the other hand, the scenario for the 2014-2020 financial programming period, measuring the achievement of the results achieved to date and trying to draw conclusions for the remaining Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. The 23 million SMEs in the European Union account for 99% of all businesses and contribute centrally to economic growth and job creation. They provide more than 100 million jobs, or two-thirds of private sector jobs.  I voted in favour of this report, which provides an early assessment of the thematic objective of strengthening the competitiveness of SMEs. The European Union must support SMEs and act to strengthen their competitiveness. They are real economic drivers for our economy.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of this report which highlights the importance of SMEs in the European economy. It proposes to simplify and reduce bureaucracy, regulation and legislation in access to aid and credit for SMEs.  We stress that the report refers to economic mismanagement and that austerity measures that paralyze demand have a tougher impact on SMEs; and which supports the creation of innovation networks, and the exchange of positive experiences, as well as technical support. To bet on investment in SMEs is to bet on the future, employment and a more sustainable economy.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the implementation of the objective 'Improving the competitiveness of SMEs' (small and medium-sized enterprises), as they are the backbone of the European economy and have enormous job creation potential. SMEs can only successfully participate in global value chains if a more favourable framework is created and international cooperation is expanded. Strengthening their competitiveness through a wide range of measures safeguards existing jobs and creates new ones. It will also make an important contribution to achieving the Europe 2020 objectives for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. Significant progress has been made in sectors such as networking, innovation and knowledge, as well as culture and education.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. SMEs form the backbone of the European production system and are the main driver of economic growth, accounting for around 99 % of all enterprises and 67 % of total employment in the non-financial sector. I agree with the own-initiative report, which recommends further strengthening support from the European Structural and Investment Funds for SMEs, reducing administrative burdens, diversifying sources of finance and simplifying access to credit, also taking into account the particular characteristics of micro-enterprises, start-ups and the context in which they operate. In order to ensure the effectiveness of the post-2020 cohesion policy, I hope that these recommendations from Parliament can guide the discussion and interventions to strengthen the competitiveness of SMEs and to remove obstacles that prevent or slow down their growth. I have therefore decided to vote in favour of the report.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the European Union there are 23 million small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) providing 100 million jobs, developing about a quarter export activities. As mentioned in the report, I consider it important to strengthen the transparency and participation of all regional and local authorities, civil society actors, entrepreneurs and other relevant stakeholders, in particular in the process of defining the requirement for calls for proposals, in order to better target the needs of final beneficiaries. There are challenges that can clearly turn into opportunities. These are the cases of the needs of adapting SMEs to the decisions of COP 21 and the possibility of integrating refugees and migrants, as is pointed out in the report. For these reasons too, I voted positively.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
