text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises are crucial for the economy of EU regions in terms of both employment and competitiveness. It is therefore important to appreciate the fact that eur 70 billion has been allocated to support businesses, mainly SMEs, under cohesion policy for the period 2007-2013, while the objective for 2014-2020 is to double this amount, which is to contribute to a greater use of the various financial instruments.  In the European Parliament, we often emphasise that SMEs are the cornerstone of the EU economy and have great employment potential, as they account for 85% of new jobs created. It is also estimated that more than 20 million SMEs provide more than 67% of private sector employment in the EU, with micro-enterprises accounting for 30%. SMEs are therefore the main driver of long-term European economic growth and the creation of sustainable jobs in the Member States. Increasing the efficiency of the use of resources by SMEs offers great opportunities for reducing production costs and increasing productivity. It is estimated that better use of resources represents an overall savings potential of EUR 630 billion for European industry. Preventing environmental damage and moving to a low-carbon economy are social challenges that create new opportunities for companies to market green products and services. SmEs need a favourable environment in which green solutions can be easily developed, financed and marketed.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted with my S&D and EPLP colleagues in favour of this report because underlines the need for simplification of administrative procedures and a better access to financing of SMEs. Furthermore, it stresses the role of local governments which – directly or indirectly – are involved in programme monitoring committees. However, many of the local authorities are still lacking the administrative capacity to properly participate in the OPs. Therefore technical assistance and their early involvement in the discussions regarding the OPs are crucial

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are of great importance to the economies of the EU regions in terms of both employment and competitiveness. I am therefore pleased that this report focuses on this key role played by SMEs. I voted in favour.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are undoubtedly the backs of the EU economy and have huge potential, especially in the area of employment and competitiveness. I voted in favour of the proposed resolution because it proposes to continue the 2014-2020 programming period with support for SMEs (support will be doubled from 2007-2013 to EUR 14 billion). This is evidenced by the fact that SMEs accounted for 71.4% of the increase in employment in 2014 in the non-financial business sector and employed almost 90 million people in 2014, representing 67% of total employment and creating 58% of the added value of the sector. I am glad that 73 500 start-ups were supported under cohesion policy in the period 2007-2013 and more than 263 000 jobs were created in SMEs. Unfortunately, even during the last programming period, we were able to encounter some obstacles (the consequences of the economic crisis, the complex management of the Structural Funds and the administrative burden, under-spending by SMEs) that threatened the successful and timely implementation of the thematic objective 'Making SMEs more competitive' (TC 3). It is therefore appropriate that we learn from these errors and prevent a repetition of these problems on the basis of the measures taken for the 2014-2020 programming period.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Small and medium-sized enterprises are the main drivers of the green economy and create green jobs. At the same time, they are very diverse and include a large number of locally based micro-enterprises, which often operate in traditional sectors, as well as an increasing number of start-ups and fast-growing companies.  This is why it is important that medium and small enterprises be supported under cohesion policy while assessing whether the funds allocated to them are spent effectively. Between 2007 and 2013, with cohesion policy support, €70 billion was earmarked to support mainly SMEs, and in the period 2014 to 2020 this amount is expected to double, as support for such businesses is one of the priorities of the European Union's cohesion policy and, in particular, the Regional Development Fund.  In its report, Parliament calls on the European Commission to follow the principles of the Circular Economy Package in order to promote more sustainable economic growth and create new quality jobs, with a focus on promoting green jobs.  Given the important role of small and medium-sized enterprises in the European green economy, I supported this report.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. 23 million SMEs, 99% of all EU businesses, provide 100 million jobs or two thirds of all private sector jobs. They therefore make a fundamental contribution to economic growth, social cohesion, innovation and quality employment. Moreover, they are an important driving force behind the green economy and job creation. The report on improving the competitiveness of SMEs provides for a very balanced approach with a view to strengthening green SMEs and local markets, in particular through support for local SMEs. In addition, the report highlights the importance of thematic concentration and its role in sustainable development, the quality dimension of job creation and the involvement of SMEs in the principle of partnership, including specific organisations aimed at eco-entrepreneurs. After a few additions to circular economy, the Small Business Act and entrepreneurship for young people, and with a focus on green jobs and the green economy, the report meets many green requirements and I voted in favour.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The D'Amato report takes a position on making the most of the potential for job creation for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). SMEs provide about two thirds of jobs in the private sector. In order to further strengthen the potential for job creation, SMEs should focus on shaping EU enterprise policy. The report stresses that reducing administrative and regulatory burdens, as well as improving the quality of legislation and enforcement, should relieve SMEs. In addition, the report emphasises that fair conditions of competition are created for SMEs compared to large enterprises. Small and local businesses are particularly disadvantaged in over-regulated and bureaucratic management systems. Measures are needed to reduce market disadvantages for SMEs in such a way as to significantly increase their employment potential. I consider the report as a whole to be very balanced and I have therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ small and medium-sized enterprises suffer from a lack of access to capital compared to large corporations. In line with the strategy of the current European Commission, we want to make it easier for them to raise funds for the development of their business, the use of modern technologies and increasing market competitiveness. The result will be a reduction in unemployment and the development of regions, as small and medium-sized enterprises are often an important economic and social actor within them.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the implementation of the thematic objective 'Improving the competitiveness of SMEs' (Article 9(3) of the Common Provisions Regulation). The report deals with the competitiveness of SMEs and, in particular, how cohesion policy, with a budget of more than €350 billion by 2020, can contribute to this as the main subsidy instrument in the EU. I reject cohesion policy as a purely redistributing instrument. The AfD stands for independent and strong local authorities in Germany. We want to enable regional and local self-government and guarantee subsidiarity, so that regional peculiarities and peculiarities can be maintained. We want to give more weight to federalism. The AfD is thus already somewhat sceptical about a policy of regional balance within Germany. At EU level, it has nothing to do with it. We stand for strong and independent nation states. I am all the more opposed to the abuse of cohesion policy for central planning support and subsidisation of SMEs. It is not the role of the state to redistribute funds to financially support supposedly rewarding industries or a certain class of companies – because that penalises taxpayers.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The aim of strengthening the competitiveness of SMEs is important for achieving the objectives of cohesion policy and strategy Europe 2020 and the report gives us the first assessment of this key thematic objective and gives us the first indicators on this policy in general for the 2014-2020 financial period. The economic and financial crisis has led to rising levels of long-term unemployment, youth unemployment and social inequality in many Member States. Therefore, SMEs can play a relevant and important role in Europe's recovery.  I support the proposal for a resolution on the implementation of the thematic objective 'strengthening the competitiveness of SMEs' as this objective fosters job creation and economic recovery.  I come from Croatia where there are various microenter enterprises at the local level that are often active in traditional sectors and there are more and more start-ups and fast-growing innovative companies, so it is necessary to simplify national and European legislation in order to facilitate access to lending for small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the thematic objective to increase the competitiveness of SMEs. As we have repeatedly noted, SMEs form the backbone of the European economy and as such play an important role in Europe's recovery from the economic and financial crisis, which has increased the poverty rate in many Member States, as well as long-term unemployment, youth unemployment and social inequalities.  I support the call on the Commission and the Member States to take into account the added value of SMEs' projects for development and innovation in traditional sectors, as this will stimulate job creation while preserving local and regional business specificities, taking into account the principles of sustainability

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Improving the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises is not just a matter of financing. The Union should adopt measures and rules that promote the establishment and development of small and medium-sized enterprises and support their survival within the competitive environment with large enterprises, such as the development of a single tax practice for small and medium-sized enterprises that allows taxation after a certain grace period or imposes uniform tax scales in all Member States.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the thematic objective 'Improving the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises'. One of the thematic objectives of investments under the European Structural and Investment Funds is to increase the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises, the importance of which has been rightly emphasised in the report several times. I agree with the report that it is essential for the 23 million Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises in Europe to simplify European, national and regional legislation and to facilitate access to credit. Given that the widespread access of SMEs to the European Structural and Investment Funds is indeed hampered by the large number and variety of support programmes, the complexity of the rules and procedures, I endorse the call for the High Level Group on Simplification to come up with concrete proposals on how to streamlin these procedures. I also support the report's call for help for SMEs to overcome barriers to access to traditional banking services and for the use of other funding opportunities to be encouraged. Any move to improve the competitiveness of SMEs, as noted in the report, must, of course, be based on respect for human rights and workers' rights and on the highest possible level of environmental protection.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises account for around 99% of all EU companies, providing 67% of total employment in the unfunded business sector. The EU Regulation establishing common rules for the European Structural and Investment Funds lists 11 thematic objectives setting out funding rules. The thematic objective 3 on strengthening the competitiveness of SMEs has one of the highest pools of funds. Between 2014 and 2020, almost EUR 64 billion was foreseen to support SMEs. The additional use of financial instruments to stimulate bank loans aims to double this amount. The expected results are 300 000 new jobs and assistance to almost one million SMEs. Specific measures include supporting entrepreneurship and business creation, investing in research and innovation, developing new business models, products and services, knowledge transfer and business cooperation, improving the skills of employees, promoting self-employment, or creating social enterprises. That is why it is so important to assess early the achievement of this key objective of improving the competitiveness of SMEs, both in terms of achievements so far and in terms of future proposals.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I supported this motion for a resolution, as support for SMEs from the ESD Fund should be more accessible. SMEs have great potential for economic growth, and these enterprises are important employers, especially in sparsely populated areas.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The D'Amato report analyses at holistic level the different aspects concerning the implementation of Thematic Objective (TOs) 3 in the 2014-2020 programming of the Structural and Investment Funds. Increased investment to promote access to credit, less bureaucracy, less delays in public administration payments, more transparency in public procurement and more circular economy are some of the important points that were voted on and approved by a very large majority in our 5-star colleague's report this week in Strasbourg. With this vote, Parliament also recognises that the crisis in European SMEs was also caused by 'austerity policies implemented by the Member States and the European Union', policies that 'stifled domestic demand'. The report points the way forward: key points are, for example, socially responsible internationalisation and an integrated process of European regional policy and policy, without forgetting to facilitate the transition to the circular economy and to initiate a decisive process of decarbonisation and self-production of energy in favour of renewable sources. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is key to the future development and prosperity of our economy and I hereby support it. SMEs are essential for the economy of EU regions, in terms of employment and competitiveness. ESI funds – through their Thematic Objectives (TO) – contribute to enhancing the competitiveness of the SMEs. For the 2014-2020 financing period more than EUR 63 bn have been allocated to the TO 3 ‘Enhancing the competitiveness of SMEs’ which – together with the national co-financing – will amount to EUR 94 bn. For the 2014-2020 programming period support is expected to be given to more than 800 000 SMEs; 396 500 micro, small and medium sized enterprises will receive ESF funding. It is important to focus on promoting entrepreneurship, developing and implementing new business models and supporting growth in national and international markets. Nonetheless, the need for simplification of administrative procedures and a better access to financing for SMEs remains. Furthermore, it stresses the role of local governments which – directly or indirectly – are involved in programme monitoring committees. However, many of the local authorities are still lacking the administrative capacity to participate in the OPs. Therefore, technical assistance and their early involvement in the discussions regarding the OPs are crucial.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I of course voted for this text. The common objective of investment under the ESI Funds is to promote the implementation of the European Union's Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. Each ESI Fund supports 11 thematic objectives, and the third ('OT 3') relates to 'improving the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises, the agricultural sector (for the Feader) and the fisheries and aquaculture sector (for The Feamp)' as well as the corresponding investment priorities for the Feder. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are essential for the employment and competitiveness of the regions of the European Union. For the period 2007-2013, the cohesion policy has provided EUR 70 billion to support businesses, mainly SMEs. For the period 2014-2020, the aim is to double this amount (particularly through financial instruments). In the new programming period, investments with SMEs will be made via OT 3. At the same time, however, it will be possible to invest in SMEs under other thematic objectives.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ SMEs are an indispensable driving force for the EU economy, in terms of growth, employment and competitiveness, as they account for around 99% of all businesses and provide over 100 million jobs in the EU. However, they often face multiple challenges due to their size. This is why I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of the thematic objective ‘enhancing the competitiveness of SMEs’, which is one of the objectives of the ESI Funds. This should be done by simplifying access to credit and encouraging innovation, with a special focus on the circular economy, by increasing coordination and consistency among all EU investment policies, by encouraging the involvement of local authorities and SMEs themselves in the implementation of programmes. It is particularly important to continue removing administrative burden for SMEs when managing ESI Funds by bringing the cohesion policy in line with the reality of SMEs.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal to increase the competitiveness of SMEs.  Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are essential for the EU economy in terms of employment and competitiveness. It expects to receive support from about 801,500 companies, which would directly create 354,300 new jobs.  SMEs are the main driver of long-term European economic growth and the potential for creating sustainable jobs in the 28 Member States.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of this report which highlights the importance of SMEs in the European economy. It proposes to simplify and reduce bureaucracy, regulation and legislation in access to aid and credit for SMEs.  We stress that the report refers to economic mismanagement and that austerity measures that paralyze demand have a tougher impact on SMEs; and which supports the creation of innovation networks, and the exchange of positive experiences, as well as technical support. To bet on investment in SMEs is to bet on the future, employment and a more sustainable economy.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ SMEs are the backbone of the European economy and the main employers in our job market. I hope that these recommendations are useful for the Commission and Member States to implement new policies to make SMEs more competitive.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. There are more than 23 million SMEs in the European Union, or 99% of the total number of businesses. These SMEs generate 100 million jobs, or two-thirds of private sector jobs. It is recalled that 14% of the available EU funds are allocated to SMEs, i.e. more than 140 billion euros for the 2014-2020 programming period. This cohesion policy is at best able to mitigate the negative effects of European policies on employment and investment in SMEs. Under no circumstances will the massive injection of public money, particularly through subsidies, make it possible to make a lasting solution to the difficulties faced by these SMEs. I chose abstention because some of the provisions of the report are appropriate.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are currently 23 million SMEs in the European Union, representing 99% of all businesses. They create more than 100 million jobs, or two-thirds of private sector jobs, thus contributing considerably to economic growth. In this regard, this report recommends strengthening their support through the European Structural and Investment Funds. In order to facilitate the creation of SMEs, the report stresses the need to improve access to finance for micro-enterprises and start-ups that want to develop. Thus, interest rates to finance SMEs and large companies should be equalised. The report also draws attention to the fact that excessive red tape has discouraged certain SMEs from applying for the proposed funding, and in this respect the Commission is asked to analyse this issue quickly. Other recommendations made in this report to the Member States and the Commission would be: the creation of a structured dialogue between the European Investment Bank and the European Investment Fund, with the aim of improving and facilitating SMEs' access to diversified sources of financing, or the establishment at national and regional level of state aid conditions which do not disadvantage SMEs. I therefore voted for the report on improving the competitiveness of SMEs.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I am optimistic about the motion for a resolution supporting the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises, given the impact their activities have on economic development, job creation and innovation. Local authorities can support the most effective actors through thorough selection, partnership and appropriate management. Increasing the efficiency of the SME sector can contribute to a more economical use of resources, lower production costs, increased productivity and thus generate savings for later innovations. I have chosen to vote in support of this initiative.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The common objective of investments under the European Structural and Investment Funds is to implement the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. I voted in favour of this document.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I vote in favour of this report which highlights the importance of SMEs in the European economy. It proposes to simplify and reduce bureaucracy, regulation and legislation in access to aid and credit for SMEs.  We stress that the report refers to economic mismanagement and that austerity measures that paralyze demand have a tougher impact on SMEs; and which supports the creation of innovation networks, and the exchange of positive experiences, as well as technical support. To bet on investment in SMEs is to bet on the future, employment and a more sustainable economy.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for, as SMEs are key drivers in the green economy and for the creation of green jobs. It is therefore important to support SMEs in cohesion policy and to assess whether resources have been spent effectively.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I call on the Commission and the Member States to urgently find a long-term solution to the accumulated backlog of payments related to regional policy and to properly apply the Late Payments Directive (2011/7/EU) in order to ensure that SMEs, as project partners, do not lose interest in participating in support programmes and projects in the current programming period due to late payments; I also note that more consistent compliance with this directive, which requires, inter alia, public authorities to make payments for the goods and services they acquire within 30 days contributes to creating the conditions necessary for the stabilisation and growth of SMEs.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on implementation of the thematic objective ‘enhancing the competitiveness of SMEs’ – Article 9(3) of the Common Provisions Regulation. The shared objective of investments under the ESI funds is to provide support for the delivery of the EU’s Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. The report highlights that there is an overall need for mechanisms that help to simplify the business environment and speed up the process of setting up new businesses with REFIT to support SME competitiveness and absorption of ESI Funds. I voted in favour because I believe that small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are essential for the economy of EU regions, both in terms of employment and competitiveness.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a report highlighting the importance of improving the competitiveness of SMEs with the use of cohesion policy tools. Further progress is important through the thematic focus on cohesion policy objectives, mainly competitiveness and employment through support for SMEs in areas such as innovation, in order to contribute more strongly to the objectives of the 2020 strategy. As always, small and medium-sized enterprises are one of the vital drivers in the vast majority of European regions. That is why it is necessary to promote the competitiveness of SMEs through the tools that this report rightly points out, and I therefore consider it necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'SMEs in Europe are an extremely important engine of the economy and the creator of jobs. I voted in favour of this report to remind the European Commission that its legislative initiatives should pay more attention to the individuality of SMEs. There is a clear need for mechanisms that simplify the business environment and accelerate the start-up process of new enterprises with the help of Refit. We need to be able to strengthen the competitiveness of SMEs and support the use of ESI funds more. More and better supported SMEs are positive for economy, employment and innovation.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The shared objective of ESI Funds investments is to provide support for the implementation of the EU Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.  SMEs are essential for the economy of EU regions (99% of businesses and 85% of jobs) in terms of employment and competitiveness. For the period 2007-2013, the support of the cohesion policy dedicated to enterprises was EUR 70 billion, mainly for SMEs. For the period 2014-2020, the aim is to double this amount (also with the help of financial instruments). This report reinforces the need to increase the efficiency of SMEs by promoting circular economy practices, the promotion of "green jobs" and international affirmation. This position does not erase all the reservations we have regarding the objectives underlying the cohesion policies that condition investment and tie regional development policies to the neoliberal agendas of the 2020 agenda.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report points out that SMEs, which provide the most jobs in the EU, are the driving force behind the European economy. It also calls for simplified and less regulated access to credit for micro-enterprises and start-ups. As the report contains good approaches to improving and supporting small and medium-sized enterprises, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the thematic objective 'promoting the competitiveness of SMEs' as SMEs play an essential role in the economy of EU regions, in terms of employment and competitiveness. For the 2014-2020 funding period, more than €63 billion has been allocated to enhance the competitiveness of SMEs. I support this report because it reiterates the need for simplification of administrative procedures and the need for better access to finance for SMEs. I would also stress the importance of central governments providing local authorities with wider decision-making powers in the management of EIS funds.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with my S&D and EPLP colleagues in favour of this report because it underlines the need for simplification of administrative procedures and improved access to financing of SMEs. There is no doubt that SMEs represent the backbone of our economy, and we must facilitate their ability to operate and trade across Europe. Any strategy on SMEs must include support for cooperatives and alternative business models that have so much potential for a more ethical way of doing business, and can bring more flexibility and accountability to the private sector. We must also ensure that vulnerable excluded groups have access to entrepreneurship education, particularly women and girls, who face greater obstacles and prejudice. We must make sure that we share best practice on enabling women and girls to become entrepreneurs.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour because the competitiveness of the EU’s SMEs is one of my top priorities. It reiterates that fact that SMEs are the backbone of the EU economy. This means that we need to facilitate and support them where needed. It recognises the biggest problems of today and proposes clear solutions that I can only support. One of those measures is to increase access to finance. This can be done by removing institutional and technical barriers. Also, they should be better informed about alternative sources of funding. In addition, Member States should ensure coherent and consistent investment policies. Herein, transparency plays a very important role. I also agree that the European Investment Bank and the European Investment Fund are important actors. But overall, we need to keep in mind that we need to cut red tape and simplify legislation where possible. I believe that all-together, these measures and guidelines will result in more competitive SMEs, more jobs and a stronger economy.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises provide 85% of employment in the EU labour sector and present potential for job creation. The report highlights their dominant role in the structure of the European economy and takes into account the conclusions of the implementation of the third objective, namely strengthening the competitiveness of SMEs, in the programming of the European Structural and Investment Funds. The report highlights obstacles preventing and hindering SMEs' wide access to funds, such as the large number of aid programmes and their fragmentation, the high complexity of rules and procedures, delays in the implementation of implementing acts and the risk of excessively rigorous implementation.  I voted in favour of the report, which points out that over-regulation and administrative burdens undermine innovation potential, hinder the development of SMEs, and recognise the need to promote market competitiveness by encouraging the use of financial instruments, simplified access to loans and diversification of funding sources.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report, which I supported, was adopted by a large majority by the colleagues of the committee responsible for Regional Development. The text submitted highlights all the individual issues relating to more effective financing of SMEs at European and local level.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report we have adopted today is aimed at holistically analysing the promotion of the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the new 2014-2020 programming. It stresses that the 23 million SMEs are very diverse and therefore need a legislative approach adapted to different contexts. The report contains several positive aspects: firstly, it is asked to take into account the additional value of SME projects for the development and innovation of traditional sectors; there is also a call to the circular economy, in order to promote more sustainable economic growth; Finally, it is recalled how important it is for SMEs that public procurement is organised in a transparent, coherent and innovative way. Other aspects that led me to vote in favour are the mention of micro-credit, which is mainly aimed at micro-entrepreneurs and overcoming obstacles to access to traditional banking services and, not least, the emphasis on the difficulties faced by SMEs on a daily basis and which certainly do not help the European Union and the Member States with their austerity policies.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 SMEs are an essential part of the modern economy and a driver of each country's economic growth, which is why I supported this report on ways to increase their competitiveness. The report provides an assessment of the current situation and at the same time provides possible starting points for the future. I am always very pleased to see that Czech companies are able to assert themselves on world markets, despite obstacles in the form of staff shortages or systematic refusal to grant permission for the export of goods. I believe that the European Union should support and assist SMEs in accessing better financing, attracting skilled workers and easy access to the global market.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing – This report, produced at Parliament's initiative, focuses mainly on evaluating the implementation of achieving greater competitiveness for small and medium-sized enterprises, which was, inter among other things, one of the objectives of the European Structural and Investment Funds, the programming period of which is currently coming to an end. The report contained many positive elements, including focusing on the key role of small and medium-sized enterprises in the European economy, diversifying financial resources or exchanging best practices. Overall, it advocated the need to create a simplified business environment and to speed up the process of setting up new businesses, which will bring significant economic growth and new jobs in the future.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the D'Amato report on strengthening the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) because I believe they are fundamental to the prosperity of the European economy. I would stress that, as a result of the economic and financial crisis, levels of poverty and social exclusion have increased in many Member States – such as long-term unemployment, youth unemployment and social inequalities – and that SMEs can therefore play a particularly important role in Europe's economic recovery. Currently, the EU's 23 million SMEs account for around 99% of all businesses and provide more than 100 million jobs. It is therefore essential that the Commission and the Member States take into account the added value of SMEs, especially when it comes to innovating in traditional sectors. I would also like to stress the role of SMEs in the services sector, which is undergoing a significant change from digitisation, and I therefore believe that the skills gap in ICT skills should be addressed, placing greater emphasis on relevant training and education.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the D'Amato report, an implementation report aimed at 'holistically' analysing the various aspects concerning the implementation of Thematic Objective (TOs) 3 of the new 2007-2014 programming, which concerns the promotion of the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises. The TO has a budget of EUR 63 billion, up to EUR 94 billion with national co-financing, and covers 23 million SMEs representing around 99 % of all enterprises. The Commission is reminded of the importance of transparent public procurement; it is asked to take into account the circular economy package to promote sustainable growth and green jobs, as well as the added value of SMEs for the development and innovation of traditional sectors. The many positive points in the report emphasise first of all the need to simplify European, national and regional legislation in order to facilitate access to credit; corporate social responsibility is highlighted; the fact that austerity policies have stifled demand and financial instruments have not helped the sector; mention is made of the importance of micro-credit and the need to find a solution to late payments relating to regional policy.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to argue because I voted against the resolution signed by Bresso. We, as the Confederal Group of the European United Left/Nordic Green Left, have tabled a number of amendments to this text aimed at clarifying a fundamental point for us: that there can be no Alpine strategy that does not respect the will of the people. In particular, I believe that the failure of the 'No TAV' movement to be involved in the consultation on the Alpine region launched by the European Commission in 2014 is unfortunately a very, very serious shortcoming.  We therefore strongly call for a halt to the High-Speed Train, the Turin-Lyon high-speed train, which has proved to be harmful to the health of its citizens, which has proved unnecessary for the strategy and for transport needs. We really believe that we need to involve the people and respect their will in that region.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I voted to have a European Union strategy for the Alpine regions, and I want to say that, if successful, it will have to be extended to many other regions and also to the Alpine regions of my country, Romania. The Strategy for Alpine Regions was launched in 2016 in Slovenia and is, in a way, following the model of the Carpathian Strategy and the Danube Region Strategy. If it is successful, I repeat, we will be able to use it in other situations, and in other regions. It is very important to say what this means. It means we're bringing people from the mountains closer to the city. They are sometimes isolated, they want to come to shows, to medical services, to social services, to all kinds of events that take place in nearby cities. That's why this strategy is useful for people. And two, we voted for it because it doesn't spend more money, it shows us how to use the funds we have more judiciously.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we cannot forget what problems the Alpine Region and the people who live in it suffer, because they are common to those in other rural areas. These areas are depopulated, schools disappear, health centres have to move to larger towns where there is no employment. The inhabitants cannot survive only tourism. It is clear that this sector must be valued and encouraged, but people will not always be attracted to it if the region is not permanently cared for and cared for by those who live there all year round. This strategy proposed by the European Union needs to be aimed at the development of agriculture, forestry and other environmentally friendly services and industries. The protection of this region must go beyond economic criteria, and this debate is a good opportunity for us to talk about it, of the need to go further; because the importance of protecting culture, the lives of areas like this—a sustainable and balanced life—is basic. It is a life that is respectful, respectful of its environment, a life and a wisdom that is only given to us by the people who live in the villages.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – I would like to congratulate rapporteur Mrs Bresso on the report on the European Union Strategy for the Alpine Region. At the same time, however, I would also like to draw attention to the need for a similar approach and strategy for other mountain regions in the European Union, in particular the Balkans.  Mountain regions, as we know, are disadvantaged compared to other regions, they are more inflexible and we need to approach it in a special way. In the report, Ms Bresso called on the European Investment Bank to explore the possibility of setting up an investment platform for the Alpine region, also calling for the creation of a project channel for the region that would attract investors.  Similar steps must be envisaged for other mountainous regions of the European Union, in particular south-east Europe, where mountains are an important link from cross-border cooperation. I therefore call for equal access to quality funding for all mountain regions in the European Union, for quality investment and growth in them, so that there is no Europe at two, even at three speeds.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, seo é an míniú vótála deireanach uaimse inniu. Mr President, I commend this report’s thorough consideration of the Alpine region, as a marked step towards the achievement of Europe’s goals of territorial cooperation and cohesion. Giving careful consideration to the effects of EU strategies on the environment as well as on economic and social development in these areas, we may build on the recommendations of this report. Thus we are in a position much more effectively to address the challenges experienced by macro regions whilst establishing and improving on the framework within which new and existing strategies will operate. I particularly support the recognition of the impact of the EU Strategy for the Alpine Region (EUSALP) throughout the EU and not at a regional level alone, as we have observed the increasing development of synergies between different institutions and agencies and, indeed, national and regional policies. While respecting the principle of subsidiarity, I would also hope to observe further improvements in the spheres of biodiversity, transport and tourism from this point forward.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is in some ways welcome in many respects, but still very problematic in others. For example, among the positive points, the approach to the issue of biodiversity and the preservation of the region's ecosystem is noteworthy, underlining the urgent need to develop new strategies to combat air pollution. However, the report also contains references to the Turin-Lyon route. In addition, there are other points that should be addressed differently. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We voted against this report because we feel that the countries of the Alpine region, not the EU, have the right to make their own decisions. We note that in Amendment 1, the EU orders Member States not to spend on their own priorities, but instead only EU ones. This kind of bullying should not be allowed.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which is the fourth EU macro-regional strategy. EUSALP covers 48 regions in seven countries, five of which are Member States (Italy, France, Slovenia, Austria and Germany). The other two countries are Switzerland and Liechtenstein. EUSALP is a vehicle for strategic investment that will benefit the region as a whole. The report tackles various important issues regarding the EUSALP: multi-level governance, investments, jobs, environment, climate change and mobility.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this report by my comrade Mercedes Bresso, which provides solutions to the common problems and challenges that arise in the Alpine region.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on EU strategy for the Alpine Region. The EU strategy for the Alpine region (EUSALP) is the fourth EU macro-regional strategy, following those for the Baltic Sea region, the Danube region and the Adriatic and Ionian region. To my mind, the European Commission needs to be more closely involved at the start-up stage of macro-regional strategies, at the design and planning stage as well as at the implementation stage. I fully agree that the European Parliament should also be involved, in its capacity as co-legislator, in the launch and approval of strategies, as well as in monitoring their implementation. It is important to mention that this report stresses the importance of financial instruments, of encouraging innovation and new technologies in key areas of the economy, while preserving also forms of traditional economic activity. I supported this report because it also promotes the diversification of tourism and underlines the importance of improving transport and energy connectivity, as well as underlines the importance of protecting and enhancing the biodiversity in the Alpine Region.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. In December 2013, the European Council invited the Commission to present an EU Strategy for the Alpine Region (EUSALP). The Commission responded to this call in July 2015 with the presentation of the Action Plan for the Strategy (EU's fourth macro-regional strategy). The Committee on Regional Development decided to draw up an own-initiative report on the basis of this action plan with a view to formulating recommendations for rapid and effective implementation. This report is now based on the principle that macro-regions are the framework for cooperation activities and for the development of synergies between the eu's various financial instruments. It also calls on the participating Member States to coordinate their national and regional actions with a view to contributing to the actions and objectives of the EUSALP strategy. It also supports, among other things, the intention to diversify tourism and the importance of improving transport and energy connectivity and protecting and promoting biodiversity in the Alpine region. I support the promotion of innovation and new technologies in key sectors of the economy, while preserving the forms of traditional economic activity. I have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report lays the groundwork for the EU's strategy for the Alpine region (Eusalp). This is the fourth macro-regional strategy. Eusalp covers 48 regions in seven different countries, including five Member States. The aim, in creating these macro-regions, is to develop cross-border strategic approaches in regions that would share the same problems, in this case depopulation, diversification of economic activity, land use planning and environmental protection within the framework of eusalp. We share most of the priorities defended by Eusalp, such as the preservation of the environment, the modernisation of water infrastructure, the creation of competitiveness poles, sources of innovation generating sustainable jobs, the development of new tourism offerings in order to limit the seasonal aspect of alpine tourism, the development of rail transport, especially for freight, in order to decongest cities.  On the other hand, we are opposed to any macro-regional strategy whose governance model is based on increased participation of local and regional authorities in decision-making bodies.  These future macro-regions will gradually escape the control of the Member States, thus leaving the field open to the European Commission to grant itself new prerogatives, particularly in the area of urban policy or education. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interests of transparency and democracy I would like to confirm I voted against this resolution. This reported wants the Commission to set up a platform for more public and private financing for the project, in other words let’s waste more taxpayers money. This report has the audacity to order Member States not to spend money on their priorities but only EU ones.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to improve the competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion of the Alpine region.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the EU strategy for the Alpine region. The Commission has developed an Investment Plan and set up a European Fund for Strategic Investments to boost investment.  This enables countries in the region to launch new investment projects and to strengthen projects that have already been launched. The EU Strategy for the Alpine Region enables countries to invest in joint projects that will have an impact not only on their region but on Europe as a whole. I therefore support the EU strategy for the Alpine region, as the region has great potential and can be increased by involving local authorities and all public and private actors in the region.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this report because we feel that the countries of the Alpine region, not the EU, have the right to make their own decisions. We note that in Amendment 1, the EU orders Member States not to spend on their own priorities, but instead only EU ones. This kind of bullying should not be allowed.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I am opposed to this report, which corresponds to a macro-regional strategy based on a multi-level governance model with increased participation of local authorities, thus limiting the scope of action of national governments to the Commission, which is granting itself new prerogatives in urban policy and education.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which calls on the competent authorities of the Union, Member States and the regions concerned to harmonize as far as possible the policies and funds to help the Alpine region develop. IN particular, MEPs call for the establishment at the macro-regional level of a support structure to implement this strategy in cooperation with the Commission, Member States and regions. In particular, they call on the Commission to encourage active cooperation between agriculture and other economic activities in protected areas in order to design integrated tourism products. They also ask it to develop the labour market in the Alpine region, to give priority to investment in digital infrastructure or, in environmental matters, to promote biodiversity.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this report because I agree with macro-regional strategies. So far these have emerged from intergovernmental initiatives, but thanks to the inclusion of the territorial cohesion objective in the Lisbon Treaty, strategies can be further integrated into the Community method.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Alpine regions, thanks to a strong bottom-up approach, have led to the development of the EUSALP strategy, with the aim of effectively addressing the challenges common to the entire Alpine area. Environment, agriculture, the risk of depopulation, employment, transport, research and governance are just some of the issues addressed in the Commission's proposal, issues that were particularly effectively taken up in the Bresso report, which I decided to support with conviction. The Eu ropean Union's strategy must have the task of reconciling environmental sustainability with economic development, in a natural area that is already an important tourist destination. The 48 regions involved, divided between seven states, retain many differences but share common problems and high capacities. However, resources are needed to deploy the full potential of the territories. The European institutions and the Commission must create a genuine investment platform for the Alpine region, a flexible instrument enabling public and private funding to be mobilised. We need a pipeline project for the region aimed at attracting investors and new forms of multi-level governance implemented with Community contributions. EUSALP represents a great opportunity to make the Alps one of the hearts of innovation in Europe.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because we believe it is essential to have a clear strategy. Although I do not agree with some of the points that are addressed, I believe that a plan to solve this and other problems affecting many rural areas without means is urgently needed. In these areas the exploitation of the natural environment or tourist attractions is often prioritized over the standard of living of its own inhabitants. In addition, the dossier includes amendments that have been incorporated with civil society concerns about problems about coal emissions, renewable energy, climate change and protection of glaciers, endangered species and biodiversity. In addition, the report supports sustainable tourism and makes interesting contributions to Cop21. Mainly, I am interested in the mentions you make about more remote areas of the Alpine area that do not have access to the most basic social and economic services, lack of job opportunities, lack of connections, depopulation, etc.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. If I try to warn often against the impoverishment of mountainous regions, especially on the problem of the desertification of public services in these areas, I had to vote against this report. Of course, the EU's priorities for the Alpine region (Eusalp) are also my own: preserving the environment, modernising water infrastructure, developing rail transport, or creating competitiveness hubs, sources of innovation and sustainable jobs. However, what lies behind this strategy is the regionalisation of Europe, the creation of macro-regions directly linked to Brussels and thus allowing the Commission to hide the States and thus to appropriate more and more powers, to the detriment of the treaties.  In short, this technique is only intended to lead to a federal Europe, where the regions would no longer be French, but would become the country's states of Europe, in the Germanic mode.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Alpine macro-region is a project of fundamental importance for the regions of Northern Italy, primarily for Veneto and Lombardy, which together with the other 46 European regions involved are the beating heart of the European economy. Thanks to the EUSALP macro-regional strategy, which includes a territory of 80 million citizens, our northern regions will be able to manage independently the many EU funding for joint projects relating to the environment, tourism, transport and energy. I supported the EUSALP project from the outset together with lega Nord, because it is a unique opportunity for economic development and governance for our territories, our businesses and our citizens. For all these reasons, I supported the text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Union Strategy for the Alpine Region is developed in a context characterized by various types of cooperation in the region, as well as various cross-border Interreg programmes. This region, home to more than 80 million inhabitants, covers 48 regions and 7 countries and has a strong human, natural, economic and cultural appeal. However, the difficulties of connection and logistics of production have marked the development of mountain territories. In addition, the area is also very vulnerable to the effects of climate change. In this context, the report emphasizes that public authorities must address existing economic and environmental challenges. The report sets out as priorities: improving the competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion of the Alpine region; ensure accessibility and connections to all the inhabitants of the region; ensure sustainability in the Alps; or protect Alpine heritage and promote sustainable use of natural and cultural resources. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has been advocated by Parliament on the EU Strategy for the Alpine Region. Macro-regional strategies are currently a key instrument for achieving the objective of economic, social and territorial cohesion. The Alpine macro-regional strategy could help to halt the economic downturn by investing in research and innovation and supporting business, taking into account the specific characteristics and assets of the region. It is also worth noting that climate change is occurring faster than the world average in the Alpine region, which makes natural disasters such as avalanches and floods more frequent. Parliament welcomed the Commission communication on the European Union Strategy for the Alpine Region and the accompanying action plan, and considers it to be a step forward for the development of the region. Parliament also invited the Commission and national, regional and local bodies responsible for the preparation, management and implementation of ESI Funds programmes to draw attention to the importance of macro-regional projects and actions.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The Strategy for the Alpine Region is an excellent opportunity to increase the participation of the Alpine regions and to help remote places.  With environmentally friendly economic development and activities that will not be based solely on tourism, we can keep the population in these areas and give them a decent life, so all my support and voice to the strategy report at the meeting itself.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the strategic importance of the Alpine region for its geographical position in the heart of Europe, but also as a "water reservoir" in the face of the energy challenges facing the EU, the strategy for the Alpine region is proposed as a macro-regional framework for enhanced cooperation. The Alpine region is composed of a wide variety of territories, united by common characteristics, which therefore require joint governance; EUSALP would bring together seven countries, five of which are EU members (including Italy) and two non-members. The report, which I support, highlights the potential of the Alpine region with a view to smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, capable of combining social, economic and environmental interests. The EUSALP action plan is a valuable opportunity to increase cross-border cooperation between Alpine states, identifying objectives common to the region and facilitating the creation of common policies. The ultimate aim of this strategy is precisely to enhance the attractiveness and competitiveness of the Alpine area, focusing on the sustainable use of natural resources and the protection of cultural heritage starting from local communities.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report makes relevant highlights of the issues common to the different Alpine regions (48) in the 5 Member States concerned. Unfortunately, it tends to strengthen the direct link between local authorities and the Union to the detriment of the states. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report lays the groundwork for the EU's Alpine Region Strategy (Eusalp), which covers 48 regions in seven different countries, including five Member States. The aim of creating these macro-regions is to develop cross-border strategic approaches in regions that share the same problems.  Of course, we share most of the priorities defended by Eusalp, such as protecting the environment, modernising water infrastructure, developing new tourism offerings to limit the seasonal aspect of alpine tourism, or the development of rail transport, especially for freight, in order to decongest cities. On the other hand, we are, by definition, opposed to any macro-regional strategy whose governance model is based on increased participation of local and regional authorities in decision-making bodies.  These future macro-regions will gradually escape the control of the Member States, thus leaving the scope open to the European Commission to grant itself new prerogatives, particularly in the area of urban policy or education. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sustainable and competitive tourism, reducing the isolation of inland and remote areas by improving their access to transport and energy services, diversifying tourism supply and products, training and entrepreneurial skills in tourism, reducing the risks caused by climate change by making investments in the water sector are just some of the priorities crystallised in order to develop a viable EU strategy for the Alpine region. Given that there are mountain areas in the EUSALP area where the level of resource use is low and lowland areas with a high concentration of production, it is necessary to develop integrated economic strategies. These strategies are in line with the objectives of the ESIF programming for the period 2014-2020 and, in particular, with the principles of innovation and the smart specialisation strategy. I voted in favour of this report, considering that it is necessary to involve all the factors, Parliament and the Commission, so that there is a coherent and common approach to sustainable development, the environment, energy to maximise the potential of the Alpine regions.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The Alpine region covers the territory of five Member States of the European Union: France, Italy, Austria, Germany and Slovenia. It is therefore essential to create European cooperation in this area. It is for this reason that the European Commission has published a communication on the implementation of a strategy for the Alpine region.  The aim of this action plan is to combat the depopulation of the region and in particular against the departure of the young population. The report calls for more harmonization of structural and investment funds and their structuring within the strategy. This must be accompanied by increased communication and a support structure. The region needs to develop its potential for growth and innovation, which is likely to create jobs. Tourism can be improved and become a significant economic resource. There is also a need to improve connectivity, both for transport and for digital. These two elements will allow the region to develop more efficiently and quickly. Finally, real environmental and biodiversity conservation structures must be developed specific to the region.  I voted in favour of this initiative report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I am convinced that the EU strategy for the Alpine region can play a significant role in efforts to revive the Alpine economy and combat the depopulation of that area, in particular the exodus of young people. I welcome the fact that the European Structural Investment Funds offer potentially significant resources and a wide range of tools and options for the EU strategy for the Alpine region. However, we need greater synergies and the promotion of coordination and complementarity with the European Structural and Investment Fund (ESIF) and other funds and instruments relevant to the pillars of the strategy, in particular Horizon 2020, the Instrument for Connecting Europe, the LIFE programme, the COSME programme for SMEs, the Interreg Alpine Area programme and the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) , for which the Commission should examine the possible added value of specific calls focusing on the challenges of particular concern to the Alpine region. I also call on the EIB, in cooperation with the Commission, to consider creating an ad hoc investment platform for the Alpine region to mobilise public and private funding.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which is the fourth EU macro-regional strategy. EUSALP covers 48 regions in seven countries, five of which are Member States (Italy, France, Slovenia, Austria and Germany). The other two countries are Switzerland and Liechtenstein. EUSALP is a vehicle for strategic investment that will benefit the region as a whole. The report tackles various important issues regarding the EUSALP: multi-level governance, investments, jobs, environment, climate change and mobility.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the Alpine macro-region has huge potential, and joint planning by the countries and regions in the area, coupled with close involvement of local authorities and public and private bodies, can help to realise that potential. The aim is to pursue common objectives for the area as a whole that are in keeping with the sustainable development, environmental and energy objectives set under the Europe 2020 strategy, and projects of a macro-regional scale are therefore required in order to meet those objectives. It underlines the importance of integrated economic strategies between the underutilisation of resources in some upland areas and the concentration of manufacturing activities in lowland areas. I agree with this way forward and voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the report comprehensively addresses several important aspects, such as biodiversity and the preservation of the region's ecosystem, employment and innovation issues, and also emphasises the importance of ensuring fast and efficient access to the high-speed Internet, I must regret that no mention is made of the HIGH-SPEED TRAIN. The delegation of the 5 Star Movement had tabled 4 amendments, 3 of which were on the TAV and one on public water, all of which were rejected. Finally, the text also calls for the creation of a pipeline project for the region, aimed at attracting investors, and explicitly urges the Commission, the EIB and the participating countries to make full use of the opportunities offered by the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) to finance projects in the region. For these reasons, I preferred to abstain on the final vote.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has dedicated a strategic development plan for the Alpine region (EUSALP) affecting 80 million inhabitants in 7 states and 48 regions, inside and outside the European Union. Although the region is already affected by various cooperation agreements, the links are limited, logistical problems and climate change create inconvenience and limit production activities. EUSALP's strategy is built on 3 pillars: improving competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion; ensure accessibility and connecting routes; promote alpine cultural heritage and the sustainable use of natural resources. I voted in favour of this important report because it provides solutions to common problems and challenges in the Alpine region, of which six Italian regions are members.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report. The EUSALP strategy does not overlap existing interregional and cross-border cooperation, but gives it added value. It is about pursuing common objectives throughout the region, in line with the major European objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy for sustainable development, the environment, and energy.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the EU strategy for the Alpine region concerns an area with specific perspectives, but also specific problems that need to be addressed. It is true that focusing on specific geographical areas can bear a positive fruit for Europe, with comprehensive proposals for individual regions. However, I believe that Europe should reconsider its targeting and support social groups and regions directly threatened by economic and social upheavals. That's why I decided to abstain.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support mrs Bresso's report to increase and fully implement the Union's strategy for the Alpine region. It is an ambitious project of territorial cohesion that would allow a full and complete development of the strong potential characteristic of the entire macro-region and from which our country will benefit greatly. The Juncker plan introduced an investment plan for the European Union, setting up the European Fund for Strategic Investments, a further opportunity for the macro-region to undertake new investment projects and complete those already underway. The synergies between the different financing instruments available to the Union and the coordination systems between local and supranational authorities aim to encourage innovation and the development of new technologies, while maintaining traditional forms of economic activity, which are the engine of local productivity. It is therefore essential to ensure better accessibility and connectivity to the whole area in line with the protection of the Alpine environment. Alpine flora and fauna are, in fact, valuable elements capable of ensuring a distinctive well-being and must therefore be protected and developed. I hope that, with regard to greater coordination between the different institutional levels, lean governance will be established, far from any bureaucratic burdens.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on an EU Strategy for the Alpine Region and noted no objections.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, through the EUSALP plan, the Alpine macro-region will be able to benefit from new funding from the European Fund for Strategic Investments and will have the opportunity to carry out joint projects with a European impact. Furthermore, I believe that the three-pillar strategy, which includes improving the competitiveness and cohesion of the Alpine region, improving accessibility and strengthening the region's transport sector and promoting the Alpine heritage and the sustainable use of natural and cultural resources, is an excellent starting point.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – I support the concept of a bottom-up strategic territorial planning as opposed to the traditional top-down approach adopted by the Commission with instruments such as the ESPON programme. This is instrumental to counter the depopulation of the region, especially the outflow of young people.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted to abstain in this report because despite containing positive aspects on multi-level governance, investment, job creation, the environment, climate change and mobility, it seems to me to be an un priority issue since it is one of the richest territorial areas of the Union, with enormous capacity to absorb periods of crisis. A proposal for better coordination is always welcome, but issues such as the correction of economic inequalities, labour rights, the incorporation of young people into the labour market or gender policies are lacking.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are currently three EU macro-regions: the EU Strategy for the Baltic Sea Region, the European Union Strategy for the Danube Region and the Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Sea regions. More than 80 million people live in 7 countries in the Alps, 5 of which are EU Member States. Linking and logistical difficulties for producers have often hampered the development of mountain areas, with the Macroregion of the Alps extremely vulnerable to the effects of climate change. I voted for increased involvement, both at the initiation stage and, in particular, in the implementation and coordination phases with other strategies and with the European Union's more general territorial cohesion policy.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. –The EU strategy for the region includes 48 regions in seven countries, five of which are EU Member States, and two others are Switzerland and Lichtenstein. Macro-regional strategies allow these countries to make strategic investments for the benefit of the whole region, bearing in mind the 'three no' principle (no new EU fund, no new EU formal structure, no further EU legislation in this regard). The strategy is based on three development pillars. The first pillar aims to increase the competitiveness and cohesion of the Alpine region, including the promotion of sustainable and competitive tourism. The second pillar is aimed at improving accessibility and ensuring adequate transport and energy network infrastructure. Sustainability, environmental protection, biodiversity and the protection of ecosystems are key words of the third pillar. The Alps macro-region, which is exemplary for other regions, has considerable potential and can be further exploited through cooperation. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support the EU strategy for the Alpine region, which concerns 7 countries, 5 of which are EU Member States (Austria, France, Germany, Italy and Slovenia) and 2 non-EU countries (Liechtenstein and Switzerland), as well as 48 regions with a population of more than 80 million citizens. I believe that the strategy covers three important thematic areas. I appreciate that the strategy does not require the use of additional resources, but emphasises the use of existing funds (implementation of ESI Funds). At the same time, I believe that this document and the experience gained in its work can help to work on an EU strategy for the Carpathian region, which should also be created and implemented.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU strategy for the Alpine Region (EUSALP) is fundamental as it improves the competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion, accessibility and transport links for everyone in the Alpine region and ensures sustainability in the Alps. I believe that these pillars provide solutions to the common problems and challenges in the Alpine Region and that this strategy ensures that the role of the European Union in such regions is fulfilled. These are the main reasons why I am in favour of this strategy.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the macro-regional strategy for the Alpine region can help reverse economic decline through investment in research, innovation and entrepreneurial support and taking into account the unique characteristics and values of the region, I believe that supporting innovation in key areas of the mountain economy can enable businesses in the Alpine region to develop new products and services in areas such as life sciences, bio-economy, new materials , e-services, tourism, healthy aging, e-care isolated patients.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report presents the European Parliament's position on the Alpine Macro-Regional Strategy (SEDRA). Published in July 2015, the strategy aims to better articulate the distribution of European structural funds and national and regional funding between seven Alpine countries, including five EU Member States, and 48 regions, in order to strengthen the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the Alpine massif.  The mountain too often creates additional barriers to working together! With this new strategy, it will unite Alpine citizens to meet several challenges, including interconnections in transport and digital coverage, innovation and adaptation to climate change. This strategy must remain a tool used by alpine cities and regions who wish to jointly develop concrete projects, a balanced territory and meet the aspirations of local people.  I have been particularly involved in this issue in the agriculture and environment committees, by enacting the need to strengthen transnational cooperation on hydraulic energy and the management of predatory species on livestock. Considering the very high quality of this roadmap, I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this report because we feel that the countries of the Alpine region, not the EU, have the right to make their own decisions. We note that in Amendment 1, the EU orders Member States not to spend on their own priorities, but instead only EU ones. This kind of bullying should not be allowed.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This report on the European Union's strategy for the Alpine region makes proposals and recommendations in line with the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in order to address the particularities of these regions and the challenges they raise.  I voted in favour of this text, which rightly emphasizes the need to improve transport networks and connectivity in alpine regions in order to promote tourism and growth, while respecting environmental imperatives in regions with rich biodiversity.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 During the September plenary session of the European Parliament, I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for the Alpine region, which deals with the Union's fourth macro-regional strategy. The EU Strategy for the Alpine Region includes 48 regions in seven countries, five of which are EU Member States, and two others are Switzerland and Lichtenstein. Macro-regional strategies allow these countries to create strategic investments for the benefit of the whole region, bearing in mind the 'three no' principle. The strategy is based on three development pillars. The first pillar aims to increase the competitiveness and cohesion of the Alpine region, including the promotion of sustainable and competitive tourism. The second pillar is aimed at improving accessibility and ensuring adequate transport, energy network and ICT infrastructure. Sustainability, environmental protection, biodiversity and the protection of ecosystems are key words of the third pillar. The Alps macro-region has considerable potential, which can be further exploited through cooperation between countries and regions.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the strategy as I consider it an important initiative for the development of the Alpine territory within the framework of international collaboration in the commercial, tourism and cultural fields. In addition, this initiative also represents another point in favour of European integration at macro-regional level in the sharing of stable economic growth and common cultural values.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report lays the groundwork for the Eu/15 Strategy for the Alpine Region (EUSALP). EUSALP covers 48 regions in seven different countries, including five Member States.
