We endorse most of the priorities defended by THE EUSALP such as: the preservation of the environment, the modernisation of water infrastructure, the creation of competitiveness poles, sources of innovation generating sustainable jobs, the development of new tourism offerings in order to limit the seasonal aspect of alpine tourism, the development of rail transport, especially for freight, in order to decongest cities. However, we are opposed to any macro-regional strategy, which is in line with the principle of Member States' sovereignty. So I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the EU Strategy for the Alpine Region. It concerns seven countries, five of which are EU member states, affecting 48 regions where over 80 million citizens live. As a goal of this strategy, synergies between the mountainous and surrounding lowlands and urban regions are at stake. From a financial point of view, the strategy does not require the use of the additional funds, but is deployed on the potential of the ESI Funds.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 There are regions in Europe with much more important problems that face greater challenges and the Union should address them.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 During the September plenary session of the European Parliament, I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for the Alpine region, which deals with the Union's fourth macro-regional strategy. The EU Strategy for the Alpine Region includes 48 regions in seven countries, five of which are EU Member States, and two others are Switzerland and Lichtenstein. Macro-regional strategies allow these countries to create strategic investments for the benefit of the whole region, bearing in mind the 'three no' principle. The strategy is based on three development pillars. The first pillar aims to increase the competitiveness and cohesion of the Alpine region, including the promotion of sustainable and competitive tourism. The second pillar is aimed at improving accessibility and ensuring adequate transport, energy network and ICT infrastructure. Sustainability, environmental protection, biodiversity and the protection of ecosystems are key words of the third pillar. The Alps macro-region has considerable potential, which can be further exploited through cooperation between countries and regions. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the report contains a number of positive points, the rapporteur's ill-intention to promote the construction of major projects such as the Turin-Lyon high-speed rail route is noted. The M5S has tabled amendments to the text to prevent projects that are harmful to health and the environment, which are not economically sustainable and, above all, in the case of the TAV, completely useless because the existing route is functioning, recently renewed and under-utilised, can be carried out today and in the future. The amendments tabled were rejected, so I abstained in the final vote.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. This is the EU's fourth macro-regional strategy and can therefore benefit from the experience of the European Union's strategies for the Baltic Sea region, the Danube region and the Adriatic and Ionian region. Macro-regional strategies have so far originated in intergovernmental initiatives aimed at areas of our continent long divided by wars and iron curtains, with the aim of relaunching economic and institutional cooperation between these territories. The EUSALP strategy operates in a context characterised by different forms of cooperation in the region, such as the Alpine Area and the Alpine Convention, in addition to several interreg cross-border programmes. EUSALP covers 48 regions and seven countries represented by five Member States (Italy, France, Austria, Germany and Slovenia) and two third countries (Switzerland and Liechtenstein). The region, in which more than 80 million people live, has a strong human, natural, economic and cultural attractiveness. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: loss of control or influence of member states.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The strategy for the Alpine region is already the fourth proposal presented by the EU in terms of macro-regional strategies. The notion of macro-regions, involving EU countries and others outside this context, contributes to the acquisition of scale, which can benefit development. This framework and the scope of this territory, having some potential, also raises some concerns, in particular as to the strategic and cohesion resources and investments needed, not only for macro-regions, but for the Member States themselves, those involved and others, knowing how clearly scarce the resources of the EU budget are. The report includes several positive points, highlighting the inclusion of social organisations in the definition of policies for the macro-region, the prospect of reducing carbon emissions, the promotion of renewable energies, mitigation and adaptation to climate change, the protection of defaults and biodiversity, the fight against the problems of desertification and economic depression and the sustainable promotion of tourism , among others.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the strategy for the Alpine region because it represents a good opportunity to relaunch and complete joint investments for the countries of the region. The potential of the Alpine region is vast, so we need a joint project capacity of the alpine countries and regions, local authorities and all public and private actors in the area in line with the major European objectives of Europe 2020. In order to do this, I believe it is necessary to design and implement projects with a macro-regional dimension, which do not end up overlapping with existing interregional cooperation, but which are capable of bringing added value.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the European Union is characterised by its natural diversification. It often brings together several regions. An initiative was already presented from the Alpine regions in 2011 calling on the European Commission to present an EU strategy for the Alpine region. It is already the 4 EU macro-regional strategy that can benefit from the experience of previous strategies. One of them also concerned the Slovak Republic, namely the European Strategy for the Danube Region. Macro-regional strategies have proved to be a successful project that links, among other things, areas of our continent that have been divided in the past by wars and aim to restore institutional and economic cooperation between such areas. The recovery of investment through the investment plan and the establishment of the European Fund for Strategic Investments must be regarded as a good step.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report because I agree with planning a series of ad hoc investments for the Alpine region that will allow the mobilisation of public and private funding.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the EU strategy for the Alpine region. Of all the regions of Europe, I believe that it is not the Alps that would be most in urgent need of assistance in their development. There are areas in Europe with much more important problems that face greater challenges and the Union should address them.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is the fourth macro-regional strategy of the EU (the prior three being the Baltic, Danube and Adriatic and Ionian strategies). EUSALP strategy, which covers 80 million people in 7 countries and 48 regions within and outside the EU, covers the Alpine region, a region that is already engaged in various cooperation agreements. However, the region has poor transport links and logistic problems for manufacturers, and suffers from the effects of the climate change. Consequently, local, regional and national authorities need to take action in accordance with the subsidiarity principle to address the problems in the whole area, as they are best placed to use the bottom-up approach that takes account of local needs while – at the same time – being subject to cross-border, transnational and interregional coordination and cooperation. Our objective is to make the trump cards of this very dynamic and innovative region better known. I believe we achieved this goal.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 During the September plenary session of the European Parliament, I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for the Alpine region, which deals with the Union's fourth macro-regional strategy. The EU Strategy for the Alpine Region includes 48 regions in seven countries, five of which are EU Member States, and two others are Switzerland and Lichtenstein. Macro-regional strategies allow these countries to create strategic investments for the benefit of the whole region, bearing in mind the 'three no' principle. The strategy is based on three development pillars. The first pillar aims to increase the competitiveness and cohesion of the Alpine region, including the promotion of sustainable and competitive tourism. The second pillar is aimed at improving accessibility and ensuring adequate transport, energy network and ICT infrastructure. Sustainability, environmental protection, biodiversity and the protection of ecosystems are key words of the third pillar. The Alps macro-region has considerable potential, which can be further exploited through cooperation between countries and regions.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I adopted the report on the EU strategy for the Alpine region. The Alps region has significant economic potential in the EU, as the relevant macro strategy affects around 80 million people in 48 regions in seven countries, five of which are EU Member States (Austria, France, Germany, Italy and Slovenia). In particular, it is to be welcomed that an important part of the strategy is the development of the labour market by improving the level of skills of the workforce and creating new jobs in the green economy. It is necessary to use innovation and funding based on smart specialisation strategies and from existing EU funds, such as COSME, Horizon 2020 or Erasmus+, for the use of new technologies in key areas of the economy. These resources can greatly help create new jobs in the region. The report also focuses on enhancing the economic activities of SMEs in agriculture, tourism and trade in the region. These enterprises are the main source of employment in the Alps, but further diversification is needed. Similarly, investment in digital infrastructure should be a priority area and people in large areas far from urban centres should have rapid and efficient access to broadband internet. This will provide access to digital and online services such as e-commerce, digital market channels, teleworking and other opportunities.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU Strategy for the Alpine Region is the Fourth Macro-Regional Strategy of the Union, so it can draw on the experience gained with the European Union Strategy for the Baltic Sea region, the European Union Strategy for the Danube region and the EU Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region. A legal framework should be established to more appropriately define, on the basis of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, the system of governance of existing and future strategies, limiting the role of national and Union authorities to initial momentum and coordination, as well as supervisory and support functions, leaving aspects relating to project governance and their implementation to regional and local bodies to be the real protagonists of the foundations of territorial and development policies. For all these reasons I voted in favour of the report.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it aims to improve the EUs policies in regards to the Alpine region and give existing EU instruments more flexibility to act according to this regions special needs and prospects. The report underlines many important areas of priority for the region and outlines which issues the EU should invest in and support. If there is one thing that is important in this Alpine strategy then it is the development of the regional labour market and to develop opportunities for agriculture, forestry and craft based economic activities in the region. Other major priorities in the Alpine region are better digital connections and to promote the self-generation of energy.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agreed with the structure of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on a European Union strategy for the Alpine region because I believe that macro-regional strategies are now an essential tool for rethinking the development of the territories from a new perspective of economic, territorial, cultural, historical and social cohesion of the European Union. The aim of the macro-regions is to ensure that better and concrete results are achieved for the different regions that are part of it, through a common approach aimed at coordinating the different interests. It can therefore be seen as a multi-level governance model in which all stakeholders, i.e. local actors, national and regional authorities, play a leading and equal role. As with other macro-regional strategies, alpine macro-regions also contribute to the consolidation of regional identities and cultural heritage, as well as protecting a popular heritage and biodiversity that must not be lost. I agree with the rapporteur's call for the European Commission, in cooperation with the European Investment Bank, to consider creating an investment platform that can attract public and private funding, in a region of around 80 million people.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for the Alpine region, which I, as rapporteur for my ECR Group, was able to shape at crucial points. I am pleased that a majority has been able to bring in a majority for the aspect of available, high-quality obstetrics in mountain regions – and here I strongly support the demands of the petition of the Citizens' Union of South Tyrol. I am also pleased that my proposal for comprehensive concepts of 'digital villages' has been adopted.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the EU Strategy for the Alpine Region (EUSALP). This macro-regional strategy will contribute to the promotion of synergy effects and strengthen the coordination of national and regional measures. However, it is important to stress that no new legislation should be adopted. This would be a further burden on the population concerned. Nor should new institutions be created, but the existing institutions should be meaningfully integrated into the EU strategy.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my S&D colleagues, I voted in favour of this report, which is part of a strategy that covers 80 million people in 7 countries and 48 regions in the EU and outside. The report will improve access and transport in the Alpine regions, improve competitiveness and cohesion and develop sustainability.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. I have already had many times to say here all the evil I think of the European macro-regions in general and the alpine macro-region in particular. There was already an Alpine Convention and even an Alpine Area, financed by the European Union. This tends to prove that this type of cooperation, including with countries that are not part of the Union, is possible without involving the Commission. This is undoubtedly the crux of the problem: the Commission does not support the fact that a single structure can escape it, a single initiative that could be linked to one of the too many powers that the Treaty unfortunately attributes to it. The question is: what more does this mean, in practice, for the citizens of the area concerned? When, where, how, did the Commission prove that its above-ground technocrats and convoluted procedures were more effective than anything?

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because we believe it is essential to have a clear strategy. Although I do not agree with some of the points that are addressed, I believe that a plan to solve this and other problems affecting many rural areas without means is urgently needed. In these areas the exploitation of the natural environment or tourist attractions is often prioritized over the standard of living of its own inhabitants. In addition, the dossier includes amendments that have been incorporated with civil society concerns about problems about coal emissions, renewable energy, climate change and protection of glaciers, endangered species and biodiversity. In addition, the report supports sustainable tourism and makes interesting contributions to Cop21. Mainly, I am interested in the mentions you make about more remote areas of the Alpine area that do not have access to the most basic social and economic services, lack of job opportunities, lack of connections, depopulation, etc.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for the Alpine region.  The EUSALP strategy is being implemented in a region where various forms of cooperation are already being undertaken, e.g. in the Alpine area and the Alpine Convention, as well as various interreg cross-border programmes. The EUSALP covers 48 regions in seven European countries: Italy, France, Slovenia, Austria, Germany, Switzerland and Liechtenstein. The region has a population of around 80 million people and is extremely attractive for its natural, economic and cultural values. The Alpine lowness and alpine mountain area are part of an inseparable natural and human system whose interdependence has influenced the entire history of the region. However, difficulties with connections and production logistics have often had a negative impact on the development of mountain areas. Moreover, the Alpine macro-region is also at high risk today from the effects of climate change.  That is why, in my opinion, public authorities should, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, respond to the economic and environmental challenges of the Alpine macro-region.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my socialist colleagues, I voted in favour of this report because it is part of a strategy that covers 80 million people in 7 countries and 48 regions in the EU and outside. The report will improve access and transport in the Alpine regions, improve competitiveness and cohesion and develop sustainability.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Alpine Macro-Regional Strategy (SEDRA), which aims to better articulate the allocation of European structural funds and national and regional funding to strengthen the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the Alpine massif.  The strategy covers 7 countries, including 5 EU Member States (Austria, France, Germany, Italy and Slovenia) and 2 non-EU states (Liechtenstein and Switzerland) as well as 48 regions. Being elected myself in a constituency in the Alps, I am committed to the development of our region and know its tremendous potential. This strategy is a real instrument for valuing our territory at the service of Alpine citizens. I am thinking specifically of the creation of these regional research centres and specific training centres that aim to respect the characteristics of the Alpine labour market, such as seasonality for example.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The Commission launched the fourth EU macro-regional strategy with its Communication concerning a European Union Strategy for the Alpine region focused on the population of more than70 million citizens who should reap the benefits of a closer cooperation between regions and countries in terms of research and innovation, SME support, mobility, tourism, environmental protection as well as energy resources management.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Our group has maintained an attitude of abstention in this report because of our opposition to clauses that threaten both the character of water as a social good and the reckless destruction of the environment on the other. Of course, as a group we support the provision of funds for the Alpine region and we welcome the fact that regions have the right to decide their own strategies for using these funds.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with the majority of my colleagues, supported this own initiative report on an EU strategy for the Alpine region which follows a number of similar macro-regional strategy reports for the Baltic Sea Region and the EU Strategy for the Danube Region. The report outlines a number of key areas where greater regional cooperation can be initiated with the goal of bringing countries, once in conflict, closer together while simultaneously growing the regional economy. Likewise, I was pleased that the rapporteur called for the use of the European Fund for Strategic Investment to be utilised in joined up macro strategies. This fund was specifically designed to reinvigorate investment in national and local economies and to incentivise further private investment. Using the fund, in conjunction with the EIB, could greatly help to create long term investment in such regional areas. Although I was supportive of the role that EFSI and private investment can play in a regional area, I did however support an amendment which called for the protection of water resources as I believe water is a public commodity and should not be privatised. Unfortunately this amendment did not pass.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 During the September plenary session of the European Parliament, I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for the Alpine region, which deals with the Union's fourth macro-regional strategy. The EU Strategy for the Alpine Region includes 48 regions in seven countries, five of which are EU Member States, and two others are Switzerland and Lichtenstein. Macro-regional strategies allow these countries to create strategic investments for the benefit of the whole region, bearing in mind the 'three no' principle. The strategy is based on three development pillars. The first pillar aims to increase the competitiveness and cohesion of the Alpine region, including the promotion of sustainable and competitive tourism. The second pillar is aimed at improving accessibility and ensuring adequate transport, energy network and ICT infrastructure. Sustainability, environmental protection, biodiversity and the protection of ecosystems are key words of the third pillar. The Alps macro-region has considerable potential, which can be further exploited through cooperation between countries and regions.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. As an elected official from a mountainous region, I am delighted that Europe is interested in the Alpine region, whose particularities it highlights and recognises. I hope that this recognition will apply to other mountain ranges. The adoption of a Eu-19 strategy for the Alpine Region (SEDRA) aims to better coordinate European, national and regional funds between countries, regions and cities that share a massif, river or maritime basin. Through this initiative, we can avoid duplication and unnecessary investment to focus funding on key needs, such as transportation, digital or innovation. In addition, this strategy takes into account the uniqueness of the labour market in these territories and therefore offers specific training and a multilingual regional online employment centre that will help border workers. Of course, we will have to assess the effectiveness of this strategy in the medium and long term, but I believe that the Union's actions in favour of mountainous regions should be better communicated to European citizens.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the proposals that the rapporteur made regarding a better strategy for the Alpine region. I believe it is paramount to improve the prosperity and competitiveness of the region – adding accessibility and transport lines, while striving to protect Alpine heritage.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the REPORT on the EU Strategy for the Alpine Region, as I support a European multilevel development planning policy that recognises the common characteristics of individual EU geographical areas and the border constraints prevail, and at one time as President of the Adriatic Euroregion I promoted the idea of creating an EU strategy for the Adriatic region (today the Adriatic-Ionian region). In this regard, I supported the creation of a macroeregional strategy that would address specific developments in the Alpine region.  I would like to stress that a change of thinking is needed on existing constraints given the functioning of the European macro-regions. A redefiniting of the "three NO" policy towards European macro-regions and the opening of additional financing opportunities for development projects in the Danube, Baltic, Adriatic-Ionian and Alpine regions is needed. It is necessary to define more clearly the mode for stronger participation of local and regional authorities in the implementation of macro-regional strategies.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. We are skeptical of macro-regional strategies whose governance model is based on increased participation of local and regional authorities in decision-making bodies. These future macro-regions will gradually escape the control of the Member States, not for the benefit of the local level, but thus leaving the field open to the European Commission to grant itself new prerogatives, particularly in the area of urban policy or education. I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Mercedes Bresso's report, which makes the European Parliament's recommendations on the European strategy for the Alpine region. The so-called "macro-regional" strategies coordinate the initiatives of cities and regions from different countries that share a massif, a river or a maritime basin. They are a privileged instrument for serving the territories to meet certain common challenges that go beyond national borders. In my view, this strategy will only be successful if the Alpine territories take ownership of it and if it does not result in an additional layer of bureaucracy. I welcome the adoption of this report, which makes proposals to this effect and emphasises the need to improve connectivity but also to protect the environment (especially glaciers) in the Alpine region.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which follows the Council's invitation in December 2013 to the Commission to propose a European Union strategy for the Alpine region (EUSALP). The Commission therefore presented the 'strategy action plan' in July 2015. This report, which brings together the recommendations of the European Parliament, recommends, among other things, that the European financing instruments available should be made as much as possible. It emphasizes the need to improve transport and energy connectivity and to protect biodiversity in the Alpine region. For the EPP Group it was important to defend the principle of "three no": no to new legislation, no to new funding, no to new institutions.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With a view to boosting investment, the Juncker Commission has introduced an Investment Plan for Europe and set up a European Fund for Strategic Investments. These offer the countries of the region an opportunity to launch new joint investment projects and build on those already in progress. EUSALP can now be used as a vehicle for strategic investment that will benefit the region as a whole. The Alpine macro-region has huge potential, and joint planning by the countries and regions in the area, coupled with close involvement of local authorities and public and private bodies, can help to realise that potential. The Commission will need to work together with the EIB and international bodies in providing guidance and support for the implementation of the strategy. Against this background, EUSALP offers the countries of the region an opportunity to invest in projects that will have an impact throughout the EU, and not just at regional level. It will allow new forms of multi-level governance to be developed, grounded in the regions but with the involvement of the European institutions. Given that it has co-legislative powers in the field of cohesion policy, Parliament has a key role to play in the design and implementation of the strategy.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report. His proposals aim to strengthen the Alpine region as a cultural, economic, natural and resource area and to prevent overexploitation. These include proposals such as the protection of natural water sources, new investment strategies for greater sustainability and the preservation of biodiversity.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it aims to improve access and transport in the Alpine regions, enhance competitiveness and cohesion and develop sustainability.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 During the September plenary session of the European Parliament, I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for the Alpine region, which deals with the Union's fourth macro-regional strategy. The EU Strategy for the Alpine Region includes 48 regions in seven countries, five of which are EU Member States, and two others are Switzerland and Lichtenstein. Macro-regional strategies allow these countries to create strategic investments for the benefit of the whole region, bearing in mind the 'three no' principle. The strategy is based on three development pillars. The first pillar aims to increase the competitiveness and cohesion of the Alpine region, including the promotion of sustainable and competitive tourism. The second pillar is aimed at improving accessibility and ensuring adequate transport, energy network and ICT infrastructure. Sustainability, environmental protection, biodiversity and the protection of ecosystems are key words of the third pillar. The Alps macro-region has considerable potential, which can be further exploited through cooperation between countries and regions.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I expressed my support to the report on the European Union Strategy for the Alpine Region, as I believe it provides an answer to regionally common issues, in line with the major European Europe 2020 targets in the areas of sustainable development, environment and energy.  Proposals for responsible management of sustainable and competitive tourism, diversification of tourism products and supply in order to overcome seasonal character and improve quality and innovation in tourism are key to the development of the Alpine region. At the same time, the protection of the remarkable system of lakes passing through the Alpine and Pre-Alpine plains, the conservation and restoration of ecosystem biodiversity by providing an appropriate system for monitoring, information and managing the Natura 2000 network presupses sustainable management of nature.  It enables the countries of the region to invest in joint projects at European and not only interregional level, as well as to promote the sustainable development of the Alpine economy and the sustainable use of Alpine resources.  I hope that the experience gained from the implementation of the strategy will also be used in other mountainous areas of the Community in the near future.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Today we approve the Alpine Strategy Action Plan (EUSALP). This strategy is based on the concept of macro-regions and their importance as a means of cooperation and development of synergies between the different EU funding instruments. It also encourages innovation and the use of new technologies in the economy; promotes tourism and the importance of transport connectivity; and enhances the biodiversity of the regions. Lastly, it called on the Member States to coordinate their national and regional policies in order to achieve the objectives of European action effectively.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it limits the scope of national governments to the benefit of the European Commission, which is granting itself new prerogatives, particularly in the area of urban policy or education.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report entitled 'European Union Strategy for the Alpine Region'. I share most of the priorities defended by EUSALP, such as the preservation of the environment, the modernisation of water infrastructure, the creation of competitiveness hubs, the development of new tourism offerings to limit the seasonal aspect of alpine tourism, and the development of rail transport.  On the other hand, I am opposed to any macro-regional strategy whose governance model is based on increased participation of local and regional authorities in decision-making bodies. These future macro-regions will gradually escape the control of the Member States, thus leaving the european Commission free to grant itself new prerogatives, particularly in the area of urban policy or education.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the Mercedes Bresso report. Text in favour of the macro-regional strategy, based on a multi-level governance model with increased participation of local authorities. It also aims, like so many others, to limit the scope of action of national governments in favour of the Commission, which is granting itself new prerogatives in urban policy and education.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it sets out the development priorities, ideas and proposals for the Alpine Region Union Strategy (EUSALP) and develops in a context characterized by various types of cooperation in the region, such as the Alpine Area programme and the Alps Convention: improving the competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion of the Alpine region. Ensure accessibility and connections to all inhabitants of the Alpine region (cross-border transport and intermodal connections to the interior). Ensure sustainability in the Alps: protect Alpine heritage and promote sustainable use of natural and cultural resources (environment, transnational terrestrial habitats and biodiversity). Because the difficulties of connection and logistics of production have marked the development of mountain territories. In addition, the area of the Alpine macroregion is also, to this day, very vulnerable to the effects of climate change. In this context, the report stresses that public authorities, on the basis of the principle of subsidiarity, must address the economic and environmental challenges of the Alpine macroregion.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted to abstain in this report because despite containing positive aspects on multi-level governance, investment, job creation, the environment, climate change and mobility, it seems to me to be an un priority issue since it is one of the richest territorial areas of the Union, with enormous capacity to absorb periods of crisis. A proposal for better coordination is always welcome, but issues such as the correction of economic inequalities, labour rights, the incorporation of young people into the labour market or gender policies are lacking.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The Union's Alpine Region Strategy (EUSALP) aims to strengthen the ties of the participating countries in order to carry out joint actions in the areas of transport, environment, protection of cultural heritage, energy and tourism, among others. I believe that given the underutilization of resources in EUSALP mountain areas and the high concentration of production in plain areas, integrated economic strategies need to be carried out. These strategies are consistent with the objectives and priorities of European funds at the moment.   In addition, EUSALP provides added value, as it is a question of addressing common objectives throughout the area, which are consistent with the main objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy on sustainable development, environment and energy and to achieve them it is necessary to design and carry out projects of macro-regional dimension.  That is why I give my positive vote for the adoption of this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which supports synergies within macro regions and the diversification of tourism. This report encourages innovation while reserving forms of traditional economic activity.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. In my think, regions where there are Alps should not have any special EU programmes. According to the report, the Alpine regions need an "action plan". I do not agree with the Commission's call for solutions to introduce broadband internet in all remote corners of the Alps. The European Commission is not supposed to deal with the Internet in the Alps, it is to be addressed by internet providers based on customer demand.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support presented EU Strategy for the Alpine Region to preserve and valorise natural resources, to develop ecological connectivity, to improve risk management as regards climate change, and carry out a comprehensive vulnerability assessment of the sectors and systems likely to be affected and developing a regional strategy on adapting to climate change.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 I support this macro-regional strategy because its implementation will help to solve the problems of alpine regions, their development and cooperation at both regional and European level. The strategy relies on three basic pillars: 1, improving competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion of the Alpine region, 2, ensuring accessibility and connections for all inhabitants of the Alpine region (cross-border transport, intermodal connections with the hinterland), 3, ensuring sustainability in the Alps: protecting alpine heritage and promoting the sustainable use of natural and cultural resources (environment, cross-border habitats and biodiversity).

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the EU strategy for the Alpine region because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. Despite several proposals that we support (the preservation of the environment, the modernisation of water infrastructure, the creation of competitiveness poles), this text is in favour of the macro-regional strategy which will deprive Member States of their decision-making fields.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report addressing the issue of the Alpine region and the EU's strategy for the development of the region. After several months of negotiations, agreement has been reached on the need to increase prosperity and cohesion in the region, to develop a locally oriented approach to the development of alpine areas, to promote sustainable and competitive tourism, with the help of improving the availability of supply and services, and a specific chapter should then be the attention paid to the protection of the extraordinary system of Alpine lakes. Furthermore, the focus should be on the use and improvement of existing infrastructure and on developing innovative logistics-related systems. I supported the draft report in the vote.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report addresses a number of important issues such as concerns about carbon emissions, renewable energy, climate change, species protection and biodiversity, the potential risks of hydropower and sustainable tourism. However, the report could go further than renewable energy. A group of Members in which I include myself tabled amendments on water as a public good, which were sinkered in plenary. In the framework of cohesion policies, we deeply regret and find it unacceptable to blackmail Portugal with sanctions through European funds.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The Transalpine Region has clear specificities within the Union, which must be taken into account in order to enable its development and that people living there can maintain adequate welfare quotas. My support for the report on the Union Strategy for this region and my hope that all measures will be taken to further promote harmonious development across Europe, which strengthens economic, social and territorial cohesion throughout the Union.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This report aims to strengthen the Alpine region. The focus is on increasing competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion, but also on the accessibility of remote areas and the protection of alpine heritage. These points are also important to me, which is why I support this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In 2011, Alpine regions of 5 EU Member States, including France (with Rhône Alpes-Auvergne, PACA and Franche-Comté) and 2 third countries, resolved to strengthen their institutional, economic and cultural cooperation, etc. Since the Lisbon Treaty, this intergovernmental cooperation must be anchored in the Commission's broader strategy of strengthening 'macro-regions'.  It is actually a dilution of democracy, hidden behind pompous terms such as "multi-level governance" and the creation of "investment structures" to receive public and private funds to serve them.  Basically, it is a question of dislocating the democratic structure of the nation-state in favour of absurd regionalisms. In short, it is public money that serves the private sector in a decision-making process that is increasingly distant from citizens. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Text in favour of the macro-regional strategy based on a multi-level governance model with increased participation of local authorities. It also aims to limit the scope of national governments to the benefit of the Commission, which is granting itself new prerogatives in urban policy and education.  Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to promote harmonious global development, the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the whole EU needs to be strengthened. Macro-regional strategies are currently the key instrument to contribute to the objective of economic, social and territorial cohesion. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it notes the particular difficulties that the Alpine region faces as well as its heritage that present ample opportunities for citizens working in the region. The Union needs to do all that it can to support regions that face inherent geographic difficulties when accessing the common market.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – The Alpine Strategy (EUSALP) is the EU's fourth macro-regional strategy. Macro-regional strategies represent a new opportunity for the comprehensive development of the wider region, as they focus on common challenges and potential. They thus represent added value at EU level and strengthen current horizontal EU policies. The EUSALP covers 48 regions and 7 countries, including 5 Member States. More than 80 million people live in the region. With its cultural, human, natural and economic attractiveness, it offers an opportunity for strategic investments for the benefit of the whole region. The strategy is built on three pillars: improving competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion; ensuring accessibility and connections for all residents of the region through infrastructure modernisation and ensuring sustainability in the Alps. I am voting in favour of the draft strategy in favour.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because it is important to provide solutions to the common problems and challenges in the Alpine region.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission presented in July 2015 an action plan for the EU Strategy for the Alpine Region. This is the fourth EU macro-regional strategy following the EU strategy for the Baltic Sea region, the Danube region and the Adriatic and Ionian regions. The draft resolution of the Committee on Regional Development analyses this strategy. It states that the EU strategy for the Alpine region gives countries in the region the opportunity to invest in projects that have an EU-wide impact and not just at regional level. The strategy will enable the development of new multi-level forms of governance, based in the regions, in which the EU institutions are involved. The draft summarises the main proposals and priorities for the strategy in three pillars: I. Increasing the competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion of the Alpine region. II. Providing accessibility and transport links for people living in the Alps region. III. Ensuring sustainability in the Alps: Protecting the heritage of the Alps and promoting the sustainable use of natural and cultural resources. I supported the adoption of the draft.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report lays the groundwork for the Eu/15 Strategy for the Alpine Region (EUSALP). This is the fourth macro-regional strategy after the strategy for the Baltic Sea region, the strategy for the Danube region and the strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Sea region. We share most of the priorities advocated by EUSALP.   On the other hand, we are by definition opposed to any macro-regional strategy whose governance model is based on increased participation of local and regional authorities in decision-making bodies. These future macro-regions will gradually escape the control of the Member States, thus leaving the scope open to the European Commission to grant itself new prerogatives, particularly in the area of urban policy or education. Unfavorable vote.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. With the aim of promoting harmonious global development, economic, social and territorial cohesion across the EU, I believe that the macro-regional strategy for the Alpine region can contribute to the reversal of economic decline through investment in research, innovation and support for entrepreneurship. It is important to stress that macro-regional strategies should aim at achieving more effectively the common objectives of the different regions, by identifying resources and exploiting the common development potential of the regions.  I support the importance of the Commission Communication and the Action Plan for the Alpine Region, which is a key step towards the development of the region, in line with the Europe 2020 strategy objective of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, as well as having a vital role in the fight against the depopulation of the region, in particular the exodus of the young population.  I endorse the rapporteur's position on the necessary strengthening of the social dimension to ensure the development of a growth model capable of ensuring sustainable growth, social inclusion and social protection for all, especially in border areas, and the importance of encouraging the creation of social infrastructure and promoting social investment.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the European Union's strategy for the Alpine region aims to lay the groundwork for the macro-regional strategy based on a multi-level governance model with increased participation of local authorities in order to limit the scope of action of national governments and to ignore the state level. All this for the benefit of the European Commission, which is granting itself new prerogatives in urban and land-use planning. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my socialist colleagues, I voted in favour of this report because it is part of a strategy that covers 80 million people in 7 countries and 48 regions in the EU and outside. The report will improve access and transport in the Alpine regions, improve competitiveness and cohesion and develop sustainability.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the EU strategy for the Alpine region. Indeed, it was necessary to show the determination of the EU to want to protect this region which is a formidable tourist and scientific asset for our continent. In particular, I have supported all the provisions aimed at protecting the biodiversity that is fundamental in this European region.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is one of the tools alongside citizens, whose resources fall entirely on the territories and remain one of the EU's sources of direct investment in regions and local authorities. In particular, the Strategy for the Alpine Region offers an opportunity to invest in joint projects, developing new forms of governance at different levels in which the European Union and the regions interact effectively. Investing in EUSALP means adding value to existing cross-border cooperation, in territories with 80 million inhabitants and involving 48 regions. That is why I was happy to welcome the proposal to create an investment platform for the Alpine region that would mobilise public and private funding, including through the EIB and the opportunities of EFSI. In particular, I welcome the idea that we need a digital policy for this region, offering more opportunities for openness and contacts. The Internet can be a tool for improving infrastructure, services as well as communication, to the benefit of both the inhabitants of the region and the tourists who populate these areas every year. I therefore voted in favour of this report because I believe that it will make a fundamental contribution to recovery and development in the regions concerned.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the European Union's strategy for the Alpine region, despite some negative points on which I voted against. The resolution calls on states to encourage the coordination of national and regional policies to implement the European Union's strategy for the Alpine region. It is essential to respect the principle of subsidiarity, as is well stated in the report.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the report on the EU strategy for the Alpine region. This macro-region has a strategic role for the Union, from a cultural, geographical and commercial point of view, making effective cross-border cooperation between those areas essential. However, because of its specificities, this macro-region is exposed to challenges that threaten it and at the same time hinder its enormous potential. Difficulties in connections, high sensitivity to climate change, critical issues in the development of energy infrastructure and promotion of start-ups and small and SMEs are some of the issues to which the report offers concrete solutions. The role of the strategy is to maximise synergies between existing cooperations and to ensure that they are in line with European macro-objectives, while also strengthening them in the areas most critical to achieving sustainable development in the area. By promoting this report, the European Parliament would also like to stress the need for an approach that starts from the territory, but at the same time allows a large-scale impact to be made, according to an intelligent application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Alps region is considered the largest natural area in Europe. The area has outstanding natural resources, home to tens of thousands of animal and plant species, not one of which is in a dying queue. It is true that the region directly affects five Member States, but we must not forget that the Alps serve as a 'water tower' for vital rivers across Europe, such as the Danube, Rhine, Po and Rhone. Melting snow and ice usually reach these rivers when they are most needed. In addition to natural wonders, the Alps region is home to about 80 million people. Every year, the huge contrast between remote mountainous areas and lowland metropolitan areas is more challenging. I welcome the EU strategy presented by this report, as it covers the whole region and the objectives and priorities set actually contribute to the preservation of this particularly important area.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission submitted an action plan for the Alpine regions strategy in July 2015 under the name EUSALP. This macro-regional strategy will contribute to achieving economic, social and territorial cohesion in alpine regions. I have voted for this report enabling the fourth EU macro-regional strategy following those for the Danube region, Adriatic and Ionian region and Baltic Sea region.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report because, on the one hand, it highlights the valuable experience gained from the implementation of the Alpine Convention, which serves the social, economic and environmental interests of the areas concerned in a non-biased manner; on the other hand, there is real concern with regard to the implementation of natural disaster risk management measures and climate change adaptation strategies. Another factor that led me to support this proposal is the harnessing of the capacity of local and regional authorities and civil society at local and regional level within the management bodies and within the operational bodies.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, which is the fourth EU macro-regional strategy. EUSALP covers 48 regions in seven countries, five of which are Member States (Italy, France, Slovenia, Austria and Germany). The other two countries are Switzerland and Liechtenstein. EUSALP is a vehicle for strategic investment that will benefit the region as a whole. The report tackles various important issues regarding the EUSALP: multi-level governance, investments, jobs, environment, climate change and mobility.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report calls on the EIB, in cooperation with the Commission, to explore the possibility of establishing an investment platform for the Alpine region that would allow the mobilisation of funds from public and private sources; calls for the creation of a gas pipeline project for the region that would attract investors; encourages clustering and cooperation between public and private enterprises, universities, research institutes and other stakeholders in order to promote innovation.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This report aims to strengthen the Alpine region. The focus is on increasing competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion, but also on the accessibility of remote areas and the protection of alpine heritage. These points are also important to me, which is why I support this report.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This is the EU's fourth macro-regional strategy. The EUSALP strategy, which covers 80 million people in 7 countries and 48 regions inside and outside the EU, covers the Alpine region, a region already involved in various cooperation agreements. However, the region has poor transport links and logistical problems for manufacturers and suffers from the consequences of climate change. Local, regional and national authorities should therefore take measures in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity to address problems throughout the region. This strategy is built on a number of pillars, reflected in the report and in which proposals have been made such as improving competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion, accessibility and transport links for all in the Alpine region, protecting the cultural heritage of the Alps and promoting the sustainable use of natural and cultural resources. For all these reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this report because we feel that the countries of the Alpine region, not the EU, have the right to make their own decisions. We note that in Amendment 1, the EU orders Member States not to spend on their own priorities, but instead only EU ones. This kind of bullying should not be allowed.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In addition to thanking the rapporteur for her work, I am reiterating my idea and the importance of key projects for sustainable European transport that serve as an incentive for the whole territory and neighbouring regions. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I supported this report as it underlines the importance of financial instruments, of encouraging innovation and new technologies in key areas of the economy, while preserving also forms of traditional economic activity. It supports the diversification of tourism, stresses the importance of improving transport and energy connectivity, as well as of protecting and enhancing the biodiversity in the Alpine Region.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Alpine area is an exceptional and huge potential for the development of the economy and needs to support programmes and strategies such as this one. The strategy applies to five EU regions, two regions outside the EU's borders and a large population falling under alpine regions.  Investments are needed in the transport system, digital technology, renewables. It is also necessary to invest in the development of tourism throughout the year, not just one season from which the population there will be able to live. It should be emphasized that such tourism must be sustainable and sensitive in terms of the environment, as well as physical planning and construction, so as not to disturb the original appearance of such areas.  Also in this proposal I see an opportunity for Croatia that has the potential in its mountainous regions to encourage greater development of sustainable tourism and agriculture.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. I am, of course, opposed to any macro-regional strategy whose governance model is based on increased participation of local and regional authorities in decision-making bodies. These future macro-regions will gradually escape the control of the Member States, thus leaving the scope open to the European Commission to grant itself new prerogatives, particularly in the area of urban policy or education. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Climate change in the Alpine region is progressing faster than the world average, causing more and more natural disasters such as avalanches and floods. Macro-regional strategies can contribute to the development of cross-border strategies and international projects to create cooperation networks that will benefit the entire region. Macrostrategy for the Alpine region will affect 80 million people living in 48 regions in seven countries, five of which are EU Member States (Austria, France, Italy, Germany and Slovenia) and two are outside the EU (Liechtenstein and Switzerland).  I welcome the fact that the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF) provide potentially important resources and a range of instruments and options for this strategy, and I underline the importance of the triple no principle, as macro-regions are frameworks for creating added value for cooperation initiatives and synergies between the different EU funding instruments.  Innovation and application of new technologies in key areas of the economy, encouraged by smart specialisation strategies and funded from existing EU sources (e.g. ERDF, ESF, COSME, Horizon 2020 or Erasmus+) will help create quality jobs in strategic sectors such as biosciences, bioeconomy, energy, organic products, new materials or e-services. That is why I agree with the rapporteur's calls and support the adoption of this report.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Social cohesion is essential for the harmonious and even development of the European Union. It is therefore the Union's responsibility to support regions that are disadvantaged by natural conditions, particularly vulnerable to climate change or seasonal influences, in order to ensure their sustainable and integrated development. The Alpine region is a dynamic region in Europe, home not only to 80 million inhabitants from 7 European countries, but also to unique animal and plant species. They are all at risk of global warming and the associated melting of glaciers, which has negative impacts on the sustainability of alpine ecosystems and the economic development of the area. I therefore welcome and voted in favour of the European Parliament's report, which takes into account the need to address the causes of climate change through various measures in the fields of energy, transport and investment in modern technologies. In this respect, renewable energy sources, to which the Alps are rich, have great potential. At the same time, however, we must not forget to balance with other vital features of alpine forests, which serve as flood prevention and protection from landslides and avalanches. I agree with the report that these problems need to be addressed in a coordinated manner through a large-scale transnational plan to combat the melting of glaciers, which, in my opinion, should cover all the related problems.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe the EU Strategy for the Alpine Region has a potential to address the main regional problems. The strategy covers over 80 million people from 7 countries and 48 regions within and outside the EU. It will be in addition to various cooperation agreements, focusing on the issues of transportation shortage, logistical manufacturing concerns, and climate change. I am pleased by the full report from the Committee on Regional Development which provides solutions to the common problems and challenges facing the Alpine Region, laying the groundwork for the implementation of the strategy. The strategy is a bottom up approach that takes into account local needs while also participating in cross-border, transnational, and interregional coordination and cooperation, focusing on a few pillar issues. These issues include improving competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion, increasing accessibility and transportation links, and ensuring cultural and environmental sustainability. I urge local, regional and national authorities to take action together to implement the EU Strategy for the Alpine Region to solve the major problems facing their region.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 European macro-regions can be the institutional framework within which to promote the exchange of good practice and the implementation of ambitious joint projects. Europe is rich in different geographical areas, each with its own peculiarities. The Alpine region is undoubtedly a part of the EU's territory which offers countless opportunities for economic and social development. This report stresses in particular the importance of encouraging innovation and the development of new technologies in key sectors of the economy, while also maintaining traditional forms of economic activity; supports the diversification of tourism, stresses the importance of improving transport and energy connectivity, as well as protecting and enhancing the biodiversity of the Alpine region. These are all objectives that I believe to be central to the implementation of a strategy that combines tradition and modernity. I voted in favour of this report with the conviction that cross-border cooperation between regions is the key to better management of European territory.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The EU Strategy for the Alpine Region covers 7 countries, 5 of which are EU Member States (Austria, France, Germany, Italy and Slovenia) and 2 non-EU countries (Liechtenstein and Switzerland), as well as 48 regions with a population of more than 80 million citizens. The strategy covers three thematic areas: growth, mobility and connectivity policies, as well as environmental and energy protection. The EUSALP provides a framework for policy coordination and territorial cooperation; aims to ensure mutually beneficial contacts between mountainous regions and the surrounding lowlands and urban areas. The report focuses on the potential of ESI Funds and other EU funding options for strategic planning for both urban and alpine areas. This strategy does not require the use of additional resources. Existing funds are used to implement it and to ensure proper coordination. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is part of the Alpine Macro-Regional Strategy (SEDRA). The mountain can be a definite geographical handicap for alpine territories. To fill some barriers, concrete achievements, such as regional research centres or training centres specific to the labour markets of the Alpine territories, will be part of this European strategy. European macro-regions are frameworks for cooperation and the development of synergies between different EU financial instruments. Indeed, seven European countries, including five Member States, comprising 48 regions, will be able, through this macro-regional strategy, to strengthen the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the Alpine massif.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Treaty of Lisbon, establishing a set of norms that point to the design of territorial cohesion, allowed the creation of macro-regional strategies, through intergovernmental initiatives, in order to relaunch economic and institutional cooperation between seemingly distant territories. The Union strategy for the Alpine Region (EUSALP) covers 48 regions and 7 countries, represented by five Member States. Around 80 million people live in the region and it has vast natural, economic and cultural resources.  This report identifies the priorities presented by the member parties of the region: improving the competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion of the region, ensuring access to and interconnection for all the inhabitants of the region, and the sustainability of the Alps. It should be noted that this macro-regional strategy is based on the opportunities of existing cooperation initiatives and synergies between different Union financial instruments, thus applying the three 'No' principle on legislation, financing and the establishment of institutions. EUSALP offers an opportunity for members of the Alpine Region, either to make investments in joint European impact projects, enabling a joint vision and action on regional problems, or in promoting territorial cohesion and the good relationship between Member States. I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this report because we feel that the countries of the Alpine region, not the EU, have the right to make their own decisions. We note that in Amendment 1, the EU orders Member States not to spend on their own priorities, but instead only EU ones. This kind of bullying should not be allowed.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, because I believe that it is necessary to invest in joint projects with european impact, not just interregional, and to develop new forms of multi-level governance, starting from the regions, with the contribution of the European institutions. The competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion of the Alpine region must therefore be improved, access to and interconnection for all the inhabitants of the Alpine region (cross-border transport, intermodal links with the interior) and ensuring sustainability in the Alps.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 These regions have significant development potential. Priorities are to improve the competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion of the Alpine region, to ensure access to and interconnection of all the region's inhabitants (cross-border transport, intermodal links with the interior), to ensure sustainability in the Alps, to protect heritage and to promote sustainable use of natural and cultural resources (environment, transnational land habitats and biodiversity).

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The EU Strategy for the Alpine Region is developed in a context characterized by various types of cooperation in the region, as well as various cross-border Interreg programmes. This region, home to more than 80 million inhabitants, covers 48 regions and 7 countries and has a strong human, natural, economic and cultural appeal. However, the difficulties of connection and logistics of production have marked the development of mountain territories. In addition, the area is also very vulnerable to the effects of climate change. In this context, the report emphasizes that public authorities must address existing economic and environmental challenges. The report sets out as priorities: improving the competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion of the Alpine region; ensure accessibility and connections to all the inhabitants of the region; ensure sustainability in the Alps; or protect Alpine heritage and promote sustainable use of natural and cultural resources. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's proposal on the strategy for the Alpine region because, as a macro-regional strategy, it can serve as a model and inspire other Alpine regions of the European Union.  This strategy helps to strengthen the objective of environmental, territorial, social and economic cohesion.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In response to the Council's request in 2013, the European Commission submitted an action plan on the European Union Strategy for the Alpine Region (EUERA).  This own-initiative report takes the principle that macro-regions should develop synergies between the different EU funding instruments, and therefore the Member States involved should coordinate their national and regional policies in order to contribute to the actions and objectives envisaged in EUERA. The rapporteur stresses the importance of a Strategic Plan for this geographical area, insisting on the adoption of partnerships for the management and implementation of actions based on respect for the principles of subsidiarity and multilevel governance. In addition, it stresses the importance of financial instruments in stimulating research and innovation, both in the context of the search for new technologies and in key areas of the economy, preserving, stimulating and seeking more added value for traditional economic activities. The diversification of tourism, the importance of improving connectivity in transport and energy networks, as well as the protection and improvement of biodiversity are some of the proposals put forward by the colleague and which lead me to vote in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to better articulate the distribution of European structural funds and national and regional funding between seven European countries, including five EU Member States and 48 regions. The ultimate goal is to strengthen the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the Alpine massif. This report makes the European Parliament's recommendations on the alpine region strategy, which was presented by the European Commission in July 2015. This strategy is an instrument at the service of the territories to respond to common challenges that go beyond national borders. It is necessary to improve connectivity in transport, energy or to protect biodiversity in the Alpine region. Innovation is one of the main challenges facing the region. In this sense, Parliament calls for the creation of regional research centres and training centres to meet the specific needs of the region.  I supported this report, which reminds us of the importance of interconnections between the border Member States which share the same challenges and opportunities. This strategy is a concrete response to the need for cooperation between different regions of the same geographical group.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because we believe it is essential to have a clear strategy. Although I do not agree with some of the points that are addressed, I believe that a plan to solve this and other problems affecting many rural areas without means is urgently needed. In these areas the exploitation of the natural environment or tourist attractions is often prioritized over the standard of living of its own inhabitants. In addition, the dossier includes amendments that have been incorporated with civil society concerns about problems about coal emissions, renewable energy, climate change and protection of glaciers, endangered species and biodiversity. In addition, the report supports sustainable tourism and makes interesting contributions to Cop21. Mainly, I am interested in the mentions you make about more remote areas of the Alpine area that do not have access to the most basic social and economic services, lack of job opportunities, lack of connections, depopulation, etc.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A macro-regional strategy is vitally important for the Alpine region and a common approach will help address the challenges and opportunities shared by seven countries with a collective population of approximately 80 million people. Some flexibility will be needed, given the variety of national, regional and local authorities from multiple countries which are responsible for administering the region. The fragile environmental situation combined with the presence and importance of tourism present particular problems; the strategy must prioritise environmental concerns so that the economic opportunities remain sustainable and Alpine heritage is protected.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on an EU strategy for the Alpine region, as I believe it makes sense for the eight Member States that have a share in the Alps to coordinate their national and regional actions and to use synergies between different EU financial instruments for the macro-region. The report also underlines the importance of promoting innovation in key sectors of the economy while preserving the forms of traditional economic activity, supporting the diversification of tourism provision and highlighting the importance of improving transport and energy connectivity and protecting and promoting biodiversity in the Alpine region.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which highlights the principle that macro-regions are frameworks for cooperation activities and developing synergies between different EU instruments. Alpine Regions can be considered as a symbol of European integration since it exists a long lasting tradition of cooperation, with a number of networks already in place, and the ambition of this Strategy should strengthen this solidarity. Experience shows that success highly depends on commitment. We therefore also need strong active involvement of all regional and national partners to fully exploit the potential highlighted in the report.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted to abstain in this report because despite containing positive aspects on multi-level governance, investment, job creation, the environment, climate change and mobility, it seems to me to be an un priority issue since it is one of the richest territorial areas of the Union, with enormous capacity to absorb periods of crisis. A proposal for better coordination is always welcome, but issues such as the correction of economic inequalities, labour rights, the incorporation of young people into the labour market or gender policies are lacking.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I believe this should be left to the Member States.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because innovation is an area that is continuously changing, RIS 3 strategies should be constant revised. For this purpose, a review of the strategies after 2017 seems mandatory in order to boost the efficiency and effectiveness of them, taking also into account the lessons learned from the initial years of their implementation.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. The European Union Strategy for the Alpine Region (EUSALP) concerns under-resourced mountain areas (indoor areas) as well as lowland areas with a high concentration of production. I support the creation of an integrated economic strategy for the region. At the same time, this strategy will help the EU to achieve the europe 2020 headline targets for sustainable development, the environment, energy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I consider the Alpine region, which affects approximately 80 million people in 48 regions and seven countries, to be one of the richest areas in the world and, from an economic point of view, one of the most dynamic, innovative and competitive areas in Europe. Unfortunately, despite these facts, the region faces many common challenges in the areas of the environment, demography, transport, tourism and energy consumption. I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that coordinated spatial planning will produce better results and create added value for the territorial cohesion of the Alpine and Alps fore-mountain areas. I also supported the EU strategy for the Alpine region because previous EU macro-regional strategies have seen the success of cooperation of this kind and have brought useful experience to developing new macro-regional strategies. I believe that the strategy is particularly well adapted for the sustainable development of the Alpine region and for promoting growth throughout Europe and mutual solidarity between mountainous territories and the foothills of the Alps. I believe that the EU Strategy for the Alpine Region will ensure the development of the region in line with the objective of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth set out in the Europe 2020 strategy.
