Finally, I would like to acknowledge the work of the rapporteur and her personal contribution to a very good report.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU Strategy for the Alpine Region (EUSALP) is the Fourth Macro-Regional Strategy of the European Union and covers 48 regions in seven countries, five of which are EU members (Italy, France, Slovenia, Austria, Germany) and two non-member countries (Liechtenstein and Switzerland). This region is one of the largest regions in Europe, with more than 70 million people living and working there.  In conjunction with EUSALP, the Commission has identified a number of challenges that this strategy will face. These are: economic globalisation, demographic trends, climate change, energy challenges and a specific geographical position.  Transport and mobility have traditionally been the two biggest challenges of the Alpine region, mainly due to the impact on the environment and climate in the Alps. Although such a strategy is welcome, it has not taken into account the proposals of Parliament's EU Committee on Transport and Tourism, and at the same time the report does not cover thematics of environmental and climate protection, renewable energy sources, which I believe are increasingly crucial in this region.  Due to the indecision of the report and the lack of coverage of these topics, I abstained from the vote.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the Alpine region is an important area that connects the south and north of the European Union. Experience from and will be carried out in development projects can serve as a model for other regions with similar characteristics, including the Carpathian Arch area.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. Only France, Italy, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Austria, Germany and Slovenia benefit from the EU strategy for the Alpine region. Why does the EU need it? If these countries are legitimate to promote the Alpine region as a tourism, agricultural and economic area, they should do so within the framework of intergovernmental cooperation. This does not require the EU, there is no legitimate added value for it. The misrepresentation of climate change, which has been repeated here, does not give this resolution any more legitimacy for EU competence. I voted against this resolution because it invites distortion of competition. Real entrepreneurship is prevented by the influence of the EIB and EFSI. The so-called 'operational programmes' do not ensure sustainable economic growth, but a lasting dependence on the goodwill of the Brussels Eurocrats. Parliament is also in favour of designing school holidays in the pre-Alpine region. This is certainly not his competence, but a matter for the country. I support the coordination of the Alpine regions within the framework of inter-regional cooperation under the sovereignty of their respective national governments. However, the EU has lost nothing here. There is no reliable evidence of added value, but it creates new dependence on the EU Commission. We should not forget that.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. The report is based on the principle that macro-regions are frameworks for cooperation and synergies between different EU funding instruments and encourages Member States involved in EUSALP (48 regions in seven countries) to coordinate their national and regional policies. EUSALP underlines the importance of financial instruments, stimulates innovation and new technologies in key areas of the economy, supports the diversity of tourism, stresses the importance of improving transport and energy links and the importance of protecting and improving biodiversity in the Alpine area. I support this proposal for a Resolution on the EU Strategy for the Alpine Region, as I believe that the enormous potential of bottom-up strategic spatial planning should be exploited as opposed to traditional approaches. I believe that a clearer definition of the governance system to be applied for strategies needs to be defined more clearly and that the role of EU and Member State bodies should be limited to starting strategies, subsequent coordination and oversight, as regional and local authorities must be the true drivers of territorial and development policies at the lowest level.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for the Alpine region.  As an alternate member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, I support the committee's call for the Commission and the Member States to strengthen multi-level governance in transport planning and implement a policy of developing sustainable, inclusive and non-invasive transport infrastructure in a highly mountainous Alpine region that will preserve the region and promote the balanced development of economically weaker regions and areas in the areas of tourism, social cohesion, economic development and employment.  The Commission should also focus on optimising the existing capacity of the infrastructure network, with the overall objective of improving the operation of the TEN-T network.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Our group has maintained an attitude of abstention in this report because of our opposition to clauses that threaten both the character of water as a social good and the reckless destruction of the environment on the other. Of course, as a group we support the provision of funds for the Alpine region and we welcome the fact that regions have the right to decide their own strategies for using these funds.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 There are regions in Europe that face much greater challenges, and the Union should deal with them first.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In December 2013, the European Council invited the Commission to present an EU strategy for the Alpine region. The Commission has complied with the request, which is the fourth EU macro-regional strategy based on the experience gained in the EU strategy for the Baltic Sea region, the Danube region and the Adriatic and Ionian regions. The EU Strategy for the Alps region involves 80 million people and 48 regions in 7 different countries, five of which are EU Member States (Italy, France, Slovenia, Austria, Germany) and the other two are Switzerland and Liechtenstein. There is already live cooperation between smaller regions, but the EU strategy for the Alpine region provides an opportunity to create strategic investments for the benefit of the whole region. I therefore voted in favour of this report. The region, along the pillars of the common strategy, can solve its transport and logistical problems, but only if they coordinate their ideas from the local level. They can also strengthen their competitiveness and cohesion and, last but not least, ensure sustainability. I trust that the Danube region can make the same use of development potential as the expected successful Alpine region.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU strategy for the Alpine region involves several Member States, including Italy and France, via the Turin-Lyon rail link. Although the Bresso report refers to the issues of depopulation in mountain areas, the importance of ensuring Internet access quickly to enable digital and online services, including e-commerce and teleworking, and, although the issue of biodiversity and the preservation of the ecosystem is also mentioned, there are still many critical issues. One of the main problems we have is the danger that there will be a great waste of money, in relation to the Turin-Lyon route which already exists and has recently been modernised. This route could already dispose of freight traffic between Italy and France. The project therefore seems to us to be an unnecessary transfer of wealth to the large companies that will win contracts. Although the report contains improvements, the system of contracts and subcontracting envisaged for the implementation of the project will make it difficult to monitor its regularity. For the above reasons, I abstained.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Alpine region is one of the main tourist areas of the European Union. In this context, the development of an EU regional strategy dedicated to the Alps area is a significant element, favoured by the objective of territorial cohesion enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon. This is the fourth such strategy dedicated to a European region, following the strategies of the Danube, the Baltic Sea area and the Ionico-Adriatic area. In this case, the EUSALP strategy covers 80 million inhabitants in 7 countries and 48 regions within, but also outside the EU, an area characterised by good inter-state cooperation but insufficient transport infrastructure, logistical problems with producers and suffering from the effects of climate change. The strategy is based on a number of fundamental pillars, such as improving competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion, ensuring accessibility and connectivity for all residents of the region, and guaranteeing sustainability by protecting Alpine heritage and promoting sustainable use of natural and cultural resources. Achieving these objectives would further enhance the region's huge potential, contributing to the Union's territorial cohesion. I believe it is a commendable initiative and I support the adoption of this report in its current form.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I followed my political group in voting for this text. Following an initiative in the Alpine regions at the end of 2011, the European Council in December 2013 invited the Commission to present a European Union strategy for the Alpine region (EUSALP). The Commission responded to this request by presenting the strategy's action plan in July 2015.  This fourth EU macro-regional strategy can benefit from the experience of the European Union's strategy for the Baltic Sea region, the European Union's strategy for the Danube region and the European Union's strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Sea region.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Alpine region, inhabited by more than 80 million, has a strong human, natural, economic and cultural appeal. It represents a huge potential for economic growth but also for increased cooperation between historically and politically divided areas at the heart of Europe. However, the economically and environmentally inconsistent development of the region has led to depopulation, especially of young people, and left it extremely vulnerable to the effects of climate change. This is why I voted in favour of the report on an EU strategy for the Alpine region, which I see as a central initiative to halt this trend. It will do so by increasing its competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion, by improving its accessibility and transport links, and by protecting the Alpine heritage and promoting sustainable use of natural and cultural resources.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I believe that the European Union's strategy for the Alpine region is extremely useful as it encourages investment in rural areas, not least by ensuring effective access to healthcare equivalent to all areas to prevent population reductions in these areas.  Namely, this region is important because it abounds in ecological heritage that requires active synergy cooperation between agriculture and other economic activities. Therefore, it is necessary to establish a better transport connection of all the inhabitants of the Alpine region by hinterland. That's why I voted to pass this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a European Parliament resolution on the EU strategy for the Alpine region.  Since mountain areas with low resource use (internal areas) and valleys with high production concentration are present in EUSALP, the implementation of integrated economic strategies is necessary.  The priorities for development are: improving the competitiveness, prosperity and cohesion of the Alpine region, ensuring access and connections to all the inhabitants of the Alpine region (cross-border transport, intermodal links with the interior) and ensuring sustainability in the Alps.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report lays the groundwork for the Eu/15 Strategy for the Alpine Region (EUSALP). This is the fourth macro-regional strategy after the strategy for the Baltic Sea region, the strategy for the Danube region and the strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Sea region. EUSALP covers 48 regions in seven different countries, including five Member States. These macro-regions aim to develop cross-border strategic approaches in regions that would share the same issues, in this case depopulation, diversification of economic activity, land use planning and environmental protection. We share most of the priorities defended by EUSALP, but are opposed to any macro-regional strategy whose governance model is based on increased participation of local and regional authorities in decision-making bodies. These future macro-regions will gradually escape the control of the Member States, thus leaving the scope open to the European Commission to grant itself new prerogatives, particularly in the area of urban policy or education.  I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Following the initial steps taken by the Alpine region at the end of 2011, the European Council invited the Commission in December 2013 to present an EU strategy for the Alpine region. The Commission complied with the request and presented an action plan for the strategy in July 2015. This is the fourth EU macro-regional strategy, based on the experience gained in the EU strategy for the Baltic Sea region, the Danube region and the Adriatic and Ionian regions. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because we believe it is essential to have a clear strategy. Although I do not agree with some of the points that are addressed, I believe that a plan to solve this and other problems affecting many rural areas without means is urgently needed. In these areas the exploitation of the natural environment or tourist attractions is often prioritized over the standard of living of its own inhabitants. In addition, the dossier includes amendments that have been incorporated with civil society concerns about problems about coal emissions, renewable energy, climate change and protection of glaciers, endangered species and biodiversity. In addition, the report supports sustainable tourism and makes interesting contributions to Cop21. Mainly, I am interested in the mentions you make about more remote areas of the Alpine area that do not have access to the most basic social and economic services, lack of job opportunities, lack of connections, depopulation, etc.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Alpine Strategy (EUSALP) is an important macro-regional strategy for the EU and shall contribute to the sustainable development of the Alpine region. It therefore has to be based on the principles and agreements reached in the Alpine Convention. Transport and mobility are traditionally key challenges for the Alpine region, mainly because of their transit character and their impact on the sensitive environment and climate of the Alps. I abstained as both the EUSALP and the EP report are too vague on these elements and not explicit enough on necessary solutions.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I note that alpine regions are environmental heritage that need to be preserved because they have a vast reserve of natural landscapes, a special diversity of ecosystems that extends from mountains to plains and even to the shores of the Mediterranean, thus creating an economic zone and a biosphere based on the coexistence of humans and nature; I stress, therefore, the need for active and interoperable cooperation in linking farming and other types of economic activity in protected areas in order to develop integrated tourism products, and I stress the importance of maintaining and protecting unique habitats in mountainous regions.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on an EU Strategy for the Alpine region. The EUSALP strategy is being introduced in a region in which various cooperation arrangements, including the Alpine Space, the Alpine Convention and a range of INTERREG cross-border programmes, are already in place. EUSALP covers 48 regions in seven countries, five of which are Member States (Italy, France, Slovenia, Austria and Germany). The other two countries are Switzerland and Liechtenstein. The report supports strategic planning among both urban and rural areas of the Alpine region, with a view to promoting networking and common targets in a coherent, coordinated and integrated policy framework. Furthermore, it stresses the need to strengthen further the social dimension, in order to ensure the pursuit of a growth model that can secure sustainable growth, social inclusion and social protection for all, in particular in border areas. I voted in favour because I believe that the strategy opens opportunities for the development of its the labour market, which has different important levels of cross-border commuting.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The rapporteur has carried out a very balanced report addressing the main points for addressing the challenges and challenges of the Union Strategy for the Alpine Region. It stresses the importance of promoting cooperation between regions and developing synergies between the various European funds within multi-level governance, as well as the use of financial instruments and innovation in key areas of the economy, the need to preserve traditional activities and encourage diversification of the productive fabric, the boost of tourism, transport and connectivity and the need to do so by protecting the biodiversity of the Alpine region. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. The EU also pays attention to the various areas on its territory that have specific needs. One of them is the Alpine region, which spreads over several countries. Climate change is manifesting itself more quickly than elsewhere and increasingly it is leading to natural disasters such as avalanches and floods. This also leads to faster depopulation. More investment is needed in equal and effective access to health care and to first aid services and emergency aid for the whole population of the region, especially in rural areas. Public transport is also not everywhere at european average level, so we are in favour of the development of new forms of localised on-demand traffic, including smart traffic information, traffic control and telematics and multimodal transport. I voted in favour of this report because all citizens in the EU should be given the same rights, regardless of where they live.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Located in the heart of Europe, with its 48 regions of 7 different states, its 80 million inhabitants, its extraordinary biodiversity and its water reserves, the Alpine region is a major challenge for the European Union. This report takes into account this particular reality and the precautions it requires, particularly in terms of protecting the environment in the face of climate change and increasing cross-border trade. That's a good thing. It will be necessary to remember and not implement the dangerous Lyon-Turin high-speed line project, incompatible with such protection. Unfortunately, this text does not resolve the issue. It is also significant that this report is concerned about the accessibility of public services in the least populated areas. It is a pity, however, that he advocates public-private partnerships to remedy this.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The strategy for the Alpine region is already the fourth proposal presented by the EU in terms of macro-regional strategy. The notion of macro-regions, involving EU countries and others outside this context, contributes to the acquisition of scale, which can benefit development.  However, this framework and the scope of this territory raise concerns that strategic and cohesion investments, being absorbed by the macro-region, cannot be lacking, resulting in a lack of strategic and cohesion funding for the Member States concerned, i.e. to the detriment of the specific needs of each Member State. The report includes several positive points, highlighting the inclusion of civil society in the definition of policies for macro-region, carbon emissions, the promotion of renewable energies, mitigation and adaptation to climate change, the protection of defaults and biodiversity, the fight against the problems of desertification and economic depression, the sustainable promotion of tourism, etc. It also mentions the potential risks of the construction of hydroelectric infrastructure – an issue that is on the agenda of the Italian government.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The aim here is to ensure that water sources must be protected and must not be privatised at any level. In addition, the financing of the Lyon-Turin train line will be disclosed and no new train infrastructure will be considered until the old one is fully utilised. As the proposal's measures can strengthen the Alpine regions, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for the Alpine region, which includes an investment involving 80 million people, 7 different countries and 48 regions inside and outside the EU. The Alpine region is already engaged in several cooperation agreements but needs to improve transport links, a solution to the logistical problems of SMEs and is suffering the negative effects of climate change. This strategy will make it possible to develop employment, economic growth and local innovation. Through the Investment Plan and the European Fund for Strategic Investments, the report will make it possible to support small and medium-sized enterprises in the Alpine area, promote sustainable and competitive tourism, strengthen the transport infrastructure by making the construction of cross-border corridors fully operational, protect the Alpine heritage by promoting sustainable use of natural and cultural resources and protect Alpine agriculture, biodiversity and ecosystems.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Together with my socialist colleagues, I voted in favour of this report because it is part of a strategy that covers 80 million people in 7 countries and 48 regions in the EU and beyond. The report will improve access and transport in the Alpine regions, improve competitiveness and cohesion and develop sustainability.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The protection of the environment and local biodiversity, together with better governance and local development, jobs and innovation, are the key points of this report which I approved with my vote in favour.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the creation of the Alpine macro-region, bringing together very rich and similar economic, productive and tourist realities, is an important vector for increasing the competitiveness of these areas, but I also believe that it must promote social inclusion and the protection of local populations. To do this, it is essential to address the enormous inhomogeneity of social, medical and structural services between the various areas of the regions involved: mountainous areas and urban centres in the first place. This applies in the same way to the employment and study opportunities reserved for people in remote areas. I am convinced that great attention should also be paid to the demographic issue, which, in addition to the ageing of the population and the depopulation of mountain areas, is also characterised by new migratory flows. I believe that these phenomena must be actively addressed. Finally, I believe that the development of public services linking remote areas and urban centres is essential, as well as strong support for SMEs and the exploitation of local production. In order to do this, and to stimulate the creation of quality jobs, it is essential to overcome the digital divide and make new technologies more widespread and accessible to the whole population.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ the Bress report deals with the European strategy for the Alpine region. This region comp includes five Member States of the European Union and is inhabited by a total of 80 million people. In addition, the region is characterised by many specificities, from unique biodiversity and cultural heritage to the negative side, namely isolation, lack of infrastructure or so-called brain drain. That is why the report proposes ways in which the Alpine region could be helped by better risk management in the context of natural disasters, ensuring universal access to services throughout the territory, with an emphasis on vulnerable people, or promoting innovation and small and medium-sized enterprises as the most important element in the creation of stable jobs. In addition, the new strategy deals with mobility, connectivity and energy security. I believe that this strategy is a step forward, which is why I gave it my vote.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. As a result of our contributions, the report has improved considerably since the first draft, and now also calls for safeguarding the existing Alpine Convention, managing the risk of natural disasters and climate change, ensuring participation and access to documents, promoting renewable, local and self-production energy, SMEs and sustainable tourism, renewing and using existing networks and infrastructures in the best possible way. , to protect biodiversity, soil and water and to take action against air pollution. However, one of the main intentions of the report is to carry out projects that are potentially dangerous and harmful to the environment, such as the HIGH-QUALITY CAR, according to the report's own explanatory statement. In fact, the report did not even mention the issue of Turin-Lyon, and the aim is to finance, through the EIB, projects that we fear are very new infrastructure projects that could perhaps not have been carried out using the Structural Funds because they are not in line with the objectives of Europe 2020 and the EU. I have therefore refrained from making a judgment now, giving us an appointment in a few years' time to make an assessment, in the light of how this strategy will have been implemented in practice, over and above the proposals set out.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 I supported the european Parliament's motion for a resolution on the EU strategy for the Alpine region. I agree with the calls for active synergy cooperation between agricultural and other economic activities in protected areas in the region (Natura 2000 sites, national parks, etc.) in order to develop integrated tourism products, and the importance of preserving and protecting unique habitats in mountainous regions.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D).
text: – Mr President, for as long as I have been a Member of the European Parliament, I have repeatedly called on the Member States and the Commission to join up their efforts and tackle the root causes of migration, which is the only way forward in terms of providing a genuine response to the migration crisis in the EU and in Africa. The Trust Fund launched at the Valletta summit on migration is designed to help foster stability in the African regions and contribute to better migration management. Most importantly, the fund will help address the root causes of irregular migration by stimulating investment and boosting sustainable growth, and through job creation in the African countries where most migrants come from. We have to ensure accountability, transparency and proper management of funds. We have to ensure well planned investments so that the proposed billions really benefit the citizens through projects which improve education, healthcare and infrastructure. Throwing money at the problem without due vigilance and commitment will not solve the migration crisis. Therefore I gave the report my vote.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I voted for this report for the European Union Trust Fund for Africa. We need to combat the causes of immigration to their homes, where people leave and come to other continents. Now we are talking about Africa: there are very fragile areas, very poor areas, there is arms trade, the land is taken over and there are all kinds of other problems that urge people to leave. That is why the fund must solve these problems. The Union's official commitment was EUR 1.8 billion. The problem, however, is that Member States contributed only 4,5 % of the promised amounts. We all know that financial allocation has three stages: promise, commitment and action. It's just that the action, that is, the payment, remained at the promise stage. So I encourage the Member States to continue and give money for it, precisely to combat immigration and help those in Africa.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report, as did the others who voted in favour of the report, I see a good idea at the level of the trust fund, through which it would be possible to reduce the risk of migration from Africa to Europe, but what has been said here applies. So far, we are only at the idea and we are very far from the actual realization. And I wish this report would contribute to the fact that individual Member States, if they have already committed to voluntarily put money into this fund, to really do it so that such a fund can actually be created, and then we can talk about how to turn that money into concrete projects in Africa so that the money is not lost or stolen in some way. It is a really good idea, but so far, unfortunately, we are only staying with the idea, and hopefully this report will help a little to get from the idea to some deeds.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU Trust Fund for Africa is a very important tool for promoting social and economic development in African regions, for example by providing young people with the education and skills they need to realise their potential and create job opportunities. I believe that promoting the economic and social development of these areas is also of fundamental importance in combating regular migration, which has been a serious problem for the Member States for some years now. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. In addition to disbursing funds more quickly and flexibly, we support the implementation of instruments which, in addition to enabling faster and more flexible funds to be disbursed, improve the coordination of policies and development instruments. But this is in no way a blank check for any kind of policy to be financed. With this vote we have made it clear that we will not allow money to be diverted from the objectives of development cooperation. We will not allow the policy of development cooperation and its ultimate end to be jeopardized, the eradication of poverty. The Eurochamber's progressives are committed to our vote in favour, for greater control and for an instrument that ensures a transparent step forward in favour of African countries, in favour of their sustainable development.  We regret that other forces on the left have not joined this call.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against the non-legislative report. It calls on Member States to contribute more money to African EU projects and wants to influence the day-to-day running of African governments. UKIP does not support increased EU influence. In addition, UKIP does not believe in the use of aid handouts but would rather see removal of trade barriers.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on the Union trust fund for Africa. The aim of this fund would be to promote stability in these regions and better manage migration. While this special fund promotes resilience, economic opportunities, security and development, while addressing the root causes of destabilization, forced displacement and illegal migration, this report is part of a logic of blind funding, without controls on the proper use and management of funds. Moreover, this text does not necessarily take into account the realities of life of the inhabitants of the developing countries. The desire to stop immigration in general still seems weak and the report is rather part of a policy of dissusing millions of euros without expected results.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This own—initiative report aims to address existing failures in the use of the EU’s ‘Emergency Trust Fund for stability and addressing root causes of irregular migration and displaced persons in Africa’ made up of EU financing and contributions from Member States. It highlights the fact that only 4.5% of the pledged funds have actually been received. But while it states it aims to promote legal migration and asylum, as well as addressing causes of displacement such as the arms trade, the Trust Fund is being used as another instrument to re-allocate and use development funds for control and management of migration flows without any development benefit. The report reinforces this as well as the general ‘Fortress Europe’ set-up. Due to these negative elements in the report I could not vote in favour of the overall report but abstained.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the EU Trust Fund for Africa.  This background is only one piece of the puzzle in the EU's response to the migration crisis. However, it must be better controlled by Parliament in all cases, because it must be noted that there is a lack of transparency in its use. In addition, it is essential that states finally deliver on their promises and contribute more to this fund.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the EU Trust Fund for Africa. Launched at the Valletta Summit on Migration on 12 November 2015, the EUTF aims to address the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and irregular migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. It has been conceived in order to assist 23 countries across three African regions (the Horn of Africa; the Sahel and Lake Chad basin; and North Africa) that contain some of the most fragile African countries, which are affected by migration as countries of origin, transit or destination. The European Union contribution amounts to EUR 1.8 billion. The report considers that the EUTF should contribute to the strengthening and improvement of local public services (e.g. social services, health, education, nutrition, culture) and that civil society and NGOs should be actively involved. I would like to underline that the rules and criteria that govern development aid for projects financed by the EUTF must be set according to the respect and promotion of human rights. It is crucially important that the Commission monitors how the EUTF funds are employed and allocated. Parliament’s scrutiny powers over the Fund are to be increased.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The EU Trust Fund for Africa (EUTF) was set up at the Valletta Migration Summit in November 2015. In view of the unprecedented level of irregular migration currently being observed, the Trust Fund was set up to support the African countries most affected, to create stability in these regions and to promote EU-Africa cooperation on issues such as migration management, security and development. The aim is to combat the causes of destabilisation, displacement and irregular migration in the Horn of Africa, the Sahel and the Lake Chad Basin, as well as in northern Africa. I support the view that one of the priorities of the EU's migration policy should be to address the root causes of migration. The Trust Fund is intended to contribute to the achievement of the long-term objectives in the beneficiary countries. It is a question of securing peace and bringing stability to these regions. In order to achieve these objectives, it is also necessary to monitor and control the distribution of funds from the Trust Fund systematically.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The main objective of the European Union Trust Fund for Africa, established in 2015 by European and African partners, is to promote stability in these regions and to help better manage migration. The fund aims to address the root causes of destabilization, forced displacement and illegal migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, security and development. Despite proactive aspects, this report is part of a logic of financing blind, without controls or hindsight, or the proper use and management of funds, the EU preferring to offload to local authorities and a partnership with the private sector, in a hypothetical hope of transferring future burdens within the framework of development policy. The report sees population growth as an asset in developing areas, while youth employment and training policies lag far behind the development goals set and the future is uncertain for the younger generations, who are more inclined to desert their country for the West for a better life than to build the future of the West. So I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interests of transparency and democracy I would like to confirm I voted against this report. For decades we have been throwing money at Africa to solve its problems. Due to the political nature of Africa there is no control how this money is spent in countries ravaged by dictators and corruption. It would be cynical to suggest that the EU wants to pump more money into projects in Africa to influence political participation and governance. I believe that trade not aid is the answer. Let´s use this money positively through education and training. Give a man a fish he eats for a night, teach a man how to fish and he can eat for a lifetime.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to promote stability in Africa and help better manage migration; Considering, more specifically, that the European Union Trust Fund aims to address the root causes of destabilization, forced displacement and illegal migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities and equal opportunities, security and development.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU-Africa Infrastructure Trust Fund: implications for development and humanitarian aid. The AIM of the EU-Africa Infrastructure Trust Fund is to address the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and irregular migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development, but in order to achieve this, we need to pay out funds more quickly and flexibly in the event of an emergency and mobilise various sources of funding to overcome the migration and refugee crisis in its various aspects. However, there is a growing risk of inadequate use of EU development aid, and I therefore agree that projects covered by the EU Practice Fund must have strong development goals.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The document is a report on the EU Emergency Fund for Africa initiative, which tries to take initiatives focusing primarily on migration and its root causes. An important detail in the text is that NGOs should be given the maximum opportunity to participate in the development of migration host, return and other strategies, decisions aimed at using the Fund's financial framework. The justification for this is highly questionable after the revelation of the activities of soros foundations in this area. The report states that regional resources cannot be used for border protection (even for countries with Schengen borders) and cannot be used to increase the level of security. In practice, it states that the safety and security of the local population is not important, and that public security, taken together, is not important if it constitutes an action against migrants. For all these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the non-legislative report. It calls on Member States to contribute more money to African EU projects and wants to influence the day-to-day running of African governments. UKIP does not support increased EU influence. In addition, UKIP does not believe in the use of aid handouts but would rather see removal of trade barriers.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. As is often the case in the reports coming out of the DEVE Committee (Development Committee), there are some good ideas in this text, especially since the development aid of these countries is supposed to stop the migration haemorrhage, but these good ideas result in too little concrete proposals in terms of monitoring said aid and evaluating their results. So I abstained.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The EU Trust Fund for Africa should have been a tool to contribute to stabilization, socio-economic development and thus the fight against poverty in that region. I did not support this report which would unbalance relations between the EU and Africa. The European Parliament and Europe in general have missed the opportunity to rethink their relationship with Africa.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Migration Summit held in Valletta on 15 November 2015 launched the EU Trust Fund for Africa, which aims to promote stability in the regions concerned and contribute to better migration management. The Corrao report, which I have supported today, effectively underlines the objectives of the Fund and the difficulties it has encountered to date. There is a clear problem of funding. The Member States have made small contributions by not following up their promises to take concrete action. The course must be reversed by increasing the financial envelope of the ETUF and allowing for the rapid and flexible disbursement of funds in emergency situations. The new instrument should be used to contribute to the development of migrants' transit and countries of origin, improving local public services, political participation and governance, mainly through community-based projects. Europe's response to the migration crisis must be on several fronts, but ETUF can be a concrete support to improve security and ensure the development of less developed African countries.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report, because there are aspects of the report which are very favourable, but still have very notable flaws. GUE's position has been taken into account in condemning the use of funds for control projects without development objectives, the recognition of local authorities as key players, the need to develop public services in countries of origin, etc. However, the vagueness of defining the role of international organizations in the report opens the door to its use to finance "military peacekeeping missions" as well as training and training in the security sector.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work in preparing this report on the Union Trust Fund for Africa. It discusses financial endowment and budgetary aspects, the financing of the least developed countries, the role of civil society, NGOs and international organisations, transparency and clarity to improve the achievement of the objectives, the coherence of the Union's policies and the commitment to human rights, including sexual and reproductive health. A very important report to move forward.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report on the EU Trust Fund for Africa. The initial aim of this fund, launched at the Valletta Summit in 2015, is genuine cooperation between Member States and African countries to address the root causes of migration, with a view to resilience, economic development and security. A goal that I absolutely share and that I have never stopped defending. Unfortunately, the report is part of a logic of uncontrolled financial assistance, without any planned management measures. Worse, the European authorities plan to offload to local authorities in partnership with the private sector. Morality, we are once again trying to water these countries with money without ensuring that it will be used to achieve the objectives set. An idea that was well-intentioned and once again misguided by the European inconsistency.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although it is a more balanced text than many others who have treated Africa in the past as the subject of European cooperation interventions, I believe it contains critical issues and shortcomings that led me to express myself with a vote of abstention.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which analyses the objectives and funding of the African Trust Fund, which was designed to help 23 countries in three African regions (Horn of Africa, the Sahel and Lake Chad Basin and North Africa). This fund is a development tool that brings together the resources of different donors to enable the Union to respond quickly, flexibly, complementaryly, transparently and collectively to the different dimensions of an emergency situation. In the area of migration, the fund seeks to address the root causes of irregular migration and displacement in countries of origin, transit and destination, through five priority sectors: (1) development migration benefits; 2) legal migration and mobility; 3) protection and asylum; (4) prevention and combating irregular migration; and 5) return, readmission and reintegration; However, Member States' contributions remain very limited, so from this House we are requesting new appropriations, and Parliament's inclusion in the fund's strategic council. We also call on Member States to respect the ODP commitment to 0.7%.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has made Parliament express its position on the EUTfo can fund for Africa, its impact on development and humanitarian aid. The EU-Africa Infrastructure Trust Fund aims to address the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and irregular migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. Africa continues to grow very rapidly and there is only a slight decrease in birth rates, and it is therefore necessary to provide young people with the education and skills they need to realise their potential and create employment opportunities in order to promote stability, sustainable economic growth, social cohesion and development in the region. However, Parliament notes with regret that member states' contributions continue to be too low and represent only a small part of the Union's contribution, thus far short of the amount of official commitments. Parliament therefore urges the Member States to implement the promises and commitments agreed at the end of 2015.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the adoption of this report to be very important and I supported it with my vote, as the Emergency Fund can contribute to addressing the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and illegal migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. The document draws attention to the elimination of the causes of emigration and the importance of supporting those in distress, as mass migration confronts Europe with a new humanitarian and security challenge. A transparent strategy that works with NGOs and leaders with significant local knowledge to provide more effective assistance will hopefully be able to protect those in distress in their own homeland. The report also draws attention to the fact that EU migration policies should focus above all on addressing the root causes of migration, involving NGOs and civil society.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Trust Fund for Africa should be a European development instrument raising funds from various donors so that the EU can intervene efficiently, quickly, transparently and jointly on various aspects of crisis situations in Africa, which continues to see very high rates of population growth, especially young people, which on the one hand represent a great social and economic potential, and on the other hand the risks of instability due to increasing poverty.  This is why both the European Development Fund and official development assistance must be allocated for clear objectives, in the economic, social, human development of aid recipients in Africa, as stated in the report. As stated in the report, local authorities, civil society and international organisations should be strongly involved in the planning, implementation and evaluation phases of the trust fund. The report emphasises, for a reason, the need for greater transparency and clarity to better achieve the objectives of this financial instrument and warns of the risk of misuse of EU development assistance.  The Trust Fund should create added value to existing sources of funding. Therefore, funds should not be diverted from other sources, as this violates financial rules and undermines long-term EU policies. All this leads us to support the report, and that is why I supported such a report.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the crisis situation and general instability in the Sahel, North Africa and Horn of Africa regions and the obvious humanitarian repercussions on Europe in terms of large migratory flows, coordinated Eu ropean Union intervention in the regions concerned is essential. For this very reason, I support the Initiative on European Trust Funds for Africa. I believe that we need long-term planning, including actions aimed at eradicating the root causes of migration, starting with poverty and socio-political instability in countries that are the scene of mass emigration. The need is precisely to go beyond programmes in a purely emergency way, such as border controls, instead preparing funds for regional and local development, establishing a real partnership between Member States, NGOs and local communities. With the resolution adopted today, Parliament stresses the need for monitoring and transparency on the disbursement of funds where respect for human rights, as a necessary condition for allocation, is ensured. A clear commitment by Member States to dealing with a transnational emergency requiring a cohesive response from the European Union is therefore crucial.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this Report on the EUTF for Africa, which aims to help foster stability in regions and contribute to better migration management, namely addressing destabilisation, forced displacement and irregular migration by promoting economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. While I consider aid to developing countries in particular in Africa essential, I regret that this report does not take any precautions in terms of prior or post-use monitoring of the destination or use of these funds. Therefore, I abstained.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's migration phenomenon cannot be tackled effectively unless the need to give stability, development and peace to the migrants' regions of origin is put at the centre of the issue. A purely military or legal approach to this issue cannot solve the phenomenon which, with its dramatic humanitarian consequences and the suffering we are witnessing every day, is in danger of getting worse every day. It must be understood that most migrants do not leave their homes for ideological reasons or for the search for exaggerated expectations about their standard of living but, much more concretely, because their survival is at risk in their country of origin due to poverty, war, disease, famine, ethnic or religious persecution. If we want to get to the root of this tragedy of the twenty-first century, we must bring peace and development to those regions: the EU Trust Fund for Africa is a first, important step in this direction.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The Africa Trust Fund, launched at the Valletta Summit on 12 November 2015 and signed by 25 Member States as well as Norway and Switzerland, aims to promote political and economic stability in Africa in order to reduce the migration of local populations. Despite extremely laudable objectives, it must be recognized that this report is part of a logic of blind funding. Without post-mortem control of the proper management of funds, the European Union prefers to offload to local authorities. Therefore, there is no guarantee that local people actually benefit from European funding. Moreover, the European Union should first begin by no longer interfering in the internal affairs of African countries in order to ensure political stability. In Libya, Western support for the rebels with the support of the European Union has been dramatic. The country, currently administered by local militias, is plagued by serious internal unrest resulting in the exodus to Europe of several hundred thousand individuals, including Islamist fundamentalists. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 EU migration policies must be addressed to address the root causes of migration, with the main objective of investigating and addressing the real causes of poverty in countries of origin. At the same time, the EU must contribute to the creation of a climate of peace and stability and to promote economic development, through efforts to ensure healthy lives for all citizens, gender equality and ensuring quality education that is inclusive to demographics. Strengthening the protection of migrants, asylum seekers and highly vulnerable groups is another EU objective by more effectively combating the exploitation and trafficking of migrants and working more closely with third countries to improve cooperation on incentives for voluntary return and reintegration in migrants' countries of origin. I voted in favour of this report, believing that only with the direct support and involvement of the European Union will the more disadvantaged countries be able to provide solutions to citizens' problems.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is the largest aid provider for developing countries. The EU's mission is to help reduce and ultimately eradicate poverty and migration from developing countries by promoting sustainable development, democracy, peace and security. On 12 November 2015, the President of the European Commission, together with other EU Member States and other European donors, launched the EU Emergency Trust Fund for Stability and addressing the root causes of irregular migration and displacement in Africa. This Trust Fund, set up in record time, demonstrates once again the EU's commitment to respond promptly to the great challenges we face in this region. It is suggestive to note that Africa receives official EU development assistance of more than EUR 20 billion annually, so it can be said that the Union has invested permanently to combat the root causes of migration. In this respect, I consider it important to introduce a more efficient monitoring system of the way EUTF funds are used and allocated, as well as to increase Parliament's powers of control over the EUTF.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. In addition to disbursing funds more quickly and flexibly, we support the implementation of instruments which, in addition to enabling faster and more flexible funds to be disbursed, improve the coordination of policies and development instruments. But this is in no way a blank check for any kind of policy to be financed. With this vote we have made it clear that we will not allow money to be diverted from the objectives of development cooperation. We will not allow the policy of development cooperation and its ultimate end to be jeopardized, the eradication of poverty. The Eurochamber's progressives are committed to our vote in favour, for greater control and for an instrument that ensures a transparent step forward in favour of African countries, in favour of their sustainable development.  We regret that other forces on the left have not joined this call.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The objective of the European Union Trust Fund for Africa is to stabilise the region (Horn of Africa, Sahel, Chad Basin and North Africa) and manage migration. It was created following the Valletta Summit on Migration in November 2015. This initiative report highlights the small contributions of Member States to the trust fund, which currently amounts to EUR 81.71 million, while EUR 1.8 billion had been committed. Civil society, local authorities and NGOs need to play a bigger role. They must be consulted and involved in the implementation and evaluation of the fund. There is also a need to improve transparency and coherence in order to properly achieve the objectives of the European Union's Africa Trust Fund. I voted in favour of this initiative report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report to support the EU Trust Fund for Africa (EUTF) which helps promote stability in the regions of the area and contributes to better migration management. However, I am concerned about the lack of coordination between all the actors involved in the management of the EU Trust Fund, in particular between the Directorate-General of the Commission for International Cooperation and Development (DG DEVCO) and its Department for Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection (ECHO), and the lack of clear guidelines on how to access available funds. The funding criteria and funds available to civil society under the EU Trust Fund should be clearer and more transparent. The Commission should also systematically monitor the way in which EU Trust Fund resources are used and how they are allocated, and strengthen Parliament's control prerogatives with regard to the EU Trust Fund. I call on the Commission to carry out a more systematic assessment of the impact of its policies and funding, including the EU Trust Fund, especially in relation to their effects on sustainable development, human rights and gender equality.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This own-initiative report aims to address existing failures in the use of the EU’s ‘Emergency Trust Fund for stability and addressing root causes of irregular migration and displaced persons in Africa’ made up of EU financing and contributions from Member States. It highlights the fact that only 4.5% of the pledged funds have actually been received. But while it states it aims to promote legal migration and asylum, as well as addressing causes of displacement such as the arms trade, the Trust Fund is being used as another instrument to re-allocate and use development funds for control and management of migration flows without any development benefit. The report reinforces this as well as the general ‘Fortress Europe’ set-up. Due to these negative elements in the report I could not vote in favour of the overall report but abstained.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Trust Fund was created to support the most affected African countries in order to help foster stability in these regions and promote tighter Africa-EU cooperation on issues of migration management, security and development and thus minimise the unprecedented levels of irregular migration reaching our shores. The report addresses many questions and concerns by the creation of this Fund and its financing, implementation and scrutiny. The report offers a critical assessment in terms of financing by Member States and calls on all stakeholders to uphold their commitments and responsibilities to make it successful. Although I commend the importance of this Fund and its success, I could not vote in favour of this report as it contained references to the sexual and reproductive health and rights.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Trust Fund for Africa responds to the need to work to eradicate the root causes of migration, acting to create development. To this end, it is necessary to operate in the long term, with planning and not only in an emergency key, investing above all in essential services such as education, health, vocational training, primary public services. The text does not fail to highlight that the real problem is that the States, at international summits and summits, engage with great pomp but then, once the spotlight is turned off, forget the promises made. All this is well expressed in Mr Corrao's report, for which I voted in favour.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as I find the EU Trust Fund for Africa very important. I welcome the suggestion concerning disbursement of funds in more quick and flexible manner in an emergency situation such as migration and refugee crisis in terms of funding of recipient country governments. Civil society actors and other stakeholders active in this field need to be supported as soon as possible. To allow the trust fund to develop its full potential, EU Member States have to keep their financial pledges and contribute to the fund as discussed.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 During the Migration Summit in Valletta on 12 November, the EU Trust Fund for Africa, signed by the Commission, 25 Member States, Norway and Switzerland, was launched. I consider the establishment of this fund to be significant, the main objective of which is to promote stability in the region and contribute to better management of migration. More specifically, the Fund should, on the one hand, address the causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and illegal migration and, on the other hand, promote resilience, economic opportunities, security, equal opportunities and development. I see with interest this initiative to address some important aspects of the migration crisis. Although action is unlikely to be effective until the promises of contribution made by the Member States are kept. I voted in favour because trying to restore stability and security and promote development in precisely those countries from which migration originates must be one of the priorities of European intervention. Care must also be taken to ensure that the Fund, which is used for cooperation projects, is used mainly for the purposes of education and protection of minors, job creation and environmental projects.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and stress that when it comes to EU migration policies, they should focus primarily on addressing the root causes of migration.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on the EU Trust Fund for Africa and the implications for development and humanitarian aid in the wider African region. Although the existence of corresponding funds is not by definition a negative proposal, we should ensure the proper management of this fund, but also exclude the possibility of trying to impose decisions and choices on the recipients of the aid, for economic, social and political purposes. As this is not sufficiently discussed, I voted against it.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the Corrao report on the implications for development and humanitarian aid in Africa. Launched in Valletta in 2015, the EU Trust Fund for Africa (EUTF) deals with a topical issue. In particular, addressing the root causes of immigration, the report proposes effective solutions, such as simplifying the disbursement of funds to promote stability, sustainable economic growth, social cohesion and development in the African region. Indeed, in the face of the serious migration crisis, I believe it is important to concentrate resources towards the completion of long-term objectives capable of ensuring peace and stability on the African continent.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on the EU Trust Fund for Africa: the implications for development and humanitarian aid and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Trust Fund for Africa, established at the Vallifa Summit in 2015 (EUTF), aims to help promote stability in 23 countries and 3 regions of Africa where some of the most fragile African states affected by migration are located, thereby attacking, from a Development perspective, the causes that are the cause of forced displacement and irregular migration, trying to promote economic opportunities , security, equal opportunities and development. I support the Corrao Report as It considers it urgent to make the funds available more quickly, and I underline the need to respond rapidly to specific emergency or post-emergency crises by taking advantage of contributions from EU Member States and other donors. It is regrettable that member states' contributions remained low by April 2016: -81.71 million of the 1.8 billion forecast, or only 4.5%! At budgetary level, I agree that an appropriate review of the ceiling should be carried out in order to allow the inclusion in the MFF of crisis mechanisms and restore unity in the budget, and Parliament has given proof of responsibility by agreeing to unlock emergency funds. I would like to say that the projects under its shelter must be in line with the values of the Union and the promotion of human rights.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Trust Fund for Africa aims to help promote stability, security and development in African regions affected by migration flows. The fund also aims to identify and address the root causes of destabilisation and irregular migration. I share these objectives and believe that the Member States must contribute to the fund in order to strengthen it and make it fully effective. Understanding the complexity and multidimensional nature of the migration crisis, I also say that we should ensure that European funds are properly used in the territories concerned. The ultimate objective of the European Fund for Africa is to promote peace and stability in critical territories, providing resources and strengthening local governance capacity.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The report highlights the potential of social and economic benefits for Africa by enabling young people with the education and skills to realise their potential and creating employment opportunities to foster stability, sustainable economic growth, social cohesion and development in the region. To promote laudable provisions against human trafficking and smuggling of vulnerable people and safeguards in favour of women’s rights and LGBTI persons, the EU should not impose obligations of a moral nature on its Member States. I agree with the rapporteur that the EU should systematically monitor how the EUTF funds are employed and how they are allocated by increasing our scrutiny powers.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU Trust Fund for Africa was conceived as a financial assistance instrument for 23 countries in three African regions comprising some of africa's most affected states by migration movements and situations of social and economic instability. By voting in favour of this resolution, I express my support for this important instrument for promoting economic growth, regional stability and integrated management of migratory flows. Indeed, the ultimate objective of the Trust Fund is to address the root causes of destabilisation, forced relocation and irregular migration by promoting resilience, economic prospects, equal opportunities, security and development. I am convinced that the EU has a responsibility to provide targeted responses to global humanitarian crises and post-emergency crisis situations. This fund, which comes mainly from the 11th European Development Fund (EDF), helps to make up for member states' shortcomings in official development aid and insufficient resources and the lack of flexibility in the EU budget and the Multiannual Financial Framework. Finally, the EU Trust Fund for Africa should promote policy coherence for sustainable development and complementarity between all development actors and programmes.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The main objective of the EU Trust Fund, signed by 25 EU Member States, as well as Norway and Switzerland, at the Valletta Summit on Migration, is to help promote stability in the regions and better manage migration. Worldwide, 1.5 billion people live in fragile and conflict-affected regions. The EU Trust Fund aims to support 23 countries in three African regions (African Horn, Sahel and the Lake Chad Basin and North Africa) of which some of the most fragile African countries affected by migration are part. I voted to transfer funds in a faster and more flexible way in emergency situations and to group the various sources of funding to address all the dimensions of the crisis.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU Emergency Fund for Africa is a mechanism for development cooperation involving significant resources from different donors. The European Commission has provided funding from various financial instruments earmarked from the EU budget, in particular from the European Development Fund. The Commission is mobilising €1.8 billion in EU funding, but it also expects member states to contribute. This is necessary because, without a common European strategy, we cannot cross the challenge of unregulated migration. I supported the creation of the Fund because it seeks to support and solve the problem of Africans living in poor conditions locally. It contributes to crisis management in crisis-stricken regions. It aims to enhance the stability of regions and promote more effective regulation of migration. The Fund will help to address the root causes of forced displacement and irregular migration by promoting economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The main objective of the EU Trust Fund (EUTF) for Africa is to support regional stabilisation and help to better manage migration. The focus should be on finding and addressing the causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and irregular migration. Then take action to promote equal opportunities in the economic, security and development fields. The countries covered by the fund are located in three regions of Africa (Horn of Africa, Sahel and Lake Chad Basin, North Africa). These are some of the most fragile countries on the continent. However, I am abstaining on this matter. In particular, the resolution draws attention to the low contribution of the Member States, stressing that words and promises alone are not enough – this must translate into action. it stresses the meaning of the EXISTENCE of the EUTF and calls on the EU to provide a more holistic solution for emergency funds as part of this year's MFF 2014-2020 review. It also warns of a scenario in which the poorest countries with the least access to other sources of funding will lose aid.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The role of the EU Trust Fund for Africa to help foster stability in the regions and contribute to better migration management is crucially important since it specifically aims to address the root causes of destabilisation leading to a significant number of persons fleeing their countries. It seeks to promote resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities and security and development. This EU trust Fund launched at the Valletta Summit, is another piece of the puzzle in the EU’s response to migration crisis and this is why I voted in favour. However, I believe that more needs to be done to ensure transparency at European Level and that Member States need to contribute more in order to really and truly address this crisis.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on the EU's concerns raised by the creation, implementation and control of the trust fund in terms of funding. This trust fund was created to help the most affected African countries and improve stability in these regions. The trust's top priorities are economic programs, migration management, stability and finally governance. Considering that collaboration with the Union for Africa calls for greater transparency, accountability and political coherence in the implementation of projects, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the non-legislative report. It calls on Member States to contribute more money to African EU projects and wants to influence the day to day running of African governments. UKIP does not support increased EU influence. In addition, UKIP does not believe in the use of aid handouts but would rather see removal of trade barriers.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text on the implications for development aid and humanitarian aid of the European Union Trust Fund for Africa, created in November 2015 following the Valletta Summit on Migration. Through this trust fund for Africa, we want to address the root causes of the migration crisis by promoting the stabilization and development of the African continent. Nevertheless, we must pay particular attention to the need to ensure that development aid to particularly destabilized countries is not diverted. However, I consider it essential that, through the payment of this trust fund for Africa, the European Union should obtain commitments for full implementation of readmission agreements in order to enable the effective return of irregular migrants to Europe.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the adoption of this report to be very important and I supported it with my vote, as the Emergency Fund can contribute to addressing the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and illegal migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. The document draws attention to the elimination of the causes of emigration and the importance of supporting those in distress, as mass migration confronts Europe with a new humanitarian and security challenge. A transparent strategy that works with NGOs and leaders with significant local knowledge to provide more effective assistance will hopefully be able to protect those in distress in their own homeland. The report also draws attention to the fact that EU migration policies should focus above all on addressing the root causes of migration, involving NGOs and civil society.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation voted against this report. It shares concerns that the European Emergency Fund for Africa does not have the desired seed capital. However, the N-VA does not think it is a good idea to include the fund in the European Union budget. Firstly, this would lead to an increase in the ceilings of the current multianne financial framework, which was set for the period 2014-2020. Secondly, the N-VA considers it important that the responsibility remains with eu Member States to decide how much they each contribute individually to this fund, which is crucial in the fight against irregular migration. In this way, countries retain the necessary flexibility to put their own emphasis on them. Belgium is one of the few Member States that kept its promises and made a strong splash. It is now time for other countries to take responsibility.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider it important to set up a European Trust Fund for Africa in order to have the necessary resources in a shared and flexible way to enable a rapid and comprehensive response to the migration phenomenon. The fund will ensure a better balance of funding to governments and reliable civil society actors in the beneficiary countries. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – I consider the adoption of this report to be very important and I supported it with my vote, as the Emergency Fund can contribute to addressing the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and illegal migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. The document draws attention to the elimination of the causes of emigration and the importance of supporting those in distress, as mass migration confronts Europe with a new humanitarian and security challenge. A transparent strategy that works with NGOs and leaders with significant local knowledge to provide more effective assistance will hopefully be able to protect those in distress in their own homeland. The report also draws attention to the fact that EU migration policies should focus above all on addressing the root causes of migration, involving NGOs and civil society.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union Trust Fund for Africa was launched at the Valletta Summit on Migration on 12 November 2015. The fund aims to address the root causes of destabilization, forced displacement and migration of African populations. However, its implementation is not optimal and is not subject to any particular control. It also sees population growth as an asset, even as African states struggle to fully integrate their youth into the labour market. For all these reasons, I abstained on this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained from the report on the EU Trust Fund for Africa: the implications for development and humanitarian aid, as I generally support the idea of providing money to African countries to develop and stabilise the region, but I cannot agree with the criticism in the resolution that member states do not contribute enough money to this fund.  At a time when Member States are still emerging from the economic crisis and funds must be invested constantly to tackle the refugee crisis, countries should not be obliged to give even more money. On top of that, the latest reports from the European Court of Auditors have many observations on the use of European funds, especially in north Africa.  The reports criticise European programmes that control over spending is weak and the effect of investment is very small. That is why I believe that before the Union starts to provide large funds for development and stabilisation, it must establish robust control mechanisms to reduce misuse of European public funds.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
