text: Writing. \u2012 I disagree with all kinds of funding from African and third countries in general.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the adoption of this report to be very important and I supported it with my vote, as the Emergency Fund can contribute to addressing the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and illegal migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. The document draws attention to the elimination of the causes of emigration and the importance of supporting those in distress, as mass migration confronts Europe with a new humanitarian and security challenge. A transparent strategy that works with NGOs and leaders with significant local knowledge to provide more effective assistance will hopefully be able to protect those in distress in their own homeland. The report also draws attention to the fact that EU migration policies should focus above all on addressing the root causes of migration, involving NGOs and civil society.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The main objective of the EU Trust Fund for Africa (EUTF) is to help promote stability in these regions, contribute to better migration management and tackle the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and irregular migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. 1 500 million people around the world live in fragile and conflict-affected regions, and fragile states and ungoverned spaces have been increasing, with many people left to poverty, anarchy, rampant corruption and violence. The fund is therefore intended to complement the current EU aid to the regions covered by more than €10 billion by 2020 to support inclusive and sustainable economic growth.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Abstention: because although draped in good moral intentions, it does not take into account the realities of life of the inhabitants in the developing countries concerned and is part of a policy of continuing to sprinkle millions of euros without expected results.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The so-called Africa Trust Fund was launched at the Vallifa Summit in November 2015, which represented a sordid attempt to impose on developing countries submission to the EU's inhumane migration policy. The Fund is therefore an instrument in the service of this desideratum, which is why it deserves our strongest condemnation. This is idissotable in the rejection vote of this report. Despite some good intentions of the rapporteur and some genuine concerns that he highlights regarding the policy of cooperation and development support, the report cannot dissociate itself from the Fund and the objectives that led to its creation. In this context, everything else becomes secondary, including some considerations that we support, whether in relation to the European Development Fund or in relation to Public Development Assistance, in particular when it rejects its transformation into instruments at the service of migration control. However, the Trust Fund is nothing more than that, and it also denotes an unbearable neocolonial vision and ambition, which we reject forcefully. The report does not do so and would not be expected to do so. It should be noted that the report denounces the lack of clarity and transparency of the criteria and the volume of funding for "civil society" under the Trust Fund.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Solidarity and respect for human rights must continue to represent the fundamental values of the European Union, as well as the objectives to be pursued constantly. However, Europe needs to concentrate its resources and efforts by selecting the most effective means at its disposal, first and foremost by avoiding the fragmentation of the financial instruments under the European Union. I voted against the report on the Trust Fund for Africa because there is too great a risk of misuse of EU development aid, particularly in those countries most affected by conflicts where security, migration and development issues are closely interlinked, as this is therefore a complex and multidimensional crisis

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ In November 2015, at the Summit on Migration in Valletta, Malta, the President of the EC, together with the 25 EU Member States, Norway and Switzerland, signed the EUTF for Africa, which aims to help promote stability in the regions, as well as to contribute to more efficient management of migration. Africa is still experiencing a high rate of population growth, leading to a sharp increase in the population of young people of working age and a possible social and economic benefit. The Trust Fund is intended to be a development tool to ensure that the EU can respond quickly and flexibly to the different dimensions of situations in Africa. It also aims to combat the root causes of illegal migration and displaced displaced people.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the report as it could be more incisive and detailed with regard to the projects that would be developed.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the EU Trust Fund for Africa: the implications for development and humanitarian aid, as I am strongly opposed to all kinds of funding from African and third countries in general.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The main goal of the EU Trust Fund for Africa (EUTF), signed by the President of the Commission along with 25 EU Member States, as well as Norway and Switzerland, and launched at the Valetta Summit on Migration on 12 November 2015 by the European and African partners, is to help foster stability in the regions and contribute to better migration management, more specifically, the EUTF aims to address the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and irregular migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. We want to make sure the ATF, which is mainly development cooperation money, is not used for security purposes or border control, and only finances education, employment, good governance, environmental projects. This is clearly reflected in the final text. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Мария Габриел (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the adoption of this report as it contains constructive recommendations to improve the effectiveness of the Emergency Trust Fund for Africa. Set up at the Valletta Migration Summit in November 2015, this instrument symbolises the EU's commitment to address the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and irregular migration.  I support the call made in the report for Member States to align their contributions with the Union contribution in order to enable the EU Trust Fund to develop its full potential. It is also essential to ensure that the EU Trust Fund reflects the principles of policy coherence for sustainable development and complementarity among all development stakeholders.  I believe that the rules for financing projects with EU Trust Fund funds should be set on the basis of shared values and common interests. Particular emphasis should therefore be placed on respecting and promoting human rights, including women's rights. Empowering women and ensuring their active participation in the political, economic and social development of countries of origin is a key element in strengthening stability in Africa and will contribute to better migration management.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the adoption of this report to be very important and I supported it with my vote, as the Emergency Fund can contribute to addressing the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and illegal migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. The document draws attention to the elimination of the causes of emigration and the importance of supporting those in distress, as mass migration confronts Europe with a new humanitarian and security challenge. A transparent strategy that works with NGOs and leaders with significant local knowledge to provide more effective assistance will hopefully be able to protect those in distress in their own homeland. The report also draws attention to the fact that EU migration policies should focus above all on addressing the root causes of migration, involving NGOs and civil society.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which is important for development and humanitarian aid. The Emergency Fund was set up to promote stability in Africa and contribute to the proper management of mass immigration. It should be borne in play that EU migration policies should focus above all on the root causes of migration, and the main objective should be to investigate and address the real causes of poverty in the countries of origin. EU migration policies should aim at creating peace and stability and strengthening economic development, with a aim at ensureing a healthy life for all people of all ages, gender equality and the emancipation of all women and girls, and closer cooperation with third countries to encourage the return and reintegration of migrants, including highly skilled migrants, into their countries of origin and voluntary return and readmission in a way that increases their potential. The population growth rate in Africa remains very high and the fertility rate is only slowly decreasing, and this situation will lead to a sharp increase in the young working age population in the near future. This must be properly managed with assistance, so that it brings social and economic benefits to the continent and not towards mass migration.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report, being aware of the vital importance of the EU Trust Fund for Africa and the potential it can have in the development of that continent. Similarly, we must promote stability in this region and contribute to better migration management, promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. However, despite their importance, Member States' contributions have so far been scarce, representing only a small part of the EU's contribution, so they are far from reaching the official commitment, amounting to only EUR 81.71 million in April 2016 (or 4.5% of the expected EUR 1.8 billion). Similarly, Member States should not ignore their commitments on the achievement of the target of allocating 0.7% of gross national income to official development aid (ODP).

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Spanish Socialists in the European Parliament support the implementation of instruments which, in addition to providing faster and more flexible funds, improve the coordination of policies and development instruments. But this is in no way a blank check for any kind of policy to be financed. With this vote we have made it clear that we will not allow money to be diverted from the objectives of development cooperation. We will not allow the policy of development cooperation and its ultimate end to be jeopardized, the eradication of poverty. The Eurochamber's progressives are committed to our vote in favour, for greater control and for an instrument that ensures a transparent step forward in favour of African countries, in favour of their sustainable development.  We regret that other forces on the left have not joined this call.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. In addition to disbursing funds more quickly and flexibly, we support the implementation of instruments which, in addition to enabling faster and more flexible funds to be disbursed, improve the coordination of policies and development instruments. But this is in no way a blank check for any kind of policy to be financed. With this vote we have made it clear that we will not allow money to be diverted from the objectives of development cooperation. We will not allow the policy of development cooperation and its ultimate end to be jeopardized, the eradication of poverty. The Eurochamber's progressives are committed to our vote in favour, for greater control and for an instrument that ensures a transparent step forward in favour of African countries, in favour of their sustainable development.  We regret that other forces on the left have not joined this call.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the EU Trust Fund for Africa: Impact on Development and Humanitarian Aid. As coordinator of my ECR Group for the EU-ACP delegation, I consider the Fund to be an important instrument, including in terms of preventing new causes of flight and refugee flows from the African continent. The report quite rightly condemns the inactivity of many EU Member States, which should have invested another EUR 1.8 billion in the Fund. So far, around 4.5 percent of the funds have been paid – Germany is also still to blame here!

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The EU Trust Fund for Africa (EUTF) is at the heart of tackling the current migration giant. The EUTF promotes new economic programmes in African countries, which can sustainably improve the situation of the states, which is usually very precarious economically. Furthermore, the EUTF makes a significant contribution to stabilising government systems on the ground and makes a significant contribution to conflict prevention. In particular, I would like to point out that all parties must honour their commitments in order for the EUTF to be fully effective and the European Parliament's powers of control must be strengthened in this context.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The Union for Africa Trust Fund, implemented by the President of the European Commission, 25 Member States, as well as Norway and Switzerland, was launched at the Valletta Summit on 11-12 November 2015. The European Union's contribution will amount to EUR 1.8 billion, but funds from Member States and other donors will be added for an equivalent amount. This fund aims in principle to stabilise African countries and thus better control migration. It is about promoting resilience, economic opportunity, security and development.  In reality, this fund will gather resources from different donors, often already existing, to provide a coordinated, faster and more flexible response. But will the European Union control the use of the funds? The report calls for regular and detailed reports from the European Commission, but if these reports are based mainly on information from local authorities, NGOs, and private partners, this will leave the whole problem of aid diversion. I therefore abstained because this report is still a matter of sprinkling public funds, without setting a requirement for results.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report, because there are aspects of the report which are very favourable, but still have very notable flaws. GUE's position has been taken into account in condemning the use of funds for control projects without development objectives, the recognition of local authorities as key players, the need to develop public services in countries of origin, etc. However, the vagueness of defining the role of international organizations in the report opens the door to its use to finance "military peacekeeping missions" as well as training and training in the security sector.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The main goal of the EU Trust Fund (EUTF) for Africa is to help foster stability in the regions and contribute to better migration management. The EUTF aims to address the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and irregular migration by promoting economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. In addition to disbursing funds more quickly and flexibly, we support the implementation of instruments which, in addition to enabling faster and more flexible funds to be disbursed, improve the coordination of policies and development instruments. But this is in no way a blank check for any kind of policy to be financed. With this vote we have made it clear that we will not allow money to be diverted from the objectives of development cooperation. We will not allow the policy of development cooperation and its ultimate end to be jeopardized, the eradication of poverty. The Eurochamber's progressives are committed to our vote in favour, for greater control and for an instrument that ensures a transparent step forward in favour of African countries, in favour of their sustainable development.  We regret that other forces on the left have not joined this call.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – We voted against the report on the EU Trust Fund for Africa (impacts on development and humanitarian aid) since the fund continues to be another instrument/tool that is monitoring the current migration crisis since on the one hand it uses its development funds to control and manage migration flows while on the other hand it strengthens the Fortress Europe approach.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am happy to support this motion for resolution. The EU Trust Fund for Africa aims to address the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and irregular migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. It is regrettable, however, that to date Member States’ contributions have remained too low, amounting only to a small fraction of the Union contribution and are thus far from reaching the official commitment. Member States should honour their pledges and to rapidly and effectively match the Union contribution in order to allow the trust fund to develop its full potential. I also believe that the EU must show greater coherence when acting in the field of international cooperation for development in the African region. These funds should reflect the principles of policy coherence for sustainable development and complementarity between all development stakeholders, and should avoid any contradiction between development aims and security, humanitarian and migration policies. The trust funds should contribute to achieving the long-term objectives of ensuring peace and strengthening governance in recipient countries.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the adoption of this report to be very important and I supported it with my vote, as the Emergency Fund can contribute to addressing the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and illegal migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. The document draws attention to the elimination of the causes of emigration and the importance of supporting those in distress, as mass migration confronts Europe with a new humanitarian and security challenge. A transparent strategy that works with NGOs and leaders with significant local knowledge to provide more effective assistance will hopefully be able to protect those in distress in their own homeland. The report also draws attention to the fact that EU migration policies should focus above all on addressing the root causes of migration, involving NGOs and civil society.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is only a part of the EU’s response to the migration crisis. I believe that the Funds need to be better monitored by the European Parliament.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the EUTF for Africa: Implications for Development and Humanitarian Aid (2015/2341(INI)), as the main objective of the EUTF for Africa is to contribute to stability and better migration management and address the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and irregular migration by promoting the economy, security and development.  Migration is about priority sectors: the development benefit of migration; legal migration and mobility; protection and asylum; preventing and combating irregular migration; return, readmission and reintegration. At issue is €1.8 billion in EU contributions and counts on the same amount of additional funding to be provided by EU Member States and other donors.  It is important that funds are channeled in a transparent way, that assistance is effective and directed where it is needed most. I support the proposal to include the European Parliament in monitoring and monitoring the use of funds.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report because, although draped in good moral intentions, it does not take into account the realities of life of the inhabitants in the countries concerned and is part of a policy of continuing to sprinkle millions of euros with no expected results.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ By making financial assistance more readily and flexibly available to the African countries in need in an emergency situation, the goal of this Trust Fund is to tackle the root causes of migration. I believe that this resolution will bring about more economic opportunities and thus enhance security, development, and resilience on the continent, a key element in our quest to stabilise the migration crisis. It should be noted, however, that full transparency and monitoring of such funds needs to be ensured to prevent abuse. Despite this challenge, I look forward to our deepened collaboration with African countries and am pleased I was able to support this resolution.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Mr Corrao's report on the Union Trust Fund for Africa. The fund was set up in 2015 to help countries in the Horn of Africa, Sahel, North Africa and the Chad Basin. To do this, four priorities have been identified: migration management, government stability, resilience and economic support. It was recalled that this initiative must meet the requirements of transparency and coherence. Through this initiative, Europe is laying the groundwork for a true partnership of the future between our two regions. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Union trust fund for Africa. As a reminder, this trust fund was created in November 2015 following the Valletta Summit on Migration. This report addresses issues related to the financing, implementation and control of this trust fund, which aims to help the most affected African countries, namely the Horn of Africa, the Sahel and the Chad Basin, as well as North Africa. Four priorities are identified: economic programmes, resilience, migration management, stability and governance. It also calls for greater transparency and coherence. It is important that the European Union finally tackles the root causes of immigration of African origin and specifically targets the most troubled countries.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU Trust Fund for Africa because I agree with the rapporteur that the EU Trust Fund for Africa should contribute to the development of migrant transit and origin countries, to the strengthening and improvement of local public services (social services, health, education, nutrition, culture) and political participation and governance , notably through community-focused projects, as well as that the fund should contribute to the development of employment in local sectors, while respecting human rights and the environment.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Given the migration crisis, it is clear that aid to African countries is important and can contribute to curbing irregular migration to the EU. An important aspect is to promote stabilisation and economic development in these countries, because it is the lack of opportunities for decent wages and a sense of security that has forced many people to emigrate.  Peace and stability are the main prerequisites for ensuring economic development. To this end, African countries should be supported in state-building, rule of law and conflict prevention. It is also important to develop employment in local sectors and to guarantee that jobs are found, as well as to prevent foreign companies from exploiting human resources. In a situation of continuous population growth, appropriate conditions must be provided for young people. They should be able to acquire education and employment prospects, leading to sustainable economic growth. In addition, basic public services such as access to medicine, safe food and water must be sought.  The fundamental rights of migrants must also not be forgotten. Eu action should focus on humanitarian aid as well as on combating irregular migration routes and trafficking in human beings. Actions to encourage return to home and reintegration in countries of origin should also be promoted.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting against this report. The content of the Trust Fund is not sufficiently effective to limit emigration from Africa through investment. For example, measures to prevent refugees are generally neglected, such as .B proper border security or control in these states.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the Commission’s efforts to address the problem of global migratory flows, but stress that efforts to address this problem should not take resources away from development funds concentrating on the root causes of migration. I voted in favour of the report as it calls for steps to be taken so that the Trust Funds are better monitored by the European Parliament, because they currently lack transparency in their use.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 13 September 2016, we voted in plenary on the report on the EU Trust Fund for Africa: implications for development and humanitarian aid. Here, in my opinion, we are getting to one of the roots of the current migration crisis. I am sure you know that I have long advocated the thesis of solving problems that people from other cultures and countries are coming to us, right in the outbreaks of problems, that is, in their home. This can only be ensured by resolving or at least greatly mitigating the current conflicts in these countries, while also significantly increasing the standard of life and prospects for the future of their inhabitants. Of course, various EU development funds should also help to do this. Although the financial allocations from this trust fund are concentrated in the least developed countries, the development of civil society, the cooperation of local authorities with international organisations and human rights obligations, there are many areas where the current setting is failing. The financial assistance provided in this area should be primarily aimed at addressing the real causes of poverty in the countries of origin of current migrants, such as the plundering and exploitation of human and natural resources by multinational supranational companies, land grabbing, support for some states for autocratic and corrupt governments or arms trade. That is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the adoption of this report to be very important and I supported it with my vote, as the Emergency Fund can contribute to addressing the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and illegal migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. The document draws attention to the elimination of the causes of emigration and the importance of supporting those in distress, as mass migration confronts Europe with a new humanitarian and security challenge. A transparent strategy that works with NGOs and leaders with significant local knowledge to provide more effective assistance will hopefully be able to protect those in distress in their own homeland. The report also draws attention to the fact that EU migration policies should focus above all on addressing the root causes of migration, involving NGOs and civil society.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ In November 2015, the Emergency Fund for Africa was launched. The aim of this fund is to tackle the root causes of irregular migration and displacement in countries of origin, transit and destination. However, GUE/NGL believes that this fund is another instrument which reinforces the externalisation of borders and the set-up of Europe as a fortress. Some good points of this report are: the references to use the fund for return and readmission programs, the necessity of strengthening and improving local public services, last but not least, the idea that EU migration policies should have as main objectives to investigate and solve real causes of impoverishment in the countries of origin. For all these reasons I voted abstention.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Trust Fund for Africa risks remaining an empty instrument if the promise of commitments is not followed by concrete action by member states. In fact, the national contributions that have been allocated to date are derisory: only EUR 81.71 million, not even 5% of the amount of EUR 1.8 billion envisaged. The EU Trust Fund aims to address the root causes of destabilisation, forced relocation and irregular migration by promoting resilience, economic prospects, equal opportunities, security and development. In order to achieve these objectives, we call for promises and commitments to be translated into concrete action. And let us remind the Commission that the Trust Fund for Africa should contribute to the development in the countries of transit and origin of migrants, as well as to the strengthening and improvement of local public services mainly through community-based projects. We believe that the Fund should help to create jobs in local sectors, ensuring respect for human rights and environmental protection. The Commission should monitor how The Fund's resources are used and how they are allocated, while this House should exercise a monitoring function on how it is implemented.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU Trust Fund for Africa (EUTF) is a very important development tool that pools together resources from different donors in order to enable a quick, flexible, and collective EU response to the different dimensions of an emergency situation. In particular, the EUTF aims to address the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and irregular migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development in 23 countries across three African regions (the Horn of Africa, the Sahel and Lake Chad basin; and North Africa). However, to achieve its goals and to be effective, the EUTF should provide a better balance of funding for recipient country governments and especially for reliable civil society actors, who tend to be more aware of societal deficiencies which are in need of support.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report because it is a catalogue of good intentions with no concrete significance, moreover naïve on immigration.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the report entitled 'EU Trust Fund for Africa: Implications for Development Aid and Humanitarian Aid'. Despite proactive aspects, this report is part of a logic of financing blind, without controls or hindsight, or the proper use and management of funds, the EU preferring to offload to local authorities and a partnership with the private sector, in a hypothetical hope of transferring future burdens within the framework of development policy. The report sees population growth as an asset in developing areas, while youth employment and training policies lag far behind the development targets set and the future is uncertain for younger generations, who are more likely to leave their countries to settle in Europe.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. As is often the case with this committee, intentions are good (such as development assistance from emigration countries to stop the migration haemorrhage), but diluted in proposals that are too little concrete in terms of monitoring aid, assessing results and real political will to stop the migration influx. In order to both welcome the underlying concept of the report and denounce the lack of concrete involvement induced by this text, I chose the ABSTENTION.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. In addition to disbursing funds more quickly and flexibly, we support the implementation of instruments which, in addition to enabling faster and more flexible funds to be disbursed, improve the coordination of policies and development instruments. But this is in no way a blank check for any kind of policy to be financed. With this vote we have made it clear that we will not allow money to be diverted from the objectives of development cooperation. We will not allow the policy of development cooperation and its ultimate end to be jeopardized, the eradication of poverty. The Eurochamber's progressives are committed to our vote in favour, for greater control and for an instrument that ensures a transparent step forward in favour of African countries, in favour of their sustainable development.  We regret that other forces on the left have not joined this call.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I believe that it is insufficiently critical of the Union Trust Fund for Africa, an instrument which does not contribute to development or cooperation with African countries, or to the promotion of human rights in the Union's foreign policy. On the contrary, these are funds for African countries to join the Fortress Europe project, designed to physically prevent migrants and refugees from reaching Europe.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. I would like to stress the importance of the Union Emergency Trust Fund for stability and in addressing the root causes of irregular migration and displaced persons in Africa. The objective of this is to help boost the stability of certain African regions and help them improve migration management. In particular, it aims to address the root causes of destabilization, forced displacement and irregular migration, promoting equal opportunities and economic opportunities, security and development. My country, Spain, supported the creation of this fund and was one of the first countries to announce its contribution. Interest, however, is common, both from a migration and a development point of view. For the reasons set out above, I give my positive vote for the adoption of this report, and I am confident that it will strengthen the capacities these countries have in the fight against the root of irregular migration.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report, which looks for more transparency and accountability for the EU Trust Fund for Africa, which addresses the root causes of destabilisation, displacement and irregular migration.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the increase in development aid to Africa. I stand for the principle of Trade, not Aid – African countries need the EU to eliminate import quotas and tariffs, not send charity there.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I regretted the fact that to date Member States’ contributions to Africa have remained too low. We live in a very connected world and if we do not support the development of Third World states its means that such indifference will return like a boomerang and will hit us. A shining example is the current refugee crisis. It cannot be resolved without wise strategic decisions. One of the instruments for such strategic decisions is the EU Trust Fund for Africa.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ In November 2015, the EUTF for Africa was set up as a supplementary fund for existing development funds. It aims to promote economic, social, economic and political stability in the regions of Africa, thus contributing to a better solution to the challenges of migration. The EU contribution amounts to €1.8 billion, while the Commission can also receive additional resources from Member States and other donors. Despite the complexity and wide range of Africa's problems, I consider it essential that the release of allocated resources should take place in a targeted, transparent and efficient manner. All the authorities and organisations concerned must focus on addressing the cause of the crisis in the various regions of Africa and establish control mechanisms so as not to misuse resources for corruption, political, economic and economic crime and illegal military armaments.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. The EU Trust Fund for Africa (EUTF), launched on 12 November 2015 at the EU-Africa Summit in Valletta, aims to promote political stability in different parts of the African continent and contribute to better management of migration flows. Specifically, the EUTF aims to address the root causes of forced displacement and irregular migration by promoting resilience, access to employment, equal opportunities, security and development. While the report considers the initiative to be positive, it nevertheless stresses that the EUTF, largely funded by the European development envelope, cannot be used for security or border control purposes. The EUTF must be a priority to support access to education and employment, good governance and environmental projects. This driving idea is perfectly reflected in the final text, so I support this report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the EU Trust Fund for Africa: the implications for development and humanitarian aid, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 12/9/2016, and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. We agree with the reasons why these aids are being released. The European Union Trust Fund aims to address the root causes of destabilization, forced displacement and illegal migration. It promotes resilience, economic opportunity, security and development. But on the one hand, there is no control over these aids and, on the other hand, they are part of a logic of blind funding, which we are fighting against.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on the report on the Trust Fund for Africa, which was set up after the Valletta Summit in 2015. The purpose of this Fund should also be to be able to mobilly mobilly and flexibly in emergency situations, e.g. in connection with the migration crisis. At the same time, the report is critical of the Commission's actions, which have committed breaches of financial rules by using only the trust fund. So we're calling for redress. At the same time, in the report, we warn of the risk of misuse of EU development aid, especially in conflict-affected countries, and recall that the funds must be used for development purposes and strictly pursue development objectives with a focus on poverty reduction, increasing stability and security in those countries. I supported the report in the vote.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The Union Trust Fund for Africa was set up to promote stability in these regions and contribute to better migration management. From the Union we are committed to addressing the root causes of destabilization, forced displacement and irregular migration, promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. My support for the report on this Fund and its impact on development and humanitarian aid, in which we propose actions to improve the use of this tool, which must remain useful in meeting the objectives with which it was born.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution relating to the EU Trust Fund for Africa on issues related to the impact on development and humanitarian aid and I believe it is necessary to find a more comprehensive solution for emergency funding in the context of the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). New appropriations should be created and transparency should be ensured in matters relating to the origin and destination of resources. Furthermore, I stress that a balance should be struck and there should be a balance in the funding received by the governments of the countries on issues related to citizens' awareness. Countries should make full use of the trust fund and have a flexible and quick approach to serious crises. Finally, I am voting in favour of this resolution and I argue that the Commission should operate more supervisoryly particularly in areas of development and combating illegal traffickers and make necessary agreements with countries on the trust fund.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This report aims to strengthen support programmes in Africa in order to stop the exodus to Europe. This is desirable in principle, but I do not agree with the report on a number of points. I cannot therefore support this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. A new form of European funds is becoming fashionable in Brussels. To "fight the root causes of irregular migration" from Africa, states and the Commission have agreed on an urgent "trust fund". It redirects the finances of EU instruments and state aid devolved to development policy to a board of directors who will be responsible for deciding on projects to be financed as varied as migrant returns and security and defence operations. In total opacity, outside the Community budgetary framework and at the expense of development projects. Parliament obviously does not sit on this council and here can only point to these risks, by requesting follow-up and impact reports. It calls for raising development contributions within the framework of the Community budget on which it is entitled to look, in order to focus more on the development of local economies and the fight against unemployment which are, together with crises, the main drivers of population displacement. I recognize this critical and well-provided work, but I am totally opposed to this fund, which it ultimately endorses. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. As is often the case in this committee, good intentions (such as development assistance for emigration countries to stop the migration haemorrhage), but mixed with proposals that are too little concrete in terms of monitoring aid, assessing results and real political will to stop the migration influx. Therefore, I abstained on this issue.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The main objective of the EU Trust Fund for Africa (EUTF) is to help promote stability in these regions and contribute to better migration management. More specifically, the EUTF aims to tackle the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and irregular migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. The EUTF aims to be a development instrument that brings together resources from various donors in order to enable the European Union to respond rapidly, flexibly, complementaryly, transparently and collectively to an emergency situation in its various aspects. It is therefore necessary to continue to support African countries in their development. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst the report outlined positive ways in which the Union can further its support for African migration management, I could not support the final version of the text, which contained unacceptable references to abortion.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Through the Africa Trust Fund, the European Union aims to address the root causes of destabilization, forced displacement and illegal migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities and equal opportunities, security and development. I insist that development money serves development goals. It is therefore necessary to distinguish between financial envelopes for development activities and those for migration management, border control, etc. Currently with 1.8 billion euros from the Commission and 81.71 million euros in the head of the Member States, Norway and Switzerland, this fund should wait for 3.6 billion euros. I very much hope that governments will echo Jean-Claude Juncker's call for Member States' contributions to be the same amount as the Commission." As for the level of the overall amount allocated to the 23 countries of the African continent,... one can wonder about the amount allocated when one considers that Ethiopia hosts more than 820,000 refugees and as such is the first country to accept refugees in Africa and a transit country for many Eritreans, Somalis and South Sudanese in search of Europe.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft resolution of the Committee on Development was inspired by current developments in the migration crisis. The Emergency Fund on Stability in Africa and addressing the causes of irregular migration was established at the Valletta Migration Summit on 11 and 12 November 2015; it aims to address the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and illegal migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. It focuses on five priority areas: 1) unlocking the benefits of migration;  2) legal migration and mobility;  3) protection and asylum;  4) preventing and combating illegal migration; 5) return, readmission and reintegration. The draft resolution takes into account financial opportunities, the role of civil society, NGOs, local authorities and international organisations, the financing of least developed countries, calls for transparency and clarity in order to achieve the objectives more effectively and highlights the importance of coherence of EU policies and a commitment to human rights. I supported the adoption of the draft.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The main objective of the European Union Trust Fund for Africa is to promote stability in these regions and to help better manage migration. It aims to address the root causes of destabilization, forced displacement and illegal migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, security and development. Despite proactive aspects, this report is part of a logic of financing blind, without controls or hindsight, or the proper use and management of funds, the EU preferring to offload on local authorities and on a partnership with the private sector. The report sees population growth as an asset in developing areas, while youth employment and training policies lag far behind the development goals set and the future is uncertain for the younger generations, who are more inclined to desert their country for the West for a better life than to build the future of the West. Forbearance.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The main objective of the EU Trust Fund for Africa (EUTF) is to help promote stability in these regions and contribute to better migration management. More specifically, the EUTF aims to address the root causes of forced displacement and irregular migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. I believe that the provision of funds should be more rapid and flexible in emergency situations and combine various sources of funding to deal with the migration and refugee crisis in its multiple dimensions. I support that the transparency, communication and visibility of projects developed under the EUTF are of the utmost importance for the dissemination of results and the participation and awareness-raising of European private actors, regional and local authorities, NGOs and civil society in order to create conditions for greater involvement and facilitate the participation of Member States.  I believe it is essential to ensure strict monitoring of the implementation of the provisions on redistribution, substitution in countries of origin and the financial commitments of the Member States, paying particular attention to human rights.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the EU Trust Fund for Africa, which aims to promote stability in these regions, to help better manage migration, to tackle the causes of destabilization, forced displacement and illegal migration by promoting economic opportunities, security and development. However, the lack of control over funding and evaluation of their results transforms this idea into a vast, inefficient dusting system. That is why I abstained in the vote on this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report; the Africa Trust fund is one piece in the puzzle of the EU’s response to the migration crisis. It is disappointing, however, that Member States (including the UK Government) have not matched the EU’s efforts in contributing to the trust fund. We support the Commission’s efforts to address the problem of global migratory flows, but stress that efforts to address this problem should not take resources away from development funds concentrating on the root causes of migration. This report calls for steps to be taken so that the Trust Funds are better monitored by the European Parliament, because they currently lack transparency in their use.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report on the financing and implementation of a migration trust fund established in 2015. Such a mechanism is essential because it is a priority for Africa's development. This is necessary to allow people to stay at home and have a possible future.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the European Union Trust Fund for Africa on its implications for humanitarian development assistance. The fund provides assistance in three African regions to manage migration, security and development issues. It is based on three pillars: economic programmes, resilience, migration management and stability and governance.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the report. The EU Trust Fund for Africa was set up following a summit of African and European Heads of State or Government on migration in Valletta. The report draws attention to the need to find solutions to migration problems in the countries of origin themselves. It calls on the Commission to regularly monitor the use of resources on the basis of an evidence-based approach and to give Parliament powers in relation to monitoring. The report points out that, when using the Fund's resources, it is necessary to work closely with regional and local authorities, as well as with civil and non-governmental organisations, who have an extraordinary knowledge base in the area.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution regarding the EU Trust Fund for Africa that will continue to foster stability with a special focus on the disbursement of funds more quickly and flexibly in case of an emergency situation.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report concerns one of the three EU trust funds that are necessary to ensure a rapid and comprehensive response to humanitarian crises, including those of a long-term nature. Unfortunately, however, member states' financial contributions are still too low when they amount to only a small fraction of the Union's contribution, and are nowhere near the level of the commitment made, namely only 4.5% of the declared EUR 1.8 billion. In order to achieve full effectiveness, emergency funds need to be released more quickly and flexibly and different sources of funding should be collected in order to address the migration and refugee crisis in its multiple dimensions. If the Countries of the Union are not willing to invest more in similar objectives and we fail to contribute to improving the quality of life in these parts of the world, it will not come as a surprise if the efforts of the people there to find a new, better life in the EU are once again substantially increased.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This own initiative report aims to address existing failures in the use of the EU’s ‘Emergency Trust Fund for stability and addressing root causes of irregular migration and displaced persons in Africa’ made up of EU financing and contributions from Member States. It highlights the fact that only 4.5% of the pledged funds have actually been received. But while it states it aims to promote legal migration and asylum, as well as addressing causes of displacement such as the arms trade, the Trust Fund is being used as another instrument to re-allocate and use development funds for control and management of migration flows without any development benefit. The report reinforces this as well as the general ‘Fortress Europe’ set-up. Due to these negative elements in the report I could not vote in favour of the overall report but abstained.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This report aims to strengthen support programmes in Africa in order to stop the exodus to Europe. So far, however, it is precisely these projects that have caused migration movements. That is why I do not support this report.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. The main objective of the Union Trust Fund for Africa is to promote stability in these regions and contribute to better migration management. This Fund is a unique tool in supporting the development and study of the causes of migration and can therefore lead to a better and more coordinated response to the problem. In order to meet such ambitious targets at a time of crisis as the current one, the Union has made EUR 1.8 billion available.  Despite good purposes, it seems that the commitment of States has once again been left on wet paper. This Parliament calls for the responsibility of States and warns of the mismanagement of funds and their misuse by many governments in which the usual practice is corruptness.  If we have been able to detect many of the problems arising from the misuse of this Fund, we have in our power how to reverse the situation and give it its purpose. This report is convenient and correct in its analysis and that is why I support it, although I regret that it will not have the impact it should have on States.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report as the EU Trust Fund for Africa established at the Valletta Summit is an important tool for the effective implementation of the action plan decided between the EU and African countries and touches on the major challenges on migration. In other words, combating the root causes by promoting peace, stability and economic development, better promotion and organisation of legal migration channels, strengthening the protection of migrants and asylum seekers, in particular vulnerable groups, more effective treatment of the exploitation and trafficking of migrants, closer and better cooperation on return and readmission. However, there must be guarantees as to the type of operations financed through the trust. For example, these resources should not be used as financial assistance at the disposal of national governments or to strengthen border controls between countries. On the contrary, they should be used exclusively for development projects in the fields of education, health care and infrastructure.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the non-legislative report. It calls on Member States to contribute more money to African EU projects and wants to influence the day to day running of African governments. UKIP does not support increased EU influence. In addition, UKIP does not believe in the use of aid handouts but would rather see removal of trade barriers.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I appreciate my colleague's work and I am convinced that thanks to the contribution of my group we now have an improved text. I reiterate my contribution so that Europe can promote the fight against discrimination based on religion or belief, sex, race or ethnic origin, disability and sexual orientation.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because I would like to support development and humanitarian aid. In times of unprecedented levels of irregular migration, this Trust Fund aims to support the most affected African countries, to help foster stability in those regions and to promote tighter Africa-EU cooperation on issues of migration management, security and development. The EUTF aims at addressing the root causes of destabilisation, displacement and irregular migration in three regions: the Horn of Africa, the Sahel and Lake Chad, and North Africa.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Trust Fund for Africa is a mechanism used in development cooperation that aims to address the causes of irregular immigration from the most fragile and migration-affected African countries and provides for transfer to cities of origin, transit and destination through a number of priority sectors. I am voting in favour of my colleague's report, in the hope that this development mechanism will allow a real, rapid and collective response to the problem of migration on the ground and in transit regions. Also in the light of the current crisis in the Mediterranean, I hope that the aforementioned Trust Fund for Africa will help to ensure respect for human rights and have a positive impact on the lives of millions of people.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union cares for and supports poor parts of Africa and tries to reduce poverty and boost the development of African countries through the Africa Trust Fund.  Unfortunately, sometimes the Fund's funds are not earmarked for affected parts of Africa but are used for border controls, migration, terrorism, etc. Here I expect much greater transparency and definition of which activities are allowed to be financed by the Fund. The funds earmarked for the Africa Fund must primarily serve this purpose, otherwise the situation that is already alarming is exacerbating.  I call on eu member states to work together and try to put more effort and effort into funding the Fund so that it can help Africa cope with poverty as much as possible. I also support the proposal for the European Parliament to oversee and monitor the work of the Fund and to inform Parliament in detail about the actions taken.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union Trust Fund for Africa was signed by the President of the European Commission, 25 Member States, Norway and Switzerland and launched at the Valletta Summit on Migration on 12 November 2015. It is expected to address the root causes of destabilization, forced displacement and illegal migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunity, security and development. Despite proactive aspects, this report is part of a logic of financing blind, without controls, nor in hindsight, or in the face of it. The EU prefers to offload to local authorities and a partnership with the private sector, in a hypothetical hope of transferring burdens. The report sees population growth as an asset in developing areas, at a time when youth employment and training policies are far behind the development targets set, and the future is uncertain for younger generations who are inclined to leave their country. I therefore prefer to abstain on this report which, draped in good moral intentions, ignores the realities and practises the dusting of millions of euros without results.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The main objective of the EU Trust Fund for Africa, signed jointly by the President of the European Commission together with the 25 EU Member States and Norway and Switzerland, presented by the European and African partners at the Valletta Migration Summit on 12 November 2015, is to contribute to stability in these regions and better migration management.  The European Consensus on Development remains a fundamental framework of EU development policy and that the European Consensus on Humanitarian Aid reaffirms the fundamental principles of humanitarian aid; whereas peace in the new 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the introduced Sustainable Development Goal 2030; 16 on peace and justice recognised as crucial to development; 1.5 billion people worldwide live in fragile regions affected by conflict and that the number of fragile states and areas without administration is growing, causing many to be exposed to poverty, lawlessness, blooming corruption and violence.  Since the idea leading up to the establishment of the Trust Fund was to help the 23 countries in the three African regions where some of Africa's most unstable countries are located, affected by migration as countries of origin, transit or destination, sometimes in all three of these roles, and will benefit the most from this form of EU financial assistance, I support the adoption of this report and the operationalisation of this Fund as soon as possible.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of setting up an emergency trust fund for stability and addressing the root causes of irregular migration and displaced persons in Africa. In view of the current situation, the establishment is a necessary step in addressing the causes of irregular migration at the place of origin, not just their consequences. However, if we want to make the Fund a truly functional instrument that will have an impact on stabilising our neighbourhood, we must not make the same mistakes as previous trusts. The fundamental question is how do we ensure sufficient financial support from the Member States, as the Fund currently does not have nearly as much resources as it needs to meet all the declared objectives. Member States are releasing their resources too slowly, notwithstanding the pressure of irregular migration. It is unacceptable that the budgetary authority of the European Parliament should continue to be circumvented, as has been the case so far. Considering that almost 30% of all foreign aid is provided through the European Development Fund outside the EU budget, a huge amount lacking democratic legitimacy. Nor is the re-control in the form of discharge granted by Parliament to the Commission sufficient to guarantee transparency in the management of the development fund funds. I therefore agree with Parliament's motion for a resolution on the need to achieve greater synergies between the various instruments of foreign aid, namely the incorporation of the European Development Fund into the budget.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am persuaded that the EU Trust Fund for Africa could help to stabilise the region and largely contribute to migration management. By focusing the monetary support on social and democratic issues like education, good governance, the environment and employment, we fight the root causes of destabilisation and forced displacement. This aims to solve a small piece of the puzzle of the larger migration crisis, which we must continue to work diligently on. I believe these funds must be better monitored for transparency by the European Parliament to ensure they promote resilience, economic opportunities, gender equality and development, as opposed to security measures and border control. Last year all nations agreed on the amount of contributions, and it is critical that each member state follows through on their pledge. Currently, only 4.5% of the promised funds are provided, while all are necessary to fulfil on our commitments to stabilise the region and better manage the migration crisis.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has allocated €1.8 billion of EU financial resources to set up an 'Emergency Trust Fund for Stability and to Address the Root Causes of Illegal Migration to Africa'.  A Trust Fund is a mechanism used in development cooperation to pool large resources from different donors. In particular, the European Union wants to help the Sahel region as a whole to meet growing challenges such as demographic pressure, environmental stress, extreme poverty, internal tensions, institutional weakness, weak social and economic infrastructure. This report addresses the many questions and concerns raised following the creation of the EUTF (European Trust Fund for Africa) in terms of funding, implementation and control. The report provides a critical assessment of the budgetary aspects and shortcomings in terms of funding by the Member States and calls on all stakeholders to promptly support their commitments and responsibilities. I believe that it has been well formulated and that is why I have chosen to vote in favour of its approval.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The main objective of the EU Trust Fund (EUTF) for Africa, signed by the President of the Commission together with 25 EU Member States (and Norway and Switzerland) launched at the Valletta Summit on Migration in November 2015 by European and African partners, is to help support regional stabilisation and contribute to better migration management. The EU Trust Fund aims to address the root causes of destabilisation, forced resettlement and irregular migration by promoting flexibility, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. The EU Trust Fund for Africa was designed to help twenty-three countries in three african regions (Horn of Africa, Sahel and Lake Chad Basin, North Africa), it covers some of the most fragile African countries that, as countries of origin, are exposed to migration, transit or destination, or those three phenomena at the same time, and which can benefit most from this form of EU financial assistance. I have hereby abstained.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Union's Africa Trust Fund was established in November 2015, following the Valletta (Malta) summit on migration, to provide support to African states most affected by irregular migration. Four regions are particularly targeted: the Horn of Africa, the Sahel, the Lake Chad basin and, more generally, North Africa. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the difficulties involved in the creation of this fund, in terms of funding, implementation and control. Through this text, we call for greater transparency and coherence, both in the development of programmes and in the implementation of projects. Effective development must be a priority, and so all stakeholders (the EU, its Member States and African States) must fully assume their responsibilities to make this trust fund a useful tool in solving this unprecedented migration crisis.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Established at the Vallifa Summit on Migration, the European Union Emergency Trust Fund for Africa (EUTF) has as its fundamental objectives the fight against the root causes of irregular migration and the promotion of stability in the regions.  This report rightly raises questions on issues such as the financing, implementation and scrutiny of that fund. The same report underlines the interest of all Member States in honouring their commitments in terms of contributions so that it is possible to implement the EUTF in a full and comprehensive manner. On the other hand, the report draws attention to the need for constant monitoring in the implementation of the EUTF. In this regard, I stress that the primary focus on migration is imperative and that the fund should give priority to conflict prevention, the implementation of the rule of law and good governance. Because I believe that a transparent, responsible and politically coherent definition and implementation is of high importance when using funds such as the EUTF, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the non-legislative report. It calls on Member States to contribute more money to African EU projects and wants to influence the day to day running of African governments. UKIP does not support increased EU influence. In addition, UKIP does not believe in the use of aid handouts but would rather see removal of trade barriers.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, as the main objective of the EUTF is to help promote stability in African regions and contribute to better migration management. More specifically, the EUTF aims to tackle the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and irregular migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. The EUTF aims to be a development instrument that brings together resources from various donors in order to enable the European Union to respond rapidly, flexibly, complementaryly, transparently and collectively to an emergency situation in its various aspects. The Commission's monitoring of the use and allocation of the EUTF's financial resources should be systematic and strengthen Parliament's powers of control over the EUTF. It is also up to the Council and the Commission to regularly report on the concrete actions taken by the EU and african states when using these funds, as well as the results achieved.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In addition to disbursing funds more quickly and flexibly, we support the implementation of instruments which, in addition to enabling faster and more flexible funds to be disbursed, improve the coordination of policies and development instruments. But this is in no way a blank check for any kind of policy to be financed. With this vote we have made it clear that we will not allow money to be diverted from the objectives of development cooperation. We will not allow the policy of development cooperation and its ultimate end to be jeopardized, the eradication of poverty. The Eurochamber's progressives are committed to our vote in favour, for greater control and for an instrument that ensures a transparent step forward in favour of African countries, in favour of their sustainable development.  We regret that other forces on the left have not joined this call.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the European Union Trust Fund for Africa. The fund aims to promote the stability of these regions and to help better manage migration. In the context of the migration crisis, the report stresses the need to increase Parliament's supervisory power over the fund to verify how it is used. Greater coordination between actors, greater transparency and communication are essential to create the conditions for wider participation. The report stresses that it is crucial to act on the causes of migration and to understand the consequences of it in order to mobilise the fund more adequately.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU Africa Trust Fund (EUTF) was established at the Vallifo Conference in November 2015. Considering the current and unique levels of illegal and irregular migration, the EUTF was created as a way to support the most affected African countries, help restore stability and strengthen cooperation between Africa and the EU on issues such as migration flow management, security and development. The EUTF aims to address the causes behind destabilisation, displacement and migration in three specific regions: the Horn of Africa, Sahel and Lake Chad and, finally, North Africa. To achieve these objectives, four priority sectors have been established to be addressed: economic programmes, resilience, migration management and stability and governance. This report raises some questions concerning the EUTF by appealing to its transparency, accountability, ownership and policy coherence, in particular in the definition and implementation of projects, as well as full respect for the principles of sustainable development. It also carries out a critical assessment of budgetary aspects, alrisking its shortcomings and urging stakeholders to assume their commitments and responsibilities. Because I generally agree with the content of this own-initiative report, I voted in favour of it.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on funding issues, implementation and control of the European Union Trust Fund for Africa. The fund was set up at the Valletta Summit on Migration in November 2015 and provides for a budget of 1.8 billion euros. The main objective of this fund is to promote stability in this region and to help better manage migration. It also aims to address the root causes of destabilization, forced displacement and illegal migration, promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. This report calls for transparency and clarity for better achievement of the objectives. It is essential that this fund respects the principle of coherence and avoids any contradiction between development objectives and security, humanitarian and migration policies. In the use of this fund, the EU and the Member States must set themselves long-term goals for peace-building and strengthening governance in the recipient countries.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report, because there are aspects of the report which are very favourable, but still have very notable flaws. GUE's position has been taken into account in condemning the use of funds for control projects without development objectives, the recognition of local authorities as key players, the need to develop public services in countries of origin, etc. However, the vagueness of defining the role of international organizations in the report opens the door to its use to finance "military peacekeeping missions" as well as training and training in the security sector.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the EU Trust Fund (EUTF) in Africa. The EUTF in Africa was set up at the Valletta Migration Summit in November 2015 to support the african countries most affected, to create stability in these regions and to promote EU-Africa cooperation on issues such as migration management, security and development, in view of the migration observed. The aim is to combat the causes of destabilisation, displacement and irregular migration. The report calls for transparency, accountability, ownership and policy coherence in the preparation and implementation of the project, with full respect for the principles of efficiency in development issues. In addition, Member States are critically scrutinised on payment bottlenecks and all stakeholders are invited to honour their commitments and responsibilities without delay.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The report is calling for Member States to contribute money to finance the EU Trust Fund. So naturally I voted against it.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it calls for steps to be taken so that the Trust Funds are better monitored by the European Parliament, because they currently lack transparency in their use.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing – I voted against. In fact, I do not believe that the rules and criteria governing development aid for projects financed by the EUTF should also emphasise that eu policy on cooperation in the areas of security, migration management and the fight against trafficking in human beings and smuggling should include specific provisions highlighting LGBTI rights, sexual and reproductive health and rights.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: In writing ‒ Following the Summit of African and European Heads of State or Government in Valletta ( November 2015), an EUTF for Africa was set up to enable the Union, its Member States and contributing donors to respond to the different dimensions of emergencies through joint flexible and rapid responses to current challenges, but also migration-related opportunities. It regrets that, despite this assistance, 1.5 billion people are still living in unstable and conflict-affected areas around the world. On the other hand, I appreciate that the EUTF for Africa, in the context of the current crisis, is helping regions of Africa, from the Sahel to the Horn of Africa and the North African region, to address the root causes of destabilisation, forced displaced displacion and irregular migration. I supported the resolution because I believe that, on the basis of the measures taken, we will be able to remedy the shortcomings of the TF to date, be it the use of trust fund funds or the actual coordination between all the entities involved in the management of this fund. I also believe that by extending EU humanitarian and development aid to refugees and migrants, we will prevent further loss of life at sea and strengthen cooperation with key countries of transit and origin.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The EU Trust Fund for Africa was established last year in response to migration flows to Europe. It aims to use certain means to combat the key causes of such migration and to support all aspects of stability that can help to better address migration.  The Fund geographically covers the Sahel regions, Lake Chad, the Horn of Africa and North Africa, and the funding mainly comes from the Budget of the European Development Fund (EDF). Possible projects that may be set up with the help of the Fund relate to the creation of economic programmes that will create employment opportunities, projects to support basic services for local people, projects to support migration management, and support for general management or management.  Although the report is flawed or repetitive in certain parts, I believe that this kind of fund can have a positive impact on potential migrants from these areas and on the lives of Europeans.  For this reason, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \u2012 The Area of Africa is currently perceived mainly as a source of migration. Appropriately and appropriately allocated financial and non-financial assistance can not only mass migration, but also create the conditions for kick-starting their own economic growth. However, aid must always be conditional on demands for democratisation, respect for human and civil rights and structural reforms.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing.
