In its resolution, the EP reiterates an important criterion in development aid: aid is only available for adopting 'European principles': gender mainstreaming, special rights for LGBTIQ, abortion and other methods of controlling the values and norms of foreign cultures. The EU is not making friends in Africa, and the representatives of the African states have repeatedly resisted this 'import of values'. As long as the EU imposes its "principles" on African states, development aid will not bear fruit. But she constantly creates addictions: "We're eating bread, that's the song I sing" also applies to relations with Africa. Development aid should always be help for self-help. Given the huge need for support to developing countries, on the one hand, and the limited resources, on the other, it is appropriate to concentrate the measures. Only those projects are to be supported, which the recipient country or the local companies can continue independently after the end of the project without outside help. Priority in development aid is on measures that can be accompanied by local private companies, both in an investment and organisation. Causes of flight in the countries of origin must be combated, even if this is detrimental to the Western economy. That is what the AfD is calling for. The EU does not grant this. That is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The main objective of the European Union Trust Fund for Africa is to contribute to stability and better migration management. In other words, the Fund aims to address the causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and irregular migration.  Africa has a very high rate of population growth, which can lead to a sharp increase in the young, working-age population and great economic benefits. In order to achieve this, it is necessary to provide young people with education and skills in order to reach their potential. I believe that more transparency is needed to reduce the abuse of development aid and to reach those most in need. I support the report on the European Union Trust Fund for Africa, as I consider the guidelines set out there to be of high quality and the implementation of these guidelines can lead to a strengthening of the role of NGOs and local authorities.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU Trust Fund for Africa: implications for development and humanitarian aid.  The creation of the European Union Emergency Trust Fund for Africa and the allocation of €1.8 billion in EU funding is an ad hoc response to the challenges we face, and it reminds us that we need a more flexible EU budget and larger budget reserves if we are to deal with unexpected crises more successfully in the future.  Despite the extraordinary circumstances that demand us to act quickly and effectively, we must not forget the legitimate, transparent and responsible use of the European Union budget. If we want to make full use of the potential of the Trust Fund, then we need a greater contribution from member states that have contributed less than 5% to the Fund. I would like the Member States to move from words to actions, to honour their commitments and contribute to the fund.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Union's primary concern should be to combat the poverty and austerity of its Member States and not to finance all kinds of African and third states in general.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal, primarily in the hope that it will inst cause changes that will allow the Fund to better fulfil its fundamental objective of addressing the causes of mass migration locally at its roots. I also hope that, as a result, the Member States will recognise their responsibilities and provide a contribution of EUR 1.8 billion voted for and undertaken to the operation of the Fund (as opposed to the minimum member states' transfers of just under EUR 81 million so far). However, in agreement with most of my fellow MEPs, I deplore the use of the Fund's resources for border surveillance, in complete contrast to its original purpose. I also resent the fact that the Fund is not part of the EU budget and therefore does not fall under Parliament's control; I am convinced that correcting this situation could also remedy the above problems of payment and allocation of resources as a result of this Decision.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The idea of setting up an EU Trust Fund for Africa was discussed for the first time at the European Leaders' Summit in Valletta on migration in November 2015. Due to the unprecedented level of irregular migration, a fund has been set up to support Africa's countries most affected by the crisis, in order to strengthen stability in the region and promote closer EU-Africa cooperation on migration management issues. The report answers many of the questions and concerns raised in the context of the creation of the Fund in terms of financing, implementation and control. The document also calls for greater transparency, accountability and policy coherence in the definition and implementation of projects, while fully respecting the principles of development effectiveness. The Fund must contribute primarily to the long-term objectives of ensuring peace and strengthening governments in the countries of origin of illegal immigrants.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report by our colleague Ignazio Corrao on the Trust Fund for Africa, for which the 5 Star Movement has always fought, was a success as it was approved by a large majority. Thanks to this report, Europe will have to allocate EUR 1.8 billion from funds to education, health, training and essential public services, and the Member States will also have to play their part by sending their contributions to the fund. If we really want to stop migratory flows to Europe, the root causes of migration must be eradicated. If operated with specific periodic controls, involving NGOs and local civil society in the planning and implementation of projects, the Trust Fund will prove to be an effective tool for achieving its objectives. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is the most important source of development aid for African countries. This stems from an understanding of the importance of solving problems on the African continent in the southern neighbourhood of the Union. The EU Trust Fund for Africa (EUTF) is one of the instruments designed at the Valletta Summit on Migration in November 2015 to stabilise the continent and better manage migration. In this latter respect, the focus must be on the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and illegal migration, encouraging solutions such as resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, citizens' security and development. However, the effective use of EUTF funds should be closely monitored in order to avoid misappropriation for obscure purposes by local actors or for border control. The areas that must be the priority investment targets are education, jobs, good governance, environmental projects, i.e. those related to the daily lives of the inhabitants of the African continent. However, the EUTF is only one component of the EU's response to the migration crisis. Member States need to support several such instruments in order to achieve concrete results. However, this is a first step in the right direction.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the text, following the opinion of my colleague PS, an expert on the subject. It should be stressed, however, that alliances with Africa must be fostered without falling into a colonial approach that would run counter to the union's values.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - Motion for a resolution on the EU Trust Fund for Africa: I supported the implications for development and humanitarian aid.  The main objectives of the EU Trust Fund for Africa are to contribute to stability in the regions, manage migration, address the root causes of destabilisation and forced displacement, and promote resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development.  We need to equip young people with the education and skills they need to realise their potential and create employment opportunities in order to promote stability, sustainable economic growth, social cohesion and development in the region.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report, because there are aspects of the report which are very favourable, but still have very notable flaws. GUE's position has been taken into account in condemning the use of funds for control projects without development objectives, the recognition of local authorities as key players, the need to develop public services in countries of origin, etc. However, the vagueness of defining the role of international organizations in the report opens the door to its use to finance "military peacekeeping missions" as well as training and training in the security sector.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The main objective of the European Union Trust Fund for Africa is to promote stability in these regions and to help better manage migration. The European Union Trust Fund aims to address the root causes of destabilization, forced displacement and illegal migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, security and development. Despite proactive aspects, this report is part of a logic of financing blind, without controls or hindsight, or the proper use and management of funds, the EU preferring to offload to local authorities and a partnership with the private sector, in a hypothetical hope of transferring future burdens within the framework of development policy. The report sees population growth as an asset in developing areas, while youth employment and training policies lag far behind the development goals set, and the future is uncertain for younger generations. So I chose abstention.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Trust Fund for Africa (EUTF) is an important tool for the development of areas of poverty, social and economic destabilisation, migration and lack of access to finance. However, the results of the work so far show that the financing of these activities has not had the intended results. The existing immigration crisis has contributed to the security of EU citizens. It is our duty to provide humanitarian aid, but aid must be carried out prudently and responsibly. In my opinion, the motion for a resolution does not meet this condition, which is why I opposed its adoption.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The establishment of the EU Trust Fund for Africa, signed by the President of the Commission and 25 EU Member States, as well as Norway and Switzerland, was initiated by European and African partners at the Valletta Summit on Migration on 12 November 2015 with the main aim of promoting stability in the region and contributing to better management of migration. The specific purpose of the Emergency Fund is to address the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and illegal migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. I supported this document.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I abstained in the vote on this report, because there are aspects of the report which are very favourable, but still have very notable flaws. GUE's position has been taken into account in condemning the use of funds for control projects without development objectives, the recognition of local authorities as key players, the need to develop public services in countries of origin, etc. However, the vagueness of defining the role of international organizations in the report opens the door to its use to finance "military peacekeeping missions" as well as training and training in the security sector.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I recall that a people-to-people-centred approach is of paramount importance, and I firmly believe that the eu trust fund should focus not only on economic development but also on public projects specifically aimed at improving the quality and fairness and universal accessibility of basic services, especially in education, vocational training, health and nutrition, food security and water and sanitation. , all of which are essential for enhancing the inclusiveness, empowerment and well-being of the local population, with a particular focus on young people, as well as in responding to the needs of vulnerable communities, including minorities, while at the same time providing better and more equitable and sustainable services to the population as a whole.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of report on the EU Trust Fund for Africa: the implications for development and humanitarian aid. The main goal of the EU Trust Fund for Africa (EUTF) is to help foster stability in the regions and contribute to better migration management; whereas, more specifically, the EUTF aims to address the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and irregular migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. The report stresses that the volatility of voluntary contributions shows that recourse to funding instruments outside the EU budget is not a viable way to mobilise additional funding and urges the Member States to honour their pledges and to rapidly and effectively match the Union contribution. I voted in favour because I strongly believe that the EUTF should focus not only on economic development but also on grassroots projects specifically aimed at improving quality, equity and universal accessibility of basic services as well as training to develop local competences.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The Union Emergency Trust Fund for Stability and to Address the Root Causes of Irregular Migration and Displaced Persons in Africa was established in November 2015, with the aim of helping to boost stability, in order to improve migration management, aiming to address the root causes of destabilization , forced displacement and irregular migration, and promoting equal opportunities, economic opportunities, security and development. This report addresses many of the issues arising in relation to the creation of this fund in terms of funding, implementation and scrutiny, calling for transparency, accountability and policy coherence in defining and implementing projects, while respecting, above all, the principles of development effectiveness. In addition, the document provides a critical assessment of the budgetary aspects concerning Member States. In this area, it should be remembered that Spain was the first to support the creation of the Fund and one of the first to announce its contribution. For all this, I considered it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. In addition to disbursing funds more quickly and flexibly, we support the implementation of instruments which, in addition to enabling faster and more flexible funds to be disbursed, improve the coordination of policies and development instruments. But this is in no way a blank check for any kind of policy to be financed. With this vote we have made it clear that we will not allow money to be diverted from the objectives of development cooperation. We will not allow the policy of development cooperation and its ultimate end to be jeopardized, the eradication of poverty. The Eurochamber's progressives are committed to our vote in favour, for greater control and for an instrument that ensures a transparent step forward in favour of African countries, in favour of their sustainable development.  We regret that other forces on the left have not joined this call.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my Labour and Socialist colleagues, I voted in favour of this report because the Africa Trust fund is one piece in the puzzle of the EU’s response to the migration crisis. It supports the Commission’s efforts to address the problem of global migratory flows, but stresses that efforts to address this problem should not take resources away from development funds concentrating on the root causes of migration. This report also calls for steps to be taken so that the Trust Funds are better monitored by the European Parliament, because they currently lack transparency in their use.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I have wholeheartedly agreed to this report. The European Parliament must at all times give its assent to the Budget of the European Union. In some situations when emergency aid is granted, it is understandable that Parliament's budget agreement cannot be requested at all times. Parliament does, however, ask that, given the extraordinary flexibility and speed of a trust fund, a periodic report is reported to Parliament at least once every six months. There is a need for transparent control, assessment and accountability for performance. It must be possible to check whether the funds have the desired effect and have been spent efficiently.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of the fund is to help promote stability in these regions and contribute to better migration management. The value of the EU contribution to the fund: EUR 1.8 billion, although in April 2016 it still amounted to only EUR 81.71 million.  Firstly, it is regrettable that Member States' contributions remain very low and that payments are delayed, and Member States are urging them to honour their commitments.  We monitor the need for development aid. We do not follow this logic of trust funds that run alongside the EU budget and which in many cases lack transparency in their management and implementation.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The Trust Fund is not an effective means of ensuring a halt to emigration from Africa through investment. In most cases, it is precisely these funds and measures that are to blame for the exodus. Instead, important escape preventions are neglected, such as .B proper border security or control in these states. I therefore rejected the proposal.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU Trust Fund for Africa: implications for development and humanitarian aid. In particular, the report highlights the importance of using the full amount of the Trust Fund for purely development projects, including education, health care and infrastructure.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Africa Trust fund is one piece in the puzzle of the EU’s response to the migration crisis. It is disappointing, however, that Member States (including the UK Government) have not matched the EU’s efforts in contributing to the trust fund. Together with my S&D colleagues, I support the Commission’s efforts to address the problem of global migratory flows, but stress that efforts to address this problem should not take resources away from development funds concentrating on the root causes of refugee flight and migration. This report calls for steps to be taken so that the Trust Funds are better monitored by the European Parliament, because they currently lack sufficient transparency in their use.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The EU Trust Fund for Africa (EUTF), which was launched in Valletta in November 2015, aims to support stability in African regions and contribute to better migration management. The Fund is intended to support the elimination of the root causes of destabilisation, forced resettlement and irregular migration in twenty-three countries, in three regions of Africa: the Horn of Africa, the Sahel and the Lake Chad Basin, North Africa. I abstained from voting because, although the report promotes a proper approach to migration, it also promotes access to reproductive rights, i.e. m.in. abortion.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report of the Development Committee analyses in detail the aspects of the budget on how aid is provided, supports the transparency and effectiveness of the objectives, and underlines the role of international and local organisations and bodies. I voted in favour.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. Because of high levels of irregular migration, the EU Trust Fund for Africa was set up to support the african countries most affected, to help promote stability in these regions and to promote closer cooperation between Africa and the EU on migration, security and development management issues. The report makes references to funding, implementation and control. Transparency, accountability and ownership and policy coherence in terms of project definition and implementation are called upon, with full respect for the principles of development and its effectiveness. The report provides a critical assessment of budgetary aspects and deficiencies in terms of funding by Member States. It also asks all stakeholders to comply promptly with their commitments and responsibilities. Finally, Spain has already made the corresponding contribution and is actively participating in this Fund, so I vote in favour of this report.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The report on the 'EU Trust Fund for Africa' also reveals the real objectives of its creation. To be another EU mechanism for its multiform economic, political and military interventions on the African continent, which is one of the geostrategic priorities of its aggressive imperialist policy and a field of fierce monopolistic competition between imperialist centres and powerful capitalist countries for the exploitation of rich - mainly energy - sources. False words about supposedly addressing the causes of migration and hypocritical human rights wishes cannot hide the true destination of the fund that the report itself confesses: Financing interventions that, under the cloak of 'peace operations', will extend the EU's already developed military missions (Somalia, Mali, the Central African Republic, Niger, Sahel countries, etc.) to every region of Africa , where the interests of monopoly groups so require. EU funds are not created to tackle the poverty and impoverishment that breeds and reproduces the imperialist system, but to combat capitalist exploitation. This exploitation must be opposed by the people and overthrown by building their own power.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ The main objective of the European TF for Africa, which was set up at the Valletta Summit on Migration in November 2015, is to promote stability in the region and improve migration management. The Trust Fund has set out to address the roots of destabilisation, forced displaced displacion and migration by promoting security, development and economic opportunities. In the meantime, he actively assisted in 23 African countries, which are countries of origin, transit or destination of migration. In this resolution, Parliament recalled that, although Member States have promised to contribute to the Trust Fund, they have so far made a real contribution of only a very small amount and should therefore be aware that it will be necessary for the fund to function effectively in order to keep its promises. In addition, the resolution also highlighted the lack of flexibility of the financial framework, which is unable to respond quickly to crises, and called for its ceiling to be raised. I agree that the promises made by the Member States with regard to contributions to the TF are to be kept, but on the other hand, I do not agree with the calls for an increase in the ceiling of the multiannual financial framework. In general, crisis situations should not always be addressed by increasing the budget, but in particular by making effective use of existing schemes and means. That is why I decided to abstain in the final vote.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Corrao report on the EU Trust Fund for Africa because I consider the role of this fund to help promote stability in the region and contribute to better migration management as key. I also stress the mission of this fund to address the root causes of destabilisation, forced displacement and irregular migration by promoting resilience, economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development. I regret, however, that trust funds are not subject to scrutiny by the European Parliament, given the added value of this institution in assessing the management of funds in humanitarian assistance.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. - Motion for a resolution on the EU Trust Fund for Africa: I supported the implications for development and humanitarian aid. Africa is still facing a high rate of population growth and only a slow decline in birth rates, which will lead to a sharp increase in the number of working-age young people in the near future, resulting in significant potential social and economic benefits.  I believe that it is essential to equip young people with the education and skills they need to realise their potential and to create employment opportunities in order to promote stability, sustainable economic growth, social cohesion and development in the region.  The Fund is also primarily a tool to combat migration.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to argue the reason for my vote in favour of this report, which deals very clearly with various aspects of the gender pay gap, from which our continent is still heavily crossed.  In general, this is a good report, which highlights the consequences that care work has on women's employment: some 3.3 million women aged between 15 and 34 have had to leave their jobs to assist people in their families.  The report also highlights the need for targeted policies for work-life balance, as well as for women with disabilities, young people, migrants and LGBTQI people, who are often victims even more affected by discrimination in the workplace. In this respect, the Commission and the Member States are called on to develop effective policies to combat gender stereotypes.  We have also voted in favour of the non-transferability of parental leave, since we believe that this is a strong signal that the European Union must give to the Member States. In addition, the issue of pensions is addressed. It is a very sensitive issue: the period of motherhood is not counted as a maturing period the levelling-up in the career path and we think that it should be equated.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, this report is a good start, and I congratulate the rapporteurs on the work done. We voted in favour, because it takes positive steps on the path of conciliation, but we cannot fail to talk about the substance: the causes of the impossibility of many, and especially of many women, of many workers, in order to reconcile personal and professional life. It is urgent to recast the Maternity, Paternity and Parental Leave Directives, so that these leaves are equal and non-transferable. For the right of all to care, for the right of all and all to be cared for, for the right of women to develop their professional career and professional life on an equal footing. Greater investment is needed in quality and free children's schools and quality public services for the care of our elders. And we need to combat job precariousness, which particularly attacks women, the pay gap and the pension gap. Ladies and gentlemen, to reconcile is to live. And life must be at the heart of our policies.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, since our glorious Brexit vote we have seen a large number of economic scare stories kicked into the long grass. But this should not disguise or hide the Government’s policies that are turning the screws on working people. We have seen record numbers of zero—hours contracts – zero—hours contracts that provide absolutely no job security whatsoever. The Government is also set to introduce ‘pay to stay’ for council tenants. Let us put that into perspective. They are levying a tax on the poorest in society. That is simply not on and we will fight it all the way. Brexit was a vote by those left behind by big business, big government and the political class and we will make sure that Brexit benefits those who voted to get our country back.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on its line in the ongoing Commission work on what is called "work-life balance" in the EU context. The report makes very far-reaching demands for supranationalism, not least in the area of family policy. Of course, it is important that a pregnant woman is offered good insurance while she is pregnant, that discrimination in the workplace is combated and that there are well-functioning parental insurance systems. But it is not an issue that should lie at European level. I therefore voted against the report.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the report is to increase women's participation in the labour market by making the current EU legal and political framework more modern and adapted to today's labour market, in order to enable people with children or other dependent family members to better balance family and professional life, to allow greater sharing of care responsibilities between women and men and to strengthen gender equality in the labour market. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that work-life balance is a fundamental right that has not yet been achieved in Europe, and which is an obstacle to achieving real equality between men and women.  With this report we send a clear message to the Commission to update and complete European legislation. It must submit as soon as possible a revision of the maternity directive, an improvement in the parental leave directive and two new directives, one on paternity leave and one on the leave of carers.  It is also important to improve the provision of quality services at affordable prices for childcare and other dependents, so that women, who are the majority among caregivers, can participate in the labour market and qualify for full-time jobs, which allow them to generate a decent pension for the future.   It is also necessary to streamline working hours and introduce greater flexibility so that all workers can enjoy their private life, which is not only in the benefit of people, but also of companies because workers are more productive.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-binding and non-legislative report. Although there were some very sensitive issues regarding equality, discrimination and helping disadvantaged people, the report went on to call for more EU action and legislation. It included calls for the reversal in the burden of proof in legal situations which would end the presumption of innocence and irrevocably alter UK criminal law. The report called for the EU to monitor national legislation, it tried to say when schools should close, and wanted changes to national taxation and social security. The only people that should take such decisions are our elected national governments, not unaccountable EU bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this own-initiative report prepared jointly by EMPL and FEMM, which calls for the Commission and Member States to implement measures such as ensuring affordable childcare, and paid leave including maternity, paternity, parental and carers’ leave in order to address the exclusion of women from the labour force due to caring responsibilities. On the issue of non-transferability of parental leave, Sinn Féin’s position is in favour of non-transferability (i.e. it cannot be transferred from the father to the mother) as it is proven to benefit the position of women in the workforce.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. It is time to assess our demographic and socio-economic challenges and adopt a set of legislative and non-legislative pieces to finally promote a work-life balance. In voting for this report, Parliament sent a strong message to the Commission, which is presenting its new proposal by the end of the year.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have expressed my support to the report concerning labour market conditions favourable for work-life balance. In 2015 the European Commission launched a public consultation titled ‘A new start to address the challenges of work-life balance faced by working families’. Despite the recognition, as a fundamental right, of the reconciliation of professional, private and family life in the last decades, the EU legal and policy framework needs to be updated. I support the objective of the Commission which is to increase the participation of women in the labour market in order to allow for parents with children and/or other dependent relatives to better balance family and work life, to allow for greater sharing of care responsibilities between women and men, and to strengthen gender equality in the labour market. I would like to take this opportunity to call on the Commission and the Member States to take necessary measures in order to promote equality between women and men at work and to ensure equal earnings and equal career opportunities. In the near future the Commission should present a proposal for a revised Maternity Leave Directive, bring forward a Paternity Leave Directive and a Carers’ Leave Directive as well as present an implementation report of the Parental Leave Directive.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. This report is about the creation of a series of legislative and non-legislative measures to promote a work-life balance. The Commission and the Member States are called upon to create equal pay and working conditions for men and women. The aim of this report is also to enable women to participate more in the labour market in general by modernising the existing legal and political framework of the EU and adapting it to the current labour market. It also highlights, inter alia, the relevance of high-quality early childhood care accessible to everyone and the need to distribute care responsibilities (of children or family members) more widely between men and women. In recent decades, there have already been a number of initiatives at European and national level in the field of reconciling work, private and family life, but progress is still needed in this area. I support Parliament's call for this debate to be strengthened and for the Commission to step up its work in this area in general, taking into account the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The general idea of this text is the desire to reconcile private and professional life as best as possible and to combat discrimination through legislative and non-legislative measures, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity. In practical terms, it is a question of organising society and the world of work so that women can participate in the labour market in the same way as men and that the same professional environment allows them the freedom to procreate, without hindrance. More broadly, the aim is to combat persistent gender inequality, particularly in the area of employment. Women's and families' freedom of choice is short-circuited. Finally, the woman is seen only as an inferior equal of the man, requiring more special legislative attention. In addition, migrants, freedom of movement and 2020 targets are added and guided by this issue. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of transparency and democracy I would like to confirm I voted against this report. It is another example of the EU forcing its narrow minded rules upon our daily lives. This report reverses the burden of proof in court cases. It forces men and women to take equal time off work using maternity and paternity leave, which may suit some but not all families. To top it off it calls on the UK to recognise legal documents that we don´t currently accept as official with a view to guaranteeing free movement.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that reconciling work, private and family life should be recognised as a fundamental right. Work-life balance not only improves the well-being of everyone, but also benefits society as a whole, as people with a satisfactory work-life balance are more productive at work.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on creating labour market conditions conducive to work-life balance. The need to modernise the work-life balance system at EU level is visible. Society is experiencing demographic change, unemployment is still a huge problem, and the availability of children still has an extremely negative impact on women's employment. I therefore agree with the need to promote employment, provide children with quality early childhood education, care and provide all opportunities for leisure employment. In addition, a policy of proper work and private life will help to ensure the safety and quality of life of elderly, disabled or dependent people with long-term illnesses.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-binding and non-legislative report. Although there were some very sensitive issues regarding equality, discrimination and helping disadvantaged people, the report went on to call for more EU action and legislation. It included calls for the reversal in the burden of proof in legal situations which would end the presumption of innocence and irrevocably alter UK criminal law. The report called for the EU to monitor national legislation, it tried to say when schools should close, and wanted changes to national taxation and social security. The only people that should take such decisions are our elected national governments, not unaccountable EU bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I am opposed to this text, which constitutes an interference in the social organisation of the Member States but also in the families themselves. There are certainly some good ideas, but it is a text that purports to profoundly change our societal models, without respecting the freedom of women and families in their life choices. Finally, the woman is seen only as an inferior equal of the man, requiring more special legislative attention. In addition, dangerous considerations on the freedom of movement of "migrants" are added to better guide this clearly globalist-inspired text.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report calling for the introduction of a framework to ensure the right to work-life balance as a fundamental objective of social systems. Like my colleagues, I believe that well-designed and well-implemented family-work life-life policies can help boost economic growth, overall labour market participation, gender equality, reducing the risk of poverty but also positively influencing birth rates in the EU (from 16.4% in 1970 to 10.1% in 2014). In particular, the report proposes that the Commission present a proposal on this package of measures as part of its 2017 work programme, including equality between men and women as a legal basis. These measures should include policies to support those most disadvantaged or currently excluded from the legislation (single-parent families, same-sex couples, self-employed, families with one member with a disability, etc.). In this report, MEPs believe in particular that the Commission and the Member States must ensure that there is a right to maternity and paternity leave as well as to leave for dependents.

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the report on the creation of labour market conditions to promote a work-life balance, as the report is an important issue for the PPE-DE and therefore cannot be rejected in itself, but unfortunately it also makes many demands that are incompatible with the principle of subsidiarity, such as a renewed call for the Commission to propose a maternity directive. Family law matters are still better resolved in the hands of the Member States. In addition, the report deals with issues that are not directly linked to the core theme of the report – the work/life balance of European workers – which unfortunately means that the report is losing its significance. Last but not least, the report equates new and flexible working models indiscriminately with precarious working conditions. Since modern, flexible working time models in particular often facilitate the reconciliation of work and family life, I cannot share this view.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE)
text: Written. I voted against this report today. My colleagues in the European Parliament's Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality have gone too far here. They are simply out of touch with reality.  At a time when we have major security policy problems and wavering support from European citizens for the European Union, we simply cannot defend this report. There will be a mix of people, where there are pure national competences, right down to family policy, for example, how many hours our children have to take to school, how EU countries should organise their social and tax policies, and how families should distribute their maternity leave.  Let us now live up to the expectations of our citizens and solve our great pan-European challenges, and then let the individual Member States and families take care of the close relationships. Otherwise, we risk seriously destroying the European project.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Work-life balance must be a guiding principle within the EU, especially at a time when it is facing a serious demographic challenge due to the continuing fall in birth rates in the Member States. The Ždanoka and Blinkevičiūtė report is an important step in a series of reflections on this issue, which is why I have decided to support it. The text reiterates the need for cultural change, which targets gender stereotypes and allows work and care activities to be allocated more fairly among men and women. We need global packages of legislative and political measures relating to reconciling professional, private and family life. The proposals from the social partners must be complemented by action by the Commission in the context of the announced European Pillar of Social Rights. We need relevant policies and measures that take into account the growing diversity of family relationships, such as civil unions and agreements between parents or grandparents, and redefine the global approach to the issue. Thinking about the balance between private, family and work life is an important element in creating economic and social growth with solid foundations.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although the report is not rooted in the causes of gender inequality in the workplace, I believe it has very positive aspects that should be implemented to improve personal, family and work life balance policies. That is why I voted abstention.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. Any policy that helps to promote true equality between men and women in working and private life in the Union must be supported and the many paragraphs in this report which highlight the deplorable situation in this area in many Member States make it clear that much remains to be done in this area. It is good that the rapporteurs denounce the gap that still exists between the remuneration of a woman and a man who do the same work. It is good that the rapporteurs warn us against the decline in the birth rate in Europe and address the demographic challenges that result. But let me nevertheless express some reservations against the paragraphs in which the rapporteurs attack the traditional model of the family. Nor do I see why a fiscal policy of austerity in times of economic crisis would by definition be detrimental to equality between men and women. Please avoid introducing ideological phraseology into a debate where reason and facts should be enough to change policy.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteurs for their work in this report, for which I voted and where my vote has distinguished from some of the indications in my group. It is essential to talk about the need for Semestro Europe to have a gender pillar, for parental leave to be shared equally between parents and for Member States to introduce social security into their legislation on equality, as well as equality in pensions. Workers should be able to have flexibility in their working hours in order to reconcile family life.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I have not been able to support this text, which is a vessel to implant ever more in the legislation the theory of gender.  Under the pretext of the difficulties faced by some women in order to both start a family and work, the relationship is in fact part of the "fight against stereotypes" which in reality aims at a genuine gender indifferentiation: men and women are interchangeable, simple economic data whose life choices should be shaped by European well-thinkers! Apparently, the priority would be to "guarantee mutual recognition of official documents for free movement". For European ideologues, making women detached workers will help them balance their family life and careers... There are also all the inconsistencies of the so-called defenders of women's rights since the text is concerned about the decline in the birth rate but does not advocate the establishment of a genuine birth policy. Finally, the "individualization of rights" and the removal of a common tax return, far from empowering women, will only make them precarious and destroy the family model.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that, while denouncing real problems and offering ideas that we can support, the report does not formulate concrete solutions or even recognise Europe's role in aggravating the current social emergency. With these initiatives, the EU is merely fuelling propaganda by publicly defending citizens' right to a healthy work-life balance, but instead forcing the Member States in practice to give up national agencies and other services.  In Italy, the cost of services replacing domestic work and childcare, in the absence of grandparents or other family members, is on average about 500 euros per month. If there is a lack of work to enable young people to create and maintain a family, if the supply of employment requires maximum flexibility on the part of the couple, but public services decrease so as not to increase expenditure bound by the EU's capeed pacts, what is the point of this initiative other than to fuel sterile rhetoric and an end in itself? For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that work-life balance is a fundamental right that has not yet been achieved in Europe, which is an obstacle to achieving real equality between men and women.  With this report we send a clear message to the Commission to update and complete European legislation. It must submit as soon as possible a revision of the maternity directive, an improvement in the parental leave directive and two new directives, one on paternity leave and one on the leave of carers.  It is also important to improve the provision of quality services at affordable prices for childcare and other dependents, so that women, who are the majority among caregivers, can participate in the labour market and qualify for full-time jobs, which allow them to generate a decent pension for the future.   It is also necessary to streamline working hours and introduce greater flexibility so that all workers can enjoy their private life, which is not only in the benefit of people, but also of companies because workers are more productive.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, first of all, we must also appreciate the rapid ageing of Europe. Facilitating reconciliation of work and private life would enable parents to pay more attention to their families and promote birth rates. It is often the case that if families, and especially if women fail to reconcile their professional activities with childcare, then women are hesitant to have more children or decide not to have them at all. It is therefore not surprising that many developed countries are currently experiencing the problem of a decline in the birth rate. It is therefore essential that a family-friendly environment is created in the workplace and that employers guarantee flexible working relationships for families with children and provide additional social guarantees. Care must also be created, and we must call on the Member States to implement the Barcelona objectives and to improve access to quality, accessible and affordable childcare services for all, namely the establishment and improvement of kindergartens, pre-school establishments, extracurricular activities, etc. It is also very important to encourage parents/men to take parental leave, which is what will help to achieve gender equality in the labour market and encourage women to be more active in professional activities. Thus, there is no one-size-fits-all solution to reconcile work, private and family life and we need to strike the right balance for every person to meet the professional, personal and family needs.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ A good work-life balance simultaneously boosts economic growth, competitiveness, overall labour market participation, gender equality, poverty risk reduction and intergenerational solidarity, and responds to the challenges of an ageing society and has a positive impact on EU birth rates.  As work, private and family life adjustment is recognised as a fundamental right, and although some initiatives have been launched at European and national level in this area, further progress needs to be made to ensure work-life balance.  This is very important, as stated in the report itself, not only for reasons of the well-being of the individual but also for society as a whole, because people who have a satisfactory work-life balance are more productive at work. In particular, the report also states the position of the child in the circumstances of a balanced work and private life.  With a thoughtful policy in this area, it allows the child to realize their full potential and provide high-quality preschool education, parental care, access to entertainment and cultural facilities and better quality time with parents. For these reasons and my support goes to this report at the session.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The key to greater involvement of women in the labour market is quality institutions that would make it easier for them to align their private obligations with their business obligations. Here I think first of all about quality childcare in kindergartens and nursegers.  Likewise, a better network of nursing facilities needs to be developed, as the burden of caring for older family members often falls on women. Another element that matters is the professional empowerment of women, through the fight against the gendered specificity of occupation and the "breaking" of the glass ceiling.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This text advocates gender equality in the face of work. While women are often discriminated against in the labour because of their motherhood, childcare, and child care, discrimination that must be combated without weakening, the fact remains that blindly pursuing the goal of strict equality between men and women is utopian. So I voted against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The reconciliation of professional, private and family life has been recognised as a fundamental right for decades. Some measures in this area have already been taken at European level (e.g. in support of women's work and the right to maternity) and by some Member States, but further progress needs to be made to ensure an adequate work-life balance for all: this balance benefits not only the individual in terms of personal well-being but also society as a whole; It has been shown that those who enjoy a good work-life balance are more productive at work and less likely to require public health service services for psychological or stress-related illnesses. To this end, it is necessary to transform the working environment beyond the notion that only time spent on (paid) work is of utility and value. It is important that a life-cycle approach is adopted as part of work-life balance policies, so that everyone can be supported at different times in their lives and can participate actively in the labour market and society as a whole.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to establish conditions in the labour market that promote work-life balance by combating discrimination against women with children. Although we share the idea that the decline in the birth rate stems from the lack of adequate income or fears related to professional development, we nevertheless consider that the Commission does not have to interfere in family choices and in the social models of the Member States. The aim of this report is indeed to make a cultural and societal transition, in particular through the European pillar of social rights. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The objective of the report and, in general, policies for balancing work and private life is not only to promote gender equality in the professional and other spheres of life, but also to give children the opportunity to develop their full potential by providing them with high-quality care and education in the early years, access to recreational activities , cultural and sporting activities, and time to spend with their parents. Appropriate policies to balance work and private life will also help to ensure a better quality of life and a high degree of safety for other dependents, in particular for the elderly and dependents suffering from disabilities or long-term illnesses. I supported this report by giving a favourable vote, considering that it is necessary to raise awareness of the role of work organisation and to promote good practices in creating labour market conditions conducive to work-life balance.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that work-life balance is a fundamental right that has not yet been achieved in Europe, which is an obstacle to achieving real equality between men and women.  With this report we send a clear message to the Commission to update and complete European legislation. It must submit as soon as possible a revision of the maternity directive, an improvement in the parental leave directive and two new directives, one on paternity leave and one on the leave of carers.  It is also important to improve the provision of quality services at affordable prices for childcare and other dependents, so that women, who are the majority among caregivers, can participate in the labour market and qualify for full-time jobs, which allow them to generate a decent pension for the future.   It is also necessary to streamline working hours and introduce greater flexibility so that all workers can enjoy their private life, which is not only in the benefit of people, but also of companies because workers are more productive.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. It is important to properly and fairly balance work and family life in order to provide the child with the best conditions to begin growing. This report highlights all kinds of issues related to the role of parents. We must ensure that both parents are equal in their children's education. Indeed, it is still often women who put their careers aside to take care of their children. Parental leave provides an opportunity for both the mother and the father to care for the child when the other parent is working. While respecting the principle of subsidiarity, we must ensure that equality between men and women in parenting in the European Union is respected. I voted in favour of this initiative report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, for which I voted in favour, focuses on the causes that prevent the achievement of a balance between the family and professional life of individuals and proposes a modernisation of the European legislative framework. The analysis carried out focuses, first and all, on the demographic changes in society, which create greater need for care, and on the emergence of new ways of working. It also highlights the still markedly negative impact of parenting on female employment rates and the inadequacy of the current EU framework to address this very important aspect of continuing gender inequality. The creation of conditions conducive to work-life balance and the achievement of a good quality of life are only possible if people have enough time outside their work to devote to their personal development. The report therefore calls on the Commission to take more action against Member States that do not properly implement the Working Time Directive and encourages Member States to introduce measures to support educational or training leave and professional interruptions.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this own-initiative report prepared jointly by EMPL and FEMM, which calls for the Commission and Member States to implement measures such as ensuring affordable childcare, and paid leave including maternity, paternity, parental and carers’ leave in order to address the exclusion of women from the labour force due to caring responsibilities. On the issue of non-transferability of parental leave, Sinn Féin’s position is in favour of non-transferability (i.e. it can’t be transferred from the father to the mother) as it is proven to benefit the position of women in the workforce.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Work-life balance is an important element that needs to be addressed in order to address gender stereotypes and raise awareness on equal treatment in respect to work-life balance. I can concur with the ideas presented in the report, but on the other hand, I believe that we need to be careful not to trample over the subsidiary principle, whereabouts certain matters fall squarely within Member States’ competence.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report aims to increase women's participation in the labour market. In particular, the Commission is asked for a revision of the Maternity Leave Directive, an extension of the minimum period of parental leave with an adequate substitute income and social protection, from four to at least six months, a directive on paternity leave providing for a minimum of two weeks of fully paid compulsory leave, a directive on leave for carers which supplements the provision of professional assistance , allows workers to take care of dependents and offers carers adequate pay and social protection and, finally, supports the development of so-called 'smart-working', i.e. an approach to work organisation based on a combination of flexibility, autonomy and collaboration, which does not necessarily require the worker to be present in the workplace or in another predetermined place and allows him to manage his working hours , while ensuring compliance with the maximum limit of daily and weekly working hours established by law. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although I actively support measures to increase the number of women actively participating in the labour market, I did not support this report. They do not consider it appropriate that we should take directives at EU level on the issue of compulsory paternity leave or the harmonisation of maternity or parental leave conditions. EU Member States and their citizens should be left with a choice. As one of the current problems is the continuously decreasing birth rate in EU countries, we should primarily look for solutions that support women on maternity leave and women with children so that they are not discriminated against when they return to the labour market or in the course of their professional careers.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are still many disparities that exist in the world of work: among the most common are the wage difference between men and women or the lack of a fair sharing of responsibilities. There is a need to adapt working conditions to the new requirements dictated by changes and changes in society which inevitably have a reflection on the labour market. I am thinking, for example, of the ageing of the population, which requires most of the care and care provided by women. Gender inequality has weakened women's position in terms of employment, pay and career advancement. The solution must be sought in new legislative instruments. That is why we have asked the Commission to prepare new directives on paternity leave which provide for compulsory and non-transferable minimum paid leave for fathers and a new proposal on leave for carers so that it is not only women who do not take family leave. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D)
text: Written. The Social Democrats in the European Parliament want to update EU legislation to improve work-life balance. We support initiatives that improve equality between men and women, strengthen fathers' right to leave and increase women's participation in the labour market. That is why we have chosen to vote in favour of the report as a whole.  However, this should not be interpreted as support for all the individual initiatives mentioned in the report. In general, the Danish Social Democrats want a greater focus on father's rights, as this is essential for achieving a more equal distribution of leave between parents. Some of the proposals in the report, in the case of legislation, could be counterproductive to this objective. At the same time, there are certain areas where denmark has a tradition of agreements being concluded between the social partners and where we do not want legislation at EU level. Since this is not legislation, but merely an own-initiative report, we have chosen to support the overall message of ensuring more equality and better gender balance through improved rules, in close cooperation with the social partners and taking into account the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and agree with the rapporteurs' position that the need to modernise work-life balance at EU level is obvious for a number of reasons: society has become aware of demographic changes by encouraging more care needs, new ways of working have emerged, unemployment is still at unprecedented high levels, the diversity of family relationships and child-rearing arrangements has increased , motherhood continues to have a strikingly negative impact on women's employment rates and the current EU framework is proving insufficient to address this most important aspect of persistent gender inequalities.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the creation of labour market conditions conducive to a balance between work and personal life has obvious and important references to the everyday life of European citizens. Ensuring a healthier and more effective approach to citizens' lives must be our objective and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it takes into account the need to protect the core of human society, the family. In particular, I welcome the positive result achieved in the area of equal opportunities. Indeed, this report provides a clear legislative framework that promotes women's participation in the labour market, not only through the call to eliminate gender inequalities, but also through the protection of parental leave. Furthermore, given the current socio-economic challenges, I believe that promoting the concept of 'agile work' will facilitate work-life balance. The introduction of the possibility of working from home and flexible hours will give workers with dependent children the opportunity to better manage their commitments.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on Work-Life Balance and also supported the inclusion of all references concerning rights for the LGBTI community and same-sex couples.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The work-life balance is now an undisputed right in modern societies, contributing to personal well-being and benefiting society at large through an increase in productivity and the desired birth rate. I support this Report, as It considers that progress is still needed in this area, encouraging both the European institutions and the Member States to adopt these concerns across the board in their policies, with particular attention to gender, age, household nature and new social realities, defending those most disadvantaged or even excluded from existing legislation and policies. Discrimination in the professional environment must be tackled, the issue of parental leave should be regulated fairly, stress must be tackled in the management of professional and personal life, to support women in their emancipation in working life, to recognise the work done by people who devote their time to caring to third parties and to recognise the role of professionally active grandparents. A just and humanist society is not commendable by the parcelling and charitable treatment of a recognized fundamental right of work-life, personal and family balance.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report to ensure that the best interests of the child are fully taken into account in the implementation of policies for balancing the working and family life of parents. Let us not forget that there is still an underestimation of women's work and that many employers view motherhood as a negative discriminating factor. There is therefore a need for effective formulation of public and private support policies for children and parents, so that they are able to assume and share their educational and care responsibilities. I very much hope that the Commission will present an ambitious new draft directive on maternity leave, not only to ensure the right balance between social and working life, but also to support families and combat inequalities, while protecting pregnant women and new working mothers.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – It is high time to step up protection against discrimination and unlawful dismissal related to work-life balance, which particularly affect female workers. As the report states, we need to ensure that women are paid and covered by social protection for the duration of maternity leave in order to support families and combat inequalities, strengthen women’s social and economic independence and avoid them being financially penalised for having children. Women are increasingly well-qualified, even outperforming men in terms of educational attainment and yet they continue to be under-represented in the labour market, or employed in jobs below their skill level. Overall low pay, a higher concentration in part-time work and greater interruptions in careers due to caring for others (children and/or dependent relatives) contribute to a greater risk of poverty and social exclusion for women as well as a large gender pension gap.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: Written. "We need to improve work-life balance in the EU and give women and men the same opportunities to combine career and family life. However, it is up to the Member States to develop systems and conditions that make this possible, in particular leave for working parents. I could not support the report because it calls on the Commission to propose maternity leave, paternity leave and leave for carers at EUROPEAN level. In addition to this, the report proposes that we should decide at European level on certain types of tax, minimum wages and social security systems, all of which are to be decided nationally. We should raise awareness, exchange best practices and encourage Member States to pursue a modern gender equality policy whereby women are not regarded as the only parent responsible for the care of children. We must focus on combating discrimination and stereotypes against women and girls both inside and outside the workplace. We still have a long way to go, but it is not by introducing family and labour market policies from Brussels that we will achieve equality in Europe.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this joint report by the Committee on Women and Gender Equality and the Committee on Employment as it recognises that the increasing deregulation of labour and social rights in the Union and austerity policies have a terrible impact on the reconciliation of private and professional life for women. To avoid this inequality, the report is committed to enhancing collective agreements that facilitate the reconciliation of private, professional and family life. It also bets on parental leave that is appropriately remunerated and for both parents to facilitate this reconciliation. Since it also points out the importance of promoting public social services for child care and care at European level, I have supported this text.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The importance of reconciling work, private and family life is aimed at promoting a balance between different aspects of people's lives. In this respect, we need cross-cutting, structural and coherent policies that include incentives and efficient measures to promote reconciliation of work, the possibility of spending family time, leisure and personal development. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the Commission and the Member States must adopt policies that improve the working environment, create good working conditions and social and professional well-being and at the same time a good work-life balance. In this respect, we need policies that also take into account the well-being and best interests of children and the improvement of women's access to the labour market and the fair distribution of domestic and care responsibilities between women and men.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In recent decades the balancing of work and private and family life has been recognized as a fundamental right. Women have become increasingly well qualified, even surpassing men in terms of education, but are also still underrepresented in the labour market or are employed to perform work below their level of qualification. It is estimated that differences in employment between men and women are reportedly resulting in losses of around EUR 370 billion per year, or 2.8% of GDP at EU level, at EU level. During the recent crisis, poverty levels have reached alarming levels. This has led to more intensive and lengthy work in order to have a decent income. Women have suffered even more because they generally earn less than men for identical work. I voted for the creation of conditions that foster the balance of work and private life. Both the modernisation of current EU legislation is needed to address shortcomings or omissions in certain areas and to improve coordination between Member States in order to ensure a level playing field in terms of the costs and benefits of balancing policies.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the report, even though I know how important it is to maintain a work-life balance. However, most of the calls for action in the report violate the principle of subsidiarity. The 2008 Maternity Leave Directive has been a failure, and I do not think that this is the case here. I believe that it should be up to every family to find this balance, and this should not be regulated by law, as the report seems to suggest.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that in order to adequately address work-life balance and avoid unintended negative consequences on women or men, the gender perspective has to be mainstreamed in order to address discrimination and gender stereotypes and thus ensure equal opportunities to both women and men. Furthermore, I believe that single parents and LGBTI couples, parents from minorities, parents with disabilities and other families should not be discriminated against based on the fact that they are non-conventional. I believe that all families should be celebrated in all shapes and forms and this is adequately addressed in this report which promotes more pragmatic solutions to work-life balance, which is an essential element of family life.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. Although it contains many positive recommendations within it which I am in full agreement with, on incentives and other help for women and men to combine their work and private lives, it is almost entirely concerned with policies that are the responsibility of national governments. The starting point for any proposed regulation in Brussels should always be to ask: does this need to be done at a European level? If the answer is no, we should not support it.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the fall in the birth rate in the European Union has been exacerbated by the crisis, given that unemployment, precarious employment opportunities, uncertainty about the future, and discrimination in the labour market are driving women, especially young specialists, to postpone motherhood.  In this respect, I believe that the Member States must promote innovative mechanisms for the organisation of working time, conciliation plans, programmes aimed at returning to work, channels of communication between workers and the workplace and incentives for businesses and self-employed workers.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on reconciling the working life of European citizens with the private life of European citizens. The rapporteurs propose new ways to modernise this balance and call on the Commission to present legislative and non-legislative initiatives, as well as a revised proposal for a directive on maternity leave and a directive on paternity leave. Considering that the report is balanced, I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-binding and non-legislative report. Although there were some very sensitive issues regarding equality, discrimination and helping disadvantaged people, the report went on to call for more EU action and legislation. It included calls for the reversal in the burden of proof in legal situations which would end the presumption of innocence and irrevocably alter UK criminal law. The report called for the EU to monitor national legislation, it tried to say when schools should close, and wanted changes to national taxation and social security. The only people that should take such decisions are our elected national governments, not unaccountable EU bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This text, with no binding legislative value, on the establishment of conditions on the labour market promoting work-life balance calls on the European Commission and the Member States of the European Union to take the necessary measures to ensure that working life is adapted to the constraints of personal and family life. I voted in favour of this text because no one should have to choose between a career or a family life. We must thereby strengthen the legal frameworks in place to address gender inequality and ensure equal and equal access to the labour market between men and women. However, I regret that these non-binding texts all too often contain provisions, which I have rejected, overstepping the competences of the European Union and undermining the principle of subsidiarity in Europe.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to put in place legal and political initiatives in the labour market to promote work-life balance. I believe that this conciliation is fundamental and must be defended at European level. It proposes concrete measures, such as ensuring equal income and job opportunities, the importance of quality, affordable and accessible care services for children, and more flexible working conditions that would allow parents to be available for their children.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as I believe it is important to support families in their professional and private lives as well as the fair participation of men and women in the labour market. I have always fought for equal opportunities in professional salaries and promotions accompanied by the possibility of leading a fulfilling private life.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The general idea of this text is based on the desire to reconcile both private and professional life as well as to combat discrimination through legislative and non-legislative measures, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity. It advocates making this conciliation a fundamental right; similarly, gender equality should be a legal basis and the pay gap a violation of the fundamental principle of equal pay. In addition, this text aims to reconcile the two objectives of encouraging the birth rate and professionalisation of women. Also, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Working families face new challenges in work-life balance. This report provides proposals for the Commission to consider in modernising and adapting the current EU legal and policy framework in the field of childcare and maternity.  Me and my political group strongly support the family and its values and I believe there should be freedom in finding a balance between family and working life. However, many of the things proposed in the report are contrary to the principle of subsidiarity, and some paragraphs suggest that even more men should stay at home in order to stimulate women in working life, which is not an EU job first and secondly is a personal choice that cannot be placed within a legal framework. That's why I abstained.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
