text: Writing. \u2012 My vision for family and the organisation of society is completely different from that of the European Union, my principles and my values differ radically and there is no point of contact.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. •u2012 Appropriately designed and implemented conciliation policies should be seen as a fundamental improvement in the working environment, which allow good working conditions and the social and professional well-being of workers. In this context, Parliament believes that well-designed and well-implemented conciliation policies could greatly promote economic growth, competitiveness, global labour market participation, gender equality, poverty risk reduction, and positively influence birth rates in the Union. Parliament therefore calls for the introduction of a framework to guarantee this right as a fundamental objective of social systems and calls on the Union and the Member States to promote, both in the public and private sectors, respect for the right to a work and a balanced life.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted against this resolution because, regardless of the fact that these are key issues that are of immense importance to me at national level, it is a typical example of policies that should be taken as closely as possible to the parties involved.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Women are increasingly qualified, even surpassing men in terms of academic qualifications, although they remain under-represented in the labour market or working in jobs that are below their level of competence. On the other hand, widespread low wages, increased concentration on part-time work and longer career interruptions due to care for others (children and/or dependent family members) contribute to a higher risk of poverty and social exclusion of women, as well as a large disparity (40 %) between men and women with regard to pensions. I therefore agree with the need to modernise the framework for work-life balance at Union level.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: text not in line with the objective.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The increasing deregulation of organisation and working relationships, an integral part of neoliberal policies and, especially, so-called austerity policies (the latter being a concentrated expression of the former), has a strongly disruptive effect on the work-life balance and private and family life. This balance is a fundamental right and is related to a number of issues, be it the above-mentioned labour regulation, gender equality, active ageing or parental rights. The report proposes measures that we can support. Examples, among others, are the criticism of the prospect that more and more working hours are beneficial to the economy in terms of increasing productivity, or even criticism of the effects of "austerity" policies, or the reference to collective bargaining and important positions agreed within the ILO. However, this report is fully framed in EU policies and its neoliberal orientation. See the reference to the need for flexibility in working relationships and working time, or to the promotion of "smart jobs" and teleworking, as a way to promote a better work-life balance. This is an approach that is essential and which we do not follow, because it does not help to solve the problem, but on the contrary.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ The reconciliation of work, private and family life is finally recognised as a fundamental right, although it remains an area where we need further progress ensuring a work-life balance for all. In order to achieve this objective, it will be necessary to change the working environment and integrate a lifelong approach into policies to achieve work-life balance, so that every single person has support at each time of their life and can actively participate in the labour market. Society is undergoing demographic change, new ways of organizing work are emerging, we still have high unemployment, and the diversity of family relationships and forms of parenting is also increasing, which unfortunately still has a negative impact on women's employment rates. We therefore need the European Commission to come forward as soon as possible with proposals for directives on maternity leave, on paternity leave, on the implementation of the Directive on parental leave, and for it to propose a directive on carers' leave.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining because, while denouncing real problems and offering ideas that we can support, the report does not formulate concrete solutions.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the creation of labour market conditions that favour a balance between work and personal life.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report responds to the European Commission’s Roadmap on work-life balance and proposes various initiatives to modernise the existing EU legislation (revision of the Maternity Leave Directive, improving parental leave) and to adopt new EU directives on paternity leave and carers’ leave. It also proposes to enhance exchange of best practices regarding flexible working time arrangements, and tools to increase labour market participation of female and male workers with dependants. I believe it is time to assess our demographic and socioeconomic challenges and adopt a package of legislative and non-legislative policies to promote work life balance to ensure workers enter, remain and return to the labour market, and can reconcile professional, private and family life. I voted in favour of the report, as through it, the EP sends a strong message before the Commission presents its new proposal by the end of the year.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I am well aware of the need to continue working to improve working conditions in the labour market in order to promote better reconciliation of private and professional life, so I voted in favour of the report. We have a long way to go in this field, and it is of great importance that we take determined steps in this direction that ultimately benefit the whole of society. The aim of this initiative is to increase women's participation in the labour market by modernising and adapting the current legal and political framework of the Union to the current labour market to enable parents with children or other dependent relatives to improve the balance between their family and work life, to enable a more equitable sharing of family responsibilities between men and women , and strengthen gender equality in the labour market.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that work-life balance is a fundamental right that has not yet been achieved in Europe, which is an obstacle to achieving real equality between men and women.  With this report we send a clear message to the Commission to update and complete European legislation. It must submit as soon as possible a revision of the maternity directive, an improvement in the parental leave directive and two new directives, one on paternity leave and one on the leave of carers.  It is also important to improve the provision of quality services at affordable prices for childcare and other dependents, so that women, who are the majority among caregivers, can participate in the labour market and qualify for full-time jobs, which allow them to generate a decent pension for the future.   It is also necessary to streamline working hours and introduce greater flexibility so that all workers can enjoy their private life, which is not only in the benefit of people, but also of companies because workers are more productive.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I think that this is a very important report that highlight the significant challenges that Europe is facing in terms of its demographic future. To counter this, it is of crucial importance that the EU does what it can to promote a more family friendly approach to work. This is in order to give all of our citizens the possibility of have children without being penalised. A better work-life balance is also key in promoting the participation of women in the labour market. Another point is that general well-being is an important factor in overall economic productivity in a modern society.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The message we have given today with the adoption of this text is that of a solid commitment by the EU Parliament to the protection of human rights and freedoms.  Europe must use all the means at its power to ensure that there are no more threats of discrimination of all kinds in the labour market.  The global crisis we are facing already makes the situation undaunted, and the risk of poverty and social exclusion is too great: it is up to us to invest in measures that offer adequate social protection to workers, families, children and the most vulnerable groups.  For this reason, I think it is extremely important to stress the urgent need to adopt strengthened instruments for reconciling private and working life, social and health care for children's right to well-being and combating poverty, for a Europe that makes social policies the first pillar of our commitment in Parliament.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the creation of labour market conditions conducive to work-life balance, for which I was shadow rapporteur for the S-D Group in the EMPL Committee, because it was necessary to give a convincing and broad response to the proposal for a roadmap drawn up by the Commission on reconciling work and private life and on the various proposals for initiatives aimed at modernising the legislation in force on the revision of the Directive on maternity leave by improving parental leave, and the adoption of new directives on paternity and care leave. During the drafting of the report, we were concerned to highlight certain good practices concerning agreements on the flexibility of working time, as useful tools for increasing the participation of women caring for family members in the world of work. The unprecedented demographic challenges facing the EU, job insecurity and the difficulty of working conditions with a negative impact on work-life reconciliation require precise responses from the EU and I hope for a very quick and targeted reaction in each of the areas we have addressed and finally adopted with the resolution.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. You will be surprised: how can the Member of the European Parliament abstain from the Family Party when it comes to the report on the creation of labour market conditions to promote a work-life balance? Well, that is quite simple: firstly, because not every political initiative that benefits parents has to be decided at European level – for example, when it comes to the proportion of fathers' months. That is entirely in national competence, and that is a good thing. Secondly, because the approach of a majority of this House to reintegrate mothers and fathers into the labour market as quickly as possible and to organise state childcare does not correspond to my ideal image of freedom of choice. All my objections have been ignored by colleagues from the Left, the Liberals and the Greens. That is why I have abstained.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. It is my firm conviction, as a Christian Democrat, that families need to be strengthened. An important aspect is the reconciliation of work and family life. This must not be at the expense of families. I therefore support the rapporteurs' proposal. However, the principle of subsidiarity, as the cornerstone of the European Union, should continue to be applied in this respect.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs fully support measures to promote a greater work-life balance. We will not meet the demographic challenges we face – including the need to care for an ageing population – unless we modernise existing leave arrangements. Fathers taking time out of work to care for children must be supported by the right to paternity leave. We also support greater rights for carers, more extensive maternity leave rights and better implementation of existing legislation. These changes will bring benefits to the economy as a whole, and ensure that women and men are equal earners and carers.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. Who does not dream of being able to reconcile private and professional life, without one harming the other? It is wrongly thought that facilitating this conciliation is intended to promote the family and the birth rate. This report is in fact a response to a commission consultation with a view to increasing women's participation in the labour market by all means - regardless of the views of those concerned for that matter - and underpinned by the desire for absolute egalitarianism between men and women, which sometimes leads to absurd measures. For example, parental leave in France, which is governed by the principles you defend - the individualisation of rights - and which prevents new parents from organising themselves as they wish or face financial penalties. It is true that there are still many things to do to make life easier for those who work. We must therefore start with the re-examination of economic policies, budgetary austerity, unfair competition, the race for competitiveness that demand ever more availability of employees or 'uberate' them. Otherwise the rights they are promised will be nothing but wind.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs fully support measures to promote greater work-life balance. We will not meet the demographic challenges we face – including the need to care for an ageing population – unless we modernise existing leave arrangements. Fathers taking time out of work to care for children must be supported by the right to paternity leave. We also support greater rights for carers, more extensive maternity leave rights and better implementation of existing legislation. These changes will bring benefits to the economy as a whole, and ensure that women and men are equal earners and carers.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. The work-life balance represents a fundamental right for socialists and democrats, who are campaigning for a European social rights base.  I also voted in favour of this initiative report which puts forward concrete legislative proposals, such as extending the duration of parental leave to 6 months, a directive for paternity leave of at least two weeks fully paid for fathers and a directive on dependent leave to supplement the provision of professional care and allowing workers to care for dependents while providing the caregiver with adequate remuneration and social protection. , or the introduction of care credits so that periods of work stoppage to deal informally and unpaid with a dependent person are counted as periods of work for the constitution of their pension rights.  Finally, the initiative report reiterates the need for a 'child guarantee' allowing every child access to free health care, free schooling, free childcare, decent housing, adequate food, as part of an integrated European plan to combat child poverty.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. I welcome the initiative, the need to modernise work-life balance framework at the EU level is obvious for several main reasons: society has seen demographic changes spurring more care needs, new ways of working have emerged, unemployment is still at unprecedented high levels, the diversity of family relationships and parenting arrangements has increased, parenthood still has strikingly negative effects on the employment rates of women and the current EU framework is falling very short of addressing this most important aspect of persisting gender inequality.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson Jens Nilsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: Written. Today we Swedish Social Democrats voted in favour of the report establishing favourable labour market conditions for work-life balance. The report is good in its overall view of a Europe in which the labour market has been modernised and become increasingly digital.  While we see opportunities, we also believe that care is needed for a modernised labour market, so that we do not reproduce destructive gender roles through, for example, atypical forms of employment in which women are currently over-represented.  That is why we voted against points that we believe would cement traditional gender roles. We voted against wordings advocating that parts of parental leave should be transferable. Since very few men take their parental leave, we believe that instead a strengthening of parental leave is needed in order to get more men to take advantage of this opportunity.  We also chose to abstain in the vote on the item that raised 'care points' for the care of relatives. Reducing the gender-based pension gap and guaranteeing decent pensions requires other types of measures, such as increased employment and the incorporation of the equal pay principle, which would reduce the pay gap. In addition to the wording, we believe that the report contains several concrete wordings. In its holistic approach, the report contains well-founded proposals on combating child poverty, securing forms of employment and increasing gender equality, all of which are moving in the right direction.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that work-life balance is a fundamental right that has not yet been achieved in Europe, which is an obstacle to achieving real equality between men and women.  With this report we send a clear message to the Commission to update and complete European legislation. It must submit as soon as possible a revision of the maternity directive, an improvement in the parental leave directive and two new directives, one on paternity leave and one on the leave of carers.  It is also important to improve the provision of quality services at affordable prices for childcare and other dependents, so that women, who are the majority among caregivers, can participate in the labour market and qualify for full-time jobs, which allow them to generate a decent pension for the future.   It is also necessary to streamline working hours and introduce greater flexibility so that all workers can enjoy their private life, which is not only in the benefit of people, but also of companies because workers are more productive.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – We voted in favour of the report because it criticises austerity measures and the increase in working hours and also recognises the existence of precarious forms of work in the EU.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on creating labour market conditions favourable for work-life balance which is Parliament’s response to the Commission’s withdrawal of the Maternity Leave Directive and its replacement following the publication of the Roadmap to address challenges in work/life balance for working families. In a world where the line between work and private life is increasingly blurred it is important workers and their families achieve a satisfactory balance. I fully agree it is crucial to have a lifecycle approach in work-life balance policies to ensure everyone is supported at different moments throughout their life in order to actively participate in the labour market and in society as a whole. That’s why I particularly welcome the call for a Paternity Leave Directive with compulsory two—week paid leave and a Carers’ Leave Directive which supplements the provision of professional care, enables workers to care for dependants and offers the carer adequate remuneration and social protection. This is crucial given that 80% of care needs are provided by informal carers in the EU and 3.3 million Europeans aged between 15 and 34 have had to give up full-time work because they lack care facilities for dependent children or older relatives.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The work-life balance report is not acceptable. It interferes far too much with the interests of the Member States and, in particular, of families. He tries to regulate how and when women should be returned to work after pregnancy and men are forced into a domestic role. The principle of subsidiarity is being trampled underfoot here. The interests of families should be decided by the families themselves, and certainly not in the EU. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to discord and strife in Europe.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: Written. "We need to improve work-life balance in the EU and give women and men the same opportunities to combine career and family life. However, it is up to the Member States to develop systems and conditions that make this possible, in particular leave for working parents. I could not support the report because it calls on the Commission to propose maternity leave, paternity leave and leave for carers at European level. In addition to this, the report proposes that we should decide at European level on certain types of tax, minimum wages and social security systems, all of which are to be decided nationally.  We should raise awareness, exchange best practices and encourage Member States to pursue a modern gender equality policy whereby women are not regarded as the only parent responsible for the care of children. We must focus on combating discrimination and stereotypes against women and girls both inside and outside the workplace. We still have a long way to go, but it is not by introducing family and labour market policies from Brussels that we will achieve equality in Europe.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Mr President, I support the report on creating labour market conditions conducive to work-life balance. Equality between men and women is a fundamental principle enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which must be guaranteed in all areas, including as regards the achievement of work-life balance. Well-designed and implemented policies to achieve this balance must be seen as a substantial improvement in the working environment, as they contribute to good working conditions and social and professional well-being. I believe that a good work-life balance is an incentive for economic growth, competitiveness, overall labour market participation, gender equality, reducing the risk of poverty and solidarity between generations.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Europe faces demographic and socio-economic challenges and should promote work life balance to ensure workers enter, remain and return to the labour market. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Labour Market Report to strike a work-life balance, as I support the idea of actively setting European legislation on this issue as well. Social and working conditions are changing rapidly, resulting in consequences for the way and quality of life.  The harmonization of private and work life is an issue that we face on a daily basis that affects the status of families, birthrates, quality of work and competitiveness of companies, general satisfaction, manner of education and conditions of education, social and economic status and many other facts that define the business and private environment and affect the current quality of life as well as in the near future.  I agree with the fact that the alignment of work, private and family life should be guaranteed as a fundamental right for all people. A framework is needed to ensure this right within the social systems of the EU and the Member States. Models that achieve a work-life balance should be promoted and all EU activities affecting this issue should be included.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The general idea of this text is the desire to best reconcile private and professional life and to combat discrimination through legislative and non-legislative measures, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity. In practical terms, it is a question of organising society and the world of work so that women can participate in the labour market, just like men, and that the same professional environment allows them the freedom to procreate without hindrance. More broadly, the aim is to combat persistent gender inequality, particularly in the area of employment. It is therefore above all a denial of sexual social functions in favour of undifferentiated human beings. I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Tatjana Zdanoka's report on the establishment of working-life balance conditions in the labour market. This initiative seeks to promote gender equality in the labour market by modernising and adapting the European legal framework. Today, this fight has not come to an end and my vote is also a way of calling on the European Commission to intensify its work in this area.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the 'danoka-Blinkevi'iut' report on the establishment of working-life balance conditions in the labour market. This report follows the European Commission's commitments to implement a number of initiatives in this area by the end of 2016.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The objective of this report and policies to balance work and personal life is not, in general, only to promote gender equality in employment and other areas of life, but aims to enable children to develop their full potential by providing them with high quality early childhood education and care, access to recreational, cultural and sports activities and time with their parents. The right political balance between work and personal life will also help to ensure a higher quality of life and safety for other dependents, especially elderly dependents, as well as dependents with disabilities or people suffering from long-term illnesses. I support this initiative.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The society of the European Union is an ageing society. Fertility has seen a marked decline in fertility in recent decades, so the drive to improve labour market conditions is very important. The measures taken should focus primarily on ensuring better conditions of access to the labour market for women: creating the conditions for returning to work after the birth of a child and preventing gender discrimination when applying for posts. Furthermore, we should facilitate access to parental leave among fathers. An important problem is the current pay gap in the same positions, which means that it is mothers who take leave to look after their children. We must also not forget single mothers who often work above the norm to ensure decent conditions for their children. Conditions must be created in which they will have the opportunity to reconcile work and the obligation to raise a child. To this end, we must strive to improve care services and make them more accessible. Balancing work-life balance will contribute not only to an increase in birth rates, but also to economic growth, greater gender equality and a reduction in the risk of poverty.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am opposed to this report. An attempt is being made to intervene in the family and social policies of the Member States under the guise of labour market policy by promoting a new social model.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted in favour of the report on creating labour market conditions that are favourable to work-life balance. I believe that this is an initiative that would improve the way of life of the citizens of the European Union and balance working life with the private, given the intense rhythm of work today. Efforts should also be made to limit existing discrimination in the labour market in the EU so that everyone has the same right to a position of employment and that, during negotiations or selection, the competences of workers and their relevance to a particular position are taken into account. On the other hand, I voted against the paragraph mentioning the introduction of minimum wage schemes. I believe that this is once again an interference with the tax policies of the Member States, which is a strong competence of the Member States in the European Union.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs fully support measures to promote greater work-life balance. We will not meet the demographic challenges we face unless we modernise existing leave arrangements. Fathers taking time out of work to care for children must be supported by the right to paternity leave. We also support greater rights for carers, more extensive maternity leave rights and better implementation of existing legislation. These changes will bring benefits to the economy as a whole, and ensure that women and men are equal earners and carers.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: Written. The Social Democrats in the European Parliament want to update EU legislation to improve work-life balance. We support initiatives that improve equality between men and women, strengthen fathers' right to leave and increase women's participation in the labour market. That is why we have chosen to vote in favour of the report as a whole. However, this should not be interpreted as support for all the individual initiatives mentioned in the report. In general, the Danish Social Democrats want a greater focus on father's rights, as this is essential for achieving a more equal distribution of leave between parents. Some of the proposals in the report, in the case of legislation, could be counterproductive to this objective. At the same time, there are certain areas where denmark has a tradition of agreements being concluded between the social partners and where we do not want legislation at EU level. Since this is not legislation, but merely an own-initiative report, we have chosen to support the overall message of ensuring more equality and better gender balance through improved rules, in close cooperation with the social partners and taking into account the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report on the reconciliation of work and family life is not acceptable. It interferes far too much with the interests of the Member States and, in particular, of families. He tries to regulate how and when women should be returned to work after pregnancy and men are forced into a domestic role. The principle of subsidiarity is being trampled underfoot here. The interests of families should be decided primarily by the families themselves and not by MEANS of EU rules.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the report on the creation of labour market conditions to promote a work-life balance, as the report is an important issue for the PPE-DE and therefore cannot be rejected in itself, but unfortunately it also makes many demands that are incompatible with the principle of subsidiarity, such as a renewed call for the Commission to propose a maternity directive. Family law matters are still better resolved in the hands of the Member States. In addition, the report deals with issues that are not directly linked to the core theme of the report – the work/life balance of European workers – which unfortunately means that the report is losing its significance. Last but not least, the report equates new and flexible working models indiscriminately with precarious working conditions. Since modern, flexible working time models in particular often facilitate the reconciliation of work and family life, I cannot share this view.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the report on the creation of labour market conditions conducive to work-life balance. The aim of the report is to make the EU's political and legal framework more modern and more appropriate to the labour market and highlights a number of issues that should be reviewed, both legislatively and non-legislatively. Among the various points, equality of opportunity between men and women is clearly central. Modernising these policies would enable families to create a balance between family and professional life, ensuring that family responsibilities are shared fairly. The report also aims to develop children's potential, and therefore to provide quality, affordable and accessible childcare services, and the importance of spending more time in the presence of parents. These initiatives, which I support, aim to ensure a better quality of life and greater safety for all those close to us.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because the EU is interfering in the social organisation of the Member States and in family relations themselves, in particular by wanting to reform parental leave.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report urges the Commission to meet its commitments to establish conditions that promote work-life balance. Too often, women are disadvantaged because of their disproportionately burdened work in the home. Creating the conditions for reconciling work and family responsibilities will help to address many of the inequalities women face in the labour market. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for measures to reconcile family and work life. In particular, it proposes to ensure equal income and employment opportunities by gender. The text also stresses the need for quality, affordable and accessible care services for children. In addition, the report highlights the need for some flexibility in working conditions for men and women who must be available for their children's education.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. Interference is a key word in the European Union. In this case, this report interferes in the social organisation of the Member States, and even in families. That is simply unacceptable.  More generally, and despite some interesting ideas, this text seems to want to upset our models of society and work. He thus attacks women and their freedom, making them an "equal-inferior" being of man, subject to the diktat of legislative demands. The icing on the cake is freedom of movement, migrants and the confused Goals 2020 are added to this issue. I voted strongly against it.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that work-life balance is a fundamental right that has not yet been achieved in Europe, which is an obstacle to achieving real equality between men and women.  With this report we send a clear message to the Commission to update and complete European legislation. It must submit as soon as possible a revision of the maternity directive, an improvement in the parental leave directive and two new directives, one on paternity leave and one on the leave of carers.  It is also important to improve the provision of quality services at affordable prices for childcare and other dependents, so that women, who are the majority among caregivers, can participate in the labour market and qualify for full-time jobs, which allow them to generate a decent pension for the future.   It is also necessary to streamline working hours and introduce greater flexibility so that all workers can enjoy their private life, which is not only in the benefit of people, but also of companies because workers are more productive.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that work-life balance is a fundamental right that has not yet been achieved in Europe, which is an obstacle to achieving real equality between men and women.  With this report we send a clear message to the Commission to update and complete European legislation. It must submit as soon as possible a revision of the maternity directive, an improvement in the parental leave directive and two new directives, one on paternity leave and one on the leave of carers.  It is also important to improve the provision of quality services at affordable prices for childcare and other dependents, so that women, who are the majority among caregivers, can participate in the labour market and qualify for full-time jobs, which allow them to generate a decent pension for the future.   It is also necessary to streamline working hours and introduce greater flexibility so that all workers can enjoy their private life, which is not only in the benefit of people, but also of companies because workers are more productive.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this joint report by the Committee on Women and Gender Equality and the Committee on Employment as it recognises that the increasing deregulation of labour and social rights in the Union and austerity policies have a terrible impact on the reconciliation of private and professional life for women. To avoid this inequality, the report is committed to enhancing collective agreements that facilitate the reconciliation of private, professional and family life. It also bets on parental leave that is appropriately remunerated and for both parents to facilitate this reconciliation. Since it also points out the importance of promoting public social services for child care and care at European level, I have supported this text.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. During the last decades, the reconciliation of professional, private and family life has become a recognized fundamental right. Although some initiatives have already been undertaken both at European and national level, it remains an area in which we need to continue to work to ensure a satisfactory work-life balance for all.  In doing so, I believe that not only is people's own well-being improved, but society as a whole also benefits. This requires transforming the working environment and also departing from the idea that work is the only useful and therefore valuable way for people to participate actively in the labour market and society as a whole. This report proposes solutions in this regard, since the absence of them has continuous negative effects on Europe's demographics which we cannot afford. I fully agree with the need to continue working, always taking into account the circumstances of the moment, to achieve this balance. That is why I give my positive vote for the adoption of this report.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The work-life balance report is not acceptable. It interferes far too much with the interests of the Member States and, in particular, of families. He tries to regulate how and when women should be returned to work after pregnancy and men are forced into a domestic role. The principle of subsidiarity is being trampled underfoot here. The interests of families should be decided by the families themselves, and certainly not in the EU.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I supported the report on creating a work-life balance environment on the labour market. In the context of this report, I draw attention to the need to ensure that high-quality childcare services and early childhood education are available to all.  We need more investment in the creation and development of childcare infrastructure. Every child should be guaranteed a place in a care institution after the parents have completed their parental leave. Following the resolution, I call on the Member States to implement the 2002 Barcelona targets for childcare infrastructure and to approve the 2014 framework for the quality of early childhood education and care services. Ensuring adequate childcare, as part of a work-life balance strategy, is also crucial for increasing women's employment.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which acknowledges the importance of work life balance, between work life and private life.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. In my think, maternity aid policy and parenting benefits should remain a national competence and the EU should not meddle. I do not agree with the call that 'parental leave' should be compulsorily shared between the two parents. Let's leave it up to the parents to decide how to split up childcare. Nor do I agree with the statement that "LGBTI people face specific gender barriers at work that adversely affect their well-being at work and threaten their mental health" and that therefore the Commission and the Member States should take "further steps to address these adverse conditions."

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully agree with reporters that reconciliation of professional, private and family life needs to be guaranteed as a fundamental right for all, with measures being available for everyone, going beyond young mothers, fathers or carers. it is necessary to promote family-friendly working environments, reconciliation plans, return-to-work programmes, communication channels between employees and employers, and incentives for businesses and self-employed workers, in particular to ensure that people are not economically penalised for having children.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Work, private and family life balance affects quality of life on the one hand and at the same time efficiency and productivity of the work performed on the other. It affects the quality of life of the individual and the whole of society at the same time. Striking this balance requires all competent authorities to eliminate existing problems at several levels, from discrimination in labour market application, the organisation of working time, gender equality in pay, the upbringing of children, the availability of quality education from pre-school to lifelong learning, as well as affordable care and the provision of the elderly. I believe that demographic developments in the EU require that the Union not only prepares and copes with an ageing population, but also creates economic, social and working conditions for the establishment of families as a matter of priority.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the creation of labour market conditions conducive to a work-life balance, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 12/9/2016, and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. Although it sets out several points that we support (equal pay, freedom to procreate, fight against discrimination, etc.) several points are reprehensible. This text proposes a cultural and societal transition that will fit perfectly into the development of the European pillar of social rights to come, with a questioning of the models of the couple (as an entity), paid work and the sexual differentiation that takes place.  These are primarily economic reasons for the decline in the birth rate: the lack of sufficient income and the fear of losing one's job (unfair dismissal linked to motherhood). The text is therefore torn between two objectives that seem irreconcilable, to integrate women into the labour market and to encourage them to give birth.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Combining work and private life is especially difficult, if not impossible, for women, mothers. Today we voted on a report that draws attention to these problems. I agree with many of the ideas contained in the text, e.g. that the policies necessary to achieve a balance between private and professional life must focus on women's access to the labour market and the shared sharing of homework and care tasks between men and women. Furthermore, a coherent policy framework, supported by collective bargaining and collective agreements, must be focused in order to enable a better balance of caring, professional and private life. The rapporteurs also mention the need to enshrine the right of every woman to maternity and parental leave, as well as the need to apply the principle of gender equality. I supported the report in the vote.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report underlines important measures on labour market conditions favourable to work-life balance, such as: the importance of a coherent policy framework supported by collective bargaining and collective agreements to enable a better work-life balance; the importance of "adequately" paid parental leave more balanced for both parents; the importance of having access to affordable, adequate and quality early childhood education and care, care for dependent people and high-quality social services; the recognition that policies to reconcile working life will not in themselves produce benefits for workers unless they are accompanied by policies to improve living conditions, alongside policies to promote and promote cultural, recreational and sporting activities, among others. Even though much work still needs to be done in the context of social inequalities and the living conditions of workers, for the reasons I have mentioned above, I voted in favour.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The creation of favourable conditions to reconcile personal and professional life has been a challenge that society is increasingly demanding of us. Much remains to be done and that is why my support for Parliament's report in this regard, in which we make our proposals to move faster on this path and to be able to unlock aspects that have been standing for decades, relating to maternity, paternity or carers' leave, which are important if we really want to resolve this issue.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 There should undoubtedly be a balance between work and personal life and this is one of fundamental human rights.  I am voting in favour of the resolution on creating conditions on the labour market which favour a balance between work and personal life because this will also contribute to the personal progress of the individual, but at the same time society as a whole will benefit because personal well-being is directly linked to social well-being. Balanced individuals are more productive and effective at what they do. Finally, there is a need to balance work and personal life and to promote and increase women's participation in the labour market because modernising the existing legal framework makes it possible to strike a balance for parents with children or dependent relatives. This is vital if we are to achieve true gender equality and harness people's abilities and talents.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. In my opinion, this report should be viewed negatively, since, under the guise of labour market policy, national family and social policy is being interfered with by promoting a new social model.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This initiative report supports the idea that work-life balance not only improves the well-being of everyone, but also benefits society as a whole, as people with a satisfactory work-life balance are more productive at work. In this area, as in many others, there are many inequalities between men and women, due in particular to the greater care of dependent persons (children and/or dependent parents) by women. The aim of this report is not only to promote gender equality in employment and other areas of life, but also to give children the opportunity to reach their full potential by providing them with quality early childhood education, as well as access to leisure and cultural and sporting activities. The report proposes to act through the extension of maternity leave, the revision of paternity leave and the emphasis on the dependant leave directive. I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The interference in the social organisation of the Member States, but also within the families, promoted by this text, makes it unacceptable. In general, some good ideas but a text that changes, in the background, our models of society and work. Women's freedom of choice is then short-circuited, making women an "equal-inferior" man, subject to the legislative requirement. In addition, freedom of movement, migrants and 2020 targets are added and guided by this issue.  So I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. According to the latest Eurostat data, the birth rate in the European Union has declined in recent decades. The Union faces unprecedented demographic challenges, to which Member States must respond. Family-friendly policies are important to stimulate positive demographic trends, as job insecurity and poor working conditions have negative effects on family planning. In order to achieve a true work-life balance, sound, cross-cutting, coherent, structural and comprehensive policies are needed, providing for incentives and effective measures to foster reconciliation between work, the possibility of providing care and spending time with family and friends and the possibility of carrying out leisure and personal development activities. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that calls for the Union to deliver solutions on the issues of work-life balance and gender equality. The report calls on the Commission, Member States and stakeholders to propose ways in which a balance can be achieved that suits the work-life needs of both women and men by taking advantage of the ever-evolving digital age in which we live.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – It continues to seek a satisfactory work, family and private life balance for every father, mother, employee or self-employed person. Initiatives were taken at both national and European level to bridge the gap between work and private life. However, demographic changes are creating new care needs and the diversification of family relationships. This report should be read above all as a call to the Commission to step up its work in promoting work-life balance. By taking the lead in the search for better work, family and family balances, the Commission can help to create a level playing field within the EU in a policy to promote the combination of work and family life. This means, among other things, that decisive steps must be taken to reverse the negative impact of parenthood on the number of women in work, that the principle of equal pay for equal work becomes commonplace, that homework and telework are promoted and that workable arrangements are in place in all Member States for men and women when they want to take on caring responsibilities.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – The motion for a resolution stresses the need to improve the balance between private life and work through legislative and non-legislative initiatives and is the starting point for a document prepared by the European Commission Roadmap: a new start to address the challenges of work-life balance faced by working families. I did not support the proposal with my vote for several reasons: family policy is the exclusive competence of each Member State. This includes the issue of revising maternity leave, improving parental leave, creating new paternity leave, as well as defining family. The proposal therefore interferes with the principle of subsidiarity, which ensures that decisions are taken at the level closest to the citizen. The Union therefore acts only if the objectives of the proposed action cannot be sufficiently achieved by the Member States and can, by reason of the scale or effects of the proposed action, be better achieved by the Community. In the proposal, parenting is defined as one of the biggest obstacles to employment. The EU Treaty only understands father and mother as employees, so the Union's intervention in family life and its efforts to guide values and norms within the family are, in my opinion, beyond its scope.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on creating labour market conditions favourable for work-life balance because it is time to assess our demographic and socioeconomic challenges and adopt a package of legislative and non-legislative policies to promote work-life balance to ensure workers enter, remain and return to the labour market, and can reconcile professional, private and family life.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Over the past decades, the compatibility of professional, private and family life has been recognised as a fundamental right, but further progress is needed to ensure that everyone can strike the right work-life balance. In December 2015, the Commission published a roadmap entitled 'A new start: addressing the challenges facing working parents in terms of work-life balance', with the aim of increasing women's participation in the labour market by modernising the existing EU legal and policy framework and aligning it with the current labour market. The draft joint report of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, while welcoming the Commission's initiative, assumes that improving work-life balance requires action at EU level. Accordingly, it urges a revision of Directive 92/85/EEC on pregnant workers (maternity leave), an overview of the implementation of Directive 2010/18/EU on parental leave and the adoption of a directive on paternity leave and carer's leave. The former should ensure that men play their part in care and the latter so that workers can look after their relatives. I supported the adoption of the draft.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I consider a real reconciliation between personal and professional life essential. Only in this way will it be possible to combat low birth rates and achieve a balance in view of gender equality. I therefore consider it important that the Commission resubmits the proposal on maternity leave, which has been blocked by the Council.  Maternity and paternity leave and parental leave will only be effective if complemented by horizontal measures of inclusion and birth support, competences that are at Member State level.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is driven by the desire to best reconcile private and professional life and to combat discrimination through legislative and non-legislative measures. However, considering that these matters fall under the exclusive competence of the Member States, and that this is therefore an interference in the organisation of the Member States, I voted against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs fully support measures to promote greater work-life balance. We will not meet the demographic challenges we face - including the need to care for an ageing population - unless we modernise existing leave arrangements. Fathers taking time out of work to care for children must be supported by the right to paternity leave. We also support greater rights for carers, more extensive maternity leave rights and better implementation of existing legislation. These changes will bring benefits to the economy as a whole, and ensure that women and men are equal earners and carers.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote of this report on the introduction of working-life conditions on the labour market. By asking the Commission to put in place policies to support migrants, this text is once again a call for air to illegal immigration, which I consistently oppose.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the introduction of working-life balance in the labour market. Although there are several unsatisfactory elements, I welcome the progress that can be made today in this area, such as the harmonisation of maternity leave at European level, the non-transferability of parental leave which could jeopardising the return of mothers to employment and the labour market, or additional protection for vulnerable women. The crisis has irreparably affected women since 2008, it is important that the European Union is concerned and legislates to improve and propose conditions for entry and return to the labour market for women and men who have children or dependants.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this own-initiative report on work-life reconciliation. At present, the inequality between men and women in taking leave is still evident: only 10 % of fathers use at least one day of paternity leave while 97 % of women use parental leave available to both parents. The European Parliament has decided to draw up this own-initiative report in order to pay more attention to the debate and to call on the Commission to step up its work in this field. Above all, this INI is a reaction to the roadmap and related public consultation launched in 2015, entitled "A new beginning to face the challenges of work-life balance faced by working families". The report takes into account the link between the current, unprecedented demographic challenges, job insecurity and difficult working conditions that have a negative impact on the balance between family and work. The primary focus is on the need to invest in social services, in particular on care services for children, the elderly and other dependents. The importance of promoting quality employment, workers' rights and safety on the labour market is also stressed.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that it is time for the EU to take action to ensure proper cohesion between Member States in work-life balance solutions. Labour market conditions that are favourable to work-life balance can only be achieved if people have sufficient time to develop personally outside of work. It is important to create a society in which women and men can be equal as earners and carers.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will address the challenges of work-life balance faced by working families. This need for modernising work-life balance framework at EU level is due to the demographic changes triggering more care needs, new emerging working ways and unprecedented high levels of unemployment.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – I supported this report because I believe that the European Union faces a serious demographic challenge and the majority of Member States are seeing a big drop in the birth rate. One of the main reasons behind this worrying trend is the lack of balance between privacy and career.  I am of the opinion that we need modern policies that pay particular attention to the need to increase labour market participation rates among young women, especially those after a period of motherhood and single mothers. Although women are more educated, their employment rates within the EU are significantly lower than that of men. I believe that in order for these policies to be successful, we must first overcome the ingesting stereotypes about the role of men and women in today's society. And stereotypes, as we know well, are built from a young age and have implications in the choice of education and profession and continue in the workplace. If we don't change our mentality, no policy will be effective.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the first commitments I had when I decided to get involved in political life was to create legislation that would give women and men equal career opportunities. The challenges of the modern world confirm to us that it is a desire that, even if in some countries has been achieved, must be preserved and reiterated, adapted to the present time. In today's family, both parents must be able to have a balanced professional and private life without jeopardizing their work and career. Unfortunately, this report does not provide solutions for companies that have shortcomings in this regard, we have a text far too general, with provisions that go beyond the original purpose of the report. Furthermore, while the document calls on the Member States and the Commission to take a stand and fight against the large number of reasons why the EU has a low birth rate and an increasingly old population, it fails to provide clarity on the implementation procedures and solutions available to improve this situation. In this context, I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this own-initiative report prepared jointly by EMPL and FEMM, which calls for the Commission and Member States to implement measures such as ensuring affordable childcare, and paid leave including maternity, paternity, parental and carers’ leave in order to address the exclusion of women from the labour force due to caring responsibilities. On the issue of non-transferability of parental leave, Sinn Féin’s position is in favour of non-transferability (i.e. it can’t be transferred from the father to the mother) as it is proven to benefit the position of women in the workforce.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. If I had taken part in the vote, I would have opposed this report, because I believe that national family and social policy is being interfered with under the guise of labour market policy by promoting a new social model.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. Adopting work-life balance measures is critical if we are to move forward with the effective integration of women into the labour market while generating a quality welfare state and encouraging increased birth rate.  It is key that the economic approach is accompanied by a life-cycle and family-based approach. Encouraging flexibility and streamlining schedules, extending the period of reduction of contributions based on maternity or paternity, deduction for household employee expenses, are measures that go the right way.  This report takes into account many of these measures and that is why I have supported it. This is an own-initiative report which aims to generate debate and which, I hope, will help the Commission to intensify its work in this area.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In recent decades, the harmonisation of professional, private and family life has been recognised as a fundamental right. However, due to a lack of effective and adequate maternity, paternity and parental leave, parents are forced to choose between family and professional life.  It is time for the EU to take action to promote upward convergence between Member States in work-life balancing solutions. This is vital if we are to achieve real gender equality, combat labour, child and female poverty and make better use of people's skills by taking action to address demographic challenges in the EU. I voted in favour of the report, which calls on the Commission to step up its work so that further progress can be made to ensure a satisfactory work-life balance for all. This balance will contribute to increasing women's participation in the labour market by modernising and adapting the current EU legal and political framework to today's labour market, to increasing the distribution of caring responsibilities between women and men, and to strengthening gender equality in the labour market.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-binding and non-legislative report. Although there were some very sensitive issues regarding equality, discrimination and helping disadvantaged people, the report went on to call for more EU action and legislation. It included calls for the reversal in the burden of proof in legal situations which would end the presumption of innocence and irrevocably alter UK criminal law. The report called for the EU to monitor national legislation, it tried to say when schools should close, and wanted changes to national taxation and social security. The only people that should take such decisions are our elected national governments, not unaccountable EU bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I can only recall how the well-being and best interests of children should be priority considerations in the development, monitoring and implementation of work-life balance policies. Overall, the text, which does not have some amendments proposed by other groups, appears to be a good compromise and I am therefore voting in favour of it.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – As underlined in the report, there is a need to modernise work—life balance through legislative and non-legislative initiatives. The co-rapporteurs emphasise the importance of reconciliation of professional, private and family life and consider it even as a Fundamental right. Furthermore it stressed the importance of flexible forms of work in allowing women and men to reconcile work and family life. For these and other reasons I supported this resolution.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. Parents today face many problems when it comes to achieving a balance between family and work life, and women are exposed to various forms of discrimination in the workplace – from access to employment for the sake of planned pregnancy in the future, through the denial or reduction of their workers' rights or benefits related to motherhood, even to dismissal.  The problem of extending working hours and working without a day's rest, weekends, holidays and holidays is becoming more frequent, and it has particularly affected shop workers. A non-working Sunday in all EU Member States would allow families to be able to spend quality time together that is not provided to them throughout the working week, especially in families where both spouses work or where the working parent supports their children on their own. At the heart of all work-life balance policies must be family and children and it is inadmissible for these policies, under the guise of protecting workers' rights and women's rights, to try to redefine a family that is a core unit of society.  Therefore, I could not support this resolution because I believe that it does not address real problems, but instead of proposaling concrete solutions to create a balance between family and work life, it tries to impose ideological issues and redefine a family based on marriage between a man and a woman.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report interferes with the social and family policies of Member States and the private lives of citizens. Its intentions are not necessarily bad, since it is about helping individuals, especially women, to better manage career and personal life. But it incorporates issues that have nothing to do with it (migrants, freedom of movement, 2020 targets) and does not respect people's freedom of choice. Under these conditions, I prefer to vote against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ in 2015, in the 28 EU Member States, the employment rate for men was 75.9 % compared to the female employment rate of 64.3 %, despite the fact that women are more educated; whereas the number of women as a workforce is even lower when taking into account the full-time employment rate, as the share of part-time employment among women is very high in some Member States; whereas in 2013 men were paid weekly for 47 hours of work and women for 34 hours; whereas, if we add up the hours of paid and unpaid work at home, young women worked an average of 64 hours and young men worked 53 hours.  GDP losses per capita attributable to gender differences in the labour market are estimated at up to 10% in Europe. I consider this inadmissible data and agree with the calls that we must do everything in our power to minimize the difference as soon as possible and abolish it al more completely. For all of the above, I support the adoption of this report.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In today's hectic world, it is very difficult to find the right balance between family and career life. Especially for women as mothers and carers, it is not easy to get a job that would allow them to reconcile their lives with caring for others. Thus, despite their good qualifications and higher education, many women are under-represented in the labour market and are much more at risk of social exclusion and poverty. This issue also has a major impact on children, as their adolescence and the possibility of exploiting their potential depend on the way they are educated and the need to spend time with their parents. Account must also be taken of the current demographic situation of an ageing European population. The need to choose between family life and career often affects the decision whether to start a family and have children at all. Such a dilemma therefore threatens Europe's future. These reasons have led me to support this report, which responds to the European Commission's plans to improve work-life balance. At the same time, it proposes various initiatives to modernise existing EU legislation and adopts new EU directives on paternity and carers' leave.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the pillar of European society is the family and that a great deal of work still needs to be done to ensure the conditions for a genuine reconciliation of professional, private and family life. This is, in fact, an area in which, although some measures have already been taken at European and national level, further progress needs to be made in order to ensure that all citizens have an adequate work-life balance, particularly for women. We must not force them to choose between a professional career and a family. Women must be able to play their fundamental role as mothers, accompanied by the irreplaceable father figure, thanks to the support of public policies capable of promoting their work.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report, which insists on the establishment of conditions in the labour market that promote a work-life balance. The necessary issues of equal pay between men and women, or the importance of the performance of social protection systems, are addressed. This text is part of the commitments announced by the European Commission to implement various initiatives in the field by the end of 2016.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report demonstrates the consideration given by the Union, and in particular parliament, to the balance between work, personal life and family life. In the rapporteurs' view, the modernisation of the regulatory framework providing this balance is necessary, mainly due to social changes in the demographic and public health, as well as due to the new reality of the labour market. Reconciling a citizen's personal and professional life not only contributes to productivity in his employment, but also promotes well-being in society and provides conditions for raising children and establishing families. Thus, the promotion of policies to increase gender equality in the labour market, the improvement of parental leave schemes and increased attention from Member States on this issue are crucial factors for meeting the objectives set in this area.  Because I consider it important that citizens have time outside working hours for their personal development, for their families and for leisure, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-binding and non-legislative report. Although there were some very sensitive issues regarding equality, discrimination and helping disadvantaged people, the report went on to call for more EU action and legislation. It included calls for the reversal in the burden of proof in legal situations which would end the presumption of innocence and irrevocably alter UK criminal law. The report called for the EU to monitor national legislation, it tried to say when schools should close, and wanted changes to national taxation and social security. The only people that should take such decisions are our elected national governments, not unaccountable EU bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. Currently, the balance between professional life, personal life and family life has been recognized as a fundamental right. However, progress remains to be made to ensure that everyone is able to satisfactorily reconcile the various aspects of their lives. The aim of this report is to promote equality between men and women in employment and other spheres of life, and also to give children the possibility to reach their full potential by providing them with high-quality education and care and access to leisure activities, cultural and sporting activities, and time to spend with their parents. It is essential to combat labour poverty, child and women's poverty, make better use of people's skills and abilities and take action to address demographic challenges. I voted in favour.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. Over the past decades, the balance between work, private life and family life has been recognised as a fundamental right. Although some initiatives have already been taken, both at European and national level, progress remains needed in this area. The lack of solutions to reconcile professional and private life influences people's decisions and there will always be one of these areas that risks being harmed.  The measures currently in force in the Member States are aggravating the situation, having a negative impact on the well-being of all people, as well as their participation in the labour market and productivity. Sound action is needed, both at European and national level, including legislative measures on different types of licence, linked to non-legislative measures such as awareness-raising and information campaigns, control mechanisms and monitoring of the situation. The absence of paid leave schemes for fathers compared to mothers, or insufficient incentives to use them, contributes to gender inequality in the sharing of professional and family obligations between women and men, rather than promoting equality.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that work-life balance is a fundamental right that has not yet been achieved in Europe, which is an obstacle to achieving real equality between men and women.  With this report we send a clear message to the Commission to update and complete European legislation. It must submit as soon as possible a revision of the maternity directive, an improvement in the parental leave directive and two new directives, one on paternity leave and one on the leave of carers.  It is also important to improve the provision of quality services at affordable prices for childcare and other dependents, so that women, who are the majority among caregivers, can participate in the labour market and qualify for full-time jobs, which allow them to generate a decent pension for the future.   It is also necessary to streamline working hours and introduce greater flexibility so that all workers can enjoy their private life, which is not only in the benefit of people, but also of companies because workers are more productive.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the publication by the European Commission of the roadmap for 'a new beginning to meet the challenges between professional and private life', Parliament adopted its position to improve this conciliation, a position I supported by voting in favour at this plenary session.   I believe that the European Union must, in particular, set up legislative initiatives to enable this better conciliation. It is for this reason that I have supported in particular the idea at European level of a 6-month parental leave, a paternity leave of 2 weeks and a leave for dependents supplementing the provision of professional care. With regard to the intervention of the various social security systems, I believe that this is a competence of the Member States.    With regard to the Maternity Leave Directive, I deeply regret that the previous proposal was withdrawn following the blocking in the Council and ask the Commission to present an ambitious new proposal in consultation with the social partners.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. Over the past few decades, the balance between work, personal life and family life has been recognised as a right. Although some initiatives have already been taken both at European level and in the Member States, progress remains needed in this area and hence the importance of this document and this discussion. It is important, first of all, to integrate work-life balance into policy, in order to ensure that everyone benefits from support at different stages throughout their lives and can actively participate in the labour market and society. This report supports the Commission's initiative to increase women's participation in the labour market by modernising and adapting the current EU legal and political framework to the needs of the modern labour market, enabling greater sharing of responsibilities between men and women. It is also intended to promote gender equality in employment and other spheres of life, but also to give children the possibility of full access to high-quality education and health care in early childhood. Because I agree with the content of the text and the Commission's initiative, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the establishment of labour market conditions that promote work-life balance. This report stresses that reconciling work, private and family life must be guaranteed as a right with measures applicable to all. It calls for a system to obtain reliable, comparable and comprehensive equality data to improve understanding of the lack of work-life balance.  It is undeniable that a better work-life balance and the strengthening of gender equality are essential to support women's participation in the labour market.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although the report is not rooted in the causes of gender inequality in the workplace, I believe it has very positive aspects that should be implemented to improve personal, family and work life balance policies. That is why I voted abstention.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. The Social Democrats in the European Parliament want to update EU legislation to improve work-life balance. We support initiatives that improve equality between men and women, strengthen fathers' right to leave and increase women's participation in the labour market.
