That is why we have chosen to vote in favour of the report as a whole.  However, this should not be interpreted as support for all the individual initiatives mentioned in the report. In general, the Danish Social Democrats want a greater focus on father's rights, as this is essential for achieving a more equal distribution of leave between parents. Some of the proposals in the report, in the case of legislation, could be counterproductive to this objective. At the same time, there are certain areas where denmark has a tradition of agreements being concluded between the social partners and where we do not want legislation at EU level. Since this is not legislation, but merely an own-initiative report, we have chosen to support the overall message of ensuring more equality and better gender balance through improved rules, in close cooperation with the social partners and taking into account the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted against the report on the creation of work-life balance-enhancing measures in the labour market, as this area, with issues such as parental leave, same-sex partnerships or minimum requirements for adoptive parents, falls within the competences of the Member States and the principle of subsidiarity must be respected.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this joint report by the Committee on Women and Gender Equality and the Committee on Employment as it recognises that the increasing deregulation of labour and social rights in the Union and austerity policies have a terrible impact on the reconciliation of private and professional life for women. To avoid this inequality, the report is committed to enhancing collective agreements that facilitate the reconciliation of private, professional and family life. It also bets on parental leave that is appropriately remunerated and for both parents to facilitate this reconciliation. Since it also points out the importance of promoting public social services for child care and care at European level, I have supported this text.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation of measures to improve work-life balance involves financial and social factors and it is important to ensure that this balance also promotes increased productivity and competitiveness in all public or private enterprises. Personal satisfaction of workers usually promotes an increase in their productivity, because a worker satisfied with their workplace performs their duties better than otherwise. We must continue to work to ensure that equal treatment and gender rights are also a reality in the workplace. At the same time, it is necessary to ensure that the work makes time available for children to live with both parents. For all this, I voted in favour of this report which promotes and advocates the existence of work regimes in which there is a real work-life balance. In this way, we will be contributing to an increase in the quality of life for the majority of European workers.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report - while some of it has good intentions I do not believe the EU should get involved in nation states internal labour laws.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – Labour MEPs fully support measures to promote greater work-life balance. We will not meet the demographic challenges we face - including the need to care for an ageing population - unless we modernise existing leave arrangements. Fathers taking time out of work to care for children must be supported by the right to paternity leave. We also support greater rights for carers, more extensive maternity leave rights and better implementation of existing legislation. These changes will bring benefits to the economy as a whole, and ensure that women and men are equal earners and carers.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I agree that the reconciliation of women's and men's work and private lives must be facilitated to the maximum extent possible, especially with regard to their family responsibilities and commitments. Above all, if we want to face up to a catastrophic demographic situation in Europe, we must support the natural family and its healthy functioning. However, the resolution adopted again seeks to interfere in areas which are solely the responsibility of the Member States. Moreover, the report presented also proposed an even distribution of domestic work and family care between men and women. We have repeatedly seen here the efforts of the European institutions to interfere with responsibilities, but also in the rights of spouses or partners who live in a shared household. It should be stressed that this is an absurd and unacceptable interference with the rights and privacy of its rightful and free citizens. The question of reconciling work and private life is about enabling women and men to make free choices, not about integrating as many women as possible into the labour market and involving more men in housework. And that is what all proposals and policies must respect. I therefore voted against.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Reconciling work and private life is a very important factor, as an appropriate work-life balance contributes to economic growth, competitiveness, overall labour market participation, gender equality, poverty reduction and intergenerational solidarity. The EU must take measures to promote upward convergence between Member States in the area of working-life balance solutions. In order to achieve real equality between women and men, it is essential to combat in-work, child and female poverty, to make better use of people's skills and talents, and to combat demographic challenges in the EU. Labour market conditions that are favourable to work-life balance can only be created and quality of life can only be achieved if people have sufficient time away from work for their personal development, for example through education and training, and for rest. It is therefore important that Member States implement the Working Time Directive consistently, but also that they introduce measures to promote leisure and education and training.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament voted today on an own-initiative report on creating labour market conditions conducive to work-life balance. I think it is important that the European Parliament deals with negative demographic developments in the European Union. The text in the introduction recalls the fall in the birth rate in the EU, which is an important warning. In view of the above reasons, I would expect the European Parliament to encourage member states to adopt a pro-family policy. Instead, the European Parliament calls on both the Commission and the Member States to recognise and support all the different forms of relationships to replace the traditional family, such as registered partnerships or 'parents' of the same sex, etc. These unacceptable proposals have nothing to do with the original objective of the report and interfere with the competences of the Member States. I also find it unacceptable for the European Parliament to call on the European Commission to submit a directive on compulsory two-week and fully paid paternity leave. Paternity leave does, but it has to be on a voluntary basis. Despite the originally good intention of the resolution, its final form was unacceptable to me, which is why I voted against this report.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. In order to achieve work-life balance, coordinated and comprehensive policies are needed to coordinate the profession, care and spend time with family and friends, leisure and personal development.  Both the EU and its members should adopt a policy tailored to today's reality and promoting gender equality in jobs and in other spheres of life. In particular, the legislation on parental leave for mothers and fathers should be updated.  There are many reasons for modernising this framework at EU level, including changes in the demographics of the population, new ways of working and parenting having a markedly negative impact on women's employment. Parliament has therefore decided to draw up a report to start a debate and to encourage the Commission to work more quickly in this area.  The report aims not only to promote gender equality in employment and other spheres of life, but also to take into account the needs of an increasingly diverse society and the integration of a life-cycle approach in the reconciliation of work and private life. At the same time, parliament wants to speed up negotiations between European workers and labour organisations on this subject with this report.  The report is, in my opinion, positive and contains important emphasis, which is why I have decided to support it.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The work-life balance report is not acceptable. It interferes far too much with the interests of the Member States and, in particular, of families. He tries to regulate how and when women should be returned to work after pregnancy and men are forced into a domestic role. The principle of subsidiarity is being trampled underfoot here. The interests of families should be decided by the families themselves, and certainly not in the EU.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ New technologies and profound changes in the structure of the economy that we are currently seeing will also bring about the redefixion of work processes. However, we should not interfere in relations between the employee and the employer in a directive, but rather create a space for free choice and adjustment of the form of work by mutual agreement.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation abstained in the vote on this report. The N-VA definitely wants to work on a healthy combination between work and family, and this for various family situations such as single parents, two-earners with young children, newly created families, etc. An appropriate legal framework should provide employees with the opportunity to create their daily puzzle between work, family and private life, as well as give employers the flexibility to respond to the rapidly changing market. However, it is primarily up to the Member States to create this framework; it must, after all, be as well as possible tailored to the needs and realities of our citizens. Here, unfortunately, the report misses the ball. It calls for all kinds of European legislative initiatives that would clearly flore the principle of subsidiarity. Other objections to the report include the complete rejection of flexible working relationships, the demand for more EU funds and a sometimes very patronising tone towards women.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I totally reject this resolution. I am very much in favour of support measures by the Member States in favour of a better reconciliation of family and professional life. Here, however, marriage and family are to be made compatible with the labour market and parental duties are to be delegated to the state. The EU was founded as a single market, mothers and fathers are not in the EU Treaty. Originally it was always said: "reconciliation of family and work". Family becomes private life. Family is therefore treated as leisure activities. Worse, the EU cannot devalue the principle of 'marriage and family as the basis of society' than to equate it with private leisure opportunities. Marriage and family should be treated on an equal footing with all other forms of life and thus devalued. The AfD, on the other hand, is committed to protecting established cultural and regional traditions and established institutions. They give people support and bond. Marriage and family in particular, as the nucleus of bourgeois society, guarantee social cohesion that has grown over generations. Meeting the needs of children and parents must once again be at the heart of national family policy. All the Brussels proposals have so far been a failure. The economy wants women as workers. Misunderstood feminism values women in the workforce, but not women who are "only" mothers and housewives. They are often less recognised and financially disadvantaged.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The birth rate has decreased in the European Union in recent decades and the Union faces unprecedented demographic challenges. Work insecurity and difficult working conditions have a negative impact on family planning, so policies that support family life are needed. The plan presented by the Commission is by no means the final solution, but it is a good starting point for fostering positive demographic trends. Work-life balance policies need to be well designed and should be seen as improving the working environment. Good working conditions and social and business well-being should be provided. I support the report on creating favourable labour market conditions for the realisation of a work-life balance, as I consider the guidelines set out in it to be a good starting point for achieving a genuine work-life balance. I believe that the reconciliation of work and family life should be guaranteed as a fundamental right for all people.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on creating favourable labour market conditions for work-life balance.  In order to achieve a harmonious professional, private and family life, we need reliable, coherent and comprehensive policies. I therefore support incentives and effective measures to coordinate work, care for and spend time with the family, and free time and time for personal development.  We must promote a family-friendly working environment, coordination plans and return-to-work programmes, as the birth rate in the European Union, which is already low, has fallen further as a result of the crisis, with young people delaying their child planning due to unemployment, precarious forms of employment, an uncertain future and discrimination in the labour market.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although we know that EU labour policies cannot be turned into anthropocentric since they are part of its economic policies, we supported this report because it contains some positive elements. Some of them are: his criticism of austerity measures and increased working hours, the recognition of precarious forms of work in the union, and the recognition that any policies to balance work and personal life will not have a positive impact on workers' lives unless accompanied by policies to improve their quality of life.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Greek model of family and organisation of society is completely different from that promoted by the European Union, as our principles and values differ radically without any point of contact.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order not to be self-contradictory because of my obligation as Vice-President, in cases where the parliamentary group votes differently from the Hungarian Members in roll call ballots, I will not take part directly in the vote. In other words, I will not press the voting button, but I will put my hand on the voting position previously decided jointly by the PP group. That's how I did it in this case.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which shows that over the past decades the compatibility of professional, private and family life has been recognised as a fundamental right. I think it is of the utmost importance to confirm that women's access to employment can be complicated by many circumstances, e.g. when there are children, the elderly and other dependants in the family, since the responsibility for caring for the family and the household is most often on women. As a result, they are often obliged to work part-time or in precarious employment, resulting in differences in wages and pensions. I agree that the modernisation of the work-life balance framework at EU level is necessary for a number of main reasons, and I therefore welcome the Commission's initiative. I believe that the Hungarian Government should also introduce more targeted measures to ensure a work-life balance in practice.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 There is no doubt that for many families, it is a huge challenge to reconcile private life with professional responsibilities. It is therefore necessary to take initiatives aimed at increasing flexibility in work, promoting part-time work and various forms of remote work. In addition, improving the accessibility of places in crèches, kindergartens and all-day childcare places is a key aspect for combining work and private life. However, action in this area should be taken at national level by the governments of individual Member States and not at Union level. The issue of maternity, tacier, parental or caring leave is a matter for the Member States only. The European Union's interference in these areas violates the fundamental principle of subsidiarity, which assumes that only those actions that cannot be effectively and effectively implemented at national level are taken at European level.  Unfortunately, many of the proposals presented in this report undermine this principle, which is why I decided not to support it in the vote.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted against the report because I believe that Parliament's EMPL and FEMM committees will go to the Member States' property on this issue. I would like to emphasise the importance of safeguarding work-life balance for both women and men. I believe that issues such as parental leave and the minimum wage should be decided as close as possible to the citizens, that is to say, at Member State level, not at EU level.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament ensures that the best living conditions for European citizens are created. Lately, however, building a career and family life are increasingly difficult to reconcile at European level. This has a negative impact on demographic developments, contributing to the growing ageing of the European population. To counter these effects, the present document aims to revise European legislation to achieve a balance between career and personal life, in particular with regard to maternity and paternal leave, flexible working hours, increasing the participation of parents with children in the labour market. These measures require further investment in social services, particularly in the field of childcare, the elderly and the disabled, the creation of quality jobs, equal treatment in the labour market. As a result of the application of these measures, paternal leave will become more frequent, allowing parents to participate equally in child-rearing, encouraging carers, children or the disabled, encouraging the re-employment of mothers in the labour market and ensuring free children's access to education, health, care, food and housing. I believe that these measures are beneficial for increasing the standard of living of European citizens as a whole and I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. It is time for the Union to take steps to promote upward convergence between Member States in favour of work-life balance. It is crucial, if we are to achieve true gender equality, to combat poverty in the workplace and that of children and women, to make better use of skills and talents and to take action to address the union's demographic challenges. There is a need to modernise existing EU legislation, to fill gaps or lack of legislation in certain areas, and to strengthen coordination between Member States to ensure a level playing field with regard to the costs and benefits of work-life balance policies.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The reconciliation of professional, private and family life for women as well as for men is crucial not only for the well-being, cohesion and productivity of our societies, but also in view of the demographic slowdown in Europe. However, I do not believe that policies in this area should be decided at the level of the European Union, which is why I voted against this report. Determining this work-life balance is very dependent on the specificities of each member state’s cultural, societal and historical dynamics, which is why I am convinced that such decisions but should remain in the hands of national policy-makers.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted abstained on the Labour Market Report to strike a work-life balance. Indeed, while I understand the importance of work-life balance, I have not been able to support this report for several reasons. One of the main reasons is that it repeatedly violates the principle of subsidiarity, i.e. the report ignores Member States' competence over certain areas. In addition, my firm view is that families, i.e. workers, must be able to determine for themselves how they will align private time with work, and this report suggests that women work more and imposes minimum mandatory and non-transferable paid leave on their fathers. Since everyone has the right to determine how much time they spend at work and how much time with their family, I did not support this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal to create favourable labour market conditions for work-life balance.  The initiative aims to increase women's participation in the labour market by modernising and adapting the current legal and EU policy framework to today's labour market in order to enable parents with children and/or other family members to better reconcile family and professional life, to share care responsibilities more between women and men, and to strengthen gender equality in the labour market.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although the report is not rooted in the causes of gender inequality in the workplace, I believe it has very positive aspects that should be implemented to improve personal, family and work life balance policies. That is why I voted abstention.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The work-life balance report is not acceptable. It interferes far too much with the interests of the Member States and, in particular, of families. He tries to regulate how and when women should be returned to work after pregnancy and men are forced into a domestic role. The principle of subsidiarity is being trampled underfoot here. The interests of families should be decided by the families themselves, and certainly not in the EU.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is an interference in the social organisation of the Member States and even in the lives of families.  Some good ideas are developed there, but the text changes the societal and working models too much.  Women's and families' freedom of choice is short-circuited. Finally, the woman is seen only as an equal-inferior of the man, requiring special legislative attention.  In addition, the issues of migrant reception and freedom of movement are added to the file.  I therefore vote against this report.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is currently experiencing an alarming demographic situation, caused by the steady drop in birth rates in most Member States. In the face of this finding, the report indicates that establishing policies for reconciliation between family and professional life can help to strengthen economic growth, competitiveness, gender equality, reduce the risk of poverty and, moreover, increase the birth rate in the EU. It stresses that the balance between family and professional life should be a fundamental right for all, and not just for young parents, and encourages Member States to promote models of social protection at the level of businesses, in the public and private domain, that respect this right. The proposed measures also include: promoting a family-friendly work environment, work-life reconciliation plans, labour market return programmes, communication interfaces between employees and employers, and measures to incite businesses, in particular, to ensure that citizens are not economically penalised for having children. I therefore voted in favour of the report proposing the creation of labour market conditions favourable to work-life balance.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Over the past decades, the compatibility of professional, private and family life has been recognised as a fundamental right. Although initiatives to this goal have been implemented at both European and national level, this is still an area where further progress is needed to achieve the right work-life balance for all. This contributes not only to the well-being of the person, but also to the benefit of society as a whole, inter alia, because people whose lives achieve the right work-life balance are more productive workers. In the final vote, I supported the group's position.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – While the report does not follow the causes of gender inequality in the workplace, I believe it has very positive aspects that should be implemented to improve personal, family and work life balance policies. That is why I voted abstention.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for, as achieving a genuine work-life balance requires coherent and comprehensive policies for reconciling work, caring for and spending time with family/friends and time for leisure &personal development. The EU and its MS need to adapt work-life balance policies to today’s reality by promoting gender equality in employment and other spheres of life, but also by taking into account the needs of an increasingly diverse society. This requires a better sharing of paid work and caring responsibilities between men and women as well as society, including by modernising existing legislation on maternity and parental leave and by adopting new EU directives on paternity leave and carers’ leave, ensuring adequate income replacement and social protection during any type of family- or care-related leaves.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I stress the need to ensure the possibility of reconciling professional, private and family life as a fundamental right of all people, in accordance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and by means of measures that are accessible to every citizen, not just young mothers, parents or carers. I welcome the fact that the Commission has launched a public consultation on the European Pillar of Social Rights in order to gather opinions and feedback on the basic principles on which well-functioning and equitable labour markets and welfare systems in the euro area should be based.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on creating labour market conditions favourable for work-life balance. The aim of this report is not only to promote gender equality in employment and other spheres of life, but also to give children the possibility to reach their full potential by providing them with high quality early childhood education and care, access to leisure, cultural and sport activities and time with their parents. The report emphasizes that a better work-life balance and strengthened gender equality is essential for supporting the participation of women in the labour market. I voted in favour because I believe that proper work-life balance policies will help to ensure a higher quality of life and security for other dependants, in particular older dependants and dependants with disabilities or long-term illnesses.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In recent decades, the reconciliation of professional, private and family life has become a recognized fundamental right. Although many initiatives have already been undertaken both at European and national level in this regard, it is still an area where further progress is needed to ensure a satisfactory work-life balance for all. This report sets out Parliament's position on ways to modernise the framework for the reconciliation of private and professional life, stressing the need to continue to deepen its improvement through legislative and non-legislative initiatives. I share this need and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that work-life balance is a fundamental right that has not yet been achieved in Europe, which is an obstacle to achieving real equality between men and women.  With this report we send a clear message to the Commission to update and complete European legislation. It must submit as soon as possible a revision of the maternity directive, an improvement in the parental leave directive and two new directives, one on paternity leave and one on the leave of carers.  It is also important to improve the provision of quality services at affordable prices for childcare and other dependents, so that women, who are the majority among caregivers, can participate in the labour market and qualify for full-time jobs, which allow them to generate a decent pension for the future.   It is also necessary to streamline working hours and introduce greater flexibility so that all workers can enjoy their private life, which is not only in the benefit of people, but also of companies because workers are more productive.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ My Labour colleagues and I fully support measures to promote greater work-life balance. We will not meet the demographic challenges we face – including the need to care for an ageing population – unless we modernise existing leave arrangements. Fathers taking time out of work to care for children must be supported by the right to paternity leave. We also support greater rights for carers, more extensive maternity leave rights and better implementation of existing legislation. These changes will bring benefits to the economy as a whole, and ensure that women and men are equal earners and careers.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report because the subject is very much in my heart. The work-family balance is viewed in the report from a broad perspective. What resources can we provide from Europe to make it easier for working people to have a family life? The report focuses, among other things, on discrimination in the workplace, the reception opportunities of young children and the role that grandparents can (but should not) play in a family with working parents. Of course, we also pay attention to the workers, mostly women, who work with sometimes shaky part-time contracts and have children. These single-parent families often fall prey to poverty. Another important point that we are urging the Commission to make is to work towards a parental leave scheme which certainly includes the father.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The report on the creation of labour-life balance-prodding labour market conditions contains a number of proposals that are equal to working life, which are largely supportable and contribute to the realisation of a more equal working life. However, there are a number of points, e.g. the 1990s. in the distribution of parental leave on a family-by-family basis, I believe that it is the families themselves who are most aware of the way in which parental leave best suits their life situation.  It is important that free quotas are also created, but this must be done precisely by the Member States themselves, listening to the wishes of the families. As far as labour and social policy is concerned, it is the EU's job to draw up only the roughest guidelines, because due to the diversity of Member States, the best skills and know-how can be found in the Member States themselves. In line with my line, I would like to keep the EU's decision-making power limited, and the issues set out in this report should be largely the responsibility of the Member States in terms of labour and social policy. The report is also confused and unbalanced in its whole. For these reasons, I deviated from my group's voting line and voted against this report in the final vote.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This resolution provides an update on the necessary conditions for a better work-life balance. The finding is damning and the austere policies only make things worse (as the text says). Some significant examples: 11% difference in the employment rate; 47 hours of paid work for men and 34 hours for women, but reversed when unpaid work is added; wage gap still at more than 16% and precariousness and poverty that mainly affect women, especially those who are in the heads of single-parent families. The report calls for work, private and family life balance to become a fundamental right to address the challenges of demographic and societal changes in Europe, including the fight against gender stereotypes affecting both men and women; the necessary investment in childcare, childcare, education and care services for children and dependents and proposes to launch an integrated European plan to combat child poverty, as a result of that of parents. May this text allow us to initiate at least some of the changes he proposes...

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Over the past decades, the balance between work, personal life and family life has been recognised as a fundamental right. While some initiatives have already been taken at both European and national level, progress remains needed in this area, notably to ensure that everyone can satisfactorily reconcile their personal and working life. They are certainly beautiful words, which become even necessary in the face of the dramatic birth rate. However, the fundamental issue of the matter is largely omitted from the exploitation of the work that is accentuated by the growing dominance of the neoliberal policies of the EU and the countries that compose it.  It is not possible to continue to hear these hollow and certainly well-intentioned words, while promoting the complete devaluation of labor relations and collective bargaining. Precariousness and low wages are promoted. And then these souls are astonished that young people are increasingly delaying, if not eternally, the constitution of their own family.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Under the guise of labour market policy, national family and social policy is to be intervened, which is promoted by the propagating of a new social model. As a result, this proposal must be viewed negatively.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted with conviction in favour of the resolution on creating labour market conditions conducive to work-life balance for a number of reasons. Firstly, because reconciling working and working life is a right that must be up to everyone, and I hope that the Commission will take action as soon as possible to adapt the legislation in force. Secondly, I welcome the fact that, once again, Parliament has recognised that there is no 'the' family, but 'families': families with single parents, rainbow families, families where partners are not married. The policies of the EU and the Member States in this area must take account of this beautiful diversity.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. The report reflects the fashionable gender ideology in many demands and makes itself the mouthpiece of the "rights" of partly off-the-top minorities, which goes beyond the stated goal of improving the compatibility of life and work. That's why: "No."

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs fully support measures to promote greater work-life balance. We will not meet the demographic challenges we face – including the need to care for an ageing population – unless we modernise existing leave arrangements. Fathers taking time out of work to care for children must be supported by the right to paternity leave. We also support greater rights for carers, more extensive maternity leave rights and better implementation of existing legislation. These changes will bring benefits to the economy as a whole, and ensure that women and men are equal earners and carers. I therefore voted in favour of this report which takes a clear stand against austerity and widening social inequalities. It highlights the sad reality that women are especially affected by precarious labour, zero—hours contracts, and cuts in public services. The Commission and national governments must heed the call here, and take action. This is an important example of how the EU promotes gender equality and social justice, and why it is so important that we stand up for it.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because I agree that a good balance between work and private life leads to higher productivity and a higher quality of life. Measures that enhance such a work-life balance will also help women to gain better access to the labour market. I welcome recent EU legislation in this regard that enhances this as well as the demand on the Commission and Member States to develop specific measures that support single parents, unmarried couples same-sex couples and, of course, the self-employed. Furthermore, it is important that we understand the role of working arrangements and their effects. This resolution also stresses the need to promote good practices. In that regard, I see great benefits for time outside work to be spent on training and both further personal and professional development.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report is the European Parliament's response to the road map published in August 2015 on the challenges faced by working families, while maintaining a work-life balance. It raises issues that are important for the family: the demographic crisis, the risk of poverty (including among children), the importance of work-life balance, the condemnation of the culture of continuous availability of workers, the family care of single people and the exchange of good practices in family policy. However, it should be noted that work-life balance is about letting families and other active people find their own ways of sharing time between work and family or time for themselves, rather than introducing more women to the labour market and leaving more men at home, as the report seems to suggest. Moreover, most of the calls for action in the report violate the principle of subsidiarity by interfering with the competences of the Member States. That is why, despite many positive provisions in the report, I abstained.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on "balancing work and family life" is not addressed in terms of workers' needs for more free quality time, appropriate conditions for raising their children, free access to public nurseries, quality care and education or public care services for people in need of assistance, but with a view to maximising the competitiveness - profitability of businesses. It is used for the imposition and generalisation of part-time work with degrading wages, an increase in female – usually underpaid – employment. At the same time unemployment is being punished twice, since it also entails the exclusion of free access for unemployed children to public care structures, as is the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government. Proposals for paternity leave or lengthening maternity leave are a trick, since they are not addressed as a requirement to governments, but as a call to employers to demonstrate "social corporate responsibility" without full pay and social security rights. It is indicative that under the work-life balance programmes thousands of children have been left out of kindergartens. The path of meeting popular needs passes only through the formation of their own social alliance, to overthrow monopolies and to assert their own power and economy.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support this report, even though it contains some good ideas. From my point of view, she was very unbalanced. However, the main reason for my opposition is the problem of subsidiarity – in my opinion, the European Union has no right to intervene in this subject. It is up to the Member States to address such issues on their own at national level.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ The motion for a resolution on creating labour market conditions conducive to work-life balance sought to find the best possible solutions for the increasingly pressing issue of private employment compliance. A great deal of attention is paid to this area at European level, which is clear not only from legislative proposals, but also from various initiatives or reports. Likewise, this resolution deals mainly with demographic problems caused by low birth rates and, as a result, an ageing population. It identifies the need to address these problems and to introduce concrete measures to eliminate gender stereotypes, increase women's employment and, in particular, provide opportunities to take care of the family at the same time. That is why it deals not only with the possibilities of available childcare services or dependent relatives, but also with motivating men to take parental leave. In my opinion, this report contained many positive elements, such as the challenges of paternity leave or the proper recognition of the work of informal carers. However, as it also interfered with the subsidiarity of countries in family policy, I abstained in the final vote.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Zdanoka and Blinkeviciute report because I believe that given the new demographic and socio-economic challenges we are experiencing, a new policy package is needed to promote work-, private and family life balance.  In 2014, 5.1 million children were born in the EU-28, which corresponds to a gross birth rate of 10.1. This fall in the birth rate in the Union has been accentuated by the crisis, as unemployment, job insecurity, uncertainty about the future and discrimination in the labour market are making young people, particularly young workers, put on their parents's level in order to remain active in an increasingly competitive labour market. I would like to highlight, in particular, the call for incentives for businesses and self-employed workers to ensure that people are not economically penalised for having children and that legitimate professional aspirations do not conflict with family planning.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal to create favourable labour market conditions for work-life balance. I support the initiative to increase women's participation in the labour market by modernising and adapting the current legal and EU policy framework to today's labour market.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on "Current developments in Poland and their impact on fundamental rights enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union" (2016/2774(RSP)). I would point out that there is no catch-the-eye procedure in this debate and no blue cards are being adopted.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are supposed to have a debate about our country, and the President announces that we will not even be able to speak out. There are no voting procedures from the chamber, no questions for those who will speak. Is this a debate at all? This debate is supposed to take place in the name of democracy, and there will really be no real discussion beyond the statements of the clubs that we can predict in advance.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: First of all, you have already taken the opportunity to speak here. That is not a problem at all. You also got the floor immediately. Secondly, a debate in this House, which is taking place in accordance with the basic rules of the Rules of Procedure, is a democratic debate. If democracy is only given to you if you draw your blue card here, that is your personal problem. This is a predetermined procedure, which you were very familiar with, and the political groups have agreed, precisely to avoid, honourable Member, that there will be non-objective disputes, to concentrate on the points of the debate, on the opinions of the political groups and not on any spontaneous ideas that any colleagues here might have. That is why we have agreed: no blue cards and no catch-the-eye procedure. This is a normal parliamentary procedure – democratic.

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, since January this year, this is the second time that the Council has been asked to intervene on this issue of the situation in Poland. Let me start by saying that the Presidency, and indeed all of us, agree that the protection of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights in our Union are of crucial importance. Today’s debate relates to the follow-up to the dialogue established between the Polish authorities and the Commission concerning, in particular, the position of the constitutional tribunal and the governance of public media. As the Presidency said here in January, both the independence of tribunals and freedom and pluralism of media are indispensable elements in ensuring the rule of law in a democratic society. The commitment to protecting and promoting human rights is a constant challenge, requiring unwavering attention and effort across the full range of policy areas. This is not the time to be complacent about the protection of fundamental rights. As we all know, the European Union is currently facing multiple interrelated crises. Those challenges test our core values in different ways, including in respect of fundamental rights, be it in the area of migration or internal security. It should be our joint commitment – Member States and the EU institutions together – to ensure that these principles consistently remain a central part of our action. Fundamental rights need to be upheld and defended as our best guarantee for sustainable, open and free societies. In June, the Council stressed the importance of applying the Charter of Fundamental Rights as a part of the wider set of applicable fundamental rights sources in the national context. Also, this year’s rule of law dialogue in the Council focuses on fundamental values in the context of the integration of third-country nationals. The rule of law and the separation of powers are at the heart of the European Union and also of the wider European continent. Our strongest partner, equally engaged in the promotion, protection and development of human rights and the rule of law, is the Council of Europe. In this context, I would like to mention three elements. Firstly, the annual report of the Secretary-General of the Council of Europe on the state of democracy, human rights and the rule of law has just been published, and I am of the view that being committed to the rule of law and fundamental rights also means being open to discussing problems and accepting constructive criticism. It is in that light that the report of the Council of Europe’s Secretary-General is an important contribution. Secondly, the same applies to the report by the Council of Europe Commissioner for Human Rights, published in June 2016 following his visit to Poland and taking into account the comments of the Polish authorities. Last, but not least, the Council of Europe’s guidance, in the form of the opinions of the Venice Commission in this area, is also of great value, and its views should be taken seriously by all Member States. The Council is aware of the situation and of the fact that the Polish authorities are in constant contact with both the Venice Commission and the European Commission. Together they are working on finding a solution to the issues raised. Vice-President Timmermans will update us on the ongoing process and on his contacts with the Polish authorities following the recommendation issued by the Commission on 27 July 2016, and I look forward to hearing from him. The issues at stake go to the heart of our commitment to this Union. We therefore trust that all sides act responsibly and constructively to reach a swift solution that leaves no doubt about our core values.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Honourable Members for putting the recent developments in Poland on the agenda of the plenary today. The last time we discussed the issue of the rule of law in plenary was in January. Today I would like to talk about what has happened since and what action the Commission has taken. As you know, the dispute concerning the composition and functioning of the Constitutional Tribunal led the Commission in January to open a dialogue with the Polish Government under the rule of law framework. We decided to do so because the rule of law is one of the fundamental values on which our Union is founded, as enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty. Respect for the rule of law is also a prerequisite for upholding the full spectrum of EU law, including the proper functioning of the internal market, and for mutual trust throughout the Union. I would like to thank Parliament for the strong support for this position which is expressed in the resolution adopted in April. Very similar concerns were expressed in an opinion of the Council of Europe Venice Commission last March, an opinion, I might add, that it issued at the explicit request of the Polish Government. Since then extensive exchanges at various levels have taken place between the Commission and the Polish Government. In order to set out the Commission’s concerns in writing and to focus the ongoing dialogue with the Polish authorities towards finding a solution in June, the Commission adopted an opinion. Following the opinion in July the Polish Parliament adopted a new law on the Constitutional Tribunal. Despite certain improvements, major concerns remained as regards the composition of the Constitutional Tribunal, the publication of judgments and the effectiveness of constitutional review by the Tribunal. For this reason, on 27 July, the Commission adopted a rule of law recommendation setting out its remaining concerns and recommending how these could be addressed.  The recommendation identifies three main issues: firstly, the composition of the Constitutional Tribunal, as the three judges lawfully elected in October by the previous legislator have still not been able to take up their function; secondly, the publication of all judgments of the Tribunal, which should be automatic and should not depend on any decision of the executive or legislature; and, thirdly, the effectiveness of the functioning of the Tribunal, which should not be undermined by the new law on the Constitutional Tribunal or by any other legislative reform. A functioning constitutional review procedure is also essential for ensuring full respect for the Constitution by other important laws in a wide range of areas which have been adopted by the Polish Parliament. The Commission asked the Polish authorities to address the remaining concerns within three months from the adoption of the resolution. Since our recommendation there have been a number of further developments, which I would like to mention. In particular, on 11 August, the Constitutional Tribunal rendered a judgment holding that a number of provisions of the new law on the Constitutional Tribunal are unconstitutional. However, the Polish Government refuses to recognise the validity of the judgment and to publish it in the Official Journal. Moreover, while the Polish Government has published a number of other judgments rendered by the Tribunal, it still refuses to publish the judgment of 9 March annulling the Constitutional Tribunal Act adopted last December. Therefore I must conclude that, at this stage, the dispute concerning the composition of the Constitutional Tribunal, and respect for its judgments, remains unresolved. That said, the Commission stands ready to continue the constructive dialogue with the Polish authorities in order to find solutions to the issues raised.  To conclude, I would like to thank Parliament for its continuous efforts to uphold the rule of law in the EU and for supporting the Commission’s actions concerning the situation in Poland. I would like to echo what was said by the representative of the Council. Upholding the rule of law is our joint responsibility, one that we all share – the Commission, Member States in the Council, and this House.  (Applause)

name: Janusz Lewandowski
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today it is very important that Poles know and understand what this debate is about and what tomorrow's European Parliament resolution is about. I doubt if they will know the truth from the Polish public media. This is not a debate about Poland, it is not even more a debate against Poland, it is a debate about the abuses of the current power, which pose serious threats to democracy, to the rule of law and ultimately turn against their own society.  (The President interrupted the speaker) Therefore, from the outset, Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent Today, it is important for Poles to know what this debate is about and what the European Parliament resolution will be about tomorrow. I doubted whether they would know the truth from the Polish public media. Well, this is not a debate about Poland or even more so against Poland, it is a debate about the abuses of the current power, which pose serious threats to democracy and civil liberties and thus ultimately turn against their own society.  Poland, understood as a collective work of Poles of the last quarter of a century, is a cause for pride. We have come a long way, from long-standing prejudices to a strong position in the European Union, a strong, dynamic economy and universal respect. Here, too, we have had a great time here, when Jerzy Buzek was the first president of the European Parliament to be elected president of the European Parliament, when 28 governments are represented here by Donald Tusk, head of the European Council, the man from Gdansk, where Solidarity was born.  However, it is not a cause for pride if Poland opens up a list of countries monitoring threats to democracy and the rule of law. It is no reason to be proud if Poland extends the list of European problems and is the addressee of a resolution such as in April this year, when the European Parliament expressed concern about developments in Honduras, Nigeria, Pakistan and Poland. What is wrong cannot be shielded by the mandate obtained in the elections, because poles did not vote for the paralysis of the Constitutional Court, which guarantees compliance with the law, did not vote for purge in the public media.  I would add that no selective publication of the judgments of the Constitutional Court improves this case, and the attempt to prosecute the head, the President of the Court, is completely out of the norms of our world. Poles did not vote in the parliamentary elections for purge in the public media, huge, 190 journalists turned into a tube of government propaganda. Poles did not vote to destroy the civil service and colonize the entire public space according to the principle of "mediocre, but faithful". Poles certainly did not vote for unauthorised interference with privacy and such changes in the law that could lead to abuse of the coercive apparatus, and this is in the hands of ministers who have carried out such abuses in the past. All this is perfectly visible to the democratic world. You can't hide or lie about it.  Today's debate, tomorrow's resolution, are testimonies of concern from real friends Polish. The concern is proportional to the hope that Poland has raised as an anchor of Europeanity in the east. The democratic world reprimanded Poland when bad things happened in the Polish state. Today he admonishes poland as a member of his family. It is admonished in the name of the principles and values inscribed in the Polish Constitution and in the Treaties, but importantly, these principles did not come out of nowhere. They don't come from dogma. They have arisen on a long path of trial and error, where a free society has found systemic principles that insure freedom and enable the organisation of an economy that is sustainable and promises to improve the quality of life. Those who violate these principles at the same time violate the security and future of their homeland.  Today I am speaking on behalf of the largest faction, the Christian Democrats, but I am also the voice of millions of Poles who feel good about a Europe without borders. They are at home, they know and remember the curse of geopolitics or centuries-old Polish loneliness, so they value very much the value of community for our security and our development opportunities. They can distinguish between the patriotism that builds and the nationalism that is ruining and causing many disasters on our continent. They do not want the price for the sins of the rulers to fall on the whole of Poland, so that the achievements of the generation that built the Polish brand are wasted. It is impossible to buy the permission of Poles to make Poland a problem for itself and for Europe through a simple spread of money.  John Paul II, our Pope, spoke to his compatriots in Rome in 2003 that Europe needs Polish, Poland needs Europe. I would add, wisely and Polish in a europe of solidarity. Then and only then will this be the last critical debate and critical resolution on Polish issues in the European Parliament.  (applause)

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the first thing I want to do, on behalf of my group, on behalf of the Polish delegation, on behalf of my colleague Mr Liberadzki, on behalf of my Polish colleagues, is to express our feeling of fraternal, warm friendship to the Polish people. We fight for you. We fight with you, not against you. We are fighting for democracy, which is a supreme good that lies in your hearts, polish friends, and in our hearts.  There is a tendency to reduce fundamental freedoms, to create a kind of a-liberal democracy. There are measures taken by the Polish Government that threaten the rule of law. That is why we have a duty to act. It is easy to make propaganda, too simple to say that the European Commission, Vice-President Timmermans, this Parliament, the majority of this Parliament, are against the Polish people. It's not true, it's a falsehood. Instead, it is the laws adopted by the government that contradict the European Union, of which Poland is an important part.  I say to the Polish Government, calmly: be calmer, have more confidence in your people! You cannot take an entire country hostage to your fears. But what do you have to fear from an autonomous constitutional court? What do you have to hide from the press, what? Why all this police? Have more confidence in the Polish people. Change the Law on the Constitutional Court to make it a once again an independent institution to guarantee the freedom of your citizens. Change the media law and do not try to give the police tasks that it should not have.  In this dialogue with Poland, we wholeheartedly support the action taken by Commissioner Frans Timmermans.

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! I am now turning to the authors of the resolution – unfortunately I have the impression of theatre of absurdity. The European Union is going through the biggest crisis in its history – some say it is fatal – we have Brexit, we have the possibility of other Brexits, immigration, the euro, an increasingly less democratic way of making decisions – and you are organising a debate about Poland. And for what reason? I think that because your political comrades have lost monopoly power in Poland, and it is difficult for you to accept that. When they ruled Poland indivisible and did all sorts of horrible things, it didn't bother you, you were even delighted. You complimented it, suddenly it changed.  But going back to the resolution – the authors write there about a few laws and a few problems, but – I regret it – they have no particular knowledge of it. But they have gigantic prejudices. How do I treat, for example, the allegation that the Minister for the Environment has fundamentally changed the composition of the body, which is in fact an advisory body. Why do you write about it at all? What, the Minister cannot change his advisory composition? Is he supposed to ask you for permission? After all, it's absurd. How should I treat the fact that the authors do not like the fight against the printer's bark beetle, which destroys the Białowieża Forest. After all, most of you have no idea where the Białowieża Forest is, what is the Forest. You don't know anything about it. You don't know what a printer bark beetle is. Where does such a strong view of the fight against the printer bark beetle suddenly come from? Folks, this is not a matter for a majority vote, it is a matter for expertise that is still fraught with the risk of error. Don't pretend you know something about it because you don't know anything. Or how do I deal with comments about amending the Code of Criminal Procedure, where, for example, it is stated that the principle of the presumption of innocence is being infringed. This is crap – there is nothing like that. You don't point to a place where it rains because you can't point to something that's not there. You really need bad will to write such an absurd document. Or the media – the media is, of course, a matter of endless problem that we have been facing in Poland for twenty years. But so with our hand on our hearts, if we compare this media offer that we have now in Poland, this media offer in terms of worldview and politics has never in recent history Polish been wider. No more voices could be heard. Certainly, these voices were not heard when our predecessors ruled for eight years and when they chased down all the defiant journalists. I will say more – I think that this media offer, which is in Poland today, is much wider than what we see in many countries of the European Union, including Germany, Belgium or France. Why do you mind?  Well, I have an answer as to why this bothers you and where all these nonsense in this resolution come from. Because it directs you to a deep prejudice to the Polish Government and to everything that this government represents. The truth is that you are organically incapable of accepting that there may be governments and parties that differ from you and that these views are right. Pluralism in the European Union is such pluralism as in the case of the Ford Model T, where all colors could be, provided it was black. In the European Union, all views are good, provided that these are views in line with the orthodoxy of the European Union. If someone is different from that, you can say anything about it and write anything, if someone agrees with it, can do anything and find absolution here.  And two more words, Mr President, if you will, about the Commission and the European Commission, which is breaking the rules of the Treaties. The rule of law procedure that has been initiated against us is in fact a procedure of non-rule of law, because it is a violation of the Treaties. We asked, my colleagues, to ask the European Commission, on the basis of what studies and legal analyses, proceedings had been initiated against the Polish Government. And the Commission sent us a text which, I apologise for these words, was a complete asemantic gibberish and contained no content. Unfortunately , I serve this text, I serve this text, please. I don't think so. I pointed out to President Timmermans, during the last debate here, that he is using a blatantly false reconstruction of the facts concerning what has happened to the Constitutional Court in Poland, but Mr Timmermans, as is customary, does not respond substantively, but resorted to the wonderful rhetoric that I admire and am full of appreciation – the Lord says beautifully – only that it is unfortunately devoid of substance. The Lord does not respond with arguments. Recently published studies, commissioned by the Polish, by a group of fifteen law professors, on the Court of Justice constitutional law and this whole crisis, which is a serious crisis – I do not deny it. But unlike you, you here, I do not see an easy solution to this crisis. Here, however, goodwill is needed on all sides, and there is no goodwill. This report has been sent to the Council of Europe and has been sent to the European Commission, i.e. the last few hours. I will be very happy if, on behalf of the European Commission, President Timmermans answers all these arguments – but really arguments – because if you want to show off your cicero swashes here, I know you can. But I would like you to really and for you, on behalf of the Commission, to say that these arguments are wrong, that they are right, that it is completely different. I am very much looking forward to such an answer. Finally, I wanted to say something else about the Commission. I say this with regret, because it is not such a thing that easily passes through the mouth, but it must be said. Ladies and see, in the case of Polish, the European Commission usurps three functions: prosecutor, judge and executor – that is, it is doing something that is actually contrary to the legal, political European tradition. Such an accumulation of three functions in one hand is characteristic of European enlightened despotism, and it is, I would say, less and less European, less and less enlightened. But whatever you say wrong about Poland, the standards that are in place in Poland today are much better, much clearer, giving people much more pluralism, not only than what we have heard here today – you just have to put a little effort into getting to know them, you really need to be interested – but also than in many other European countries, including those standards that the European Union has recently wanted to impose.

name: Sophia in ’t Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to say this to our colleague Mr Legutko: I think that eight minutes of filibustering, caricature and ridicule will probably get you a lot of airtime on Polish television, but you are not actually doing anything for the interests of the Polish people. I would like to underline the fact that this debate today is not about Poland, and we have had similar debates about situations in other countries, as you know full well. What this is about, and I will quote the Council Presidency – pay attention because I rarely ever quote the Council Presidency – who said that ‘the issues at stake go to the heart of our commitment to the Union’. That, Mr Legutko, is what we are talking about today. The situation that we are going through might be described as the growing pains of a community of values that is developing. We readily accept that the Commission intervenes in matters of tax evasion, state aid, or disrespect for environmental standards. But then we say – and Mr Timmermans always says – we have to be big on big things. This is big. This goes right to the heart of what the European Union is all about: about the rule of law, about fundamental rights, and about democracy. In this sense, I would give full support to the initiative of Commissioner Timmermans. However, I would like to make one remark because I think that the current situation shows the limits and weaknesses of the toolkit that we have to protect and promote democracy, the rule of law, and fundamental rights. I am glad that, in this House, we are jointly working on a mechanism that will monitor and evaluate all the Member States because I think that we should move beyond the situation in which there are accusations of countries being singled out, or of interventions being politically motivated. Personally, Mr Legutko, you have accused some people here of being politically motivated. You know, we are not in government, so we have absolutely no issue here and no interest. But I think it is very important that the European Union provides itself with a toolkit that will allow us to promote, protect and uphold democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. That includes, in the part of the European Union where this fantastic people, the Polish people, live – and I would wholeheartedly endorse the actions by the Commission.

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is not the first time that the Eu ropean Union has called its states to order when the Rule of Law is in danger: it happened with Hungary, in 2004 it happened with Italy.  Today we are once again giving our opinion on constitutional democracy in Poland. I am talking about constitutional democracy, not democracy, because obtaining a majority at the ballot box does not protect against regression. In Poland, declines are multiplying: the Constitutional Court is unable to exercise full independence, new media laws and counter-terrorism reduce pluralism and data protection.  My group will support the joint resolution and table a number of amendments. We criticise government positions against Muslim migrants and, with the Greens, a government-backed abortion bill: already very difficult, termination of pregnancy risks being banned even in the presence of rape or serious malformations of the fetus. It has been said that we do not have the right to meddle in national policies, neither we nor the Commission, but it seems to me that we are not interfering: we are remembering that there are rules that everyone has signed the Treaties and that are our common law.  The rulers of Hungary and Poland announced a counter-cultural revolution a few days ago which extols Christianity as our only root, the imaginary ethnic identities of states, their semi-absolute sovereignty – the more important it is to respond with this resolution to say what makes us stand together in Europe, if only the market or even the Rule of law and constitutional democracy , both recaptured after the two dictatorships of the twentieth century.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – I only realised how much the understanding of the current Polish Government differs from that of the European Commission when the Prime Minister of Poland came here in January. She made no distinction between the party, the government, the nation and the people. Questions and comments on the new legislation, which restricts judges and silences journalists, were seen by her as a criticism of the citizens of Poland.  This immediately touches on the following misunderstanding: European values, European fundamental rights relate to the individual, sovereignty over one's own body, sovereignty over one's own thoughts, such as the woman's right to have her own body. I would like to say to the current Polish Government: 'You seem to have a different definition of law and sovereignty: the law and sovereignty of the group, of the people. Poland, however, has fought hard for democracy in recent decades. You put an end to a totalitarian system. You took back the right of the citizens. You became a democratic country in a Union of democratic countries. And right now you're going back to work."  Where the law shifts from the individual to the group or the state, people fall between shore and ship. For example, women, half the population. Restricting the right to abortion forces women and girls to commit criminal acts. That is very unwise. And we all know that the number of abortions in a country has nothing to do with the law, but with necessity. The green message to the Polish government is: "You claim to be heir to Solidarnosc. Then you cannot restrict the freedoms of women, of the right or of journalists." And to the Polish people, I would like to say: 'The European Greens will continue to fight for your rights.'

name: Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz
text: On behalf of the EFDD Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Once again, the European Parliament is gathering to interfere in a legitimately elected government and in a sovereign, stable European state. However, you do not have the courage, ladies and gentlemen, to respond to the real challenges facing Europe: when the police are helpless against the squadrons of Islamic terrorists, when other EU countries are fighting the spectre of bankruptcy, when European countries are falling under the flood of millions of illegal refugees, this House intends to discuss the Constitutional Court, of respect for the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which Poland has not signed. Well, I answer all these questions: hands down from Polish! This whole debate is a brutal attack on my homeland. Anyone in this House who has at least a little sense of decency would be ashamed to speak up to instruct my country and my people. We Poles do not need the advice of this chamber, we Poles do not need your comments and talk, because we Poles are able to govern ourselves. You can learn from our Polish history how to fight for freedom and sovereignty, honor and solidarity. Our Polish-Lithuanian Union lasted more than four hundred years, yours will not survive even seventy! It is not Poland that is the problem for Europe's development, but the flawed and damaging policy of the current European elites, led by Mrs Merkel and Mr Holland. Europe is not safe! Europe must wake up!

name: Stanisław Żółtek
text: On behalf of the ENF Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It is true that the two main political forces in Poland – the PiS and OP parties – are trying to gain all the power and, under the guise of the common good, seize the property and freedom of citizens and determine the pecking order. But Union officials were only on the side that is kneeling in front of them. And the institution that steals our freedom the most and fools us with a terrible bureaucracy is the European Union itself. In Poland, I can criticise this government, but here Polish I will just say this: EU Commissioners, you have forgotten where your place is and you want to rule your lords, that is, the peoples that have appointed you through your governments. Take better care of what you have created yourself, which is the influx of the plague of Islamic terror. The resolution should have the same content as the proposal tabled by the Europe of Nations and Freedoms group: the European Parliament considers as unfounded any attempt to interfere in the internal policies of the Member States, including internal affairs Polish, solemnly reaffirms its commitment to the principles of identity and national sovereignty, which create an inseparable unity with the principle of freedom. recalls that the Commission is not a political body but an executive body of the Union and should strictly respect the Treaties;

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – Mr President, those who have put the poland issue on the agenda today are demonstrating that they have not taken up the message of Brexit. The populations of more and more countries are rejecting the fact that the defining rules of their lives are not made by the democratically elected parliament and government, but by a centre in Brussels – more Europe, deeper integration. The Polish Parliament is called to account for decisions which are delegated to national competence by the Treaties. They want to have a say in the organization of the norms of family life. It will not be tolerated that Christian teaching in Poland has a greater social impact than in most countries of Europe. They do not accept it and protest against the fact that they want to sanction public blasphemy. It seems that today in the European Union only the religious sensitivity of Muslims must be taken into account. Poland is constantly referred to as the Charter of Fundamental Rights, as if they did not know that the United Kingdom and Poland had been exempted from its mandatory application in Lisbon. This Parliament has twice dealt with the so-called situation in Hungary, now the situation in Poland. As we have heard from a Communist congresswoman, she rebukes them. I am afraid that if there are still a lot of rebukes and sanctions here – and also for other countries – then you are on the right track to tearing the European Union apart.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me briefly reflect on some of the remarks that have been made. First of all, let me be very clear. If any information pertaining to this issue is brought to our attention, we will carefully study it and reflect on it and take a position on it. We do not disregard any information. If it is academic information, give it to us and we will analyse it and give our point of view.  Secondly, let me reflect for a moment on the nature of the rule of law: why is it so important? It is because we have learned through history, through a very painful history in Europe, that in order to have a democratic pluriform society functioning and the rights of everyone respected, we need the virtuous tripod of democracy, rule of law and full respect for human rights. You cannot give in to the temptation to use one against the other: all three are equally important. And, as an essential part of this, the independence of the judiciary is of extreme importance for respect for individual rights and also for the functioning of our form of market economy. This is nothing to do with politics. Politics can lead the electorate to make a different choice, and then governments make different programmes go in a different direction, but they need to stay within the remit of the rule of law, which is full respect for the position of the judiciary in our Member States.  So, then, this brings me to a number of very precise questions that Mr Legutko clearly does not want to go into. If you accept my premise that the independence of the judiciary is an essential part of respect for the rule of law, how is it that in Poland, the executive can choose whether it wants to publish the rulings of the highest court in the land according to whether it likes the rulings or not?  (Applause) That is not in line with the principle of the independence of the judiciary. Mr Legutko said, just for you, Mr President, that what I am saying is not true, but let me remind him that several rulings of the Constitutional Tribunal have still not been published by the Polish Government. That is a fact, Mr Legutko. Secondly, let me also add that if a parliament decides lawfully to elect members of a court, then the fact that such a lawful election has been followed by other elections does not entitle you to use the new composition of the parliament to undo a legal decision by the previous parliament. So these are the issues we are discussing in a constructive way with the Polish Government. Let me end on one thing which is also a bit personal, I have to say.
