My professional life, from the very start as a student, was focused on bringing an end to the divide in Europe and bringing down Communist dictatorship in half of Europe. The Polish people have achieved that. It is one of the biggest victories in European history, and I will not be accused of acting against the Polish people. This is a dispute between a tribunal and a government, nothing more and nothing less. But let us remind ourselves of the beauty of the victory of democracy and the rule of law against oppression and Communism, and let us not forget that this is the true, true achievement of our common European dream. (Applause)

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I thank all those who intervened today. I will not comment on those interventions but rather I want to reassure you that I will take back with me the strong interest shown in this House for what is, I hope, our common objective of upholding values on which the European Union is built and, above all, the rule of law. I take note of everything. I have nothing to add to my earlier statement on behalf of the Council. I also thank Commission Vice—President Timmermans for an update by the Commission on Poland’s stance in its dialogue, and many thanks to the Commission for reassuring us of its readiness to continue this dialogue. We, as the Council, will follow this and further steps attentively.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: At the end of the debate, three motions for resolutions were tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday 14 September. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Soraya Post (S&D)
text: in writing. – The EU has to promote human rights and defend the rule of law. We have let Hungary under Viktor Orbán slide down the path to autocracy. The combat for human rights and respect for the rule of law must be applied systematically. An Article 7 procedure should be launched against both Poland and Hungary. Human rights can never be cast aside in pursuit of the rule of law, or vice versa. Today women are denied the right to their bodies in Poland and in other EU countries. Recent initiatives taken in Poland are aimed at restricting sexual and reproductive rights even more by completely banning abortion. Article 1 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights states the inviolability of human dignity and the right to physical integrity. The charter clearly states that we women are to be considered as individuals in our own right, free to make our own choices concerning our life, sexuality and health. I call on the European Union to take a clear stand: the developments in Poland, when it comes to fundamental rights for women as well as the rule of law, are in breach of the values of this Union.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union is going through the biggest crisis in its history, and instead of talking about the future of the European Union, a debate is being held about Poland, simply because the political faction that would suit the European Commissioners has taken power in Poland. The resolution on Polish is written so vaguely that it leaves no illusions that it is constructed by lay people with little knowledge of the current situation in Poland and the problems raised by the resolution. The question arises: why? Why is the Białowieża Forest so popular? Everyone today is an expert and wants to advise Poland on how to preserve the Forest, and in their own countries they do not have wilderness, because they destroyed it many years ago. Why does the Commission want to interfere more and more deeply with the exclusive powers of the Polish Government and even usurp the right to choose an advisory panel for Polish ministers? Why is the Commission still rebuying the reform of the Polish media, even though the current programme offer is often wider than that proposed in other EU countries? And because Poland is free for the first time under the rule of Law and Justice, that it has its own opinion, that it is on the side of its own country, its own citizens, it is developing its own economy and gaining international importance, and all this is unacceptable to many Commissioners and Parliamentarians.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, let me first of all say that very often when we are in this Chamber we speak about parliamentary diplomacy and the added value that it brings to our external action, and how important it is for European foreign policy, so let me start today by thanking President Schulz and the AFET delegation, both Elmar and Kati, for the visit you made to Ankara, for the timing, the messages you passed on, and most of all for our close cooperation on our joint visit. I believe that in our cooperation last week, this Parliament contributed enormously to forging and reinforcing our common European position. Together, we send a clear, united, and quite unequivocal message to our Turkish friends, that the European Union is committed to engaging in an intense, open, frank, and constructive dialogue on all issues and to continuing to work together on all strands of our cooperation – from foreign policy to regional crises, from energy to trade, from visa liberalisation to the upgrade of the Customs Union, from migration to counterterrorism. We need especially to work together, openly and frankly, on all issues in these very difficult times. It is a difficult moment for Turkey and we have all seen this. We saw this at  first hand just a few days ago. On Friday we were together with Commissioner Hahn in Ankara. The attempted coup of 15 July risks sending the country back in time to a very dark era of its history. It would have been a dramatic blow to Turkey’s democracy and destabilised the whole region even further, a region that definitely does not need to be destabilised still more. This is why we intervened and I intervened personally in support of Turkey’s democratically elected institutions as soon as I got the news. It was well before midnight, and let me share something with you on a personal note: I personally tweeted. We were in Mongolia with the two Presidents, so it was night-time, and I personally tweeted ‘In defence of the democratically elected institutions’, long before the outcome of the coup or even the dynamics were clear. It was something that we had been thinking about a lot, but we did it without hesitation, well before midnight, and we did it first, before other international partners or actors reacted publicly, because, for us, for the European Union, it is always absolutely clear that there is no space in our world, and in particular there is no space in our region, for any attempt at a military takeover of power.  This is an absolute truth for the European Union that cannot be questioned at any time. Even more so in our region and even more so in a candidate country. So, for us, it was an absolute priority immediately to state clearly that the defence of the democratic legitimate institutions, starting with the parliament that was attacked in those hours, is a priority.  Last week in Ankara we had the high-level political dialogue between the European Union and Turkey. This is an exercise that we do quite often, the last one was in January, and it allows us to cover all the different issues and strengths of our cooperation. This time, however, was an opportunity for us to first of all pass on the message again and to honour the victims of the attempted coup, the people – more than 200 – who died during that dramatic night. Commissioner Hahn and I also had the chance to express our great respect for the Turkish people, first of all, to all the institutions, starting with the parliament, and to all the political parties, which we met, majority and opposition alike, and to applaud them for the way in which they came together that night and the following days to stand up for their democracy. So at this very difficult and delicate juncture we also have made it clear that Turkey must recommit strongly to those principles and values that are at the core of the democracy that the Turkish people protected and defended on the night of 15 July: the rule of law, freedoms, pluralism, including the rights that are at the core of any democracy, not least the guarantee that everybody has the right to a fair trial. Following the entry into force of the state of emergency, a large number of judges and prosecutors have been suspended or dismissed. Warrants have been issued for the arrest of many journalists, and several media outlets have been shut down by decree. It is of the utmost importance that all those who bear responsibility for the attempted coup should be held accountable. But any alleged wrongdoing or crime should be subject to due process, and the right of every individual to a fair trial needs to be respected. All detainees should have access to lawyers and family members, and detention conditions need to be constantly scrutinised. Independent monitoring of trials is essential to ensure due process. All these elements were central to our conversations in Ankara during those days and we very much encouraged cooperation from the Turkish authorities on these issues with the Council of Europe. We ourselves, including me personally, are in contact with our friends and colleagues in the Council of Europe in order to work on these points hand in hand.  Our dialogue, our common work in many fields, can support Turkey at a very difficult moment, and ensure that the choice of the Turkish people in favour of democracy and the rule of law is fully honoured. We both need to reaffirm our partnership, and as partners we need to be open, frank, constructive, respectful and clear to each other. We are doing that and have been doing it in these days of dialogue and the days before; and I am sure that we will continue in this way. I believe that our dialogue can support Turkey at this difficult moment and even help it move forward.  In Ankara we all agreed first of all on one thing: that we have to talk more to each other and a little bit less about each other without communicating directly. Let me mention two issues in particular, on which our dialogue is particularly crucial, two difficult issues. One is the Kurdish issue. It was once again at the core of our meetings in Ankara, both with the government and with opposition parties. I have repeated very clearly – we have repeated very clearly – that the European Union deems the PKK a terrorist organisation and so do all the Member States of the Union. We believe that all violence and terrorist attacks have to end and arms should be laid down. At the same time, we believe that a credible political process should start. Just now we are seeing new clashes in the south-east and the east of the country. As you know, I also had occasion to say yesterday that the suspension of 28 elected mayors and the appointment of trustees is an issue of particular concern. We expect and we are confident that the population of these municipalities will be in a position soon to elect new mayors according to Turkey’s own laws. This is extremely important for precisely those principles of the rule of law and democracy that we discussed with the Turkish authorities a few days ago. The second issue, but linked in a way to the first, as you know very well, is Syria. I know that the number of issues that we could discuss here would be large, and Commissioner Hahn certainly can and will tackle some of them in his concluding remarks, but let me take a few minutes to say that on Syria we agreed during our talks in Ankara on some points that we have not discussed as openly and constructively in recent months.  First of all, we agreed that there is no military solution to the war. This is not a minor issue. It is a relevant issue, especially at a time when a new glimpse of hope, which for the moment is only a glimpse of hope, is opening up with the announcement of a renewed cessation of hostilities on Saturday. We also  agreed that only a political process and a political transition can bring peace and democracy to the country. We agreed on the basic principles that should guide the future of Syria. The territorial integrity of the country, which is not irrelevant at all, far from it. The unity of the country, the inclusion of all parts of Syrian society, the protection of all minorities in an inclusive and non-sectarian state. So despite all the difficulties, we have common ground on which we can work.  I have mentioned Syria. I have mentioned the glimpse of hope that is hopefully opening up. That would at last offer scope for some joint work that we, together with our Turkish friends, could do on, for instance, the delivery of humanitarian aid. And on the facilitation of the political process. We need both elements to start, and you are well aware that these two fields, humanitarian aid and the political process, are the ones in which the European Union can and will play a key role. We are ready. It is the military field which is, shall we say, a little too busy at the moment to enable the political and humanitarian work that is needed, and urgent, to be pursued. So I really hope that all actors on the ground will now open up the space for the political and humanitarian work to start. So despite all the difficulties, both Turkey and the European Union realise that there are many interests that we have in common, many things that our people have in common, and many things that our people share. There is another special issue that I would like to mention which is absolutely key for us, the entire European Union, and on which we have found a clear political will in Ankara to move forward in the direction that we want to see.  We have seen that both the European Union and Turkey, at this moment, are willing to facilitate, to help, to support, to finally reach a solution to  conclude the settlement talks on Cyprus, to bring peace at last to the island, and to send a powerful message of reconciliation to the entire region and, in a way, to the European continent. This is one of the issues which, far from being minor, are central to our discussions with Turkey. I have just mentioned a few of the issues that we have on the table with Turkey. You might have seen that I did not refer to the ones which I am sure will be at the centre of our thoughts: management of the refugee flows, our support to the refugees in Turkey, the visa liberalisation issue, other things that are on hold in the accession negotiation process. These are key elements in our relations with Turkey, but that is not the only point, and we have to keep in mind that Turkey is a candidate country. It is also a key partner in a region with which we share at least some common interests. For all these reasons and many others, our relations cannot be limited to one single issue. To that extent, the accession negotiations provide an excellent framework for a broad dialogue on the entire spectrum of our cooperation. Still, if we really want our dialogue to benefit both of us, our conversation cannot be limited to governments.  If we look at the opinion polls, European and Turkish societies are growing further apart, and that is something which really worries me personally. It is not only the institutions, it is the people. European Union citizens on the one hand and Turkish citizens on the other are seemingly going in opposite directions.  I believe that this Parliament can help us. I believe that Parliament somehow has a special responsibility to keep our ties healthy and alive, frank and open, and constructive and real, through constant dialogue with all Turkish parties, with the Turkish Parliament as such and with Turkish civil society. For us, it was key to meet all the political parties while we were visiting Ankara and to listen to their views on our relations, their views on their country, their views on the political direction of the country, and their views on our joint work. We need to work on our societies. We need to work on our politics, and we need to work on that together. I think that here Parliament is essential. In the long term that is the only thing which will pay off, and I believe that both for the Turkish people and for European citizens it is an exercise worth doing. It is not an exercise in realpolitik, but it is about our own history and the values that we have within the European Union. Dealing as we are with a country that is not only a neighbour, but also a candidate country, it is also about trying to make these difficult times an opportunity to strengthen democracy and the rule of law instead of straying far away.

name: Elmar Brok
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her High Representative, Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has My group is pleased that the military coup has failed. For all the criticism we have from time to time about Erdogan's policies, I think it is important that it is an elected parliament, an elected government that is in office, with which we have to negotiate – also critically – and not military coup plotters. We should make that clear. At the same time, we see that a degree of uncertainty is spreading in Turkey due to the Brotherhood infiltration of the entire state by the Gülen movement, which – certainly through its own fault – is also failing to control the Kurdish problem. We demand that peace talks with the Kurds finally resume and that the HDP be included, but we must say that we also understand that a government that simultaneously has PKK and ISIS acts of terrorism against the civilian population in its own country is in a difficult situation after this military coup and before that. And for that, I believe, we should give Turkey support and understanding.  However, we must ensure that, under the law of emergency, things are handled fairly and in accordance with the rule of law, and here monitoring by the Council of Europe is of great importance. We need Syria for the peace process. We see that again these days. We need Turkey for the peace process in Syria, as we need Iran and Saudi Arabia for it, and we should not destroy that. This is an important country on this issue, as we know. And we need this country in the fight to solve the refugee problems. We need Turkey to end the war, and at the same time it is important that the people who have been there for four years receive support from us, as has now been agreed, through direct aid that the Commission provides to cities and municipalities – for schools and medical care. I do not think we should destroy that. And if the traffickers are no longer involved, if there are no more people dying in the Mediterranean, and fewer people are coming, we should see this in a positive light. We have common economic interests.  Turkey's membership is separate from this. This has its own criteria, and Turkey does not currently meet these criteria, particularly in the area of diversity of opinion and many other issues. But that is another problem. We should not mix this up.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff (ALDE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". – So I would not have taken a blue card if you had not now also highlighted the role of the Council of Europe in your speech; the High Representative has already done so. This is an institution with which we work well and which does a great deal of good. However, the appearance in Ankara by Thorbjorn Jagland, in which he said literally that he understands the 'cleansing' that the government is currently carrying out, contradicts everything we have just heard in terms of the rule of law and contradicts the actual role and mandate of the Council of Europe. Elmar, how do you see that?

name: Elmar Brok (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – ... the translation from Norwegian to Turkish has taken place. What came out of this – the term is certainly not the right one in this context. However, I think it is extremely helpful in this context that the Council of Europe, with its conventions to which Turkey is committed, is carrying out a review and that this is going on in a reasonably decent direction with regard to the question of processes in terms of attitudes, as regards the question – as we have also said to Turkey – that someone should be reinstated in his position. if it is established that it has nothing to do with it. I believe that we should pay attention to this. And I hope that this will be done in a sensible way.

name: Kati Piri
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, after a summer in which the events in Turkey were headline news all over Europe, it is good to have a debate here with Federica Mogherini, High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy and Vice-President of the Commission, on the current situation in that country. It is a lot that the Turkish population has to deal with: more than three million refugees, terrorist attacks on an almost daily basis and, on top of that, a bloody coup attempt on 15 July 2016. That night left a deep impression in Turkish citizens’ minds. The Government said that the temporary state of emergency would not influence people’s daily lives, but so far more than 100 000 people have been directly affected either by losing their jobs or by ending up in a prison cell. It is understandable that, in the aftermath of the coup, a number of measures had to be taken, but the current situation also leaves us very concerned. It is difficult to understand what the link is between respected journalists like Asli Erdogan and the coup plotters. It is difficult to understand what the link is between thousands of teachers and the coup plotters, and it is also difficult to understand how appointing trustees to municipalities and dismissing directly elected mayors is related to the events of 15 July. Turkey can be proud that its citizens massively went out on the streets to defend their democracy that night. It can also be proud that all political forces joined hands in rejecting any illegal overthrow of the democratic institutions. Turkish democracy does have the chance to come out of this situation strengthened: by embracing media plurality, which played a crucial role that night in informing the people; by working together with all political forces on much-needed constitutional reform; and, as a last point, by proving that the rule of law is the guiding principle in bringing the perpetrators to justice. On a final note, I would like to also highlight, on our part, the fact that cooperation with all the EU institutions on Turkey is of great importance and it is important that we keep sending the same messages. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), "blue card" question. – With all these tragic events happening in Turkey, with the violation of human rights, with the issue of the Kurds, with the flattening, in fact, of entire villages, and Turkey entering Syria as an invasive invading force and violating rights but also displacing Kurdish forces and, while taking into account that Turkey does not apply and does not meet the criteria and conditions for the European Union , particularly with regard to respect for the Ankara Protocol on the recognition of the Republic of Cyprus, do you continue to believe that Turkey can be a strategic and critical partner for the European Union? When it unilaterally ignores what the European Union stands for today in terms of principles and values. And one last point, it is well known that an attempt is being made, and I am addressing Mrs Mogherini, to solve the Cyprus problem. The key is in Turkey and, to understand the extent to which the occupied territories depend on Turkey, imposed on the occupied territories .... (The Chair interrupts the speaker.)

name: Kati Piri (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, I think there is one lesson that we must learn: that although we have great concerns about certain developments in Turkey, just shutting the door and thinking that if we do not speak with the government or address the issues, perhaps the next day things will be wonderful in Turkey is not sufficient. I think we have to be realistic here: not talking with one another is not an option. When we talk, we have to do it respectfully. So, I think, yes, Turkey is a valid partner to discuss things with and also a valid partner sometimes to raise our concerns with.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, following the collapse of the peace talks with the PKK (Kurdistan Workers’ Party) last year, the attempted coup earlier this summer and the continued ISIS/Daesh attacks on Turkish soil, there are genuine internal security threats that Turkey does have the right to counter. This right cannot equate, however, with enabling President Erdogan and the AK party to have carte blanche to detain, arrest and remove from office all political opponents at will, under the pretence of fighting terror. Neither can it justify disproportionate military force against the Kurdish civilian population in the south east. As we now see tens of thousands removed from their posts in the army, the judiciary, the civil service, academia and private media outlets, with little due process, such an approach – solely on the basis that they are old Gülenists and terrorists – is very difficult to justify. Commissioner Hahn has even hinted that there is evidence of pre-prepared lists being used in preparing purges following the coup attempt. As we now watch with renewed hope – if not total confidence – in the emerging ceasefire in Syria, I am minded to comment on the recent efforts by Turkey to support the Free Syrian Army in liberating parts of the Turkish-Syrian border areas from ISIS/Daesh. For much of the five-year conflict in Syria, Turkey’s priorities have sadly often be more focused on hindering the efforts of the YPG—PKK alliance rather than those of ISIS, so I hope that this recent development represents an awakening to the supreme threat that ISIS’ jihadism poses to Turkey and the West and a new willingness to collaborate more fully with the US – and now Russian – coordinated coalition to defeat this evil scourge and the threats it poses to the European Union and the western world.

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, I would also like to say how happy we can all be – Turks, Europeans, all – that this coup has failed. There is no doubt that he should be condemned. In this context, I would like to stress, for once, the opposition in Turkey and its role. It is remarkable that Kemal Kuldaroslu and his CHP were present at the rallies. It was not easy to see that in the past we had a trusting cooperation between the government and the opposition. So in this respect, this is an important step in the right direction.  Mrs Mogherini, you have described our dialogue in many words: intense, open, honest and so on, and also respectful. I think it is a question of honesty and respect that one thing is being admitted, which is that the accession process has failed. You have identified areas in which we can cooperate. They are all the subject of the accession process, but we are not getting off the mark. You mentioned the fight against terrorism, you mentioned the customs union, the modernisation of the customs union, the refugee issue; we could also talk about cultural and scientific exchanges, we can talk about tourism, about environmental policy. I think it is time to treat each other with respect and replace this failed accession process with a fundamental treaty, with a new positive agenda that is much broader and much more practical than this process, which has ultimately led to bitterness on both sides and to a decline in our relations. We have been negotiating for eleven years; relations have not improved during this period, but have deteriorated. Let me mention one final point, which is important to me and which also has to do with respect: we can expect the Turkish side to expect the internal political conflicts that are to be fought there and which must be fought there, to be fought there as well. I do not want to have situations like the one in Cologne, where AKP supporters and Gülenists are clashing, as we see in many German cities, but also in the Netherlands and other countries. I believe it is very important that the Turkish embassies and consulates act in this direction on their interlocutors in our Member States of the European Union.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – First of all I would like to say to my friend Lefteris Christoforou that his question was fair but should not have been submitted to Mrs Piri. It should have been submitted to Mr Brok. Because Mrs Piri was the only one who criticised here what is happening today in Turkey. I understand that what is happening in Turkey today is really a very complicated matter and I understand mrs Mogherini's difficulty as well. But while the European Union and its representatives behave as representing a soft power, a leafy European Union, it is natural to choose with Turkey in a way that makes it easier. It makes it easier for President Erdogan to continue his anti-democratic attitude towards his citizens rather than showing him the right way. It has already been said that 100,000 people have left their jobs; some 3,000 judges have been expelled from their jobs, as have more than 2,000 academics and more than 130 journalists. We cannot, while we are discussing Poland, rightly, in a very strong way criticising what is happening in the country, do the exact opposite when it comes to a country that is in the process of negotiating accession. The Kurdish issue, a huge issue, with 500,000 displaced people inside the country itself, and the attack in Syria, another terrible issue, where in the end what do we have? We have a replacement for the people of ISIS who changed uniforms and have now become people of the so-called free Syrian army. I close with a phrase on the Cyprus issue because there is a debate on guarantees. How can Turkey demand that the Turkish army guarantee the democracy of Cyprus when this Turkish army cannot guarantee democracy within Turkey itself?

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, I would like to thank Mrs Mogherini for her work and for her work First of all, I would like to thank you for once again so clearly condemning the failed coup and leaving no doubt as to what the European Union's attitude is towards these coup plotters. I believe that it is also self-evident that we in the European Union should support the persecution and enlightenment, the persecution of those responsible for the coup and for more than 100 deaths, for many injured and also for the devastation in Turkish society. However – and you have already made this very clear, and I would like to emphasise this for us – this persecution of the rule of law must be appropriate. And what we have been seeing in Turkey since the coup is no longer appropriate; this is a far from the rule of law. As true as some of Mr Lambsdorff's questions are, after decades of mistakes by the European Union in series in the Strategy for Turkey, we must not make a mistake now, and that in this acute situation we must throw the child out with the bath and say: everything must be completely different. In this acute situation, it is precisely the people of Turkey, who have always referred to us and the European process, who expect us to stand up for the rule of law. We need dialogue, we need all the means of dialogue to protect people, to demand the rule of law. For me, too, it is becoming more important every day to advocate a return to the peace process. The military escalation towards the Kurds, which is now being intensified under the pretext of fighting ISIS, cannot continue in this way. We have always supported the peace process; this is the second major issue for which the European Union must make use of all its relations. You have described the position very sensibly, and I think you have the support of my group for that.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, how far can realpolitik go? In our relations with Turkey, it has gone too far. We strongly condemn the coup d'état attempted by the army, but in the same firmness we condemn the successful coup d'état against Erdogan: 100 000 purges in the public administration, 43 000 detainees, 2 100 closed schools and universities, 3 500 judges and magistrates removed.  While we are debating, Turkey, on the pretext of targeting terrorism and ISIS, is instead attacking the YPG, those brave Kurds who have fought for months and years, and putting at the head of operation 'Euphrates Shield' a character like Adnan Tanriverdi, an Islamist who is also suspected several times of radicalism.  When, in our talks, are we really going to put a stake on Erdogan? When are we going to call into question an accession that has now finally failed? Erdogan's Turkey has replaced the rule of law with the law of the state, Europe the state of reason with the reasons of some states, and we call on this Parliament to say no to Turkish blackmail and to return to europe for once.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, you are now disconcerted by the Turkish geopolitical shift. Most of you were warm supporters of Turkey's entry into the Union. You have dreamed of a Turkey that never existed, you are facing the reality of Turkey. The reality is Mr. Erdogan, the man of thousands of political cleansings, the man of eliminations without trial, the man of the Kurds under the bombs, of support for Daesh. We need to speak to Turkey in a frank and firm way. This is what Russia understood with stabilizing action in the Middle East. To do so, accession negotiations must be stopped, otherwise your Parliament will legitimize false hopes and give its support to the satrap Erdogan. Stop negotiating Turkey's accession with your billions of euros.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Mr President, Turkey has always been a country that violated the principles of democracy and the rule of law. Recently, under the pretext of the coup, President Erdogan has openly become a dictator within the country, while on the international stage he is endangering peace in the Middle East. Recently, Turkey invaded Syria. In other words, he did what his predecessors did 40 years ago by invading Cyprus, much of the territory of which they illegally occupy even now. What is the European Union's attitude towards Turkey's behaviour? Phobic, sluggish, compliant and Turkish- While we have an opportunity to press Turkey to be consistent with its international obligations, we tolerate it not recognising the Republic of Cyprus, blackmailing the European Union with the issue of granting visas to its nationals, criticising the European Union for not giving it subsidies in time, and finally flooding the Greek islands with illegal immigrants.  Does the European Union have the courage to change its policy towards Turkey? If not, an unacceptable situation will be sustained that reduces and ridicules the European Union in the eyes of every serious person. Do you know what happens every day on Greek islands? Syrians, Afghans, Pakistanis and other nationalities fight each other, stab themselves, injure themselves, rape women and intimidate the local population. And I ask, how long will the Greek people tolerate this unacceptable situation? If the inhabitants of the islands get their hands on the law, as they threaten, what will happen? Are we ready to face such a crisis? If not, then please press Turkey. It's not hard. It's very easy.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would first of all like to strongly condemn the coup attempt that took place in Turkey in July. The fact that this attempt to take power through violence has failed is something we must welcome. Because, obviously, in a democratic state, violence cannot in any way replace the voice of the ballot boxes. No one knows, however, whether this is the end of attempts to take power in Turkey, other than democratically. Beyond that, I would like to express serious concern about how this failed coup was used to settle a number of political accounts. Of course, those who have tried to take power by force must be sent to justice. But there is nothing to justify using this pretext to eliminate political opposition, to hunt down teachers, journalists, ordinary Turkish citizens described as terrorists. Turkey must respect freedom of expression and association. I believe that our Turkish friends need to be clear that we will not give up any of the conditions for visa liberalisation. Turkish citizens will have the right to travel freely within the Union when all 72 criteria are met by the authorities.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We feel friendly with the people of Turkey. That was the case, and it still is today. Turkey is an important NATO partner, Turkey is an EU accession state, many millions of Turks live in our countries and also help us to maintain our prosperity. I understand the shock, the outrage of the people there about the attempted coup. Turkey has a right to protect itself, including against the terror of the PKK. But not every means is allowed; Proportionality, the rule of law and the protection of minorities are in demand. The freedom of the media and Parliament must not be compromised. We can use our accession negotiations with Turkey to talk about these things and to help those who want to bring about a democratic, a liberal-minded Turkey. If we had opened Chapters 23, 24, it might have been a little easier. However, I think there is one point that We must also make clear: in an hour of really bitter hardship, it was the Kurds, the Peshmerga, who left and freed people. And we must not forget that today, whatever Raison. These are also our friends for which we have to stand up.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: Mrs Mogherini, as democrats, of course, we all condemn the failed coup. But let's call a cat a cat. Erdogan will commit his own internal putsch after July 15. His purges and his prosecutions are without measure, excessive and unreaccountable. The fact that Europe welcomed the 'salvation of democracy' after the failed coup attempt is therefore particularly cynical. I have not forgotten that Erdogan recently sang the praises of the approach to Nazi Germany. You don't have to be a great historian to see the similarities between the events of the 1930s and those now in Turkey. The free media had already largely sidelined Erdogan before, and now his hard hand extends even to my own country. The Flemish-Turkish newspaper Zaman Today stopped at the end of August because of the pressure on readers, advertisers and especially on journalists. This has never happened before in Flanders, in my own country, and that is unacceptable. I repeat what I said here before: by waving an EU member card for Turkey, we have put our democratic foundations of the Union at risk. Anyone who shows the characteristics of an autocracy deserves no prospect of accession. We forget our principles and we balance on a limp cord, because we need Turkey. It's going to break us down in the end.

name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, first of all, the relations between Turkey and the European Union and the Member States should be governed by facts and not by all kinds of emotions. This means we should be clear that everybody who has a role in the EU, its institutions or the Member States has denounced the coup d'état. There was no sympathy for it at all and there was a direct reaction. Happily, today we see that both members of the opposition – of the democratic opposition in Turkey – and also some government representatives have come to the conclusion that there was some overreaction, and that the process of dealing with the aftermath of the coup d'état and bringing to justice those who committed it, or are thought to be involved in it, should be governed by independent judges and by the rule of law. That is vital. Secondly, Turkey is an important neighbour of the European Union, and is a NATO partner, irrespective of the whole discussion about membership. This means that visa liberalisation should be subject to the criteria set. If they are met, liberalisation will follow. If not, it will take more time. No deadlines should be applied. The same goes for the membership issue. Let us also come to the conclusion that the visa deal is on. It is good both for Turkey and for the European Union. The Turkish Government should do everything possible to prevent people who sympathise with Erdogan or Gülen taking to the streets in the Netherlands and in Germany: such activity should be stopped. And we should keep calm and have a constructive talk with Turkey.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I give a voice to The Kurdish Member Dilek Acalan: she and the rest of her colleagues can be arrested at any time by the Turkish police. In an email sent yesterday, he tells us about the bombing of Kurdish civilians, the offensive against the HDP, the arrest of one of its vice-presidents, the dismissal of 11,500 teachers; authoritarian drift, in short, from Erdogan. I regret that the Council is once again absent, so I will urge the Commission to do much more in the face of this massive violation of fundamental rights and freedoms by one of its main partners. If we don't, the words will sound hollow at this point. Being concerned is useless if we don't do something real and effective in the face of the planned devastation of Kurdish towns and cities. With all due respect, Mrs Mogherini, going to Ankara doesn't seem enough to me. Review the aerial photos of Sur, in Diyarbakir, and you'll understand it much better.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would also like to begin by condemning the attempted military coup that Turkey was subjected to last summer. No matter what I think of the Turkish President's way of leading the country, he is elected and it should be respected. I also condemn all forms of violence. Both the violence perpetrated by President Erdogan's opponents and the psychological and physical violence the President is now exerting against all his opponents. The methods we have seen during the summer feel closer to the Middle Ages than the twenty-first century.  I cannot accept journalists being detained, judges and teachers dismissed, given travel bans, etc., etc. The president crosses all boundaries in his pursuit of opponents. Most recently, he has taken over power in 28 municipalities that are also governed by democratically elected people. 24 Kurdish mayors and four from the Gülen movement. He himself shows no respect for the rules of democracy, but expects to be respected himself. It is now more important than ever that we show that we are clearly on the side of democracy in Turkey, and democracy also includes respect for human rights.

name: Raymond Finch (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the EU is pandering to a country which is sliding ever closer to barbarism. The fact that this project is bribing Turkey with EUR 2.2 billion of EU taxpayers’ money, in a desperate bid to stem the migrant crisis of its own making, is a total political, economic and human disaster. To stem this migration, the EU was willing to bend over backwards and ignore the war on the Kurds, the smuggling of oil from ISIS and the continual destruction of human rights in Turkey. Instead of dealing with the real issues of the Schengen zone and Ms Merkel’s insane open doors policy, the EU is choosing to believe that a coup was attempted, when in reality it was set up by the Turkish Government to crack down on internal dissent. I am only glad that we in the UK are getting out of the EU while we can, because this policy is madness. The cowardly, self-delusionary posturing of the EU towards Turkey is an utter disaster, and the accession process must end soon. It is an offence against both human rights and democracy. You are simply enabling a totalitarian regime, Ms Mogherini. Halt all talks now and stop giving bribes to them.

name: Μανώλης Κεφαλογιάννης (
text: PPE). Mr President, 15 July was a difficult day for the Turkish Republic with hundreds of innocent victims. The attempt to break up democracy, and indeed with arms, is absolutely reprehensible to all, I hope, the democratic citizens, of all the Members of the European Parliament. But what happened the next day does not honour democracy, it shows a lack of democracy in Turkey. The Turkish authorities have carried out an incredible series of prosecutions and dismissals on military, judicial, civil servants, journalists and the media. An endless list of arrests, as if she'd been ready for a long time. But Turkey-European Union relations are also deteriorating and distrustful. For Turkey, the refugee agreement is equal to the abolition of visas for Turkish citizens. The fulfilment of the prerequisites, the European principles and values, the Republic is in second place. Either the visa waiver will go ahead, or there is no agreement on the refugee issue. Europe's response must be unanimous, firm and lasting. Europe respects friends and partners. But Europe is not threatened, it is not blackmailed, it does not discount principles and values. This must be understood by everyone.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I have to confess that I heard some of my colleagues speaking realpolitik, a lot of it in a quite cynical way, but saying very little, if anything, on principles and values. Turkey is a candidate country and it has to guarantee high standards on human rights, freedom of expression and the rule of law. Turkey took steps towards democracy and secularism many decades ago and has strengthened its position as a credible and powerful actor on the international scene. But this also implies external and internal obligations and responsibilities towards all its citizens – I repeat all its citizens – and international partners. Otherwise we must realise here today that, after the failure of the coup d'état, which we all condemned, Turkey has chosen lately to undermine its commitments. Since the coup attempt, the Turkish Government has overseen a vast purge. More than 100 000 people have been dismissed or suspended from their jobs and many others have been detained. Therefore I call on Turkey to respect the right to justice and to a fair trial for all its citizens and for the foreigners living in Turkey. Turkey is facing a wide range of threats, including terrorism, in relation to which cooperation between Europe and Turkey is fundamental. Finally, another very important aspect is that Turkey is a key actor in finding a political solution for Syria in the fight against ISIS and in the management of the Syrian crisis and refugee flow. I urge Turkey to play a constructive role and to change its behaviour for good.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: – This morning I spoke on the phone with a Turkish citizen about the situation in his country. He painted a grim picture of a totally poisoned social climate. You'd only be accused of being a Gülenist for whatever reason. Then the prison gates open for you. Sadly and at the same time alarmingly, the same political accusation (Gülenist) is causing enormous unrest and division among the Turkish diaspora in EU Member States, including in my country, the Netherlands. Because, as it turns out today: Erdogan is influencing the Turkish diaspora in Europe in a way that is unprecedented. His main instrument for this is the Diyanet, the presidium for religious affairs. Instead of the candidate country Turkey implementing European political principles, the EU now faces the implementation of Erdogan's Islamist views on its own territory. And in passing, Erdogan continued to push for visa-free travel of Turkish citizens to the EU, probably successfully. Then Erdogan is the hero of the home front and the diaspora. A striking illustration of the bankruptcy of The European Turkey policy.

name: Marietje Schaake (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the despicable coup in Turkey was rightly condemned and today we stand with the people of Turkey, but I fear that the national unity we see will be short-lived. Turkish democracy needs deepening and needs to be meaningful. Yes, the perpetrators should be brought to justice but in fair trials and with proportionate measures, and that excludes the death penalty. Let us be clear: the measures we now see after the failed coup and the anti-terror laws are being abused for disproportionate cleansing and silencing of critics. The rule of law was, is and will remain our Group’s key priority. The fact that Gülenists and the AK Party together built an illiberal coalition for so long and the Government now accuses the Gülenists of this coup is a confirmation of a breakdown of accountability, checks and balances and transparency. We must work with Turkey on security measures; trade and people-to-people relations are strong; but let us not narrow the relationship to the toxic migration deal or the crippled accession talks. Turkey needs tough love. ‘Friends tell each other the truth’ goes the old Turkish saying, and we should remind them of that and build our relations on our own principles.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President. Grazie, signora Mogherini, per essere cui, un'altra volta. Always good. Too much for a minute, but let's try it. He condemns without palliatives the coup d'aqueal of 15 July and full support for the Turkish people, parties and society, who were able to react and overcome the situation created, even paying a high price in lives. But everything that happened next worries us. The repression of groups that constitute the democratic skeleton of any society is incompatible with any possibility of rapprochement, of understanding, between the European Union and Turkey: teachers, mayors, judges, journalists...  The fight against the Islamic State, which we all share, is now confused with military actions aimed at the whole territory and the Kurdish population. The European Union-Turkey relationship has therefore entered a new phase, believe it or not. Turkey has, it seems, taken another strategic option about its role in the region and its alliances. We are now focused solely on interest management, some as important as the refugee issue. The European Union must decide with serenity and clarity what can remain the same and what should be reviewed of the position held so far. In any case, we must strengthen contact with Turkish citizens, parties and entities to work and regain the democratic pulse lost in the country with which we want to maintain friendship and the shared future. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Dear Colleague, You are saying that it is necessary to put it on a new footing or, in a sense, to change it, to open a new chapter in the negotiations with Turkey. An hour or two ago, here in this chamber, we debated the violations in Poland, and I can say the same for my own country, Hungary. In your opinion, there are two types of standards, i.e. we send a clear message to Turkey, but not within the European Union.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" response. – It is precisely the opposite, Mr Szanyi. What we must do, I believe, is to maintain a single criterion and a single assessment of our behaviours, our attitude and our democratic demand to our own Member States, as well as our friends, or in our relations with third countries; turkey, especially. It's time not to go on as if everything is the same, it's not business as usual, you don't have to keep negotiating access simply. We must consider the whole situation and make the appropriate decisions with the serenity, with clarity, with which Mrs Mogherini is doing so.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, the European Union has been negotiating with Turkey for decades about its accession to the EU, yet Turkish President Erdogan has completely different ideas about law and democracy than we do. His sweeping purges in education and the judiciary consolidate his power after the military coup. He wants to introduce the death penalty and take revenge on his enemies. Turkey, our supposed ally in NATO, is slaughtering Kurds in a neighboring country who are trying to fight the greatest evil of our time – the Islamic State. So you are negotiating with such a country to join the EU, and half an hour ago you had the ausage to criticise Poland again for allegedly endangering the rule of law. Aren't you ashamed at all?  Mr Schulz legitimised Erdogan's government with his visit to Turkey last week. Do you really want Turkey in the EU? You want Turkey in Schengen? Do you want 100 Turks to sit in this hall and vote with us on migration policy, on men's and women's rights? Turkey is not in Europe and does not belong to the EU, and I therefore call on the European Council to immediately end negotiations with Turkey on EU membership.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, let us be clear: the failed coup on 15 July 2016 was an attack against democracy, in which 265 people lost their lives in front of tanks. I regret that the EU was slow in denouncing the coup and in supporting the elected Government. It is imperative now to stand by the people of Turkey and show understanding for the trauma they went through. It is also important that the rule of law and human rights are fully respected, while bringing those responsible to justice, and, of course, important to remain firm on freedom of expression. But it is by engaging with Turkey that we will achieve results towards democracy. By just condemning and criticising emotionally we are adding fuel to the fire and polarising people. It is time to intensify dialogue with Turkey on all issues of common concern. That is why it is urgent to relaunch the joint commission with Turkey, which has been blocked for two years, on an open agenda post coup. The best way to advance reforms in the judiciary and fundamental rights is to open Chapters 23 and 24. Turkey is not backing away from the migration deal and neither should we. We should not punish children and women because of Erdogan. I welcome the Commission’s decision to disburse meal cards for the three million refugees who are welcome in Turkey but not everywhere in Europe. Visa liberalisation should be a merit-based process with no double standards against Turkey. Again, we have to engage with Turkey to break the deadlock on the terror law and move forward. Turkey is a crucial partner for us. We need to restore trust and to build bridges. We cannot afford to let the people feel let down. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), blue card question. Mrs Bildt, I have a very specific question for you. I am following you here in the European Parliament and my question is very simple: Have you heard in recent months about the thousands of judges who have been dismissed? Have you heard of the thousands of teachers who have been fired on suspicion of collaborating with terrorism? Have you heard of the invasion of Syria? Have you heard of the occupation of Cyprus? I can report more. Do you think there is a rule of law in Turkey? Can someone have a fair trial in Turkey? Answer us directly.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I said in my intervention very clearly that the rule of law and human rights should be respected and that we have to remain firm on freedom of expression. I did not say that there is rule of law at the moment in everything that is happening in Turkey. What I am saying is that, in order to achieve results in a country that is absolutely crucial for the European Union, and to make sure that the people of Turkey do not feel let down by Europe, we need to engage in dialogue. By just criticising, attacking and condemning a proud nation we will not achieve results. Will that make it more democratic? No.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we should all agree with the strong words of the High Representative against the failed coup in Turkey but we must insist that our support for elected governments is not interpreted as legitimising every action of this government, just as our support for due process for alleged coup plotters from the Gülenists should not be interpreted as political support from Europe for their movement. Ms Mogherini, the removal of elected mayors from the Kurdish HDP party is more than a matter of concern. It is quite simply a different sort of coup, and it repeats the actions taken in the actual coup of 1980. Europe must stand resolute on Turkey amending anti-terror legislation if we are to make progress on visa liberalisation – legislation which the UN has said denies due process and targets human-rights defenders. Finally, a coup is the ultimate attack on democracy, and Christian Democrats must drop their opposition to opening negotiating Chapters 23 and 24 on democracy. If you do not see that now, frankly, you never will.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, for the imminent derailment of the situation in Turkey, I personally sounded the alarm in this Chamber as early as January. At the time, a colleague, using the blue card, had asked me for a milder treatment and, unfortunately, that was the attitude chosen by the European Union. What does this colleague and his like-minded people have to say now? Now that the regime in Turkey is accelerating its path towards totalitarianism? All this at the same time as the European Union continues to silence Ankara. To tolerate human rights violations, the war against the Kurdish people, the invasion of Syria, the blackmail of the refugee agreement, which has not been respected since the coup. A coup that the European Union denounced only when it had become apparent that Erdogan had prevailed. At the same time, the European Union continues to tolerate the continuing violations of international law by Turkey. To monitor inert violations of Greek airspace by the Turkish air force. The Islamization of world heritage sites, such as Agia Sofia, and the continued occupation of 37% of Cyprus. The European Union must find ways, immediately, to force Turkey to respect international law and human rights.

name: Nedzhmi Ali (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, as European partners of Turkey we have to repeat again our condemnation of the July coup attempt. This coup was a test for Turkish democracy. The reaction of the Turkish people deserves our solidarity and support. Despite the turmoil in the country, the government institutions are continuing to function properly, thus guaranteeing the existence of democratic society. Together with Turkey we are in a complex geopolitical situation, we are pressed by the same challenges and we have a set of common interests. The problems can be handled by acting together. This inevitably means increasing all aspects of our cooperation. The accession negotiations with Turkey must continue, raising the level of constructive dialogue. The process of visa liberalisation should be accelerated, thus improving trade relations and providing for economic growth and employment both in the EU and Turkey. We should not forget that Turkey has been sheltering more than three million refugees for over four years, having spent more than EUR 8 billion to sustain these people. Do we abide by our commitment to provide financial resources to support the efforts of our Turkish partners? Finally, on the subject of migration pressure, are we doing enough to protect the external border of the Union – as in the case of my country, Bulgaria, and of Greece – in order to keep the internal borders open?

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, many colleagues have said the situation is grave, and I will not repeat that, but a lot of Members have also said that Turkey is a strategic partner – but what is that actually? Turkey is not just a president. Turkey is not just a government. It is the people who live in Turkey: the people who defended democracy on the streets in Turkey. It is the people who demonstrated for their rights in Taksim Square and elsewhere. It is the journalists who are trying to do their job, actually. It is the transgender people who are fighting for their rights. It is the Kurds who are looking for some sort of cultural rights as well, and it is the neighbours who are helping Syrian and other refugees. Those are our strategic partners. Those are the people we should work with, those are the people we should support and should welcome and should be open towards. That is what should be our task: not to see Turkey as one person or just one government. Turkey consists of many people, who have different ideas, and we should not only ask that this diversity is recognised, we should also recognise it ourselves.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE)
text: – The events of this summer have shown the need to discuss and define our relations with Turkey. The attempted coup has shown that Turkey has problems that we can hardly predict. The post-coup situation tends to rein in authoritarian tendencies: thousands of arrests, dismissals, cleansing in the judiciary, academia, civil service and secret services. All of this indicates which direction Turkey may be heading. I believe that we should remain principled. We should be concerned about the state of democracy in Turkey. Concerned about the state of the rule of law and the civil liberties being seised. We have cause for concern about the further development of our relations. In doing so, however, we must not forget that Turkey is our partner, the country with which we are conducting accession negotiations. We are also partners in security and defence matters, but also on migration, for example. And it is on these foundations that we should build our partnership. However, we must be clear about the principles on which we want to develop our relations. We need to set clear limits on what is acceptable to us in this partnership and what is already crossing borders. I feel that it is high time for this, because we are now beyond many limits. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would like to express my sincere thanks to Mr Kukan, because, of course, the debate is now very much about the visa-free regime, and that is why My question is: is the visa-free regime really designed in such a way that it does not constitute a permanent residence permit or a work permit, and also in such a way that, after the normal period, the return to Turkey is guaranteed again accordingly?  I believe that this is something that is highly discussed in public and where we need clarification.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I listened very attentively but I did not hear any questions so it is difficult to answer.

name: Presidente. –
text: The question was clear: how do returns work.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – Like the European Union, Turkey is at a crossroads. The country is facing so many problems that Turkish President Erdogan cannot be blamed for trying to extort certain concessions from the European Union at the expense of the refugee problem. As well as resenting the leaders of the Union and the Member States for trying to secure refugee peace with money. However, our citizens will be very resentful if, in the current situation, we completely forget the fact that Turkey has chosen a road at this juncing, on which it is increasingly moving away from democracy and respect for human rights. If Turkey does not qualify for visa liberalisation, it cannot happen. The rules are clear. And it is hard to see why President Erdogan is taking an authoritarian approach with little dialogue with which his citizens are taking away their freedom.  And while we are dealing with Turkey, the movements are already taking place in other neighbourhoods, such as Egypt. If we overlook them, it may soon be possible for the Union to slip at a crisis juncing.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I fully share the criticism made here of the Turkish Government's policy. However, criticism of the critics is also appropriate: all too often today, Turkey has been equated with Erdogan. Even if the propaganda images and the seas of red flags in Istanbul, Ankara, Berlin and Düsseldorf suggest otherwise – there is also Turkey of the democrats, there is also Turkey of the enlightened, and there are many Turks to whom The Policy of Erdogan is contrary. Instead of just criticising or courting Erdogan because German refugee policy has made us blackmailed, we should back those in Turkey who are committed to a different Turkey.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: – Mr President, last autumn I visited Rodjaava, a territory in northern Syria controlled by the Kurds. I was a guest of command of the People's Defense Units known by the acronym YPG. With their armed forces, I drove several hundred kilometers through Rodjava. I visited the town of Kobani destroyed by IS forces. They were mainly Kobani defenders who tried to liberate territory west of the Euphrates from IS earlier this year. Their assault failed thanks to the intervention of the Turkish army, which crossed the Turkish-Syrian border for the first time in the conflict and openly bombed the position of Kurdish forces. Turkey has escalated the conflict so dangerously. Turkey's intervention is further proof that Turkey cannot rationalize its national policy. It is developing a spiral of national hatred even on its territory. He does not understand that Kurdish terror is a response to the unprecedented anti-Kurdish state terror.  Turkey justifies anti-Y10 armed raids at home and in northern Iraq and into Syria by pointing to the fight against terrorism. He also justifies his progress ideologically by pointing to Marxist forms of terrorism. Indeed, the Kurdish resistance is broad-spectrum, but its ideological labeling is only a manifestation of Turkey's weakness. The YPG have red stars on their work, but they are not suing for a bright communist future, but for their physical survival. Democratic forces in Turkey should be aware of this.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It has often been stressed today that the situation in Turkey is extremely worrying in terms of democracy, the rule of law and human rights – not only the coup attempt, but also the excessive response to it. The situation is particularly problematic in south-eastern Turkey, where civil war-like conditions have prevailed since the end of 2015. Just two years ago, many people inside and outside Turkey had high hopes for the peace process between Erdogan and the PKK. There has been great progress, and it is a tragedy that this process has come to a halt. There have been cruel consequences: deaths and injuries, many lives, destroyed cities, deprived livelihoods, and now – as a mockery – the removal of elected representatives, mayors and local politicians in the region. I remember the conversation with a mayor of Surué in November last year, who was also removed, and who, in that conversation, stressed to me the importance of the peace process in Turkey. I hope that we will be able to start again.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Dear Mrs Mogherini, honourable members, your policy towards Erdogan is completely wrong and shows a profound ignorance of the situation in the country and the region. The illegal occupation of northern Cyprus continues, which is inherently an annexation of foreign territory. The crushing of freedom of speech, citizens' rights, ethnic cleansing in Diyarbakir and eastern Anatolia continues to support Islamic State. The coup in Turkey succeeded. Looks like only you and some of the colleagues here didn't understand. Dividing dictators into "good" and "bad," dividing the annexation of foreign territories into "good" and "bad" is severe political hypocrisy. Erdogan's agreement on illegal immigrants is a grave political mistake because it lends itself to blackmailing a dictator. Visa liberalisation with Turkey is unreasonable because it will flood Europe with millions of illegal immigrants. I demand an end to the negotiations taking place on Turkey's membership of the European Union, because Turkey today is not a European country and has no place in this European Union, not sharing the values that we all claim to profess and share.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by There are no ready-made scenarios. We only realize that among those scenarios that are – they are more or less expensive. And this can also be seen after today's debate. We know that we have at least three serious costs. The first is trust: you can see how much Turkey has lost as a result of not so much the attack as the reaction to the attack. The second thing is very important and the second important cost, that is, the cost of time. Now will take time to return to the state of negotiations, especially the atmosphere from a year ago or even two years ago. The third significant cost concerns safety. Turkey is an important component not of the European but of the global security-building system. An extremely important ingredient. The loss of confidence, the need to return to the negotiations, which are so difficult at the moment, seems to be the most serious challenge for the Commissioner as well. Finally, I would like to say one thing: if we convert earlier optimism into scepticism, into realism, then there will be a chance of success. If we turn this into pessimism, it will be a disaster.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I really want to say that, day after day, the situation in Turkey is reminding me and other people of my age, who lived in the socialist system, of the days of the beginning of Stalinist terror. But I suppose that, now, we are able to learn from history and to stop this development in Turkey. The world listened last week to the outcry of Noble Prize winner Orhan Pamuk, who said that Turkey is, day after day, moving further from the rule of law towards a terror regime – and, really, that is what we have to bear in mind, the fact that Orhan Pamuk and intellectuals and democrats in Turkey need our help. They are looking to us. We understand that Ms Mogherini, as High Representative of the Union for Foreign and Security Policy, has to do her job, and she is doing it with great dignity, but she has her limits. We as a parliament do not have such limits. We have to send a high-level fact-finding mission, consisting of representatives of the Committees on Legal Affairs and on Civil Liberties and of other committees, to Turkey, to look at the situation of human rights and political freedoms there and to bring back information so that we can have a real reconsideration of our policy. Concerning visa liberalisation: visas are put in passports, but in a country which deliberately cancels passports there is no real place for liberalisation. (Applause)

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the events this summer in Turkey and especially the aftermath are, as many colleagues already stated, worrying. By his actions, Turkish President Erdogan is putting democracy at risk. As has been said here, the attacks on the Kurdish people should be condemned, but they are not the only ones who are suffering. Other minority groups in Turkey, such as Syriac Christians, are put in real danger by the acts of the Erdogan administration. The recent invasion by Turkey into Syria is officially taking place to attack ISIS. In reality it is mainly against the Kurds and their partners in the Democratic Self—Administration (DSA) in Northern Syria. The troops of this DSA, named the Syrian Democratic Forces, are at this moment very successful in combatting ISIS. If the Turkish army destroys these Syrian Democratic Forces, how can we expect ISIS to be defeated? For this reason, I call on Ms Mogherini to support the Syrian Democratic Forces and the DSA of Northern Syria in Rojava. We need to stop Turkish aggression both in Turkey and in Syria.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Turkey is an important partner, because developments in recent years show how important it is, for example, to end the fighting in Syria and to pacify the region as a whole in a sustainable way. However, we can only achieve this objective together with Turkey. We must therefore cooperate with Turkey. It is precisely for this reason that criticism of the Turkish Government's disregard for the rule of law and massive restrictions on fundamental rights is more important than ever. Whether it is systematic repression of criticism of Erdogan, mass detentions, or a ban on academics entering the country, we must not only criticize all of this, but urge change. Not only, but also because Turkey is a candidate country, we must support democratic developments in Turkey.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (
text: S&D). Mr President, the situation in Turkey is painful. Persecution of journalists, degradation of the secular state, persecution not only of Gulen's coups, but also of thousands of citizens through procedures that are not consistent with a rule of law. Pushing the legitimate party, the progressive Kurdish party, towards illegality. It is even more painful for us that we believe that Turkey is an important partner in the effort to solve major problems in our region, such as the refugee crisis, such as the Cyprus issue, such as energy diversification, such as terrorism. We must therefore intensify the dialogue with Turkey. We should also intensify it with the Turkish opposition, the pro-European opposition. Because otherwise we won't find solutions, right solutions to these problems. There is a big thorn and this thorn is Mr. Erdogan's yearning for presidential super powers and the use of extreme polarization to achieve his goal. This, unfortunately, makes the whole of Turkey bleed.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, it is important for the European Union to cooperate with Turkey. As a MEMBER of NATO, Turkey plays an important role in the security of Europe and, as we know, Turkey also plays an important role in solving the refugee crisis. At the same time, however, we cannot overlook the authoritarian regime's actions that are currently taking place in Turkey. Even before the coup attempt, it could not be said that Turkey was a model country for democracy, but now human rights are being further trampled under way, freedom of expression and media are being curtailed and the rule of law is not being implemented in Turkey.  It is important for the European Union to raise the grievances in the negotiations and to try to address them. Turkey is an applicant country for the European Union and is required to have the rule of law and good governance. It is clear that visa liberalisation with Turkey cannot be achieved until Turkey fulfils the conditions for visa liberalisation.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Turkey is an important partner for the European Union: the same decision to sign the agreement on managing the flow of migrants last March is based on this consideration.  However, respect for human rights remains a fundamental principle for the European Union, which is essential for the proper functioning of the agreements. The post-coup events have, alas, led to a further deterioration in a situation that observers agree does not respect fundamental rights.  I am, of course, in favour of dialogue with Turkey, but the European Union must find a way of ensuring that European standards of democracy are guaranteed in Turkey, without 'ifs' and without 'buts'.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: " Mr. President, in this great deal with Turkey, and all that awaits us with Turkey, we can definitely succeed only if we set things principled at all times. That is why the approach put forward by the High Commissioner seems principled to me. Of course we have to condemn the coup d'etat, but of course we also have to condemn everything that happened after the coup.  No one here can promise anyone anything, let alone Turkey membership in the European Union. We can only promise to stick to the principles and rules for joining the European Union, as any country that has become a member must have done. I am one of those who believes that Turkey can meet democratic criteria and become a member of the European Union, but it must also meet that.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Turkey is one of the best examples of the double standards of this European Union which claims to be concerned; a country to which we have given safe country status to outsource the control and deportation of refugees fleeing the fires we have helped to create. But is Turkey a safe country? No. It is not for uncomfortable judges, it is not for journalists, it is not for intellectuals who sign critical manifestos, it is not for the fourth party, the HDP, which is harassed and tried to outsource, is not for 20% of the population, the Kurdish population, which is bombed and repressed, and is not for refugees. We don't say it, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees says. But you guys keep looking the other way, worried. Look, the Turkish government has an expansion agenda that destabilizes the region, tolerates extremist groups, has, taking advantage of the coup, an internal agenda that dismantles lay democracy. He shouldn't be a reliable partner. Less hot cloths and less cynical worry.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Mr President, in turkey's presidential palace, unfortunately for it and its people, the neighbouring countries and the European Union, not to mention on a global scale, there is a man his policies are described as dangerously grandiose and speculative. We need to look at the reasons that led to the coup attempt. We must act decisively and not just condemn and vote for practically useless resolutions.
