Let us not forget the inanimate act of the collapse of the Russian fighter jet which was intended to drag the North Atlantic Alliance into a war with immeasurable consequences. The massacres of Kurdish civilians, the support and financing of the Islamic State, the persecution of political opponents and freedom of speech. The conversion of the brilliant pan-Orthodox church of Agia Sophia into a mosque, the bloody suppresses of the demonstrations, the threats against everything, whether on the issue of the recognition of Armenian genocide, on alleged support for coups, or on visa liberalisation. All of the above have one common denominator: Erdogan. Finally realize that Erdogan is not a stable and reliable interlocutor. It is necessary immediately and with drastic measures to restore the democracy of the rule of law, and that is as far as it is concerned. Because Turkey will never become Europe.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: for VP/HR. Mr President, I would like to thank the On behalf of the High Representative, I would also like to express my thanks for this debate. It has shown that it is very important to remain in dialogue with Turkey. I think it is also important that we understand that this country is still in shock collectively. This country has seen several military coups in the recent past; this time it was a failed one – thank God – which also signals a certain development. I believe that we in Europe, too, have been in shock, and perhaps we are still in shock, that something like this is still possible in our immediate neighbourhood in the 21st century and that a candidate country of the European Union can find themselves in such a situation.  All of us who have had the opportunity to be there recently after the coup, I believe, to note, that the Turks themselves – let alone us here in Europe – have not really properly assessed the extent of the infiltration of the state and essential parts of the state by the Gülen movement. It is clear that this must lead to consequences in the process of dealing with this, but – and you have said this in almost all of your statements – this must, especially for a country that is a candidate country, be based on the highest principles of the rule of law, to which we have committed ourselves and which are also part of our self-image. It may also be a challenge here and there in Turkey for us to apply this standard, but we are applying this standard, because Turkey is a candidate country, and that is to be accepted by Turkey.  I believe that it is also important, despite all the criticism of the government that can be had, to state that Turkey is a country with 80 million inhabitants, is ultimately also very heterogeneous and does not consist of President Erdogan, and that therefore, so to speak, any reflection cannot relate exclusively to the fact that he is now President there, but that we must keep an eye on the overall development of the country.  As far as our current task is concerned – and this was also made clear in our joint mission on Friday last week – we must ensure that this country is stabilised again in the interests of us Europeans. Because if a country of 80 million inhabitants in our immediate neighbourhood becomes unstable, then much can happen here, which also has a direct impact on Europe. In other words, to restore the rule of law, to restore economic stability – look at the economic figures: they have all fallen, tourism has fallen dramatically, and I believe that Turkish Airlines has written a deficit for the first time in its history. These are factors that must also be taken into account, and it is therefore also important that we help Turkey to deal with the refugee problem in the country itself.  It has already been said that we are, so to speak, at the beginning of getting into cruising speed with this help, cruising speed, because we also have an obligation to use the money in such a way that you, as representatives of European taxpayers, have a guarantee, so to speak, that the money will be used correctly, precisely for school attendance, for health care, nutrition, but also for language training for adults and the provision of micro-credits, but also to support particularly affected communities and cities in the infrastructure sector, which, like Kilis, have seen a 50 per cent increase in the population.  But when we talk about stabilisation, it is also a question of political stabilisation, and that includes resolving the issue of the Kurdish conflict at political level and not at military level, and that includes a strong political commitment by Turkey, above all in Syria, because there too we need a political solution.  However, I am also saying – and this has been mentioned by some of you – stabilisation also means that we are addressing the tensions that we see in some European countries within the European Union between members of the Turkish minority and the rest of society, or tensions between different groups of the Turkish minority of a country, that we are dealing with it and that we are also making our contributions, that things do not escalate here. It is not just the European Union that is called upon to do this; the representatives of today's Turkey are also called upon to make their contribution.  We are all called upon to disarm here; language can sometimes be more offensive than weapons, and it can often be a very be a deadly weapon. We must be aware of this. It is precisely at this stage that megaphone politics or megaphone diplomacy may not be the right approach. I believe that the High Representative said in the press conference that we must talk to the representatives, so to speak, robustly, but not about them in public, and we can expect the same from the Turkish representatives. Then we can take an important step towards stabilising the situation; the rest must then be left to the future.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. I would also like to inform the House that no request has been received to put to the vote the corrections announced yesterday at 5.00 p.m. pursuant to Rule 231(4) of the Rules of Procedure. These corrections are therefore considered to have been approved. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. Since the abortive putsch of 15 July, a widespread crackdown has been on Turkey: 35,000 people have been arrested, media censored: 45 newspapers, 16 television stations and 23 radio stations closed. In order to be able to de-incarcerate all these political prisoners, the Turkish Minister of Justice announced the release of 38,000 prisoners, including many prisoners of common rights. The Turkish President has announced the reinstatement of the death penalty "retroactively"! We must open our eyes to the reality of the situation in Turkey: the recent resignation of the head of the European delegation in Turkey, because of the failure to respect the human rights component of the migration agreement, is yet another example. Finally, such integration would constitute a major contribution of geopolitical problems, by projecting the borders of the European Union to countries as unstable as Syria and Iraq. European leaders must show lucidity, responsibility and honesty towards Turkey and its people by stopping turkey's integration process into the EU now.

name: María Teresa Giménez Barbat (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Before the coup d'am, the human rights situation in Turkey, such as freedom of the press or freedom of thought, was already badly deteriorated. Now, with the excuse of taking down all the promoters of the coup, President Erdogan is pursuing any opponent who is not to his liking, including journalists, magistrates, academics and even lay people and non-believers. We have a certain record, from press reports and first-hand testimonies, that the situation of the Laity and Non-Turkish Believers has been deteriorating since 15 July. In a context marked by the purge of opponents and the attempt to erase any remnants of secularism from the law, government representatives frequently equate atheists with terrorists, instigating a climate of social hostility that ends up apologizing acts of violence, persecution and censorship, such as those experienced by the Istanbul-based association of Turkish atheists, Ateizm Dernecai. I am talking about human rights violations related to religious freedom, conscience and expression. Europe must take a clear, robust and unanimous position in defence of universal human rights and who are our natural moral allies.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. – On 15 July, Turkey suffered a military coup in which more than 250 people were killed and nearly 1,500 injured. The government initially targeted Gulen's movement as perpetrators of the coup. Following the foiled coup, the government declared a state of emergency and began a purge with some 80,000 arrests of journalists, judges, police and army officers, businessmen, teachers and the withdrawal of media licenses. 49,337 workers have been suspended. The attack on democracy requires exceptional measures to safeguard democratic institutions. However, the exceptional nature of the measures and the State of emergency must be proportionate and the rule of law must be guaranteed. That is why the Council of Europe's cooperation with the Government of Turkey is essential in the investigation into the coup attempt in the country and on the trials that will follow, to ensure that they will be based on the European Convention on Human Rights. A high-level dialogue took place last week between Vice-President Mogherini and Commissioner Hahn addressing, inter-group, the Kurdish issue, Cyprus and the EU Turkey Agreement.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: Writing. – Turkey's internal stability is of the utmost importance to both the European Union and NATO, we have absolutely no interest in chaos and instability in the country, and action to violently overthrow a democratically elected government is always reprehensible. However, this claim is independent of the current migration situation. We cannot change our attitude towards Turkey according to whether the Turkish Government is turning its gaze away from illegal migration on its shores or, on the contrary, taking a hard action against people smugglers. Similarly, human rights must not be judged in the light of Turkey's important ally in the coalition fighting Islamic State. A few months ago, even after the EU-Turkey summit, I insisted that accelerating Turkey's accession negotiations was incomprehensible and should not apply to the Turks, thus undersaking the credibility of the entire enlargement process. I can only confirm this today: we must have a strong position on matters relating to the Turks, we cannot behave as if Turkey is doing some kind of service to Europe, which we reciprocate with visa-free travel. This kind of discourse suggests to European citizens that the EU is powerless on this issue without Turkey, which I am convinced is not the case.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. – We are talking about the implementation of the EU-Turkey agreement as if nothing were going on, but the situation has changed significantly since the agreement was reached! For example, we MEPs cannot go to Ankara next week because there are legitimate concerns about the inability of the Turkish authorities to ensure the purpose of our visit. I am very concerned about this situation in view of Turkey's pressure to introduce visa-free travel and also in view of the overall developments in Turkey. If we cannot personally see the situation in Turkey, if Turkey does not meet the conditions, we will not be able to agree to visa-free travel. I do not want us to punish Turkish citizens who want to travel to the EU for President Erdogan's mistakes, but we must show that we do not agree with the way in which the ruling AKP party, which no longer punishes coups but imposes arbitrary repression against people who are accused of cooperating with the coup without evidence, is doing. Officials and friends of officials are put in positions of managers of offices, schools, enterprises. The president is exploiting the situation to intensify the persecution of Kurds and independent journalists such as journalist Asli Erdogan. Precisely because Turkey is a strategic partner, we must all the more follow its dangerous orientation towards dictatorship, violence and Putin. We should be able to tell where our borders are, and we can't pretend like nothing's wrong!

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. – What has been happening in Turkey for a long time, and above all what we saw in July, completely excludes this country from any European civilised society. Given president Erdogan's disproportionate response, there are growing concerns that Turkey is on the path to an authoritarian state. This country is increasingly diverting from democracy, the rule of law and, after all, secularization. If Turkey wants the EU to continue to treat it as its partner, it must act as a rule of law in which every accused person has the right to a fair and independent court. The events of the summer must not be repeated.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the post-election situation in Gabon.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: VPC/HR. Mr President, first of all, thank you for organising this debate at this crucial moment in the history of the Gabonese Republic. Gabon may seem like a small country, but its potential is immense. These are not just important natural resources, with a significantly higher per capita income than most African countries. The people of Gabon have faith in democracy. The elections were peaceful and the turnout was high. The people of Gabon are confident that through the democratic process, the country will more effectively exploit its own potential. It is therefore important not to limit ourselves to the current crisis, to put an end to all forms of violence and to restore the confidence of the Gabonese population in the country's institutions. That is the aim of the European Union. This is also the objective of the election observation mission in its daily work. Let me thank the Chief Observer, Ms. Mariya Gabriel, and all the members of the mission, who have done an excellent job, who are doing a great job. You know that the mission and some of its members have been the target of personal attacks. The Gabonese authorities are responsible for the safety of the members of the election observation mission, and these personal and regular attacks cannot be tolerated. We reiterate this message to the Gabonese authorities in Libreville as well as in Brussels, every day, even at present. The impartiality of the mission was questioned. Let me also be very clear on this point. We are not taking sides in the political life of the Gabonese Republic, but we are working for democracy, transparency and the search for a peaceful solution to the crisis.  The international election observation mission complied with the methodology and memorandums of understanding signed with the Gabonese authorities. The Gabonese authorities themselves have invited the mission to observe the entire electoral process, and this is exactly what the mission is planning to do. It will work alongside Gabonese institutions until the final results are announced after the appeal phase. I will therefore focus on three steps which I think are crucial to getting out of the current crisis. First, it is essential that the electoral process be completed in a transparent manner. We continue to advocate for the publication of polling station results by polling station to ensure the quality of the results. This recommendation was also made by the African Regional Organization, the Economic Community of Central African States, as well as by the African Union. Only legal means, not acts of violence, can put an end to this litigation. We are ready to support the appeals process to the Constitutional Court and hope that the Court will act transparently and independently, in accordance with its mandate. In this regard, we call on the Constitutional Court to grant full access to the European mission of these procedures. These are part of the electoral process that Gabonese have pledged to make transparent and accessible to our observers. Second, all parties must refrain from violence and ensure the protection of the population. Both the government and the opposition have a responsibility in this regard. Attacks on Parliament or the official media have nothing to do with Gabon's legitimate aspiration to strengthen its democracy. The role played by the security forces is particularly critical. We expect the army, the police and the intelligence services to act in full compliance with the rule of law and with full respect for human rights. There is an urgent need to restore and maintain the public communication system, including social media, and it is important that the issue of those detained be dealt with promptly and fairly. Thirdly, Gabon's international partners, starting with other African countries, can play an important role in helping to ease the tension, as we recently said in a joint statement with Commissioner Mimica. We work closely with the United Nations, the United States and France. We actively support the mission of high-level heads of state, which is currently being set up by the African Union and the United Nations. The availability of Chad's President Idriss Déby, President-in-Office of the African Union, is an encouraging sign of Africa's determination to facilitate a solution to the crisis. I am also encouraged by the presence in Libreville of the African Union in the Commissioner Smail Chergui. I can only hope that the mission will have the opportunity to get there as soon as possible. I would particularly like to commend the efforts of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General of the United Nations. He is currently leading mediation efforts at the local level and needs our continued support. The citizens and institutions of Gabon have a primary responsibility to put an end to the violence and achieve a peaceful solution to the post-election crisis. However, the international community must be on their side to facilitate and accompany the process. I am convinced that the African Union should be the leader. Regional integration can be a powerful instrument for peace and security in Africa. At the same time, the European Union, all of us, are ready to support Gabon by all our means.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Madam High Representative, thank you for your clear and relevant messages. This is the first electoral observation mission deployed in Gabon. It is therefore a clear signal of our support for the Gabonese people for democracy, the rule of law and human rights, and I am honoured to be able to lead this mission. I would like to begin by expressing several thanks. First of all, I would like to thank all the observers of the European Union and in particular my team, some of which is still deployed in Gabon. They do a remarkable job. Secondly, I would like to thank the Gabonese citizens for the warm welcome they have given to our observers, for their patience and for the calm that was preserved on polling day. I would also like to thank the Gabonese authorities, who have invited the European Union to observe the elections, signed the Memorandum of Understanding and has so far guaranteed the safety of our observers. During this mission, we were able to meet all stakeholders, the authorities, the various political parties, all the presidential candidates and civil society. We have also worked closely with other observation missions and representatives of the international community on the ground. Today, it is crucial to finalize the work of the mission without wasting time and energy for unacceptable accusations, false allegations or lies. This brings me to my second part. A real dialogue and a true partnership are also an opportunity to tell us things as they are.  In respect of the framework of the mission, I would like to draw attention to a few facts, because the possibility of expressing oneself on facts identified by our observers is also one of the strengths of the Union's electoral observation mission. The main facts at this stage are that, contrary to what was provided for in the Memorandum of Understanding, the mission had unequal access to the consolidation of results according to local electoral commissions. The results have not been publicly announced in the province of Haut-Ogooué, contrary to the statutory provisions. In the same province, there was an anomaly in the turnout and in comparison with an analysis of the number of non-voters and blank and null ballots. There was no publication of the polling station results by polling station, in accordance with international best practices. Today, as we have since the beginning of the process, we call for non-violence and calm. We continue to be guided by the need for transparency at all stages of the electoral process. We call on all actors to stick to legal and peaceful remedies. This now includes observing the handling of appeals filed with the Constitutional Court. This is a key phase in the electoral process and we are waiting for our legal expert to have access to the work of the Court to be guaranteed, as is the safety of the team members who are still there. International experts' access to the Court is also welcome. Finally, I would like to express the full support of the mission to Mr Chergui, Commissioner of the African Union, Professor Bathily, Special Representative of the United Nations, and Mr Abdallah, of the International Organization of the Francophonie, and to thank them for their efforts. I will end by saying this: all actors have a responsibility to contribute to the calming of the situation. Restoring Gabonese confidence in the integrity of the electoral process requires transparency. Today, by respecting the law, as an election observation mission, our gaze is turned to the Constitutional Court, from which we expect it to continue to be the embodiment of this justice without which no rule of law can avail itself of it.

name: Jo Leinen
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been a member of the European Parliament. The importance of the European Union's election observation missions was demonstrated in the presidential election in Gabon. This is a small country, but this presidential election is also a symptom and also a signal for democracy and democratic development in West Africa, if not for the whole of Africa. I would like to thank Mariya Gabriel, the team and, of course, our parliamentary delegation, for the work that has been done. The people of Gabon have welcomed the EU mission very favourably and positively. Wherever we went, we were even greeted with joy, with clapping that the EU is there and watching this election. And, of course, the public was interested in our conclusions, in what we saw. Now it can be said that Election Day itself is not so critical, but the weeks before the election and the days after the election. In Gabon, it has once again been shown that there are no fair conditions for such elections between a candidate who comes from government and an opposition candidate. The public media was completely unevenly distributed in terms of coverage of the president and the opposition candidate. And there is not much to say about the financing of election campaigns. State money is also used time and again for the election campaign. On Election Day, we have very often noticed that the electoral register is not in order and that it was not clear who is entitled to vote. It was really ironic that you could vote with the health insurance card, but not with the provisional identity card, even though no new identity cards have been issued since 2013. The counting of votes is very worrying, I agree. This lack of transparency in the centralisation of elections speaks volumes, and what has taken place in the province of Ogooué is as implausible as anything. So, High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, Gabon needs the EU, and you said it: together with the African Union, we must hope that this will be peaceful, that the process will end and that we will help the country to take the next step towards democracy.

name: Marek Jurek
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In Gabon, we have witnessed how much this young democracy – because this is a country that has barely twenty years of democratic rule – wants to exercise its full civil rights. The people of Gabon cannot under any circumstances be denied involvement, takeover of elections, a sense of responsibility for what they mean. Democracy, on the other hand, is, of course, the decision of the majority, but a fair debate must precede those decisions. Two things are needed in Gabon today: firstly, social peace, which has been repeatedly called for here, and secondly, the development of civil society. There we met not only two main candidates, but also people who talked with such a takeover about the need for this development, such as Dr. Bruno Ben Moubamba. We should help them. I would particularly like to thank Maria Gabriel for her work, for her presence, because i am sure that the many weeks of work of her and her team have helped to carry out this election and help to establish their fair result.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I am happy to share the appreciation of the work of the monitoring mission, although I am the first one speaking here today that was not a part of it. But I think that we have managed to monitor the work of the mission and I think that I can only praise the work. The Bongo family has been in power from 1967. This is not something specific to Gabon, it is something that we have seen throughout Africa in recent decades. The very fact that we have these illegitimate leaders, whether it is Gabon or any other country, logically in a country where there is a certain civil society this creates civil unrest. That is where the roots lie. You have outlined the points Madam President, I was approaching the more or less the same ones, but from a different angle. The first point that I would like to highlight is that if the mission came to the conclusion that there were obvious abnormalities then we have to insist that the electoral commission publishes the results. The second issue is that this has to be recalculated, and I do appreciate the support that you are also giving to the efforts vis-à-vis the court, and I very much hope that the findings will be objective, transparent and independent. The third point – and the key point – I would like to underline is, and maybe I am just an observer getting it wrong, but it seems to me while the African Union does play a role, we see that the mediators’ mission has been postponed, and honestly I would have expected the African Union to be much more vocal and much more engaged.  Bearing in mind and coming back to what I said at the very beginning, this is not just a problem for Gabon but something that we see more or less every year or every couple of years copy. There is a significant role to play for the African Union and it is also a task for us to ‘motivate’ the African Union. I would also like to wish Members good luck in all their efforts and to thank them for their points and for addressing the issue.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, while it is only natural that pan-African and regional organisations should be on the front line in Gabon, the European Union cannot leave it at its best. We are able to say the size of the stitches of a fishing net and enforce it in Africa and we would not be able to say what an honest election is? And in the end, in the interests of appeasement, we would put on the same level the cheats and those who are the subject of this cheating and who are victims of it? In the same way, we would put everyone on the same level, calling for peace, when the violence is the exclusive act of the government in place against Mr. Jean Ping's supporters? We must demand that this violence be stopped immediately, by naming it.  What I mean is that the count, the new count of ballots cannot simply be referred to the Constitutional Court, which is already proven to be biased and malicious. It has to be an international organization, and the European Union has the power to ask that it be the United Nations or the OAU that ensures that.  Ladies and gentlemen, Mr Gbagbo was only sent to the ICTY when he was asking for a recount, and we would let Mr Bongo refuse us it by using violence without saying anything?  It would be better if Mr. Gbagbo were released and Mr. Bongo curbed.

name: Michèle Rivasi
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, it is true that the political situation in Gabon is very worrying, with each candidate remaining camped on his or her positions at the risk of the situation escalating into a civil war. Violence must be prevented at all costs. Here in Brussels, I had received Mr Jean Ping, who was already afraid of this situation at the time. I had taken the initiative to send an official letter to Ali Bongo, so that there would be an observation mission sent by the European Union. I am delighted that it was our colleague Mariya Gabriel, with her experience in this area in the Democratic Republic of Congo, who led her.  But between the lack of electoral lists displayed in front of polling stations, failures in indelible ink control, the authentication of ballots and the use of ballot seals without identification numbers, there is much to complain about the holding of elections. We must therefore support the work of this observation mission and its demands for transparency and, more specifically, the need to publish the polling station results by polling station, as you have indicated. Jean Ping's referral to the Constitutional Court for a recount of votes could be a door to the exit from the crisis, but it also risks inflaming the situation since his judgment will be the last possible remedy. And since Gabon's political life is a family affair, it is feared that the judgment rendered will be challenged for the simple reason that the President of the Constitutional Council is none other than the former companion of Ali Bongo's father. And that's a problem. Today, we must at all costs avoid the reproduction of the Ivorian precedent, where the international community had granted itself the right to intervene. It is in Gabon and the Gabonese that their destiny belongs. We need to give them our support in that regard. Above all, I hope that all the Member States of the European Union and the African Union, as you have pointed out, are mobilising, and it should not be France that interferes in Gabonese political life, because France-Africa has lasted long enough. It is therefore our responsibility to follow up.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, High Commissioner, I was part of the delegation, so I confirm what chief executive Jo Leinen said about the reception we were given in Gabon. This reception, in my opinion, was the reception of those who received an election observation mission for the first time and expected the election observation mission to be sure that there was no fraud, because rather than talking about restoring confidence – because there was no confidence there, indeed everyone told us that there had certainly been fraud in previous elections – our presence received such high media attention precisely because the Gabonese wanted to , indeed they want from us, because the mission is still ongoing, the certainty and the control of regularity.  Unfortunately, the next day, as soon as the results were published, this kind of hope turned into a disappointment. So we are still in time, through our mission, but also through dialogue with the African Union, to try to restore this confidence that we really have noticed from the Gabonese and turn it into something concrete, because otherwise I think it is very difficult for the People of Gabonese to be able to find a solution peacefully on this outcome of the elections.

name: Louis Aliot
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the arbitrary declaration of victory by each of the candidates follows the arbitrariness of elections and constitutional amendments in other neighbouring countries. Behind these manoeuvres, politicians and large groups protect their interests, but people routinely toast. The violence is unacceptable and the presence of European observers has not changed anything. I am also quite surprised, Mrs Mogherini, that the same outbursts and violence that took place yesterday in Congo did not provoke the same reactions on the part of the European Union and on the part of France and other countries. No one here can dispute the cheating of this presidential election. Each side sought to impose itself through fraud at the expense of the sovereign will of the Gabonese people. These breaches of the basic rules of democracy illustrate the need for new impetus in Gabon as in all of Central Africa, but this momentum is not to choose the candidate in place of the Gabonese or to attempt to destabilize the country in favour of unspeakable foreign or merchant interests. Beware of the risk of civil war! The Rwandan precedent must lead us to great caution. The future of Gabon belongs to the Gabonese and to them alone. In Both Gabon and Congo, the release of political prisoners is a prerequisite, and respect for the opposition is a guarantee. I urge Europeans to pay attention to the political manoeuvres under way, so that the smouldering fire does not turn into a blaze. The stability of Europe is closely linked to the stability of the African continent.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Madam President, first of all, let me congratulate Mariya Gabriel, who led the Union's observation mission, and Jo Leinen, who led our Parliament's mission. My colleagues Mr Mélenchon and Mrs Rivasi mentioned the case of Côte d'Ivoire. In that regard, let me say that, in my opinion, this is a similar case. As it happens, in 2010, I was the head of the election observation mission when Mr. Gbagbo refused to leave power and it is in fact the same idea: he was trending towards Soviet results in his region of origin and wanted, at the time, to cancel the results in the departments where Alassane Ouattara had won. The problem is precisely the challenge to the election results. Instead of calming the mood, instead of calming the political atmosphere, elections lead to political crises. I think the only duty we have is to continue the work of the team led by our colleague Mariya Gabriel and to demand what we do all over the world, the publication of polling station results by polling station, so that citizens, first of all, can verify what has been done with their vote and then , independent observers, including our observers of the Union's mission, can have an overview of the results and can synthesize them. Only the precise calculation of the voices will soothe the spirits; otherwise, the violence, looting and the dying crisis will continue. Of course, there is also a family problem because Mr. Ping himself is a member of the Bongo clan. It is not someone else, it is not an outside opponent.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Madam President, I have had the privilege of being a member of the European Parliament's delegation on the European Union's election observation mission. The extraordinary momentum that accompanied the elections in this country represented a sign of immense hope for the Gabonese people, who by going to the polls, demanded democratic institutions, demanded free political debates and also invoked the alternation of power. These elections were a missed opportunity for Gabon's ruling class to prove to the entire African continent and to the entire international community that it is able to hold a transparent election and show the utmost responsibility throughout the electoral process. In a democracy, it is necessary to guarantee opposition parties the opportunity to develop and propose their own political project in the greatest, purest tradition of political adversity. However, a few weeks after this vote, we express our great disappointment at the lack of transparency in the management of the electoral process, which has particularly targeted the methods of party financing and the election campaign, as well as the control of all vital information, such as the electoral list and the list of voting centres. In addition, there is excessive media coverage for the outgoing president and the lack of confidence of opposition candidates and part of civil society in the bodies responsible for the administration of elections. We vehemently denounce the loss of life and all forms of violence that followed the publication of the provisional results, and are still ongoing. I therefore ask that this violence cease. Incidents that reflect a lack of transparency in the management of the electoral process, as well as the violent repression of protesters by the security forces, all contribute greatly to the loss of the confidence of voters and stakeholders. Until the conclusion of the electoral process, the European Union's election observation mission will continue to observe all stages, including electoral disputes, in line with the protocol signed with the government. I call on President Ali Bongo to honour Africa and also to honour his people by renouncing the presidency because of the lack of transparency in the whole process. As for the Gabonese people, they can count on the unconditional effort of the European Parliament to stand by their side.

name: Joachim Zeller (PPE).
text: Madam President, High Representative, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for the work she has We have been talking lately often about causes that force people to flee their home countries. I fear that we will soon have to add a new country to the list of countries from which people are fleeing – that is Gabon. But it is not hunger, climate change or drought that is forcing people to flee, but a president and his aides who are unwilling to follow the democratic will of the people of Gabon to step aside and clear the way for democratic change in the country. No, they are taking violent action against the opposition. Gabon is one of the richer countries in Africa with a gross national product per capita, which is much higher than, for example, Bulgaria's. Nevertheless, more than two thirds of the population still live in extreme poverty, because the family of President Bongo has been exploiting the country's wealth for decades and generating billions in foreign exchange income abroad, including in EU Member States. The people of Gabon welcomed us with joy at the election observation – as some of my colleagues have already said. They hoped that the election would be free and fair. We simply owe it to the citizens of Gabon to justify their confidence and to use all political means to ensure that the democraticwill of the people of Gabon is followed, including sanctions if necessary. It is regrettable that the African Union is using the President of Chad, Idriss Déby, as a mediator in Gabon. He is not exactly a witness to fair and free elections in his own country.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it is with great regret that we follow the news of the post-electoral violence in Gabon. It should be reiterated that all political leaders have their responsibility in Gabon to maintain peace in the post-electoral environment. The EU is ready to contribute to this process.  No electoral process is completed without transparent post-electoral mechanisms. Transparency is one of the fundamental principles of free, fair and competitive elections, and must also be ensured in the days after the election day. In the case of Gabon, this needed to be ensured by publishing the results of the voting stations and by a transparent appeal process. This also applies to the current complaint procedures at the constitutional court. I am sure that our observation mission, which operates under the highest international standards, will continue to observe the situation and we can rely on their report and recommendations.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the recent announcement of President Ali Bongo's re-election for a third term in Gabon was the reason for violent incidents in the country with at least a thousand hundred arrests and three deaths.  Moreover, although Gabon is considered the country with the highest growth rate in sub-Saharan Africa, it is not the first time such conflicts have occurred. Therefore, in the face of the deranged post-election situation in the country, the Union should contribute to restoring democratic normality in Gabon, to respecting human rights, and to respecting democratic freedoms.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I would like to say that, for once, I think we are all very much united, first of all in understanding and supporting the role that we have. Sometimes we forget it. Sometimes we focus on our own limits or divisions – and, for sure, we have both limits and divisions – but when we look at the work the European Union does from the outside, with the eyes of the citizens of Gabon who were welcoming our mission, we recognise how relevant our work is, how important our values are, how powerful our instruments are, and how much expectation as well as how much change we can bring to peoples’ and countries’ lives. Maybe it is also useful to remind ourselves about this when we debate our own internal affairs back home. I would like to sum up, so it is not really a reply, it is more a sharing, I think – thanking very much first of all Mariya Gabriel for her work, all the colleagues here who expressed common views on the situation, and also the European Parliament as a whole for its important role. I have to admit that sometimes we forget how important our EU missions are on the ground. This is really a key part of our common work that I appreciate very much. On the situation, I have seen that our analysis coincides. These coming days, I agree, are crucial, especially in relation to the process ongoing at the Constitutional Court. We will look at what is happening and follow and monitor the situation in these critical hours and days extremely carefully, and I know that you will do the same. I believe that this will have an impact: it will be important for the people of Gabon to know that this House is following developments with such attention and that we are committed to continuing to follow this in a very careful way. We all share a common interests in finding a rapid, peaceful and just solution to this post-electoral crisis, as all of you mentioned, and we will ensure continued full support for our mission still on the ground. Thank you also for reminding us that we still have staff on the ground who need to continue their work in proper conditions, and we need to guarantee that – not only but especially – on the ground. So we will keep monitoring the situation in every dimension and I am sure you will do so too. It is going to be very important that we keep each other in line and updated and continue to exchange, as we have done all over these difficult weeks in a very good way. Let me express once again our full appreciation for Parliament’s role in this respect, your leadership and capacity to lead a difficult mission. Also, a last point: some of you mentioned the role that is, or should be, there for the African Union. I have said, and I will reiterate, that there is plenty of scope for the African Union to play a leading role in Africa. It is not an easy one but it is an important one, and our role there is to support the African Union in this respect, and also to support the African Union and the African Union countries in the difficult task of upholding the principles that they have set for themselves. Sometimes, as we know well, it is a challenging exercise, but I am sure that the African Union and its Member States have the means to live up to the expectations of their own people.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: VPC/HR. – Madam President, first of all, thank you for this debate. I know that you are always surprised to have a ‘thank you for this debate’, but I really think that it is important that we have issues on the agenda regularly and I have always noticed that the European Parliament has kept a constant focus on migration. I am sure you will remember this very well: just two years ago, migration was very low on our common European agenda, both here in Europe and globally, and this year it will be one of, or maybe the, central issue of the UN General Assembly.  So let me say, maybe it’s stating the obvious today, but looking backwards, it was not obvious at that time. There is a new global awareness and an understanding that migration can only be dealt with as a global issue. It is not an issue for one country or another, it is a global issue that needs a global response. And this is happening, this new global awareness, also because there is a new European awareness. We came a bit late, but we got there. So for sure this is linked to the magnitude of the phenomenon that touched the European continent, but I would say that finally we woke up to the ‘new normal’ of global migratory trends and in the last months I believe we have shaped an adequate external policy to manage this complex phenomenon on a global level.  So our approach is feeding into the global approach in the last months in quite a significant way. Our work in the European Union, especially on our external site, is becoming in these months, in these weeks, a point of reference for the global community. And again if I look back and think that when I took office less than two years ago migration was not even an issue or a topic for the Foreign Affairs Council, we have come quite a long way. Today, we have some – some – elements of our policy that are points of reference for the global response, to the need to manage together the migratory flows. Operation Sophia has been repeatedly endorsed by the United Nations Security Council resolutions. The same concept of migration compacts or migration partnerships that we have started last June is reflected in and will be central to our discussions next week in New York in the General Assembly ministerial week.  The declaration for refugees and migrants that we will adopt in New York is consistent with many of the actions we are currently putting in place – currently and finally I would say, putting in place. The declaration sets out an immediate comprehensive refugee response framework, which should lead to a global compact for refugees. This parallel of global compacts with our compacts, our partnerships, I believe are the result of European thinking that was somehow contaminated by, and contaminated itself, the global thinking in quite a relevant way. In parallel it outlines the process towards a truly global management of migrations with a future compact for safe, regular and orderly migration.  So the logic is to look beyond the current ‘refugee crisis’ as we have called it in the last year, realising that this is not only something that is happening here and now in our region, but is, as I said, the new normal of global trends. We have to look beyond this crisis approach. We even need to look beyond the other refugee crises happening in other parts of the world, with countries such as Ethiopia or Kenya hosting huge numbers of displaced people.  Migration will stay with us, and this is I know something that some of you in this room, and some of our citizens, do not like to hear, but this is a simple reality of today’s world. In a world of 7 billion people with rising inequalities, with dramatically diverse demographic trends, migration is the new normal; and if properly managed, let me remind you of something that is also some of you might not like to hear, and some of our citizens might not like to hear, but if properly managed it can bring about great opportunities for those who leave, for those who stay and for those who welcome.  And we need to face also with a certain realism our own European demographic trends and realise that we need and we will continue to need migration. So it is not something we need to stop, it is something we need to manage, and manage properly in an orderly way, in a way that is respectful of human rights and can become mutually beneficial.  So this is not simply about how we manage our frontiers. This is something that touches on many different other aspects, much more in-depth. We need investments, first of all, and both on refugees and on the wider issue of migration our Union is finally investing new resources in innovative ways – and I will come to that in a moment.  But I want to be very clear. I started with things I am proud of, the things that we are bringing to the global stage, our concept of partnerships, of compacts, or investment. In our response to the refugee crisis and the migratory phenomenon there is also a lot I am really not proud of, and I will be also clear about that. I am not proud of the hate campaign we have seen around Europe, I am not proud of the walls. I am not proud of discriminations based on race or religion. And we have to be clear also on that if we want to be credible on the global scene. I believe many were caught by surprise when the refugee crisis arrived in Europe to such an extent. I understand that many are scared. But we have also shown that we can manage both the emergency and the long-term challenge. So to go back to the things I’m proud of, because I believe that in these times we need a bit to focus also on what we’re good at: I’m proud of the unity we have shown in creating and running together Operation Sophia. I’m proud of the lives we’ve saved. I’m proud that we’ve mobilised incredible resources, especially to build schools and hospitals but especially on education for refugees. I’m proud that we’re finding innovative tools, from debit cards to the migration compacts, to help millions of refugees in Turkey, Jordan and Lebanon. And the same goes for our long-term approach. This is something I’m finally proud of. The world is changing fast and we couldn’t just stick to the old way of doing things. So we’ve started to change the way of doing our things. I know that most of the debate around this has been focused, in our Member States in particular, on the issue of returns and readmissions, and that is indeed part of our policies. But readmission, obviously, is important to move towards a better system for human mobility, to make it sustainable, providing better channels for legal migration, and discouraging or preventing dangerous travels through the desert or at sea.  I remember we had a very heated exchange here in this Chamber a couple of months ago about this, and I always recall that I witnessed myself first-hand the great work we do in countries like Ethiopia for the reintegration of women who were reduced to slavery after they fled their home country. So this is something we always have to keep in mind, and something I’m proud of. But as I said, readmissions are only one part of our approach, and I would say maybe not the fundamental one. Because if anyone believes that we can solve the issue of migration by sending everyone back, that person needs a reality check and would be proven to be wrong. We need to work hard within the countries of origin and to look beyond the short term.  As I said, readmissions and returns are an important part of our policy, but it is only one part. We need to look at the causes of the huge migratory movements we’re facing in the world, and we need to tackle them where they are. This is the reason why we are investing in a new approach based on partnership.  As I see our African friends are now truly willing to engage with us and to take responsibility, with a new true commitment to a common shared approach to manage migration properly and together, we’re opening somehow a new chapter, I think, based on partnership. And this is not happening without a reason. There is this global awareness shaping up between those who understand that migration is there to stay and has to be managed together. And this is the new global context we are living in. This new global context also requires from our side creativity, respect and the ability to bring about new instruments.  Public resources alone will never be sufficient, in an era of harder financial constraints even more so, but our funds can help mobilise private investors and international institutions towards shared strategic goals, and this is the core idea behind our new External Investment Plan which we have just established today. European firms are already employing hundreds of thousands of people, in Africa but also in our neighbouring countries, generating wealth both in those continents, in those countries, and here at home. But to expand business or to move into a new country, often a very difficult one, they need security and protection from risks, be it financial, legal or due to instability. So we can provide them with a guarantee, and this is what the new investment plan will do. We are getting to establish new tools for dealing with an unprecedented challenge, we are changing our mind-sets, and this is quite difficult to do but finally I believe we might get there. We’re building new partnerships beyond the traditional fault lines, beyond a donor-recipient mentality, beyond the traditional divide between public and private, and even beyond the North and South divide, because we are together in this, so that’s why the partnership approach is so crucial. Ultimately we are calling for a global partnership to deal with migration, and the UN summit will be an important step in this direction. This can be the beginning of a new path, also for the UN approach to migration and refugees. But for the first time in history, 193 countries will gather together and commit to a common approach to migration. And this is already a major achievement, determined also, I would say mainly through the contribution of the European Union.  Now we will need to ensure that intentions are turned into actions, and that our European Union process feeds into a global engagement to shape up the world’s migration system. We do count also on Parliament to make this a reality, and to continue engaging with us on the follow-up to the UN summit in New York. It is an opportunity, it is an opportunity that Europeans cannot miss, and Europe can and must lead the process, also following up the UN summit in New York towards a global partnership on migration.  But let me stress here again, we can play this key role on the international, global level on creating this new global compact for migration, first if we are consistent internally, second if we are united in this approach. And here comes also the role of Parliament. I believe that no matter if you come from the right or the left, from Portugal or Finland, or from the far East or the far West of the European Union, we all share an interest to make migration managed, properly managed and sustainable, and to invest in our neighbours’ development, and when I say neighbours I include the whole continent of Africa which is our neighbour. So I really count on your support. But more than that, let me say, I count on your work. And I especially look forward to reading your report to move towards a system for human mobility that is fit for the 21st century.  (Applause)

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, let me get directly to the bottom of the matter, beyond the very importance of convening this summit.  I would like to highlight some of the points that the European Union should stress at the summit. First, international aid needs to be strengthened for host communities. This summit commitment will have to be implemented as soon as possible and at a sufficient level in the current Syrian refugee crisis.  Secondly, I am pleased that refugee women are given an important place not only as vulnerable people, but also as those who bring about change and the future. Encouraging women's empowerment means investing in the reconstruction and stabilization of the country of origin. Secondly, I find it encouraging that border management and the dismantling of criminal migrant trafficking networks are taken seriously. We need a clear mechanism for cooperation between countries of origin, transit and destination. Information and analysis of roads, border control and prospects for migrants are three key elements in promoting safe, fluid and regular immigration. Fourth note: the summit document needs to be strengthened on the root causes and anticipation of movements. I am thinking in particular of conflict prevention and the effects of climate change on people's movements. Finally, the draft document recognises existing regional initiatives such as the Rabat and Khartoum processes and the Valletta Action Plan. The EU must ensure that these initiatives are effectively fully taken into account at the global level and a clear timetable for implementation will be welcome.

name: Elena Valenciano
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, thank you very much, Madam High Representative. As stated in the declaration, which will be adopted in New York, migration phenomena are not new, have existed throughout history and, by the way, have been an essential element in human progress. It is true that today the world is living in an extraordinary moment and that is why we have to respond with extraordinary actions, such as this United Nations Summit, which must be a historic event for us to live up to current circumstances and needs and, perhaps, up to the response that was given more than six decades ago , when the international community was able to sign the Convention on the Status of Refugees, to create UNHCR, to create the International Organization for Migration. But I want to stress the need for this to be addressed from a human perspective. It seems a lie to remember, but it is. Human rights protection at the heart of their action, regardless of personal status: migrants, refugees are human beings, that is what they are. And the European Union, as the High Representative said, must play a leading role. Perhaps we would be more visible if we set a better example with our practices, if we complied with the given word, and with our own standards. But we also know where the real problem is and we know of the efforts of the Commission and the High Representative. The real problem of this Union, which is being broken, is the insolidary action of many governments of the Member States, uncoordinated, short-sighted and often unfair. We have to figure this out inside. The appointment in New York on September 19, and the Day After Summit with President Obama must mark a before and after. They must be the beginning of a global response to a phenomenon that is global, that of human mobility — that is what we are talking about, human mobility — which, for the good of all, we must order, respect and manage in solidarity to be all more worthy.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, last year over a million people arrived on the shores of Europe from Africa, the Middle East and beyond, an unprecedented figure that has focused the debate. This can lead some to view this as an isolated and regional phenomenon rather than a global issue, but we only have to look at Jordan and Lebanon to realise that mass movements are occurring across the globe.  It is a mistake, however, to believe that the patterns, motivations and effects are always the same. As has always been the case throughout human history, military conflicts of course make individuals flee for safety just as horrible regimes encourage those to escape persecution.  But seeking better employment and economic prospects is also no less of a natural motivation to move elsewhere. However, as poverty levels decrease across the world, the financial means for more and more people in the developing world to do this increases. In my view, the 1951 UN Convention on Refugees is no longer adequate or fit for purposes. In my opinion, we need to accommodate this emerging phenomenon, particularly in a world of mass communications and accentuated wealth disparity, by looking at the Convention again. It is therefore imperative for the UN Summit to look at this, in addition to state building, sustainable development and conflict prevention.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, according to the UNHCR, more than 85% of the 60 million refugees in the world live in developing countries. That should be kept in mind when we are discussing the 1.5 million refugees who made it last year to this continent. Migration is a global issue and therefore I am very happy that the United Nations has now decided to call for the summit next week. I am personally happy to lead the LIBE delegation there. I look forward to working closely with the Commission and European players in ensuring its success.  Europe has a proud history of granting asylum and defending the fundamental rights of migrants. During these last years, however, we have seen how rising tides of xenophobia and populism have also had a detrimental effect on the European debate. We have unfortunately seen how principles of asylum law, such as the respect of non-refoulement, the right to family reunification and the right to apply for asylum have come under pressure in the European Union as well. During the summit I hope that we can once again unite around the principles of humanity and tolerance that were the basis for the creation of the Geneva Convention and other international standards for the protection of refugees. We must also be much better at tackling the root causes that force people to flee in the first place. But, as long as there are human beings who need protection, those of us who are lucky enough to live in places that people flee to rather than from, need to take our responsibilities seriously. Again I encourage all of us in the global approach to migration and I am happy that we are, as a delegation, participating in the UN summit.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – Madam Representative, you mentioned that you are pleased to be a part of this delegation. There's very, very little time until the 19th. And you also mentioned, of course, that there is no clear approach to the question here in the Member States of the European Union, but – and this is an honest question – what will you answer to a question that is good and good, there are governments in the Member States that behave badly, but what are the other Member States doing about these renituous Member States?

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – I would respond that we are in the process, it is work in progress that we are now trying to shape up a good policy for migration and refugees, where every Member State has to take its part of the responsibility. I am personally the rapporteur for the Dublin Regulation that is under reform at this moment, and I am happy to convey a message that Europe prevails, a humanitarian continent, a humanitarian Union, and that the good principles still do prevail even if they are challenged from time to time.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, this UN summit is indeed a summit of hope. For months, the United Nations and its various bodies have been warning about the situation of migrants, and the least that can be said is that the richest states in the world are not up to the task. The number of refugees, even more displaced, is at an all-time high. Among them, an unbearable number of children. Fifty million, according to Unicef, have fled war, internal conflicts, misery, climate change and, more broadly, environmental, because the hand of man is often behind many natural disasters. Member States are responding with ever-increasing demands for border controls and hunting of so-called economic migrants at a time when the border between refugees and migrants is becoming increasingly difficult to establish and legal migration to the European Union is decreasing. Last year, one million people, including more than a third of them children, crossed the Mediterranean, 0.2% of the European population compared to 20% in Lebanon, for example. Madam High Representative, even the relocation mechanism does not work, less than 5,000 people welcomed in one year, for 160,000 announced. At this rate, it will take more than 30 years to reach the two-year target, which is far from meeting the needs, and there will be more deaths in the Mediterranean by the end of the year than last year. I do not have time to talk about the consequences of the mobilizations of all the Union's external policies, the economic partnership agreements, the European Development Fund used for the outsourcing of border management, including with the worst dictatorships, especially in the Horn of Africa. An example: 50 Sudanese recently returned from Italy directly to Sudan. The United Nations calls for responsibility and solidarity. The European Union must ensure that its Member States take action that is truly in line with global needs, particularly in Africa where, as I recall, 85% of migration is intra-African.

name: Bodil Valero
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I had hoped that we would have had both a debate and a resolution today or during the week, so that we could also give our input to the UN meeting here from Parliament. But a debate is better than nothing at all. When the large influx of refugees from war-syria began to arrive in Europe, we stood with our pants down. There was no preparedness, and it also turned out that some countries showed no solidarity whatsoever with the refugees or with other Member States. With poorly prepared ad hoc measures, we tried to solve urgent problems. That is why the UN meeting is so important. We must resolve this issue jointly.  After all, some 60 million people in the world are fleeing, not only from war, but also from poverty, political repression, climate change. If we do not seriously address the root causes, they will only become more and more.  Those fleeing poverty are no less valuable than those fleeing war, but they have no legal protection. These are the people that the Member States now want to send back home quickly. To continued poverty, to continued oppression, to continued drought. They will not disappear simply because we choose to receive only those we have to receive under the Geneva Convention. The risk is that we will create large groups of undocumented people in Europe in the future and in the world.  Most people don't actually leave their homes because they want to, but because they have to. If we are serious, we must start by helping people not to migrate when they do not want to – both in terms of those fleeing poverty and those fleeing war.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President,  I am pleased that the UN General Assembly will shortly be debating the issue of migration and refugees, as this matter must be looked at from a truly global perspective. There are many international laws and norms that clarify refugee rights, and these must be adhered to by all nations. Last summer’s tragic waste of life could have been avoided if Chancellor Merkel had not made the reckless decision to open Germany, and thus the rest of the Schengen area, to all who could physically make it to its borders. As we know, the wave of people taking up this call also allowed for infiltration from terrorists opposed to Western values. President Erdoğan has used the migration crisis to pull the European Union’s strings. Many concessions have been made, notably in visa liberalisation and Turkish EU accession talks. Opinion polls in Hungary show 70% to 80% opposition to this migration deal. The EU must learn to respect the opinions of such citizens or risk further fragmentation. Now the UK is looking beyond the European Union, the need for mutual cooperation and cordial relations is nowhere more apparent than in affairs of migration and refugees. The UK, France and the Republic of Ireland must continue to cooperate effectively on our mutual borders and avoid any unnecessary and punitive restrictions on UK-EU travel arrangements.

name: Gerolf Annemans
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Yes, Commissioner, allow me. I don't agree with you. If you say we need immigration, I don't agree with you. Please stop using the new speak and the word "refugees". This morning, so-called refugees were removed from their refugee camps in Schleswig-Holstein and Lower Saxony because they turned out to be IS terrorists. Die Welt am Sonntag also revealed in a report over the weekend that Iraqis and Syrians are travelling back to their country with their suitcase, even though they are registered as refugees here. I am not the one who says that all immigrants are terrorists, but please stop saying that they are all refugees. Of course, you need that moral sauce: refugees, saving lives at sea and more like that. But it would be less hypocritical and fairer of you if you were to simply tell the truth: "We in the European Commission have decided to organise a popular replacement over the heads of you, European citizens. We have decided that you will have to deal with immigration uninvited, the largest and the wildest immigration and the mass immigration with the greatest impact in the history of this continent." You should say that. You should have the honesty for that, and I call on you to do so.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Madam President, it is at least a good thing that you have begun to admit as a problem that the mass movements of refugees and illegal immigrants need to be solved. We have heard many political leaders, even in this Chamber, say that immigrants will solve the problem of the ageing of the peoples of Europe, that they will contribute to our economic development. You will of course also remember the graphic events with the slogans in Germany 'welcome refugees'. The results of the recent elections in some European countries show us that people have a different view than you would like them to have. So, afraid of losing your seats and privileges, you are now starting to treat the situation as it really is. Based on ideological obsessions, you are trying to provide a propaganda rather than a humanitarian solution, while in practice the huge and illegal turnout of desperate people from every corner of the world continues. Firstly, as far as refugees are concerned, this designation should be given to those provided for but should apply only in the host country. Do not become countries, such as Greece and Italy, warehouses of human souls. As a host country it cannot be other than the first country in which refugees enter. All countries must contribute financially to the costs required to ensure them a human living as long as they remain there, and exert political pressure to end the situation that forced them to become refugees. Every refugee's dream is to return home. Economic migrants can only come after expressions of interest, and illegal immigrants should immediately be deported back to their countries. If the wars do not stop and we allow large companies to exploit the peoples of developing countries inhumanely, there will never be a real solution.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, High Representative, I have listened with interest to your speech on this point. Personally, I am very happy that a summit is being held to address the causes of migration and not just the consequences and follow-up. Here, in the European Parliament, we are essentially just debating how to deal with the consequences of migration waves, and that is simply not enough, because we will never solve or reduce migration by following measures.  I believe that the key is to work with the countries where migrants primarily come from. It will be necessary to have targeted investments in these countries, to help people in countries so that they have no reason to make big migration waves. It will be very difficult to find a concrete form, especially when we look at, for example, this morning's negotiations, there has been a debate about the Trust Fund for Africa, where money is simply lacking. So, in my opinion, finding concrete solutions to help countries from which people migrate is to be the aim of your summit negotiations.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the United Nations Summit on Refugees and Migrants will be a test of cooperation to respond to the greatest global challenge we face: to be able to make millions of people forced to leave their countries in search of protection and dignity.  European governments - some more than others - have not lived up to their moral and legal obligations as members of the European Union. Refugees and migrants are suffering at europe's doorsteps and on European soil horrendous human rights violations, especially women and unaccompanied minors. Thousands give their lives to networks of traffickers and other organised crime, which our governments thrive by refusing to open legal and safe avenues for those who need asylum or work. This is what this is about not only the credibility, but really the very security of Europe.  The relocation process decided by the European Council marks a step, only 3 000 of 160 000 people have been resettled. For six months, a group of 470 Yazidis have been waiting near Idomeni, Greece, for arriving in Portugal, which reiterates that it can welcome them.  The EU-Turkey pact promotes the opening of new business routes for traffickers and involves deporting people prevented from even seeking asylum or family reunification.  As if that were not enough, the Union wants to replicate the model with regimes causing the oppression and misery of refugees and migrants fleeing - such as ethiopia, which is killing Ethiopians, Madam High Representative, in the face of the complicit silence of the European Union. Building walls, as announced in Calais, in addition to wasting resources, is ineffective and goes against everything the European Union stands for.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE).
text: Madam President, Madam High Representative, this summit is a great first, but it must not go unheeded. For this reason, the key question is to make it a real turning point in the face of migration challenges so that this approach, for the first time in the world, will enable leaders to evolve, to change behaviours, as you pointed out in your opening remarks. There will be many world leaders there, and at the same time they have refused, for the most part, for months, the reception of Syrian refugees, especially in Europe. They refuse to participate in relocation and resettlement. For the record, in 2015, 8,500 people were resettled in Europe. It is necessary, Madam High Representative, to take this summit the important step, the step you were talking about, of this comprehensive approach and not turn it into a ball of hypocrites, because we need a clear message, concrete answers, to prevent it from looking like a charade. Many of us rely on you in New York.

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, of course this summit will be a great opportunity to talk about resettlement, and resettlement is a good thing. It is something we should do and, of course, we should do it well. But I think it would be a mistake if we, the European Union, were to go to the summit and say ‘Hey, we are doing great, you should do more!’ because we should not forget that other regions of the world are carrying a much larger share of the responsibility. Think of poorer countries like Lebanon, think of countries like Pakistan that host a huge population of refugees, while we as Europeans, a rich continent with 500 million inhabitants, are not even able to host one million refugees – which I think is a big shame. So we should not be finger-pointing, we should instead look at ourselves and see how can we do more and what can we do better, and I think there is a lot of room for improvement. One of the issues that it would be good to reconsider is the fact that money is indeed needed, but that we need fresh money, not money already earmarked for certain projects that are not going to be done, or just calculated into the resettlement effort. We should be honest with ourselves here.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Never, ever have we witnessed the migration that is now taking place to Europe. The attempts to stop it will not succeed, because you are wrong about the root cause of why it is happening now. It is no coincidence that such a large proportion of migrants make their way to Sweden and Germany. Our preferential benefit systems, combined with incompetent leaders, who, without thinking of welcoming the whole world to our countries, have created this crisis. Now we in Europe have instead found ourselves in a situation where we are being blackmailed by Turkey. In addition, we are putting forward idiotic proposals on coercive mechanisms and removing the right of Member States to self-determination on immigration. You are constantly talking about solidarity, but we in Sweden know what your solidarity means. We always take care of your problems in the end and pay the most to the EU budget per inhabitant of all. It is time for you to start thinking about the real refugees, on the ground, without confusing them with economic migrants.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it has taken this extraordinary migration crisis to open its eyes and make the European Union open its eyes and finally decide on the policy that we have always been calling for, that of helping these peoples in their countries and perhaps stamping out this unworldly trafficking in human beings that is called immigration that is enslaved to major interests.
