We can ask the Dalai Lama tomorrow what he thinks of immigration, as he said in ten interviews: it is the uprooting of peoples, so we can have a different idea of immigration without being racist or xenophobic, because the Dalai Lama is neither racist nor xenophobic, nor is the very important document that in Italy three presidents of the regions most affected, three regions of the North, is not comparable to these judgments. , have drawn up – I will give it to the High Representative – which sets out a number of points. It is a balanced document, which deals with the immigration emergency in a secular but intelligent and constructive way.  We must recognise this state of emergency, the fact that the landing of illegal immigrants through the carts of the sea is the wrong method that serves only the traffickers. We are now discovering the tragedy of organ removal, a disgrace that should be fought militarily by Europe, we need to support policies to combat trafficking and to set up centres for collection, identification and assistance in Africa as well.  In order to be opposed to this immigration, we have the right not to be accused, as I have heard from Mrs Mogherini's speech, of being the least of racism. We reject this thing, which we consider unworthy of a political force, unworthy of our honour. We are opposed to this immigration, which means trafficking in human flesh, the removal of organs, mafia trafficking, which you have not been able to combat properly. It is high time that we began to help the peoples of Africa and not to serve the interests of the big banks and multinationals. It's about time!

name: Linda McAvan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, like colleagues here, I welcome this summit. It is a first, and let us hope it leads to some concrete results and that these two compacts will actually lead to change and to new players being brought into both humanitarian aid and development aid. I think Ska Keller is right that we should go for a certain humility though. We do not have a perfect track record on refugee policy, and 86% of refugees live in the poorest countries on the planet, not in Europe. As you said, Ms Mogherini, it is only in recent years that we have begun to take this issue seriously, as refugees started landing on our shores. We were not particularly bothered until that point. But you have also spoken about the need for a long—term approach and I hope that is something we will take into account when we develop the appropriate instruments. This morning we voted on the Africa Trust Fund in this Parliament, and the key message from our resolution is that we need to keep an eye on long-term development, on reducing poverty and reducing inequalities, on gender equality, tackling climate change and improving the lives and the economic and social well-being of people in the world’s poorest countries. We have got to be very careful not to divert funding into things like border controls or to use our development policy as a kind of carrot and stick, introducing a new kind of creeping conditionality into it, linked to returns and border controls. I think you get that, Ms Mogherini, but I think there are some in our Member States who do not get it at all. They see the EU development budget as an endless pot of money which they can dip into for their new ideas. But we will not tackle the refugee crisis and the migration crisis by cutting development funding. So I think your approach on partnership is the right one and I hope you will be able to stick to it.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Madam High Representative, this UN summit represents a unique opportunity to establish a more inclusive system at the international level, which is much needed because the crisis we are currently experiencing is not a refugee crisis but a refugee crisis. With fewer than a dozen countries alone taking in half of the refugees, there is an urgent need for states to commit to a better sharing of responsibilities. I hope that the European Union will defend an ambitious and united position with numerical objectives and concrete measures. Without this, we know, unfortunately, that States will turn away from their good promises far too quickly. This summit should also be an opportunity to affirm that development aid should not be conditioned on border management objectives. Development aid aims to combat poverty and inequality, not to strengthen border control to prevent people from leaving the country. I hope that the countries of the European Union will be up to the challenges of this summit.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we have to tell the truth to the United Nations about illegal economic immigration. We must abandon this Eirenist vision of immigration at the expense of the law, the rights of our peoples, but also the peoples of the sending countries, who are losing their economic strength. We must abandon this collusion between illegal immigration and the maximum profit economy that exploits illegals. We must abandon indirect support for mafia and criminal groups and submit, among other things, to the Satrap Erdogan.  Will these facts be heard? I do not know, because we have a vision of a world of mobility, of a generalized world where countries are nothing more than hotels of an open world, but this hotel becomes a world of going for traffickers and criminals.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The UN Summit is a very important event, perhaps the most important event of the year that is coming to an end. It is in the tradition of decades of work by the United Nations – UNHCR, UNRWA, etc. – and it is good that, at a time when the world seems to be getting out of hand and the refugee movement is growing and many people are also unsettled by it, the international community is starting a structured discussion about more coordination and better protection of individual rights.  There are two phenomena at the summit. It is about migration – a phenomenon that has always existed, but which has a very special significance in the globalised economy. And it is important that migration is seen not only as a burden, but also as an opportunity for the host countries and for the people. That is why it must be shaped politically. As the number of refugees increases, it is also important to take a special look at this issue. This is not voluntary migration.  And we should try to improve the situation in the refugee camps, to discuss safe zones and how we can organise them, to improve funding – above all, the promised funds should actually arrive. And it is also important that we talk about the organisation of resettlement, quotas, humanitarian entry corridors and quotas, because that is the best guarantee that people will not drown on the high seas.

name: Barbara Lochbihler (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, High Representative, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. This UN summit on migration is certainly also an opportunity to put the current EU refugee policy to the test. And there are areas of which we cannot be proud at all, such as the term 'proud' at the beginning, Mrs Mogherini. The EU-Turkey-Deal, for example, has been highly questionable from the point of view of international and human rights from the outset. And it is more than obvious that the EU is aiming to ensure that fewer people find protection here. Now the European Commission has announced that it will take the EU-Turkey deal as a blueprint – presumably again past the European Parliament – in order to conclude similar treaties with other third countries, despite a sometimes disastrous human rights record on the ground. Ana Gomes has quoted some country examples here.  The Commission's proposals are therefore in part blatantly at odds with Article 21 of the European Treaties. They violate international and human rights norms. That is why I strongly warn against bringing these very proposals forward as solutions at global level.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it must be admitted that the European Union found itself unprepared a year ago when mixed flows of refugees and migrants from the east and the south reached the European continent, those driven by war, persecution, and those seeking better opportunities.  I think that next week's summit will serve to remind us Europeans that this is not a limited phenomenon, affecting only our coasts or our borders. The large movements of people, refugees and migrants, are a global event and therefore require an equal approach. And where can we discuss global solutions if not in the United Nations, the forum best suited to firmly renewing the values of dignity and equality of each individual?  I believe that, in order to better deal with these movements of people, governments must have a clear difference between the status of refugee and migrant, not in the treatment of human beings, but in the formation of more appropriate, more appropriate policies, emergency measures for extraordinary situations in the case of refugees and long-term measures for managing the flow of migrants. I hope that world leaders will be aware of the need to create a more responsible system, based on the paradigm shift proposed by the General Assembly, that is, the transition from weight sharing to sharing responsibility in the management of large movements of people.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am totally behind the concept of a holistic approach to migration and the refugee movement, and also the debate on that important issue at the United Nations. What I have to observe critically though is the timing. Today, we have about 60 million people regarded as refugees. Ten years ago that number stood at about 37 million so it has almost doubled in that short timespan. We could have, and should have, acted much sooner. It is crystal clear that action – decisive action – cannot wait any longer. Another point which is important to me is that one third of all people fleeing are children. I am counting on you, Ms Mogherini, to ensure that the debate in New York will concern itself particularly with that tragic aspect. We must not forget, we cannot forget, we cannot afford to forget those most vulnerable.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too will be at the New York Summit, and while it is good that it marks a new awareness that this is a global challenge which, as the High Representative says, needs a global response, the summit unfortunately looms as a missed opportunity.  The commitment of the richest countries to take in 10% of the total number of refugees has been skipped, a request made by Ban Ki-moon himself. There is no concrete agreement, only wishes and good intentions; the adoption of the two Global Compacts is also postponed until 2018, but people fleeing cannot wait two years, as can developing countries, which are making the greatest efforts.  Only 27 states have regular resettlement programs around the world. Of course, we too would be more credible in calling for a global sharing of efforts if, in the meantime, we were to sets a good example within ourselves. A year ago, European governments committed themselves to resettlement and the 160 000 relocations, and made a few thousand of them, while Canada, for example, resettled 25 000 Syrians in four months, showing that the European union is not a problem of numbers or means, but only and exclusively of political will.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D). Madam President, according to UN figures, there are 65 million displaced persons and refugees worldwide and 244 million migrants. The unstable geopolitical and economic environment, the consequences of climate change and the demographic explosion in african countries lead us to conclude that these figures will increase further in the coming years. That is why it is important for the UN conference to prepare for an era of very high human mobility. But I hope that we do not stick to words and move on to actions in relation to what we as Europe have done. A typical example is the relocation programme, which is growing: only 3677 refugees out of 6400 have gone from Greece to other countries. Three Member States have not taken a single refugee and two Member States have not even declared availability. If there is no comprehensive plan, a solidarity plan respecting human rights but also the social cohesion and security of citizens, we will experience the rise of intolerance, either by extending the power of its own representatives, such as Mrs Le Pen, or by adopting their ideas through the conservative turn of the current governments.

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the official key speaker of the UN summit at the end of September will be Prince Zeid Raad el-Hussein of Jordan, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, who, in one of his most recent speech, listed Prime Minister Viktor Orban as one of the politicians who called him a 'populist' whose 'ideology is close to the spirit of the Islamic State'. A few days later, Luxembourg's Foreign Minister Jean Asselborn launched a similar attack on our Prime Minister in connection with the forthcoming quota quota in Hungary, directly initiating the Hungary of the European Union. Rejecting these false and hostile attacks by founding Muslim and European prejudice and bias, I respectfully ask Parliament and, personally, Vice-President Federica Mogherini, to defend Prime Minister Viktor Orban, who has been wrongly accused, and Hungary, which insists on its national sovereignty as a Member State of the Union.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with regard to the summit organised by the United Nations, I look forward to the private sector meetings to be held on the sidelines of the summit. I find this area significant because we know that the contribution made by NGOs has proved indispensable in carrying out assistance and relief functions that local institutions and authorities, due to lack of resources or mandate limits, cannot always provide; their role and contribution must be recognised and encouraged.  I sincerely hope that at the next summit we will be able to find shared, sustainable and long-term solutions to the dramatic situation of the movement of migrants and refugees, so as to make up for the lack of solidarity and responsibility that has unfortunately been experienced in Europe, even in recent times. And in my opinion, our greatest responsibility relates to unaccompanied minors. It is necessary, and that is why we know that we can count on you, Mrs Mogherini, to bring the tragedy of unaccompanied minors into the discussions of the summit so that the protection of children becomes a priority, a reality and everywhere.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Honourable High Representative, honourable members, the huge migration waves are the global phenomenon of this decade and there is no national solution for them. I therefore believe that the high-level forum to be held under the auspices of the UN is essential. We must have a leading role in it as one of the most affected countries, but also the largest humanitarian aid donor in the world. For the first time, state leaders, NGOs and all stakeholders will gather in search of a response to the refugee crisis. The European Union must work towards a strong political declaration that forms the basis for a global and effective framework for cooperation based on the shared responsibility for accepting refugees and migrants. I believe that this forum is also a historic opportunity to counter the xenophobia and hate language that refugees and migrants most often fall under, while at the same time seeking the global formula for their integration into free democratic societies.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam Representative, on the 19th, as you said, there will be a United Nations General Assembly, the first International Conference at Heads and Government level on refugees. Everyone is talking about an important historic opportunity to finally come up with a comprehensive plan to deal with refugee flows. I wonder what the leaders of Europe will support the day after tomorrow because, as you said, those who will speak of solidarity are the same people who refuse to accept refugees in their countries. Those who will talk about fair sharing of responsibilities are the same people who, after a whole year, have carried out less than five per cent of the famous redistribution mechanism. Those who will defend safe and smooth refugee flows are the same people who build walls and publicly beg refugees not to come to Europe. After all, just the day before yesterday, the President of the European Council made it clear to us that the practical capacity of the Europe of twenty-seven states and five hundred million citizens to host new waves of refugees, not to mention irregular economic migrants, is close to the limit. What are you going to do about it, Madam Representative? That's what I want you to answer.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the summit but it appears that the historic opportunity to find a desperately needed global solution to the crisis has been lost. Some governments are rejecting the plan to resettle 10% of the world’s refugees annually and have delayed any chance of a deal until 2018. We cannot allow the politics of fear to paralyse us and allow this humanitarian crisis and suffering go on. Policies focused on deterrents and building walls are doomed to fail. Europe must redouble its efforts in addressing the sources of the refugee crisis and not just the symptoms. This means providing more support to developing countries to get refugees access to employment and education opportunities. However, maintaining aid is not enough. One in five people in Lebanon are refugees. By comparison, there is one refugee for every 530 people in the UK. We must step up the responsibility sharing, not responsibility shifting. War and instability, poverty and climate change all mean that people will keep trying to come to Europe in search of refuge or a better life. Only if we act globally can we find effective and lasting solutions to this crisis. Europe must lead the way and set an example.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy/Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, many of you called – well, some of you called – in this room for us to tell the truth, so let’s try to do this exercise once again together. First, as some of you mentioned, migration or human mobility is part of the history of mankind. To tell the truth mankind itself is the result of human mobility, and maybe we should keep that a bit in mind. Coming from some countries this might be easier to remember, for others maybe a little bit difficult, but all of us, all of us, are the result of human mobility: truth number one. Second truth, others are doing more than the European Union is doing, you were saying this perfectly well. This is not a European phenomenon, and even less a European crisis. If you look at the movements of people inside Africa, inside Asia, they are much bigger than the movements of people towards Europe from these two continents, not only combined but also taken alone. And wherever you go in Africa or in Asia, every single country, or almost every single country, is itself at the same time a country of origin, a country of destination and a country of transit. So we have to get a little bit out, in our public debate, of this Eurocentric approach that we are at the centre of the flows of the whole world, and realise that indeed there are many other countries in the world, most of the time countries that are living in conditions that are much more difficult than ours from an economic point of view, from a climate point of view, from a conflict point of view, that are doing much more than we are doing. And indeed that we can lead by example, if we are able to provide some good examples – and let me tell you in some fields we are not. I mentioned things which I am not particularly proud of, but we are in some other fields capable of leading by example.  And let me tell you, on a personal note, I had the occasion of briefing the UN Security Council twice, this year and last year, on the EU policies on migration and I have noticed a radical change in the attitude of our global partners to our response, or our policies on both refugee and migration, which means that probably – let me put it this way a bit bluntly – last year we woke up. We woke up in what was for many a surprise, not for me personally, not for many in this room, but for many of us was a sudden wake-up. And this year we managed to elaborate or to react to this shock and put in place policies – finally.  I often told you, I told you at the beginning of our debate today, to me it was a shock when I came in, moving from my time being an Italian minister to the position of High Representative, that migration was not on the table of the Foreign Affairs Council. It was a purely internal matter, as if we had to tackle this issue only from an internal point of view, but where are these people coming from? So we come from there. Two years ago, this was not an issue, if not an issue of interior ministers only, so in two years I think we have come a long way. Third truth: there are things where we can lead by example. There are solutions we can find only if we do it together, as Europeans and globally. And what we can try to do is to manage this complex phenomenon in all these different aspects. I will come to the different aspects in a moment, but let me stress one point that I think Mr Panzeri mentioned. I refer to this as the need to manage a complex phenomenon. I will never, never personally call this a problem or a burden, because it is people. It is people with names, stories, even when we do not see the photos, it is people. So the language we use is important, the respect we pay to persons is important, especially to children, and the point on non-accompanied children is one that we will for sure bring up in New York. We have to keep that in mind also when the photos are not on the front line, on the front page of the newspapers, and let me tell you with sadness and shock, I never understand the fact that those that claim our Christian identity the most are also those who are the first to forget the word and the message of Pope Francis on migration and refugees. This is a mystery to me. So we can do things to manage this phenomenon together, as Europeans and globally. It is different aspects of things we need to do. On the refugees, it is the urgency of supporting globally, first on resettlement programmes, something good, something we need to do more, something we need to encourage our partners to do more, and also financial support, which is what we are doing the most. We need, on migration, to work on the implementation of the SDGs, on Agenda 2030, on investments in countries of origin and transit. I am glad to hear also from the right side of the Chamber tonight that indeed there is support also from that side to increase our budget for development policies. This is news to me, welcome news, and I think that will need to be tested with coherent and consistent voting, but this is good news if we realise that investing long-term in the economic and social development of countries from where people are coming, is indeed a major step forward in our own policies.  Then, we also need to work very much on dismantling the smugglers and the people traffickers. This is what we are trying to do at sea. This is also what we are trying to do with our partners in some countries, in full respect of human rights, and in coordination with the IOM and with UNHCR. This goes together with opening regular channels for migration. The more we open regular channels for migration, the more we manage to discourage the irregular channels, thus preventing the loss of lives at sea and on land, especially in the desert.  And here let me mention we have to work with partners more and more. I mentioned the UNHCR and the IOM. The summit in New York will be essential in this respect, the role of civil society and NGOs is crucial, as is the role of local authorities also here in Europe, in so many cases they are doing much more the national governments, let me tell you. So we need a partnership approach, also internally probably, to put together different strengths, and I will close by saying that indeed the role of the European Parliament’s delegation in New York at the summit will be important. We will meet there and I hope that we will manage to pass on together this message, knowing that it is a political fight, and that we have taken some steps forward in the last two years, in the last year in particular, and that I think we will need to continue working together using this window of opportunity.  I would not call the UN summit that is coming ahead an exercise that has its limits. Let’s go, let’s go and bring our inputs, let’s go and test our own policies. Let’s go and meet our partners, let’s go and try to build these global partnerships and with a sense of the limits, but also with a sense of hope that this phenomenon can be managed. I thank you very much and I am continuously counting on the European Parliament’s support and work in this respect. (Applause)

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE)
text: in writing. - I welcome the United Nations High-Level Summit on Large Movements of Refugees and Migrants and the political agreement reached by 193 States. I am particularly grateful that there is a compromise that focuses on both sides: on the one hand, refugees and, on the other hand, safe, orderly and regular migration. It was absolutely essential that all countries come together to provide a comprehensive response to a problem that is. I welcome the creation of a more responsible, predictable and supportive system, with shared responsibility. For all this, UNHCR plays and will play a key role, as initiator and developer of the response, but in coordination with all other actors, such as receiving States, local and national entities, international organizations, etc. UNHCR cannot deal with the problem alone. I therefore applaud the willingness of these 193 countries to give a global approach to this crisis, but I hope they do not stay in that, in simple will. We must thoroughly study the causes of these mass population movements, so that we can anticipate them, and take it as a development challenge and not exclusively humanitarian.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Dear Mr President, I welcome the organisation for the first time of a UN summit on refugees and migration and the adoption of a global framework to tackle the problem. Indeed, the migration situation in Europe's neighbourhood should not be seen as an isolated, regional problem, but as a global challenge with deep roots that needs lasting solutions.  The current humanitarian situation requires a collective political response and shared international commitments. In order to demand more solidarity at global level, an example must also be given by the European Union and its Member States – by overcoming the current solidarity crisis and fully sharing responsibility for refugees.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The representatives of the Member States and the European Union make a very significant contribution to this summit. The silence! The silence of shame of those who have responsibilities in destabilization and war, particularly in the North Africa and Middle East region. The silence of shame of those who tolerate and sponsor walls at the borders of several European countries, of which Hungary and France are recent examples. The silence of shame for those who respond militarily to a very serious humanitarian crisis, from whom it has allowed the Mediterranean to become an authentic mass grave. Over 10, 000 dead in three years! The silence of shame of those who trample human rights on European soil every day and have created genuine concentration camps. Be ashamed of the xenophobic and racist agenda they have promoted and which fuels waves of discrimination, the upsurge of the far right and fascism! They say fire to teach lessons on human rights or on responding to the drama and needs of refugees, because they have none to give!

name: Kati Piri (S&D)
text: Written. – With nearly 60 million people on the run worldwide, it is good for the UN to come together to discuss the major challenges of global migration. But major challenges call for ambitious solutions, which I am unfortunately not in the preliminary conclusions of the summit. As the UN countries cannot agree on large-scale resettlement, it is decided to discuss it again next year, but a solution is now needed for millions of people who are entitled to international protection. The European Commission is proposing to resettle 20 000 people a year in Europe, but I would ask Federica Mogherini to adjust this ambition and call for the resettlement of at least 100 000 vulnerable refugees a year. The EU must take the lead and fulfil its humanitarian duty by setting a good example: working to resettle the most vulnerable refugees on a scale and to put an end to the appalling conditions in Greece and Italy through redistribution.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 2011 – just five years ago, many people greeted with naïve enthusiasm the so-called 'Arab spring' which were turned into 'Islamic winters' at an early stage. Despair has taken the place of the dream, fear has replaced optimism, violence has occupied those squares where it used to manifest itself peacefully.  What was then the leading country in the democratic aspirations of the Arab world, today, in a North Africa and a Middle East torn apart by civil wars and terrorism, pressed by the return of strong men and by a continuing economic, political and social instability, becomes the last hope, the only torch in the darkness: that hope is called Tunisia.  Unfortunately, its recent achievements constitute an extremely fragile architecture that needs protection first and for all from us Europeans, its immediate neighbours. To this end, together with my fellow shadow rapporteurs – whom I warmly thank for the important contributions proposed and for the extremely constructive spirit that has animated every stage of our work – I have tackled the pillars of the definitive consolidation of a partnership and cooperation that we want to be solid, lasting and fruitful for both sides, on an equal footing and on an equal footing.  Economic development and security are inseparable. The terrorist threat feeds precisely on many young people who, disappointed by the lack of immediate responses to the high expectations raised by the jasmine revolution, end up being easy prey for recruiters of terrorist organisations, fuelling Tunisia's sad record of the number of foreign fighters. Libya is there, one step away, as is the entire Sahel region and its perennial pre-international state, where jihadist armed gangs easily violate borders.  On the other hand, the difficult economic and financial situation in the country, with public debt now reaching 62% of GDP, with a further 15% drop in tourism, presents us with the need for timely action. Without real social inclusion, without an energetic fight against unemployment, we will perhaps win a few battles but we will lose the revolution.  That is why in the report we call for a decisive increase in the funds from the European Neighbourhood Instrument and for the coordination of aid from other donors. I welcome the recent statements by the High Representative, who has repeatedly expressed his willingness to do so as early as next year. However, we must have the courage to tackle with sincerity the issue of the sustainability of Tunisia's debt, which is the odious result of the years of dictatorship. It is necessary to aim for conversion into investment projects, in particular by exploiting the country's enormous potential in the field of renewables and by redeciting regional disparities, which are particularly evident in the south and west of the country.  The sense of responsibility and commitment certainly do not disre end to the Tunisians, who continue to act, despite some physiological turbulence, with rare commonality of purpose. The Carthage Agreement has led to the creation of a new executive of national unity, which is also open to civil society. Prime Minister Youssef Chahed has before him the enormous challenge of making the reforms necessary, on the one hand, for the socio-economic recovery of the country, in particular on the basis of public administration and an effective anti-corruption plan, and, on the other, for the defence of public order and security, which is as effective as it is in accordance with constitutional principles and the rule of law – a difficult balance.  In front of the Union and all of us Europeans, however, there is no less important duty to live up to the expectations we have raised and nurtured. In addition to economic aid, we must encourage circular mobility, visa facilitation, especially for artists, students and professors, as well as all forms of partnership in the field of culture.  Tunisia's stability is our stability. Tunisia's prosperity is our prosperity. To achieve them, encouragement – however sincere – is no longer enough, unless it is followed by actions that live up to the words of the poet Abu l-Qasim al-Shabbi, who has always been a symbol of the struggle against the authoritarianism of the Arab world, words that have finally become part of the national anthem: "If one day the people wish to live, then fate will listen to his prayer".  As Europeans, as defenders of democracy, as friends of Tunisia, we have a moral duty to be part of the destiny of the Tunisian people and to listen to their prayers with fraternal solidarity.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: VP/AR. – Signor Presidente, onorevoli deputati, ringrazio l'on. Castaldo e tutti i colleghi che hanno lavorato a questa relazione che mostra una panoramica davvero completa su un paese fondamentale per l'Europa e per la nostra regione.  La Tunisie n'est pas seulement au centre géographique de la Méditerranée. Comme on l'a dit, elle est un symbole, premièrement d'espoir, d'espoir d'unité, de démocratie pour toute la région, avec beaucoup de problèmes qu'il ne faut pas cacher, mais qu'il faut essayer de régler ensemble. C'est un exemple, c'est un symbole d'espoir et de démocratie, premièrement parce que sa classe politique a préféré la négociation à l'affrontement. Le prix Nobel a reconnu la société civile tunisienne comme un acteur clé de la réconciliation nationale et le principe même de réconciliation nationale est en soi un élément d'espoir et aussi un symbole d'unité pour toute la région. L'histoire récente du pays est le démenti le plus évident à la prétendue incompatibilité entre islam et démocratie. Pour toutes ces raisons, le succès de la démocratie en Tunisie répond aux intérêts des citoyens européens, de la même manière qu'il répond aux intérêts des citoyens tunisiens et de toute la région Aujourd'hui, cinq années après la révolution, le pays traverse une phase décisive. Le projet de résolution met en lumière quelques-uns des principaux défis que la Tunisie doit encore relever, y compris la menace terroriste, la radicalisation d'une partie très importante de sa jeunesse, une situation économique difficile et un processus de réformes difficile.  The report also proposes a long and good list of possible actions in support of Tunisia asking to go ‘beyond conventional measures’. So I must say that this approach is exactly the same that we have taken in our global strategy, calling for a full use of all of all our foreign policy instruments in a combined and coherent way. The report spans from security sector reform to development cooperation. It calls for greater engagement with local actors and with regional organisations, with the private sector as well as with civil society. It focuses on trade, but also on climate change and the fight against desertification, and it endorses the work that Operation Sophia is doing in the Mediterranean, while calling for greater engagement of EU agencies in Tunisia.  So if you look at this list, it is clear that no national government – no-one of us alone – has the tools or the resources to implement such an ambitious plan alone. The plan is good. We need the European Union to make it. So only together, as a true European Union, can we aim this high. In fact the last year has already marked a very significant step in increasing cooperation between the European Union and Tunisia. In the wake of recent terrorist attacks we have invested EUR 23 million to support Tunisia’s security sector reform. In particular we focused on securing Tunisia’s borders and in strengthening its intelligence services’ capacity to prevent and fight against terrorism.  At the beginning of 2016 Tunisia became the first Arab country to participate fully in our Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme, offering new opportunities for Tunisian researchers and academics. I could not exaggerate the importance of this – of people-to-people contacts – especially for our young people, in our relationship. The negotiations for the readmission and visa facilitation agreements, which will begin in exactly one month, also have the potential to strengthen the legal channels for mobility between Tunisia and Europe, as you just mentioned.  Less than a year ago we launched negotiations towards a Deep and Comprehensive Trade Agreement which could attract huge investments to Tunisia and help restart growth. Another round will take place this autumn. Since the revolution we have doubled our financial assistance to Tunisia and we hope to increase the total envelope by almost a third in 2017. So the trend is very clear. Our partnership is growing stronger by the day. This trend will be confirmed in the joint communication we are presenting together – myself and Commissioner Hahn. The text is under preparation and will soon be adopted, but I can anticipate that its priority lines will be very much in line with your report and the draft resolution. The communication will be a key instrument for us to engage our institutions – European institutions and Member States – in the support to the Tunisian transition. It will offer a mix of announced financial cooperation and non—financial measures, responding directly to the main axis of the Tunisian five-year development plan.  For this reason we will focus on good governance and the reform of public administration, on security as well as on tackling inequalities and unemployment, particularly among young graduates, because we know very well that is the place where the biggest problem lies. To do so we will keep engaging with Tunisian institutions to support reforms. Let me just mention the urgent adoption of the Code of Investment and the long-awaited five-year development plan. But we will also look at civil society, the private sector, mayors and local authorities, and especially – let me stress this once again – at Tunisian youth, starting from the Tunisian girls who played such a huge role in the revolution at that time and who are now seeing their dreams fading away. I believe that, thanks to our work, and to your work, with Tunisia this Parliament has directly witnessed the impact of our policy in the country. Tunisia’s Foreign Minister has recently defined the European Union as ‘the first sponsor of democracy and human rights in the country’. So indeed our engagement there is making a difference in very concrete terms. It is one of those places where we – and only we – can make such a big difference. To all Tunisians the European Union means something good, and if we manage to do something good for the Tunisians we are also going to do something good for the Europeans. I believe that Europe really needs to rediscover this huge potential, this huge transformational power, we have in some parts of our neighbourhood. And our region does indeed need a stronger Europe as a champion of peace and democracy, starting from Tunisia.  Come ha giustamente detto: la stabilità della Tunisia è la nostra stabilità. La sicurezza della Tunisia è la nostra sicurezza. E vorrei aggiungere che la speranza della Tunisia è anche la nostra speranza.

name: Lorenzo Cesa
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam High Representative, I should like to begin by congratulating Mr Castaldo on the report we are debating and on the absolutely inclusive working method he has used, thanks in particular to Castaldo. I am particularly pleased today that the High Representative and Commissioner Hahn are here, stressing the importance of this issue and helping to enrich our debate.  Tunisia is an example of valuable aid for the Maghreb countries and can play a key role in the Euro-Mediterranean area. That is why we have strongly emphasised in the text the country's strategic role and our support for the completion of reforms and the implementation of the Constitution. The report that we are going to adopt offers important food for thought: we condemn acts of terrorism and express strong solidarity with a country that has repeatedly been the victim of attacks that risk weakening the democratic process and which have a strong impact on the internal economy of the area. The terrorists' goal is to conquer the country and throw it into fear. The issue of safety is a priority and, unfortunately, a very difficult situation persists.  We must not forget the migration issues. The reality on our doorstep is dramatic and it is clear that we cannot respond to this emergency on our own. I believe that the European Union should address all the countries bordering the Mediterranean and that Tunisia can play a decisive role.  We also want to identify shared interests in the priority areas of intervention. The centrality of the country and the considerable progress made by Tunisia must be valued and fully supported. It is becoming necessary and urgent to invest in tunisia: every euro spent on Tunisia is also a euro spent on the stability and security of our Europe. In this context, it bodes well for the birth of the new executive on 29 August: a young government determined to take the path of rehabilitation and relaunch of the country.  I believe that the firm adoption of this report is the best way of informing the Tunisian people that Europe is with them.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am convinced, Mr Solana, that Tunisia is a hope in the Middle East and southern Mediterranean region.  I do not want to talk about a model, because to think that the Tunisian experiment can be successfully replicated in other similar contexts is now a gamble, because in the face of the many steps that have been made there is still a long way to go to prevent Tunisia from remaining suspended between the desire for change – an epochal change, finally structural and definitive, with a view to the future of the new generations – and the traditionalist pressures , suspended between a generation of people from the last century and that 55% of the population under the age of thirty, suspended between a developed east and a decidedly backward west, and suspended between the young people who go to the streets to demand more social justice and the 3 000 young people who have chosen the cause of ISIS.  This report, which Mr Castaldo has worked out well, points the way and the objectives to be achieved and is a contribution by this Parliament to the democratic and social stabilisation of Tunisia and, together with it, of the region. It is to be hoped that the new government will seize these opportunities. We are going to Tunisia next week and it will be an opportunity to bring this strong message of the European Parliament's consensus; we will then have the opportunity of the Week for Tunisia organised in November in the European Parliament. In essence, we want to work together with the Tunisian authorities and citizens because we are very interested in a modern and democratic Tunisia.

name: Amjad Bashir
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, firstly I would like to thank the rapporteur for his diligent and comprehensive work on this report. It has focus and presents clear ideas. Our relationship with Tunisia remains pivotal in terms of providing stable government, economic growth and a more pluralistic society. Economic development will be the bedrock of Tunisia’s stability, security and transformation into a successful democracy.  So let us encourage growth within the SME sector, and internal reforms to reduce bureaucracy and stimulate growth. Carefully managed macroeconomic assistance can help, but it must be coupled with tangible microeconomic benefits. In other words, one can build bridges and airports, but training teachers and addressing issues like water shortage is how to really win over the Tunisian man in the street.  It is also essential that we share best security and defence practices in order to help defeat extremists, but let us not forget that without stability in Libya, peace in Tunisia will be difficult to achieve. I support the efforts of the Tunisian Government to modernise and liberalise their economy to meet new domestic, regional and global demands. A strong and diverse economy will create jobs, opportunity and prosperity, allowing the country to achieve its aim of participating fully in the international community.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Bashir, the question is this: you talked about security and we have heard, even this evening, about the radicalisation of many youths, but we also see that there has been improvement in the situation in Libya, and this relates to the pressure on Daesh and the risk of these people going to regional countries. What regional strategy can we have to help to prevent this?

name: Amjad Bashir (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – I think you ask a very pertinent question, Mr Khan. It reminds me of when I visited the United Nations and Kofi Annan said: security or development, which is more important? He said that development was even more important than security, because if people and youth are gainfully employed they are averse to becoming radicalised and falling into the trap of extremism. So I think we need to support Tunisia by developing it and providing its youth with job opportunities.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – With this report, we want to send an important signal from Parliament. Let us improve political dialogue with our neighbour Tunisia and strengthen our cooperation in the areas of trade, tourism, culture and, last but not least, the fight against terrorism. We believe that a more ambitious partnership is possible. Europe can only be prosperous and safe if things go well in neighbouring countries. That is what we want to achieve with this report. Politically, we call for Tunisia to take action against torture, to abolish the death penalty and to repeal a law prohibiting homosexuality. On the economic front, we, as members of the ALDE Group, believe it is very important for Tunisia to work to modernise and liberalise its economy, in order to create more jobs and to provide opportunities for young Tunisians. And that is very important for my third priority: the fight against terror. As Mrs Mogherini said, I am very concerned about the large numbers of Tunisian young people who join Daesh and other terrorist groups. We must join forces with Tunisia in this fight, ensure that young people are not recruited and draw up a plan of what to do when they return from those countries. Terrorism is a shared problem that we must tackle together. But did you know, ladies and gentlemen, that Europol is not even capable of cooperating with Tunisia in this area? Tunisia is not on the list of countries with which Europol can cooperate. I continue to think this is an incredibly missed opportunity. How do we want to make it safe in Europe if we cannot work together with all our European neighbours in this area? So please, Commission and Council, add Tunisia to that list of countries and let us fight with Europol and give our citizens the security they deserve.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, thank you first of all to our colleague Fabio Castaldo for the quality of his work and his desire to find the most consensual agreement possible. Tunisia is worth it, the Tunisian people deserve it. Yes, Tunisia has a special place. In 2011 many peoples looked at what was happening there. Tunisia has raised many hopes and the success of its democratic transition is more than ever an essential issue, far beyond the Maghreb. Much progress has been made, notably through the mobilization capacity of its civil society. We have seen that, particularly with the Constitution. Much remains to be done and concerns remain, particularly about young graduates and regional gaps. But also on the issue of human rights, including women's rights, on the issue of marriage, the issue of inheritance rights, LGBT rights, freedom of expression, torture, police violence, transitional justice, but also the death penalty. We owe real solidarity to the Tunisian people, we cannot be content with aid conditioned on structural reforms, geared towards European interests, which aggravate the Tunisian debt. The Assembly of People's Representatives is before a bill signed by almost all political groups in Tunisia, requesting an audit of the Tunisian debt. I welcome that and I hope that many of us will support them. Tunisia needs a real partnership, not just an economic one. A partnership that respects its interests, respects the interests of its people and especially its youth, to whom we must open the doors within the framework of a real mobility agreement.

name: Jordi Sebastià
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, welcome this report and thank you very much for the magnificent work that your manager, Mr Castaldo, has done. Tunisia's current president, Béji Ca'd Essebsi, told a delegation from this Parliament, in which the rapporteur was also, that there was no Arab Spring, that this was an invention of Western journalists. There was a Tunisian Spring. And it is true, because Tunisia is the only country in the area where there has been a popular revolution against a dictator and where fragile structures of democracy have been created, which may or may not be stabilized. Much more must be involved, not only financially but politically. You should look a lot further south and help eliminate those black spots that are lasoing the Tunisian process. Some of my colleagues have already said this: restrictions on freedom of expression, legislation against LGTBI groups, exception laws. And for that, our trade agreements with Tunisia must prioritize mutual benefit and take into account that we have a great ally there: civil society. They must also help that country on issues as basic to its economy as the development of renewable energy and the fight against desertification. And Tunisia also needs to recover, that we help it recover the money that dictator Ben Ali stole and which is still hidden in Europe. Tunisia's future is also ours. A unique opportunity for the Mediterranean to become a sea of encounter again and not that cemetery it is becoming.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would first like to welcome Mr Castaldo's report, which sends a positive message to our Tunisian partners. Tunisia has made remarkable progress over the past five years, with the restoration of freedoms, the holding of free elections and the adoption of a new constitution. Now the country is in the most delicate phase of the transition, because it seems to me that the essential challenge is a socio-economic challenge: getting the Tunisian economy back on track, reviving growth and jobs, is the way to avoid the explosion of this time bomb that is the unemployment experienced and the disenchantment felt by a majority of young Tunisians. It is obvious that Tunisia is in a geopolitical situation that does not help it at all, including the major impact of the Libyan crisis. The European Union has a vital role to play in helping Tunisia, first of all at the economic level. Initiatives such as support for the Tunisian olive oil sector are of paramount importance. It seems to me that this is in line with the new Union's neighbourhood policy. Our instruments need to be responsive and flexible so that we can use them when we need them most. I welcome the presence of Commissioner Hahn, who has worked for this new neighbourhood policy. We must also support Tunisia on a security level, not only through a strengthened partnership, but also by contributing to the resolution of the Libyan crisis. I am pleased to mention the fact that we are paying particular attention here in Parliament to relations with Tunisia, in particular by setting up the Joint Parliamentary Committee which will meet for the second time next week in Tunis. We will work in tandem, as we have done with other countries, notably Morocco and Algeria, and we will have the opportunity to support Tunisia as a model for other Arab countries.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Signora Presidente, onorevoli colleghi, caro amico Castaldo, ti voglio ringraziare per il tuo lavoro e anche per la tua amicizia verso la Tunisia. As he underlined in his very balanced report, the post-revolution example of Tunisia is a successful one and we need to do everything within our possibilities to support this new democracy. The stability and security of Tunisia are paramount for the stability and security of the wider region and are fundamental for European security. It is for this reason that Tunisia has been targeted by Daesh, and it is for the same reason that we need to be even closer to, and to support, Tunisia. Tunisia has suffered heavy consequences in its tourism industry and has also had to use large resources from its still fragile economy for security and military purposes and to face the Libyan refugee crisis. This is not the only reason for the current social and economic situation, but it has certainly contributed to it. I am glad that this Parliament played an active role in the case of olive oil under macro-financial assistance. We are right in demanding reforms, but we need to give this country and its new Unity Government all the necessary support and tools. And one final proposal. There is discussion right now about some of the Tunisian people’s assets which used to belong to Ben Ali and are still in European banks and within Member States. Let us do something and send back the assets to their owners, the Tunisian people!

name: María Teresa Giménez Barbat (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, tunisia is often said to represent a successful political model of transition to democracy after the Arab Spring in the Maghreb. It is, and we admire it. The new President's main challenge will be to put an end to the country's serious economic and social crisis, which poses a concrete threat to Tunisia, but also to the security of the entire Euro-Mediterranean area. I acknowledge, Mr Castaldo, the merit of having stressed in your report that a worrying number of young Tunisians are captured by the Islamic State or Dáesh. Numerous factors contribute to young people being attracted to the false promises of extremists, and one of them could be that a third of Tunisia's total working-age population does not now have jobs. In this context, the protests of young people in Tunisia are an alarm that Europe has to listen to. We need to put in place concrete measures so that the Union can support the country, with policies aimed at young people to integrate them into the labour market and help them plan their careers, and invest in new companies, and promote women's participation in the country's workforce.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank and congratulate rapporteur Castaldo on the very good report presented to us today. Tunisia is in the process of triple transition, political, economic and social, and also faces significant security challenges. This is a priority of the Union's neighbourhood policy, not only in order to ensure the continuation of the transition, but also because it has the potential to become a locomotive of the Mediterranean region on several fronts. On both sides, everyone must do their job in a mutual investment that is up to the challenge.  I will emphasize three things. First, young people. Their participation in the upcoming local elections is crucial, as is their inclusion in the labour market. To do this, we know, the education system must be able to meet the needs of the labour market, particularly in high-potential sectors such as agriculture or renewable energy.  Secondly, regional integration must be part of the security objectives of EU-Tunisia relations, on the one hand, in relation to the situation in Libya and radicalisation, and from an economic point of view, on the other hand, it is clear that greater cooperation and integration between Tunisia and its neighbours would be beneficial. The EU's approach must also take this dimension more into account. Finally, I am pleased that the report focuses not only on financial support, but also on operational opportunities to support the Tunisian transition.  The EU-Tunisia Joint Parliamentary Commission, the exchanges between parliamentary and local administrations and the sharing of experiences in regional development are all concrete elements.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, first of all congratulations to Mr Castaldo for the quality of his report. This gives us a diagnosis which must lead to concrete measures on the part of the European Union, with the aim, as my colleague Gabriel mentioned at the time, of fighting terrorism for the security of Tunisia. There are more than 500 kilometres of porous common borders with Libya, so it is obvious that this is a security issue that we Europeans need to develop in close partnership with Tunisia. Finally, of course, we need to ensure that we have an economic, agricultural and tourism partnership. The fall in the main tourist activity in Tunisia is deadly, and therefore, the fight against terrorism, for democracy, for development, is a struggle of Tunisia, but it is also the struggle of Europeans.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I congratulate Mr Castaldo first of all on his very balanced report. Tunisia, despite its great difficulties, is a positive case in the context of the so-called "Arab Springs". There has been limited violence during the transitional process and, finally, a remarkable degree of consensus among the various political actors, which led to the adoption of the Constitution in 2014. The process has now been strengthened, following the formation of a new government of national unity, despite regional instability, in particular that generated by the civil war in Libya and repeated terrorist attacks. These hinder, yes, the transition in Tunisia, and to this we must add the economic difficulties and high youth unemployment, also the result of the weakness of tourism, as has been said. The Union must maintain close political cooperation by helping Tunisia to consolidate its democratic transition, as the report calls for tomorrow will vote on. It must also deepen our mobility partnership, advance the now ongoing trade and services negotiations, promote economic reforms and maintain our support for security sector reform. Tunisia is an important partner, which we must support in its efforts for political consolidation, the country's economic and social development, security and the fight against terrorism. A partner, and a neighbour too, which is also a political model in the current Mediterranean regional context and in the Arab world, which, in general, is finding so many difficulties in achieving stable and inclusive democratic political formulas.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would also like to congratulate and also join in the congratulations, Mr Castaldo, because it is exciting to read a text that dives both in the country, in Tunisia and its people, being demanding also with your Government, with your parties and institutions, as if, in short, it was a report from one of our countries. Thanks a lot. I would also like to congratulate and thank the High Representative for her courage and wisdom, for breaking so many austericidal reserves and giving another character to her work, to gradually go, with enormous teson and intelligence, building an almost Marshall Plan - I would rather say a Mogherini Plan – for Tunisia: macro-financial support of more than 500 million euros; commitment to a free trade area that makes a difference and boosts Tunisia's autonomous economy and development; facilitation of visas, so urgent and necessary to make a clear difference. It would only be necessary to add the Euro-Mediterranean bank, which this Parliament has supported in many of its reports; also the EU Global Security Strategy, which recognises peoples, but also the opportunity to share such a challenge, and to congratulate Horizon 2020 finally having Tunisian resonances as well.

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the enhanced dialogue between the European Union and Tunisia supports the process of political and institutional reform. Better functioning of the State is therefore essential in the success of economic and social development.  The European Parliament must participate directly in this dialogue and take an active role, and the Joint Parliamentary Committee is an extremely important instrument. In the process of political reform, the elections in Tunisia are a key moment.  I therefore welcome the involvement of the European Commission and the EEAS and consider it extremely important that the allocation of funds, which is otherwise absolutely necessary, be complemented by technical assistance and support in the organisation of these elections.  I welcome the Commission's generous proposal to allocate EUR 500 million. For the effect of this financial assistance to be sustainable, it is essential that young people are given real alternatives, access to quality education, jobs and an inclusive policy. These measures are the strongest weapons in the fight against radicalisation and against recruitment by terrorist organisations.  Tunisia's reform programme in cooperation with the European Union in the field of security is an extremely important one, knowing that terrorism is a common challenge. So measures and responses must be common. Tunisia is not on the list of third states with which Europol will conclude agreements and in order to be in line with the declared policy and common objectives, I believe that Tunisia's inclusion on this list must be taken into account.  I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs on this report.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as Mr Mc Schulz has just mentioned, we must not just be a member of the European Parliament. Panzeri, next week a delegation from the European Parliament to which I attach great importance, because it is a joint EU-Tunisia delegation together with the Committee on Culture, will make this mission to Tunisia because we recognise its priority role for the future of the Mediterranean, for the neighbourhood policy, but also to support the democratic process and relaunch the partnership in various areas, among which I would like to highlight the culture of the Mediterranean. , cultural heritage, education, the audiovisual sector.  As the Castaldo report points out, it is necessary to develop economic and commercial actions together, with the strengthening of human capital, civil society and the training of young people, as well as intercultural dialogue through broad cultural relations and also the strongest participation in the Erasmus Mundus programmes and also in the former Tempus programme, which is linked to Erasmus+.  I would also like to point out that some very interesting projects are currently under way, and I would like to see an organic framework within the framework of the European cultural strategy, which we have greatly appreciated, and of European cultural diplomacy, which was launched by the three Commissioners, that gives more importance and links these actions.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, as the PPE rapporteur for the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy, it is with great interest that I follow events in this young democracy. Tunisia should, indeed, use this opportunity to become the role model for the region and show that the Arab Spring has not turned into an Arab winter everywhere. The EU can deepen its partnership with Tunisia by supporting a continuous democratic process and offering guidance in that process, for instance in the judiciary sector and through reinforced European Neighbourhood Instrument (ENI) resources. The security situation in Tunisia remains extremely volatile as a result of both internal and external factors. Here too the EU can be instrumental in supporting the building of state security structures. This needs to be done together with our partners. I welcome the launch of the EU programme of support for security sector reforms in Tunisia. Last year, Tunisians were awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. We should stand by them as the people of Tunisia try to make democracy in their country really work.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, tunisia was initially the origin of the Arab Spring, but also of that humanitarian dimension of what we have mis called the refugee crisis. We therefore welcome here a report which crystallizes the positive case of a country which has succeeded in demonstrating that it has not all been Arab hell, but indeed a transit to democracy and the Constitution, but which reminds the European Union of the need to be globally relevant, to have a foreign policy of positive stimuli and not only of negative gaze and remorse of conscience afterwards towards the southern shore of the Mediterranean and also of correcting humanitarian policy managing that terrible dimension of refugees coming from the south bank. And the occasion — and I emphasize it — is the visa code for the introduction of humanitarian visas at source, in embassies and consulates in the European Union, because they can make a difference and show that not only in the bilateral case of Tunisia, but in learning the lessons learned from that experience, the European Union has improved as well.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, in accordance with point 42 of the resolution, the European Parliament 'expresses its concerns about the sustainability of Tunisia's debt and calls for the investigation of possible ways to make it more sustainable; From what I have heard, neither Mrs Mogherini nor, of course, the colleagues who have spoken from the political groups objected to this.  So the question arises: why not apply the same to Greece? Why does the Commission disagree on the restructuring of Greek debt? Why does the European Union not accept a write-off of Greek debt, which is also shameful? Why is the European Union imposing austerity on Greece in order to pay off the debt? Why is it forcing a sell-off of Greek property to pay off the debt? Why does the same not apply to Greece?

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the democratic development in Tunisia represents one of the few successful examples of democratic transition in the wake of the Arab Spring. Unfortunately, after the terrorist attacks in Tunisia which had a tremendous impact on the country’s economy, this Parliament did not fully deliver on the promised solidarity. We should have fully supported macro-financial assistance and additional exports of olive oil in order to secure growth. Anyhow, we supported the EU-Tunisia Free Trade Agreement and that help was needed in the short term. Now the EU must not miss the opportunity to step up in terms of financial support and technical assistance for Tunisia to cope with the political, economic and social needs in the medium and long term. Trade openness and structural economic reforms aimed at supporting long-term employment should be explored in order to enable the Tunisian economy to achieve tangible results. I hope that Parliament will not, once again, let the Tunisian people down and that we will, together this time, fully deliver the promised solidarity.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, this report brings nothing new about what the European Union's external relations with third countries are.  The front-of-hand chamber of a possible free trade agreement and neocolonial instrument of economic exploitation that the Union has been dissecting throughout the world, the strategy of interference and interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign country is well designed: democratic reforms, institutional policies of economic and social development, security and defence policy, of alleged combating terrorism, and reforms for research , education and culture. Reforms, read, to transform a country, conditioning the financing to the policies and ideological concepts of the Union, liberalizing the economy and further imposing the exploitation and impoverishment of workers and people at the expense of the stumble of the wealth of that country.  A submission agenda, which is blatantly intended to compare, imagine, to a Marshall plan, a clear denunciation of the real objectives of this relationship that is widely unbalanced.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: for VP/HR. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I will make an effort. I would also like to thank all of you for this constructive exchange of views, also on behalf of the High Representative, in particular the rapporteur, Mr Castaldo, for this very comprehensive report. As has already been said, we are paying particular attention to Tunisia. In a few days' time, we will present a comprehensive communication for Tunisia. It is also envisaged that we will almost double the budget, the financial expenditure, for Tunisia in the order of around EUR 300 million per year. However, as some speakers have also mentioned, it is a question of these funds being used in a targeted manner for economic development. Economic development also includes support for vocational training, for example. There are also some interesting programmes from some European Member States. We need the cooperation between the training side and the economic side. However, I should also like to invite those ladies and gentlemen who will be travelling to Tunisia from Parliament in the next few days and ask them to urge their interlocutors to ensure that the necessary reforms also take place. Because if you want to attract companies, you also have to create the appropriate legal framework conditions. There is certainly room for improvement, as it is said, and the Tunisian side also needs to cooperate here. We are all glad that the internal political turmoil has dissipated and that there is a stable government. And it is also gratifying that Tunisian President Essebsi will come to Brussels at the beginning of December at the invitation of your President and give a speech. This is the case for the first time and shows that relations between the European Union and Tunisia are deepening further. Tunisia is definitely one of our priority countries. And one final remark. It is also important – Tunisia is also very important for us – to promote regional development in the region, in the Maghreb. It is the only country in the region that is on good terms with virtually all neighbouring countries, and this should and must be used to promote economic development there and, therefore, stability. Once again, thank you very much for your sustained interest in the development of Tunisia!

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like once again to thank the shadow rapporteurs and all the speakers because their speeches have clearly demonstrated how much this report is indeed the result of shared work, of participative work, in which the various demands and priorities, which are the expression of the political groups, have merged, finding a balance and harmony.  Tunisia has demonstrated with a small miracle that compatibility between Islam and democracy that many have found impossible in the past is completely possible, objective and tangible. The European Parliament's commitment can and must be constant and fundamental, as a passage in the report also says, in supporting our tunisian counterpart, the Assembly of Representatives of the People, which today still has important technical and operational difficulties. , our Tunisian parliamentary friends, to work on individual dossiers. This is the way forward: we must not confine ourselves to declarations, but must make concrete commitments, specific plans on the individual issues addressed.  Today, terrorism unfortunately remains the number one item on the agenda. On 29 August, three soldiers also died on the border with Algeria, in an area where borders are losing their meaning, where the mobility of certain groups really does call into question those states that want to close down and do not want to cooperate from a regional point of view. Algeria-Tunisia cooperation has been a pillar in this respect and we hope to be able to extend it to the entire Maghreb as soon as Libya is stabilised.  I would like to highlight another very important aspect: the issue of human rights, many of you have mentioned it. We continue to bring them to the attention of the government, even though we are aware that Tunisia is, from this point of view, certainly the first country in the class. However, we demand a strong, concrete and total commitment to the abolition of the death penalty, because to date we regret the fact that this step has not yet been taken.  Tunisian civil society deserves all our full and firm support, not only because it won the Nobel Prize, but because, before, during and after the revolution, it proved to be the true beating heart of the country. We Europeans earn the Nobel Prize for solidarity and also foresight by supporting the miracle of the Tunisian revolution.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 14 September 2016. Written declarations (Article 162 CRP)

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I welcome this report’s strong emphasis on closer collaboration between the EU and Tunisia, which this year mark 40 years of cooperation. However, our objective of helping Tunisia implement adequate reforms, boots employment and develop sustainable and inclusive growth will only materialise in a just and fair society. The EU must pay closer attention to the new Tunisian draft economic reconciliation law which may jeopardize this process. It offers no accountability, but blatant amnesty, for the many economic crimes committed against the Tunisian people, and its state. The victims are outraged, and civil society organisations are mobilizing against it. The law’s defenders argue that it is necessary to turn the page on the past in order to attract foreign investment. I fundamentally disagree. The corrupt must not escape justice. If they do, the promise of the Tunisian revolution will be lost. We in Europe have a duty to monitor this process carefully, as plans to implement an ambitious free trade agreement between the EU and Tunisia must not come at the expense of fairness. The democratic transition process in Tunisia is still a successful example of reform possible in the Arab World. We must ensure that it remains that way.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Guillaume Balas on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs on social dumping in the European Union (2015/2255(INI)) (A8-0255/2016).

name: Guillaume Balas
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, it is said all the time, Europe is in crisis and we know that one of the reasons for this crisis is that we have a single market, freedom of services, capital, people who can circulate, but we have completely different social systems and we know that social dumping is taking place. For a long time, it was not possible to define what social dumping was and we have now come to an agreement that there is a set of illegal and abusive practices that has led to a profound challenge to the dignity of workers. Dignity when you are housed in an abject way, when you are not paid for the work you have done, when you work all day or all week and you do not respect the rest times. But it is also a financial and budgetary problem, because social dumping is taking resources away from our social protection systems and making them poorer by the day. Finally, it is an economic problem, because it tends to weaken labour incomes, as we know, and obviously to push for a deflationary trend. I would add that this is a huge political problem and that European citizens, considering that Europe does not protect them but, on the contrary, weakens them by accepting these practices of social dumping, are increasingly sceptical or even turn against Europe by deciding that we must vote for parties that now want to destroy it, that many States today are beginning to say that the internal market must be called into question and the existing directives must be called into question and that existing directives must be called into question , sometimes even unilaterally.  How do I respond? Of course, this report is only a stone, but a stone that still appears necessary and important. First of all by applying existing legislation. In order to do this, we must increase the means of control, we must ensure that there is cooperation at European level to enable labour inspectors to work together, to have the means to translate. It is important to establish genuine cross-border cooperation that will enable us to fight against the companies that are drifting today. Existing legislation must also be improved, and this is why, in particular, a number of measures are needed, for example to combat these famous mailbox companies that do not exist, or exist at some point to disappear immediately afterwards. These companies have to have a real business to be able to employ people today, to detach them, for example, in another country. We need a transport agency for the road and that is very important, because how can we fight social dumping in the road sector today if there are no instruments at European level to do so?
