A blacklist is needed so that companies that have seriously wronged, which have seriously contravened European and national legislation, cannot today claim contracts that would be very dangerous to award them. Finally, we must register, for example, declarations of secondment in a European register, if only that, so that we can know exactly who is detached and when. Finally, we must work on social convergence. Indeed, there are specific measures to be taken, for example at European level, on the condition of women, who are often the first victims of fraudulent detachment or even abuse. We also need to work on the issue of wages and, if we know that a minimum single wage is impossible today in Europe and not even desirable, a national minimum wage of around 60% of the average wage would obviously be a very important step forward. I want to finish by telling you one thing. These discussions lasted thirty hours. They have helped to overcome the divisions, to bring together the forces of progress to work together, but also the political divisions within this House. They have also transcended the geographical divides between the North, the South, the East and the West. We must now ensure that the European Parliament supports this proposal to combat social dumping.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Balas, whose recommendations are in line with the ambition of this Commission. We vowed to put people at the heart of our policymaking and we have already taken action to defend our social values and strengthen fairness in our common market. For me this is very clear: there is no place for unfair working conditions and social dumping in the European Union. While it is true that there is no legally recognised and universally shared definition of social dumping, I agree with you that it is crucial to ensure a level playing field and fair competition across the European Union. I welcome, Mr Balas, your call to Member States to increase efficiency and secure appropriate staffing levels and resources for their control bodies. I take note of your call to the Commission and the Member States to ensure more effective implementation of the existing legislation. I am glad that you welcome the newly established European Platform on undeclared work. This will contribute to turning undeclared work into declared work and ensure social protection for millions of Europeans who are losing out through various kinds of risky job arrangements. This platform will soon formally adopt its working programme and then the first activities to exchange information and best practices, engage in joint cross—border action and develop knowledge and capacity can start. In March this year we presented the proposal for the targeted revision of the 1996 Posting of Workers Directive, with the aim of ensuring fair wage conditions for posted workers and a level playing field between posting and local companies. As you know, 14 national parliaments from 11 Member States raised concerns in relation to compliance with the principle of subsidiarity, triggering the so—called yellow card procedure. We analysed the concerns voiced by the national parliaments and concluded that no subsidiarity issue subsists with this proposal. Therefore, we decided to maintain the proposal unchanged. I am now looking forward to discussing my proposal and possible amendments with you and to working with this Parliament and with the Council in order to come to an agreement as soon as possible. I also welcome the emphasis in the report on upward social convergence. This is one of the main objectives of the European Pillar of Social Rights, which is now the subject of a broad consultation. It should be seen as a reference framework expressing essential principles, common to participating Member States, for the conduct of employment and social policy and it should serve to screen the performance of participating Member States and to drive the process of reforms at national level in the light of 21st century realities. Its underlying vision is one of fairness on the European labour market and social protection systems. Last but not least, we take note of the report’s position on illicit employment practices in the transport sector, particularly bogus self-employment and its significant consequences for the social protection of workers. Bogus self—employment in all sectors leads to unclear legal situations, barriers to access to social protection, risks such as those of precariousness and two—tier segmented labour markets, and potentially also a risk in terms of safety. Combating unfair working and business conditions in road transport is at the core of the so-called road initiatives which the Commission is preparing for 2017 and the same concerns are reflected in the Aviation Strategy for Europe, adopted by the Commission in December 2015, which emphasises the need to the reinforce the social agenda and create high-quality jobs in aviation.

name: Jens Nilsson
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The Committee on Transport has, of course, discussed social dumping in transport industries: shipping and ports, trains, air and, above all, road transport. This is also where we say that monitoring and control of existing rules is important and must be maintained. The Member States and the EU have a common responsibility. We can do more at European level.  That is why we say that we want the rapid introduction of smart tachographs that can make controls more efficient using GPS technology. We also want to create an electronic and integrated operator register. We want there to be access to all relevant national registers. If a vehicle is checked on the road in a country, the person controlling the vehicle shall be able to connect immediately to the relevant driving licence register, to obtain information on the operator and the vehicle's inspection record to see the technical status. We must have transparency in those systems.  We also want a common road authority to facilitate the monitoring and control and coordination of The Member States. Everything that we propose is aimed at bringing order to an industry that is important for the common market and to put an end to the exploitation of people that is taking place today.

name: Evelyn Regner
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. As draftsman of the opinion in the Committee on Women's Rights, I would like to emphasise that social dumping is not limited to the posting of women workers, but has many faces, and the ugliest of these is undeclared work. Women are particularly often affected here – in the care sector, in households, etc. So many companies do not adhere to non-binding and voluntary guidelines. That's why we need this blacklist – a blacklist for the black sheep in the industry, those who behave wrongly and break the law. This makes it all the better for companies that pay their people fairly, register properly, and accommodate appropriately. Why not give encouragement to those good companies that play by the rules and then protect the black sheep accordingly? It cannot be. The question, of course, goes to all the political groups, especially those who are reluctant to blacklist and to fight the ambitious fight against letterbox companies. It is precisely in the fight against letterbox companies that a strong joint action is needed so that we can finally get rid of these opaque constructions.

name: Jutta Steinruck
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her There are still some who claim that there is no social dumping and no precarious employment in Europe. But the reality is different. Many of us know it: we have many exploited workers, we have bogus self-employed workers bycircumventing the law. Competition in Europe is indeed taking place on the backs of workers. What we need, however, is not competition for the cheapest wages and for the worst working conditions. This report is finally putting its finger in the wound.  I really thank Guillaume Balas and the shadow rapporteurs for making so much effort that they have looked so hard at the subject. I also keep wondering why there are Members here in Parliament who have the privilege of equal pay for equal work, but who deny their workers and their own citizens at home exactly that.  It is not really an East-West conflict. It is about protecting workers and fair competition. I appeal to everyone, and I ask everyone out there – the workers, the citizens – to look closely at who is voting and how tomorrow. Those who vote against this own-initiative report tomorrow say 'no' to the protection of workers, and they say 'yes' to unscrupulous exploitative undercutting competition by companies. I would ask you to vote in favour of this report tomorrow! It's a signal to the people out there.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Today, the phrase 'social dumping' is very controversial, it is a very controversial subject. Given the effects of the economic and financial crisis and the difficult situation on the labour market in some Member States, it is used for political struggle by anti-European and populist communities.  Increasingly, the term 'social dumping' has been used in European Parliament documents, which, in my opinion, is unacceptable because there is no legally binding definition of social dumping. In the European Parliament, however, we are committed to preparing clear and transparent laws. By not following these principles, we have led to a situation where populists and nationalists manipulate this phrase in all possible ways, deceiving our societies. Thanks to the negotiations and the goodwill of many political groups, we have succeeded in developing a definition of social dumping, and I believe that this is one of the greatest achievements and the most important elements of the report.  In the European Parliament, we agree that the violation and abuse of the law must be combated in order to reduce labour costs and not respect workers' rights. I hope that the problem thus defined will cease to be a breeding ground for populists and Eurosceptics and will reduce attacks and accusations against, among other things, foreign workers and companies for taking jobs and unfair competition.  When we talk about social dumping, we should first of all focus our attention on actual practices related to breaking the law, such as false self-employment, the activities of mailbox companies or undeclared work. Such practices need to be combated and the report we will be voting on tomorrow contains a number of recommendations in this regard. From the outset, as the EPP, we have pointed to priority actions, such as better enforcement of national and European law, strengthening cooperation between Member States, improving the exchange of information, for example on the social status of workers, and the efficient identification and closement of loopholes.  Finally, I would like to address the issues relating to the posting of workers. Very often, companies delegating workers are unfairly accused of social dumping. Let us remember that in most cases they are honest traders. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Jens Geier (S&D)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I have a question for the PPE-DE speaker.  I am certainly well informed that, as a colleague from Poland, you will receive the same pay from the European Parliament for your work as I do from Germany. My question to you is: why is it so difficult for Christian Democrat Members, your group, to grant this privilege – equal pay for equal work – to workers from your country elsewhere in the EU?

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I must tell you that I would be the happiest person if the people of my country could earn the same as the people of Western Europe earn. But unfortunately we are a country on the acquis, and we still need time to achieve the same standards as Western Europe. And therefore it is so difficult in one stroke to equalize wages. I would like this to happen, but it is impossible.

name: Czesław Hoc
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Human capital is the greatest wealth of entrepreneurship in general. Good human capital management is a guarantee of success for every business. However, in the case of social dumping, it is this capital that can be wasted, so it would be necessary to take this phenomenon seriously and specifically, namely to know its causes, the circumstances of its creation, to establish the criteria for its identification, to take preventive action, to counteract the causes and to take corrective action, and then to control and enforce it. However, social dumping has not yet been precisely defined. So how do you counteract something, repair and perfect something that is not yet precisely defined? Inevitably, any decision in the interpretation of this problem and recommendations can be regarded as discretionary, even instrumental. In my opinion, the problem of social dumping must first be clearly, accurately and urgently defined and appropriate and rational action taken.

name: Martina Dlabajová
text: for the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, I thank Guillaute Balas for conducting all the negotiations with great honour. He did not have an easy task, we did not always agree, but I would very much like this report to be the beginning of a new communication on this subject. I think that if we want to solve the real problems of the labour market, then we should stop juggling political and ideological terms, such as social dumping, and populist slogans, which, unfortunately, have already been said here and today. I am very dissatisfied with the overall tone of the report, which seeks to hide behind this term the defence of the protectionist efforts of certain national labour markets and refers to all inequalities and differences in the European Union and even the posting of workers as a manifestation of social dumping. This alibist label overlaps the true nature of the problems facing the working environment in the EU. My position certainly does not mean that I advocate unfair competition or unfair business conditions. Just the opposite. Illegal activity must be systematically combated. I therefore propose, for example, that we ensure sufficient resources to strengthen the work of labour inspectorates, which must detect workers on the ground without proper contracts and basic social standards. But let us also look at the real situation on the labour market through the eyes of business owners, who are real job creators. What do they really need? Are these more and more regulations that will bind their hands even more? Or simple and effective solutions that can be easily applied in practice? I think deep down, you all know the answer.  We must take the path of better exchange of information between Member States, adapting the rules of social systems, adapting tax rules and other stimulus instruments. We should communicate more openly and factually, look at the factual arguments. We should ensure that individual labour markets are not fragmented. This is the only conceivable way that, from the very heterogeneous conditions of Europe's different labour markets, we can at some point in the future achieve that truly pan-European labour market with which we could all be satisfied.  (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the Blue Card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Here, other speakers were unsure what the concept of social dumping was at all. To be honest, I on the left see social dumping as a way for employers to push workers' wages down and down, period. That's the concept we've dealt with. However, I ask with great respect whether you would agree that there should be a limit. Namely the European minimum wage, which is probably very serious ... (The President withdrew the floor from the Member.)

name: Martina Dlabajová (ALDE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I have to say that it was very funny, because the interpreting, even though there was a Czech channel, was in Spanish. This may be some kind of approvedness by colleagues here on the left, but my answer is certainly no, because I also understood the Spanish question. No, definitely not.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, the writing of the report on social dumping is in itself an important political act and we would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr President-in-Office of the Council. Balas for his decisive contribution. The disastrous effects of the neoliberal austerity policies and memoranda imposed on the Member States are no longer hidden under the carpet. Devotees of deregulation of industrial relations and the supposedly free market can no longer look elsewhere, It is time to discuss the issue of deregulation of industrial relations and the real causes of unemployment and insecurity. We do not accept that it is difficult to find a common definition of social dumping. Insecurity at work, the reduction of workers covered by collective agreements, the increase in reduced-term contracts, the impoverishment of workers, chronic unemployment, especially of young people, and uneven wages are social dumping. The conservative and neoliberal forces in this Parliament must stop hiding behind the technical conditions and express themselves clearly on whose side they are: with the large multinational corporations that increase profits by confiding in workers, or with workers in Europe claiming a decent life? As the GUE Group, we have clear relations against the dismantling of the social fabric as a result of the neoliberal policies imposed by the Stability Pact and the European Semester. We shall be voting in favour of the Balas report because it recognises the existence of social dumping. It is recognised that neoliberal policies have failed.

name: Karima Delli
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, social dumping is poison that destroys the European project. In Europe in 2016 and tonight, in this Chamber, I say to you, I am ashamed to see women and men still exploited as employees, I am ashamed to see abusive practices imposed by unscrupulous employers that sweep away national and European legislation. In 2016, truck drivers have to sleep and eat in their cabs, employees are sometimes crammed by the dozens in a room to sleep. That's what their lives are all about. Where is dignity in Europe? It's time to put an end to unfair competition, it's time to punish those who don't want to enforce the rules, it's time to get this all in order. Colleagues, who in this Chamber is against putting an end to the exploitation of workers, whether they are French, Polish, or Cypriot? The tools, we have them in this report, and I congratulate my colleague, Mr Balas: minimum wage, blacklist of fraudulent companies, strengthening of controls, combating false independents, liability of contractors and subcontractors. The question at the heart of the debate is: what Europe do we want? Do we want a europe of the wild of everyone for himself, destroying the neighbour if necessary, or a Europe of solidarity, in which everyone has a place, a life, a dignified work?  Colleagues, between a social Europe and the whole market, between a Europe that protects and one that destroys, I have chosen the one that protects. And you, I hope you will make the same choice by voting on Mr Balas' report.

name: Laura Agea
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, commissioner, the first thank you goes to Mr Guillaume for the work he has done, because it has certainly taken courage to face this issue with the determination that he has used.  Social dumping is no more and no less than the photograph of Europe, a fragmented Europe, where not even the 28 countries can be put together in such a way that they can compete together in a project of well-being, stability and growth for the citizens who are part of it, because that is exactly what it is all about.  Today we are faced with the problem of unfair competition in all production sectors, in the agricultural sector... in any sector we have unfair competition. We have a fragmentation between the states of Northern Europe, those of Eastern Europe, those of Southern Europe. In fact, what we have managed to produce is a war between the poor, because it is the citizens who are at the expense of these choices that we are making of not clearly and effectively regulating legislation that must be implemented in all sectors. In the end, it is simply the citizens who pay the highest price, who are suffering and becoming the bargaining chip that countries sell to each other, between those who produce labour at very low cost, without protection, and those who take advantage of cheap labour, without protection for profit. So there are no winners and losers, there are no people who are more right and those who are most wrong, because on both sides the only people who pay the cost of these policies are the citizens, who suffer the consequences.  So I thank Guillaume for all those indications that he wanted to include: from the minimum wage, to the minimum income, to effective control policies: labour inspectorates must work more and better, a register must be made – you are right Guillaume! – and it is important.

name: Mara Bizzotto
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe must decide once and for all which way to stand: whether to continue to support the single market at all costs and thus to support a project that is slaughtering entire sectors, or whether to put itself on the side of the citizens, our citizens, our serious entrepreneurs and rewrite these damn treaties.  Free movement and the huge difference in labour costs between states are a problem, they are the problem. I don't say it, but the entrepreneurs say it, the ones that I, unlike you, meet every day. Conftrasporto says that social dumping in Italy pulverizes more than 30 000 jobs in the road transport sector alone every year. The problem is foreign temporary agencies offering cheap labour, thus putting the rights of our workers and their jobs at risk. Italian companies have much, much higher taxes and labour costs and therefore will never, ever be able to compete with those who make this unfair competition.  Is this the European Union project? Is this the model of social injustice that you want to impose? Europe must rewrite the rules of the single market before the unease and anger of its citizens turns into a real revolt. We must act now, now, before it is too late.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Madam President! Social dumping – a word that actually plays down what is happening in Europe at the moment. The report not only trivialises, it does not mention the real causes. Too low minimum wages drive workers into old-age poverty and allow them only a life of subsistence. Many have to pursue two or three professions to ensure the existence of the family. On the high seas, there are no social standards at all when it is flagged out. Temporary workers, temporary workers, undeclared workers, social and nursing services now work under the conditions of a modern slave trade. Their open borders policy is responsible for this. I call on you to close the Pandora's box! Help people where their homeland is and protect Europe's social achievements!

name: David Casa (PPE).
text: – Nixtieq l-ewwel nett, qabel ma nibda, nirringrazzja lir-Rapporteur u lix-Shadow Rapporteurs gsax-xogsol kbir 1afna illi huma gsamlu tul dawn l-assarimgsat. U nitkellem proprju biex inwassal messa politiku iktar milli fuq l-aspett tekniku li ppreparajt, gsaliex wara dax-xogsol kollu, anke meta wasalna fi stadju ta' kumitat, illum irnexxielna nsibu bilan, bilan importanti 1afna, bilan illi jiena rrid li jibqa' biex, sa g서ada, ana nkunu nistg au nivvotaw favur and ir-rapport.  U allura, kummenti b aal ma smajna min-na a tal-Partit Sojalista fil-konfront tal-partit tiegsi, f'dan il-mument, mhumiex aettabbli u rridu noqogsdu attenti biex and il-bilan li sibna wara tant imgsat ta' 1idma flimkien, and il-bilan jibqa' hemm. Issa, kemm asna, minn din-na a tal-Kamra, kif ukoll minn dik in-nasa tal-kamra, saru sagrifiji - edejna bia a a ana, edejtu bia intom; u llum ninsabu, mhux kuntenti mija fil-mija, imma kuntenti b'dak li g aandna b aalissa quddiemna. U allura, l-appell tiegsi sa gsada huwa illi nsallu and il-bilan kif 서dimnieh ilkoll flimkien tul dawn l-assarimg aat. Grazzi 서afna tax-xogsol tagskom, grazzi lil kulsadd u ejja, f'dawn l-ass sekondi, insallu kollox kif ippjanajna.  (Il-kelliem qabel li jwieeb g aal mistoqsija "karta blu" skont l-Artikolu 162(8) tar-Regoli ta' Proedura).

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), "blue card" question. – Dear colleague, you have spoken of balances. How can you explain the phenomenon that, in committee, on the one hand we support flexible forms of employment with hunger wages and four-hour jobs, and on the other hand we are talking about social dumping and we want to ensure workers' rights and wages?

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: tweġiba karta blu. – Nista' nistaqsi biss, minn liema partit ġej, Sinjura President? Minn liema duckit qed jitkellem is-Sinjur?

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: tweġiba karta blu. – Fil-bidu nett, meta kont qed nitkellem, kont qiegħed nitkellem dwar bilan大 politiku li nstab bejn il-group politi大ikollha. Issa jiena ma nafx is-sinjur min kellu jirrappreżentah fix-shadow meetings illi saru, illi jiena naħseb kienu r-record ta' meetings li qattna fuq rapporti li kienu Own Reports Initiative. U naħseb illi, la nstab dan il-bilan大, jista' jkun ma jkunux kuntenti b'kollox, però naturalment dan il-bilan大, nerġa' nsostni, huwa importanti ħafna.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D).
text: – First of all, I really thank the rapporteur. A lot of work has been worked on, compromises have been sought, because this report is vital for us. And I certainly support the basic idea of the report that the competitive advantage of companies in our single European union market, if it is obtained by unfair practices or the cost of exploiting workers, is absolutely unacceptable. This practice is giving birth to exclusion in certain Member States, confrontation in the European Union and simply breaking down our unity. Unfair practices must be tackled by a number of measures, both by strengthening labour inspectorates, as well as in cross-border cases, in the fight against the shadow economy, illegal employment, bogus self-employment or tax avoidance.  However, I now want to draw the attention of my colleagues to another very important point: the persisting large differences between working conditions and pay between Member States. To overcome this, economic policies are needed to promote economic growth, increase labour productivity and create quality jobs in all Member States.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: – What Europe really needs is competitiveness and freedom to do business. This will create enough jobs. Unfortunately, all well-intentioned measures, as well as those against social dumping, are causing the exact opposite. The number of jobs in Europe is declining. While we constantly complain that companies are abusing their employees, we are also inventing new and new regulations and new and new burdens. With socialist measures and efforts, we are still levelling everything up and actually killing the labour market. The same work in the same place is dysfunctional socialist nonsense. No measures against social dumping will help. The only thing that will help is a fundamental improvement in the business environment. That is when new jobs are created, and that is the best social protection for employees.

name: Thomas Händel (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for Social dumping is the reason why more and more people in Europe are living on the poverty line, including in work. Workers, however, are not human material – the ugly term – which can be exploited at the lowest price, bycircumventing national and European laws and collective agreements, and cross-border. The fear of social decline and exclusion on the one hand, migration and xenophobia on the other, are two sides of the same coin of politics that leads to this result. I would like to say this to speakers: social dumping has nothing to do with open borders. Social dumping has something to do with anti-social behaviour by companies that are constantly depressing wages. Workers, however, are not Holland tomatoes, where the price has to fall when there are many, but people with social rights. Mr Balas is quite right in his report. With this report, the left side of Parliament is closer to this President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, than to the right. In particular, I call on the PPE-DE group to include the compromises from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs in this report tomorrow.

name: Patrick O’Flynn (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the European Union seems almost purpose-built to encourage social dumping. Freedom of movement seemed to work okay when only a few countries were in the club and all were at similar stages of economic development, but following the various rounds of enlargement, particularly with the arrival of the A8 and A2 countries, all that changed. Suddenly countries with wage levels only a fifth of those that pertained in the more established members were part of the club. Without major restriction of the right of free movement, the outcome was inevitable: vast migration from poorer countries to richer ones and the undercutting of wages and conditions. Yet the Commission permitted only short-term transitional controls, and the UK did not even take advantage of those. Rather than tailor controls to the long-term closing of the living-standards gap, the ideology of European integration took precedence and immigration soared. The result in the UK has been beneficial to big corporations – an endless supply of cheap and compliant labour – but terrible for pre-existing working-class communities, with pay and conditions undermined and competition for public resources, such as social housing and school places, greatly intensified. This was not the only factor behind the Brexit victory in our referendum in June, but it was a major one. To sum up, as an ardent Brexiteer, I must offer you my heartfelt thanks as a Union for your bureaucratic inflexibility and your political incompetence. Britain will soon have within its grasp the national controls needed to support working people and ensure their wages and conditions are not grievously undermined, but other countries of northern and Western Europe will have no such powers. More fool them!

name: Steeve Briois (ENF).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, from a region hard hit by the effects of savage globalisation, I did not need this report to realis the devastating effects of social dumping.  Wages below the SMIC, non-compliance with the legal duration of working time, undignified accommodation conditions, it still took twenty years for the "eurogagas" of the right and left to finally realize that their sacrosanct directive on the detachment of workers would produce such a social disaster.  Today, with this report, you continue to push an open door and lure the French. There is a lot of talk in this report because, rather than addressing the real causes of social dumping, you pretend to act only on the consequences. By taking half measures, you smoke the French workers once again.  For it is indeed the directive on the detachment of workers itself and the principle of free movement of workers that have led to unfair competition, thus throwing hundreds of thousands of French people into unemployment and hyper-precarity. Commissioner, Mr Balas, if you really want to combat social dumping, there are not 36 solutions. First, this infamous directive on seconded workers must be repealed outright and then the principle of free movement of workers within the European Union should be suspended. It is under these conditions, and only these conditions, that we can finally stop this social breakdown and preserve our social model.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Mrs Jazaowiecka! I saw that you wanted a blue card for the colleague. But you have already had speaking time, and since we are very short of time, I am not giving a blue card to someone who has already had time in this debate. I ask for your understanding.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, there are hundreds of laws, laws and directives at Union level relating to work, employment, insurance, social cohesion, ensuring the health of workers and protecting them from atypical and flexible forms of employment. In Greece of the six memorial years and the successive governments of right and left, which murder Greek workers and pensioners with their policies, there is a work ethic. In my country, everything that this report is trying to combat and more is being implemented: undeclared and uninsured work, the abolition of collective agreements and safeguards, abusive practices, blatant distortions of competition, labour intimidation, social exclusions, literally hunger pay, third-world working conditions, indifference to human dignity and health. And all of the above, with the blessings of the institutions that evaluate the respective Greek governments. I would suggest, instead of this report, that two simple laws be passed: one that makes it compulsory for everyone to apply labour provisions, i.e. institutions, Member States and social partners, and a second that removes all practical ones that are impractical.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her If social laws are circumvented, when letterbox companies are created to save taxes and levies, when sites are relocated to undermine co-determination, when cash is made at the expense of the general public, then social dumping and outlawing. However, social legislation in the Member States varies widely, from minimum wages and protection against dismissal to retirement age. That is why national social policies have hardly been harmonised. To usher in a radical change and to seek EU-wide unification is a step in the wrong direction – see Europe-wide unemployment insurance, which is an entry into the transfer union. The Balas report mentions the revision of the Posting of Workers Directive on several occasions. After all, it is not to be adopted until the end of this year and, above all, legislatively. We are opposed to any pre-determination at this stage. The fight against social dumping is necessary. Yes, we obviously need better controls. We must ensure that we also implement more effective cross-border measures. Above all, we must begin a clear process of awareness, and we in Parliament are certainly suited to that. The basis for this is to say that we will then have a chance that lived solidarity can finally be discovered, and for that we must cooperate here in Parliament.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D).
text: Madam President! I have taken the floor to appeal to you. I would appeal to us to stand together today, regardless of which country or political party we come from. That we are united in sending a signal to European workers and businesses that we are taking them seriously. We take it seriously when cleaners, earth and concrete workers, drivers and pilots from different European countries are played off against each other and underpaid. We take it seriously when companies that pay their employees a decent wage and comply with the common ground rules we have in Europe are out-competed by people who cheat. We can disagree on exactly how we tackle the problems, but by voting in favour of this report we are showing the citizens of Europe that we take them seriously and that we refuse to accept a race to the bottom. We have not created a common market to minimise pay and working conditions. We have created a common market to increase prosperity and prosperity in Europe and to ensure fair competition and fair working conditions across Europe.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the European Union is far from an example in raising workers' rights. On the contrary, its class nature and ideological capitalist matrix have imposed legislation, recommendations, policies and a vast set of exploitation instruments that, over decades, have contributed to deepen ing the so-called social dumping.  Free movement, without guaranteeing equal labour rights between countries, is an example of this. The promotion of precariousness, through the attack on collective bargaining or the abusive use of temporary work, validating this procedure for the occupation of permanent posts – and which the Commission itself sanctions – the assault on wages and labour rights in the name of sacred competitiveness and productivity, the facilitation of the relocation of companies also within the territory of the European Union and the endless benefits to large multinationals are reasons that require the break with the policies of the European Union and that require the development of policies of economic and social progress as the only way to combat inequalities.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for In the haulage industry, we see very serious concerns in Sweden precisely with regard to social dumping. Drivers are exploited for slave wages, which means that Swedish companies, which need twice as much in compensation, die like flies in unfair competition. This is largely due to the cabotage rules which allow for this particular cheating. It cannot be the intention that membership of the EU simultaneously kills the ability of its domestic businesses to operate on a healthy basis. The Commission must act vigorously to protect the companies of the Member States. Controls must be effective. The regulatory framework must be simple and easy to comply with, and the Posting of Workers Directive must be redone. Mailbox companies must be fought. Serious companies must be given a chance to survive. If the EU cannot give Member States' businesses a chance to survive, what is the value of being a member of the EU? Opponents of this proposal may rethink when their own countries face similar competition with unfair means.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – The social sphere is one of those where the European Union has remained halfway through harmonisation.  On the one hand, we have the free movement of people who can travel and work anywhere in the Union. They can also work in different forms of employment. On the other hand, we have companies that are in the single market. They are placed in a position where they have to ensure competitiveness, otherwise they can close their doors.  We also have countries within the European Union that cannot guarantee the same level of social rights, because, of course, their budget cannot take it. We need to distinguish between the exploitation of employees, where some employers make profits for their own gluttony. This is, of course, unacceptable. And we must separate, on the other hand, between ensuring equal income and equal social status. These are two different things.  Of course, I strongly condemn exploitation. However, I would like to remind you that we must also be aware that social rights cost money. They cost businesses and cost the states. The answer to how we can ensure the same social situation would be simple if there was a single European resource from which social rights were financed. But while that's not the same, of course, we're in the position we're in.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, social dumping, as you know, is simply an abusive use of the detachment directive, at best. In the worst case scenario, it is simply overt fraud or even abuse of workers. Fighting these practices will guarantee in the future the true mobility of workers, the one that will guarantee them the right, regardless of their nationality. Fighting social dumping also means combating unfair competition between businesses, and in particular SMEs, the very SMEs that do not resist these unfair practices. Tackling fraudulent practices also means ensuring that all Member States - I say all Member States - get their dues back to ensure the social protection of their workers. Guillaume Balas' report, which is before us, proposes appropriate solutions to combat all these practices, solutions that would enable, if implemented quickly , and I do think that there is an urgent need to combat abusive practices in the interests of all.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, as the truckers who came to the European Parliament to denounce their situation said a few months ago, it is only necessary to go to a truck parking lot anywhere in Europe to see which underworld the road transport sector has become. Unfair competition in this sector is spreading to many others, such as agriculture, catering or domestic and care, creating huge pockets of precariousness across the European Union. Social dumping is a particularly serious problem for cities such as Avilés and regions such as Asturias, where I come from, with a great weight of steelmaking and heavy industry, permanently subjected to the blackmail of relocations to countries with lower labor and environmental costs. Those who advocate deregulation are leading us to an unstable, absolutely unsustainable situation. That is why we support measures aimed at eradicating phantom companies, combating tax evasion and evasion, and defending decent working conditions.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would first like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for this balanced report. Social dumping is a complex subject, whose perceptions differ according to political sensitivities, but also according to geographical sensitivities. For some, social dumping does not exist. Differences in wage and social costs are said to be inherent in freedom of competition and the principle of competitiveness. They would allow less developed regions to return to the level of the so-called more prosperous economies. For others, of which I am a part, even if from time to time, they are considered a populist, indeed social dumping is a reality, which endangers whole swathes of our economies every day and leads to an ever-increasing rejection of the European project. Beyond these differences in perception, the issue of social dumping is closely linked to the revision of the Detachment Directive, an issue which will occupy us for many months and on which Parliament will have to be proactive and speak with one voice. This is a difficult but not insurmountable task and the proof is the compromise found on the definition of social dumping. It is our duty to get out of sterile oppositions, to build win-win solutions to meet the expectations of European citizens, namely to enable more balanced economic development in the different European regions and, at the same time, to put an end to competition between European countries, companies, but also salaried workers.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: – We all know that Bulgarian truck driver who has been on the road for months and eats his meals along the highway. We know the Polish construction worker who works in a Dutch construction site and shares a room with ten others in the evening. And we also know this Western European worker who sits at home unemployed and thinks, "what are we actually doing about that?" Social dumping takes many forms in Europe and unfair competition through secondment is one of them. As rapporteur, I want to work very hard to make this secondment fairer in the future, but with only an adaptation of the Posting of Workers Directive, the European single market will not be social at once. Competition between employees and companies is still far too often a competitive battle with a race to the bottom. Strengthening social rights very often goes against the dictates of the free market. So more needs to be done. That is why I am very pleased with Guillaume Balas' report. Fortunately, it's a very good start. I hope that the Commission will indeed respond quickly to the proposals and come up with proposals on mobile workers, bogus self-driving and social security fraud.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: – Social dumping is a very real problem. It is true that there is no legal or political consensus definition of it. But ask the Dutch lorry driver who is sitting at home unemployed or ask the Portuguese concrete braider who is put to work in another Member State under dubious circumstances. They can tell you very clearly how social dumping feels.  We need to enforce existing rules much better. We need to implement new rules, such as the Enforcement Directive, much better and faster. We need to close existing legislative loopholes, such as the Posting of People's Directive, quickly. We need to better equip labour inspectorates to work and maintain cross-border work.  But let us also be clear: We must not, under the guise of the fight against social dumping, carry out all kinds of unrealistic wishful thinking of the Socialist Group in this House. I am thinking in particular of paragraph 49, for example, which calls for a radical change in the direction of income towards work and a basic income for all Europeans. Let us not pollute the debate on social dumping with proposals of this kind, but let us focus on realistic, efficient measures that actually help the hard-working Europeans.

name: Ismail Ertug (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The right to free movement is an important privilege within the European Union. But this is often misused in the goods sector, in the transport sector, in order to maximise profits even more by outsourced companies to countries that have lower wage and social standards. The victims – and this is also obvious and has been mentioned repeatedly – are, on the one hand, the workers who have to accept the worst conditions in order to escape unemployment. However, it is also the companies – and I think we all know this here – that are following the rules of the game, which comply with tariffs – they are the ones who suffer because they are no longer up to competition. That is why we must effectively prevent the Europe-wide undermining of wage and social standards. We must implement the existing laws properly; in particular, the European Commission and the Member States are called upon to implement this. Once again, my appeal, my wish, especially to the EPP Colleagues, to wipe this off the table together tomorrow.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been a very I have to be a little surprised at the debate. I have a bit of a feeling that we, as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, are trying to blame us here, that we are not committed to social dumping. Anyone who has looked at this in the meetings in committee, including on this report, and in the many meetings that the shadow rapporteur has also attended, cannot claim that. What bothers me even more here in this Chamber, however, is that the far left and the far right, who have now accused us here as Europe, that we are the most anti-social region in the world, are making great speeches here in Parliament, who claim that everything we are doing here is bad – they are making a speech here, that is being recorded, and then they are going home. Probably already sitting in the restaurant and eating good food here in Strasbourg. If we really want to take part in this, then I would like to say one thing: then you have to make amendments, you have to cooperate in committee and not just in plenary, you have to make big speeches here.  What bothers me a little about this report is that there are things in it that do not actually belong there. The issue of the Posting of Workers Directive has already been raised on several occasions. Commissioner Thyssen has made a proposal on this, and we will be working on it here in the European Parliament. It belongs there and not here. There are a few other things, but they have all already been listed. Earlier, I found it quite interesting that it was claimed that a Polish and a German Member of Parliament supposedly deserve the same thing here. That is not entirely true either – look at the Members before 2009; some of them earn a four-figure sum more than others. So even in the European Parliament, there are different payments.

name: Georgi Pirinski (S&D).
text: – Madam President, countering social dumping urgently requires effective cooperation between national authorities and social partners in order to end exploitation of workers and unfair competition. It is therefore the explicit obligation of the Commission to ensure full use of the new Platform to tackle undeclared work from its very next session in September, as a most valuable venue to develop just such cooperation. I very much welcome your introductory words Commissioner to that effect. As to the particular challenges regarding transport – a sector of particular importance for Bulgaria, with over three thousand personnel providing vital income for their families – it is imperative that there must be no further liberalisation of cabotage until implementation of the current legislation is ensured, together with the necessary guarantees for equal access to the single transport market.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would first and foremost like to congratulate and thank the rapporteur, my French colleague Guillaume Balas, for the spirit of openness and consensus with which he has written this report. Indeed, on issues as important as social dumping, it is essential that we show good will and unite across political divides. However, for states as well as for companies or individuals, the success of one cannot be at the expense of the other. We therefore have a duty to act, otherwise we will see, helplessly, the dismantling of the internal market, which is one of the pillars of European integration.  It is necessary to respond to the dysfunctions and even the excesses of some of our directives in order to protect fundamental rights such as the free movement of people. It is the will of the group to which I belong, but also yours, Commissioner Thyssen, to have the courage to revise, in particular, the directive on the secondment of workers. As such, I would like to pay tribute to my colleague and friend Elisabeth Morin-Chartier, who is a high-quality parliamentarian and who, I am sure, has the skills and expertise to succeed in this reform, of which she will be the rapporteur. I will conclude, Madam President, by putting States in front of their responsibilities. Indeed, much of the dysfunction of European rules lies in the slow and sometimes partial or partial application of these rules by national authorities. But the British example has shown that the ease or even cowardice of blaming Europe can have a sad boomerang effect.

name: Marita Ulvskog (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Thank you, Commissioner, for being here. We have a serious problem in Europe today. Instead of strengthening each other, we compete to quickly reach the bottom. Social dumping through low wages and poor working conditions is not only a problem for individual workers, for individual drivers, construction workers, nursing assistants – virtually every part of the labour market. No, it is not just about this, it is also a problem of democracy. People lose faith in the future and in Europe when people sitting in this room allow social dumping and refuse to plug holes in legislation. Then that picture is also confirmed. Commissioner Thyssen has taken an important step in order and fair play through the proposal for a change to the Posting of Workers Directive. It is extremely important. Warm thanks for that! Guillaume Balas has now presented a very important report on social dumping with very great work and very good cooperation with others. Thanks for that! Now all this must only be lifted from Parliament and into reality.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE).
text: - Dear Colleagues, The report tries to answer important questions. Although the starting point is to define the concept of social dumping, it cannot even answer this exact answer, it is an exact wording, as it is not to the other questions. I find it particularly inappropriate to include the concept of the Posting of Workers Directive, i.e. the posting of legally employed workers and its rules. In doing so, it wants to re-gradise a legal and competitiveness-enhancing provision as illegal. This must be strongly opposed. The preconceived notion itself is flawed, since it assumes that there is only one element of competition, namely wage costs. If this were indeed the case, all businesses would be looking for labour in the third world and not within the European Union, where continuous and balanced catch-up between Member States is still needed, rather than the preparation of such sentiment-inducing reports in the European Parliament.

name: Lara Comi (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for the work he is doing and also the rapporteurs.  'Social dumping' is a term which, at present, is widely used but does not have a legally recognised and shared definition. However, we are all aware of the proliferation of these illegal practices which allow the development of unfair competition. So there is an asymmetry between the reality of the internal market and actually social rights, which are very heterogeneous.  Rather than hiding behind protectionist policies, and therefore taking unilateral decisions on social matters, I would suggest that the Member States should do more in cooperation, in strengthening controls to prevent the use of abusive practices, such as false work, which is seriously damaging to small and medium-sized enterprises in agriculture, in the agri-food sector and also in the construction sector.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, back in the 2000s, Central and Eastern European countries joined a European Union based on an open market economy with free competition, and on a single market with four freedoms, opening up their economies to fierce competition from companies that had far more capital and far more technological advantage than theirs. What we see today, however, are attempts by old Member States to introduce a pick-and-choose variety of competition and single market, depending on what suits perceived interests or populist political approaches better. This happens, be it through attempts to restrict the rules on the posting of workers or be it through the fabrication of an ill-defined notion with highly negative connotations, which is how, today, we are talking about social dumping, instead of enforcing existing single market regulation. In a fight that is about neutralising less-developed countries’ main competitive advantage – lower wages – the next logical step would be to set higher tariffs on goods imported from there. I do not think that is the direction in which the European Union should be heading.

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D).
text: –Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to congratulate my colleague Guillaume Balas on his report. I think we all agree that we need, at this point, better protection of employees, their rights and security in all Member States. Equally important, in my opinion, is the fact that this report should leave no question mark about its objectives. I believe that the benefits of the European Single Market and freedom of movement in Europe are obvious and have been felt in the east and, at least to the same extent, in the west of the European Union. It's a reality I ask you never to forget!  That is why I would like to encourage and support, and on this occasion, all constructive steps in good faith, which contribute to strengthening this founding principle of our Union and which, at the same time, take into account the rights and protection of European employees, irrespective of the Member State in which they operate.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the undeclared work and social dumping that are increasingly occurring in the Member States of the Union are not only leading to distortion of competition and the dismantling of social security systems, but also undermine labour rights. At the moment, in many Member States of the Union there is an increased number of precarious jobs and reduced levels of worker protection, which are really breaking up labour relations at the moment. In addition, since 15 July 2014, Mr Juncker has allegedly committed himself to taking action to combat the risks of social dumping. However, the course of industrial relations in European countries shows that no effective action has been taken while social dumping continues to exist by reinforcing discrimination and unequal treatment among workers. Therefore, in order for competition to work properly, but of course mainly for reasons of social justice, social dumping reinforced by austerity policies must be eliminated.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – Thank you, Madam President. Dear Commissioner, colleagues. I agree with many of the provisions contained in this report. However, I note that we must not overdo it, especially with regard to transport companies. Cases of exploitation of workers are repeated on a regular basis. It is clear that it is very difficult to prevent these violations, all the more so because workers who are subject to crises, deprivation or other reasons often agree with all the conditions of the employer. These people rarely report irregularities to the responsible authorities because they would lose their jobs. What is further complicated by the fact that some companies are registered in one country and actually operate in another country. We need to protect workers, but on the other hand we cannot create a procedure that prevents business competition. For example, we cannot force a Lithuanian transport company to pay the driver of a vehicle a huge German salary just because he loads and unloads goods in this country, even though that driver already receives a higher than average Lithuanian salary. Thanks!

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Balas, and all the shadow rapporteurs and other Members of Parliament who cooperated in preparing this report. With our social acquis, we have rules in place to prevent social dumping but we need to make sure that our rules are correctly applied. Member States are responsible for enforcing labour law, rules for the posting of workers, rules on free movement and on health and safety at work, and – yes, Mr Balas – national labour inspectorates need sufficient resources to do that. We have already put in place several instruments that offer national authorities more and better tools to make sure that free movement is fair and well managed and that abuse is prevented. We have the Platform against undeclared work, we have the Enforcement Directive on free movement of workers that makes mobile workers more aware of their rights and establishes national bodies to enforce those rights. We have the Enforcement Directive on posting of workers that introduces measures to prevent and penalise any abuses or circumventions of European rules on posting. With the upcoming social pillar – and this is important because, indeed, social dumping is not only about mobile work – and with the targeted revision of the Posting of Workers Directive, with the amendments of the social security coordination regulation that are under preparation, with the roads initiatives, we want to make our acquis stronger and adapt it to the new challenges on the labour market. In conclusion, I am convinced that, by pooling all our efforts, we can ensure a fair labour market where there is no place for social dumping. So let us continue to work together. Thank you very much for this debate.

name: Guillaume Balas
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, you heard from Mr Briois earlier from the National Front. He set out the real alternative if we do nothing, that is, it is simple, the end of the European Union, the end of the internal market, the end of directives, the re-establishment of national borders, the end of free movement. He's clear and he's counting on us to fail. He thinks we will fail, because he thinks we are too divided today to answer him. I believe that the work that has been done and which has resulted in the majority of groups in the Committee on Social Affairs and Employment voting on this compromise is the best answer we can give to it, but especially to the European citizens who will thus see that Europe does not remain fossilised, but moves to defend them, that Europe is not a problem , but at last it becomes the solution. For that reason, I would like to say, Mr Lenaers, that no, this report is not there to fulfil the dreams of the Socialists. You know, I'm a socialist and not a slacker, but Mrs Jaz-owiecka is not a socialist and she is not soft either. I can assure you that we Socialists, we the left, have to accept a lot of compromises that we did not want at the beginning and that the EPP has had many victories in this report, which it has not been easy to get accepted on the left. So this is not a socialist report, far from it. Moreover, I would like to point out that the only elements relating to Directive 96, the source directive, merely recall Commissioner Thyssen's proposals, without even judging them. There is therefore no opinion on the issue of Directive 96, since we know that this is a debate that will come later. When we talk about the secondment of workers, it is the application of existing legislation and, in particular, the question of controls. I conclude by saying that I agree with Mr. Casa. There has been a long, difficult and exciting work, where I have met with fascinating shadow rapporteurs. You have to respect the balance that has been found, but all the balance that has been found. In this way, we will be able to respond to our fellow citizens in a useful way.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 14 September 2016. Written declarations (Article 162 CRP)

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: Written. – Social dumping not only erodes the social achievements of our workers, but also leads to exploitation of the workers involved and makes it more difficult for honest companies to compete. It is high time for a vigorous action and a guarantee of equal pay for equal work in the same place for all workers. Crucially, there are stricter European rules, better transposition of the rules and more control by the inspection services. Parliament significantly expanded its control capabilities in 2014. The new proposal by Commissioner Marianne Thyssen must now tighten the rules itself and ensure that all Belgian wage and working conditions apply in full to foreign workers temporarily employed in Belgium. This proposal is at the top of our agenda.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Finally, we have a text that clearly defines what social dumping is. We have been waiting for this definition for years. Even if social policies are the competences of the Member States, it is essential that there be European cooperation in this area. I have been advocating for many years for social convergence so that we can fight together against unfair social competition. This convergence must, of course, be upwards. It is inconceivable that the most successful social systems would be undermined in this process.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The internal market is undoubtedly a great opportunity, but the lack of uniformity of workers' rights in the EU and controls to prevent unfair competition result in the occurrence of dangerous phenomena of social dumping. Competition is in fact set up through a race to the bottom in the cost of the worker and is therefore lacking for the same protections that should constitute inalienable rights. The report adopted by the European Parliament seeks to put a stop to this situation by, for example, calling for improved controls and inspections resulting from the application of legislation to combat unfair competition. Another interesting proposal is to draw up a kind of European black-list of companies guilty of serious infringements, such as the use of undeclared work. Furthermore, there is talk of the development of a single digital document on the transfer of social rights for each European worker. It is right to try to correct the distortions of the single market, and we will continue to work towards that.

name: Christine Revault D’Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. Today I voted in favour of the report by my colleague, Guillaume BALAS, on the fight against social dumping in the European Union. This report sends a clear message to the Commission and calls for concrete measures to combat social dumping. The development of a blacklist of companies that do not comply with social legislation, the registration of declarations of secondment in a European register, the strengthening of controls or the limitation of detachments over time, are all proposals that would strengthen the social dimension of the internal market. The Commission must now act, this vote shows that there is a parliamentary majority to move forward on these necessary measures. I also welcome the fact that the report calls for the introduction of a 60% threshold for the national average wage as a benchmark for setting the minimum wage within Member States. Finally, on road transport, which crystallizes the issues of social dumping, this report also goes in the right direction by asking the Commission to create a European Road Transport Agency to monitor compliance.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – The report on social dumping highlights that Europe faces significant differences in the application of employee rights. From the transport sector's perspective, these differences lead to distortion of the internal market and endangerpassenger safety. The solution to achieving common rules, but also to ensuring their implementation, lies in having a body with clear powers and the legitimacy to coordinate actions at European level. That is why the European Union needs a European Road Transport Agency. This would ensure that Member States do not impose restrictive unilateral measures that punish firms in countries with low GDP. At the same time, better coordination will help us combat legislative gaps and stop some firms from abusing the freedoms of the European Single Market. There are, however, a few things to be clarified. Firstly, we must beware of labelling and create a level playing field for all participants in the European market. A constructive attitude will require all stakeholders to mobilise to create a unified legislative framework that leaves no room for a race to diminish social rights from which to lose the most vulnerable or consumers.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European Parliament's motion for a resolution on social dumping is welcome, given that inequalities in Europe are increasing, thereby undermining the achievement of the Europe 2020 targets on poverty and employment. This implies taking a strong EU position towards what we call 'social dumping', which gives it an exemplary role on the world stage, imposing an obligation on third countries to respect fundamental human rights, international standards in labour law and social, limiting the effects of social dumping worldwide. We agree that there is no widely accepted definition of the concept, but social dumping generates, through its forms, effects not only economic, social, financial and budgetary, but also environmental effects, of which nothing is specified in this proposal. The free movement of persons is indispensable to achieving the objectives of economic, social and territorial cohesion, but it would be desirable for the situation of workers in developing Member States, accused of social dumping in the developed EU Member States, to be clearly regulated, not just to take note of the Commission's proposal to revise Directive 96/71/EC.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council statement on the Council's position on the draft general budget for the financial year 2017 (2016/2768(RSP)). I would point out to Members that there is no catch-the-eye procedure in this debate and that no blue cards are adopted. Now I say goodbye to Commissioner Thyssen, and Commissioner Georgieva is not here yet. But the first on the list of speakers is, on behalf of the Council, Minister Vazil Hudik. In other words, I will give you the floor first.

name: Vazil Hudák
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to wish everybody good evening. It has been a long day for all of us but I believe that those who have actually stayed here – and I see Madam Commissioner joining us – and had the courage and stamina to stay here into the late evening are the true friends of the budget. I have the honour of presenting to you the Council’s position on the draft budget of the European Union for the year 2017, which was adopted yesterday by the Council.  I would like to begin by stating clearly that the main thrust of the Council’s position is the prioritisation of expenditure. This means that we wish to finance adequately investments to spur growth and jobs, for example through the European Fund for Strategic Investments, and to provide sufficient funding to tackle the still ongoing migration crisis and the related external policies. At the same time, it is the Council’s express wish to create sufficient margins to enable us to cope with unforeseen situations that we will surely have to face into 2017. In our view, the annual budget is an expression of our solidarity, the solidarity which goes internally amongst the Member States, and the citizens as well as externally towards third countries, which is a common goal that we all share. Therefore, the EU budget should concentrate on the main objectives of the EU and on benefiting our citizens.  Let me now explain to you how the Council looked at priorities and the guiding principles. These priorities, which were reflected in the thinking by the Member States and the Council, translate into concrete guiding principles that were applied when adopting the Council’s position on the draft budget for 2017. First, tackling the refugee crisis is a key priority, and hence so is the financing for migration and related external policies. Therefore, heading 3 – Security and citizenship, which funds policies on tackling the migration and refugee crisis, benefits from a significant increase of 4.9% in commitments and 24.4% in payment appropriations compared to 2016. The Council has accepted in full all appropriations destined for the programmes and agencies dealing with the crisis, including the use of the flexibility instrument for an amount of EUR 530 million and the contingency margin for an amount of EUR 1.14 billion. In total, the Council has agreed an amount of EUR 3 billion, which goes mainly to the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund, to the Internal Security Fund, to emergency assistance and to the related agencies such as Frontex, EASO and Europol.  In heading 4 – Global Europe, the Council undertook a thorough analysis in order to identify space for creating the necessary margin since the Commission’s proposal for 2017 has completely exhausted the margin for commitments. The overall increase in commitments remains at 1.74%, compared to 2016. Programmes and instruments related to the migration crisis and the facility for refugees in Turkey were not affected by reductions. So you can see that the Council stands fully behind the European Agenda on Migration, as was agreed between us in 2015.  Second, a priority and concern for all of us is the creation of jobs and growth. Subheading 1A – Competitiveness for growth and jobs, therefore increases overall by almost 9% in both commitments and payment appropriations compared to 2016. The Council protects and supports the budget for instruments that spur growth and thereby create jobs, namely such instruments as EFSI, COSME, Erasmus+ and others. Subheading 1A, however, has also contributed to the general savings effort concerning some budget lines where the Council considers, following a detailed technical analysis, that the Commission has overestimated the real needs. Concerning Subheading 1B – Economic, social and territorial cohesion, which is another core policy of the European Union for the creation of growth and jobs, the Council proposes limited reductions of payment appropriations on new programmes of EUR 199 million. However, the Council has not reduced appropriations dedicated to the previous programming period, 2007—2013, and to the treatment of the backlog of unpaid bills. That deadlock should be fully resolved by the end of this year in accordance with the payment plan.  Before concluding, let me briefly address the issue of Heading 5 –Administration. As you all know – and I think Parliament has been part of this deal – 2017 is the last year for institutions to achieve the goal of reducing their statutory staff by 5%. Frankly, the Council and the Member States are very concerned to note that not all institutions will achieve that goal. Therefore the Council has made it very clear in a statement that it expects that all efforts will be deployed to avoid any additional delays in implementing this jointly-agreed reduction target.  In conclusion, as you can see, in an effort to find the right balance between, on the one hand, a sustainable budget in times of budgetary constraints throughout Europe and, on the other hand, financing essential political priorities, the Council has identified areas where savings are reasonable and necessary. In those areas that cannot be qualified as top political priorities in the current circumstances, reductions in the proposal of the Commission have been made in a careful fashion in order not to harm programmes that perform well and are coming up to speed. In doing so we have followed the Council’s budget guidelines for 2017.  Let me express my hope and confidence that we will find a common path to securing a reasonable and sustainable budget that will bring maximum benefits for all our fellow citizens. Above all, I hope that our debate on this important but technical matter will pave the way to a successful compromise based on mutual respect and understanding and shared goals and concerns.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, as Mr Hudák has just said, those who are most committed to the European budget are in this Chamber and I see Mr Arthuis among them. On the discussion of the Council reading on the Commission’s proposal, I want to start from where we are clearly in alignment. There is a commonality of purpose which is to make sure that our budget for 2017 is aligned with our two top priorities: investment in jobs and growth and dealing with migration, refugees and security. We are clearly more in alignment on one of these priorities – migration, refugees and security – on which the Commission proposal has been fully endorsed in the reading of Council. However, there are some discrepancies in views and I want to concentrate on the logic behind what the Commission has proposed and to defend our proposal. Regarding investment in jobs and growth, we have dedicated nearly half – 47.4% – of the budget to that, which includes an increase vis-à-vis 2016 of 7%. We have done that consciously, taking into account the status of our economies and we have looked very carefully into each and every budget line. For that reason, we were quite underwhelmed by the reading of the Council on Heading 1A, where, on competitiveness, jobs and growth, there are proposed cuts of EUR 400 million. This means 52% of the cuts that Council is proposing falling on an area that I do not think any one of us can disagree is important for Europe. I would point to some of these cuts, for example in research, at a time when we need to stimulate innovation and make sure that European researchers are coming close to the real economy. We were surprised to see that there are proposed cuts for some large—scale projects for which there is very high demand, like transport and energy, Galileo and Copernicus. Some of these cuts are just very bad use of the knife, in terms of the consequences of the costs we would then incur. If, in Galileo, you build the satellite but you do not shoot it up, you have to store it and pay for its storage. Similarly, I would express a bit of concern that there is some mechanical cutting when it comes to some of the Heading 3 small programmes like health, SMEs and dialogue with citizens, or cuts in global Europe – EUR 62 million in cuts – when we know that, if anything, we have to do more to address the root causes of poverty, and thus of wars, refugees and migration. I would say, from the bottom of my heart, that I have sympathy for the Council in terms of keeping us on the straight and narrow when it comes to administrative cost. We are very mindful that every day we have to look into what we spent on administration, with an eye to economising: and we do that. I can tell you that – line by line – we are cutting every budget line that is not driven upwards by natural forces. But to demand from us that we go beyond the 5% staff cut, by introducing an additional reduction, I do not find very wise because we are committed to the 5% cut: we are executing the 5% cut while undertaking more responsibilities, and we motivate our staff by telling them we are cutting as much as we have promised – no less, but also no more.
